But setlife took over for a couple days and Agatha’s text sat unanswered in her inbox.

One evening she’d stayed out with two of her fellow cast members and had too much to drink for someone who had to be awake at 5am and know her lines the next day.

And in that precious time between falling into bed and falling asleep, she decided to talk to Alice about it.

She’d been struggling through like a pathetic loser pining after someone unattainable. She now knew she needed the help of her friend.

And so, halfway through the day on set the next day, when she arrived at her trailer for an hour’s turnaround where she could take a quick nap or call her parents (which she was still yet to do), she was delighted to find Alice already there and waiting for her.

“This place is a mess, Rio.”

“Shut up,” Rio said with a grin as she tackled Alice in a hug so hard she knocked them both down onto the couch.

Alice’s cackle filled the trailer and Rio felt at home in there for the first time since she’d arrived.

Still, Alice was shoving her off so she rolled away with a grin.

“Miss me much?”

“Like you wouldn’t believe.”

Alice laughed and her smile faded to something softer as she pulled her legs up beneath her and turned properly to her friend.

“You look tired.”

“I’m exhausted.”

“Wouldn’t happen to be because you were out until the early hours last night, would it?”

“Who told you?”

“I have my spies.”

Rio rolled her eyes but had her suspicions that it was probably one of the younger actors who liked his gossip as much as he liked his coke.

“Fine. Maybe I was. I just needed to let off some steam.”

Alice nodded slowly and watched Rio for a second before asking, “Everything okay? Lily says everything’s great, your performance is outstanding and she’s really excited for the final cut.”

Rio nodded in acknowledgement, pleased her director wasn’t just blowing smoke up her ass every time she praised her performance on set. But she knew Alice was giving her an opening and so she took it.

“Actually, I want to run something by you. Something that… well something stupid. But I can’t shake. And I’m telling you as your friend, not as your client, okay? Be my friend with it.”

Alice raised her brows but shifted and placed a hand on Rio’s knee where it rested against the back of the couch, “You got it. What’s going on?”

“It’s so stupid,” Rio qualified, already finding it hard to voice the embarrassing thing that had such a hold on her for months now.

“That’s okay. I’ve seen and heard you do many stupid things. And you me.”

Rio scoffed and ran a hand through her hair. “I have a crush. A big, fat, inconvenient crush.”

“Rio, not on Lily. You can’t screw the director.”

“No,” Rio said with a small frown, “Agatha.”

Rio didn’t know how she’d expected Alice to react but laughter wasn’t it.

“Right, okay, and who doesn’t? Half the population is in love with her.”

“No, look… it’s hard to explain. I just…” Rio cleared her throat and pulled her knees to her chest, dislodging Alice’s hand. “I think about her a lot.”

“Okay,” Alice said slowly, looking at Rio closely and with a slight suspicion in her gaze, “You know she’s married, right? And like, has a son and everything? With a man?”

Rio huffed and rolled her eyes, “Yes, people keep telling me.”

Alice frowned and began chewing on her lip, “Okay… Jen mentioned something a while back about you being a big flirt when Agatha was around but… it’s just a crush, it’ll disappear.”

“That’s the thing, Alice. I don’t know. It’s been weeks since I’ve seen her and-…”

“Rio, is it just because you can’t have her?”

“What?”

“Look, you’re a hot movie star. You can usually get whoever you want. And I mean anyone but Agatha… well she doesn’t want you and maybe that’s just it. You want her because you can’t have her.”

Rio blinked and for a second felt mortified, horrified that her friend had psychoanalysed her so mercilessly.

Maybe that was it. Maybe she was forbidden fruit and so every interaction she’d had with her Rio was reading into it, bolstering the fantasy.

Agatha didn’t want her. Rio wanted her because she didn’t want her.

She’d been wrong to read into the touches and smiles, Agatha simply found her amusing, knew she was flirting, and was secure enough to flirt a little back.

But then the was the way she kept close, the way she’d wrapped herself so securely around Rio that last night.

Because maybe Agatha was happily married but Rio was convinced she had even a slight curiosity about Rio. She knew she found her charming. She knew she touched her far more than she’d seen her touch Alice or even Jen.

But she couldn’t bring herself to vocalise all of this.

For one she’d be accusing a married straight woman of flirting with her which went against her general moral code and for another, perhaps she was wrong and Alice was right.

“Holy shit. That can’t be it, Alice. I’m… fuck, am I an asshole?”

Alice laughed, cracking the tension in the air immediately with the noise. “I mean… you’re not not an asshole.”

“God,” Rio put her head between her knees and groaned loudly, “all this time I thought I was going insane with it.”

Alice shuffled closer until her knees were just before Rio’s feet and she pushed at the top of her head to get her to look at her: “You need to get laid. When was the last time-… Oh. Is this why you went rogue and fucked some poor girl on the beach?”

Rio narrowed her eyes a little but didn’t have the strength to keep it up so flopped her head back down, “I was trying to get it out of my system.”

“Oh babe,” Alice laughed again, “Get over yourself. She doesn’t want you. I know it may be a shock to the system but just deal with it. Like the rest of us have to. Do you know how many times I’ve been left wanting?”

“Shut up, you do just fine. Besides, you have a hot girlfriend.”

“One I hardly ever see.”

“You’ve just flown back to LA for a week to be with her.”

“A week is barely any time at all. We were both still working.”

Rio just huffed a heavy breath and lifted her head slowly, reluctantly meeting Alice’s amused gaze, “You think that’s really it? I’m a dick?”

“Yes, I’m afraid so.”

“Did Jen really call out my flirting?”

“Yes. She said you may as well have crawled on top of her and stuck your tongue down her throat.”

Rio grimaced a little and had to fight the images that conjured in her mind.

“I wasn’t that bad.”

“I think she was just pissed that Agatha gave you that photo.”

Sighing softly, Rio fished her phone from her back pocket and clicked about until she turned it around to show Alice the texts from Agatha.

Alice read through them and raised her brows, “Please don’t tell me you’ve left Agatha Harkness on read for three days.”

“Maybe.”

“Rio. Get a grip. Text her back. Say you’re sorry you’ve been busy but would love to teach her son basketball or whatever.”

Rio rolled her eyes but stole her phone back and put it to the side, “I was overthinking it.”

“Clearly. Look, you’re both at the top of your game, you’re both used to getting what you want, you’re both hot. But think about it this way, if she were into you, it would never work out anyway. You’d have one hot night together and then it would be hell every time you saw her. At least this way you get to enjoy her pretty smiles and not worry about her icing you out of the industry.”

Rio hated to admit when Alice was right, but she was. At least about this part. And so Rio nodded and picked her phone back up to send the response that was three days overdue.

1:09pm
Rio Vidal: Sorry, work has been manic. I’d love to. After Venice I have a week or so early September back in LA. Let me know time and date and I’ll be there.

She turned her phone back around to show Alice and her friend beamed at her before snatching her phone away to check her call log.

“You ass. Call your mother.”

Rio laughed and snatched her phone back, “Dick.”

Alice, despite her teasing of Rio the rest of the day about her disastrous crush - whenever she got a chance between filming - insisted Rio have an early night so she could rest up for the following day of no filming but press instead.

The production company had worked around Rio’s schedule so that she could do press for All The Wrong Gods as the awards machine continued to pick up momentum.

What that meant, though, was that a usual press day of anywhere between 6-8 hours was now a full 12.

Rio was back to back with journalists from practically the moment she woke up, doing call-ins to radio shows, sitting in hair and makeup whilst she spoke to journalists in the room with her, heading for lunch for publications doing longreads, and sitting in a small stuffy room answering the same questions again and again about a movie she’d made over a year ago.

Her only respite during this time was Alice who kept her morale up by feeding her snacks, making sure she had plenty of coffee, and plenty of moments to complain when out of earshot of everyone else.

It was just after lunch with a journalist from The Times when the response to her message to Agatha came through.

Her phone had vibrated in her pocket as she hugged the journalist goodbye and Rio had checked it as she waited for her driver for the day to pick her up and take her back to the hotel where she was to do more interviews.

2:17pm
Agatha Harkness: 4pm, after Nicky finishes school, 2nd, 2270 La Granada Dr.

This time, Rio didn’t make her wait.

2:22pm
Rio Vidal: Looking forward to it. :)

She regretted the smiley face.

She didn’t receive a text back.

But that was fine. She’d sucked up her pride and decided that she would have to get over herself in order to get over Agatha. And she had over a month to do just that.

But a month goes by surprisingly quickly when all you do is work and sleep.

Alice was Rio’s lifeline, as usual, during this time.

She made sure Rio kept cheery during her ‘off’ days when she had to squeeze in more interviews that she’d ever done in her life. She made sure Rio had the right amount of sleep and the right amount of alcohol in her system at least once every two weeks to blow off steam but not ruin the next day.

She even convinced Rio that sleeping with the DP was not a good idea, which turned out to be great advice because the DP in question had a boyfriend and the boyfriend just so happened to be the Assistant Editor.

And Rio coached Alice through her pining for Jen. She helped her analyse everything phone conversation they’d had, every text that looked apathetic or every selfie where there appeared to be a pretty woman in the background.

It felt a lot like college all over again, where they were each other’s bastions of strength and support.

But perhaps the best thing Alice managed to do for Rio was to remind her weekly to call her mom.

And once this pattern was established, a grateful Anna Vidal sent a care package to Alice’s hotel room full of Puerto Rican snacks and a postcard from Delaware thanking her for managing Rio so well.

Rio was not happy about this and as punishment stole as much of the package for herself as she could.

But after filming wrapped and both her and Alice got so drunk at the wrap party neither was sure how they ended up in Rio’s bed the next morning in one piece, they still had another film festival to go.

Venice was a means to an end. A chance to campaign a little more in the European market but mostly to get Rio on the best dressed lists and get her face out there as much as possible.

Schmoozing. Rio could do it better than anyone.

And the best thing about Venice was that Wanda would be there, which meant Rio would have an ally other than Alice and someone else to complain to when it all got too much.

Alice had done Rio a solid and arranged for her and Wanda to arrive on the boat together, which meant that Rio could spend at least the first day of the festival with someone she liked and was technically working so Alice couldn’t tell her not to just stand gossiping with Wanda.

Turned out that this paid dividends for both Rio and Alice because whilst the press went insane over capturing the two of them together, Wanda had just finished filming on a set with a tyrannical director with a penchant for furious rages.

Which meant that Alice got what she wanted and so did Rio.

The gossip was so juicy that it continued into the late night as the three of them had dinner together in a small restaurant in the heart of the city.

“I’m telling you, I don’t understand how he’s still working.”

“He’s a man,” Rio said dismissively, swirling her Chianti, “and he’s considered a genius which is practically a pass for any kind of bad behaviour.”

“Rio, you don’t understand he was savage. At one point I thought he was going to go for the production assistant.”

Rio grimaced and Alice frowned at Wanda, “Did you have anyone come in to intervene?”

“No, a few of us-…” she stopped abruptly then because the waiter had come over to fill their wine glasses. When he was gone she cleared her throat and continued, “so, yeah, we rallied round, made sure everyone felt protected as best we could and… that was it.”

Rio reached for Wanda’s hand and squeezed it gently, “You could have called. I was just in London, I could have easily hopped a flight-…”

“Sweetheart, you never answer your phone. Plus if your schedule is anything like mine you wouldn’t have had any time to swoop in and do what, exactly?”

Rio shrugged but smiled a little, “I don’t know? Be a drinking buddy?”

“That’d help. Dealing with a maniac on a hangover.”

Rio laughed and pulled her hand away, “Whatever gets you through.”

Wanda smirked and took a sip of her drink before she turned to Alice with a sudden change of topic.

“So, Alice, you are in a lot of trouble with a lot of different people, I hope you know.”

This was news to Rio and apparently news to Alice who looked more than a little shocked as she placed her wine down. “Why?”

“Oh,” Wanda grinned and Rio relaxed instantly, knowing it couldn’t be bad if Wanda were getting enjoyment out of it, “getting your client to be announced as the best actress alive right now’s favourite actress.”

Rio scoffed and ran a hand through her hair, “It’s so offensive that you don’t think I’m just that good.”

Wanda laughed and Alice smirked as she leant back in her chair, “Unfortunately I’m not powerful enough to make Agatha Harkness say anything she doesn’t want to so that was all Rio.”

“That good,” Rio repeated, shrugging with a grin and making Wanda roll her eyes at her.

“Unbelievable.”

“Thank you.”

“Don’t think you’re winning though. It’s hers to take.”

“Oh, I know. And now Sylvia’s gone and said something racist it would be a miracle if she were even nominated.”

“I heard.”

Alice hummed quietly and glanced around them, cautious of any eavesdroppers, “It’s an industry town right now. Keep your voices down.”

Rio raised a brow and looked around briefly too, “I’m pretty sure everyone here is Italian and no one much cares what we’re saying.”

“Haven’t we had one too many lucky escapes with the press lately?”

Rio shifted in her seat, her eyes darting briefly to Wanda and hoping she wouldn’t pick up on Alice’s insinuation. But she did.

“What did they not get you on?”

“Alice, don’t.”

“What? You did it, the least you could do is own up to it.”

Rio sighed heavily and leant forwards towards Wanda, “I had a… moment with Agatha’s husband and then a… moment with a girl on a beach.”

“A moment? Is that what they’re calling it these days?”

Rio laughed and leant back again, “anyway, nothing happened so it’s nothing to worry about.”

“I don’t know, babe. It’s a little perverted if you ask me: sex on a beach and sex with another woman’s husband. Maybe speak to your therapist about it.”

Alice grinned at Wanda, enjoying having an ally in Rio-ribbing and Rio just smirked as she sipped her wine. “In case you hadn’t noticed I don’t swing that way and Ralph is… well I wouldn’t even if I did. Both very cruel friends.”

“You love us.”

“Unfortunately for me.”

So Venice went by easily, and Rio barely thought about her inconvenient crush at all.

She spent almost every second with Alice and now Wanda in tow, and focused her efforts on being as effortlessly charming for the interviewers and cameras as possible.

Every morning, Alice woke her with news of the previous night’s press.

“Everyone’s insane for the photos and you and Wanda on the boat. X is blowing up with people wanting you-…”

“Call it ‘Twitter’, please. We don’t like that man.”

“Yeah, yeah. Anyway, best dressed, best dressed, best dressed. You’ve practically won the festival.”

It helped a lot in moments like these, when Rio was exhausted in her bed and Alice was shoving her phone in her face, that Rio loved her best friend so much. She couldn’t imagine a world where Alice were just someone she paid and not someone she could happily see every moment of the day and not get sick of.

But by the time she was back home in her little house in the Hollywood Hills, Rio was determined to speak to no one and be comatose for two days.

The exception to this rule was of course Alice, though she was mostly busy fielding journalist requests and making up for lost time with Jen, and her mother, whom she called to tell all about the festival and to let her know she was home safe.

But two days of being horizontal soon disappeared and Rio, on the third day she was back from home, found that suddenly she felt rested and relaxed enough to actually be looking forward to seeing Agatha without the usual fear that she’d say or do something stupid or embarrassing - though there was always still that risk.

She hopped in the car with her hopes high that today would be a good day and called Alice on her way over, following Google Maps as she went.

“Hey.”

“Nervous?”

“No, I think… I think you cured me.”

Liar.

“Good. So all you need to do is not injure the kid and not try to kiss her or anything, okay?”

“Asshole. How’s Jen? You didn’t tell her about…?”

“Of course not. She’s fine. She’s away on a call with a studio. I told her I loved her last night.”

“You did? And?!”

“Well, she said it back.”

Rio laughed and grinned as she took the next turning, “Alice, I’m so pleased for you.”

“Not mad still we won’t both die alone together?”

“Nah, there’s room for Jen in our little beachfront retirement home.”

“I’ll be sure to let her know.”

“I’ll call you later, okay? When I’m heading back.”

“Sure. I need to talk to you about Late Night anyway.”

“Fine. Speak later.”

“Bye, Rio. Behave.”

Rio smiled to herself as she watched the little phone modal disappear on her car display.

Alice was happy, maybe soon to be settled. Miracles did happen. It was enough to relax her further as she drove the rest of the way to Agatha’s home deep in the Hills.

The street was quiet, with large houses spread along it, all white buildings with terracotta roofs. It looked not unlike where Rio stayed though the houses along here were, admittedly, much larger than hers.

Rio pulled up slowly in front of Agatha’s home and as she turned the key in the ignition to shut off the engine she felt for the first time in weeks a sudden nervousness.

It crept over her body slowly, so that stepping out of the car felt like a momentous task. But it was 4:01pm so she had to make herself move for fear Agatha would consider her late.

She stepped out into the afternoon heat and reached in the back of her little hybrid to take the gifts she’d brought for Agatha and Nicky, wondering suddenly if she should have brought something more, something grander.

But it was too late.

She shouldered her bag of gifts and tucked the basketball she’d bought with her under her arm, took one last deep breath, and made for the gate. She pressed the buzzer and chewed the inside of her lip as she waited for it to grant her entry, wondering if Agatha had any staff who would greet her before she had to come face to face with her herself.

But she didn’t have to wait long.

Ten seconds later the sound of the gate unlocking let Rio know she could push it open and she entered into a small court yard before a stately 1930’s villa home.

The lawn either side of the little walkway was perfectly manicured with palms and bird of paradise plants along the edges. And above the entranceway, creating a grand porch, were two stone pillars, framing the arched front door that stood open with Agatha Harkness in the middle of it.

Rio’s heart skipped a beat at the sight of her but she forced herself to remain calm, repeating Alice’s words in her own mind: “Get over yourself.”

“I wasn’t sure you’d show.”

“Are you kidding? Basketball and an excuse to hang with my biggest fan? What would keep me away?”

Agatha rolled her eyes but smiled warmly as Rio got closer and she stepped aside to let her in.

The impact of stepping into Agatha’s home was immediate. Even in the foyer it felt warm, comfortable, and it had Agatha’s signature charm all over it.

“He’s just out back,” Agatha said, answering a question Rio hadn’t even asked or considered as she turned to look at Agatha with an incredulous grin.

“You gotta give a girl a second to take this in. Your house is huge.”

Agatha laughed and hesitated for only a second before she placed a quick kiss to Rio’s cheek and then motioned for Rio to follow her.

Rio chewed on her lip as she followed her through to the kitchen, taking her around the large round table in the middle of the square entranceway with a fresh floral arrangement in the middle of it, trying not to focus on the faint blush she knew to be across her cheeks now.

Rio turned this way and that, spotting an inviting looking living area to the side with a mosaic fireplace and a door off of that, noticing the mirrors and art on the walls and the soft furnishings that gave the white house colour and comfort.

“Seriously. My place is tiny compared to this.”

“If you don’t stop talking about how big my house is, I’ll ask you to leave.”

They’d arrived in the kitchen now and Rio had a sinking feeling that her gifts would leave quite a lot to be desired at the sight of it.

“Holy shit,” she mumbled quietly, but Agatha had caught it and raised a brow at her.

“What? You’ve been to industry parties before. You must have seen some of the mansions in the Hills.”

“Yeah, but they’re all glass and metal this is… Agatha, this is gorgeous.”

Agatha seemed to soften then and she leant back against the countertop, watching Rio as she did a once over of the open plan kitchen, her eyes lingering on the breakfast nook just off of it and her breath taken away by the way Agatha had managed to make the space seem cosy, despite being in one of the largest houses on the street, in one of the most expensive neighbourhoods in Los Angeles.

“Thank you,” Agatha said with a smile that Rio returned when she looked back to her.

In her admiration of the house, she’d missed taking in Agatha’s appearance, which meant she’d almost forgotten her nerves.

Agatha now looked at her in a soft grey sweater, wearing light jeans and bare feet, fresh faced with little makeup and her hair up in an effortlessly messy bun, she looked exactly as Rio remembered: beautiful and intoxicating.

“I,” she started before she could be accused of staring, “I bought some… umm, well,” she shuffled and placed the clean basketball on the marble island beside her, and then fished in her bag.

“You didn’t need to bring anything,” Agatha clarified, folding her arms loosely across her chest as Rio pulled out her gift.

“My mom made these last time she was here. Actually, it was whilst we were in Italy. She comes and goes when I’m away just to get away, y’know? Anyway, she makes the best empanadas in the world so…”

She held up the large tupperware box and for a second felt like the biggest loser on the planet, offering the biggest movie star on the planet a box of her mother’s defrosted empanadas as a gift.

But Agatha looked touched and stepped forwards to take the box with a gentle smile, “You didn’t need to bring these.”

“You’re hosting. It’s polite.”

“It’s too much. I hope you kept some for yourself?”

“I’ve had a million.”

Agatha hummed and reached to touch Rio’s arm which sent a jolt of imagined electricity through her body that she wasn’t expecting and Rio flinched a little, playing it off by moving her arm quickly to run through her hair.

If Agatha noticed, she pretended not to, and went to put the box of empanadas in the large fridge opposite Rio, speaking as she did: “Nicky’s been excited about this since I told him you were coming.”

“Really?”

“Mm. Apparently I’m not very good and his father…” she trailed off as she closed the door and turned back around, “Well. He’s excited.”

Rio bit down on her lip and picked her basketball back up again, spinning it in the air before catching it once more. “I can teach you a few things if you like? So you don’t embarrass yourself in front of a seven year old?”

“Watch it,” Agatha warned with a smile as she made to swipe the ball from Rio’s hands as she threw it up to spin again but Rio was too quick and laughed as Agatha stumbled closer.

For a second it felt like nothing at all, the two of them, in Agatha’s kitchen, now less than a foot apart. And Rio forgot that she had a crush. She forgot that she couldn’t have Agatha. She forgot everything because she was close once more and looking at her in a way that Rio found she’d missed in their two months apart.

“Precocious,” Agatha accused with a glint in her eye and Rio hummed, narrowing her gaze a little.

“Not sure you can be precocious past the age of twelve?”

But Agatha only laughed a little and instead of trying for the ball again she stepped closer and placed her hands on Rio’s where they held the ball between them.

Rio sucked in a short sharp breath and Agatha’s brow furrowed just slightly as she watched her, “Come meet Nicky? I promise he’ll be worthy of you.”

Rio fought the grin for only a moment and then nodded, her fingers twitched beneath Agatha’s and her pinky moving to cross over Agatha’s on her right hand.

“I’m sure he will be.”

Blue eyes dropped briefly to where Rio held her little finger and Agatha seemed to hesitate before she pulled away, leading the way out to the backyard with a wave of her hand.

Rio picked up her tote bag again and followed her out, internally groaning at the hold this woman had on her.

It was insane to think that she was married to a man. A waste, she thought, as she stepped into the yard with her, and her eyes widened at the sight of it.

There was a wooden veranda directly off the kitchen with a little seating area with two cushioned chairs and a two-seater armchair. On the little table in the middle of them was a tray with five glasses and what looked like fresh lemonade in a jug and then a bottle of white wine chilling in an ice bucket.

But the view beyond this was what took Rio’s breath away. The yard was surrounded by tall palms and potted plants that dotted about the space, adding green to the area that housed a large rectangular pool with a smaller hot tub in the middle of it, raised up to create a water fall dropping into the crystal clear water.

Rio could see hanging lanterns in the trees and saw across the water another seating area with more comfortable chairs and sofas and an awning that gave it privacy and the cosiness she’d felt inside.

She glanced to the right and saw a built in bar and barbecue area and had to work hard not to let her jaw drop at the sheer opulence of it all.

“Stop staring,” Agatha said smoothly, turning to Rio with an amused smile, “Really. You’re being very uncool, Rio Vidal.”

“Agatha, this-…”

But she was cut off suddenly by the noise of heavy footsteps coming towards them and the sight of an out of breath little boy shocked Rio back down to reality.

Nicky.

He ran beaming towards them and threw himself to his mother’s side, but grinned at Rio as he pressed into Agatha and hid half against her.

“Honey,” Agatha said softly, placing a hand on Nicky’s back and gently coaxing him from his hiding place to stand in front of her where she could place her hands on his shoulders and introduce him properly to their guest.

“Nicky, this is Rio. Rio,” she looked up at Rio with a proud smile, “the best basketball player in all of California, Nicholas Harkness.”

Rio’s eyes moved from Nicky to Agatha and back again but before she could say anything Nicky had held out his hand to Rio, not saying anything but looking at her expectantly.

Rio laughed a little at the formality of it but stepped closer and shook his hand, grinning at the heavy up and down motion he provided.

He had long brown hair, tucked behind his ears and in a loose ponytail, dark hazel eyes and a slightly off-kilter shy smile.

Agatha had made a cute kid.

“A pleasure to meet you, Nicky. I hear you’re going to embarrass me quite a bit on the court.”

“Mama says you’re really good.”

“Oh?” Rio asked with an even wider grin, shooting an amused glance at Agatha before focusing back in on Nicky, “She’s exaggerating. But I have heard that she’s terrible so maybe I’m just better than her?”

“Watch it,” Agatha said again with a smile at Rio before she bent down to kiss a giggling Nicky on the cheek and murmured, “go pour us all some lemonade and you can play soon, okay?”

Nicky ran off dutifully and poured the drinks as Rio watched Agatha watch her son.

“Adorable,” Rio whispered so only Agatha would hear and she turned to her with a gentle smile, tilting her head just a little in acknowledgement before she touched Rio’s arm and stepped over to take a seat on the little couch.

Nicky settled on one of the chairs and Rio took a seat beside Agatha, placing the ball gently down so it wouldn’t roll away by the table.

“So,” Rio said officially, keeping her tote bag in her lap and turning her attention to Nicky as he drank from his glass of lemonade.

“Your mom didn’t tell me which team you supported. Which made bringing you a jersey very difficult.”

“A jersey?” Nicky asked in surprise, wiping his mouth quickly.

“Well, a true basketball player has to have a jersey when he plays.”

“Right,” Nicky said, suddenly serious and watching Rio like she were the Queen of the Basketballers.

Agatha, on the other end of the couch leant back against the arm, her eyes darting between Nicky’s serious face and Rio’s smiling profile.

“Now I only bought these just in case because I assume you have one already?”

“I have a couple.”

“Good! So what’s your team?”

Nicky looked concerned for a second, looking to Agatha for help and Agatha leant forward, her hand landing on the couch just beside Rio’s knee.

“Well, he’s between teams at the moment. I like the Lakers’ purple, his dad likes the Bulls.”

Rio grimaced and glanced around at Agatha who raised her brows at her, “Something wrong with either of those?”

But Rio had turned back quickly to Nicky and hummed pensively, pursing her lips. “Which do you like?”

“I… I don’t know. Both.”

“Okay,” Rio said slowly, “both is fine.”

She was about to follow up when Nicky quickly asked: “Which do you like?”

“Well,” Rio started with an amused grin, “my team has been the same team since I was about your age.”

“What is it?”

“Celtics,” Rio said as she reached into her tote to pull from it a green jersey. “I liked the green and my dad used to take me to games when he had the time.”

Nicky nodded seriously and Rio felt the brush of Agatha’s fingers just graze the side of her thigh.

“I like green too.”

“You do? Well, I have one other jersey I brought with me. And it’s a special one too because this is my best friend’s team.”

Rio pulled out the second jersey, holding it up properly for Nicky to take in. “Warriors. She grew up in San Francisco so this is her team.”

Rio looked down at the navy blue jersey hanging in front of her and then raised her gaze once more to Nicky who seemed to be taking this discussion incredibly seriously and she felt a wave of affection for the little boy.

“Okay,” he said slowly, glancing across at his mother.

Rio raised her brows and glanced back at Agatha before focusing back in to Nicky and asking: “Okay? Do you want to wear this one?”

“No, I…” Nicky hesitated and his eyes went wide for a second as Rio gently dropped the navy blue jersey back into her lap, feeling the silky fabric fall over where Agatha’s hand was, her fingers only just making contact with the skin near the bend of her left knee.

“Can I wear yours?”

“Nicky,” Agatha gasped dramatically, removing her hand from the couch to place across her heart in a theatrical display, “And not your mother’s favourite team? That purple is lovely.”

Nicky grinned suddenly and Rio snorted as she leant back to look at Agatha, “Name one player on the Lakers.”

She heard Nicky laugh and from the corner of her eye saw him bounce a little in his seat but kept her gaze on Agatha who pretended to think for a second before she pronounced: “John Smith.”

Rio rolled her eyes but grinned at Agatha, batting lightly at her arm before she turned to Nicky and picked her green Celtics jersey back up, holding it out to him, “Fine, you can wear this. But just this once, okay? And then when you pick a team I’ll bring you the right colours, alright?”

“This is my team,” Nicky announced without a second’s hesitation, taking the jersey with a smile.

Rio opened her mouth to respond but didn’t know what to say and simply watched as Nicky slipped the too-large jersey over his t-shirt and grinned down at it.

A movement on the couch told her that Agatha had moved closer and so she wasn’t surprised when she heard her voice close to her ear, “You’re already more popular than me.”

Rio fought her laugh just as much has she fought a shiver and turned a little to raise her brows at Agatha, “Seems I’m everyone’s favourite in this household.”

Agatha narrowed her eyes at her and Rio felt a familiar brush near her side but she anticipated it before Agatha could jab her and she moved quickly, standing from her seat to shrug off her light blue shirt so she was just in her white tank.

“Okay!” She announced, shoving Alice’s Warrior’s jersey over her head. “Will we go play?”

“Yeah!” Nicky jumped up and motioned for Rio to follow him. Rio shot Agatha a quick wink as she scooped up the ball and went to follow her new biggest fan to the small patio’d area around the corner.

She figured she’d be safe for a while if she focused in on Nicky and not on the complicated woman who had just been touching her thigh out of the eyeline of her young son.

There was a basketball hoop set up on the wall and a discarded ball already laying there at the bottom.

“Okay,” Rio said with a smile as Nicky turned to her and held up his hands to catch the ball, “show me what you got. Take a shot.”

Nicky caught the ball on the bounce and turned to shoot his shot, missing as it hit the rim and ricocheted off.

“Close,” Rio reassured, already darting off to fetch the ball as it bounced towards the trees, “again, let’s see those master skills at work.”

Focusing in on Nicky and keeping his excitement levels up, Rio missed Agatha join them and lean against one of the trees with a glass of wine, her blue eyes darting between her son and the woman entertaining and coaching him.

And Nicky, though Rio wasn’t at all surprised by this, had clearly inherited all of his mother’s charm. He listened carefully to everything Rio told him, he watched with a seriousness that belied his age, and he grinned with such abandon that Rio wondered if Agatha had ever grinned like that in her life.

It didn’t take long for her to become fond of him, and clearly Nicky was fond of Rio.

After an hour or so of playing in the sun, Agatha stepped onto the court and held her hands in the air to stop the game, right when Rio was in the middle of an allstar run.

“Okay, enough basketball now? Can we all sit down and enjoy a cool drink and some snacks?”

Rio laughed and Nicky shook his head, “Noooo! We haven’t finished.”

“One more point,” Rio pleaded teasingly, smiling breathlessly at Agatha where she’d been running around the court like a madman, trying to elicit the feeling for Nicky of being at a real game.

Agatha rolled her eyes but dropped her hands where they hung in the sky and said in an exasperated tone, “One. Score one more and then done.”

“Okay, kid. Remember what we just discussed?” Rio shot Nicky a smile and motioned with her head where he should stand, already spinning the ball in her hands.

Nicky moved obediently and his toothy smile disappeared as he focused in and Rio had to bite her lip to stop from grinning at the change in his expression

Agatha hadn’t moved yet from the court and so Rio took advantaged of this, bouncing the ball expertly around her, making out like she’d try to take it, and spinning dramatically around her and then bouncing it back to Nicky who caught it easily and turned to aim and shoot.

He missed, but only just, and Rio was quick to recover the ball and bounce it back to him, this time scooping him up and allowing him to score in an assisted alley-oop.

When the ball flew through the net, Rio cheered and placed Nicky on her shoulder with a soft grunt of effort and began running with him to Agatha who laughed as loudly as Rio had ever heard it.

She caught them both, stumbling back a little in surprise but maintaining balance as she helped Rio to balance Nicky and soon stole him from her hold, making a soft noise of exertion as she pulled him down into her own arms and spun him around.

“A regular John Smith!”

Rio laughed and clutched her stomach as she caught her breath, beaming at the mother and son duo as Agatha halted her spin and let Nicky drop to his feet.

“Are you doing that on purpose?”

“What?” Agatha asked with an innocent smile, “He’s the best player.”

Rio was so exhausted that she couldn’t bring herself to argue and instead smiled widely at Agatha, only looking away when an excited seven year old threw himself at her and wrapped his arms around her.

Rio released a quiet ‘oomph’ at the sudden smack to her body but quickly dropped down to hug Nicky properly, laughing as he held on tight, his arms now around her neck.

“Come play again?” He asked quietly into Rio’s ear and Rio nodded gently, feeling strangely emotional about the request.

“Sure. Whenever you want.”

She pulled back only when Nicky did and saw in his face the return of his shyness that Agatha had told her about all those weeks ago back in the pool.

He didn’t quite meet her gaze again as he ran off to where the lemonade was and Rio was left standing with Agatha, feeling clammy and tired in the late-afternoon sun.

“You’re good with kids,” Agatha said softly, watching Rio with a kind of tenderness that made Rio want to turn away and hide from.

“I… probably just kids who like basketball. Or any other sports, maybe. Mostly basketball.”

She shrugged a little self-consciously and rubbed the back of her neck, mortified to feel that it actually was a little clammy and clearing her throat as she turned to where Nicky had run off to.

“He’s a good kid. You should be-…”

But her words died the instant she felt Agatha’s hands on hers and she turned suddenly to see Agatha close, holding her left hand in both of her own.

Rio felt something swell in her chest and couldn’t fight it as whatever the feeling was made her right hand move to rest over Agatha’s too, her eyes wide as she took in the face before her, wondering how she’d gone so long without being able to look at it.

“Stay,” Agatha instructed softly, not exactly a demand, not exactly a request. “Have dinner with us.”

Rio could only nod once, her mind a mysterious blank where it had just been firing on all cylinders, buoyed by the enjoyment of the exercise.

Agatha’s lips twitched ever so slightly and Rio felt her whole world stop as she leant in to her.

It must be what it felt like to die, she thought. Everything slow, everything wonderful.

As if she couldn’t take it in properly, her eyes fluttered closed and it was in the darkness that she felt Agatha’s lips against her skin for the first time in weeks.

Her cheek was flushed and she was sure it was a little sticky with the sweat from the past hour or so she’d been pulling out all the stops for Nicky in the Los Angeles sun.

But Agatha hadn’t recoiled. She’d pressed her lips to Rio’s cheek like she’d meant to do it, like she’d meant to anchor there for longer than would be considered a greeting in a European country or a friendly exchange between two movie stars.

But it couldn’t last forever.

And so Agatha pulled back and when she did, Rio’s eyes fluttered open and she turned her head ever so slightly towards her, seeking more of her warmth, wanting more.

As Rio moved and Agatha pulled back so slowly that Rio could have counted every freckle, their noses brushed and Rio sucked in sharp breath that caused the spell to be broken and for Agatha to pull away entirely.

Their eyes met and Rio saw that Agatha’s were darker than usual, her pupils swallowing the usual blue of her irises. Her lips were parted and her cheeks were flushed and Rio’s brain short-circuited when she saw where Agatha’s gaze was.

And then the world righted itself.

There was a shout.

A greeting.

A man’s voice.

Ralph was home.

Chapter End Notes

Don’t @ me about basketball I know nothing about it is alley ooping still a thing?
Teams chosen for colours and Bulls just sounded aggressively stupid so that’s Ralph (sorry to any bulls fans)

This is the penultimate of my already written chapters. I technically have two more written but it’s going one way and I might pivot back and make it go another… as of yet undecided but next update will probably be tomorrow and then I might rewrite the next one so they won’t be as quick coming out post 11 buuuuut hopefully soonish

Thanks for reading as always!!

Chapter 11: Fleetwood Facts

Chapter Summary

Ralph is home.

Rio comes to a realisation.

Chapter Notes

See the end of the chapter for notes

Ralph.

Rio had forgotten about the husband.

In all the work she’d put into convincing herself that she only wanted Agatha because she couldn’t have her, she’d forgotten about the main reason she couldn’t have her.

Her gaze fell from Agatha’s suddenly panicked eyes to the joined hands between them and she hesitated for a second before she pulled away, taking a step back and clearing her throat.

“Ralph?” She asked needlessly, watching as Agatha’s panic morphed to something different and she’d turned from her to march around to where Nicky had gone.

“He wasn’t supposed to be here.”

Rio felt suddenly like a spare part, no, like a mistress.

Without the obvious benefits.

She ran a hand through her hair and awkwardly patted her jersey down, though really there was nothing she could do to make herself look more presentable as she followed Agatha back around the house to where her husband had clearly arrived.

She was ashamed of herself but for what, she couldn’t really fathom. Maybe lustful thought, but those she’d had about various people since she was a teenage. Maybe that she’d half convinced herself that Agatha might return them.

Maybe because she thought if Ralph hadn’t arrived Agatha might have kissed her.

Waiting for them by the outdoor sitting area was a tall man with a dark sweep of hair that Rio recognised immediately as the surface-level polite husband of the woman she’d prefer to have all to herself.

A Clark Kent-type without the glasses and not for the first time Rio couldn’t help but see how someone, inclined to men, could fall for him. Which made it worse. But then maybe Rio wasn’t cruel enough to wish Agatha were married to an ugly man.

Maybe.

A red-blooded American finance bro with a strong jaw and a winning smile.

And Rio stood, a Puerto-Rican American woman with a basketball jersey that wasn’t hers and a light sheen of sweat across her brow.

Who would ever pick her?

Ralph turned to Agatha from where he’d been sat in the place Rio had been only an hour or so ago and gestured to their son, “Celtics? Really?”

Rio hated this guy.

“It’s my team,” Nicky said quietly and Rio shot him a reassuring wink as she stopped beside Agatha.

“I thought you’d be out all night,” Agatha said with such a lack of warmth that Rio turned to look at her, taken aback by this display.

“I came home to change,” Ralph said distractedly, now eyeing Rio as he stood and moved to offer her a hand, “Hi. Rio, right? You look different to the last time I saw you?”

Yeah, I’ve not been sat through hair and makeup for the last three hours you fucking asshole.

Rio shook the hand offered to her, refusing to look away from the man who so clearly wanted to say ‘you look much worse’.

“It’s amazing what a team of makeup artists and hair dressers can do.”

Ralph smiled a little and glanced at Rio’s jersey, guessing correctly, “so you’re the basketball influencer?”

“I just came over to test my skills against Nicky’s.”

She leant round slightly, and shot the boy a smile before looking back up to Ralph, almost daring him to say something.

The man seemed disinterested though, or else, already smug that whatever he thought the battle was, he’d won.

He had Agatha after all.

But Agatha interjected and moved just enough in front of Rio that Ralph had no choice but to turn to her instead, “You should hurry if you want to make your dinner reservations. Especially if you want a drink beforehand.”

“Actually,” Ralph said with a raise of his brows, looking past his wife and to Rio, “A lot of the guys in the office are fans of yours. I didn’t get to ask in Cannes and this might be a little strange but… mind if I get a selfie? They’d shit themselves if they-…”

Agatha had cleared her throat.

Rio opened her mouth and then closed it again, surprised by the request. But she couldn’t think of an excuse quickly enough to deny it so she simply nodded her assent and surreptitiously tucked her hair behind her ear.

“Excellent,” Ralph grinned and Rio once again saw what Agatha must find attractive in him. He had a boyish charm.

Superman in a suit.

“Honey,” Agatha said suddenly in a tone much softer than the one she’d used with Ralph earlier, “why don’t you go to your room? You can have an hour on your Switch before dinner, okay?”

Rio looked on as Nicky beamed and disappeared before the offer could be rescinded and Rio smiled a little at the sight, thinking that having been within Ralph’s presence for collectively less than twenty minutes she already couldn’t see any of him in his son.

And Ralph paid his son absolutely no mind as he reached over to pour himself a glass of wine, only pouring one for Rio and Agatha too when Agatha cleared her throat pointedly again and the man remembered his manners. “Excuse me, should be ladies first.”

“Where are you from?” Rio asked suddenly, accepting the glass offered to her without a thank you and trying her hardest to remain polite when all she wanted to do was run away.

“Dallas, originally. Moved to Chicago when I was a kid.”

“Hence the Bulls?”

Ralph smiled and thanked the universe that she was, fortunately, immune to his charms.

“Yes. Where exactly did my son get the idea in his head that Celtics was the way to go?”

“That would be me.”

Ralph took such a large gulp of his wine that made Rio raise her brows a little but he only nodded once he’d swallowed it down, “I suppose you can’t force a team on a kid. He’ll pick his own one day.”

“So,” he said suddenly, before Rio had even had a chance to take a sip of her wine, “selfie and then I’ll be on my way.”

Rio cleared her throat quietly and shot Agatha a quick glance and in seeing that she looked a little paler than usual she decided she didn’t mind doing this quick favour to get this man as far away as possible.

She shuffled to the edge of the couch and placed her glass down, and paused momentarily where Ralph had scuffed his chair along the stone slabs to push it back to the couch, holding his arm out behind him for Rio to slip into.

But Agatha had stood up before Rio made to move.

“Let me take it.”

Rio glanced around and saw that Agatha looked furious, her hand held out for Ralph’s phone, her fingers already twitching in a ‘give it to me’ motion.

“You’re the boss,” Ralph said in a tone that made Rio want to hit him.

But he stood and Rio stood too, allowing him to drape his arm around her waist and pull her closer than she’d have liked.

He smelled like expensive after shave and a hint of whiskey and Rio fought hard to force a smile when in interactions like these they usually came so easily.

But her gaze met Agatha’s above the phone she held to take the photo and when it did she felt the heavy weight of reality.

This was Agatha’s home.

This was Agatha’s husband.

Agatha took just one photo of the two of them and Rio decided she didn’t want to see what it looked like but she could bet she looked sweaty and uninterested in it.

“Here,” Agatha said as he held the phone back out to her husband, and Ralph took it with one hand, his other still on Rio’s waist.

Rio moved from his hold and went to stand a little further away, which Ralph didn’t object to, and Rio realised that he’d been holding her as if it were his right but that he had no real knowledge of his own actions: he was simply a man who was used to having a pretty woman on his arm.

But that didn’t sit well with her and apparently not Agatha either who’d moved around to take Rio’s hand and tug her in the direction of the lone armchair opposite where Nicky had been sitting.

Rio moved without question or thought and even sat down, looking up at Agatha as though to expect more instruction, but they never came.

“They’ll love this,” Ralph was saying with that same charming grin across his face.

“Really.” He turned to Rio and held his phone up like a trophy even with Agatha now standing between the two of them like an armed guard. “Thank you.”

Rio could only nod, smiling a little at the type of man who would consider the look on her face in the photo to be a ‘grin’ from a pretty girl and she brushed her hands down the tops of her thighs slowly as she watched Ralph turn back to his phone and broadcast the picture to anyone and everyone he thought would be impressed by it.

“Rio, Nicky, and I were going to have dinner,” Agatha said firmly, still standing between Rio and her husband, “I assume you’ll be back later?”

“Actually,” Ralph turned with that same, brilliant grin, “I might stay out with the boys. That okay, hon?”

“Of course,” Agatha said with a kind of shrug, and Rio watched as Ralph leant in and placed a firm kiss to Agatha’s cheek, making a ‘mwah’ sound that Rio would have thought Agatha would hate but she didn’t respond at all.

Ralph then turned and threw the rest of his wine down his throat, wincing ever so slightly and then turning to smile at Rio, back to his charming self.

“Nice to see you, Rio.”

Rio barely had a chance to wave before the man had turned on his heel and disappeared back into the house.

It was strange. Being suddenly confronted again with the person the subject of your months-long fascination had chosen to be with.

Because Rio wouldn’t have picked Ralph for Agatha.

She’d known that the first time she met him. She knew that now.

Sure, he was handsome, seemingly harmless though a bit obtuse, but there wasn’t much substance to him, no real personality past the cookie cutter mould he’d been carved out of.

But who was Rio to say it didn’t work. She’d been told for weeks now how ‘happily married’ Agatha was.

And maybe Agatha turned a blind eye to Ralph who sometimes looked at other women, maybe sometimes touched.

But all evidence pointed the way of a happy, functioning marriage: a cute, well-adjusted kid, a great house. What else was there?

And Rio, single and pining, was hardly a good judge of who was made for each other and who wasn’t.

So Agatha maybe flirted a little, she was a movie star, she was built to be charming to everyone. And Rio just so happened to be charmed by everything she did.

With Ralph now disappeared upstairs to change, Rio turned her attention back to Agatha and saw that she was still standing, and she reached for her hand that was nearest to her, tugging lightly at it to pull her to sit just as Agatha had done to her earlier.

Agatha allowed this and slowly sat down on the couch and reached with her free hand for her wine, taking a sip before she spoke, “Sorry, he’s just… busy with work and he doesn’t get a lot of time to blow off steam so…”

Rio recognised an excuse when she saw one and gently turned Agatha’s hand over in her own two, interlinking their fingers together without saying anything for a while.

“He’s handsome. Very handsome.”

Agatha scoffed lightly and when Rio looked up from their joined hands she saw Agatha was looking at her.

“What?” Rio asked quietly, a small smile tugging at her lips, “You think just because I like girls I can’t recognise a handsome man?”

“No, I just…” Agatha sighed and Rio’s smile faded as she shifted in her seat to watch Agatha.

“What? Think I have bad taste?”

Agatha laughed and turned to Rio properly, her smile not quite reaching her eyes as she gazed across at her, “I don’t know anything about your taste.”

“It’s good,” Rio said, “I promise you that.”

Agatha opened her mouth to say something but closed it again almost as quickly and Rio wriggled her brows at her, attempting to get her eyes to light up again as they had on the basketball court.

“I’ll have to take your word for it.”

Agatha had whispered the words and Rio looked away suddenly for fear she’d see something in her gaze she’d never recover from. She felt dizzy with her need for Agatha, unsure how this had happened again when she’d entered the house so determined to keep a hold on herself and her emotions.

There was a beat.

A silence.

And then Rio squeezed Agatha’s hand, afterwards pulling her own away for fear she was overstepping.

Agatha allowed it but dropped her gaze to where Rio had placed her arm on the arm of the chair and offered suddenly: “You want to take a shower?”

“Oh? Do I smell?”

“No, I just-…”

And Rio looked up to meet blue eyes again and she bit down on her lip, watching as Agatha’s gaze flew briefly to her lower lip now pulled between her teeth.

It must have been a trick of the light, a misfire of her brain, because as soon as she thought she saw it, it was gone. Agatha’s gaze was back meeting her own and she was smiling slightly, “You’re maybe just a little sweatier than when you first arrived.”

“Just a little?”

Rio lifted her arm and made a show of smelling her armpit and Agatha laughed properly this time, and when Rio looked back at her she looked more relaxed.

But it lasted all of two seconds.

“Hon?”

Ralph had appeared back in the door, gazing over at his wife in a new clean, crisp outfit that looked very similar to the one he’d been wearing before.

Rio pulled her arm down quickly, a little mortified that she’d been caught out trying to impress his wife in the most juvenile way possible.

“My uber’s here. I’ll see you tomorrow?”

Rio felt her heart leap to her chest when Agatha stood from her seat and went to kiss Ralph’s cheek. And her treacherous brain told her that Agatha hadn’t kissed her like that. She’d been softer, lingering longer, had pulled back slower.

She dropped her gaze and reached for her wine.

She didn’t look up again until she heard Agatha sit down on the couch and even then she didn’t look Agatha’s way, just glancing up to where Ralph had previously been.

“Offer’s there,” Agatha said as if they hadn’t just been interrupted, “if you want to shower, you can.”

“I didn’t bring anything to change into,” Rio said, more shyly than she usually would and she caught Agatha’s gaze then, seeing her tongue dart out to wet her lips and feeling the dull blankness of her mind as she watched it retreat back into her mouth.

“I have clothes. A whole closet full.”

Rio met Agatha’s gaze then and wondered how long she could tolerate this. How long she could possibly spend being friendly with Agatha when all she could think about was kissing her.

All the time. Constantly. Forever.

“Then sure, if you don’t mind.”

Agatha shook her head and Rio put her wine back down to follow Agatha through the house. She took the time to look around, seeing things she’d missed before when they’d walked through to the kitchen then out to the back.

There were little photos of Nicky dotted about everywhere and pictures of Agatha with him, but Rio was yet to spot a picture of Ralph.

Just as she was wondering why that was, she collided into Agatha’s back as they reached the top of the stairs.

“Shit.”

Agatha raised her brows as Rio straightened herself out and motioned to a door to the right on the large landing.

“Use the guest bathroom. Ralph will have just used ours so… you’ll find clean towels on the side and use whatever you want. I’ll find some clothes and leave them just outside for you.”

Rio nodded, suddenly feeling shy again and wondering whether this was a good idea.

But she’d committed already and it would look weird if she bailed so she shot Agatha a quick smile before she turned to disappear into the bathroom.

The room was large, pristine, and Rio resisted the urge to search through Agatha’s cabinets.

She didn’t want to dawdle so she stripped herself quickly of her clothes and stepped into the walk in shower, and after a few attempts got the waterfall head to turn on at just the right temperature.

She lathered herself in Agatha’s expensive soaps and washed her hair with shampoo and conditioner with fancy french names on a monochrome label.

Everything was expensive, everything felt and smelled incredible and Rio had to actively not think that soon she would smell like Agatha, and soon she would be wearing Agatha’s clothes.

But as she stepped out she had a horrifying realisation.

She was clean, fresh, and she now had two options: she either wore Agatha’s clothes with underwear she’d already worn that day, or she went commando.

Neither were good.

But she dried herself, squeezing as much water from her damp hair as possible with the plush white towel, and soon wrapped herself in it to open the door and look for the clothes that Agatha had promised to leave.

Sitting in a neat little pile was a light green cashmere sweater and white linen pants.

Celtics colours.

She smiled to herself as she pulled them inside and put them on.

She could smell Agatha’s fabric conditioner on them, and she checked herself over in the mirror, seeing herself reflected in Agatha’s clothes. Maybe the universe had a sense of humour because this wasn’t exactly how she’d fantasied about getting into Agatha’s pants.

She folded her old clothes up and left the bathroom with them, making sure to place her used towel in the laundry basket to the side.

When she went back down to find Agatha she saw the little table and chairs empty and looked around to find her.

Across the pool Agatha was sitting below the awning, smiling across at her and waving at her to make sure she’d spotted her.

It was almost too much to bear. Too domestic and easy.

But Rio placed her sweaty clothes in her tote bag and left it on the side to go and join Agatha in the more private part of the yard.

“A change of scenery?”

“It’s nicer under here when it gets a little darker,” Agatha said with a shrug, her gaze roaming over the sight of Rio before her in her clothes.

“Like the colour choice?”

“Subtle,” Rio said with a grin, taking a seat opposite Agatha in on of the little armchairs.

Agatha just hummed and reached over to pour some wine for Rio, leaning across to hold it out to her.

“I don’t think I’ve ever seen Nicky take to someone so quickly.”

“I don’t think I’ve ever taken to a kid so quickly as I did to him.”

Agatha bit on her lower lip and dropped her gaze to her own wine glass, swirling it slowly before her.

“Ever think about having kids of your own?”

Rio paused before she answered, wondering how honest she wanted to be.

“I’d have to find a woman first.”

“Wanda doesn’t want kids?”

Rio blinked, unsure she’d heard Agatha correctly. She tilted her head and remained silent until Agatha looked back up at her, “What?”

“I… I’m not dating Wanda, Agatha. Do you think I am?”

Agatha shrugged slightly, her eyes back down on her wine glass, “I saw you guys at the roundtable and I thought… maybe… and then at Venice you were-…”

“On the boat?” Rio asked with a frown, “We hung out together because Alice knew I was miserable and exhausted and needed a friend nearby.”

“They got pictures of you together out at a restaurant. Holding hands.”

Rio couldn’t believe what she was hearing. If holding hands with someone was all it took for Agatha to think they were dating then she must have considered her and Rio married five times over by now.

“Agatha,” Rio said gently, unable to get a hold on Agatha’s feelings about this.

Goddamn Best Actress, she thought.

“Those photos were taken at a dinner with me, Wanda, and Alice. They just didn’t get Alice because she was beside me. And…,” she added with a little smile: “she’s little.”

Agatha’s eyes darted back up then and she looked at Rio for a second before she said: “I just assumed…”

“We’re just friends.”

Agatha nodded slowly and Rio smiled a little, chewing her lip as she watched the cogs turn in Agatha’s mind and once again she found herself wishing she could unwind them, read what they were saying.

“But yes, if I found the right person, I’d want a family.”

It was a half-truth. The unspoken part of it being that right now, sitting in Agatha’s clothes, in her house, with her son upstairs, she wanted this family. Husband excluded.

“You’d be a good mom,” Agatha offered, and Rio saw that she’d drifted somewhere again, somewhere where Rio wouldn’t be able to reach her until she came back to herself.

“As good as you, I’d hope.”

Agatha laughed a little, “You’ve barely seen me as a mom.”

“But I know you as a woman. I’ve seen enough of Nicky to know he’s all you. There’s none of Ralph in him.”

Thank god, Rio added for herself.

Agatha’s brows raised slowly and Rio could see that she was fighting off a small smile, “You think?”

“Practically a mini-you. Minus the attitude and the poor ball skills, of course.”

Agatha’s smile really hit then but she was rolling her eyes, tucking her legs beneath her on the couch. “Well now I don’t need to improve my skills because I have you.”

“Oh? Is that what this is? Pimping me out to your son for basketball practice? I’ll have you know I’m soon to win an Oscar.”

“Winning now, are you?”

“Best believe it, Harkness. Alice thinks you’ve secured me a good few votes with your public announcement of my being your favourite actress. She said Jen was pissed.”

Agatha shrugged, “She got over it.”

“How?”

“Well, I’m pretty sure after a few heated phone calls with your manager she had to relent for fear she’d lose Alice.”

“That would never happen,” Rio said with her full chest, so certain that Alice was in it for the long haul with Jen. “Did she tell you they said ‘I love you’ last night?”

“She did.”

Rio smiled a little and adjusted herself in her seat, resting her free arm along the arm of the chair, “Maybe they’ll have a kid.”

“I’m pretty sure Jen likes Nicky despite her protestations sometimes. Maybe they will.”

Rio hummed softly, wondering if this was a conversation Jen and Alice had already had because Alice was a big softy with babies.

“It’s hard not to like him.”

“Because he’s so like me?”

Rio laughed and reached for a chip from the large bowl in the centre of the table between them, “Sure, tell yourself that.”

Agatha grinned and took a sip of her wine before swirling it and looking off to the little basketball court in the distance, just about making out the net from where she sat.

“I mean it though, you can come over whenever you want, if you want. Nicky would be thrilled.”

“See, another issue on the whole kid thing,” Rio said, ignoring the warm feeling in her chest that came from the open invitation. “After this week I’m away again.”

“You are?”

“In Toronto for about three months. Press in between.”

Rio saw in Agatha’s gaze such a look of such shock that she thought she was imagining it.

But it disappeared quickly and Agatha cleared her throat, “See when you have kids you have to pick and choose carefully… I’m shooting in Studio City for around four months, starting in about three weeks.”

Rio nodded slowly, her tongue sticking into the inside of her cheek as she watched Agatha’s gaze fall to her wine again.

“Anything good?” She asked lamely, feeling as though the bubble had burst somehow.

“It’s just a tv thing. A limited series based on Heartburn.”

Rio raised her brows, and sat up a little more, “I forgot. I read that you’d got that. I auditioned, you know.”

“Too young,” Agatha quipped with a grin and tilted her glass to Rio in a pseudo-toast, “That role needs experience.”

“Ah yes, I always forget I’m talking to an old woman. Tell me, how’re the aches and pains today?”

“I could run rings around you, Vidal.”

“I don’t know. Weren’t doing much running earlier.”

“It’s cute that you think you’re cute.”

“Making me cute, no?”

Rio tilted her head to the side and gave Agatha her best grin, placing her hand underneath her chin. Agatha rolled her eyes but smiled and shuffled a little in her seat, “So irritating.”

“Hey, I just provided an hour’s worth of free childcare for you. And a selfie for your husband. I usually charge for those, you know.”

Agatha’s smile fell slightly, “Yeah, I’m sorry about that. You didn’t have to.”

“It’s okay. Happens.”

Agatha nodded and Rio took the opportunity to take another large sip of wine, deciding she wasn’t drunk enough to be able to hold a proper conversation about Ralph.

“He is a good dad,” Agatha said suddenly, making Rio almost choke where she’d gone to take another sip.

“I mean,” Agatha clarified, watching Rio with a slight frown when she was now recovering from her choking by taking another sip of the very thing that had choked her in the first place.

“He loves Nicky.”

Rio wasn’t sure that loving a child was all it took to be a ‘good dad’ but she also wasn’t sure she was in any position to judge, mostly because given the chance she’d insult Ralph for days - whether he deserved it or not.

“Okay,” she said quietly, unsure how to respond or what Agatha was trying to say.

Agatha took her own large gulp of her wine and then reached for the bottle to top Rio up again, “Oh. No,” Rio said quickly, coming to her senses just in time to stop Agatha from filling her glass, “I need to drive home. I shouldn’t.”

“Stay,” Agatha said suddenly, holding the bottle up and raising her gaze to Rio’s, watching her closely.

And without thinking Rio simply nodded, and removed the hand that hovered over her glass to allow Agatha to refill it.

When it was done she raised her gaze to meet cautious blue eyes and she took a slow breath in before she said: “This dinner on Friday… this opportunity for a double date plus me… I’m assuming Ralph is coming?”

Agatha dropped her gaze and nodded as she filled her own glass and put the bottle back in the ice bucket. “Yeah, he’ll be here.”

Rio nodded too and sat back slowly in her seat, “I’m trying to think of excuses to get out of it.”

“Why?” Agatha asked suddenly, a deep frown marring her features at this news.

“I’ll be the fifth wheel, I’m not exactly looking forward to sitting with two couples.”

Maybe the wine had made her say it, and Rio would have been embarrassed but mostly she was just glad she hadn’t said the real truth of it: “I don’t want to see you with Ralph.”

But Agatha said something next that made Rio worry she’d said the bad part out loud.

“Then I’ll make sure Ralph’s at the top of the table. You can sit with me.”

Rio opened her mouth to ask how this might make a difference but closed it again when Agatha held out her hand to her, making a bridge between the couch and the chair.

“It’ll be good, I promise.”

And Agatha wriggled her fingers because Rio was yet to take her hand. And she only didn’t for a few seconds longer because she enjoyed seeing Agatha work for it, her fingers dancing expectantly towards the sky.

“Fine. I’ll turn up. Maybe without any basketball jerseys this time.”

She reached across and took Agatha’s hand, smiling when her fingers wrapped around her own.

“About that…” Agatha said absently, looking down at their joined hands. “I spoke to Nicky whilst you were showering. He’s pretty set on Celtic.”

“Celtics,” Rio corrected with a raised brow, “Does this mean I’ve lost my jersey?”

“I’ll buy you another.”

“Mm,” Rio said with a smirk, “The thing is, I don’t even mind because they’re the best team in the world so I’m glad to have been such a good influence.”

“If you wanted to have a word with him about bed times and brushing his teeth, that would be good for me too.”

“I don’t believe that Nicky has any problem with either of those things.”

Agatha hummed quietly, her gaze still down on their hands and her thumb now brushing idly in a way that made Rio yearn for her, as pathetic as she was.

“No, maybe not. I lucked out with him.”

“I think it’s more than luck,” Rio said kindly, shaking Agatha’s hand gently to try to get her to look up at her, “you must have had some influence in there along the way.”

“Maybe,” Agatha smiled coyly, raising her gaze to Rio. “Just wanted to hear you say it again.”

Rio laughed and pulled her hand away suddenly, staring at Agatha in faux-horror, “Fishing for compliments? A woman who gets truck loads every waking hour?”

“Hey,” Agatha protested, and whether because Rio had taken her hand back or because she was accusing her, she didn’t know. “Parenting compliments are different.”

“Agatha, who meets that kid and doesn’t compliment your parenting skills?”

Agatha just rolled her eyes and made a motion with her hand to get Rio to give hers back but Rio wilfully ignored it, deciding it was for her own good more than anything. Because the next time she was over, she certainly wouldn’t be able to hold Agatha’s hand.

“Just doesn’t hurt to hear it, that’s all.”

Her fingers stopped dancing and she held her palm flat out, reaching for just one more second before she pulled it back in.

Rio considered this for a second, considered the implications of it, and wondered where it had happened that they were fine with just holding hands whilst talking over wine.

It was new, for sure. Perhaps it was just a fluke. Perhaps Agatha were drunker than she realised, and maybe she was too.

Or perhaps, just perhaps, Agatha had missed her, had just been told she potentially wasn’t going to see her again for a few months and… she was making up for lost time.

But Rio couldn’t let herself do it.

Agatha had gone silent too and something settled between them that Rio couldn’t name but that made her not want to break it for fear they would have to broach a topic that neither of them were ready for.

And it was true soon enough, but the peace broke in a way that Rio didn’t mind: the return of Nicky.

The noise of the boy running to them made Agatha shift in her seat and them both to turn to watch his entrance and Rio had to fight a laugh where he was still wearing his brand new, old Celtics jersey.

“It’s been an hour,” he announced with a sheepish smile and Rio raised her brows around at Agatha, shocked that this kid would be so honest when he probably could have got away with another few hours playing his games if Rio had anything to do with it.

“Okay,” Agatha said with an easy smile, pulling Nicky closer to lean against the couch so she could lean up and kiss his temple, watching Rio from where she now rested her chin on his shoulder.

“Dinner, then?”

“Dinner,” Rio and Nicky agreed at the same time and Agatha’s smile widened before she let her son go to chase down to the kitchen.

Rio stood and smiled at Agatha as she matched her movements, glancing around to check Nicky was gone before she lowered her voice and said: “Whatever you did in a past life to deserve that kid, well done.”

Agatha only rolled her eyes but Rio saw her proud smile and she laughed as she grabbed the bucket of wine from the table, “You couldn’t be more smug if you tried.”

“Hey, I’m allowed to be proud of my son.”

“Yeah, yeah.”

Agatha followed Rio down the path, around the pool, and back up to the house. And, once inside, Rio placed the bucket down and leant up against the island in the middle of the grand kitchen.

“Is there anything I can do to help?”

“Music duty?” Agatha asked with a thrown smile over her shoulder as she turned the faucet on to wash her hands.

“Music I can do.”

Rio pulled out her phone from the tote bag just outside the back door and noticed a few new unread messages but scrolled past them as she went to take a seat beside Nicky at the island.

“What do you like, kid? Jazz? You seem like a jazz kinda guy.”

Agatha snorted and Nicky laughed with a scrunch of his nose, “No! Something fun. Rock!”

“Rock?” Rio asked with an amused smile, scrolling through her playlists until she came across something that would surely do the trick.

“Okay, Fleetwood Mac it is. Classic. Excellent. Rock.”

After some fumbling, she connected it to the bluetooth speaker and watched Nicky’s face as the first chords of the guitar kicked in and Lindsey Buckingham’s voice filled the kitchen.

“You are so cheesy,” Agatha said from the other side of the island where she was chopping garlic.

“Fleetwood Mac are not cheesy. How dare you.”

Agatha just rolled her eyes and Rio grinned at her. And something took over suddenly, her desire to show off or her desire to have Agatha’s attention again. Maybe she just wanted Nicky to like her.

But she slipped from her stool and began to sing along with Lindsey, hamming it up as best she could.

“Oh my god,” Agatha protested, but Rio had stolen a wooden spoon from the nearby utensils pot and began to belt out the lyrics with abandon.

“Nicky!” She shouted, gesturing for him to jump up and join and for a second he looked too shy to jump up and do it but then the chorus kicked in and Rio really went for it around a still protesting Agatha.

“I’ve not had enough wine for this.”

“Shut up,” Rio grinned, tugging her arm to pull her from the chopping board and draping her arm around her neck so they were cheek to cheek and Agatha had access to the wooden spoon now masquerading as a mic.

And Agatha wrapped her arms around Rio, which made Rio’s heart race, and for just a second she’d turned her face around and pressed into Rio’s cheek.

It made Rio stutter as she sang and she lost all sense of the lyrics for the time Agatha was pressing against her but by the next line it was done and Rio turned to look wide eyed at Agatha, singing as she did: “Open up, everything’s waiting for you…”

Agatha still had her arms around Rio, resting her hands on her left hip, Rio’s side flush against Agatha’s front.

And there, in the breath between the verse and the chorus, Rio knew that Alice had been wrong. That ‘happily married’ wasn’t true. That Agatha wanted her maybe as much as she wanted Agatha.

Her father had been right all those years ago when he’d told her that rock and roll music was the thinking man’s Jesus Christ.

But Agatha’s lips were moving and she was relenting to the pull of the song and shouting with Rio now into the mic as the chorus kicked up again.

His mother joining in was all Nicky needed.

And soon the three of them were bellowing “YOU CAN GO YOUR OWN WAY” into the mic, Rio making sure everyone got equal opportunities to share the spoon.

Agatha was now only holding onto her with one arm, her other had pulled Nicky into the fold and Rio felt sick with it, sick with the ease in which the three of them huddled together and sung their hearts out.

This borrowed little family for the night was all it would ever be.

Even if Agatha might want her too. Even if she continued to hold her hand and touch her leg.

This wasn’t hers to keep.

As the first guitar solo kicked in, Rio’s rational mind overtook and she pulled away to give herself over to the sacred art of air guiltar.

Agatha was unwilling to join in so two guitarists would have to do.

Her and Nicky tore it up around her and Rio felt the familiar flush of an adoring audience admiring her, though this particular audience was made of just one.

“I hate theatre kids,” Agatha mumbled as she fell back against the counter and laughed at the sight before her, shaking her head in disbelief as the song drew to a close and Rio was back on her again, mic at the ready.

“No, not again!”

“You can go your own way!” Both Rio and Nicky sang, both grabbing at Agatha who now had two maniacs in her arms once more.

Rio was laughing too much for the next guitar solo and Nicky fully went for it, throwing his long hair about the place that Rio had to applaud him as he did so, trying to ignore that Agatha had draped her arms around her middle and was laughing into her shoulder.

But she leant back into it, her mic-less hand resting above Agatha’s, and the only thing that could break them apart, would ever make Rio pull away from being held like this, was Nicky as he finished the song with a fist in the air and a brilliant, proud grin.

Agatha squeezed Rio’s middle and then moved around her to place a firm kiss to her son’s pink cheeks and beamed down at him.

“My little rockstar.”

Rio grinned as she leant against the island and caught her breath, horrified that she could be so out of it after just one song when she’d been more than capable of running around the basketball court for an hour in the hot sun earlier.

Wine, she thought idly, but her gaze drifted across to Agatha and she wondered if she was another reason she felt breathless.

She chewed on her lip to stop herself from getting carried away again with thoughts that would send her over the cliff edge until she felt a hand on her stomach and she looked up just as Agatha kissed her cheek sweetly.

“Goofy,” she whispered close to Rio’s ear and grinned at her as she pulled away, her hand moving round to the safety of Rio’s side when Nicky moved back around again and jumped on the stool.

“We should do that before dinner every night.”

Rio’s cheeks were now flushed for a different reason but she turned around to smile at Nicky and raised her brows, feeling a soft touch at the small of her back before Agatha pulled away entirely to focus back in on the meal prep.

“I think your mom would love that. You can pick a different song every night and sing it together.”

“Rio,” Agatha muttered quietly, and Rio turned to raise her brows at Agatha, challenging her to it.

“Mm?”

“I can kick you out, you know.”

“But you won’t,” Rio grinned, turning where she stood to lean her back on the counter again, and reaching across Agatha to get her wine.

Agatha only huffed but returned to her meal prep, occasionally adding to the conversation where Rio and Nicky mostly spoke about basketball and occasionally soccer.

By the time dinner was made, a prawn linguine, with chilli on the side so Nicky didn’t have to have it, and it was presented in a large bowl in the middle of the table in the breakfast nook, Rio had decided that Nicky was the best kid she’d ever met.

And Agatha, well she knew how she felt about Agatha.

And sitting here, at the little table with her son, half a bottle of wine in her system, and Agatha’s knee every so often knocking into her own, was enough to confirm it.

It hadn’t been this a silly vacation one-sided infatuation. She’d fallen for hypnotic blue eyes and soft, secret touches. She’d fallen for Agatha Harkness, totally and utterly, and she now believed, despite Alice’s voice ringing in her ears, that Agatha might have fallen too.
