“One more. I haven’t even seen you naked.”

“Nicky,” Agatha warned quietly, raising her brows as Rio huffed and closed her eyes as she forced her body to relax, going slack beneath Agatha’s firm hold on her.

“Okay. I’ll behave. But next time.”

She flashed her eyes open and saw that even Agatha looked reluctant now to keep her from touching her.

“Naked,” Rio said insistently. “I want you naked and I want to taste you.”

Agatha’s hold on her wrists tightened so much that Rio hissed as her nails dug into her flesh and groaned when Agatha pressed a little firmer with her hips, “Rio.”

“Agatha.”

“Friday. Just two days.”

“If you can last that long then you need to let go of me,” Rio challenged suddenly, feeling a flair of confidence that Agatha wanted it as much as she did.

But Agatha had the trump card.

She had the son.

She had ultimate reason to not give in when Rio could have forgone her principles just one more time and pushed Agatha back onto the couch.

Agatha relaxed her hold on Rio slowly, and then all at once, stepping backwards with a frown and a huff that told Rio everything she needed to know.

And Rio smiled because at least this way, she wouldn’t be the only one suffering until she could get Agatha naked and on her back.

She moved a step closer and leant in to kiss Agatha’s cheek as politely as if they’d just met for the first time at a premier.

“You’ll have to sleep in the guest room,” Agatha said softly, watching as Rio pulled away.

But Rio hadn’t expected or wanted to sleep in the bed she assumed Agatha shared with Ralph and so she only nodded, taken aback slightly when Agatha suddenly held her face in her hands and kissed her firmly, keeping their lips pressed together for a longer than Rio was expecting and not pushing for anything more than the contact of it.

But she pulled away again and Rio was left with nothing but a hand in hers and a soft promise that they could be together properly again in two days time.

They walked silently through the house and up the stairs until Agatha stopped them at the entrance to the guest room and she pressed a quick kiss to Rio’s cheek.

“I’ll fetch you something to sleep in.”

She turned then and began to walk down the hall as Rio watched her and chewed on her lip for a second.

“Agatha?”

Agatha turned halfway down the hallway and looked at Rio curiously.

Rio’s fingers tightened briefly where she held the doorframe and she hesitated only for a second, encouraged by the soft expression on Agatha’s face.

“Don’t make me sleep alone tonight.”

Chapter End Notes

I cannot tell you how much I have been going back and forth on this chapter. I edited down to just kissing and talking then to just talking and then back again. And then??

Anyway, poor Agatha hasn’t been touched properly and whilst that’s not exactly true for Rio she feels it is because she’s so down bad

Also! Comments always appreciated they honestly make my day and I’m actually not sure if it’s cool to respond to them all or cool to not respond ? What do other authors do? Who knows?

Chapter 13: The Morning After The Night Before

Chapter Summary

Rio begins to pine.

Chapter Notes

A little short one for you all because the next one is going to be hella long so sorry in advance

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“Don’t make me sleep alone tonight.”

Agatha strode back over to her, her hands finding their home on Rio’s face.

“I can’t tonight. If Nicky…”

She trailed off as Rio looked down and began toying with the hem of Agatha’s sweater.

“I’ll be right back.”

Agatha pulled away then and Rio felt the loss of her in a way she never had before. Because she’d had Agatha. In her home. She’d felt her against her skin, pressed against her body, writhing and moaning on top of her.

And now she was being faced with the reality.

That she had had Agatha.

And maybe, if she were lucky, she could have her again.

But she’d have to sleep alone.

Because Agatha didn’t belong to her.

Just as Rio was hitting the peak of her pity spiral, Agatha arrived back.

She pressed a dark t-shirt and soft pyjama pants against Rio’s chest and Rio saw a hesitation in Agatha as they locked eyes again.

“I want to,” she said quietly, her fingers tensing in the fabric of the offered pyjamas. “I don’t want to leave you but I can’t risk it.”

“I know,” Rio uttered, because she did understand the need to protect Nicky from this. They were fully grown adults and they didn’t know what they were doing. How would they explain it to a seven year old who had only just been introduced to Rio was suddenly sleeping with his mother.

That his mother was betraying his father.

So Rio had to be an adult and endure sleeping across the hall from Agatha when she knew what she tasted like, knew how she felt against her.

“Goodnight,” she said in a whisper, barely able to form the two syllables that locked her out of the night she wanted with the woman before her.

Agatha’s lips parted and Rio thought, hoped, she might waver on her decision.

But she turned away.

She took long, confident strides back to her own room and left Rio standing in the door, staring hopelessly at the woman she’d just broken her own moral code for.

And then Rio closed the door.

And she was alone.

As the lock clicked into place Rio felt her world collapse in on itself.

She felt small, in a large room.

She moved away to strip Agatha’s clothes from her body and instead slip into the borrowed pyjamas.

They were soft against her skin and smelled of Agatha. And she hated herself for lifting the collar and breathing it in.

She’d become a monster who yearned.

The bed was a welcome embrace when she finally climbed into it after washing her face and brushing her teeth in the en suite attached.

She curled in on herself, tugging a plush pillow down to act as an inanimate, and therefore willing, receptacle of her sorrows. She wrapped around it and squeezed her eyes shut and willed sleep that wouldn’t come.

Perhaps fantasies were fantasises for a reason. Perhaps Agatha’s imagined lips and hands on her were better than the real thing.

Because the fantasy made Rio yearn.

But they didn’t make her mourn.

And now she’d had what she’d fantasied about. But she didn’t want the fantasy Agatha.

She wanted the real, warm, alive woman who could light a fire in her body and ask her to burn everything down.

Rio closed her eyes and tried to think of things that weren’t Agatha.

But all she could smell was Agatha.

All she could feel on her body were the soft fabrics of Agatha’s clothes.

Sleep eluded her.

She lay awake all night, drifting for no more than twenty minutes at a time until the little alarm clock on the side told her it was 6:45 and she heard movement outside.

She peeled herself out of her Egyptian cotton prison and went quickly to brush her teeth and splash cool water on her face in an attempt to force herself to wake properly.

But there was no waking from the living nightmare that meant she had now experienced something she could probably never have again.

In the mirror she spotted the bruise on her neck and she touched it gently. It was evidence that last night had been real. That Agatha had wanted her enough to mark her as her own.

With no makeup with her and the prospect of seeing Nicky she simply swept her hair over her shoulder and hid it from view.

The hall was empty by the time Rio stepped into it and but she could hear noises not far away, the telltale signs of a coffee pot brewing, the tinny sounds of the radio, the soft giggles of a little boy who Agatha believed was hers because she’d wanted Rio so badly.

It made Rio’s heart stutter in her chest at the thought.

But her body moved where her mind remained stuck on the same topic that had kept her awake all night.

She made her way to the kitchen and found before her a sight that to anyone else would have been a simple, happy vignette but now to Rio Vidal was a reminder of what she didn’t have and was therefore barbarous to her sensitive heart.

“Morning,” Agatha said softly from her place by the island.

She wore a light, flannel robe and her hands were curled around a large mug of coffee.

“Did you sleep okay?”

Something in Agatha’s gaze told Rio that this wasn’t what Agatha actually wanted to know but she couldn’t say anything other than the bare-faced lie that came from her lips: “Amazingly.”

Agatha’s lips twitched at the sides and Rio had to look away for fear she’d simply stare.

And staring over cornflakes was not a very cool thing to do.

She moved instead to sit on a stool beside Nicky, mirroring the smile he sent her over his bowl of Cheerios.

“Morning, kid. What’s on the schedule today?”

“School.”

“Just school? No championships to win?”

Nicky grinned around his spoon and Rio grinned back when he managed to dribble milk back into his bowl.

He was easy to love.

Agatha moved around with a paper towel to wipe at his mouth, kissing his cheek when she was done.

“Messy,” she said with a smile.

“Nicky’s taking his new jersey for basketball practice this afternoon.”

“Is that right?” Rio asked in amusement as Agatha moved away to fetch more coffee.

“They have a game next week.”

“I don’t think we’ll win. We never win.”

“Hmm,” Rio hummed thoughtfully, watching the little boy turn his attention back to his cereal. “Well, if you take that jersey with you I think you just might. Green is a lucky colour. Plus, with how good you were yesterday there’s no way you won’t win.”

Agatha placed her coffee down before her and grazed her fingers along the back of Rio’s hand as she pulled away.

“I’m not as tall as the others.”

“That’s okay,” Rio felt Agatha’s hand settle on her shoulder. She forced herself not to take it.

“I’m not that tall either and I can run rings around everyone.”

She felt Agatha squeeze her shoulder and then move away.

God, she wanted her.

“Rings?”

“It’s an expression, honey,” Agatha clarified with a smile. “Go get ready and I’ll be up in a minute.”

Nicky nodded and slid from his stool, moving quickly with his bowl to place it by the sink before he ran away upstairs.

In the quiet of the kitchen Rio felt suddenly nervous, suddenly exposed. She watched as Agatha took up the stool beside her and reach her hand halfway across the distance between them along the cool marble countertop.

“Did you actually sleep okay? Because-…”

“I didn’t sleep at all.”

Rio placed her hand cautiously by Agatha’s on the counter and stretched her fingers out so the pads of hers could brush over Agatha’s nails.

She watched as Agatha looked down at the movement and saw her biting her lip.

“Did you?”

“You know I don’t sleep.”

Agatha raised her fingers enough then to capture Rio’s as they moved down again and she interlocked their fingers in a move that made Rio’s heart stutter.

She took a breath and looked up to see Agatha watching her cautiously.

“Didn’t you take a pill?”

“No, I wasn’t sure if… no, I decided not to.”

Rio nodded and swallowed down the unspoken between them: she could have gone to Agatha in the night.

She frowned slightly and looked down at their hands.

Agatha took Rio’s breath away when she rubbed her thumb in small circles against Rio’s skin.

“Can you stay? It won’t take long to drop Nicky off and I don’t have to be anywhere until the afternoon.”

“I have wardrobe fittings today,” Rio said quietly, mesmerised by the thumb still brushing slowly over her skin.

It felt unreal, unbelievable. Like Rio had found the road to El Dorado. Only the gold was instead a goddess and Rio would worship at her feet if she asked her to.

“Rio,” Agatha whispered softly, snapping Rio from her daydreams of Agatha draped in white robes, wearing a laurel wreath and Rio feeding her grapes on a chaise.

Dark eyes moved up to meet light blue and that’s when Agatha moved.

She stood from her stool in one quick movement and pressed her lips to the corner of Rio’s mouth, her free hand just ghosting along Rio’s jaw.

Rio gasped quietly and turned her head to capture Agatha’s lips properly, and Agatha’s hand settled properly on her cheek as she kissed her back.

It was tender more than fierce. Gentle rather than greedy.

And Rio thought she’d die because of it.

She thought she’d cease to exist when Agatha pulled away from her. When she was denied the ability to simply live against Agatha’s lips.

“We can’t,” Agatha whispered as she pulled away. But she kissed Rio again. And then again. And Rio found herself pining in the half a second between each kiss.

It happened ten times, though Rio hadn’t counted. Hadn’t had the wherewithal to do so.

But Agatha was pulling away properly now and Rio actually whimpered because of it, actually fell from her stool and reached her free hand to brush hair behind Agatha’s ear and capture her lips again.

Now just an inch away from her, Agatha wrapped an arm around Rio’s waist and pressed her closer, their soft kisses truncated with soft breaths in between, brief and unconscious checks that the other wanted the next kiss.

But Rio could have done it forever.

She could have given up everything to just wait around for Agatha to kiss her like this. Just like this. She would make a promise to never press for more. Would simply always just wait patiently for Agatha to press her lips to hers whenever she wanted.

But Agatha was pulling away again, only this time moving so far that now the island was between them.

She ran a hand through her hair and Rio was pining again.

“We can’t,” Agatha repeated.

And Rio knew she was right.

Knew they were being too brazen with it.

She dropped her gaze to her coffee and pulled it towards her for something to do. For something to hold.

“I should go check on Nicky.”

“I should go change.”

Rio glanced up and saw her own pain reflected in Agatha’s gaze. It made her pine more.

“Friday,” Agatha said quietly, “Come over. Stay for the day.”

Rio could only nod, her gaze falling back to the hand she’d just been holding that now rested on the island.

“Rio,” Agatha said gently, forcing Rio to look up at her again. “I want to talk about this. About us.”

Rio nodded again but her tongue felt thick in her mouth because the reminder of Friday brought with it two things that made her feel sick: the first being that Agatha could easily tell her this wasn’t what she wanted. The second being that Ralph would be there in the evening, and Rio wouldn’t be able to look at her for fear she’d see Ralph too near, too close.

But Agatha was moving back around and touching Rio’s arm as she walked past, squeezing her forearm gently.

And Rio took just another second before she went to grab her discarded bag of dirty clothes from yesterday and she disappeared back to her assigned bedroom.

Once alone behind a closed door she changed quickly, folding Agatha’s pyjamas up and placing them neatly on the end of the bed. She checked the bathroom, and did one final check of the room to make sure she’d left it as pristine as she’d found it.

Once sure it was perfect, she left again in the clothes she’d worn when she arrived yesterday.

Only this was the worst walk of shame she’d ever experienced.

She’d been part of an affair.

She’d kissed and fucked and been fucked by a married woman.

She’d made plans to do it again. To talk it through. To continue the affair.

She hovered by the front door, killing time as she waited for Agatha and Nicky by checking her phone.

It had died.

Alice would kill her.

But five minutes later and Nicky was barrelling down the stairs and Rio looked up just as she saw the little boy appear in the hall, grinning at Rio with his backpack almost the same size as him on his back.

“Will you be back soon?”

Agatha had appeared behind him and Rio felt her stomach flip as she felt her eyes on her.

“Would I really want to miss learning from the best?”

Nicky’s smile turned shy and he reached to grab the straps of his backpack as Agatha moved closer and Rio caught the familiar scent of her perfume on the air.

It was torturous.

“Come on. Let’s get you to school.”

Rio caught Agatha’s eye and she paused for just a second before she stepped out of the way and felt the brush of Agatha’s arm against her own.

It had to be deliberate. She’d given her enough space.

Rio let Nicky go out before them and she looked up as Agatha met her gaze when she stepped past.

She looked tired, and somehow nervous.

And Rio couldn’t help herself when she stepped in and gave her a quick kiss on the cheek. It was friendly, or as friendly as she could manage.

And she turned before she could see Agatha’s reaction.

Nicky was too interested in walking towards the outside gate anyway to much notice what his mother was doing so Rio felt confident she hadn’t overstepped.

She waited at the gate for Agatha to join them and watched as she tapped in the code so it would open onto the quiet street.

It felt like entering a different life, stepping out of Agatha’s arena and back into the tree-lined street.

But as the gate closed, Agatha had turned to catch her eye and reached for her arm.

“Friday?”

Rio could only nod, only turn as Nicky stepped towards his mom to take her hand and smile shyly at Rio again.

She forced herself to return the smile and turned from them both with a wave to find her little hybrid parked up the street.

Once in the safety of her car she released a breath she didn’t know she’d been holding and stared at her steering wheel.

Had last night really happened? Had she just spent two precious minutes in Agatha’s kitchen, kissing her sweetly, allowing Agatha to hold her hand and wrap her arm around her?

She started the car and shook her head to herself, finding a discarded wire somewhere so she could plug in her phone and get out of there as quickly as possible.

Halfway down the freeway her phone lit up with Alice calling her and she grimaced as she pressed the button to answer and Alice’s tinny voice came through the speaker.

“Holy shit, Rio. I was so close to sending a search party. What happened?”

“I stayed over at Agatha’s.”

“You stayed over? What? The kid was so useless at basketball you had to run into extra time?”

“No. No. He’s cute. Sweet. I just… had too much wine to drive so Agatha told me to stay.”

“Please tell me you didn’t get drunk again.”

“No, Alice,” Rio said with a huff, wondering if this was what Alice was annoyed about then how she might feel about Rio being inside of the great Agatha Harkness just a few hours ago.

“I behaved.”

“Sure, whatever. Just get back soon. The costume guys will be here in less than an hour and I want to tell you all about me and Jen. And you can reassure me that you managed to charm Agatha.”

Rio rolled her eyes but hung up.

The drive back home allowed her the time she needed to sort through her complicated feelings about what she’d done.

She knew she didn’t want to be the cause of anyone’s marriage breaking up. But she also knew she hated Ralph. And everything was currently pointing to Ralph being a prick so that hatred was justified.

She knew she liked Agatha. She was beginning to suspect that she might be falling for Agatha. She knew she wanted to kiss her and touch her and taste her.

She knew Agatha liked her. At least enough to be curious. At least enough to come within barely minutes of Rio admittedly not doing her best work on a couch when she’d been taken by surprise and was so shocked that she was even allowed to touch Agatha like that.

She knew that Agatha would be nervous and scared and the chances of her burning her carefully curated image down for Rio were next to zero.

Let alone her family.

She knew she’d never destroy her family for Rio.

Which left her with one choice: if she wanted Agatha she had to be a mistress. She had to be as discreet as possible. As available as she could make herself on the off-chance that Agatha had the time and the inclination to let her near her again.

She would have to get a handle on her feelings and treat this as just another girl she could have fun with. But even as she thought that, even as she agreed that in her mind, she felt her chest feel hollow with the idea that it could never be more.

That she could touch Agatha but never reach her.

No further through working through her feelings than she had been whilst tossing and turning in the bed the night before, Rio soon pulled up to her little house.

She spotted Alice’s car already parked up a little on the sidewalk and she rolled her eyes at the haphazard nature of it.

Sometimes she wondered how Alice managed to be so diligent and professional when it came to work but so clumsy and unbothered in her real life.

But she had little time to think on it as her own front door was flung open and Alice was there to greet her.

“Dirty stopout,” she proclaimed with a grin.

“Get in here. We don’t have long and I want all the details. Did she talk to you about working together? Was there any chat about-…”

“Alice,” Rio groaned as she stepped over the threshold, “Please. I’ve barely slept I-…”

“No, no. Don’t give me that. You have to work today. Tomorrow and Saturday you have to complain and sleep but this morning you’re working.”

Rio rolled her eyes and threw her bag down as she traipsed through to the kitchen to source coffee.

She idly wondered what Agatha’s coffee of choice would be. Did she get only organic beans? Did she only shop in Erewhon? Probably.

“So, tell me!”

“We mostly spoke about Nicky. And a little about the circuit and-…”

Alice huffed softly but Rio ignored it as she stirred an ungodly amount of sugar into her coffee.

“We watched a movie and then we went to bed.”

“God. Well, the fact that she let you stay is positive. She could have called you a cab and been done with it.”

She nodded and swallowed down the horrifying idea that Agatha could have done just that even after what they’d done together on the couch.

But Alice soon moved onto the topic of her and Jen.

And Rio soon relaxed into the corner of her couch, watching but not really listening to her best friend.

She kept thinking about Agatha.

How she’d felt against her. How she’d looked at her during and afterwards.

How she’d been so soft this morning. How she’d kissed her over and over until she had to pull away. Twice.

And she thought of nothing but Agatha for the rest of the morning. After Alice had finished her romantic tale of how she’d told Jen she loved her and how Jen had said it back. After the costume department descended upon Rio’s little Spanish villa and poked and prodded at her for sizings and colour testing.

And then she was free to be alone for a while.

She showered and changed and decided that she couldn’t sit around and pine for a woman she may never have again. And even if she did, she’d have her only in ways that were physical. And secret.

She took herself off to her gym and threw her thoughts away as she pushed her tired body to the limit of what she could handle.

The text came as Rio was finishing up the workout.

The endorphins she’d sweat for dissolved in her brain and body as she read the words over and over.

She wasn’t an idiot.

She knew what they meant.

2:30pm
Agatha Harkness: Ralph will be home all day tomorrow. Some meetings have come up for me. You can’t come over early. Sorry.

Agatha had changed her mind.

Or maybe it was simply that she’d got what she wanted out of Rio.

And she’d been acting that morning, trying to soften the blow she knew she’d eventually deliver.

She’d had her orgasms, felt what it was to be with a woman, and decided it wasn’t for her.

Or simply that Rio wasn’t.

The only solace Rio could get from the situation was that at least she’d felt the touch of Agatha Harkness.

She was now one of the privileged three people in the world who had been deigned good enough to be inside of her, to hear her moan, to be pressed so close nothing else existed but her.

True to form, she didn’t text back.

Chapter End Notes

Set up that Rio doesn’t answer her text messages just for this lil cliffhanger sorry for that ✌🏻

Chapter 14: Flesh Wounds

Chapter Summary

Rio is made to return to the scene of the crime.

Agatha doesn’t like being ignored.

Chapter Notes

This took me AGES to write but here you go

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The text came as Rio was finishing up the workout.

The endorphins she’d sweat for dissolved in her brain and body as she read the words over and over.

She wasn’t an idiot.

She knew what they meant.

2:30pm
Agatha Harkness: Ralph will be home all day tomorrow. You can’t come over early. Sorry.

Agatha had changed her mind.

Or maybe it was simply that she’d got what she wanted out of Rio.

She’d had her orgasms, felt what it was to be with a woman, and decided it wasn’t for her.

The only solace Rio could get from the situation was that at least she’d felt the touch of Agatha Harkness.

She was now one of the privileged three people in the world who had been deigned good enough to be inside of her, to hear her moan, to be pressed so close nothing else existed but her.

True to form, she didn’t text back.

She spent the rest of the afternoon doing everything she could to not think about Agatha.

She cleaned her house within an inch of its life.

She did her laundry and tidied her clothes away, placing her favourite cowboy shirt in pride of place in her second drawer.

She called her mom and spoke to her for over two hours.

She threw herself into bed at 10pm and took a melatonin to help her drift off.

But the sting of it really settled in when Alice called to ask if she wanted a lift to Agatha’s house on Friday morning.

Alice was excited for the dinner and chatting away about the wine she’d bought especially for the occasion, about the outfit she was wearing because she knew Jen liked it and it wasn’t too smart or too casual.

It reminded Rio of the gifts she’d bought Agatha and Nicky when she went over two days ago.

Her mother’s empanadas and her own basketball jersey.

Sweet. Domestic.

Now a fantasy.

She’d been a fool to think it could be anything but.

Alice hadn’t been right that Agatha didn’t want her at all. But she had been right that if anything were to happen it would be a flash of desire, a quick fuck with no feelings and then nothing.

And Rio would be shunned because Agatha would make it so.

She’d push her from Hollywood because she could and because the fear of people knowing she’d stooped so low as to sleep with a barely-established actress like Rio would be enough to make her burn Rio’s career to the ground.

She could block her from the best producers, the best studios, the best directors.

“Rio?”

Alice asked suddenly, making Rio snap from her doom spiral.

“What? Sorry. I didn’t sleep great.”

“Well snap out of it. Tonight’s important to me. Agatha is Jen’s best friend and I know you two are getting on now but you need to nail this. Not just for me but for your career.”

Rio rolled her eyes but felt her stomach flip as she realised that her stupidity would impact Alice too.

If she were flung from Hollywood then Alice would be right behind her.

And what that meant for hers and Jen’s relationship, she didn’t know.

But Rio hadn’t spoken for a second or two and Alice was already filling the silence.

“Jen floated the idea of a joined project. Of something Agatha was producing. Just an idea still but I think if things keep going well then we might be in there.”

“As in… me and Agatha working together?”

“Yeah. I know she’s Agatha Harkness but you’re hot shit too. Don’t forget that. She’d be a fool to overlook you and the pull you have at the box office.”

Rio sighed and flopped down onto her floral bedspread, toying idly with the soft fabric by her hip.

“Besides in just a couple months time you’ll have an Oscar nomination and-…”

“Wait, wait. Alice.”

Rio took a deep breath and then fell onto her back, staring up at the ceiling as she said: “Has Agatha asked Jen about this? Has she given her some sort of-…”

“She’s optioning a movie and has you in mind for one of the roles, apparently. Don’t get your hopes up. It’s early days but just to say: keep on her good side. Being friendly with Agatha is your ticket to the best this town has to offer.”

Not long after, they hung up.

Rio had long since fallen into a deep depression, and she allowed herself to wallow in it for an hour only.

She timed it precisely. Keeping an eye on the clock on the side to make sure she didn’t slip into hour two of her self-pity party.

But her wallowing brought with it a determination to act, to protect, to reassure.

She couldn’t make Agatha want her. But she could protect Alice. She could ensure Agatha knew she’d protect her too.

And maybe, just maybe, Agatha wouldn’t destroy more than her heart.

Pushing her heartache to the side, Rio focused for the rest of the day on building herself back up to a facsimile of an actress with the world at her feet and the kind of happy-go-lucky attitude she used to carry with her like a permanent badge of pride.

She went to the local market to buy fresh flowers and organic wine. She picked out a dress that was casual enough for a dinner at a friend’s but pretty enough to still look like she’d made an effort. She put on a little more makeup than she usually would, wore more jewellery, wore flattering lipstick and nice shoes.

In short, she did everything she could to look good, so she’d feel good too.

When Alice was outside her door at six, honking impatiently, Rio felt more energised, more ready to face Agatha than she had felt since she received the text.

“Goddamn, Vidal.”

Rio slipped in the car beside Alice and narrowly avoided smacking herself in the face with large bouquet of flowers.

“Pulled out all the stops? Or just got a date after this?”

Rio smirked a little, pleased her choice to dress up had an immediate affect, even if Alice weren’t the intended audience.

“Just wanted to look good for our host.”

Not a lie.

Alice hummed and started the car back up as Rio looked her best friend over with a small smile.

“You look good, superstar. If I didn’t know any better I’d think you were trying to seduce your girlfriend.”

“I’m always trying to seduce Jen. By Sunday we’ll be away again so I need to squeeze in as much seduction as possible.”

“You can stay, you know? If it’s easier? I know you get so bored. And now you have Jen, well, it’s different.”

Alice shot Rio a sideways glance and Rio knew what she was about to say before she even said it: “You need me around. You get lonely.”

“I do not.”

Alice just raised her brows and Rio sighed and turned her head to look out the car window.

“It’s time to find someone.”

“Alice.”

“I mean it. You’re cute and funny and kind and rich and-…”

“Stop.”

“After the Oscar’s. Four more months. I want you to seriously consider getting out there. You’ve not had a proper girlfriend since college.”

“Not true. Victoria was-…”

“You saw her for six months then decided you weren’t in love.”

“And? Still a girlfriend.”

“It was an extended affair.”

Rio rolled her eyes, knowing Alice was right. Victoria had been a warm body who knew how Rio liked to be touched and how to make good coffee and where the best bars were in any city in the world.

But they hadn’t really talked. They hadn’t shared things or welcomed each other into one another’s lives.

It was just convenient. Just easier than having no one.

“Besides,” Alice was continuing, taking Rio’s silence as an invitation to go on.

“I want to see you happy. To see you settled.”

“Don’t lie. You think it’ll be good for the brand.”

“Don’t be a bitch. You’re my friend before you’re my client. I’ve not been this happy in a long time and that’s because of Jen. I want that for you too.”

Rio felt her chest constrict as she thought of what could have been with Agatha.

Was there a universe where Agatha had left Ralph and run away with Rio? Could she have seen herself as a step-mom to Nicky? Would they work longterm? Would Agatha get bored of her or decide a fleeting fantasy of Rio wasn’t as good as the reality?

But then a hand had reached across, and amidst the forest of fresh flowers, Alice had linked their fingers and was squeezing Rio firmly.

“I love you. I want you to be happy. You deserve someone who will make you happy.”

But Rio found she couldn’t respond.

She only squeezed Alice’s hand and tried to funnel into it the acknowledgement of her friend’s care.

They remained silent for the rest of the short journey into the Hills and by the time they arrived Rio had schooled her thoughts again to be ready to act rings around her own emotions.

They traipsed up to the gate and waited for the familiar sound of it unlocking, Rio watching Alice with amusement as she took everything in.

“Holy shit.”

Rio laughed even as the door opened and Agatha appeared in the doorway.

She was in a striped blue and white button down and matching white jeans. She had a pair of glasses on her head and a hardness to her expression that made Rio want to turn and run.

“Agatha!” Alice shouted with a grin, moving towards the woman with a beam and brandishing her wine, “this place is… huge.”

Agatha only smiled tightly, stepping aside to let Alice in and offering only a cursory hug as the smaller woman stepped inside and muttered another, “holy shit”, once she’d seen the inside of the house.

“Ralph and Jen are out back.”

“I’ll put this in the kitchen,” Alice said happily as she slowly stepped away and gazed all around her in awe of what money and taste could produce.

It was Rio’s turn to step up now and she did so with a fear that so clenched her heart she could barely breathe.

But Agatha hadn’t reached for her or even offered the small hug she’d deigned to give Alice.

Her blue eyes were focused on the floor and Rio sucked in a sharp breath at the sight of Agatha’s jaw flexing before her.

The jaw she’d brushed her lips and tongue and teeth across only two nights ago.

“Hi,” she offered softly, turning fully to Agatha in the open doorway, unsure whether or not ignoring her would be a better option.

“I thought it meant more than that,” Agatha said in a venomous whisper that chilled Rio’s very soul.

Agatha moved then, still not exactly looking at her as she made to close the door behind her and Rio had to shift quickly to avoid it closing on her.

“What?”

But Agatha raised her gaze to her and Rio was thunderstruck by what she saw in it.

Agatha looked hurt.

She looked devastated.

“Not glam enough for you? Not fun and sexy with a kid in tow and-…”

“Agatha.”

Rio felt a prickling sense of shame tickle her body, hitting every inch of her with it’s creeping tendrils and it’s insidious promise of pain.

“You called it off.”

But as soon as the words left her lips she could see in them a truth she’d missed before. Perhaps because she’d expected Agatha to call it off. Perhaps because she’d assumed she would or maybe, just maybe, she’d hoped that she’d do it sooner rather than later to save Rio falling more for her.

Agatha’s brows furrowed a little but she still looked just as hurt as before, her face just as taught.

They stared at each other for what felt like a lifetime, and Rio took a step closer even as Agatha took a step back, her body coming into contact with the closed front door behind her.

Agatha took a soft breath.

And Rio had never seen her eyes sparkle like that before.

But it wasn’t something she ever wanted to see again because Agatha was fighting tears.

“Ralph was here. I had meetings. I couldn’t get away and you couldn’t come to me.”

Oh.

Oh.

There was a noise then through in the kitchen that made Agatha’s gaze dart from Rio’s for the first time since she’d looked up, and Rio felt in the absence of it a sudden sinking feeling of panic overwhelm her.

Agatha hadn’t pulled away. Agatha had simply had to change plans.

But now Agatha was walking past her and Rio swallowed thickly where her perfume filled her lungs and she had to fight to remain cognisant of the role she had to play today.

It was different to the one she’d assumed it would be.

She wasn’t a spurned lover.

She was a grovelling one.

She turned to follow Agatha into the kitchen and found Ralph in there with her.

He looked handsome. And Rio felt sick that he was there. In his kitchen. Where he had every right to be when Rio was just there to make up the numbers, to keep Alice company.

He was opening a bottle of red and indulgently sniffing the cork. “Beautiful bouquet on this one.”

Agatha was fetching another glass before placing it on the side, glancing at Rio as she did.

She’d pulled back the tears that had threatened to spill but still looked haunted.

Rio’s nausea increased.

She forced herself to look away and swallowed the sickness down.

“Pinot isn’t for me. Tastes like juice. I prefer a Barolo. Fuller bodied,” Rio said in Ralph’s direction, even as her eyes moved back to Agatha as the woman moved forwards to take her flowers from her.

“Oh no, a Pinot Noir for me. Much lighter. That way you can enjoy the fruits.”

But Rio didn’t much care for Ralph’s opinion on wine, or anything at all for that matter.

Agatha’s hand had just grazed her own when she took the flowers from her and Rio felt her whole body react to it as if she had burned her with a lit match.

“Ralph,” Agatha said as she turned away from Rio, moving to a cabinet to fetch a vase.

“Enough wine talk. Go entertain our guests and top up their glasses. I’ll be out with Rio in a second.”

Ralph didn’t object to this but then Rio supposed he wouldn’t, would he? It was Agatha who was the catch here. Agatha with the millions and the face that could launch a thousand ships.

And Ralph was just a man.

Left alone again, Rio placed the tote bag with the bottle of wine she’d brought on the side and remained silent as she turned her gaze to Agatha who seemed intent on the flowers she was currently arranging.

“You thought I’d had my way with you and were done?”

 

There was a beat of silence and Rio felt the sickness settle in the base of her throat.

“Or maybe you thought I’d changed my mind? I’d faked it and lied to you?”

Agatha’s tone hadn’t softened as she transitioned from instructing Ralph to berating Rio and Rio flinched with it, moving slowly closer.

“I thought-…”

“You could have at least had the decency to tell me. To use your words, Rio. God knows you use them enough any other time. I am not some slut you fuck and then ignore.”

It would have been easier if Agatha had slapped her.

But she persevered, being braver now than she had been when she had assumed Agatha didn’t want her anymore.

She moved close, placing her hand on the island by Agatha’s hip and when she didn’t react or pull away she moved it to her body to get her to turn to her.

Agatha resisted for a second before she did, and Rio felt her heart thrum in her chest when she realised that Agatha wasn’t looking at her but her eyes had gone that same watery way again.

She raised her hand cautiously to cup Agatha’s cheek and lifted her head up to look at her properly.

It was dangerous. Too out in the open.

There would be no good excuse if anyone walked in.

But Rio didn’t care. And Agatha clearly didn’t either.

“I assumed you’d got what you wanted out of me and I didn’t know what to say. But I wanted to come here and let you know that even if that were true, that I’d never tell anyone what happened. You’d always be safe with me.”

“Don’t say things like that,” Agatha breathed softly, as she moved her hands to the collar of Rio’s dress.

“Why not?”

Agatha just shook her head and pulled away, her fingers tightening their hold and then releasing suddenly, and Rio felt like she’d faint as her own hand hovered in the space between them.

“We can’t do this. The other night was a mistake.”

“Agatha, don’t. Please.”

“I got carried away. I wasn’t thinking straight.”

Rio took a sharp breath in and reached back out for Agatha, this time stepping close so she could wrap an arm around her front and reach for her hip.

“Agatha.”

Agatha didn’t pull away, she simply remained standing, her gaze down on one of the daisies hanging limping from the bouquet. She touched it lightly as Rio’s fingers curled more tightly around her hip.

“Don’t.”

“It’s best for both of us,” Agatha said quietly, turning her head to look at Rio who was now just inches away.

And Rio knew she was right, knew she was doing to right thing. And that it was only Agatha who could decide. After all, it was her marriage.

But it hurt. It hurt beyond reason.

She met Agatha’s gaze and saw her blue irises begin to swirl again with unshed tears and she couldn’t believe it when she felt herself nod and pull away.

And Agatha opened her mouth as if to say something but Rio had turned away quickly for fear she’d fall to her knees and grovel if she didn’t.

She made quick strides towards the doors and didn’t turn back to see Agatha watching her.

Outside in the still warm September sun, Rio saw a discarded basketball on the deck and thought of the little boy who must have left it there.

She thought of his smile and his charm that was so like his mother’s.

And the evening she’d spent with both of them. Of the world now completely shut off from her grasp.

And then Ralph came into view, sitting in one of the armchairs and grinning across at Rio as she approached.

She’d been right the first time.

There was none of him in Nicky.

“There she is! Talking shop with my dear wife?”

“Something like that,” Rio said with a sweet smile, feeling the absence of the feel of Agatha against her never more than when she was in the presence of the husband.

“What took you so long?” Alice accused with a frown, her arm draped over Jen’s shoulders on the couch.

“I was helping with the flowers.”

“Jennifer,” Rio added with a smile as she went to sit by Alice’s side, leaving the second armchair free for Agatha.

“Vidal. Always a pleasure, never a chore.”

Rio laughed as she settled in, brushing her dress down over her legs and crossing them demurely.

It was easy to pretend. It was what she was good at.

“Trying to convince my client to star in some crappy chick flick with you?”

Rio raised her brows and tilted her head as Jen watched her suspiciously from the other end of the couch.

“I didn’t know that was an option for polite dinner party conversation. But I’ll be sure to bring it up.”

Jen scoffed and Alice nudged Rio gently even as she raised her brows down at her, wondering if this had anything to do with their phone conversation the previous day.

But Ralph had moved from his seat and was pouring Rio a wine without checking first that she wanted red when there was an open bottle of white that both Alice and Jen were drinking.

She thanked him anyway and took a sip of the Pinot Noir, a testament to her acting skills that she didn’t grimace at the thinness of it.

But she was distracted suddenly because Agatha was approaching, and she caught Rio’s eye.

Rio had to look away for fear she’d dissolve before her.

“Finally, the host!” Jen shouted with a grin, “took you long enough.”

“Actually I’m also the host,” Ralph said suddenly and Rio looked to Agatha’s reaction to this but saw she was too focused on Rio’s red wine, raising her brows at it.

“Sorry, Ralph. Of course. Just used to it being mostly Agatha, is all.”

Agatha had stood from her chair, pouring herself a glass of white before she went to take Rio’s wine without asking and swapped the glasses.

“Rio doesn’t like Pinot Noir.”

Everybody turned to stare at Agatha as Agatha made eyes at Ralph, taking her seat up again.

Rio blinked, her hand now curled around the cold cup of her new wine glass as she watched as Agatha took her seat and sipped at the deep burgundy liquid she’d just stolen away from Rio.

“She didn’t say no.”

Rio’s head snapped in the direction of Ralph and she saw his eyes flash, a challenge to his wife for showing him up. Perhaps also Jen’s dismissal of his position as host getting to him too.

“But she told you in the kitchen she didn’t like it.”

This was more than just about wine.

Rio shifted slightly in her seat and looked back to Agatha, willing her to look her way and drop it.

“It’s just never good enough, is it?”

Rio felt the wind change around them, saw the flash in Agatha’s eyes and the twitch of her fingers against the red of her glass.

Ralph was staring at his wife, his free hand in a fist at his side, his gaze as cold as the wine in Rio’s glass.

“I think we got off topic here,” Jen said suddenly, panic lacing her voice as she sat forward from Alice and cleared her throat.

“Come on! You’re the dream couple! Cute kid, amazing house, both hot. It’s just wine. And Ralph’s right, Agatha. Rio didn’t say no.”

Rio felt this was a little unfair, she’d barely had time to and was being polite either way. Then, she supposed, she wasn’t being exactly polite when she was negotiating an affair with Ralph’s wife not minutes ago in the kitchen.

“You know what?”

Ralph had said suddenly, turning to Rio, “You didn’t say no and you also didn’t say you wanted the white. So we’re all at fault here. Which do you want, Rio?”

Rio knew this was a power play, that he was trying to get her on side, to manipulate her into going for the first choice but even if Agatha had handed her a cup of poison she’d have picked Agatha’s offering over his any day.

“I was being polite before. I don’t like Pinot Noir. I never have. But this,” Rio held up the glass and glanced briefly to Agatha. “This I’d drink any day of the week. Gladly so.”

They locked eyes and Rio thought she saw a flicker of the anguish she’d seen before in Agatha.

But she looked away quickly, unwilling to let herself get sucked in again.

Ralph scoffed and muttered something under his breath that made the atmosphere crackle with something dark and incendiary.

Alice’s hand flew to Rio’s leg and she dug her nails into her, turning her body ever so slightly towards her as if there were something coiled nearby ready to spring and Rio hadn’t seen it yet but she was in the predator’s vision.

Rio glanced at her best friend, saw in her eyes the panic that had caused her to turn to her and raised her brows in question.

But it was clear she’d missed something. That she hadn’t heard what Ralph had said.

But everyone else had.

“Ralph,” Jen had said quietly, shifting her weight ever so slightly forwards.

But Rio looked to Agatha and saw that she looked beyond reason suddenly, beyond any placatory tone that Jen may have used onto try and calm Ralph.

“Get out.”

Rio shifted slightly, Alice’s grip on her upper thigh so tight she thought she’d rip her dress.

“What did you say?”

Rio asked suddenly, wanting to know why everyone was losing it. She dragged her gaze away from Agatha to look at Ralph who still looked furious but who wasn’t looking at anyone in particular, his gaze on the floor.

“Rio,” Alice warned quietly, but Ralph was already speaking again:

“I said: fucking flirt.”

Rio’s brows shot up her forehead and Agatha raised to her feet, repeating what she’d said earlier: “Get out.”

“Surely it’s enough to have your little fan club on set, on the red carpet, but not at my table, convincing my son to swap teams. Flirting with you so openly.”

Rio moved her hand to Alice’s still clutching at her thigh and she went to extricate it gently, and Alice allowed it.

Rio moved cautiously from her position on the couch to stand just behind Agatha and touched her forearm gently, curling her fingers slowly around it, her steady gaze on Ralph who’d turned to watch her move to his wife.

“Agatha, don’t.”

“You need to leave.”

Ralph didn’t move, his eyes briefly dropping to Rio’s hold on Agatha before he raised his gaze again and looked across at his wife.

He watched her for a second and Rio could only guess the coldness in Agatha’s eyes, but she remained where she was just behind her, her fingers tightening ever so slightly on Agatha’s arm.

“I’m not homophobic,” Ralph said suddenly, sounding an awful lot like a homophobic person might.

“I don’t care that you’re gay. Or that you clearly have a crush on my wife.”

His gaze dropped down to Rio’s hand on Agatha’s arm again and Rio briefly wondered if he knew the fingers now clutching his wife’s arm had been inside of her if he’d change his mind on not caring about her crush.

He seemed to think on it, and his shoulders dropped a little.

“I was just getting back at you with the wine for Nicky, that’s all. He hasn’t taken the jersey off since he got it.”

Rio raised her brows at this, wondering why he was so concerned about this when he’d barely acknowledged his son a couple days ago.

But Agatha beneath her hand was still tense and so Rio shoved down her instincts to tell this guy to fuck off and to be a better dad if someone who’d known his kid all of one day could overtake him in the rankings. She swallowed thickly and squeezed Agatha’s arm as she said: “It’s fine. I’ve been called worse.”

“And,” she started slowly as Agatha shifted, “I don’t have a crush on your wife. I actually find her very smug and annoying and,” she paused as she felt Agatha’s arm flex beneath her hand, making her second guess her choice but she had to say it, had to do it for the sake of keeping the peace as well as letting Agatha know she’d keep their tryst safe, “and she’s not my type at all.”

Rio could feel both Alice and Jen looking at her and she saw Ralph do the same, but the only reaction she really cared about was Agatha’s, though she only had the gentle second flex of her arm to go by.

“Well I’m sorry,” Ralph said a little stiffly, and Rio wondered whether he was simply uncomfortable with the conversation of a lesbian’s preferences in women, if he wanted to get back to drinking his disgusting wine, or if he wanted to be thought of as the host again, take back the power that Agatha had so swiftly gathered for herself.

Rio only nodded once, not offering her forgiveness back and squeezed Agatha’s arm gently before she returned to her seat.

Silence descended on the little group again as Rio watched Agatha sit down, her face as angry still as she’d ever seen it.

It was touching, really, a display of protectiveness she would never have expected from Agatha.

Especially not now.

Or maybe it was something else. A self-preservation. A defensiveness.

And she didn’t take her eyes off of her until Agatha looked back up to her and Rio lost her nerve and looked away.

“Anyway,” Jen said quickly, still sitting on the edge of the couch where Alice had now stolen Rio’s free hand and was holding it hidden down against her own hip, looking a little shell shocked.

“Rio. Details. Industry crushes. Go!”

Rio raised her brows at this and cleared her throat quietly, squeezing Alice’s hand reassuringly before stealing her own away again.

“Now that would be telling.”

“Oh come on,” Jen said with her own raised brows and a look that said to Rio: ‘please keep the conversation going’.

“Okay,” Rio relented, but only to get the conversation flowing again. She panicked and her mind went blank suddenly and she stared at Jen like she’d never been asked a question before in her life.

“Wanda,” Alice added quickly, nudging Rio’s thigh, “Wanda. You like Wanda.”

“Yes, but-…”

Rio cleared her throat quietly, realising there was no point protesting when she had to come up with a name anyway and Alice had just done that for her.

“Wanda. Right.”

“The redhead?” Ralph asked curiously and Rio turned to him and nodded, feeling suddenly a little disloyal to Wanda and a whole lot disloyal to Agatha.

Despite what they’d just agreed in the kitchen.

But Ralph looked totally at ease again as if he hadn’t just insulted his guest and pissed off his wife.

Which infuriated Rio.

“She’s cute,” Jen was saying, which meant Rio had a chance to glance at Agatha who looked as if she’d just swallowed a very large pill as she drank down the last of her wine.

“She’s maybe going to be the only nomination for A24 this year. Sad, really. They had so much promise and just fucked it on all their marketing. Though the movie wasn’t great either.”

Agatha was staring at the table between them.

“We’re negotiating a little Christmas movie at the minute. Some big names attached, actually. Calderu, Kaplan, Maximoff, it’s an ensemble.”

“Oh god,” Jen scrunched her face up but Rio missed it, her gaze on Agatha still.

“Not the cancer one?”

“That’s it!”

“Cancer at Christmas. It’s poignant.”

“It’s crap. They sent it to Agatha but I passed immediately. Who’s Rio playing? Not part of the family surely? They’re all white.”

Before Alice could answer Agatha spoke for the first time since her last attempt to get Ralph to leave and she said, “Excuse me, I’ll be right back.”

Rio met Agatha’s gaze for a split second before she’d turned and left.

Her anger had morphed into something else, something that made Rio shift in her seat.

There was a pause and then Ralph followed her down and Rio didn’t turn away until they’d both disappeared into the house.

“Jesus, Rio. Are you okay?”

Alice turned to her immediately and placed her hand on her leg over where she’d been holding her so tightly earlier.

“He gets wound up,” Jen said softly, looking over at Rio with a gentle frown, “they both do. I tell Agatha she just needs to have sex with him more and they’ll be fine.”

Rio wondered if Jen knew how much sex Agatha were actually having with her husband but felt it best to not broach the topic.

“I’m fine.”

“I’m telling you, usually if things like that happen she screams at him until she runs out of breath. It was impressive, how you handled her.”

“I didn’t ‘handle’ her. I just…”

But Rio wasn’t really sure what she did and so she went quiet and took a sip of her wine.

“How she’s married to him, I don’t know.” Alice said with a deep frown as she turned in the direction Agatha and Ralph had disappeared to.

Jen sighed quietly, “Look, if it works it works, okay? He’s usually away and so is she and… anyway, her and Nicky are very happy.”

‘Happily married’, Rio thought bitterly.

“I saw a photo of him on the wall,” Alice said absently, swirling her wine, her frown still across her features, “he doesn’t look like Ralph.”

“Are you suggesting Agatha had an affair?”

“No, just, I thought he looked like Rio, actually.”

Rio blinked across at Alice and stared at her for longer than would be considered polite.

“Pardon?”

“Well he’s got dark eyes and a goofy smile and big buck teeth.”

“I do not have big buck teeth.”

Alice ignored this.

“Plus he’s a little tan and I just thought… yeah, there’s Rio’s kid.”

“That is-…”

“Now you mention it, it’s not that crazy,” Jen said with a frown, staring into Rio’s face as if she were mapping out what features of hers Nicky had stolen.

“Actually, not at all. Sure he’s not yours and Agatha didn’t just steal him?”

“I-…”

But a sudden movement from down the way alerted them to Agatha marching back up to them and Rio forgot all about their conversation as she entered the little secluded veranda.

“Ralph’s taking a work call.”

Rio didn’t believe this, and neither did the other two if their expressions were anything to go by.

“Agatha,” Jen said with a smile, “we were just saying-…”

But she lost her train of thought as Agatha, instead of taking her chair back again, stood before Rio and hovered awkwardly there, earning a frown from Jen and raised brows from Rio.

“I’m sorry.”

Rio shook her head slightly, frowning up at Agatha who was almost leaning over her.

The look she’d noticed before hadn’t been sadness, it had been longing.

“It’s fine. He didn’t mean it.”

But Agatha pursed her lips and slowly pulled away, reaching to fill everyone’s glasses with the right wine.

Jen cleared her throat and started again: “Agatha, we were saying how much Nicky looks like Rio.”

A soft sound of glass on glass rang out as Agatha accidentally knocked the lip of the bottle on Rio’s wine glass.

“Well….”

“What do you mean ‘well’?”

Rio blinked across at Agatha and watched as she slowly turned to look up at her, “Well… he does.”

“What?”

Alice snorted beside her and Rio turned to slap her, “I’m sorry? Is everyone listening to themselves? Your son doesn’t look like me.”

“I mean, he does,” Jen said with an unhelpful grin.

“He does a little,” Agatha said with a smile that made Rio soften to it just a little, the memory of what Agatha had told her two nights ago making her chest suddenly feel warm.

“Big eyes, sallow skin, goofy teeth.”

“And since when have I had goofy teeth?”

Even Agatha laughed a little at this and despite Rio’s outrage, she couldn’t help but be pleased they were all laughing now, all at ease without Ralph there.

Prick.

So she played it up a little, shooting for the rafters with a performance that would have killed in any theatre up and down the country.

“Poor me, being told I have goofy teeth and look like a little boy.”

“Hey!” Agatha said with a small smile that had taken the edge off of her sad eyes, sitting back more in her seat to enjoy this little performance, “a very cute little boy.”

Rio rolled her eyes and huffed heavily, receiving a nudge from Alice.

“At least you don’t need to bother having a kid now. Technically you already had one.”

“Oh, thanks.”

“I’m not sure Rio is the family type,” Jen said with a smirk, “given the amount of women she runs through.”

Jen turned her attention to Agatha, “Alice was telling me when she moved into her new house it was a new one every night for a week.”

“Jesus, Jen. Some discretion please.” Alice said suddenly, clearly concerned Rio’s penchant for running through girls would put Agatha off associating with her.

Agatha’s gaze was still on Rio and it had softened a little, the laughter in her face gone as she took her in, and Rio blushed a little bit didn’t turn away.

That was then, she thought. She’d never touch another woman for as long as she lived if Agatha asked her not to.

But she hadn’t. She wouldn’t.

It was none of Agatha’s concern what she’d do.

“I’m not saying it’s bad. I just think it’s not for Rio.”

“She was good with him,” Agatha said suddenly, breaking their gaze as she turned to Jen and Rio saw the sadness return in her. “Really good. Ralph’s right to be jealous about that. Nicky loved her. He doesn’t light up like that with his father.”

“I’m sure I was just new and exciting, that’s all.”

Agatha looked back to Rio and raised her brows at this show of modesty, tilting her head a little, “He’s not like that with most people. Anyone else, actually.”

“He likes me,” Jen protested with a frown.

“You scare him.”

“Oh. Because I wore a red light mask around him one time.”

Rio scoffed out a laugh and Alice grinned at her girlfriend. “You did not.”

“Good skin care waits for no one.”

Agatha rolled her eyes and Rio caught her eye. For a second, it was just the two of them again and Rio felt like moving over, taking Agatha’s hand and draping herself across her lap, curling around her.

She felt like asking her if she’d change her mind.

But Alice nudging her brought her back to real life and she turned with raised brows.

“Isn’t that right?”

“What?”

“Plan: get Vidal a girlfriend.”

“Not this again. Alice.”

“Oh, shut up. It’s just us.”

Rio rolled her eyes and felt her cheeks flush under Agatha’s intense gaze.

“Rio is going to get herself a girlfriend as soon as the awards season is done. She needs one. She’s getting old and lonely and it’s sad.”

Rio made a noise between a squeal and a scoff and slapped Alice’s arm. “Says the woman two months older than me who only just got a girlfriend.”

“That’s different.”

“How?”

“I was never lonely.”

“I am not lonely.”

“Tell us again how many women you had over the first week in your new place?”

Rio narrowed her eyes around at Jen and attempted to lean around Alice to slap her arm but Alice nudged her away with ease.

“So,” Jen said as if she hadn’t been interrupted. “How do you plan on getting this girlfriend?”

Rio turned slowly to Agatha and was surprised to see that she looked a little spaced.

“I’m not. I’m just going to-…”

“Start texting people back, firstly,” Alice said with a grin.

Rio rolled her eyes but caught Agatha’s arched brow and huffed a little, “I’m busy.”

“I think if you want a girlfriend Alice is right. You have to text people back.”

Rio blinked as Agatha looked back around to her and she suddenly wanted to scream. She suddenly wanted to shout at Agatha and tell her that it wouldn’t have mattered anyway because Agatha wasn’t interested.

But she didn’t. She couldn’t.

She dropped her gaze.

Agatha took a slow sip of her disgusting wine and inclined her head a little.

“I know if it were me you were trying to date then I would appreciate a text back.”

Pushing it, Rio thought with a scowl.

“I think you’ve forgotten I don’t have a crush on you. So you don’t need to worry about me trying to date you. I’m not interested.”

Rio looked up then and caught a flash of emotion in Agatha’s gaze. A glimmer of hurt. Or of triumph. She wasn’t sure.

But Agatha hummed even as Alice piped up again and Rio began to wonder at what point her best friend had turned into a traitor.

“Oh, I’m afraid that’s a lie too.”

“Alice.”

“Oh you’re friends now. Ralph’s not here. Agatha, Rio does have a crush on you. She was all worried about it for a while but has calmed down now. I think seeing you in a bikini in Italy freaked her-…”

But Rio had slapped her friend’s arm and Jen was laughing beside her.

“Oh I think it’s clear she’s only interested in one thing. Right, Rio?”

Agatha asked softly and Rio heard the accusation in her tone and felt it deep within her bones.

She wanted to scream again.

Instead she sucked in her cheeks and watched as Agatha’s gaze fell from her, sweeping down to her hand that held the wine she’d given her and remaining there.

“But maybe Wanda doesn’t mind you picking up a different girl every night of the week.”

Rio bristled, not quite believing what Agatha was accusing her of. That she’d even suggest what she thought she was suggesting.

She turned away, deciding not to give Agatha the satisfaction.

Agatha had gone from furious to soft and then repeated the pattern again.

And Rio couldn’t get a grasp on it.

Agatha didn’t want her and yet she was pushing her further away when Rio had already agreed she’d step back, that it had been a mistake that wouldn’t be repeated.

From the corner of her eye she saw Agatha knock back her glass of wine.

“What are you guys doing?” Jen asked suddenly, lowering her wine glass from her lips and frowning deeply at the two of them.

“The vibes are off.”

Rio raised her brows and flexed her jaw, unable to steady her racing heart and the anger that threatened to spill over.

“They’re just teasing, aren’t you, Rio?” Alice asked suddenly and Rio heard the pleading in her voice and looked around at her, managing only a quick nod.

But she couldn’t give anything else because her brain was going a mile a minute.

Agatha clearly thought she’d used her. A quick fuck and she was done.

How she’d come to that conclusion Rio had no idea but she couldn’t pry now.

She just had to silently take what she threw at her and focus on getting through the evening.

She could do it. She could do it for Alice.
