She threw herself into her packing, deciding she couldn’t sleep in the soiled sheets and allowing only herself one indulgence of pressing her face into the pillow where Agatha had laid her head.

But she knew she had to move on. Get on. Get over.

It took until the late evening for the final straw in her bad afternoon and Rio found herself sat in a pile of folded clothes and two open suitcases crying over her lost favourite shirt.

She’d spent the last hour tearing the house apart trying to find it, certain that she’d recently washed it and put it away in the second drawer of her dresser.

But she couldn’t find it anywhere.

Unwilling to give up until she saw that the clock had struck 11pm and she would feel Alice’s wrath in the morning if she slept in or was less than chirpy on their early flight, she’d simply disintegrated where she sat, sobbing for a lost shirt with little cowboys with their flying lassos on it.

And Alice wouldn’t understand because she hated the shirt.

And Alice wouldn’t understand that it wasn’t just the shirt she was crying over.

Chapter End Notes

Agatha good with the physical not so good with the emotional

Talking will happen soon I promise you

Also apologies for Spanish: google translate is to blame if it’s awful

Chapter 16: YYZ - BOS

Chapter Summary

Rio has a realisation.

Chapter Notes

Loving that everyone is pissed at Jen and Alice

That might continue for a while but… you’ll have to keep reading

See the end of the chapter for more notes

It turns out that a good way to get over heartbreak is to be so busy that you can barely think.

A month went by and Rio had no time at all to think about Agatha.

To think about how they’d left it.

About how unhappy Agatha was in her marriage.

About how badly she wanted to see her, talk to her, touch her.

Setlife was the same as it always was. Rio was number one on the call sheet and so had to set a precedent which meant no flirting with extras, being earlier than anyone else to the set, knowing all of her lines and marks off by heart.

Which meant that her days off were mostly spent sleeping.

She was horizontal almost every hour she could be.

And not in any fun way.

In fact, she’d not slept with anyone since Agatha. And a month of no sex was longer than Rio had ever gone before. But even if she had the time or the energy she wouldn’t be interested.

Why settle when she’d had the best?

Even Alice was worried for her.

But Rio ignored the concerns of her best friend and focused on doing a good job, and on not worrying about a woman thousands of miles away with a husband.

Which was made ever so slightly easier because Rio hadn’t heard from Agatha since that last morning spent pressed together in her bedroom.

Any spare time she had she spent making sure to call her parents. Ever since she’d been embarrassed by the care package they’d sent to Alice she was now diligent about speaking to them every week.

And in all honesty, it made her feel better. It made her feel normal.

Only one night, about six weeks into the shoot, she’d plugged her headphones into her cell to make the call and she was chatting away about something a cousin of hers had done when her attention was stolen away by something else.

“…and I just said to your tía…”

Agatha had text her.

Rio had been so distracted by the name that appeared in the modal at the top of her screen as she’d idly being scrolling Instagram - and only vaguely listening to her mother - that she’d forgotten to read the message preview.

“…he’s just always been such a good boy, un ángel…”

Rio swallowed thickly, only now vaguely aware that in her little house in Delaware Anna Vidal was happily chatting into her phone thinking her beloved child was paying attention.

She flicked out of Instagram and clicked into WhatsApp.

There on the Home Screen, right at the top of the list of her chats with coworkers or old friends, was Agatha’s name, the message and a little green ‘1’.

“…I have no idea how he gets away with it now…”

Rio clicked into it to expand it properly.

7:34pm
Agatha Harkness: I thought you’d be pleased to know that I’m taking Nicky to his first Celtics game next weekend.

Rio stared at it.

“… if you were doing anything like this dios mío…”

Agatha had reached out. Agatha was telling her her plans. Agatha was going to be much closer to Rio in just over a week.

And Rio had learnt her lesson now.

She’d first not text Agatha back for three days and regretted it.

Then she’d not text her back at all and regretted that even more.

“… anyway, your father was saying that he once knew…”

Rio sucked in a breath as she sent her response, knowing it was risky, knowing that it could be potentially embarrassing.

7:35pm
Rio Vidal: Can I come?

“…that niña encantadora…”

7:36pm
Agatha Harkness: I’ll buy you a ticket.

Rio’s heart leapt in her chest and she stared at her phone, unsure what had just happened and knowing only that next weekend she’d be seeing Agatha again.

And that Agatha wanted her there.

She wanted to see her.

“…mija?”

Rio was too busy staring down at Agatha’s last text that her mum had to repeat herself three times before she heard her.

“God, mom. Sorry. I’m so tired. Can I call you back tomorrow?”

There was a beat of silence and then Anna Vidal said in a softer tone, “Are you eating well? Do you need me to send anything?”

“No, mom. I love you. I’ll call tomorrow.”

“Okay, mija. I love you too.”

Rio hung up with a click of the button on the wire and went right back to staring at her phone screen.

She went through all the possible response she could think of and eventually settled on:

7:41pm
Rio Vidal: In exchange I’ll buy you a jersey.

7:42pm
Agatha Harkness: What would John Smith say?

Rio grinned at her phone like she were fifteen and her crush were online.

Turns out six weeks thinking she was safe from Agatha’s gravitational pull were just a delusion.

She had her in her orbit.

She chewed on her lip and her thumbs danced over the keypad before she eventually tapped out:

7:44pm
Rio Vidal: Hard to know what imaginary men might say. But the very real Agatha Harkness should thank me.

It was pushing things towards flirty perhaps, but not overstepping so much that Agatha couldn’t either shut it down or pull it right back.

7:45pm
Agatha Harkness: I’ve booked you a suite at The Langham. Is that thanks enough?

Rio couldn’t believe it. She wanted to reach through the phone to get to Agatha.

To pull her through it and have her here with her.

But she tempered her thoughts with the reminder that this wasn’t a private trip.

That anywhere Agatha went - particularly a big basketball game - she would be photographed.

And more than that, her seven year old son would be there.

Both things meant no subtle touches, no sly hand holds, no yearning looks.

And Rio could handle it because they’d agreed: they’d made a mistake, made it now properly, and it wouldn’t happen again.

But she was fucked now.

For the rest of the week all she’d be able to think about was the fact that she’d soon be back in the presence of Agatha. Soon be able to talk to her, to see if she missed her, to see if she still wanted her.

7:52pm
Rio Vidal: I’ll let you know when I see you.

7:54pm
Agatha Harkness: Nicky’s excited already.

7:55pm
Rio Vidal: Are you?

Rio put her phone down then. Ripped her headphones from her ears. Buried her face in her hands.

 

She’d slipped up already.

She took long slow breaths and had to remind herself that she was talking to the woman who broke into her house, who touched her leg whilst sitting just feet away from her husband, who cheated with her not once, but twice.

It would be insane for Agatha to have bought her a ticket and a hotel suite and to not be excited.

But the question felt exposing anyway.

It felt incredibly vulnerable to ask.

She waited until she could catch her breath again before she checked her phone.

8:01pm
Agatha Harkness: I don’t care for basketball.

Rio had to roll her eyes, had to huff a little at the response. Because surely Agatha knew what she’d been asking.

With Agatha’s refusal to play ball she pushed a little, because she couldn’t help it now, deciding that she could no longer run anymore. She couldn’t just lay down and let Agatha fuck her physically and emotionally.

8:03pm
Rio Vidal: I’m excited to see you.

Rio didn’t receive a text back after that. Not for five minutes. Not for ten. Not for twenty or even an hour.

She’d moved on, she had to. She’d gone to cleanse her face and get ready for bed.

She’d pulled her script out of her bag and was settling down for the night to force the lines into her Agatha-centric brain when the next text came through.

9:17pm
Agatha Harkness: We’ll see you Saturday at the hotel. Reception will have my room under John Smith. I’ll let them know you’re coming so you can come find us. Have a good week. X

Rio read and reread the message.

She read it so many times she memorised it like it were one of her lines that she was yet to even partially commit to memory.

She read it in her own voice, in Agatha’s voice, in the voice she hoped Agatha would use when she said it.

She felt the whispered words on her temple, on her cheek, on her lips, she felt it against her breast, over her ribs, between her thighs.

She didn’t respond to it. Not out of habit but out of necessity. She couldn’t respond to something that she didn’t know how to.

Perhaps a ‘thank you’ or a ‘cool see you then’ would work or perhaps a ‘great I’ll be thinking about it every second until I’m with you again’.

She put her phone down on the side and returned to her script.

The words were ephemera to her. The meaning behind them lost on her as she tried to focus in.

By 11pm she gave up. Deciding a quick run through in the makeup chair with Alice would be the best bet.

Sleep eluded her too.

But by morning, as tired as she was, she felt a little more sane.

Agatha didn’t have to agree to her coming. Hell, Agatha didn’t even have to tell her they were going. Agatha could have gone with Ralph, could not have gone at all.

And yet she was taking her son, the one she said she had because of Rio, the one she said looked like Rio, to see Rio’s favourite team play. And she’d told Rio about it.

Made the arrangements so Rio could join them.

Perhaps have dinner with them.

It’d be like a field trip into family life. A life with Agatha.

“Rio,” Alice said sharply, snapping her fingers in front of Rio’s face - an annoying habit she’d picked up from time spent with Jen - “snap out of it. You need to nail these lines.”

Rio sighed from her position in her makeup chair, earning her a gentle squeeze on the shoulder from the woman currently adjusting the curl of her front layers.

She glanced up and shared a soft smile with her before she focused back in on the script.

She had just over two hours before she was due to shoot her first scene. Which was usually more than enough time to get lines into her brain.

“Amply sufficient,” her dad would have called it.

By some miracle, the time taken was enough for her.

She managed to squeeze the lines into her full brain and by the time she was on her mark she was Rio Vidal the actress again, not Rio Vidal the lovelorn.

The day went smoothly after that, with the only interruptions being from Alice telling her about some interview she had lined up later that evening over the phone.

And soon Agatha was pushed to the back of Rio’s mind, protected under lock and key so Rio could focus on being a person again.

Someone who took charge of the set and its culture with a gentle hand and genuine enthusiasm for what they were doing.

With the weekend approaching Rio decided not to tell Alice what she was doing or where she was going. Alice was flying off to see Jen on the Friday night anyway so Rio felt no real desire to stress her out by letting her know her plans.

So she arrived in Boston with zero fanfare, a Celtics cap on her head, a light button down hiding the Celtics branded T-shirt she wore and a heavy oversized blazer that only just protected her from the chill of the October temperatures.

She was recognised by the flight attendant on the way over and the woman sitting beside her on the plane.

Both were polite. Both left her alone after whispered mentions of their being fans.

By the time Rio got to the hotel she was in a good mood, practically vibrating with the prospect of seeing Agatha, and excited even to see the littlest boy with the biggest smile.

She checked in, and found that the staff knew to expect her and so told her before she even had to ask where Agatha was.

Or John Smith, as she’d labelled herself.

The concierge took Rio to her floor, showed her to her suite, and pointed out that Agatha’s was just down the corridor from her.

Tipping the concierge generously before she was left alone, she went to drop her bag by her bed and straighten herself out in the bathroom.

She applied more lipstick, ruffled her hair slightly, and liberally sprayed more perfume on herself.

It was pointless to pretend she didn’t want to look good for Agatha.

Once satisfied that she looked good enough she went to sort her bags, finding in her suitcase the plastic bag branded with a Sports Store logo, containing the gifts she’d bought for Agatha and Nicky.

With her bag and her courage raised, she left her suite to go and knock on the door of Agatha’ suite.

The door opened not ten seconds after Rio had knocked and for the first time in over a month Rio found herself face to face with Agatha.

She looked just breathtaking. Casual. Happy.

“You came.”

“You thought I wouldn’t?”

Rio raised her brows slightly and wondered why Agatha always suspected she wouldn’t show up when she said she would.

But she had no time at all to dwell on it as gentle hands found her hips and she felt a kiss against her cheek.

“I hope you’re prepared for a very excited little boy.”

Rio smiled a little and felt a strange kind of calm as Agatha pulled her into the room, her hand now curled around her blazer still as she shut the door behind her.

This Agatha was different to the one she’d left behind in her bedroom. She seemed relaxed and more at peace and Rio wondered if it was because she was away with Nicky or being in a new city, or maybe, just maybe she hoped it might be because Rio had asked to come along.

“I told you I was excited too.”

Agatha hummed quietly and Rio had to resist the urge to kiss her as her hand slipped away and the sounds of another person entering the room came into Rio’s conscious.

Agatha turned and Rio looked over to see Nicky sporting her jersey and smiling where he had a chocolate bar in his hand and evidence that he’d been enjoying it smeared across his mouth.

Rio laughed at the sight and Agatha muttered, “Don’t encourage him.”

“Hey, kid,” Rio said, ignoring Agatha’s comments as she moved around to Nicky and held up her bag of goodies.

“You got some chocolate, riiiiiiight,” she raised her hand to point it out and smiled widely, “there.”

Nicky wiped at it hurriedly but Rio didn’t seem much concerned about it so neither was he. His eyes were on the bag anyway.

“So, in honour of your first game, I wanted to make sure you had the right fit.”

“Okay,” Nicky said quietly, his serious expression returning as he stared at Rio.

Agatha moved over behind them and perched on the edge of the table beside where Rio had now crouched down to be more level with Nicky.

She rifled through the bag for a few seconds before she pulled out a cap that matched the one she had attached to her small cross body bag.

“Here,” she placed it carefully on Nicky’s head and smiled at the sight of it.

“Goes perfectly with your jersey.”

Nicky looked up to see the underside of the cap’s lip and Rio shot Agatha a quick glance to see she was smiling at her, and Rio felt weak for it.

But Nicky had already moved forwards to hug Rio, clumsily smashing his cap into her shoulder and just about holding his chocolate bar away so it didn’t smush into her white shirt beneath her blazer.

“You’re welcome,” Rio said softly, to the silent thank you, squeezing the little boy gently before releasing him and watching with a laugh as he turned to his mother and proudly held his head high with his new cap.

“Gorgeous!” Agatha proclaimed with a grin, playfully grasping the lip of the cap and shaking it to make Nicky laugh.

Rio watched the two of them for a second until she reached back into the bag and produced the next gift.

“But wait, we need to make sure your mom doesn’t embarrass us.”

She held up a brand new Celtics jersey and beamed at Agatha who looked suddenly less than thrilled and rolled her eyes.

“I don’t need to wear it.”

“You do, mama!”

Rio laughed and turned it over with a wink, “It has your name and everything.”

This seemed to soften Agatha’s resolve a little but she still eyed it suspiciously, “Why four?”

Rio shrugged and cleared her throat, standing suddenly so that she could shake off the question and hold out the jersey to Agatha.

“You have to wear it.”

Agatha narrowed her eyes up at Rio but took it and held it up for herself, and Rio just knew she was playing the part of a reluctant fan when really she’d soon give in and would wear the jersey - if not for Rio, at least for Nicky.

“Mama,” Nicky said suddenly and both women looked down to the little boy who was motioning to Rio with an unsubtle movement of his head.

Agatha rolled her eyes but stood swiftly and bundled the light fabric of her gift in one hand, using the other to snake around Rio’s waist and pull her in for a hug just as her son had just done, only this time it wasn’t as clumsy.

“Thank you,” she murmured so close to Rio’s ear that Rio had to fight for her life not to shiver at it in front of Agatha’s little boy.

She returned the hug loosely, fearful she’d cling on.

But Agatha was already pulling away and her hand fell back down to the fabric of Rio’s blazer to hold her in place as she turned to Nicky.

“Go wash your face and we’ll leave soon, okay?”

Nicky nodded and scampered off only to have Agatha call after him: “No running!”

Rio laughed until Agatha turned back to her and she softened suddenly, her smile still present but tempered by the expression on Agatha’s face.

“I am not wearing this.”

“Why not? You don’t want to upset your precious Lakers?”

Agatha’s grip tightened a little on Rio’s blazer and Rio’s smile began to grow again.

“I don’t wear sports jerseys.”

“Think it’ll damage your brand?”

“No, I-…”

“Because if you ask me, attending a game with your son and another actress with just as much chance of winning the Oscar as you but not joining in will look much worse.”

“Just as much chance?”

“You know it.”

Agatha narrowed her eyes and her gaze dropped briefly to Rio’s grin before she pulled away and released her hold on her blazer.

“Fine. Fine.”

And Rio almost choked on nothing as Agatha pulled her shirt over her head and stood just in a lacy black bra.

She took her time unfurling the jersey and Rio used that time to stare at her breasts, remembering how they felt in her hands, in her mouth, pressed up against her.

“You’re staring,” Agatha pointed out, as if she weren’t going painfully slow to make sure Rio would.

But she was tragically covered again, only Rio couldn’t help but think she somehow looked better this way. The loose jersey showed off Agatha’s toned arms and Rio stared at the way it hung.

She’d never much thought about the look of a jersey before, about the way it could sit on a beautiful woman.

But suddenly she found herself practically salivating and she knew she was staring but she couldn’t help it.

And then hands were on her arms and Agatha had stepped closer, “Something on your mind?”

Rio’s jaw flexed, her fingers twitching at her sides, desperate to reach out and touch but unwilling to give herself an inch for fear she’d take a mile.

“No. No. Just excited for the game.”

“Hmm.”

Agatha pulled away just as Nicky appeared in the room again, looking significantly less messy than he had before.

Brushing off her inappropriate lust for a married mother of one, Rio unattached her own cap from her bag and placed it on her head, receiving a shy grin from Nicky as she did so.

“Twins,” Agatha announced with a wry smile in Rio’s direction that she rolled her eyes at.

“Let’s go, it’s good to get there early so-…”

But she’d stepped towards the door and Agatha held her arm out to stop her, “I should maybe have explained first.”

Something like fear settled in Rio’s stomach and she stared with raised brows at Agatha, watching as the woman before her glanced at Nicky and then looked back to her.

“I’ve hired security,” she lowered her voice a little and Rio looked around to see Nicky now slipping his cap off to admire it as he waited by the couch.

“Just one guy and a driver. I took Nicky to a show on broadway last year and it got pretty intense.”

Rio turned slowly to look back at Agatha and nodded, understanding that whilst she were famous to some, Agatha was famous to all. And the chances of fans being subtle about seeing her out with her son were next to zero.

“Okay,” she said softly, “that’s fine.”

She frowned a little when Agatha continued to watch her and it took a second for her to clock why she was still being watched.

She glanced at Nicky to make sure he wasn’t paying attention and stepped closer, leaning in until she could feel the warmth of Agatha’s cheek just millimetres from her own. “I’ll keep it friendly. No one will see anything that-…”

“I’m not worried about that,” Agatha said quietly, turning her head a little to catch Rio’s gaze again. “I know you will. I just want to make sure you’re prepared.”

Rio frowned but nodded slowly, feeling a sense of foreboding at the way Agatha was looking at her but unsure how else she could calm her concerns.

Only Agatha was moving away again to pick up her jacket and Rio felt her excitement transform into nerves. She wouldn’t think twice about going to a game usually. Sure, there’d be paps. There’d be people trying to get her attention, get selfies, get her to send a video to their friend, but nothing she’d ever consider dangerous.

But where Rio was known, Agatha was infamous.

And Nicky, well he was just a little boy.

Rio followed the little family out of the suite, stood beside them in the elevator, answered all of Nicky’s shy questions about the team, about the best players, about the snacks his mom said he could have with as much enthusiasm as she could muster when she was thinking about what they’d be facing when they exited the hotel.

They arrived in the lobby to zero fanfare but a tall man in dark clothing approached and nodded once at Rio and Agatha and Rio felt her shoulders fall in relief.

No one would be getting past this wall of a man.

Still, she kept close to the other two as they moved through the open space. But through the revolving doors she saw a little of what Agatha had tried to warn her of.

“You’re kidding,” she uttered softly, but Agatha caught it and glanced at her, her hand tight in Nicky’s.

“I told you.”

“How do they know you’re here? They weren’t here earlier.”

“They’ll know I’m going to the game. It’s staff, usually. Anyone with eyes to see me arrive, who saw Nicky’s jersey.”

Rio scowled and swallowed down her disgust that someone would scurry to the press to tell them that a lone woman and her young son were easy pickings for press photos.

“Nicky,” she said quickly, as they were approaching the doors, “can you hold my hand?”

The boy was frowning and Rio saw that Agatha had turned to look as he took Rio’s hand and she held his left in her left, falling into step behind them so she could guard them from behind.

Agatha shot her what she thought was a grateful smile but Rio couldn’t return it, feeling her blood boil at the audacity of these men primed and ready and already snapping photos of them through the glass.

Two concierges and the hired security moved forwards first to battle out a route to the waiting SUV and Rio moved her free hand to Nicky’s shoulder to trap him safely between herself and Agatha.

“Keep your head down, Nicky. Your mom and I will be right here.”

She straightened from where she’d bent to whisper to the boy and moved when the other two did, striding forwards with her head down and her eyes on Nicky as Agatha’s name was shouted from all angles.

She heard her own too.

But she heard Nicky’s as well and she wanted to punch the throat of whichever man felt it appropriate to try and get the attention of the scared little boy behind his mother.

The barrage lasted no more than ten seconds, with the security and hotel staff able to keep the worst of it at bay and direct Agatha, Nicky, and Rio into the back of the truck.

Rio caught her breath as she watched Agatha check on her son, her blue eyes wide and full of concern as she brushed her thumbs over the boy’s cheeks and watched him until he settled against her and she tucked him under her arm.

Rio had to look away, her whole body vibrating with fury that a simple trip to a game couldn’t be normal for Agatha and her son and she found herself flinching when a gentle hand touched her arm.

“Rio.”

Rio didn’t look over and clenched her jaw as she stared out of the window, relieved they were driving now, that she’d have five minutes to calm down before she’d have to face it again.

“Honey.”

Rio looked then, surprised Agatha had called her that with her son present and unable to ignore for a second time the softness in Agatha’s voice.

“Are you okay?”

Rio nodded stiffly and caught Agatha’s gaze drop to her tight jaw.

She looked away again and turned to look out the window once more, feeling Agatha squeeze her arm before pulling away.

The three of them remained silent for the short journey, the only noises the soft movement of Nicky as he toyed idly with his mother’s buttons on her jacket.

Rio hadn’t looked back at Agatha or Nicky since Agatha had checked on her but when they pulled up to the stadium she was relieved to see that there was no hoards of paparazzi waiting for them, only crowds of fans and attendants milling around trying to direct everyone to the right entrance.

Rio turned back around then, and caught Agatha’s eye, she froze for a second, seeing Agatha so concerned and so soft with Nicky still against her that she forgot how angry she was and suddenly remembered how smitten she was instead.

But the door was being opened and Agatha turned away to step out and help Nicky.

Rio slipped out behind them and looked around when her hand was taken by the little boy and he grinned up at her. She’d forgotten in the stress of earlier how excited he was. And far be it for her to ruin his special day by being in a bad mood about some idiots with cameras.

They made it through the crowds with the security hanging back a little to give them some space.

But Rio was more aware than usual of the faces and fingers that pointed in their direction. She could feel eyes on them, could see phones being raised and knew by the time they reached the turnstiles to enter, they’d been captured on various devices at least a thousand times.

The brick wall of a man who’d protected them earlier waited outside the stadium to collect them later and Rio could only hope he’d be right there as soon as they needed him when they left.

They were taken straight to their court side seats by an attendant and Rio felt the rush of being back in one of her favourite places in all the world.

The smell of the rubber, the hot dogs and the popcorn, god she could bathe in it.

Which reminded her, as Nicky began swinging his legs on the seat and Agatha shrugged her jacket off to reveal the ridiculously attractive way she wore her jersey: “Snacks? Who wants what? I’m getting a beer and nachos.”

Agatha grimaced a little but Nicky looked up and bounced a little in his seat, “Nachos!”

“And beer too?”

“No! Soda please.”

“Okay, coming right up. And for her ladyship?”

Rio looked up and grinned at Agatha who was now lounging back in her seat, looking surprisingly at home where she sat in amongst the crowds at TD Gardens.

She heard her name called as she stood up and she glanced up at the stands behind them to see a couple women waving frantically at her.

She smiled and turned back to Agatha, “So?”

She caught Agatha on the turn and arched a brow slightly, seeing Agatha work through something in her mind.

“Will you take Nicky? Show him the delights of a stadium snack hall?”

Nicky was already jumping from his seat and Rio had no choice but to accept the hand held out to her and she watched curiously as Agatha glanced back at the women now shouting again, calling Rio’s name over and over.

She wanted so desperately to say something, to ask if she were being sent away with Agatha’s child to ensure she didn’t return with a girl on her arm, but there was no way she could do it without either Nicky hearing or the whole stadium getting a shot of Rio Vidal whispering suggestively into Agatha Harkness’s ear.

She merely smiled and tugged Nicky in the direction of the food hall, pulling him in front of her when the crowds got a little close and guiding him by his shoulders.

A few people looked her way but most were polite enough to move swiftly on when they saw she had a child with her.

And Rio focused most of her attention on Nicky, making sure he was close and safe and that he saw all of the varieties of foods that would set his pulse racing and make his stomach churn if he had too much.

Just as they were waiting on their order - Rio, with the help of Nicky, had chosen a hotdog and a beer for Agatha - she felt a tap on her shoulder.

“Excuse me, are you Rio Vidal?”

“I am, yes.”

“Like the actress?”

The woman’s voice was so loud that even through the crowds Rio could feel people starting to turn. She felt Nicky turn his head where she still had a hand on his shoulder.

“Yes.”

“Can I get a picture? I’m such a fan!”

Rio smiled and bit her lip briefly, “I usually would but I’m with my friend here so maybe another time.”

“Oh please?” The lady looked down to Nicky and raised her brows before looking back to Rio who’d turned to check on him too. “He looks so like you. He’s not…?”

“No,” Rio said quickly, suddenly panicked that the assumption from a stranger that Nicky was her child would confuse the boy.

“A friend’s son.”

“Well are you sure on the quick selfie?”

“Yes, only if I do it for you I’ll have to-…”

“Rio Vidal?”

Rio glanced instinctively over her shoulder and felt Nicky turn that way too, her hold tightening on him as she spotted a man through the crowds pointing at her.

“Seriously, it’ll take a second.”

And as she turned back to the woman she flinched at the raised phone and the sight of herself on the little screen, Nicky’s cap just visible in the bottom corner.

“Please don’t do that,” Rio said sternly, holding her hand up, “I’m just trying to get snacks and get out of here.”

The woman grumbled something about Rio being ungrateful but Rio had already ducked down to speak directly to Nicky, “You okay? We won’t be much longer.”

“Mm’fine,” Nicky said quietly but he looked serious again where before he’d been wide-eyed and happy.

So Rio stood back up and pulled him closer, crossing one arm over him as she fished her phone out of her pocket and dialled for Agatha.

“Hey,” she said quickly as Agatha answered after one ring.

“No se asusten. ¿Podrían enviar a un empleado? Estamos cerca del puesto de comida, el número seis. Todo está bien.” Don’t panic. Can you send an attendant to us? We’re at the food stand. Number six. Everything’s fine.

Rio heard her name rippling through the crowd and she wondered why she felt so exposed now, so vulnerable to it when usually she’d barely register it at all.

But then Nicky was holding her arm that sat across his chest and she realised with a pang that it was him who’d changed the way she felt.

“Rio.”

“Te prometo que estará a salvo conmigo.” He’s safe with me, I promise.

There was a muffled noise on the end of the line as Rio moved two steps forwards with Nicky as the queue moved.

“Someone’s coming,” Agatha said and Rio could hear the panic in her voice and it broke her heart as that coupled with Nicky’s firm grip on her arm made her sick with emotions she didn’t have the desire to name.

“He’s fine, Agatha. I’m just being cautious,” she said in soft English, now more worried about reassuring Agatha than being overheard.

“Can you stay on until they’re with you?”

“Yes.”

“Are you getting mobbed?”

“Something like that.”

There was silence for a while as nothing much happened. But Rio began to relax a little and she hoped Agatha were too.

“Any pretty girls?”

Rio raised her brows and bit her lip, glancing to the side to check that though people were looking they weren’t close enough to overhear her.

“Some.”

Rio felt Nicky toying with the fabric of her shirt and she glanced down at him, unable to see his face because of the angle. She gave him a gentle squeeze and he rocked his head back to look up at Rio and Rio grinned down at him matching his goofy smile.

“He’s quite the helper when it comes to-…”

“Don’t even say it.”

Rio laughed softly and turned when she felt a tap on the shoulder and a man in a Celtics bib was smiling at her.

“They’re here,” she said into the phone.

“Hurry back.”

Rio hung up and placed her phone in her pocket as she spoke to the attendant in a low tone, her hold never relenting on Nicky, even as the attendant moved them away to a separate area and stayed close as he spoke to his colleagues through a radio.

Rio felt a little embarrassed that she’d been given special treatment but she couldn’t risk Nicky being hounded or photographed or scared so she turned her attention back to him and bent around to whisper to him, “Beer’s coming up!”

Nicky laughed just as Rio felt another tap on her shoulder and she straightened again, her grin fading at the sight of the two women from the stands before grinning at her.

“Hi.”

“Hey! We couldn’t find you for ages but we just had to say hi.”

“Hi,” Rio repeated, feeling Nicky toy with her shirt again. She cleared her throat and looked across the way to see if their food and drinks had arrived yet.

The attendant was still close by.

“We were wondering,” one of them started as the other clocked Nicky and made to lift his cap.

“Woah,” Rio said quickly, pushing her hand away as she pulled him back.

“Everything okay, Miss Vidal?”

Rio glanced at the attendant and then frowned back at the women, her other arm now crossing over Nicky too.

“Fine. Don’t touch my kid.”

The woman who’d done it just blinked and at least had the decency to flush at Rio’s sudden change in demeanour, apparently recognising that she’d overstepped.

Rio turned then, once sure no one would be trying to get to Nicky again, and asked the attendant if he wouldn’t mind bringing the food and drinks down to them and then gently guided Nicky back through the crowds and out to the stadium.

Only when at the top of the tunnel to get to their seats did Rio breathe again and she released Nicky’s hand to let him run to his mum and dive at her.

Even from afar she could see that Agatha looked relieved to have him back with her and Rio knew she couldn’t look as stressed as she felt so Agatha wouldn’t panic more so she schooled her face into a smile and took her seat back up.

“They’re bringing it out. We got you a hot dog.”

Agatha hummed, too busy kissing a wriggling Nicky on the cheek over and over to respond to the prospect of a stadium-cooked hotdog.

Rio turned away from the sight and lifted her cap off her head to shake her hair out, running her fingers through it as she watched the stadium slowly fill around them.

It took Agatha reaching over to nudge her arm for her to turn back.

“Are you going to be loud?”

Rio raised her brows and laughed, “You cannot be questioning if I will be loud when-…”

But Agatha was smirking and Rio narrowed her eyes at her, aware suddenly that she’d been trying to pull her from her own thoughts.

“Yes. I like to cheer my team on.”

Agatha hummed as she surveyed Rio, “Well my team aren’t here so I won’t be cheering.”

“Your team is your son’s team and Nicky has chosen the best team in the world haven’t you, kid?”

She turned to Nicky who grinned and raised his hand to match Rio’s offered high five.

Agatha scoffed and Rio winked at her over Nicky’s head, replacing her cap back on her head again and grinning once more.

“Can I take a picture?”

Rio raised her brows but nodded, turning herself more in her seat so Agatha could get a good angle.

“No, of the two of you.”

Rio tilted her head and watched Agatha for a second, moving automatically when Nicky turned around in his seat too to place a hand on his arm.

“By the pitch,” Agatha instructed as if it were the most casual thing in the world and she motioned for them both to go.

“Court,” Rio corrected with a genuinely soft smile as Agatha rolled her eyes. But she stood all the same and held her hand out to Nicky to pull him with her. She stood with him just on the edge of the court, holding his shoulders as she bent down to grin at the camera with him, both in their matching caps.

Agatha took a few snaps and laughed when Rio flipped both their caps to sit backwards on their heads and Nicky giggled as the picture was taken.

And Rio couldn’t help but beam up at Agatha, watching her as she checked the pictures she’d taken and moving to look over her shoulder at them. Her perfume filled her lungs and she had to step back, feeling dizzy with it suddenly.

A voice behind her saved her from her sudden turn and she looked to see the guy who’d come to rescue them standing with a large tray with their food and drink.

“Oh god, thank you.” She moved quickly forwards and helped him put it all down.

“Want me to take a picture of the three of you? I’ll get good angles, I promise.”

“I…”

“I’d love that,” Agatha said from where she was now beside Rio suddenly, “thank you.”

Rio felt her hand on her upper back as she leant over to pass her phone over and she turned to catch Agatha’s eye but she’d already looked away.

“Caps forwards? Caps back?” She asked with an attempt to pretend her stomach wasn’t doing flips at the prospect of being photographed with Agatha and Nicky. On Agatha’s phone. In front of thousands of people.

“Either,” Agatha said with a smirk, “both.”

Rio rolled her eyes but suddenly became aware of her limbs as she approached Agatha’s side.

Nicky had fallen easily into place in front of his mum and Agatha’s hands were on his shoulders so Rio had to squash in.

“Feeling shy?” Agatha asked softly, raising a brow but continuing to smile as Rio hesitated. “Put your arm around me.”

But Rio’s limbs felt heavy and strangely long and she didn’t quite know how to move them until Agatha was reaching for her hand and lifting it, transferring it to her shoulder furthest from Rio so she moved closer so the stretch wasn’t so strange.

“Better,” Agatha muttered softly and Rio cleared her throat before she finally relaxed into it, curling her fingers properly around Agatha’s shoulder and turning to smile for the camera.

She was aware behind their photographer that a lot of the crowd were snapping shots too and she whispered, “Jen will be furious.”

“So let her be.”

Rio raised her brows and watched in surprise as Agatha turned to smile at her, raising her chin slightly in challenge. “What?”

“Nothing. Just… missing something.”

“And what might-…?”

But Rio had transferred her cap to Agatha’s head and was grinning at the sight.

“Perfect.”

She ruffled her own hair to make sure it was sitting okay and turned sharply to smile for the camera again, squeezing Agatha’s shoulder as she did.

“Idiot,” Agatha muttered quietly but Rio noted that she didn’t take the cap off.

“One with the two of them,” Rio said after a few more seconds of posing. She stole her cap back and replaced it on her head and strode away, turning to admire the view instead of the most beautiful woman in the stadium and her son.

Agatha looked up at her and Rio took in a sharp intake of breath because she was radiant. She was glowing. She was…

Shit.

She was in love.

Rio swallowed down the truth as if she’d been told to swallow a golf ball and saw that Agatha was now looking at her curiously, was adjusting herself with Nicky to lead him back and was approaching her.

But Rio looked away, turned to duck down and grab her beer so she had something to do, something to focus on when Agatha touched her arm but said nothing and made no enquiry into her sudden change in demeanour.

She’d been in the precipice of it for so long that she hadn’t even noticed that she’d tipped over.

That she’d fallen head first and hadn’t even noticed until she was swimming in her love for Agatha, drowning in it, and swallowing it down like the cool beer in her hand.

She’d downed half of it before she knew what she’d done.

“Rio!”

Rio looked over and saw Nicky pointing at the tunnel, and looked up to see the cheerleaders begin to stream out.

Rio raised her brows and glanced Agatha’s way, watching as she took a sip of her beer and almost managed to hide her grimace but Rio didn’t know if it was the beer or the young women now running out to the centre of the court that had caused it.

But Rio couldn’t look at Agatha any longer because she finally had an answer as to why it all hurt so much. Why she’d given in so easily.

But the lights were swirling, the music was picking up, and Nicky beside her was transfixed on the dancers, his large coke resting in his lap, almost the same size as him. And Rio decided to focus on him rather than the tempest of emotions storming through her.

“You think you could dance like that?”

“No. Mama dances.”

“Oh does she?”

Rio looked up to see Agatha glance her way and raise her brows, “What?”

“You dance like that? Nicky says you do.”

Agatha rolled her eyes and playfully tugged Nicky’s cap down to cover his eyes. He squealed and giggled and Agatha relented with a grin before she focused back in on Rio again.

“I think you know that isn’t true.”

“I don’t know,” Rio said with a smirk, “You have rhythm.”

Whether real or imaginary, Agatha blushed a little and Rio grinned at the sight of it, thrilled then that Agatha’s eyes dropped to it and she felt a little more of that hope that still stoked flames in her stomach.

But Agatha narrowed her gaze a little and Rio had to look away for fear she’d stare all night and turned instead to the dancers, choosing to focus in on them instead of the tragedy of the family beside her that she may be able to occasionally intrude on but would never be her own.

But the cheerleaders spot Rio and Agatha too and the little boy between them swinging his legs to the music and after the routine and the stadium applause, they all took their turns running around the perimeter and one stopped right in front of Rio.

“Rio, baby!”

And Rio recognised this woman when she was close up and she swallowed thickly, forcing her smile, “Hey!”

She stood quickly and gave the cheerleader a quick, one-armed hug.

“Who’s this little guy?” The woman pulled half back, their arms still around each other as Rio swung to look where she was pointing and saw Nicky look suddenly shy again.

“This is Nicky. He’s new to the Celtics family.”

Her gaze flicked across to Agatha and she saw that blue eyes were focused on Rio’s hand curled around the bare waist of the cheerleader whose name Rio did not remember.

“Hi,” Agatha said quickly, placing a reassuring hand on Nicky’s back before the cheerleader could address him.

“Rio, why don’t you introduce us?”

Bitch. Rio thought suddenly, wondering briefly if she had a tell for not knowing someone’s name and how she could get Agatha to tell her what it was.

“Of course,” she said quickly, unable to think of anything else to say and simply offering her free hand to refer to Nicky and Agatha in turn.

Suddenly she was aware of the crowd around them, of the people taking photos and videos and she wondered if she would come out well from this or if she’d tank her career because of a brief dalliance with a cheerleader two years ago and her love for the woman in front of her.

“This is Nicky. And this is Agatha.”

God, fuck me. Kill me. Now.

Agatha was looking at Rio now, her brows raised, her jaw tight.

And Rio felt two things at once: how cruel it was that Agatha was doing this to her and how good it felt that she was doing this to her.

Because it meant she was jealous. Surely it meant she was jealous.
Nicky, shy as he was, held his hand out and Rio forgot her torment for a second and smiled down at him.

“Please to meet you, little one. I’m Danielle.”

Thank fuck, Rio thought.

Nicky shook the woman’s hand and Rio moved away from her, withdrawing her arm from around her waist and turning to her properly.

“Think you could get us in with the players?”

“Babe, I’m barely allowed to be here for as long as I’ve been.”

And the lights moved and changed and Phil Collins began blasting signally the team’s imminent arrival so Rio and Danielle looked around them before their eyes met again.

“Leave it with me.”

Rio grinned genuinely at the woman and settled back down in her seat, her excitement overwhelming her previous concerns as she turned to Nicky to shake his shoulder but she saw Agatha’s hand already curled around it and her expression tense but purposefully softened for the lens she knew would be on them.

“She’s pretty.”

Rio’s brows raised from Nicky to Agatha and she tilted her head a little, her tongue poking in the side of her cheek.

“Old friend,” she said enigmatically and caught the flash in Agatha’s eyes.

The crowd roared into life around them and even the promise of her precious Celtics couldn’t tear her away from blue eyes.

But Nicky was on his feet and almost spilling his soda and so Rio had to shift her focus to the little boy as Agatha did too. And silently, without acknowledgement, they put everything aside to focus on making sure Agatha’s son had the best time of his life.

Rio took it upon herself to become the pseudo commentator for the little boy, making sure he knew who everyone was, what the plays were, why things were fouls and why other things were not fouls (“biased ref, hates the C’s”).

And Agatha spent half the time watching Nicky too, holding the back of his oversized jersey when he stood on his seat for a better view, and otherwise shooting glances at Rio as she dedicated her time teaching and entertaining her son.

By the time half-time was called Rio was exhausted from imparting her knowledge and screaming at the court.

Nicky was high as a kite on the excitement of the thing and due to the excess soda he’d consumed.

And Agatha was, and looked, more relaxed than she had in a long while.

Even as the boards began to light up and cameras headed their way she didn’t seem concerned or fussed at all as the spotlight first fell to her.

And Rio looked up at the jumbotron with a grin, beaming at the sight of Agatha’s smiling face on it. The crowds went wild for her. And she could see why.

Agatha Harkness sporting their team’s jersey was a win even if you weren’t a huge fan.

But the camera moved and suddenly Rio was on the board. She was a known fan. A known frequenter of games. So this was perhaps less exciting for everyone but she still received a huge cheer from the crowd as she waved and gestured for them to get louder for her.

And they sure did.

Nicky was giggling by her side and when the camera was away again Rio turned to stick her tongue out at him before she looked across at Agatha and raised her brows, “Oh Jen’s gonna be maaaaad.”

“Screw Jen.”

Rio laughed and reached down for her now warm beer, and finished it in one go, relaxing back in her seat as she luxuriated in the day out and vacation from her recent working life where she’d barely had time to think, let alone enjoy.

And then there was the happy kid bouncing to the music beside her and the woman beyond him, pulling him in to cuddle him into her side and ask him questions about the game.

Rio looked around at them and felt herself yearn once more.

The way Agatha was softer for Nicky, the way she sometimes was with Rio.

The way her hands brushed the soft hair sitting along his upper back, the hands that had done that to Rio, the hands that had held her own and caressed her cheek.

Agatha looked up then, her chin rested on Nicky’s head as he settled against her and she smiled curiously across at Rio, watching her watch them for a while before she shouted above the noise.

“Are you having fun?”

“Like you wouldn’t believe.”

Agatha laughed and then turned her head to kiss the top of Nicky’s and the game started again.

Rio resumed her new favourite role of Nicky’s personal entertainer and lifted him from his seat when the final whistle blew and their team won.

Nicky tried his best to give Rio tinnitus by screaming loudly by her ear but Rio didn’t mind because she too was bellowing her pleasure at the court.

Agatha didn’t shout but at least stood and clapped and soon moved closer to place her hands on both of their backs.

“Did you win?”

“Shut up!” Rio laughed, placing Nicky back on his feet again so she wouldn’t lose her hearing and her ability to stand straight for the next week.

“You know we did.”

Nicky was beaming so much that Rio worried he might actually break his face and then she saw it. He put his tongue between his teeth and giggled as Agatha took him into her arms and something triggered in her brain that she hadn’t noticed before.

They did look similar.

Her face fell slightly as she stared at him and Agatha caught it, and tugged at her shirt, making her eyes dart over.

“What’s wrong?”

Nicky was looking around and he turned serious again, frowning where Rio must look stricken.

“Nothing, nothing.”

Rio cleared her throat and tried to shake it off. Maybe it was a trick of the light. Maybe it was an overspill from her desire to be with Agatha.

Of her love for Agatha.

Regardless, it didn’t mean anything.

“We should wait a little,” Agatha was saying quietly, “just so the crowds are a little less. That security guard will be there when we get out the stadium but best just wait.”

Rio only nodded and lifted her cap to shake out her hair, and her attention was caught as she did as the cheerleader from before ran over and straight into her arms.

Releasing a soft noise when their bodies collided, Rio cleared her throat quietly.

“I had a word. Do you want to come back? You can wait in the tunnel when the guys come out the locker room.”

“Oh my god,” Rio babbled, unaware her hand was being held and blue eyes were down on it.

“Seriously?”

“Yeah!”

“Nicky?” Rio turned to Agatha and Nicky and saw the little boy hiding half against his mum now, blinking up at the cheerleader shyly.

“Want to come meet the team?”

“No thank you.”

“No?” Rio asked with a frown and dropped down to crouch before him, tweaking his cap up a little so she could see his face better, “Are you sure?”

Agatha bent down too, turning Nicky so the three now sat in a triangle, all the same level, all facing each other, Rio and Agatha knocking knees.

“Yes, mama.”

“Okay, honey. Why don’t we go back to the hotel and order some chicken nuggets instead?”

Nicky smiled at this and nodded furiously which made Rio’s concerns fade quickly but Agatha had taken her knee just as she’d made to stand again.

“You can stay with your friend if you want.”

“No,” Rio frowned, “no. I’ll come with you.”

Agatha only nodded and dropped her hold on Rio’s knee as they both straightened and Rio turned to break the news to Danielle.

“Maybe another time?”

“You have my number. Maybe use it sometime?”

Rio received a kiss on the cheek and the woman was gone, leaving only the three of them now by the edge of the court and Agatha avoiding her eye.

“A friend,” she repeated with raised brows even as she looked anywhere but at Rio.

“Yes. A pretty one.”

Agatha looked around then and Rio smiled a little at the intensity of her expression but didn’t push it.

Soon enough the attendant was back with them and as the stragglers left the stadium, so did they. Rio hung back a little to keep an eye on Agatha and Nicky from behind, intent on making sure there were no surprise fan interactions that would ruin the rest of their day.

They moved through the whispered sounds of their names and the unsubtle pictures being taken without much hassle and when they finally cracked the outer shell of the stadium and hit the cool outside air they were guided back to the waiting car with security in tow - which made Rio feel a hell of a lot better.

Nicky slid in first this time with Agatha in the middle and Rio bringing up the rear.

She felt the press of Agatha’s thigh against hers before she’d even properly settled in her seat and in the pretext of putting on her seatbelt she brushed her hand over the small of Agatha’s back, enjoying for a second the secret proximity to the woman she’d hopelessly fallen for.

By the time they were bundled back into Agatha’s suite, Rio was exhausted with the energy of the day.

She was left to lounge whilst Nicky went find something in his room and Agatha went to see he was fine before she came back out and sat by Rio’s hip on the couch.

“You’re so good with him.”

“He’s easy to be around.”

“What happened in line for food?”

“Nothing.”

“You wouldn’t have-…”

Rio sighed and sat slowly, now sitting level with Agatha on the couch and reaching to hold her wrist gently, as if that would help calm her.

“If I hadn’t had Nicky with me it would have been fine, and it was. I… I just wanted someone there. Just in case. I didn’t want him to freak out.”

Agatha’s jaw was working, flexing and unflexing with every clench of her teeth but her eyes were still soft and she nodded slowly, dropping her gaze to where Rio held her wrist.

“He’s shy.”

“I know.”

“You did the right thing. I shouldn’t have sent him with you in the first place.”

“Why did you?”

But Rio knew why. Agatha had thought with Nicky there Rio wouldn’t flirt. Would be too distracted. And she was right, obviously. But she didn’t know that Rio wasn’t interested in flirting with anyone anymore.

Anyone that wasn’t Agatha, anyway.

But Agatha didn’t respond and instead squeezed Rio’s hand gently before she stood from the couch.

“I’ll order food.”

Rio watched her go and then watched Nicky arrive back in the room holding up a mini basketball.

“Can we play?”

Rio laughed and glanced at Agatha who had pursed her lips in response, clearly not keen on the idea of her son and Rio smashing expensive vases in an expensive suite.

“Not tonight, buddy. But next time, okay? We gotta get you good enough to be captain of the Celtics!”

The little boy only nodded and jumped up on the couch beside her, throwing the ball up in the air to catch and soon they’d devised a game whereby they sat at opposite ends and gently tossed the ball back and forth.

Which Agatha only allowed because they’d get to fumble it and even when Nicky’s aim was off Rio could reach out to catch it before it drifted off to cause any permanent damage.

They evening went by happily, with Nicky entertained by Rio’s post-match analysis and thoughts on how she’d have done things differently and scored at least ten more points.

And Agatha contributed only to ask questions that would make Nicky laugh and Rio roll her eyes.

They feasted on nuggets and pizza and Nicky even got a special bowl of chocolate ice cream delivered and soon enough they lounged all on the same couch, with Agatha’s arm casually draped over Rio’s thigh and a tired little boy tucked into her side, unaware of his mother’s hold on the woman the other side of her.

The whole time Rio felt like she was flying.

She had Agatha back.

Nicky liked her.

Nicky wanted to talk to her or keep her talking.

And Agatha was smiling or laughing or rolling her eyes.

It was a facsimile of a family again. And Rio wanted it to last forever.

But Nicky had to be taken to bed and the illusion dissolved as the reality of being alone with Agatha meant she had to be brave, be bold, be as clear as she could be about how she felt about her.

Nicky gave her a quick hug and then Agatha whispered, “I’ll be right back.”

And she was alone, waiting for the woman she loved to come back to her.

Chapter End Notes

Oh babies.

Rest assured Jen and Alice will have ~thoughts about this little field trip but I wanted to focus on the little trio before any mention of ~that comes up again (also Rio never checks her phone and Agatha will have purposefully been ignoring it)

Anyone who spots Rio’s grammar mistake when protecting Nicky gets a hug from me

I wonder how the evening goes 👀

Also someone said that I should be talking more about this on Twitter (liliththemommylover 👀💕) so if anyone is on there and wants to follow me I’m @Salong44 DMs are open (I think) 😘

Chapter 17: Don’t Say It

Chapter Summary

Rio and Agatha talk.

Chapter Notes

Quite the sea change from the previous chapter! Be warned!

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Rio sat in the familiar position on Agatha Harkness’s couch, albeit in an unfamiliar hotel suite, waiting on Agatha to return to her from putting Nicky to bed.

Unlike before she knew what was to happen when she came back to her because she was going to take control.

She had to.

She was going to come clean, to tell Agatha that it was more than the crush Alice had told her about, it was more than incredible sex and a lust so undeniable she felt like she was on fire whenever Agatha touched her.

She’d never been the first to say it, never been the first to feel it, but now, now she’d gone and fallen for the most famous woman in the world who just happened to be married, who just so happened to want her too. Maybe just not love her.

And maybe Agatha would pull away again, she thought, or maybe it would go how she hoped.

Agatha would tell her she was divorcing Ralph, that she was going to run away with her, that they could buy a cottage somewhere in the woods and live a happy and easy life just the three of them.

Just as Rio were imagining a forest-themed basketball court, Agatha appeared again.

“Hey, he okay?”

“Fast asleep,” Agatha said with a small smile, eyeing the dishes Rio had piled up on the side.

“You’re a good house guest.”

“I try.”

“Wine?”

Rio nodded with a smile and reached to hold her glass for Agatha when she came to pour the rest of the wine they’d started earlier.

The bottle was finished by the time Agatha filled her own glass and Rio pulled her legs beneath her as they leant to cheers.

“To an incredible win today.”

“To you making Nicky’s day.”

Rio paused before she drank and began to second guess herself once more. If Agatha did pull away then she’d take Nicky with her too and as much as she barely knew the kid she’d grown fond of him.

Or maybe everything Agatha had told her about the reason for his existence, the fact even she could now see they looked alike, his shitty dad, it was all making Rio feel protective of him.

Rio drank down more than a mouthful of the wine and noticed Agatha watching her carefully. But she’d turned away, glancing briefly in the direction of Nicky’s door, just taking a second to breathe.

She felt a shift beside her and a hand on her cheek and Agatha was turning her head to kiss her.

And Rio could have cried for it, could have suffered a thousand humiliations to just feel the way she currently felt with Agatha leaning into her, holding her in place so their lips could be together for the first time in over a month.

But it lasted barely five seconds and Agatha was talking again, her thumb tracing the familiar sweep over her cheek.

“It’s been too long.”

Rio reacted only by lifting her hand to curl around the thin fabric at the neck of Agatha’s new jersey and she swallowed before she whispered, “We need to talk.”

Agatha pulled away then and broke Rio’s hold on her as she put at least two feet of distance between them, her blue eyes over on the bar.

“Agatha,” Rio said softly, frowning at the reaction, unable to reach back out for fear she’d be rejected again.

“More wine?”

Agatha asked suddenly, pushing herself up from the sofa and grabbing her glass to march to the bar at the end of the room.

Rio watched silently, her traitorous heart thrumming in her chest as her eyes scanned over Agatha as she sourced a bottle from the fridge and proceeded to open it with an expert flourish.

“You never did tell me why the four.”

Rio blinked, her mind so cloudly she couldn’t determine the question.

“What?”

Agatha turned over her shoulder as she tugged the cork from the bottle with a soft pop. “My shirt.”

Rio’s gaze dropped to the large ‘4’ displayed on Agatha’s front and she felt herself blush for it.

“It’s just a number.”

“Then why react this way every time I ask.”

Rio bit down on the inside of her cheek, knowing Agatha well enough now to know she wouldn’t drop it.

“It was a random number, or was supposed to be. I knew the players wouldn’t mean anything to you so I was just trying to come up with a number and,” she shrugged and watched as Agatha slowly walked back to where she sat on the couch, stopping just before her with a bottle in one hand and her glass in the other, “you have four little freckles on your nose. Tiny ones. I only noticed them the last time we-… anyway they’re in a vertical line and they’re… whatever… four.”

Agatha didn’t react for a second and Rio feared she might laugh but she maintained eye contact and refused to look away. If she backed down now, she’d never get through the night.

The woman before her slowly came back to life, stepping past her and sitting down beside her.

“Drink your wine,” she said in a soft voice, her gaze elsewhere as she lifted her own glass to drink down the remnants of the wine there.

Rio did as she was told and winced slightly at the volume of the liquid that poured down her throat.

But Agatha was soon filling her glass back up with the new wine and their eyes met again. She looked softer again, far more at ease than she had been when Rio had suggested they talk.

And Rio had to look away for fear if Agatha kissed her again she’d forget about talking altogether.

“Have things,” Rio started slowly, knowing she needed to get to the point quickly or she’d get drunk or too nervous and wouldn’t be able to get to what she knew she needed to bring up, “with Ralph, have they been… any better?”

“Ralph’s fine,” Agatha said curtly.

Rio turned to look at Agatha then and saw her focus in on her wine, saw the flex in her jaw.

“Agatha.”

Agatha glanced over and Rio almost lost her nerve entirely.

“Have you had sex with him since we were together?”

Agatha turned away again and took down another gulp of wine. Rio held her glass in her lap, one hand curled around the cup, the other toying with the stem.

“No.”

Rio could only nod, only breathe a silent sigh of relief that nobody had touched Agatha since she last had. Least of all Ralph.

The man who didn’t deserve her but had her all the same.

“Have you?”

Rio shook her head, watched Agatha eye her for a while and then turn away again.

“Why not?”

No one compares. I’ve barely had the energy to think because I’ve spent the last month learning lines and thinking about you. I just want you. All the time.

“Agatha,” Rio started softly, shifting where she sat to lean forwards a little but something sparked in the woman opposite and Agatha looked panicked suddenly, fearful.

“Don’t,” she said quickly, “don’t say something sweet. Not again.”

“We slept together twice. That’s all.”

“You know it is.”

“I’m married, Rio.”

“And you don’t have to be.”

Agatha just shook her head and turned away fully, her gaze on the dark night sky out the window.

“You’ve got what you wanted. I don’t need to push.”

And then she’d back away if Agatha didn’t open up.

If she didn’t soften even slightly to her.

“And you have someone waiting for you on the other side.”

“Don’t,” she said quietly. “You can’t keep saying things like that.”

“Agatha,” Rio breathed out, “I mean it. If you wanted me I’d be here.”

“Our mothers are friends. It was a set up. One neither of us had much choice in. And then my career took off and he had to move to LA with me and I got pregnant and we became the dream couple.”

She trailed off with a venom in her tone, a sarcastic spiteful lilt to the last two words.

A marriage of convenience. A forced one. Rio felt white hot fury flash through her, adding to the sharp pain still present in her chest.

It was needless then. Agatha’s misery was needless.

She clenched her fists over her knees and forced herself to calm down, but the idea of Agatha being shackled to a man because of a choice her mother had made was intolerable.

Inconceivable.

Irredeemable.

Not in this way. Not in any true way that mattered.

“Have a safe flight,” Agatha eventually whispered, not quite meeting Rio’s eyes.

She then pressed her face against the back of her hand and breathed her in for a second before she turned to leave and stepped from Agatha’s shared suite with Nicky into the long hallway and back to her suite to pack her things and fly back to Toronto.

Chapter 18: A Christmas Gift

Chapter Summary

Rio receives a surprise.

Chapter Notes

A short(ish) interlude as time moves on and Rio does not

See the end of the chapter for more notes

It hadn’t been an easy couple of months.

But the first day had been the worst.

The news about Rio and Agatha attending a Celtics game together had broken not five minutes after they’d entered the stadium. There had been photos of them from every conceivable angle, in every imaginable pose, moment, and emotion.

Particular attention had been picked up online by Rio’s fans that she looked like Agatha’s son and imaginations had run wild as to why that was and questions as to how no one had noticed it before were plastered over gossip sites and Twitter timelines the world over.

And then there had been Alice.

Alice had blown up Rio’s phone two minutes after she’d arrived at the stadium.

Only Rio hadn’t even looked at her phone until she was on the way to the airport.

So Alice was furious.

They’d spent a week in a deeply unpleasant space with each other.

Rio was depressed and morose anyway and Alice was incandescent with her friend.

Alice had only eventually given in and conceded that it was probably a good move - albeit a needlessly sneaky one - on Rio’s behalf to be photographed being friendly with Agatha and her son. And Rio had no energy or desire to do anything but accept her apology.

And so they were back to normal.

And Rio had to live with the fact that people on the internet wanted her to be with Agatha almost as much as she herself wanted it.

But she hadn’t heard from her. It had been weeks and the last she’d seen of Agatha was her standing in the door to her suite wearing the jersey she’d had made for her.

The last she’d felt of her touch was when she’d held her hand to her face.

The last thing she’d heard her say to her was to ‘have a safe flight’.

And then radio silence.

She knew, when she could stand to tune into updates from Alice about Jen and Agatha, that she’d fallen out with Jennifer. She knew that they still weren’t on great terms and that Ralph had taken the whole thing badly too.

But she didn’t know anything else.

The only other news of Agatha came from the announcements of the Critics Choice Award nominations, followed swiftly by the Golden Globes. They both got nominations. And were both favourites to win.

Which meant only one thing to Rio: she’d be seeing Agatha in early January.

With two of the top five awards bodies already teeing both Rio and Agatha up to be potential winners, all talk had turned to which of them would top the other.

Which, ironically, was a lot of the chat about the two of them online as well.

But Rio had done all she could. She’d been as honest as Agatha had allowed her to be. And Agatha hadn’t reached back out, so Rio lived now in a liminal space: a space between loving Agatha and needing to move on.

But she’d promised to wait.

And so she began to resent that she had even decided to be in a movie that was awards fodder, let alone turn in a stellar performance in it. She began to hate herself for her aspirations, for wanting to be as good and as well respected as Agatha, because it had forced them together, it had meant that she’d fallen for her.

Fallen so hard and so painfully that she’d been celibate since Boston.

She’d taken to lying to Alice about the women she wasn’t sleeping with. Saying she was trying harder to date rather than to just shag. And Alice was pleased she was being more discerning. So she made up girls she’d matched with on Raya, and she flirted in front of her so she wouldn’t suspect that she’d lost her mind over a married mother.

And by late December she was beginning to feel a little more herself.

She’d acted her way into a better place.

She’d wrapped filming on her Toronto project and was back home for the holidays.

And her parents were staying with her, which was a blessing and a curse. It meant she got no alone time but also meant she had a full fridge and an even fuller stomach.

Her final piece of work was scheduled in for the day before Christmas Eve and much to her parents confusion it was reading thirst tweets for Buzzfeed.

“I can’t believe you told them what this was,” Rio was saying as her blusher was topped up and an anxious Alice was shuffling in front of her.

“It slipped out, okay? I’m not sure they understood anyway.”

“Yeah, telling them people on the internet were writing dirty stuff about their daughter wasn’t exactly the Christmas present I was hoping you’d get them.”

“Actually I got your mom a nice scarf and your dad some whiskey. This was just a treat.”

Rio rolled her eyes and swung for Alice, narrowly missing her shoulder as she stepped back.

“No hitting. I didn’t bring a change of outfit and I don’t want your grubby paws ruining my shirt before my flight.”

Rio rolled her eyes again but said nothing more, knowing Alice was anxious enough as it was because as soon as this shoot was done she was hopping a flight to Indianapolis to spend Christmas with Jen’s family.

“Relax,” she said as the makeup artist moved away and one of the producers was making his way over. “They’ll love you.”

“Easy for you to say, everyone loves you.”

Rio grinned widely to hide the twinge of sadness that told her she could name one person who didn’t.

But grinning helped. It almost felt real.

“Rio! Are you ready? Not vetting these first is crazy, by the way. We’ve thrown in some absolute zingers.”

Rio laughed and Alice began to chew on her lip.

“Maybe we should have.”

“C’mon. We see loads all the time. You’re constantly reading them out to me and laughing about them.”

Alice hummed her disapproval and Rio sighed as she turned back to the producer and took the phone offered to her.

“Swiping right through them?”

“Yeah. Tried to put them in a random order so some will be more tame than others. We’ll just point and shoot and edit out any that make you want to vomit.”

“Fine, I’ve a strong stomach.”

Rio was left alone then, perched on a small director’s chair in the middle of a blank backdrop, and she watched as everyone took their seats behind the camera and Alice’s smile returned to her face once she saw how Rio looked on the monitor.

She took it as a sign that she looked good.

“Ready when you are, Rio!”

Rio nodded and held her phone up to swipe up and read the first screenshot of a tweet.

She laughed. Genuinely. Loudly. And then looked to the camera with a raised brow.

“Hi I’m Rio Vidal and I’m here today with Buzzfeed to read thirst tweets.”

She dropped her gaze to the phone again and clicked her tongue. “God what a way to start.”

“@RidalsGal1 says: ‘I have two perfectly good holes and one needy mouth and none of them are full of @RioVidal. America please explain.’” Rio laughed again and looked at the camera.

“Jesus.”

She swiped the screen until the next tweet came up and whistled a low note as she read it over before voicing it: “@Darby789 says: ‘All I want for Christmas is for @RioVidal to use me as her personal’… oh my god,” she cleared her throat but her lips twitched into a crooked grin, partly for the camera and partly because she couldn’t believe what she was about to say: “‘use me as her personal cum bucket’.”

She ran a hand through her hair and looked up at the camera with raised brows, “Gimme a time and a place and I’ll be there.”

She heard Alice laugh and smirked as she looked to the next one: “@VidalsPlaything says @RioVidal I am free this Thursday for dinner and also anal thanks.’ Straight to the point. Like it.”

The next one she swiped to and laughed again, her tongue poking in her cheek as she chuckled and tried to get a grip on herself. “Jesus, man. You guys are freaks. Okay, @RioRioRio says: ‘Need @RioVidal biblically. Like, fist so far up my ass she’s wearing me like Kermit the Frog.’ Dios mío!”

She dropped the phone to her lap and looked back up to the camera, remembering the chat she’d had before with Alice and the producer; “make sure you comment briefly between each read”, “feel free to pause or laugh or whatever you need to do”, “try to react as naturally as possible”, “flirt, Rio. You’re excellent at it.”

“Listen, I’m pretty busy right now but I might have fisting time in the new year. I’ll keep you in mind.”

She looked back to the next one and smiled as she adjusted her free arm over her lap, “Okay this one is pretty sweet, actually. ‘@VidalsWife says ‘If I had one nickel for every time I’ve masturbated to thoughts of @RioVidal I’d be the richest woman in the world.’ Sweet. Romantic, even.”

She smirked at the camera and flicked to the next one.

“@Feral4Vidal says: ‘I love Rio Vidal’ and then it brackets it says… ‘I want Rio Vidal to rail me’.” She snickered and groaned as she grinned, “with all these requests I’m going to be a busy girl.”

And here is where she paused, when she swiped for her next tweet, and almost lost her composure. Because Agatha’s name was the first thing she saw.

“@HarknessHymen: ‘Feeling v French today. @RioVidal and #AgathaHarkness how would you feel about recreating the Eiffel Tower with me to celebrate?’” She forced a laugh, forced her smile to remain on her face. “I’ll text her later. Thanks for asking so politely.”

“Man, oh man, you people. I hope you don’t kiss your mothers with these mouths.”

She cleared her throat and shifted in her seat, beginning to toy with her hair as she read the next: “From @GayDream13 says ‘Sometimes Rio Vidal is so mommy and sometimes she’s so daddy I don’t know whether I want to suckle or suck.’” She laughed and took herself by surprise at it, blushing ever so slightly as she rocked her head back and grinned. “Christ.”

“Honestly this is the weirdest ego boost I’ve ever had.”

“@RiosToothGap says… oh god. They say: ‘I hope Rio knows she has an army of women willing to crawl miles over broken glass just to beg her to spit on them’.”

“I mean… how many miles, guys? Be specific please. Details.”

She looked up with a grin and saw Alice indicate one more and so she looked down to the next tweet on offer. And Agatha’s name was there again.

She cleared her throat quietly and read it over properly, feeling her jaw clench as each passing word made her feel increasingly more uncomfortable.

@Whre4Rio: I wouldn’t even want to join. I just want to live in a world where Rio Vidal knows what Agatha Harkness’s puss tastes like.

The recent flurry of internet interest in Agatha and Rio’s relationship that caught the attention of almost every journalist worth their salt. So Buzzfeed were clearly no different.

Most had focused on the rivals turned friends angle and some industry-focused journos had been deliberating and debating over whether this was a clever PR stunt for more attention, for more votes.

But Alice had told Rio that her Twitter was full of tweets like these and Rio was able to laugh most of them off, to roll her eyes and smile as Alice read them out, but sometimes they hit that little soft part of herself that wanted to cry instead of laugh.

She stared at it for a while and in her peripheral vision saw Alice moving a little as if to come to her. But she looked up before she could and shook her head slightly, “I’m sorry. Not this one. Can we cut that out and I’ll read one more.”

“Sure sure,” came the voice of the producer, keen to make sure Rio could continue comfortably and not ruin what he and his colleagues knew would be a huge hit for them on their YouTube channel. “Whatever you want. Start from the top on the next one.”

Rio smiled a little and swiped to get the next tweet up. She scanned it over and then looked to the camera with her smile back in place, “Everyone seems to think I wanna hurt people but I promise I’m actually every nice.”

She looked back at the tweet and read: “@D1ckD4re says ‘Rio Vidal could run me over, spit on my mangled body, and burn me to ash and I’d come back and thank her for it.’ I mean… I don’t want to do that but if you really want it then I guess who am I to say no?”

She laughed at her little joke, hamming it up for the camera to make up for her refusal to read the last tweet and then she dropped the phone and smiled, “Am I done humiliating myself now? Is everybody satisfied or would anyone like me to provide my services as a puppeteer?”

She held her hand up with a grin and wriggled her fingers, much to the delight of the video producers who now had their perfect end to an expertly performed video.

“We got it!” The main producer shouted and Rio raised her brows as Alice rushed in.

“You did? Need me to repeat or-…?”

“No, honest, Rio. You gave us everything we needed.”

Rio smiled and held the phone back out as she stood from her seat, “They were… Jesus.”

“Told you.”

“Hey. Amazing. Which did you skip?”

“Oh,” Rio shrugged and was grateful the phone was gone so Alice couldn’t make her show the tweet in question.

“Just one about… just felt a bit weird.”

“Okay. Well you fucking nailed it.”

“Yeah, yeah.”

“Must be all that sex you’ve not been having lately.”

Rio only hummed at Alice’s whispered words and moved with her to begin making the rounds, thanking everyone and saying their goodbyes and merry christmases as they finally, after a long day, left the little studio.

Outside by Rio’s old hybrid is where Alice pulled her best friend down into a tight hug.

“I’ll miss you.”

Rio sighed heavily and held Alice tightly against herself, turning her head after a few seconds to kiss her cheek.

“It’s just a few days.”

“Say it back, you bitch.”

Rio laughed and pulled away, “I’ll miss you too.”

Alice hummed and went to remove her bags from the back of Rio’s car, “You make sure your mom leaves me plenty of food, okay? Jen’s promised an anti inflammatory menu and… I think by the time I’m back I’ll be craving anything other than whatever that means.”

“Yeah, yeah, it’s practically a production factory in my poor little kitchen. I’ll try not to eat it all.”

“Very much appreciated,” Alice grinned as she shouldered her duffel and slammed the door shut.

Her expression softened as she took Rio in and Rio just knew she was about to ask her the same question she’d been asking her since she got back from Boston: “Anything you want to talk to me about?”

Rio knew she’d not kept her low moods hidden particularly well but she couldn’t reveal the truth for fear of outing Agatha so secrecy was important. It was paramount.

“No. Go and have a great time with your beautiful girlfriend and call me every day, okay?”

“Okay. I love you, idiot. Behave. Don’t run off on anymore trips that make my girlfriend furious.”
