She was just another woman with her sleepy son in a hotel in London. Just another movie star.

And Rio was just another victim of falling for the wrong person.

Agatha’s suite was first and Rio stopped to kiss Nicky on the top of the head, smiling as he cuddled in briefly before she turned to Agatha. She kissed her, briefly, sweetly, on the cheek and then turned before she could begin to pine once more.

The solitude of her own room didn’t help much. By the time she’d shrugged off her jacket and changed into soft flannel pyjamas, she was thinking about the woman a few doors down. How she’d be tucking Nicky in, changing into her own pyjamas, and waiting for her husband to return.

Rio settled on the little bench by the window and similar to any myriad of movie scenes since the dawn of time, she rested her head against the pane, thought of her lover, and watched the rain pour.

There was a soft knock at her door just as Rio was beginning to wonder if anyone in the world had ever been this down bad before and she turned to see if she’d imagined it. When it happened again she knew she hadn’t.

She moved slowly to open it and blinked furiously into the light of the hotel corridor where Agatha stood, still in her clothes, minus her jacket, smiling hopefully across at her.

“I don’t have long.”

Rio stepped aside to let Agatha in and closed the door quietly behind her.

“Nicky’s asleep but he’s alone. I can’t be long.”

“Okay,” Rio said softly, now standing with her hand on the door handle in the dim light of the unlit room.

“I don’t have long,” Agatha said again and Rio wondered who she was trying to remind of this fact. Rio bit her lip and cautiously reached up towards Agatha and found her waist was grabbed before she could even make contact.

“I don’t have-…”

“Rio,” Agatha whined quietly, “baby.”

“Can I… can I have a picture of you in these?”

She looked up, blinked at the woman above her, unashamed and unfaltering in her request, needing to have the sight before her memorialised forever, perhaps she’d blow it up and have it above her bed.

Agatha was breathing heavily, her top teeth buried in the softness of her pouting lower lip, and she brought her hands over to run through Rio’s dark hair, scratching briefly at her scalp.

“Yes. If you hurry.”

Rio smirked, leaning close to sink her teeth into the delicate lace, conscious if she ripped them her picture would be ruined - and only briefly wondering if it might make it better.

But she pulled them down quickly, hurrying against whatever internal timer Agatha was working against and her own desire to taste Agatha again.

Agatha was wet already, she didn’t need to touch her to know that. Staring up at her dumbly she caught something predatory, something furious in Agatha’s gaze.

It made her whine a little, unable to speak, instead just pressing her thighs tightly together to try for some relief.

She knew she must look pathetic to her. In her plaid pyjamas, her eyes wide and her mouth equally so, her lips swollen and her face covered in Agatha.

But Agatha was looking away, she was leaning around Rio, and crucially, she hadn’t softened.

“Agatha,” Rio uttered as Agatha leant down and pulled her underwear and jeans back up.

“Hey, just stay. Just give me five more minutes.”

But Agatha was moving around her, ignoring Rio as she remained kneeling before her. The older woman stumbled a little as she stepped aside and buttoned her jeans back up.

There was a second of no movement at all and then she’d stepped around her fully, opened the door as much as she could with it now knocking Rio’s knees, and had stepped outside.

The door closed with a soft click and Rio was alone again. Naturally.

The change in her demeanour was so sudden, so unexpected, that Rio could barely register the pain of it.

She wiped Agatha from her lips and stared at the door now shutting her off from the woman she’d just been worshipping.

The shadows beneath the door told her that Agatha still stood there, that she was just on the other side, and she stared at them until she could no longer stand it and she breathed her name like a prayer: “Agatha?”

There was silence, no movement, but Rio knew it was her. She could feel her through the wood.

And then, slowly, the shadows moved and there was a soft knocking on the door.

Rio leant up to open it but didn’t move from where she knelt, just pulled the door back until it hit her knees and watched as Agatha slipped back inside.

Agatha didn’t look surprised at Rio’s position, stock-still, waiting. She merely stood before her again, her left hand moving just the few inches forwards to curl beneath Rio’s chin.

“Tell me.”

In the dim, Agatha looked softer than Rio had ever seen her before. It was like a magic trick. She’d disappeared for ten seconds and come back a different woman. She looked almost as if she weren’t there at all. But Rio’s hands now rested on her calves and she felt the soft brush of Agatha’s thumb along her jaw which told her all she needed to know about Agatha being here, being real, being soft again.

Rio could only frown, only clutch at Agatha’s jeans, only lean into her touch.

“Tell you what?”

Agatha sucked in a slow breath and before she spoke again Rio realised what she was about to say: “Tell me what you tried to tell me in Boston. If you still feel it… tell me.”

Rio had grown up on fairytales. She’d consumed them with a ferocity that neither of her parents could keep up with. First in Spanish, then she’d wanted them all over again in English. She devoured the stories they told her like she had been starved of words all her life.

As she got older she’d moved onto books of her own, movies that deemed themselves “romantic comedies”, stories of love lost and love found.

Later, she sought it out in bars and on apps, in work, and even on beaches.

She found love in every form she could get it, and it never satisfied her.

It never felt real or wonderful or enough.

Until the day she’d looked across at Agatha Harkness at the side of a basketball court and she’d realised she’d found what she’d always been looking for.

And now Agatha was asking for it. Asking her to confirm it in words when she’d been trying to confirm it in her actions before she could even put a word to it.

So she breathed the words she’d said disingenuously to women before, the ones she hadn’t meant until now:

“I love you. I’m in love with you.”

And Agatha sucked in the words she’d breathed out, as if they’d been a surprise, as if she had expected Rio to refuse or to say something else.

And then her soft eyes closed and Rio had no choice but to lean into her, to kneel up and move her hands up to the soft fabric of her sweater in an attempt to pull her down towards her. But Agatha didn’t move, she kept her eyes closed and Rio waited patiently for them to open again, hoping she might say it back.

Rio whispered her name but Agatha only gasped out the words she’d inhaled, breathed the feel of them back into the room, but saying nothing.

More exquisite than any pain she’d ever experienced, the pain of Agatha being silent when she’d told her how she felt was excruciating.

In the quiet, in the dark, in the space of just the two of them, she hadn’t said it back.

But her hand was still curled around Rio’s chin, her other hand moving to rest on Rio’s arm, Rio knew she felt it, she had to believe she felt it, or she’d crumble beneath her. She’d die like the tragic heroes of the tales she used to read; only there was nothing heroic about her anymore, only tragedy was left.

“I need to get back,” Agatha murmured eventually, pulling her hands away and slowly opening her eyes.

Agatha looked defeated rather than comforted and Rio shifted beneath her, “Just stay a little longer.”

“Nicky’s alone. I need to get back to him.”

Rio nodded, not because she wanted to, but because she knew it was the right thing to do.

“It hurts,” she said as Agatha made a move to go, “it hurts to see you with Ralph. To not be able to-… it hurts.”

Agatha’s pale hand was on the door handle beside her, and she stopped where she stood to turn and look down at Rio still kneeling before her.

Rio’s hands moved down again, moving to the backs of Agatha’s thighs to pull her closer, and the woman above her allowed this, allowed Rio to pull her until she was sitting back and pulling Agatha into her lap, holding her in place as Agatha’s hands found their home in Rio’s hair again, softer and more tender than they had been before.

Rio found she couldn’t speak, the vulnerability of her declaration suddenly choking her. But Agatha didn’t let her suffer any more than she already had.

She leant in and kissed Rio, kissing her so delicately that Rio’s lips barely reacted before she pulled away. “I have to go, Rio.”

And Rio nodded again, and found strength in Agatha wrapping her legs around her waist, in Agatha’s soft eyes moving over her face, in her thumbs as they rubbed gently against her temple.

It felt like she were being treasured, like she was being cherished, and then she caught the tear that had fallen from Agatha’s eye and she raised her hand to wipe it just as Agatha pulled back and stood, stumbling a little back into the door.

“I need to go.”

And she was gone before Rio could protest.

Chapter End Notes

This chapter was 20k but I split it at the most painful point so I’ll buy you all the best milkshake in the world

Any art lovers check the title thanks

BAFTAs up next, some more pining, more Ralph (yuck) and Agatha wants to talk to Rio (about what? Couldn’t possibly say)

Chapter 21: Red Is The Warmest Colour

Chapter Summary

Agatha wants to talk.

Rio stands her ground.

Chapter Notes

Milkshakes all round

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“He’s an ass,” were the words that woke Rio from her sleep. She shifted and groaned and huffed but found she couldn’t move away because above the covers Alice was lying beside her with her arm thrown around her middle.

“I can’t believe… he’s just such a…”

“Cunt?” Rio offered groggily, assuming she already knew who Alice was taking about.

“Yeah. A cunt.”

Rio huffed an attempt at a laugh but it died somewhere along her mid-nasal passage.

“And that kid, Rio. I didn’t mean to stare but… it’s weird.”

“I know.”

“No, like, it’s weird. It’s like someone has taken you, maybe sprinkled a bit of Agatha in there and-…”

“Yes, Alice.”

Alice sighed and rolled onto her back to let Rio struggle out from the cocoon she’d made for herself in the bed.

“Is it hard?”

“What?”

“Loving a woman and loving her son too?”

Rio froze where she sat at the edge of the bed and turned her head slightly, waiting for Alice to say “gotcha!” or change the subject immediately. But she didn’t.

“I don’t love Nicky.”

“Rio, it’s unbelievable that you think it’s not totally obvious.”

“You didn’t pick up on my feelings for Agatha. You’re just seeing things now.”

Rio moved over to the en suite to grab her toothbrush.

“I’m seeing that you want them. The family. You want this family.”

It was too early to feel this fragile, to feel the keen sting of every word said to her that contained even the vaguest memory of the night before.

“It’s not mine to have.”

Alice sighed quietly where she now stood watching Rio brushing her teeth and avoiding looking at her own reflection in the mirror.

“Wanda’s here now. She got in early this morning. Let’s grab lunch with her.”

Rio didn’t say anything and eventually Alice left her to it, trusting that she’d get on with getting ready for the day without her constantly by her side.

And Rio did. She showered and changed and put on a little makeup just to hide the bags under her eyes.

She’d scrubbed her face so as to remove the memory of Agatha all over it. She’d washed her hair to wash away the feel of Agatha’s fingers tangled in it.

But nothing worked to rid herself of the weight that had settled deep within her chest.

By the time she was ready she was decidedly not excited about the BAFTAs that night. Because Ralph would be there, and Agatha would be with him.

She left the room to go and fetch Alice at precisely 8:15am and soon they were on their way to the first stop of the day: getting Rio’s nails done.

Leaving the hotel wasn’t as stressful as arriving the night before. Perhaps in the UK paps didn’t start until 9am and worked until the early hours of the morning before rotating again. Or perhaps, no one cared as much about Rio Vidal as they did about Agatha Harkness.

Still, London was waiting, and whether to cheer Rio up or simply because Alice loved London almost as much as she loved organising Rio’s life, the two went off - via the tube, much to Rio’s secret delight - to Borough Market, where, after getting her nails done, they spent the morning shopping the stalls and Rio spent much of it looking for a replacement to her favourite shirt.

It would have been a good distraction from her torment if it had worked.

She found that fans were a little more polite here, or at least quieter than they were in the states. She was bothered a little less but stared at more and soon decided on buying a beanie hat to try to be more incognito.

This did not work either.

But with a new shirt that Alice absolutely hated - it had the words ‘lick my’ and then ice cream cones printed all over it - and several garish souvenirs she thought her mom would like, they made their way back to the hotel in time to meet Wanda for a quick bite at the restaurant.

Rio settled herself in one of the little red dining chairs and found herself alone at the table with Wanda, Alice having excused herself before they’d even been shown the table.

“You’ve worked your magic on my manager.”

“Nonsense! I’ve just… asked her to leave us alone for an hour or so.”

“Which is strange because usually you love her company.”

“I like yours more.”

The flirt was clear and Rio might have gone along with it a little while ago, or perhaps even if she weren’t on the edge of a breakdown, but this time it felt like it meant too much, could mean everything.

“I’m not doing what you want me to,” she said quietly as a waiter hovered nearby ready to take drinks orders.

“And I won’t force you. I just-…” She was interrupted by the very waiter who’d been hovering. They made their order and he left. “I just think it would help us both. Admittedly me a little more than you.”

Rio began spinning her hair around her finger, “What’re you wearing tonight?”

Changing the subject was easier than fighting it.

“Louis. Some sleek, black, sparkly thing. Will we match?”

Rio settled back in her seat as the waiter came to pour the wine. “I’m in red and black so, we’ll be fine. Actually, Versace want to exclusively dress me for the rest of the season. Alice thinks they might make me their spokesperson.”

“Oh, c’mon, Rio. Give me a little piece of the pie. Please make sure we stay together at the after party? Even with Agatha there it’ll be…”

“Are you making my big win with a huge fashion house about you?” Rio grinned behind her wine glass, relaxing a little with how ludicrous this whole situation was.

“I’m trying to make it a little about me.”

Rio laughed and placed her glass down again, leaning over the table towards Wanda. “Why won’t you take no for an answer?”

“Because you’re holding out on me and I want to know why.”

Rio laughed again but made the mistake of turning her attention to the restaurant entrance as she reached back out for her wine. Across the heads of the various diners, Rio saw the one person she’d not expected to see until later. The one person she could still taste on her tongue. Agatha was standing beside her son at the entrance to the restaurant.

The fingers outstretched to take up her wine glass missed and red wine went pouring onto the white table cloth and into Wanda’s lap.

“Fuck. Shit.”

In the middle of the Ritz restaurant, Rio performed in the most mortifying scene of her career.

She stood as two waiters arrived to help, and Wanda laughed as Rio panicked and her cheeks flamed as red as the Shiraz now bleeding out on the table.

“Sorry,” Rio huffed as she uselessly patted at Wanda’s shirt with a cloth napkin, scowling at the mess she’d made across it.

“It’s only Zara,” Wanda whispered and placed her hand over Rio’s busy one to stop her. “Hey. It’s okay.”

“Ladies, allow us to remove you somewhere a little… drier,” came the patronising voice of the head waiter now looking at Rio like she were trash, or worse, American.

“Actually,” Wanda started just as Rio felt a hand on her lower back and the only thing that could have possibly made this worse arrived on the scene.

“Too much wine already?” Agatha was smiling and raising her brows at her, the pads of her fingers pressing into her back and her eyes glinting in the midday sun streaming through the tall windows.

The light caught Agatha’s face just as she turned slightly and Rio saw the telltale signs of a sleepless night. The weight that had settled in her chest since the night before now dropped further into her stomach and she felt nauseous all of a sudden.

“Just clumsy,” Rio said quietly, her cheeks still aflame.

Agatha’s hand slid away and Rio caught her gaze dart to her red cheeks before settling again on the state of Wanda Maximoff covered in a £30 glass of Shiraz.

“Red suits you,” she said with such amusement in her voice that it almost made Rio smile. Almost.

She felt movement by her side that distracted her from Wanda’s reaction and looked down to see Nicky now standing before his mom, watching Wanda with a shy gaze.

“Oh,” Wanda laughed breezily, “Not the worst thing that’s been thrown on me. You must be Nicky?”

She bent down to grin at the boy and Agatha’s hand moved swiftly to his shoulder.

Nicky held out his hand to her and Rio bit her lip, taking it upon herself to introduce the two when Agatha remained silent. “Nicky, this is Wanda.”

Wanda shook his hand with an easy smile and then straightened up, “God, the internet was so right. It’s almost eerie. Has he ever thought of acting?”

Agatha opened her mouth to respond - Rio assumed in the negative, it would just be the degree of venom that would differ - but the waiter had placed himself closer again.

“Ladies? Will I make up a table for four?”

“Oh,” Wanda said, “no, thank you. Rio and I will take ours up to my room. Thanks so much.”

Agatha glanced at Rio and Rio saw the panic in her eyes before she had a chance to cool it and Rio couldn’t do anything but step forward and press her lips to Agatha’s cheek, muttering a quiet, “Just friends,” before she pulled back and ducked down to Nicky.

She gave him a quick squeeze and then watched as Wanda moved to place a kiss to Agatha’s other cheek and she caught the pursing of Agatha’s lips, the way she couldn’t even fake a smile.

But Wanda was leading her away, unabashed by the large red stain across her crisp white button down. And Rio followed, turning only when they were at the end of the long room to see Agatha taking a seat at a nearby table with Nicky, her attention on him, her eyes that soft way again.

“It’s Agatha, isn’t it,” Wanda said cautiously as they settled into the elevator to go up to her floor.

“You’ve got a crush.”

Rio cleared her throat, “On a married woman? How would not dating you help me with that?”

Wanda was silent for a while and Rio watched her as she bought into Rio’s lie, “The kid looks like you.”

“I’ve heard.”

She broke into a smile and Wanda glanced at her only to catch it too, laughing at the absurdity of it, “He’s cute.”

“Thank you.”

“Oh shut up.”

Rio laughed properly then, tugging at the still-damp and ruined shirt Wanda wore and Wanda slapped her away. Some of the tension broke in that little elevator and Wanda didn’t ask again about the proposed PR relationship.

Instead, they ate salads (they had to be red carpet ready), drank wine (Rio opted for white this time to save the soft furnishings in Wanda’s suite), and lounged around until Alice and Wanda’s manager came to find them to whisk them away for the prep ahead of them.

It was easy. But it wasn’t Agatha.

Rio’s prep didn’t take as long as it usually might because she’d opted for a block colour tux, red to her waist, and black along the bottom of the blazer, matching the pants which had a red stripe down the outer side of each leg.

It meant the focus of the afternoon’s work was on her face, and the part of her chest that would be exposed, rather than her whole body.

Which also meant there were fewer bodies surrounding her as she sipped an iced coffee through a straw and Alice read off the names of people she needed to thank if she won.

“I really don’t think-,” but she was cut off but a light kick to her shin. It was a good thing she was wearing pants. Alice had left some bruises from the previous night’s dinner.

“Just listen,” Alice insisted, “it’s good to thank the right people.”

Rio rolled her eyes and went back to staring at herself in the mirror wondering what Agatha would show up in tonight.

She thought of the way she’d held her face last night, searching for something Rio couldn’t figure out.

She thought of the strange mixture of hard and soft that made up Agatha’s personality. She thought of why she was so frightened all the time. And the heaviness that had settled hours ago started to churn in her hungry, salad-filled stomach.

“Get those?”

Rio’s brow twitched as Alice nudged her again.

“Of course.”

“How can you learn so many lines but not remember names.”

“I remember names.”

“Who did I just say last?”

Rio frowned a little and bit on her cheek, “Yourself?”

“Great.”

The makeup artist trying to perfect Rio’s eyeliner laughed and Rio grinned up at her, pleased someone was on her side at least.

“Did you coordinate your look tonight?”

“With who?”

“Agatha Harkness.”

In the mirror Rio caught Alice leaning closer.

“No? Why?”

“Well, there’s pictures of you everywhere and you’re the favourites to win and I just thought…”

Rio blinked up at the makeup artist and then looked up the ceiling when she moved to do her waterline. “Is Agatha in black?”

“Red.”

“How do-…?”

“We all know each other. We all talk. You’d be surprised what we know.”

A delicate hand pulled away to inspect her handiwork and Rio blinked up at her, fighting off the tears that always threatened to come whenever someone was anywhere near her eyes.

“Hear anything good from Agatha’s camp?”

It was like discovering gold at the end of the rainbow, this perfect, untapped source of knowledge, of information. She couldn’t help the question as she tilted her head back again to allow for her second eye to be painted.

“The usual. It’s always a little more tense over there when the husband’s around.”

“Oh?” Rio asked, feigning casual when she was suddenly rabid.

“Mmhm,” the artist hummed, “cute kid though.”

Rio opened her mouth to ask more questions but closed it again, wondering if she were being given as much as she could get already and she’d look too unprofessional if she asked more.

But she was saved the indignity of begging for details: “I know you’re friends with Agatha so I don’t want to say anything out of turn but… she can be frosty.”

Rio fought a smile but decided to remain silent.

“Not rude, apparently. Just… not friendly.”

Alice beside her looked up from her phone and said: “With a husband like that I think I’d be frosty too.”

Rio scoffed quietly and the makeup artist pulled away to admire her work with a smile, “Oh, she’s not the worst I’ve heard of. But I hear it’s been getting worse lately.”

This made Rio speak. “Oh? How so?”

She caught Alice looking at her through the mirror, caught the way her gaze dropped to Rio’s hands that now clutched at her sleeves, felt the way she continued to eye her as she got her answer: “Hard to say. A little more tense, maybe. I’ve only heard she’s been a bit snappier, is all.”

But to Rio, Agatha appeared sadder, softer, so if she were snappier that was news to her. Must be because she… but Alice was speaking and Rio lost her train of thought.

“Ralph told us last night they were in a really good place.”

Rio started to feel hot, too hot.

“He said they had a good Christmas and-…”

“That’s not true.”

Alice and the makeup artist both paused and looked around at Rio, one in slight shock, the other with a knowing glint in her eye.

“It’s just,” Rio trailed off, realising her bravado had overtaken her logical mind. “It’s just not true.”

“Okay, babe,” Alice said softly, reaching over to hold Rio’s hand and squeezing it but changing the subject immediately.

And Alice spoke so much for the rest of the day that Rio barely had time to dwell on Agatha’s apparent dip in moods or the fact that she was across the corridor with her husband or that Ralph was telling everyone who would listen how happy they were.

She thought she might see Agatha before they left for the Southbank Centre where the ceremony was to take place. But she saw nothing.

Though, apparently, this wasn’t the case for everyone. Because the lobby was full by the time Rio entered it with Alice. Everyone looked their way and Rio felt strangely judged by everyone suddenly, strangely inspected, strangely…

“Holy shit,” Alice said quietly, her grip on the back of Rio’s blazer as she carried two purses and her own phone.

Rio just pushed through, ignoring the stares as best she could. Until, finally, mercifully, she was stepping into their waiting car and the door was closed on the mayhem.

“That felt…”

“Yeah. Think everyone was expecting Wanda.”

“Oh, thanks.”

“No,” Alice huffed quietly, “You and Wanda.”

Rio’s head almost snapped off its axis as she turned to Alice. “What?”

Sighing like this was the fiftieth time Rio had asked today, Alice responded: “Some ‘source’ claimed you’d told some wannabe model you were seeing someone. The internet has decided that’s Wanda.”

“Fuck my life.”

“Yep. Well I’m pretty pleased.”

Rio turned to look out the window, and wondered why it wasn’t easy. Why everything made all of this harder and harder and the only time she ever felt sane and calm was when she was alone with Agatha.

The traffic made the journey to the red carpet last a lifetime and by the time Rio was in the centre of it all again, being followed up the carpet with a man and his large umbrella, she felt more tense than she usually did at these things - which was saying something.

But the rain helped.

It meant there was less time spent alone on the carpet, and more time huddled under large umbrellas, making small talk with vaguely familiar faces.

“Rio,” a hand found her lower back and a warmth by her shoulder told her that Agatha must be nearby, but this was not her, this was Ralph.

“Ralph,” she said with no hint at warmth as she turned just in time to receive a kiss to her cheek from the man who was still holding her back.

“You missed a fun night.”

“I’m sure.”

“Prefer to go home with my wife and young son? A sin, you know.”

“What’s that?”

“Coveting thy neighbour’s wife.”

Smarmy, sanctimonious shit.

Rio bit down so hard on her tongue she was surprised when she didn’t taste pennies.

“You look lovely, by the way.” His eyes darted briefly to the expanse of skin visible beneath Rio’s blazer, “Maybe you’ll find someone else to-…”

“Rio.”

Rio hadn’t realised that her hands were fists at her sides, that she was squeezing so hard she was hurting her bruised thumb, leaving indents of her nails in her palms. But a soft touch to her injured hand brought her back from the brink and Rio didn’t have to look to know who it was.

“Necesito hablar contigo.” I need to talk to you.

The whisper was soft, and took Rio by surprise, and she turned into Agatha, saw her blue gaze and red lips and she nodded, unfurling her fist to hold Agatha’s hand instead. “Okay. Let’s go-…”

“Later,” Agatha promised just as quietly, a small frown gracing her features as her gaze dropped to look Rio over. “You look good.”

“You look,” Rio breathed in slowly, her eyes trying and failing to take all of Agatha in as her brain equally failed to describe what she saw. Agatha’s makeup blocked her favourite freckles from view, but her red lips matched her red dress and the sight of it against Agatha’s pale skin was enough to make Rio fall to her knees all over again.

The bodice of the dress was tight to her torso and Rio’s free hand moved up to wrap around her upper ribs, unable to stop herself from reaching for the woman who’d left her alone in the dark the night before.

“You look-…”

She raised her gaze again, and saw a pain reflected back at her in blue eyes that made the weight in her stomach triple and her body react before she could think. She’d pulled Agatha back into her, wrapping the arm that held her waist tightly around her and squeezed their entwined fingers down at their sides.

Agatha had gasped into the hold and Rio felt her turn her head slightly when Rio whispered: “Esperé toda la noche a que volvieras.” I waited all night for you to come back.

Agatha pulled away, breaking Rio’s tight hold on her and grinned at Rio in a way that the receiver knew to be false because the giver’s eyes were swimming with unshed tears.

It was for the cameras, the people around them, for Ralph, but Rio couldn’t bring herself to lie anymore. And so she frowned at Agatha, saw the fault lines appear in the structured smile, and Agatha’s fingers squeeze her own so tightly she thought she’d have another bruise soon.

“Luego. Hablamos luego.” Later. Let’s talk later.

“Darling,” Ralph’s voice cut across them and Rio ignored it and Agatha did too, keeping her teary gaze on Rio as she watched her process the request. “Is that Spanish? Bon voyage, let’s go grab a drink before it starts.”

Rio barely reacted to his words, saw that Agatha hadn’t either, and she instead leant in to cup Agatha’s cheek and press a soft kiss before her ear, allowing herself to just brush her nose on the soft skin there before she pulled away and turned totally to Ralph.

“I’ll see you in there.”

Ralph only grinned and held his hand out to his wife who took it behind Rio and stepped around her. The soft squeeze of her hip hold her that Agatha had gone with her husband and Rio looked the other way so she didn’t have to see her again.

And Rio was alone again, only this time in a sea of people.

But not for long. No one is ever truly alone on a red carpet, shoulder to shoulder with other industry heavyweights, every move photographed, every turn noted down.

Buoyed along by the tide, Rio eventually made it to safer shores and entered the auditorium with Alice back by her side.

“Remember, Jen’s given us the go ahead but I’d really encourage you to stick with Wanda. Wanda and Agatha, if you have to. But Wanda. It’s good for the movie and it’s good for you. Those photos were golden and maybe lightning does strike twice.”

Rio couldn’t help but roll her eyes just as an attendant came to show them to their seats.

But Alice was still talking: “She’s hot and sweet and you already like her so I can’t see-…”

“Alice,” Rio whispered back, “please. Not now.” Alice didn’t say anything else as they moved towards their seats.

They were on the front row, and Rio had the pleasure of being beside Ralph, who sat beside Agatha on her right, Jen unfortunately having chosen her left side, meaning Rio was left with the husband.

She smiled at Jen, shot Agatha the same, and ignored Ralph.

“Lucky me,” he said with all the charm of a tapeworm as Rio took her seat and crossed her legs over neatly.

“Clearly I’m the lucky one,” Rio drawled, unable to look his way and instead choosing to turn around to see if anyone else was nearby that she could focus her attentions on whilst the audience settled in.

But she felt a hand on her knee and she was just about to slap it away - assuming Ralph - when she turned to see Agatha leaning across her husband and smiling up at her, “Try not to look too disappointed when I win.”

Rio’s chest swelled with warmth at the look on Agatha’s face, none of the softness from before was gone but she looked a little more hopeful, the warm hand that held her knee still, the teasing tone of her voice, she was back to her usual self, “Only if you promise not to gloat later on.”

“I’ll buy you a drink to make up for it.”

“It’s a free bar, superstar.”

“A poet now?”

Rio laughed and for a fleeting, happy moment, forgot that Agatha was only leaning this way because her husband was between them. Only Ralph wanted to make his presence known and he reached for Agatha’s hand and stole it away as a photographer came by to capture the three of them: two lovers, and the husband.

Rio smiled for the camera and then turned to catch Agatha’s eye and saw her smile had faded as quickly as her own had and she looked apologetic, almost guilty.

But Ralph was still holding her hand, and had wrapped his free arm around Agatha’s shoulders as if to keep her from leaning back in, but Rio wouldn’t give up without a fight. Not anymore.

“Okay, Agatha, a wager.”

A quirked brow and a twitch of Agatha’s lips was all the encouragement she needed.

“If you win, you can post on my insta. Any of my socials. Whatever you want,” Agatha’s grin grew and she tilted her head, leaning a little out of Ralph’s hold. “But if I win, then I get a dance. And photographic evidence of it.”

Ralph cleared his throat quietly but Agatha ignored it, and lifted her hand out from underneath her husband’s to hold it out to Rio, “You got yourself a deal, Vidal.”

Rio smirked shamelessly, squeezing Agatha’s hand as she shook it. “I look forward to our dance.”

“Yeah yeah,” Agatha laughed as she pulled away and settled back in her seat. Suddenly Ralph’s arm around Agatha mattered a little less, and Rio bit the inside of her cheek to hold back her grin as she leant back in her seat.

“Flirting,” Alice murmured from the corner of her mouth, watching Rio with a warning look in her eye. “Save some of that for Wanda.”

Rio only hummed and took advantage of Ralph stubbornly keeping his hold on Agatha and placed her arms on both the armrests now available to her, choosing to hold them to stake her claim properly.

It didn’t take long for the lights to dim and the show to start and Rio could only think of the woman two seats away, her husband having moved off of her - because of Agatha’s protests or through his own volition, Rio didn’t know.

But he couldn’t use the armrest to his right which was barely a victory, but it was something.

The comedian hosting the night was funny, so much so that Rio didn’t have to fake her laughs as the cameras swung close. But the ceremony was still long, made ever longer by the constant movement of Ralph beside her.

He was bored, that much was clear. He wasn’t interested in celebrating the wins of Agatha’s cast or crew, and he made sure to be touching his wife in some way when the cameras were near. For that, Rio supposed, she couldn’t blame him. She’d have her hands constantly on Agatha if she could.

Theirs was the penultimate award, and Rio had a strange feeling in her stomach that felt a lot like nerves. The shock of winning the Globe hadn’t really left her so anything could happen tonight; though the fans, the trades, the critics, all believed the BAFTA was Agatha’s.

The winner of last year’s Best Actor stood proudly centre stage and twinkled down at the audience before him.

Rio felt Alice take her hand.

She saw Ralph do the same with Agatha.

The nominees were read out. The cameras were honing in. The envelope was being opened.

“And the BAFTA for Best Actress goes to…”

Rio sucked in a breath, kept her smile up on her face, felt Alice dig her nails in.

“Agatha Harkness!”

And Rio released the breath she’d been holding, and she stood with the rest of the audience, and she turned just in time to see Agatha being kissed by her husband.

She kept her smile up, kept clapping, and fought off the need to fight this man then and there. But Agatha met her gaze over Ralph’s shoulder and her need to fight died at the sight of blue eyes.

Agatha moved over and pulled Rio to her, hugging her close and whispering, “Regretting that little bet?”

She pulled away and gave Rio a dazzling smile before she turned up to walk up the stairs to accept her award. And Rio was dazzled.

Agatha was dazzling.

“Wow. Wow, wow, wow.”

A Hollywood smile, a sprinkle of humility in her laugh.

“From British people this just feels so much more special.”

The audience ate it up.

“I’ll do the polite thing and keep this short. I…” and Rio caught her eyes, just for a second, and felt a swell of pride in her chest. “I’d first like to thank my fellow actresses, the immense talent in this category, the friendships we’ve forged.” The swell settled and Rio bit down on her tongue, aware of a camera close by. “the admiration I have for you all,” Agatha’s eyes flickered up and Rio caught her gaze again, it held this time, and Agatha smiled a little as she said, “I can’t wait to dance with you later.”

Rio beamed up at her and Agatha turned just as she caught the smile, just as her own face split into a grin that lit up the whole stage.

“To my cast, my crew, this is a result of your hard work, your dedication, and your love for this project. Before I go, I’d just like to…” but Agatha’s lips twitched in a way that suggested she was feeling real emotion and Rio wanted to go to her. “I am a mother before I am anything else. And this role made me experience even a tiny piece of what it would be to be a mother without her child and I… to all the mothers, the parents out there, experiencing child loss, of feeling as though your heart is broken outside your body, I see you. I’m holding you. Thank you.”

Rio watched this married mother of a shy little boy leave the stage and she yearned for her. She wanted to step up there and follow her backstage, to hold her hand and kiss her face. But she sat, beside her husband, clapping with a smile on her face as the cameras remained close.

In the change over between Agatha leaving and the new presenter arriving, Ralph leant in: “She looks beautiful, doesn’t she? This gorgeous thing that everybody admires, wearing my ring, sleeping in my bed. I’m the luckiest son of a bitch in this audience.”

It was irrational to be angry, futile to be jealous, but Rio felt both things so viscerally she could have screamed. Maybe it was that she’d been on her knees for Agatha the night before, that she’d confessed her love and still been left alone, but she found she couldn’t respond, she couldn’t even fake a smile, she simply turned away and pressed her lips close to Alice’s ear so no one else could see or hear what she was saying: “I’m going to get drunk tonight.”

Agatha didn’t return after her win, and Jen had slipped away to go and help her in the press rooms out back.

The show went on and Rio found herself zoned out, counting down the seconds until she could have a glass of wine in her hand or a shot of tequila burning down her throat.

When the show came to an end and Rio left her seat before most, pulling Alice with her to escape smalltalk with Ralph. She found Wanda and after exchanging compliments and a quick hug she repeated her promise to Alice from earlier in Wanda’s ear. Wanda was much more encouraging of this behaviour than Alice had been.

The audience of Hollywood’s elite, of the British talent, of the execs and producers and wallets with legs, all funnelled into the space designated for drinks and debauchery. Some disappeared off to other parties across the city, but Rio held tight to Wanda, caring only that Wanda held her hand close and that she didn’t care who saw it.

Rio was three glasses of wine deep by the time she saw Agatha again.

Neither had changed from their ceremony outfits and Rio was once again reminded of the power of a pretty girl in a pretty dress.

The lights of the room span and flashed and Rio was briefly blinded by them, and missed Agatha’s first steps as she made her way over to her, BAFTA in hand.

“Hey,” Wanda said from her side, her hand still in Rio’s, “We need to pose a little more. Ham it up.”

“I’m not-…”

“Hey.”

Agatha had pulled Rio into her, turned her with one strong arm around her waist, and in doing so Rio automatically dropped Wanda’s comforting hold on her hand.

“I need to talk to you,” Agatha whispered by her ear, pulling away only to scan over Rio’s surprised face, frowning a little at the sight of drunk eyes.

“Congratulations!” Wanda announced as she stepped closer and placed a hand on the arm around Rio, “Really, Agatha. And everyone was tearing up at your speech. It was…”

Agatha moved her arm from Rio, grasping her lapels briefly where she kept her eyes on her rather than on Wanda. And Rio turned away, catching the hurt in Wanda’s eyes and not knowing how to fix it.

She took Wanda’s hand back in her own when Agatha dropped her hold entirely and said, “Your husband’s over there somewhere. We’re just going to get-…”

“Champagne, please,” Agatha said, though it was more a demand than a request and Rio looked back around in surprise to see that some of the softness from before was gone. “I’ll wait here for you.”

Rio only nodded, her lips twitching just slightly as she made to pull Wanda away with her, feeling dizzy with the intensity of it all.

“Rio,” Wanda insisted as she pressed into her side when they were at the bar and she placed Rio’s hand that had been holding her own to her hip, “Kiss me.”

Rio blinked, turning to her hopeful friend and seeing what she’d suspected all along writ large across her open features.

“I can’t.”

“Tell me why.”

Rio’s hold tightened a little and she pursed her lips as they were jostled by the people around them fighting for room in the crowded space.

“Because it would mean more to you than to me.”

“I’m okay with that.”

A humourless laugh floated between them that Rio just couldn’t contain and she saw reflected in Wanda’s gaze some of the pain she was feeling.

“I’m not. Let’s just be friends. Please?”

Wanda nodded and dropped her gaze so Rio dropped her hold and didn’t reach back out for her hand. They silently fetched drinks and made polite smalltalk with everyone who approached but the air about them had shifted and Rio knew she couldn’t in good conscience reach back out for the comfort of Wanda’s hand again that night.

They made their way back to Agatha and found her surrounded by well-wishers and sycophants.

Rio slipped in to pass her champagne over and found the little group opening up for her and Wanda to stand. Agatha had no free hand for Rio to try and take but as the conversation swirled around them, Agatha shifted and Rio glanced at her, seeing her arm flex with effort as she carried the heavy metal mask that was her BAFTA award.

She didn’t think before she took it from her, holding it to give some relief to the woman beside her who then twisted her wrist to work it out and then squeezed Rio’s arm in gratitude.

“And Agatha,” someone said as Agatha pulled her hand away from Rio’s arm, “Where’s that charming husband of yours?”

“Oh, off being charming somewhere else,” Agatha said dismissively, moving so her arm was now pressed against Rio’s holding her award.

Rio looked over the heads of the crowd to see if Ralph were anywhere near but saw no familiar jawline, heard no barking voice, no sign of his clicking fingers in the air seeking another drink.

She sipped her champagne, focused on the soft pressure of the woman beside her, only vaguely paying attention to the conversation and adding where she needed to until people began to move along and Agatha muttered, “I hate these things.”

“You do? You’re so…”

“What?” Agatha moved to stand before Rio, blocking her from all who dared approach, “Charming? Witty? Eloquent?”

“I was going to say ‘at ease’, but maybe I mean arrogant.”

Agatha laughed and shrugged, and Rio fell for her all over again. “Maybe. Years of my mother’s social conditioning.”

“She must be so proud,” Wanda said innocently, and Agatha turned to her with raised brows, looking almost as if she forgot she were there.

“She must be.”

Rio cleared her throat quietly, “Wanda earlier was admiring your dress.” Nice, easy, basic small talk would save them all.

“We all match,” Wanda added with a hopeful smile, picking up what Rio was putting down quickly, “Maybe we should recreate what went so viral at the Globes.”

“Red on top,” Agatha said with a smile as she touched Rio’s red shoulder, her eyes on Wanda in a way that let Rio know the safety of the small talk manoeuvre had not worked.

And Rio realised then that Agatha had done it on purpose. She’d worn a dress that would match her tux and Rio suddenly stared down at what Agatha was wearing and raised her arm to wrap around Agatha’s waist, holding her award upright against her hip.

The impact on her heart was immediate. In the rain outside she’d been too busy admiring to notice. In the glamour of the ceremony she’d been too distracted to see. And now, with Agatha pressed against her side, her pale arm snaking its way around Rio’s shoulders, she saw what she’d missed: she’d matched them.

The colour was an exact copy, the red of Rio’s blazer bleeding into the red of Agatha’s dress as they pressed together and Rio bit down on her lip as she caught Agatha’s eye.

She’d turned to her with an amused smile, watching the realisation hit in real time. “Strange how we managed to match.”

Rio turned away, feeling that dizzy way again that wasn’t a result of the alcohol she’d consumed.

“So,” Wanda tried again, avoiding looking at how Rio and Agatha fit against each other, “Can we? Some pictures? There’s been some taken already I’m sure but,” and with the confidence only an actress could muster, even in the presence of a woman who was not a fan, and had much more power than her in the industry, Wanda moved over and placed her hands on both of their arms.

Agatha smiled tightly and Rio felt her flex her hold on her as she turned to Wanda, “Perhaps we should sit.”

“Yes,” Wanda agreed with a grin that to Rio looked a little frightened, but she continued anyway, “good idea.” And Wanda peeled away, leading the other two who hadn’t yet moved.

“You matched my tux?” Rio asked quietly, turning a little more into Agatha so they were facing each other properly, the heavy award now resting on the small of Agatha’s back.

“We should talk, Rio.”

Agatha’s face was soft again, her expression open and if Rio didn’t know any better she might think tortured. But the wine was making her a little hazy around the edges and Agatha was scanning her over, a far cry from the tense woman she’d just been in Wanda’s presence.

“Are you toying with me?”

The weight in Rio’s stomach shifted, shrunk, sizzled inside her, but Rio had to know, had to find out if all of this, if Agatha the great and powerful, were stringing her along for her own amusement and colour-matching was just another clever torture device.

“No,” Agatha shook her head slightly, a deep frown changing her face as she watched Rio think it over, “It’s not a game.”

Rio swallowed and nodded once, her heart feeling a little lighter when Agatha pressed her palm over it, pressed so firmly Rio thought she might slip her fingers through the fabric, slip them right through her flesh and bone and take what was rightfully hers.

“We should go,” Agatha whispered as she pressed more firmly, moved a little closer, and Rio gasped at the intensity of her gaze, at the hold she had on her.

It lasted all of a second longer before Agatha pulled back and took Rio’s wrist to pull her through the noise to find Wanda again.

And Rio followed dumbly, holding Agatha’s award and the champagne glass that was now almost empty.

They made their way to a corner and Rio sat beside Agatha only to be told to move into the middle by Wanda but held back by Agatha’s hold on her.

“She’s fine here.”

And Rio could only lean over, could only offer Wanda a reassuring smile as she draped an arm over the back of the couch, resting the BAFTA there, turned her body into Agatha’s, and reached her hand holding her champagne over to Wanda’s lap.

“This is really starting to feel a bit too contrived, no?”

But Agatha snuck her arm around her waist and suddenly, contrived or not, there was nowhere Rio would rather be.

“You can leave if you want to,” Agatha said softly, and Rio didn’t dare turn her head for fear she’d faint before her, but she kept her eyes on Wanda, watching as she reached to hold her wrist, leaning in to say in a whisper: “Just three friends enjoying each other’s company.”

Rio hummed quietly but smiled as Wanda did and risked glancing at Agatha. The risk paid off. Agatha’s gaze had been on Rio’s chest and Rio wondered if the angle gave Agatha more to see than her stylist had intended. But blue eyes jumped back up again and Rio smiled at her, enjoying the brief look of embarrassment on Agatha’s face and the fingers that dug into the sensitive spot at her waist that made her jerk a little and pull back.

“There you are!”

All three women turned to look up at the man now smiling down at them, a double whiskey in his clutches. “Babe, let’s go make the rounds. I need to show you off.”

Rio’s jaw clenched and she felt Agatha squeeze her reassuringly, her hand moving slowly away from her, “I’ll catch you later? Don’t get drunk, okay?”

Rio could only lean back, giving Agatha the space she needed to stand up, but found she’d stopped to press her lips to Rio’s cheek before she did so and brushed the lipstick left her as she whispered more urgently than before, “Por favor mantente sobria.” Please stay sober.

It took her off guard, the earnestness of the request. Rio’s stomach churned at Agatha’s words, and her need to be alone with Agatha flared so desperately in her chest that she could almost cry for it.

But Agatha left and she knocked back her last dregs of champagne, stealing Wanda’s to finish off too as Agatha and Ralph disappeared into the crowd with her award back in her hand.

Ralph hadn’t taken it for her. Prick.

Wanda moved into her side. “The greatest tragedy on earth is that she’s married to that man.”

Rio scoffed and leant forwards to place Wanda’s glass down, “Isn’t it?”

“And you know the second greatest?”

“Mm?”

“It’s that you can’t see what’s right in front of you when she’s around.”

Rio turned her head and saw Wanda look down, taking Rio’s free hand to hold gently, her fingers toying with Rio’s in a way that made Rio want to die. “You were right before. It would mean more to me. But is that so bad, Rio? I think that you could grow to feel differently about me.”

“I love you. I’m just not in love with you.”

Wanda nodded, her gaze still down on their fingers, and Rio moved her arm from the back of the couch to drape over her shoulders, pulling her a little closer, “You’ll get over it soon,” she tried gently, ducking her head to try and catch Wanda’s gaze, “I’m not that great.”

“Oh I know that,” Wanda shot back, gracing Rio with a brilliant smile, “I’m not in love. It’s just a tiny crush, is all. And I was kinda hoping to get laid tonight.”

Rio released a laugh and rolled her eyes as she leant back in the seat again, “Well you’ve basically got your pick of London, so.”

“Will Alice let you off your leash enough to come dancing later?”

Rio smirked as she turned to Wanda, “I’m sure that could be arranged.”

Rio’s mission then, despite Agatha’s request, was to get as drunk as possible. The prospect of Agatha wanting to talk to her and potentially leave her on her knees again - figuratively or not - loomed larger and larger as time went on and with every glance in the Oscar-winner’s direction, made only slightly more palatable by the dulling affect of the alcohol now flowing bountifully through her veins.

She managed to keep it together to talk to the right people, charm the important ones, and not make Alice want to string her up by her ankles. It was only Jen who had a vocal problem with her less than sober state.

“I told you I wanted you with Agatha tonight. Where have you been? Up at the bar by the looks of it.”

Rio only laughed and draped an arm over Jen’s shoulder, allowing the taller woman to catch her waist as if afraid she’d fall, “Jen. Agatha has been with her shitty husband all evening.”

“Rio,” Jen insisted quickly, her hold moving from cautious to firm as she glanced around them and pushed Rio back out of the throng of people nearby. She turned them and took Rio’s hand to pull her clean away, only stopping once they were in a quieter area and she could crowd Rio into the wall to keep her from leaving.

Rio only watched her in amusement, “What? You think he isn’t shitty?”

“I think-,” Jen snapped and then released a slow breath, pinching the bridge of her nose as she thought it over for a second, “That you’re drunk and I think Agatha is a grown woman and has made her choices. If one of them happens to be a shitty one then-…”

“Jen he’s a moron. He couldn’t even get them to the car last night. Couldn’t even…”

“Look, Rio, I know you’re sweet on her-.”

Rio laughed and turned her face away, looking out over the mass of people all dressed in their finery. It seemed so false to her in that moment, so vacuous and meaningless. No one was wearing a genuine smile. Everyone was fawning, preening, pawing.

But Jen had moved closer and was holding her arms, her face a little sterner than before. “Rio, I don’t like him anymore than you do.”

Rio scoffed.

“But she’s been with him for eighteens years and they have a son together.”

“She’s miserable.”

Jen’s fingers tightened briefly against Rio’s arms and Rio turned to look at her, seeing for the first time in Jen’s gaze a strange mix of sadness and resolve. “I know.”

“Then why-.”

“Agatha’s complicated. And she has Nicky. Nicky is all she-,” someone moved past, closer than before and Jen glanced around and cleared her throat as she dropped her hold on Rio’s arms and turned her gaze back to her.

“My makeup artist told me she’s been snappier lately. She’s been morose or angry or-…”

Jen sighed and glanced around again, brushing down the front of her blue dress in what to Rio looked like an attempt to buy time. “It’s a stressful time.”

Rio just shook her head and turned away again, leaning fully now against the wall and letting her gaze drift over the sea of people trying to spot the woman she was looking for.

“I’m going to ask you something. Not as her manager. As her best friend.”

Rio’s gaze drifted back to Jen and she frowned as she saw the hesitation on Jen’s face, her wide brown eyes unable to quite meet her own gaze.

“After all this is over, don’t drop her, okay?”

“Jen.”

“No, I know, I… god she’d kill me for saying this but… Rio, you don’t need to tell me anything. I’m not asking for-… just…” but Jen trailed off and Rio’s eyes widened as she took in the woman before her now scanning over her face. “Look, I don’t know what’s going on exactly but I know… I know something is. I’m just asking you to go easy. Please. And to keep… to keep it… please be...”

Jen cleared her throat and Rio stepped into her to pull her into a tight hug, not trusting her drunk brain to say what she wanted to without letting slip more than she meant. Jen took a second to respond but eventually hugged her back and Rio sighed heavily into it, squeezing her eyes closed.

“Have I missed something?”

Standing just a foot away was Agatha, and Rio frowned as she opened her eyes to see her, a blazer draped over her shoulders that she knew must be Ralph’s covering the top of the brilliant red dress that matched Rio’s outfit. She pulled away from Jen and ran a hand through her hair just to give herself something to do.

“Jen was just,” she started but was unable to think of anything to say so Jen picked up the slack for her: “Just consoling the loser over here. Are you ready to go?”

“Yeah, can I get a second with the loser first?”

Rio scoffed and turned away and Jen left them both to it.

Neither of them moved or said anything for a while until they both spoke at once:

“Is that Ralph’s?”/“You're drunk?”

Rio looked over and met Agatha’s soft gaze with a deep frown, unable to look for long until her eyes fell to the man’s blazer over her pale shoulders.

“I couldn’t exactly take yours,” Agatha said quietly as she moved closer, taking up Jen’s spot now in front of her and reaching to hold Rio’s right hand in her left.

“You’re drunk,” she said again, though this time it wasn’t a question, a frown returning to her features as her eyes scanned over Rio’s face, though Rio still refused to meet her gaze.

“Only a little.”

“I wanted to talk to you.”

“Right. Well I’m too drunk for that so maybe another time.”

She looked up then, a fire flaming across her cheeks as she caught Agatha’s tender expression, as the hand that held hers now moved to release it and her fingers pushed beneath Rio’s sleeve to stroke intimately at the soft skin at the inside of Rio’s wrist.

“When are you leaving tomorrow?”

“First thing.”

They were both silent for a while and then, in a voice so quiet and so soft Rio felt her chest tighten at the sound of it, Agatha asked, “Are you pulling away?”

Rio’s eyes closed with the weight of her feelings. Her lips parted but no sound came and Agatha’s soft touches to her wrist only made it all worse, because they were secret, hidden from view of anyone else, just for her, just like everything else between them.

“Rio? I’m sorry for the way I left yesterday. I-…”

Rio blinked her eyes back open, her chest aching with the need to be alone with Agatha again and she shook her head as she watched her, took a step closer even as Agatha took a smaller one back.

Rio struggled for words again but found something to say that her drunken mind couldn’t compute hadn’t been part of this conversation: “I’m not shitty.”

“I know,” Agatha said quietly, nodding a little. She tore her gaze from Rio and glanced over her shoulder briefly before she turned back to her. “I know you’re not.”

“And we look good together.” Rio’s free hand raised to vaguely motion between them, the red on red making her feel bolder, and the wine helping stoke the flames of it.

“I know,” Agatha breathed out, even more softly this time and Rio found she couldn’t look anymore, she just stared down somewhere around Agatha’s mid-section.

“I’d give you my blazer if you were cold.”

“I know,” Agatha repeated again, her fingers still tickling steadily over Rio’s inner wrist. “You’re not wearing anything underneath it.”

“That isn’t the point.”

“I know.”

Rio forced herself to look up, dragging her gaze slowly across the expanse of pale skin on offer to her, trailing along a perfect jawline, pausing at a perfect nose, landing finally on swirling baby blues.

“I want you to leave him.”

Agatha sucked in a breath, and her cheeks flushed a soft pink, and Rio moved in to pull Agatha to her, dislodging the hand up her sleeve, and instead pressing her arms beneath the blazer that smelled of Ralph.

But the borrowed jacket gave Rio a semblance of protection from any curious onlookers, the one decent thing Ralph had perhaps ever done in his life, though unwittingly. It meant she could hold Agatha for a little longer, squeeze her tighter, press her as close as she could muster.

All Rio could feel was Agatha, all she ever wanted to feel was Agatha. And the arms that encircled her neck told her that the woman in her arms wanted her too.

She just hadn’t said anything, so Rio clung to what she felt rather than what she knew. And she pulled away, leaving her hands on Agatha’s waist, hidden from anyone’s view.

“I can’t wait forever.” Ask me to.

Agatha nodded imperceptibly, her lips parted but no words passing them.

“I need to go.” I love you.

Agatha frowned but Rio moved swiftly to press a kiss to Agatha’s cheek and stepped around her before she could do anything else.

From her peripheral vision she saw Jen watching her, and realised she’d kept close the whole time, watching her client and Rio like a hawk.

But Rio didn’t have the energy or heart to care who was watching her anymore and she pushed through the hoards of people until she found the person she was looking for.

“Hey, let’s get out of here. I need to dance.”

Wanda only grinned in response and took Rio’s waiting hand in her own as they left, two losers in love, into the night.

Chapter End Notes

Jen and Alice trying to help but pulling in opposite directions I’m sure that’ll be good

And no, Ralph doesn’t know Spanish but he does know bon voyage is French he’s not a total moron just a total knob

Also just a note that all Spanish is google translate so if it’s wrong I’m so sorry

Chapter 22: Stolen Valour

Chapter Summary

Rio takes a pill and it’s hard to swallow.

Agatha runs away.

Chapter Notes

This took me soooo long to write but in the interim I loved reading all your comments so thank you for caring about these two as much as I do

Please be nice to Wanda

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“God, you’re so fucking hot.”

Rio had lost track of everything but long hair and a hand beneath her blazer, warm over her breast. Her body thrummed with the music around her, though she could pick out no discernible lyrics, make no decisions as to which artist to thank for their magnificent offering into the wonderful world of noughties pop music.

It was nice like this, she decided, nice to not think, to be in her body, to experience the feeling of someone against her. She liked being touched.

Someone was kissing her neck, perhaps the same person who’s hand it was against her skin, perhaps not. It felt good either way.

The lights of the nightclub provided little relief to the haze Rio was in, making it harder to focus on something solid, something real.

But the feeling was real, the feeling was good.

Her mind was empty and she felt like a million fireflies were sparking up inside her.

“Blitzed” would have been the perfect word to describe it. Though Rio wasn’t sure if it were appropriate to use such a word in London.

But her brain power was focused on more important things right now, like who was groping her, who was kissing up her neck, and who was shouting her name from close by.

The perfect little pill had passed her lips not half an hour before and was washed down with warm beer and the hands of a pretty girl encouraging the concoction to slip down her throat. Rio had lost her mind for the sake of soft hands and softer lips - she’d lost her mind for much less before.

She closed her eyes as the haze grew and the shouting got louder and she felt a tongue reach her ear before it was rudely snatched away and more hands found her head.

They were harsher but somehow familiar.

“Feels good,” she mumbled with a lazy, slightly off-kilter grin, her eyes still closed as she felt bodies moving around and on top of her.

And then, no one was touching her, and she woke with a start, sitting bolt upright in bed, her head spinning and her memory blank.

The room was familiar but only vaguely so and she turned nervously to see what she could already feel was beside her. There was a wave of red hair splayed out across the pillow just beside where Rio’s head had been and beneath it Wanda Maximoff slept soundly, curled under the heavy duvet.

Rio glanced down at herself and saw a t-shirt she didn’t recognise, felt below the blankets a pair of shorts that weren’t hers, and cautiously moved to see if Wanda were similarly dressed.

She was, and so Rio lay back down and reached for her, placing a gentle hand on her side.

“Hey,” Rio whispered softly, shaking Wanda to get her to rouse, “Wanda.”

Wanda groaned and rolled onto her other side, squinting over at Rio with a frown that slowly morphed into a smile, “Hey. Feeling okay?”

“What happened?”

“You don’t remember?”

Rio shook her head and began chewing on her lip, noting that they were dry and her mouth felt dry too. Her head was thumping painfully and she realised whatever she’d taken hadn’t been a clean high.

“I lost you for a bit in the club. You were so drunk I got worried and when I found you I think you’d taken something and this girl was…” Rio’s eyes flashed in panic and Wanda moved her warm hand to Rio’s cheek, “She was feeling you up but you weren’t all there so I took you away and brought you home.”

“And we didn’t…?”

Wanda’s smile widened a little and Rio huffed in embarrassment. “No. We didn’t.”

“I’m sorry you didn’t get laid.”

“It’s okay. I made out with someone extremely good looking so.”

“What stopped you going all the way?”

“I caught sight of my good friend Rio Vidal high on molly and off her face with a random brunette in her lap.”

Rio groaned and rolled onto her back, hiding her face in her hands, “Jesus.”

“If it helps at all she was a total-…”

“Don’t. It doesn’t help.”

Wanda sighed quietly and Rio felt her shift next to her, and turning she saw she’d leant up on her elbow to smile down at her, “You’re very charming whilst completely off your face. You kept telling me how you were going to propose.”

Rio frowned, turning to Wanda in complete disbelief, unsure she’d heard her correctly, “Propose?”

“To Agatha.”

Wanda said the words like they meant nothing to her, like they were an obvious answer to an obvious question. But Rio hadn’t even admitted to herself - at least when sober - that she wanted to marry Agatha and she had certainly never told anyone else this. Let alone a woman who had just the previous night told her that she had a crush on her. A woman who had protected Rio when she didn’t need to, a woman who was now smiling at her, soft and warm.

“Oh my god, Wanda.” Rio sat up as sharply as she had when she woke up, only this time she was on her knees before Wanda, her eyes as wild as her hair, though Wanda just looked back at her calmly, a warm smile on her face as she sat back against the headboard. “I was just… I was high I-…”

“It’s okay. You don’t need to explain. Like I said, it was very charming.”

Rio groaned and dropped her head into her hands, allowing Wanda to take hold of her wrist lightly, “You love her. You didn’t even say it you were just rambling on about making her happy but I lost you when you went into Spanish.”

Rio groaned again and flopped down onto the bed, keeping her face covered because she could feel the heat in her cheeks. “That’s so fucking lame.”

“It’s not. She’s a lucky woman to have someone so smitten.”

Rio didn’t say anything for a while but she felt Wanda shift and she looked up to see her kneeling beside her with a smile, “Way to let a girl down though.”

The wind was knocked out of Rio then, at how soft Wanda was, how gracious she was with Rio making out with a stranger then telling her how much she loved someone else. And so she didn’t protest when Wanda leant in slowly and pressed her lips cautiously against Rio’s.

It was surprising, how good it felt, how soft Wanda’s lips were. How warm the hand was that cupped her cheek, how tender the thumb that brushed the tear that Rio hadn’t been aware she was crying.

“Rio,” Wanda whispered quietly as she pulled back and Rio blinked owlishly up at her. “I don’t stand a chance, do I?”

Rio sucked in a soft breath and felt Wanda brush away another tear but shook her head slightly, frowning up at Wanda as if seeing her for the first time.

“No. No, it’s… it’s just her.”

“Okay,” Wanda whispered softly, pulling her hand away, “I just had to check.”

Rio could only nod, only close her eyes and turn her head away as she felt Wanda move back up the bed.

They were both silent for a while until Rio decided she couldn’t lay around miserable and guilty any longer so she forced herself to sit and look at Wanda curled into herself by the headboard.

“Thank you for…”

“Don’t mention it. And don’t worry about any evidence of… y’know, there weren’t any paps around so worst case scenario it’ll be grainy pictures in the club but I didn’t see anyone near you.”

“Okay,” Rio whispered, moving now to kiss Wanda’s cheek, “but I mean it: thank you. Even if you did apparently strip me and put me in your clothes.”

Wanda laughed and swatted her away, “I didn’t look… much.”

“Whatever,” Rio smiled as she slid from the bed, momentarily pausing as her centre of gravity shifted and she felt dizzy. But she righted herself and went to sweep the floor for her expensive, and most likely ruined, suit.

“Safe flight,” Wanda called out from behind her as Rio smiled and slipped out the door onto a random floor in the Ritz. She looked up and down the hallway before she chose a direction and took it until she found the elevator and went to her floor with no option other than to knock on Alice’s door.

There was no answer for a long while until the door was ripped open and Jen stood before her, and Rio’s heart sank.

“Jesus, Rio.”

She was pulled inside.

“Rio,” Alice announced from where she sat up in bed. Rio hadn’t expected a warm welcome but she hadn’t exactly expected this.

A hand on her back pushed her further into the room and Alice swung her legs over the side of the bed, her phone in her white-knuckled hand. “Are you okay?”

“I’m fine.”

“Good, because I’d really like for you to explain to me why you were in the middle of a club with some bitch’s hand down your blazer.”

Rio grimaced, and even if she’d wanted to explain, she wouldn’t have been able to. She didn’t remember whose hands had been where. Or even what club they’d been in.

“Alice, I-…”

Jen had moved around her to perch on the end of the bed.

“Explain, Rio.”

“Champagne, molly, exhaustion, I… what else is there to explain?”

“Jesus.”

Rio turned away and went to curl up on one of the armchairs in the corner, dropping her suit unceremoniously on the floor by her feet before rubbing her face with her hands, “What time is it?”

“Just after five.”

Rio could only hold her knees to her chest, staring down at the carpet as she felt the weight of two pairs of eyes on her. It was Jen who spoke first, and Rio’s eyes snapped up to hers when she realised she, at least, wasn’t angry. “Wanda took you home?”

“Apparently. She said there weren’t any paps.”

“Good. Good. That’s something.”

“Are the pictures… are they bad?”

Alice moved over to her and held out her phone. The screen showed a slightly blurry photo of Rio sitting back with her arms splayed out either side of her and a brunette in her lap, one hand pushed below the opening of her blazer, her face pressed in against Rio’s neck. Rio’s head was tilted back, her eyes closed, her mouth wide open.

It was embarrassing to say the least.

“Shit.”

“It’s just one, so far but…” and Alice trailed off, her gaze dropping from Rio’s blushing cheeks to a deep bruise on her neck. She reached to brush her hair back and poked it, making Rio hiss, “Holy shit.”

“We’re so close Rio. So close to getting what we want and you just-…”

“Alright,” Jen said suddenly, moving over to drape an arm around Alice as Rio covered the right side of her neck with her hand, “okay. It’s done. There’s one picture. It’s not as if someone’s done something illegal… minus the molly… but it’s just a single girl having a good time, that’s all.”

Rio looked up and caught Jen’s eye and saw that she was smiling just a little, and maybe Rio was still a little drunk but she seemed to be on her side with this and so Rio relaxed slightly, slowly lowering her hand from her neck.

“I just-…” Alice started with a huff and then caught herself and caught Rio’s gaze, “You’re safe,” she said after a second, “that’s what matters.”

Rio chewed on the inside of her cheek and watched the thoughts paint a picture across Alice’s face. She waited until they’d settled slightly and then she uncurled herself and reached for her to pull her close and when Alice relented into the hug Rio only held on tighter until she felt Alice give in properly.

“Mm’sorry,” she mumbled into Alice’s hair, and she felt Alice squeeze her and saw Jen turn away, striding back to the bed to give them some space.

“I’m sending Wanda flowers,” Alice mumbled, “So many fucking flowers.”

Rio laughed a little and Alice slowly pulled away but braced herself on the arms of the chair so Rio’s hold could remain but they could look at each other properly, “Did you sleep with her?”

“No. She just put me to bed.”

“Okay. Did you fuck the girl in the bar?”

Rio sighed quietly, “No. Wanda saw what was happening and pulled her off me and took me home.”

“Maybe a whole orchard or something. Think you can buy those?”

Rio rolled her eyes but Alice’s lips twitched a little and she leant in to press a kiss to Rio’s cheek. “You need to brush your teeth.”

Rio scoffed and pushed Alice away then, huffing as she strode through to the bathroom and picked up the first toothbrush she saw - assuming the pink one was Jen’s she avoided that one.

“Dammit Rio not my-!” But Rio had already emerged with the blue toothbrush hanging from her mouth and Alice just rolled her eyes as she sat back on the bed with Jen. “I know where that mouth has been. I hate when you do that.”

But Rio just smiled around it and went to perch on the bed beside Alice, brushing her teeth with her toothbrush as if nothing had happened.

“At least it’s a flattering photo,” Jen yawned out as she squinted at her own phone and zoomed in, “No nip slip either.”

“Thks,” Rio mumbled around the toothbrush and a little fleck of frothy toothpaste spilled onto her chin. Alice grimaced and shoved at her until she moved back to the bathroom.

It was as she was spitting up that she heard a knock on the door and she froze, her toothbrush in midair and her lips a whiter shade of pale. She heard the door open and a familiar voice in the room and she wanted suddenly to find a hiding place in the modern, glass-forward bathroom.

She spat again, rinsed the stolen toothbrush, and wiped her mouth on the back of her hand. In the mirror she stared back at herself, her eyes a little wider than usual, her hair fluffier, more wild than usual, her skin bare and tired looking.

And there, the evidence of her night, sat purple and obvious against the right side of her neck. She touched it lightly as she heard voices but couldn’t derive meaning from them.

But she could recognise the new one that had entered the fray.

She had no choice but to face Agatha, to see why she was in Alice’s room at five in the morning, to hope that she wouldn’t notice the mark of another woman on her neck.

Just as she moved her hair across her right shoulder Agatha appeared in the door.

“Hey,” she said softly, her eyes on Rio through the mirror.

Rio sucked in a breath and turned slowly to her, forcing a smile, “What’re you doing up?”

“I wanted to say goodbye but when you didn’t answer your door I thought I should… I just wanted to check you were okay.”

Rio nodded and gripped the sink behind her for support as her legs began to tremble beneath her. And Agatha was moving into the room, closing the door behind her. It made Rio look away, drop her gaze and chew on her lip, unable to look at Agatha as she stepped closer and tugged at the front of her light grey t-shirt.

“Is this…?”

“Wanda’s. I borrowed it.”

Agatha dropped the fabric like she’d been burned and Rio looked up to catch her gaze then, seeing the flames in her blue eyes. “I got drunk, was off my face, and she took me home and put me to bed, that’s all.”

But Agatha’s gaze had dropped again, and Rio knew immediately what she was looking at. Her hair had shifted without her realising it and the bruise was now visible to anyone looking close enough. And Agatha was looking closely.

She reached the hand that had just touched Rio’s borrowed shirt and she brushed back Rio’s hair to see the mark on her skin. Rio gasped quietly when Agatha’s fingers brushed the bruise, much more gentle than Alice had been earlier, and for some reason that meant it was more painful to Rio who’d turned her head away and squeezed her eyes shut.

“I was drunk. I was high. I was-…”

Rio gasped.

Agatha’s tongue was easing down the bruise, applying just enough pressure that Rio could feel the sting of it beneath the soft, warm relief. Her left hand was now anchored on her hip and her right had slipped through wild hair to hold Rio’s head back as she worked her tongue until she was satisfied and Rio had released a whimper.

Agatha pulled back then, her fingers clutching at the base of Rio’s scalp, tugging her hair a little. She felt her nudge her jaw with her nose, a brief moment of tenderness before she placed her lips back to the bruise and her tongue was this time replaced by her teeth and lips.

The sting was exquisite and almost unbearable but Rio didn’t think that Agatha was trying to make this bearable. She tugged harshly at her hair and sank her teeth into the most tender spot of the mark, adding to it, marking over it, replacing the signature of the other woman with her own.

Rio had to clench her teeth, and grip the sink behind her to try and stop herself from alerting Alice and Jen to what was going on in the little bathroom.

But Agatha didn’t stop until she was satisfied. She pulled up a few times to soothe the bruise with her tongue, to check in on her progress, to ensure she had covered every part of it and the mark was now twice the size, twice as angry, but unmistakably Agatha’s.

Agatha was panting softly now against her neck, her grip loosening on her hair, her lips trailing a soft line up to Rio’s ear where she whispered, “Was that Wanda’s?”

“N-no. Some girl. I… just some girl.”

Agatha hummed quietly and released her hold on Rio enough so she could turn her head and press into her, her hold relenting on the sink so she could wrap her arms around Agatha’s shoulders.

Agatha nudged their noses together and looked at Rio with eyes so black they could have swallowed the sun. “It’s mine now.”

And Rio could only nod, only swallow thickly, only feel the dull ache of her neck where Agatha had marked over the already tender bruise.

“Did you fuck her?”

“No.”

“Did she leave any of those anywhere else?”

“No.”

Agatha nodded just once and dropped her gaze from Rio, glancing down over Wanda’s t-shirt and shorts and Rio bit down on her lip as she moved her hands to lift Agatha’s head back up so she could meet her gaze, “Agatha, it didn’t mean anything. I was high as fuck.”

“Did she touch you?” Agatha’s jaw felt tight beneath her palms and Rio frowned at still too-dark eyes, fighting against the urge to either deny deny deny, or tell Agatha that she had put her hands all over her to see what she might do.

But, having been raised well and for fear Agatha might simply walk away if she caught Rio lying, she sucked in a soft breath and said, “She had her hand on my breast. That’s it.”

“That’s it?” Agatha repeated flatly, pulling away now to turn from Rio.

Rio swallowed and nodded, watching Agatha with wide, sad eyes. “Baby.”

“Don’t.” Agatha snapped without looking. Her hands were in her hair, her elbows up and out to the sides, her back ramrod straight. “Don’t call me that.”

Rio closed her eyes and dropped her head, trying and failing to take in a slow breath as her heart raced apathetically in her chest, caring only to reach maximum velocity rather than to keep its bearer alive.

“Agatha,” Rio managed to force out, trying to keep her voice steady, “I was basically blacked out. It was only because Wanda-…”

“Fuck, Rio. Don’t talk to me about Wanda.”

Rio looked up then and saw that Agatha had turned back around. Her hair was as wild as her eyes and Rio felt small before her, tight with anxiety and pressed closely in on herself by the sink.

“I have been waiting for you. I was on my knees for you… I didn’t tell you I loved you as a joke, Agatha. I wasn’t just saying it.”

“Loved?”

“Love.”

Agatha’s lashes fluttered and she dropped her gaze.

In the silence that settled between them Rio took the opportunity to study Agatha’s face, absorbing the micro expressions like an ornithologist watching a long-looked for bird. “What?”
