“Your room key is on the desk,” she eventually muttered, still not moving from her position on the bed. Rio moved to grab it, feeling more tension in the room with just her and Alice than she had even when Agatha had entered the bathroom earlier.

But she said nothing, too focused on thoughts of Agatha to be able to form a coherent thought related to Alice.

She left the room and went to her own to shower and change and throw all of her belongings into her suitcase.

There was a knock at the door exactly twenty minutes after she arrived and a member of staff in a crisp burgundy vest had arrived to take her things down to the car that would be waiting to take them to the airport.

Out in the lobby Rio found Alice waiting for her, an unusual sight without her phone in her hands. She didn’t acknowledge Rio as she approached her and instead led her out to the car without a word.

Two lone photographers were there to greet them but Rio kept her head down as she stepped into the foggy London morning and slipped into the car.

She’d done a half-decent job of covering the bruise on her neck but kept her hair swept over it for fear anyone with enough interest in her would spot it. Certainly Alice would see that it had grown.

The journey to Heathrow was silent, and Rio felt a familiar guilt churning in her stomach but whether for what had happened with the girl in the club or the silent treatment she was receiving from Alice she didn’t know.

By some miracle Alice’s seat in First was two rows behind Rio so she didn’t have to concern herself with trying to think of something to say across the aisle on the flight home.

Though of course she knew she hadn’t. Rio’s phone sat, as usual, untouched and unchecked somewhere in her carry on. She hadn’t looked at it since Heathrow.

But there, bright and obnoxious on Alice’s screen was a picture that Rio would have happily avoided forever if she were given the choice.

It was a picture of Agatha and Nicky, and Ralph. They were bundled up in sweaters and jackets and scarves and out for a walk in a park. Ralph had his arm around Agatha and Agatha was holding Nicky’s hand, though the little boy was just out of shot, but in the next photo he was there, with Agatha crouching beside him, his Celtics cap on his head, his face angled down as he fed the ducks. They looked perfect. Beautiful. Happy.

Ralph looked tall and masculine and handsome. In the next shot Agatha was turned into him, face up, smiling at him as if she loved him, as if this were a normal day in the park with her little family.

It made Rio’s stomach churn.

“I saw,” Rio deadpanned, “She let him be photographed?”

“Not technically. Not his face, anyway.”

Rio could only nod, keeping her eyes away from Alice so she wouldn’t see how three such simple pictures could destroy her.

“You’re having an affair?”

Her tone was light, breezy, as if the silence between them had been nothing, as if she’d asked her what she wanted for dinner that night. But the question still came out of nowhere and Rio turned to her and saw that Alice still looked pale, and she wasn’t quite meeting her eye.

“Are you?”

“You know I couldn’t.”

Rio swallowed thickly.

“Will she leave him?”

“I don’t know.”

Alice had followed her.

“Did Jen know?”

“I… don’t think so. Maybe suspected but… no I don’t think so.”

“Made it worse,” Rio said quietly, a blush rising from her chest to her cheeks.

Alice had stepped back again and Rio bit the inside of her cheek and looked away, “I’m not sure.”

Alice went silent again and Rio kept her gaze on the floor, now toying with the cap of the bottle that hung from its spindly plastic tie.

Rio looked up, suddenly breathless, seeing her best friend frowning over at her, pale and confused but sure and soft. She put the bottle down on the counter beside her and stepped into Alice’s open arms to bury herself in her embrace.

Alice stayed with Rio that night and for the first time in a while she held her as she slept.

By morning Rio was groggy and aching, her body’s reaction to a stressful few days. Alice was curled up the other side of the bed, having drifted in the night away from the heat of Rio’s warm body.

And Rio watched her friend sleep for a while, looking peaceful and at ease. They’d barely spoken after Alice’s realisation and Rio was grateful for it, because the only words she wanted to say were to Agatha and they were myriad and meant too much.

She pressed a kiss to Rio’s cheek and whispered into her ear, “She told me everything.”

Rio couldn’t respond because being open with Agatha was all she wanted and now she had two people she could be in a room with and scream about her love for her. But she wasn’t there to witness it, she wasn’t there to share in the release, so Rio remained silent.

Jen and Alice hovered around her all day, neither bringing up the topic Rio knew they wanted to, but neither leaving her alone for more than five minutes.

By the time evening fell and Jen looked like she were on her last legs, they decided to leave.

When alone Rio opened a bottle of wine and drank all of it until she was able to fall asleep.

6:03am
Agatha Harkness: We’re in Barcelona. Nicky’s practicing his Spanish. Thought I’d pick you up a dictionary so you can improve too?

6:05am
Rio Vidal: You told Jen?

6:13am

6:17am
Agatha Harkness: My driver can pick up an overnight bag for you and drop it off.

Rio hadn’t known what to do. She had two coffees before she text back.

7:05am
Rio Vidal: Do you think there’s any world in which I’d refuse?

7:06am
Agatha Harkness: Took you long enough.

7:07am
Rio Vidal: Can I call you?

7:11am
Agatha Harkness: I’ll call after Nicky’s in bed.

One time Rio called and Nicky picked up and she spoke to him whilst Agatha was busy making snacks and even when she heard her come back she continued to talk to the little boy about nothing more exciting than the things he’d seen on his vacation. One time Agatha called so late in the day, so late that it was the middle of the night for her, and Rio was out for drinks with Alice.

“Hey. Everything okay?”

“Evidently.”

Alice didn’t have to ask this time. She knew exactly what was going on.

Her and Jen had agreed to keep Rio and Agatha together as much as possible, giving them as much time - even if they had no space - to be close as they possibly could.

Separately, they’d promised their managers they’d behave, that nothing would change with how they behaved now that two people had been let in on the secret.

And she knew she looked good - she had eyes.

“Jen.”

“Are you in love with her?”

Jen was silent for a second and then: “Just remember she’s happy. She’s not used to that. And she wants more of it and-…”

“Jen.”

“I’ll see you at the theatre, Rio.”

“Jen.”

“Jen asking me not to hurt Agatha. But it sounded like… I don’t know…” she trailed off and turned to see the worry across her features in the large mirror.

“She’s probably being protective, that’s all,” Alice said gently, but Rio didn’t think she sounded convinced. “I’ll have a word with her.”

“No,” the word came out sharper than she meant it to, “Don’t. I want tonight to be easy. To be drama free. I’m just going to sit and smile and maybe get a dance with her. I don’t want anything to ruin it. She was being protective. It’s fine.”

Alice could only nod at her friend, squeezing her arm supportively before she went to fetch the glam squad to come back in and make the finishing touches.

Once Rio was as perfect as perfect could be, the glam squad left, and they passed by a man at the door in a crisp black shirt who’d come to fetch an overnight bag. Alice got it for him and didn’t exchange a word, unable to come up with the right thing to say to a man who was helping her friend have an affair.

On the way to the Shrine Auditorium downtown, Alice finally broke her silent streak. “I want you to know that I’ve been thinking about the many, many things that could go wrong with this.”

“Alice.”

“No, listen. It would be a dumpster fire, Rio. It could absolutely fucking-…”

“Yes, got it.”

“I want you to know that I have you. That I didn’t have you before. But I do now. And if it comes to it, and I’m not saying it will, but if it does… I have you over Jen too.”

Rio turned to her sweet friend and hesitated for just a second before reaching out because reaching out meant admitting that it could go wrong. It meant acknowledging the very real, very persistent part of her that told her this couldn’t last much longer. Because Agatha had so stolen her heart, but the thief had left nothing to replace it.

“Alice,” Rio whispered, her hands not quite able to take Alice’s, but instead both sets of fingers gently tapping at Alice’s thigh. “I promise that whatever happens, I’ll make sure that the fallout-…”

“You’re in too deep, Rio. If it were Wanda, that would be different. Hell, anyone else… but not… her. She’s too powerful.”

Rio nodded slowly and found the strength to take Alice’s hand, “She wouldn’t do anything to hurt me. She’s not like that with me.”

Alice tightened her hold on Rio’s hands, squeezing them gently, “I’m just saying, I’ve got you. For anything at all. Whatever you need. We’ll work through it.”

Rio looked up and smiled a little, squeezing Alice’s hands right back.

“And hey, maybe after you get this Oscar she’ll be-…”

“I am not getting the Oscar.”

“Listen, if it were ethical I’d have put down my savings on it. Agatha made sure the actors branch-…”

She trailed off and Rio looked at her curiously, “Holy shit I’m such an idiot. I knew it was insane for her to call you her favourite actress in an interview. What the fuck.”

Rio laughed and ripped her hands away, “But maybe I am her favourite actress and she likes to kiss me.”

“Jesus,” Alice said, too in awe of her own blinkered worldview to react.

“That was before we’d even done anything, anyway.”

“Fuck me,” Alice muttered quietly, now staring out the window and thinking of interactions past. “And in Italy you we’re being so weird. Jen asked if you were trying it on and if Agatha would be safe sharing a bed with you and I-…”

“Jesus. Jen thought I’d what? Assault her or something?”

“I think more just that you’d get a good look at Agatha Harkness in a slip or something.”

Rio rolled her eyes and huffed, “She doesn’t sleep in a slip.”

A well-aimed poke to her ribs made her jolt and laugh, “I hope you packed sexy underwear for tonight. It might be your last chance at romance before filming starts.”

“We’re taking a week away. Before I have to work again. Just the two of us.” Rio turned then and smiled a little at Alice who looked surprised, “She’s booking someplace where we can just be alone.”

“You have lines to learn and-…”

“I know. I’ll take my script and it’ll be fine.”

Alice sighed quietly but nodded, “Okay. Just make sure you actually check your phone. It’s one thing to disappear but another to go off grid on me.”

“Yeah, yeah,” Rio said with a smile, though she realistically had no plans to be on her phone whilst away with Agatha. She would have more important things to be focused on.

“The other thing,” Alice said after a little while longer of quiet in the SUV, “is that I was thinking about what this would do to Agatha.”

“What do you mean?”

“Well, look at it this way, she’s married, she’s got a kid, it would-…”

But the car had come to a sudden halt and the noise of thousands of fans lined up to see their favourite celebrities was enough to make Alice’s words die on her tongue.

She leant across Rio to look out the tinted window and frowned at the sight. No matter how many times either of them did this, neither would be used to it.

Rio stepped out of the car and arrived to a roar from the waiting fans and photographers. It stupefied her for a second. Her eyes temporarily blinded in the chaos of the red carpet. It was getting worse, she realised, with every awards show. More photographers, more screams.

But Alice was guiding her gently through, leading her to the entrance of the carpet where a stressed looking woman with a headset ticked off something on a clipboard and pointed to where they needed to be.

It wasn’t raining like London. There weren’t great hoards of people gathered under large umbrellas. Instead the carpet was wide open and slots were available to the talent moving in slow droves to take their places for the waiting, hungry photographers.

Rio moved up, taking precedence over some of the others in the long line to join the fray. She was ushered ahead, whispering soft apologies to those she overtook, smiling at those she recognised, and squeezing those she knew.

And then, just ahead of her, she saw Agatha for the first time.

She wore a black strapless dress with a peplum at her hips that accentuated her waist. Agatha was posing with her hand on her hip and Rio saw something that made her heart flutter.

Agatha was wearing an emerald ring on her wedding finger - the green standing out against the black and drawing her eye immediately.

Rio’s heart didn’t settle as she was directed to the middle of the carpet again, just a few metres down from Agatha. She posed, avoided looking, smiled for the cameras, avoided looking, straightened her back, avoided looking, kept her eyes forward, avoided looking, her teeth visible.

The shouts got louder and there was a hand on her hip, a warm thumb just grazing the skin of her stomach, a voice in her ear that drowned out all else: “Rio Vidal.”

Chapter End Notes

So Jen knows everything. But does Rio? HMMMMMM

Chapter 23: The Thief

Chapter Summary

Rio catches a thief.

Chapter Notes

TGIF

Only nice things happen in this chapter

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“Agatha!! Over here!!”

“Rio!! Rio!!”

The shouts were deafening.

Agatha’s star power was of a magnitude that Rio still just couldn’t comprehend. And the photographers were rabid for it as she shined her light on Rio.

And Rio laughed as Agatha grinned at her, as she pulled her hand away making sure to brush along her front, the feel of her touch on her skin making the choice of dress oh-so worth it.

The impact was immediate, Agatha turning to the photographers, the shouting thunderous amongst the star shine.

But Agatha was now at her side, her arm around Rio from behind, her gaze towards the men capturing the stellar collision through their DSLRs.

Rio’s smile was no longer practised or poised but genuine and bright. She found herself slip her own arm around Agatha too and she posed with her, feeling the tender squeeze at her side that was just for her.

“Give her a hug!!

“Agatha!! Over your shoulder!! Agatha!!”

Rio began to laugh again as the shouts showed no sign of abating and Agatha squeezed her more tightly, turning her head to see the laughter for herself.

“Something funny about posing with me?”

Rio raised her brows and leant her top half back a bit, grinning where Agatha clearly began to struggle to keep her eyes up on her face, “Hilarious.”

Agatha arched a brow, and Rio continued to grin.

But a hand that wasn’t Agatha’s was on her back and Alice had moved in, causing the photographers to yell things other than their names.

“Let’s move along please, ladies. You have all night together, remember.”

Rio laughed once more and Agatha just rolled her eyes as she pulled away, capturing Rio’s fingers in hers and not letting go until the last second; David reaching for the god in his brain.

“Some solo shots,” Alice instructed with a half-smile up at Rio, leaving her alone to do as instructed.

And Rio did. She posed with a warmer, more easy smile than before, half paying attention to the instructions yelled her way and half keeping an eye on Agatha as she too posed and moved up the carpet.

Midway along the interviews began and Rio dazzled her way through them, always aware that Agatha was no more than two feet away. Sometimes Jen was between them. Sometimes she could reach out and touch Agatha’s skin.

Sometimes an interviewer would reference Agatha and Rio felt her turn her way as Rio tried to keep her gushing to a minimum - though she wasn’t always successful at that.

Agatha left the carpet before she did. Her routine was much more nailed down than Rio’s and Jen much stricter on the outlets she’d allow her client to do interviews for than Alice was.

Agatha was a different echelon of movie star after all; a supernova to Rio’s dwarf star.

So she was taken into the auditorium long before Rio was and Rio was left to continue her job without the comforting presence of Agatha nearby.

She did it well, she made the journalists laugh and she answered every question as if she weren’t PR trained and instead was just naturally savvy on the complex politics of a movie about a wayward woman at a time when most movies were about men and their uninteresting problems.

And soon she was ushered into the hall where the ceremony was to be held, and as usual, her eyes swept across heads and bodies until she could find Agatha.

There she was, standing by a beautifully set table, a glass of champagne in her left hand, her emerald ring prominent on her finger, her eyes on Rio.

It stopped Rio in her tracks. So much so that Alice collided with her back and Rio turned to her in surprise.

“Stop staring. It’s insane to me I never caught on.”

“Too busy checking out Jennifer.”

Alice smirked but turned Rio back around and pushed her towards a small group of studio higher ups that contained the one and only Tony Stark. And Rio had no choice but to go where she was led.

“Ah! The woman of the hour!”

Rio could only grin, only accept the compliment because she had no means of denying it. But she also accepted a glass of champagne, which made the whole thing a lot easier.

“We were just talking about you. Got some good news coming your way, kid.”

“Oh? Do tell.”

“Can’t I’m afraid. But let’s just say, we had high hopes for Snow and they’re about to skyrocket.”

Rio raised her brows and glanced across at Alice who was sipping her own champagne and looking just as confused as she felt.

“Very enigmatic,” Rio said just as she felt a hand on her hip and a body against her opposite side. Agatha.

She turned with a grin and saw that Agatha was looking a little pale, her eyes on Stark. “Stark.”

“Harkness,” Stark said with a wide smile, “What a coincidence.”

But Rio couldn’t see how Agatha appearing just then could be a coincidence so she frowned a little and caught Agatha glance around at her.

“Mind if I borrow Rio? Girly things to discuss, you know.”

Stark nodded quickly and waved his hand to dismiss them and Rio found herself being tugged away by Agatha with Alice following meekly behind them.

“‘Girly things’?” Rio asked when they were far enough away to be out of earshot.

“I wanted to steal you,” Agatha said with a shrug as she dropped her hold on Rio and stepped back. “Couldn’t find a dress that would match your necklace?”

Rio grinned as Alice gasped beside her, “That green one? Holy shit. What is wrong with me?”

Rio spared her best friend a look of amusement and then turned to Agatha and caught her checking her out. “My eyes are up here, Harkness.”

“Harkness, is it?”

“Stark calls you that. Why can’t I?”

“I prefer-…”

“Baby?”

Agatha’s cheeks flushed a soft pink that drew Rio’s attention and she saw suddenly the thing she always looked for, the sign that she was beginning to realise meant Agatha was hers for the night. She could see the tiny, darker pigments of skin across her pink cheeks and perfect nose and her heart fluttered at the sight.

“The two of you,” Alice said quietly, moving a little closer even as Rio continued to fixate on the sprinkle of freckles across Agatha’s face, “are so fucking obvious-…”

“Alice?” Agatha asked suddenly, breaking eye contact with Rio to look down at Alice with a movie star grin, “Could you please give me Rio’s phone?”

Rio blinked, raised her brows, stepped back a little, “Why?”

“I believe you owe me a post.”

“You owe me so much, Harkness.”

“Call me that again and I’ll never give you what you think you’re owed.”

Alice looked between them two of them, a little dumbfounded that she’d never picked up on the obvious flirting, the sizzling chemistry, the easy intimacy.

But she fished in Rio’s bronze clutch that was tucked under her arm to produce Rio’s phone.

“Oh you’re just giving it up?” Rio asked in mock-outrage as she watched Agatha smirk and tap at the phone to make it light up.

Alice smiled and sipped her champagne as Agatha asked: “Passcode?”

“Six zeros.”

“Seriously?”

“What? It’s easy to remember.”

And the phone opened up for Agatha and Rio saw her flick about the mess that was Rio Vidal’s disorganised chaos. She had five pages of apps all scattered in no order whatsoever.

“This is an insane way to live.”

“Shut up,” Rio insisted as she snatched her phone away and scanned about a bit to find Instagram which she opened and then handed it back over to Agatha.

Agatha said nothing as she began to type using only her left hand and Rio watched her with narrowed eyes. “You don’t even have a picture to use yet.”

“I’ll get one later.”

Rio rolled her eyes and moved closer to try and see what Agatha was typing but she pulled back and held the phone at an angle where Rio couldn’t see the screen.

Agatha’s right hand holding her champagne moved to hold Rio back, her knuckles pressing in against Rio’s exposed abdomen and Rio had no choice but to stay still if she wanted to keep Agatha’s hand against her skin. And she wanted it. Desperately.

She tried to act cool about it, sipping her champagne and looking everywhere but at Agatha, but she felt the soft, minuscule movement of one of Agatha’s knuckles against her skin and could think of nothing else even as Alice started yapping about Rio speaking with some director or other who was standing not too far away.

Her phone was soon pressed back to her and Rio could snap out of her daze as Agatha pulled her hand away from her to sip at her champagne.

“I think you’ll like it.”

Rio huffed as Alice leant in and they read the draft post together: This woman is a walking masterclass. Every scene, every moment, she’s pure electricity. We’re all just lucky to be able to witness it, let alone stand close.

Rio finished it faster than Alice did and she looked up at Agatha who seemed to purposefully be looking around the room as if she hadn’t just written the most obnoxious paragraph Rio had ever read.

“Absolutely not.”

“Oh? Then no dance for you.”

Rio narrowed her eyes at Agatha and began to grin when Alice chimed in: “Definitely not.”

“Outnumbered,” Rio said as she sipped her champagne.

Agatha shrugged and grinned as their little group was infiltrated by some of Rio’s cast mates and Rio focused in on them rather than the smug woman beside her. After greeting everyone properly she settled back and wrapped her arm around Agatha’s back, resting her hand on her opposite hip.

To her surprise and delight, Agatha relaxed into the hold, leaning into it as she continued to make smalltalk with Rio’s costars who looked positively dazzled that she was deigning to shine her light on them.

There was something intoxicating about being able to hold Agatha like this, in a way that could be casual, but to Rio was anything but. She felt possessive over her, desperate for people to know she was taken - not by her husband, but by her.

But conversations at these things were never long, and Rio was begged to be introduced to someone across the room, so she had to relinquish her hold on Agatha, and barely had a chance to say goodbye as she was carted off to a director in the corner.

Alice followed her and soon Rio was selling herself to this auteur like her life depended on it. She’d auditioned for the man before, but he’d never hired her. Hadn’t even brought her in for a callback, and so Rio was surprised to find him suddenly hanging off her every word.

And even more surprised when mention of his next project was made and a gentle hint that he’d like - no, expect - to see her for a reading. Alice had almost collapsed beside her when he’d left them to do the rounds.

“I fucking told you. This is our time. This is our shot, Rio. We’ve got this.”

Rio could only grin, could only try to hide it behind her champagne glass because no sooner had the director left them than they’d been cornered by two producers. And Rio was back on her best behaviour, selling herself by being as charming as she possibly could.

It was a cattle market, really. An auction house where only the best and biggest stood a chance.

Those with reputations, with shelves full of glittering awards always demanded an audience. Like Agatha, who stood beside Jen, both surrounded by sycophants and desperate people trying to vie for her attention.

Then those with growing reputations, with a solid amount of work behind them, with decent to excellent reviews, and a handful of awards or nominations were next in the running - and Rio chief amongst them.

Rio got Agatha’s dregs. She got the people who’d already spoken to Agatha or the people who were yet too afraid to approach her. But she got people nonetheless.

By the time the lights changed and the call was made for the show to start and people to find their seats, Rio was already exhausted. Small talk wasn’t always easy when you were in too-high heels, and had said “oh yeah, the weather in London was as you’d expect!” a million times over.

Rio was settled between Alice and her director at their cast table and she didn’t get much time to relax as the ceremony began. The only saving grace was that Agatha was visible to her if she just turned her head to the right, risking her neck snapping for the angle she had to be in to see her. But the sight was worth it.

Agatha was sat not too far away, but too far for Rio’s liking; always too far for her. She looked poised and calm and Rio wondered if she felt that way or she was so good at faking that at this point no one could tell the difference.

But she must have felt Rio’s eyes on her because she turned to look and the cracks in her appearance showed as she smiled at her. Rio dipped her head a little in acknowledgement and Agatha bit the corner of her lip as she turned away.

These moments were precious still, because moments were all they had.

The ceremony started as most ceremonies do, with jokes that landed and jokes that didn’t. Rio smiled and laughed and clapped when it was called on her to do so. She followed the unspoken script of awards shows: look happy, look grateful, be beautiful.

And with each passing category she thought of Agatha. She thought of the night they could spend together. Of the things she wanted to say to her. Of the things she wanted to do to her.

Pulled from her increasingly perverted thoughts, Alice touched her side when the presenter stepped out to announce the category for Best Actress. She kept her warm hand there, hidden from view of the cameras as Rio’s face was zoomed in on and her name was read amongst her fellow nominees.

The ritual of it, the pretence of the piece, it always felt strange that these people were being congratulated for doing so little in the grand scheme of the world. But the world always shrunk in moments like this, always dissolved into the iris of a beautiful woman’s blue eyes.

“Rio Vidal!”

Alice reacted. The director reacted. Rio turned.

Agatha was on her feet, her smile genuine and wide, and Rio lost sight of it as she was rushed at by cast members and crew alike. She barely made it to the stage alive with the amount of hands desperately grabbing her as if she’d provide them with just a slither of the glory she had been blessed with.

Someone from a nearby table helped her to the stage and she accepted The Actor trophy and turned to her expectant audience.

“You know,” she began hurriedly, trying to capture the very edges of thoughts as they flew one by one from her shocked brain. “I was expecting anyone’s name but mine so this is… god, this is genuinely… it’s shocking is what it is.”

There was a smattering of laughter and Rio smiled a little, unsure where to look but knowing the one place she wanted to.

“Acting is the only thing that ever really made sense to me as a career path… and I’m so, just unbelievably, honoured that I’m able to do it. The fact that I’m able to do it surrounded by the incredible women in this category…”

She looked then, making eyes at Sylvia, at Jessica, at Shuri (an actress who’d been nominated for her work in a small indie that had grown in popularity at the smaller festivals), and finally at Agatha, where her eyes settled.

“It’s incredible to me that I’m able to do what I do alongside you.”

“To SAG, to my ridiculously talented and supportive cast and crew, to my Alice who persuaded me into trying this out in the first place, to my incredible mom and dad, I’m so endlessly grateful.”

She looked away and cleared her throat softly, “It’s almost a cliché to say now but women’s stories are important. The stories of marginalised people are important.”

The room cheered and Rio swallowed as she continued, “And as an openly queer, proud Latina, I know how necessary representation is.”

More cheers. A wolf whistle. Rio smiled a little.

“So lets keep our minds on the kids at home who need someone to look up to, who need to see themselves represented in order for their dreams to grow. Thank you.”

She turned from the stage as the applause kicked up again and she grinned her way backstage only to be greeted by Alice who pulled her so violently against her that Rio actually shrieked in surprise.

“Jesus, Alice!”

“You’ve got that Oscar on lock. You’re a freakin’ movie star, baby!”

Rio could only laugh, could only vibrate with delight as she was sped through the interviews that now seemed so redundant because the post-awards questions were the same and Rio’s answers were the same and the only thing different was the outfit she wore.

But Alice kept her on a tight leash, had clearly taken a leaf out of Jen’s book during this round of interviews, and was pulling Rio from the little makeshift stage in the press room to get her out.

Rio could only imagine that holding a SAG meant she’d been given the key to a different level of fame and notoriety. But she didn’t complain, she instead went back out to her table, slipped in during a change over of presenters, and placed her award by her champagne as she settled back in.

Her little movie that could won three awards that night, including Rio’s own. With Best Actress, Best Cast in a Motion Picture, and Male Actor in a Supporting Role, the table was on a high, made only higher by the free champagne and limited food.

The show was over, but the party had just begun. And Rio was swept up in it, her arms never not full of people coming to congratulate and hug her. But they didn’t feel full enough until Agatha had snuck around, had pulled her in without Rio much noticing until she was already in her arms.

Agatha squeezed her tightly and then leant back to see her, her smile as warm and wide as ever, her eyes containing Rio’s whole world.

“Jen is so mad at me.”

Rio laughed and rolled her eyes, resisting the urge to pull Agatha in to beg her to speak closer to her lips, “Can’t she ever give me credit for achieving something myself.”

“Absolutely not, Vidal.” Jen’s voice was loud and clear as she stepped in and slipped her arm coolly between the two bodies pressed together at the hips to replace Agatha against Rio - though not as close, not as welcome.

“She got you that damn trophy and you know it.”

Rio sighed as she hugged Jen properly and grinned over her shoulder at Agatha who was watching the two with a tender sort of gaze.

“I am also very talented and charming, Kale.”

Jennifer pulled away but didn’t hold her the way Agatha just had and instead dropped her hands to Rio’s arms and stepped back a foot, “If you get that goddamn Oscar I’m going to-…”

“Try to steal it?”

“Crucify you.”

Rio laughed and found herself being pulled back by Alice who had stepped in similarly to how Jen had earlier but this time to steal Jen rather than Rio.

“She’s just mad because her girlfriend has the better client.”

“I am here, you know.” Agatha joined the fray then and stepped closer to Rio but didn’t reach for her again.

Alice turned back around with an amused smile but didn’t push it as Jen leant around her and pointed at the two actresses, “Umm? Go mingle, please. Keep away from each other. The agreement is-…”

“Yes,” Agatha said quickly, lowering her voice to an urgent whisper, “Yes, others first. Rio never.”

“Never?”

“Later,” Agatha clarified with a quick smile, turning to rest her hand against Rio’s exposed abs and press a kiss to her cheek, “Come find me?”

Rio hummed quietly, briefly meeting Agatha’s gaze with a smile before Agatha stepped away and Rio felt the loss of her warmth instantly. Now they were open with Alice and Jen it meant they were being watched constantly. They’d created prison guards for themselves, and the guard always expected them to attempt an escape.

It meant where Rio could have feasibly been beside Agatha all evening with little suspicion, she now had to make a conscious effort to be apart from her.

Jen stepped around her and left her alone with Alice again.

But, as usual, they weren’t alone for long.

Hollywood as a concept was much more complicated than the reality of it. A small town with one business interest was all it really was. Hollywood was the Stratford-Upon-Avon of California, or the Las Vegas of acting.

It was where dreams came to be and where dreams came to die.

And in the centre of it all, standing proudly with her statue and her award-winning smile, was Rio Vidal. She was on the precipice of greatness, and had her heart’s desire waiting to be with her in private in just a few, short hours time.

And those hours began to fly past with the help of a thousand faces kissed and only slightly fewer glasses of champagne drank. And Rio didn’t see Agatha again until she felt a presence at her side as she leant around at one of the small tables set up for those unwilling to dance - or as Alice had so eloquently put it for the “boring old fuckers who need to make sitting at a party a personality trait”.

Rio was, unfortunately, one of those such people for the sake of talking to the very far from boring Lilia Calderu.

“Ah, and the prodigal daughter is here,” Lilia announced with a grin as she turned her attention from Rio to the very presence she’d just felt settle beside her. “Looking glamorous as always, Agatha.”

“You too,” Agatha said not unkindly as Rio felt her drape her arm over her chair as Rio dropped her left hand below the table to seek Agatha’s knee. If Lilia noticed anything off about this she didn’t say anything but she did change the subject from where they’d just been discussing days of Hollywood past.

“It’s striking, isn’t it, the way Rio looks like young Nicholas.”

Rio’s brows rose halfway up her forehead and she felt Agatha move a little closer to her, her own hand now squeezing at Agatha’s knee.

“Dark hair, dark eyes,” Agatha said in what Rio took to be an attempt at nonchalance, but the leg that now pressed against her own told her it was anything but.

“Goofy teeth,” Rio added in an attempt to ease the conversation, grinning widely on purpose at Lilia to show off the little gap between her two front teeth.

“There are many who believe,” Lilia began, ignoring Rio’s smile and Rio felt Agatha draw in a heavy breath behind her, her left arm moving a little closer along the table under the pretence of toying with Rio’s half-empty champagne glass, “that children’s faces can tell us a lot about the parents.”

“Obviously,” Agatha drawled, her emerald ring catching the light where she held the stem of the glass, “It’s called genetics.”

Rio scoffed a laugh and regretted it when Lilia shot her a look.

“Actually, a lot of cultures have very real and very ancient beliefs about the faces our children inherit.”

Rio cleared her throat quietly and squeezed Agatha’s knee, “I’m not sure there’s anything culturally significant about Nicky’s face, Lilia. He’s a little white boy after all.” She shot Agatha a look and muttered, “No offence.”

“None taken.”

“I mean to say,” Lilia bristled a little, not used to being interrupted quite so much, “that some cultures believe children’s faces are the result of a great love passed down from mother to child.”

Agatha’s hand stopped its movements against Rio’s glass and Rio’s hand went suddenly still and stiff over Agatha’s knee.

“That those mother’s pass on that love and the child grows into the image of the love inherited.”

Neither Agatha nor Rio moved for a few seconds, until Rio forced herself to say: “Well, I suppose Nicky has some of his dad’s-…” but she’d trailed off because it made bile rise up her throat.

“He does looks like Rio,” Agatha said calmly, so eerily calm that Rio turned to look at her properly for the first time since she’d arrived, “I’ve always thought that. He’s nothing like his father.”

Agatha didn’t look around at her and Rio turned back to Lilia to assess her reaction to this. The grand dame of acting only smiled, her sharp brown eyes remaining fixedly on Agatha, “I didn’t think he would be.”

Agatha’s hand moved from Rio’s glass to find Rio’s hand under the table and Rio bit on the inside of her cheek as she interlocked their fingers together, resting still on Agatha’s knee.

“Where is the handsome Ralph?” Lilia asked as Rio began to focus more of the feel of Agatha’s thumb brushing her own than anything else.

“He’s been working on the east coast. Nicky and I stayed overnight last night at the in a hotel as a treat to end off our vacation but Ralph’s back now so he’s with Nicky.”

“A shame,” Lilia said as her eyes moved to Rio who’d taken it upon herself to drink down the rest of her champagne. “I always so enjoy speaking to him.”

Rio didn’t know whether Lilia were being sarcastic or not but ever hopeful she said: “Me too. Love that guy.”

Agatha squeezed her hand and Rio smirked as she met Lilia’s gaze and found the old woman smiling at her, “well, I should leave the two of you alone.”

She made to stand and paused as she did so, “You two really are a formidable pair.”

Rio raised her brows and she felt Agatha’s hand leave her own, slide up her forearm and squeeze at her bicep. The touch was brief, tender, and made Rio shiver slightly as Agatha held her arm and whispered close to her ear, “Formidable.”

Rio fought her grin from overspilling into a laugh and turned to Agatha as Lilia left them alone, knowing it wouldn’t last for long.

“Also,” Agatha said before Rio could say anything, “Since when do you love talking to Ralph.”

“Since every time I do I prove to myself that I am better than him in every feasible way.”

Agatha rolled her eyes but grinned all the same, shifting away a little in her seat.

“His useless genes couldn’t even outdo my-…”

“Don’t even finish that sentence,” Agatha chided with narrowed eyes that Rio took as a challenge so with a grin she said: “Big dick energy.”

“What does that even mean?”

“Oh you’re so old.”

Agatha laughed and Rio grinned, squeezing Agatha’s knee below the table. “But more importantly: this ring?”

“What about it?” Agatha’s eyes sparkled as much as the jewel on her finger still against Rio’s arm.

“Green looks good on you,” Rio said enigmatically.

Agatha raised her brows and brushed her thumb across Rio’s skin, squeezing her gently. “Honey, everything looks good on me.”

Rio felt a hand on her shoulder as she was leaning into Agatha again and she turned to see Alice standing above her, “Come on. You’re dancing with me.”

Chapter End Notes

Just to say: please forgive the very obvious fact that I don’t know how to use semi-colons but continue to use them liberally

LOTS of people concerned the person touching Rio’s stomach on the red carpet (?!) wasn’t Agatha and I think that means I’ve scared you all too much so apologies for that

But more scares to come!

Chapter 24: Slowly Slowly

Chapter Summary

Rio wants to commit. Fully.

Agatha starts to get bolder. Fearfully.

Chapter Notes

Only good things happen in this chapter 😃

See the end of the chapter for more notes

As she moved to stretch out her limbs she felt another movement against her, a soft body that rolled as she did, a gentle presence that curled with her and a precious face that pressed into her shoulder.

“Incredibly?”

“Alice said you’re taking your mom?”

Jen had picked up the thread and secured it tightly so the conversation could move without fear that Agatha would snip it. “Yeah, my dad too but he’ll have to sit back with Alice.”

“Agatha will be with Ralph.”

Rio nodded, having expected nothing less. Agatha beside her uncrossed and recrossed her legs and Rio looked down to them, seeing her pale knee slip through the gap in her robe.

“You know,” Jen started, slower this time, her dark eyes trained on Rio’s as she looked back up, “we should start thinking about cleaning up your image.”

Rio looked up, frowning at Jen as Agatha scoffed beside her, “Don’t start, Jen.”

“There’s nothing wrong with her image,” Alice said almost as quickly as Agatha had responded and Rio felt grateful to the both of them but she could fight her own battles.

“What exactly do I need to clean up?”

“Well,” Jen started and Agatha shook her head but said nothing, “This party girl sports fan image. You’re getting too old for it and-…”

“I’m thirty two.”

“Exactly.”

“Jen,” Agatha said suddenly, “Drop it.”

“It’ll be easier for you if Rio appears to be a little more wholesome when you-…”

“Don’t, Jen.”

Agatha had pulled her hand away from Rio’s clutches and Rio turned to look at her, seeing the sharpness in her blue eyes as they stared across at Jen. But it didn’t matter that Agatha had interrupted her, Rio had guessed what Jen was trying to say.

If she wanted to be with Agatha, if Agatha would ever leave Ralph, Jen was trying to tell her to be prepared.

“I have little cousins,” Rio said suddenly, turning from Agatha to focus on Jennifer. “They’ve papped me before with them. They love me and I love them. There’s been articles about me taking them to the park. I talk about my family on talk shows. I take my mom and dad to games. I attend rallies for causes I care about and I’m a Goodwill Ambassador for UNICEF. But more importantly than all that I’m a good daughter, a good friend, and a good person. I don’t need my image cleaned up. And I don’t need your judgement on me either.”

Agatha’s arm reached across her as she came to her conclusion and unlike her tentative hold before, she’d stretched her arm fully across Rio, protectively guarding her from the woman across the room.

“You don’t need to defend yourself,” she said without looking at Rio, her eyes still on Jen. “She doesn’t, Jen.”

“I’m not saying she’s a bad person.”

“You’re saying I’m not good enough.”

Jen huffed and Agatha’s hand clutched at the fabric of her sweats, her knuckles pale with effort.

“Rio, babe,” Alice said in a faux-calm voice, “You’re fine. Your image is fine. You’re well-liked and-…”

“I’m just saying you’re not exactly on Agatha’s level.”

“Jesus, Jennifer!” Agatha exclaimed and Rio instinctively grabbed Agatha’s arm as it sat diagonally across her. “Back off.”

Rio cleared her throat and slipped her left hand down the length of Agatha’s arm to curl over her hand. “It’s fine, Agatha. She’s being-…”

“A bitch,” Agatha concluded.

“No one will come out of this clean if it ever comes out or you decided to go public.”

Rio felt Agatha stiffen beside her but she didn’t pull away and Rio took in a steadying breath as she said: “We don’t need to worry about that right now. We’re being cautious - overly so. The world sees us as friends, or as being friendly until the season is over. Soon I’ll be back to filming and there won’t be cameras on us every second.”

“Mention Rio cleaning up her image one more time and I’ll fire you.”

It was a warning shot. One delivered with impeccable accuracy, but one that had clearly been anticipated.

“You’ve lost yourself an Oscar because of a crush, Agatha. I’m not sure firing me is in your best interests if you want to keep your career.”

Rio wasn’t sure if she or Agatha had tensed first but the fact was that both of them had. Alice had moved on the couch to throw her arm over Jen in the same way that Agatha’s arm was over Rio, and she was staring wide-eyed at the two women opposite.

“You don’t mean that, Jen,” Alice prompted softly as Rio moved her hand over to wrap around Agatha’s thigh, her head turning to look at the woman beside her.

“Cheap fucking shot, Jen. That all you got?”

Rio swallowed and shook her head, “Agatha. Leave it.”

Jen sneered but looked away, “Alice and I are handling this because the two of you-…” she seemed to think better of it and sighed as she tried again, “we know what we’re doing. I just hope you two do too.”

Rio kept her eyes on Agatha, leaning around her to dislodge her arm and cup her cheek to get her to turn into her, “Hey. Relax. It’s fine. A whole week soon, okay?”

It took a few seconds but Agatha pulled her arm from Rio and instead took the hand that was on her cheek. She kissed it and dropped it to her lap, toying idly with her fingers.

Alice was looking away, a faint blush across her cheeks. Jennifer was staring at the floor now, her face set, her brow furrowed.

And Rio breathed out slowly, and forced a smile, forced herself to not say anything that might start the arguments again and instead settled on: “Can we go back to bed?”

The curve of Agatha’s lips told her she was taken by surprise and the laugh that followed was soft and for Rio’s ears only. “Please.”

“Alice and I should leave,” she said once she’d enjoyed Agatha’s smile a little while longer, pretending not to see her blue eyes filling with tears. “We’ll just keep arguing.”

“I’m not arguing, Rio. I’m telling.” Jen was watching the two again and Rio sighed quietly, beginning to extricate herself from Agatha’s hold.

“Alice, we should go.”

As she stood Agatha moved closer to the edge of the chair and Rio turned to her to tilt her face up and kiss her. To her surprise Agatha didn’t pull away. She held onto Rio’s wrists with a firmness that was as welcome as it was unexpected. She kissed her back, pressing another softer peck to her lips when Rio broke it.

“I’m sorry. I’ll call you later.”

Rio smiled as she pulled away and shot Jen only a cursory glance as she moved back through to grab her bag and collect her things.

“I’m trying to help!” Jen called out behind her but Rio ignored her and heard Agatha say something back but she didn’t hear exactly what.

Alice was waiting by the door and Rio managed to smile at her as she opened it for her but just as she was stepping out a hand found her arm and she was turned around, “I just need a second.”

Rio raised her brows but turned to Agatha readily, “What is it?”

Agatha’s eyes darted to Alice and then back to Rio and Rio frowned as she turned to motion to Alice to leave them and she pushed back on the door to close it. “Agatha? What-?”

But a pair of soft lips had silenced Rio and Rio’s words were the last thing on her mind as her fingers curled into the soft flannel of Agatha’s robe at her waist. Agatha broke the kiss after only a second or two and whispered just for Rio’s ears, “That’s how I’d kiss you when you win.”

“Agatha,” Rio whispered back with a deep frown, her eyes fluttering open to take in Agatha’s soft smile before her, the blue eyes that looked pained. “I expected a little more tongue.”

Agatha’s laugh ghosted her lips and Rio tried not to shiver as she wrapped her arms around the brunette’s neck, “You’ll be a two-time Oscar winner soon and safe in the knowledge that I always want to kiss you. With or without tongue.”

Whether real or imagined Agatha’s shoulders dropped an inch and she shrank her body more into Rio. And Rio frowned as she did. She tightened her hold as Agatha murmured, suddenly serious, with more sincerity than a mourner’s prayer: “Rio, I had a really good time last night.”

“Agatha.”

“I mean it.”

“I know,” Rio said calmly, though she felt anything but. “I did too.”

“It’s not a crush.” The words were rushed out, falling over their own consonants to make themselves heard.

Rio nodded, swallowing the truth that Agatha couldn’t yet bring herself to admit.

Alice was stepping back over though and Agatha pulled away before Rio could kiss her again. Rio’s hands lingered for as long as possible on Agatha and she only turned at the very last second to follow her manager out the door.

They made it to the car in record time, with Alice not keen on dawdling when she knew Agatha em Jen wouldn’t be far behind.

“Will she leave him?”

Rio’s head with leaning against the window of the car that had arrived to take them home and her eyes were trained on the road outside as they powered to her little house in the hills.

“I hope so.”

“She’s not told you she will?”

“We didn’t exactly do a lot of talking last night, Alice.”

“Has she even hinted that-…?”

Rio sighed and closed her eyes, “Why did Jen ask if I were okay earlier?”

“I don’t know.”

Rio turned to blink at Alice, “At all?”

“No. I asked her why she called you yesterday and she didn’t give me an answer.”

Rio turned back to the window and felt Alice reach for her sleeve. “Hey. You look good together. She’s smitten, that’s clear. Jen knows it’s not just a crush.”

Rio scoffed but softened as she thought back to how Agatha had curled into her the night before, how she harboured the secret of the stolen shirt, how she looked more refreshed that morning than Rio had seen her in a long time despite only getting a handful of hours’ sleep.

“I’m so in love with her.”

“I know, babe.”

“Last night she… she’s frightened. I hope of just losing Nicky. At least… she won’t tell me what else she’s frightened of. But she’s scared and she hides it well but sometimes she just lets go and lets me see it and I don’t know how to fix it.”

“Jen says they’ve been arguing more.”

Rio shook her head and turned from Alice again, unsure she wanted to hear this.

“I can’t believe she’s with him.”

“It’s strange,” Alice said in a much lighter tone than before, but Rio could hear the strain in her voice, “How natural the two of you look together. She’s this big, megawatt movie star and you’re my best friend and yet you look… you both look like you’re where you want to be when you’re together.”

Rio didn’t respond after that. They made their way back to Rio’s house in silence and Rio disappeared for a run before Alice could broach the topic of her affair again.

The cool air stung her lungs as she raced through the hills and valleys in the dusty trails of northern Los Angeles. Each heavy step in the Californian soil brought her closer and closer to her decision.

It wasn’t born of nothing, it wasn’t made from scratch. It had been tumbling round and round in Rio’s brain for weeks now. But the intensity of the exercise, the heart that thrummed in her chest but really remained across the city with another, gave her the courage to stand by her convictions.

She would make it clear to Agatha that she would be there for her after Ralph. That she would be there for Nicky too if she wanted her to be. That she’d hold her fears as her own and try everything to soften them until they were harmless ghosts of worries past.

She’d tell her when they were away, in no uncertain terms, that she wanted to be with her, turn this into something that didn’t have to remain hidden, and she’d proudly announce to the world that Rio Vidal belonged with Agatha Harkness.

It was as she was deciding exactly how she’d tell Agatha - over dinner, in candlelight - she felt her phone vibrate against her hip and the music blasting in her headphones pause.

“Alice, what is it?” She barked into the open air, her wireless AirPods picking up her voice as she continued her run.

“Actually it’s me.”

Rio almost skidded as she stopped suddenly and managed to right herself quickly before she said: “Agatha. Shit. Sorry. I told Alice not to bother me whilst I-…”

“Are you busy?”

“I’m just on a run.”

“I won’t keep you. I just wanted to check you were okay.”

Rio was panting softly and though she knew she was alone she looked around to make sure she was. “I’m fine. Are you?”

“Jen is just mad that I’ve kept this from her for so long.”

“I know, Agatha.”

“She’s making the wrong call about keeping us apart at the lunch.”

“Is that right?”

“Rio.”

“Yeah, Agatha?”

“I’m sitting next to you at that lunch.”

Rio laughed and stretched her arm across her chest, “Are you going to bully someone into switching?”

“No. I’ll just move the place names.”

“It’s that important to you?”

“It’s not to you?”

Rio sighed as she moved to lean back against a nearby tree. “I don’t like it any more than you do. But it’s also not something to worry about. I’m just focusing on our week alone where we can sit where we want and do what we want.”

“That isn’t the point.”

“Then what is the point?”

“The point is,” and Rio began to grin as Agatha’s voice got louder, “That I want to sit next to you.”

“Me?”

“Stop it.”

Rio laughed again, “You’re mad because you can’t sit next to me.”

Agatha didn’t answer for a second and then she said, “Will you wear your necklace?”

“I was planning on it.”

“It’s more than a crush.”

Rio raised her brows and slowly lowered herself into the dirt, crouching by the base of the tree. “You said.”

“I just don’t want you to think it’s just sex or something.”

Rio glanced at her watch, wondering if she’d soon get a warning about her heart rate being suddenly dangerously high. “I don’t think that.”

“Good, because it isn’t. And I want to make sure you know that.”

“Agatha? Is everything okay?”

Rio’s question went unanswered for a few seconds before Agatha eventually said again: “I just want to make sure you know that.”

“Okay, I do. I know that.”

“Okay,” Agatha said in a voice that sounded to Rio like she was finally relaxing.

“Agatha?”

“Mm?”

“We just need to get through the next few days and then we’ll discuss everything when we’re together again, okay?”

“Not calling it off, though? Not breaking up with me for-…?”

“Breaking up? I didn’t realise we were in a relationship.”

There was silence again and Rio began to chew on her lip, worried she’d pushed it too far. She slid down properly onto her ass and stretched her legs out in front of her, watching the red dust float into the air where she’d disturbed it.

“Are you going to break it off with me?”

“No. That’s the farthest from what I want.”

Agatha was silent again and realising she wouldn’t break it Rio did it for her: “What’s going on, Agatha? Jen asked me if I were okay yesterday and you reacted to it before I could even respond to it and now you’re suddenly worried I want to break it off?”

Rio was met with another wall of silence, another barrier to the internal workings of Agatha’s brain.

“We have to be able to talk, Agatha. Or this will never work.”

“Our trip. We’ll talk when we have the time to. When it’s just us.”

“Fine.”

“It’s not a crush, Rio.”

Rio sighed heavily, her heart sinking under the weight of her own patience. “I know, Agatha.”

“I’ll let you get back to your run.”

“Okay. I’ll see you tomorrow.”

“Hey,” Agatha breathed out quickly before Rio could tap her AirPod to hang up. “I just want to sit beside you.”

Rio nodded on the deserted trail, watching the wind move the dust by her feet. “I know. I want that too.”

“Bye, honey.”

“Bye, Agatha.”

Two taps and Agatha was gone.

Rio finished her run but with none of the gusto she’d had before.

The wind had been taken out of her sails only to be replaced by a slow sense of dread that stayed with her until the next day where she went through the motions of getting ready with her usual glam squad.

She couldn’t rationalise it. Couldn’t reason it. Agatha was telling her without saying the words that she wanted her, that she was scared Rio would back away, that she wanted to talk when they were together. These were all good things. But something was sparking in her mind like a flint stone aiming for a fire.

All she could calm herself with was the impending reunion with Agatha, the sight of her again, the feel of her hand in her own.

Her face and body were moved this way and that as she was made up to be the star everyone wanted her to be. She’d chosen - alongside her stylist - a simple grey plaid suit with cropped pants and a white crop top underneath. It was formal enough and allowed her to wear Agatha’s necklace without angering the man hired to arrange every detail of her look. Alice had simply rolled her eyes when she saw the green jewel sparkling against Rio’s tanned skin.

But Alice wasn’t invited so wouldn’t be able to roll her eyes at Rio anymore that day. And Rio knew that was partially the reason her and Jen had tried to keep Rio and Agatha apart. They would have no control once the event started. It was closed off, press free apart from the initial red carpet, and supposed to be informal.

The Oscars Luncheon was an event arranged to get all the nominees together; it was an excuse to mingle, to congratulate each other on their mutual success, and for the Academy to get their annual nominees photo.

But for Rio Vidal, it was an excuse to see Agatha again.

“Jesus, Vidal. Give us all a break.” Rio rolled her eyes as Jessica Dyson pressed a kiss to her cheek and squeezed her arm, “You look hot. Who’re you trying to impress?”

“Jess, if it were at all appropriate I’d be asking you to make out right now.”

Jessica laughed and Rio twinkled a grin up at her after looking her over appreciatively. A glass of champagne in her system and the familiar butterflies that came with soon seeing Agatha had killed any concerns she’d had in the hours before her arrival. And now, surrounded by her talented and beautiful peers, she was just excited to see the most talented and beautiful of them all.

“Flirt.”

“Such a shame you’re straight.”

“Is anyone these days?”

Rio laughed and raised her brows, “Then you’re telling me I have a shot?”

“Hey.”

A hand on Rio’s lower back and a soft voice told her Agatha had arrived and Rio’s teasing smile softened as she looked over her shoulder to see Agatha arrive by her side, her hand still comfortably on her back.

“Am I interrupting something?”

“Just the usual flirting,” Jessica said breezily as she smiled at Agatha, not daring to lean in and greet her properly.

But Rio did. She reached her arm back around Agatha’s shoulders and leant in to kiss her cheek.

“Flirting?”

Rio had barely pulled back before Agatha was asking the question, her blue eyes bright and her smile frozen in place on her face.

“Well I can’t flirt with you, being a married woman and all.”

“I’m not sure that would stop you, Rio.”

Rio shot Jessica a playful glare and then turned back to Agatha, seeing her eyes flicker across her face, not settling on her gaze. “I’m an excellent flirt. Just sharing the love.”

Agatha hummed and Rio felt her hand move around to her hip, pulling her in closer to her side.

Rio’s smile widened and she settled more against Agatha, her own arm still draped across her upper back. Agatha had opted for a black dress with a floral pattern across it and a scoop at the neckline that Rio had to fight hard not to focus in on.

“So, got a date to the big event?”

“My parents.”

Jessica smiled and turned her attention to Agatha, the person Rio knew she really wanted to chat to. “Agatha? Are you taking Ralph?”

“Who else?”

Agatha’s fingers squeezed Rio’s hip and Rio bit the corner of her lip.

“He’s handsome,” Jessica said with a smile that was getting more delighted by the second, assuming as she did that Agatha Harkness was interested in her compliments about her husband. “Tall, too. You’re this, like, crazy beautiful couple.”

Rio wondered if she’d ever been as starstruck as Jessica currently was around Agatha and had to force herself not to think of how she’d acted around her when they first met for fear she’d give herself away and blush.

But Jessica was doing an incredible job of looking like a deer in the headlines as she addressed Agatha.

“Thank you,” Agatha said demurely, turning her head away from Jessica to look at Rio and leaning away as she did to get a better look at her.

“Maybe Rio could learn from me and find someone tall and beautiful for herself.”

Rio raised her brows and before she could respond Jessica had jumped in. “My money’s on Wanda.”

Jesus

“Not my type,” Rio said quickly, her hand now sliding down Agatha’s back, her fingers resting perilously close to the curve of her ass. “More into brunettes.”

Agatha had pulled away completely now but not before squeezing Rio’s hip. “Well I’m not sure you’ll get lucky here.”

“No?”

Rio shot Agatha a hopeful smile and Agatha avoided her gaze.

“Keep flirting and you might,” Jessica said with a grin in Rio’s direction before turning to Agatha. “So, Agatha, how’s the kid? Nicholas, is it?”

Agatha didn’t have her arm around Rio anymore and so Rio decided she couldn’t just keep touching the most admired woman in the room. She pulled away and shot Jessica a quick goodbye smile before she turned to leave but found her hand had been snatched up and she was being pulled back to Agatha so roughly that she collided with her side.

Jessica was so dazzled by Agatha that she didn’t really notice and Rio managed to play it off, just.

“He’s fine, thank you. I’ve just bought him a season ticket to the Celtics so he’s over the moon.”

“You have?” Rio adjusted her stance to step back a little from Agatha but placed her hand on her back again. “What about the Bulls?”

“Ralph will just have to deal with the fact that Nicky’s not a Bulls fan.”

Rio opened her mouth to respond, momentarily struck dumb by Agatha’s matter-of-fact tone, but Jessica had beat her to it: “He likes basketball? Oh wait. You went to a game together, right?”

Rio could only nod, and turned from Agatha to her friend with a smile, “Yeah. Experienced life as a mega star for a day. It was…” Agatha stepped a little closer to her side again and Rio thought she caught her checking her out from the corner of her eye. “Frightening how crazy people get around Agatha.”

“Rio was our protector.” Rio blinked and turned in surprise to Agatha as she smiled up at Jessica, “She kept us safe. She was so diligent about making sure Nicky was okay in the crowds and with the paps. It was… incredible.”

Was Agatha bragging about her?

“A superhero? Rio, who knew you had it in you.”

Rio rolled her eyes at Jessica but felt her cheeks flush all the same.

“Anyway, Agatha, I haven’t had a chance all this time to tell you how incredible you are in No Heaven. It was honestly a revelation. I’ve been doing a lot of dream work lately with my acting coach and I-…”

Rio’s attention began to drift. A, being in this sort of conversation about acting always made her feel a little queasy, and B, because Agatha’s arm had slipped not only around her waist but somehow under her blazer. Her warm skin was now against Rio’s and her long fingers had curled around her side. It felt illegal to be here like this with her, so casually leaning against each other, so deliciously close and perilously open.

Her attention soon turned to Agatha and she watched her respond, saw the polite smile she kept on her face, the distant look in her eyes as she rattled off something about emotional cues or breath work.

Rio wondered how Agatha could stand being so idolised all the time, how she could comprehend the people around her always wanting to be near her but never knowing her. And suddenly, through the lens of Agatha as a movie star, the woman currently pressing her into her side made a little more sense.

Agatha had only really let Rio close. No one else.

No one, in the history of the world, had ever been closer to Agatha than she was.

And Rio felt the spark that had been trying to ignite before slowly die again.

“Rio?”

“Hmm?” Rio’s head snapped around to Jessica and she blinked stupidly across at her as she felt Agatha’s fingers slide a little further up her ribs.

“I said we should go sit. I think you’re not too far from me, actually.”

Rio nodded and smiled and reluctantly pulled away from Agatha. She shot her a quick glance before she followed Jessica over to the large banquet table laid out with seasonal flowers and crystal glasses. Jessica dropped off their little group some way up the table and looked bereft as she took a seat beside a bald man in a beige suit.

Rio could only squeeze her shoulder for support and move on up. She scanned the place cards until she found her own and smiled when she saw who was next to her.

“Jen gave in?”

“Not exactly.”

Rio pulled out Agatha’s chair for her.

“You actually swapped them?”

“You catch on so quickly.”

Rio rolled her eyes as she helped Agatha push her chair in and took up her seat beside her, “Jen will be pissed.”

“I don’t care, do you?”

Agatha’s hand landed on Rio’s thigh as she settled in and Rio rolled her eyes as if it didn’t affect her and placed her hand on top of Agatha’s, sliding it up just an inch or two. Blue eyes darted down to the movement and Agatha’s fingers flexed before she spoke again: “Is this the kind of flirting only I have access to?”

Rio laughed as she removed her hand from Agatha’s and made eyes at someone familiar across the way, taking a second to wave before she turned back to Agatha, “The kind of flirting you have access to is not luncheon appropriate.”

“Can it be week away by ourselves appropriate?”

“Without a doubt.”

Rio’s earlier wave had been interpreted as a waving over and so Agatha’s smirk had to quickly morph into a smile as they were pounced on by their acquaintances. Rio was left with the memory of Agatha’s warm hand against her as she turned to commit to the act of charming Oscar nominee.

By the time Rio’s smile was beginning to feel tight on her face, the food was beginning to arrive along the banquet tables and so Rio was saved from her cheek pain as people once again moved away.

She turned back as Agatha did and smiled more genuinely when Agatha muttered, “Kiss asses.”

“Hey, Rio Vidal.”

Rio looked up and smiled genuinely again at the sight of Wanda Maximoff leaning across the table to her. She stood and lean too, just about managing a quick cheek kiss without knocking over the carafe of water directly beneath her.

“Where have you been?”

“Oh, trying my best to charm Hollywood’s elite.”

Rio grinned as she sat down again and Wanda turned to Agatha, still leaning across and holding her arm out to her. “Agatha, so great to see you.”

Agatha didn’t move. Rio kicked her under the table. Agatha still didn’t move.

“So,” Rio said quickly to recover the awkward moment as Wanda schooled her face and sat down again. “Getting ready for jingle bells and making merry?”

“God,” Wanda’s facade fell completely as she took her seat and helped push the chair out for an arriving Lilia. “Apparently the studio is still arguing schedules.”

“Really?”

“Some bullshit about some pickups that I just don’t understand. We’d scheduled those for later in the year so I don’t know where all this has come from.”

“But,” Rio frowned as a waiter leant in to fill her glass with champagne, “We start in two weeks.”

“It’ll sort itself,” Wanda said with a reassuring smile and a hand held out to Rio across the table. Rio could only take it but felt as her fingers came into contact with Wanda’s a hand back on her thigh, at least two inches higher than it had been earlier.

“Perhaps the studio is looking for a reason to get rid of you.”

“Agatha.”

Rio turned to the woman beside her then who shrugged like she didn’t know what she’d just said and pulled away her hand from Rio. “It’s a possibility.”

A laugh escaped Rio’s lips as she pulled her hand from Wanda and stared incredulously at the woman now sipping her champagne and looking down the table as if she hadn’t just been openly rude to one of the nicest people in Hollywood.

“It’s fine, Rio,” Wanda said softly, but loud enough for Agatha to hear too.

And Rio knew that was the wrong thing to do the moment she felt Agatha shift beside her, her ankle looping underneath her own and her jaw - from what Rio could see out of the corner of her eye - suddenly tight.

But Agatha didn’t say anything else.

“Did you get my flowers?” It was going to be a long lunch.

Wanda’s question made Agatha sniff loudly and Rio wished suddenly that Agatha hadn’t switched the seating plan because this could be a conversation between herself and Wanda that Agatha didn’t need to be privy to.

“Didn’t you get my text?”

And Rio caught something she wasn’t expecting in Wanda’s face: triumph.

She glanced aside at Agatha and saw that her jaw was working overtime and then turned back to the redhead and suddenly realised what she was doing.

“Wanda?” She said urgently, standing as she said it, “Do you need the bathroom?”

“No, babe.”

“Okay well I do and you should come with.”

She could feel Agatha’s eyes on her but she couldn’t look back. She needed to speak to Wanda.

Wanda nodded once and murmured a soft apology to Lilia beside her as she stood and went to follow Rio as they walked down opposite sides of the table, met at the top, and allowed Rio to take her arm and pull her to the bathroom.

“Everything okay?” Wanda asked as they stepped inside and Rio moved to check under all the stalls.

Satisfied that they were alone she sighed and ran her hands through her hair, “I know Agatha can be difficult.”

“She hates me, Rio.”

“She doesn’t hate-…”

“She does and I think I know why.”

Rio went to lean back against the counter and looked down at her feet as she waited for the inevitable denial she’d have to deliver. She tensed her body, prepared her face to be as neutral as possible, shifted slightly when Wanda moved closer, “She wanted my part in the movie.”

Okay, she’d read that very wrong. She looked up and almost laughed in Wanda’s face.

“What?”

“She wanted the part. I overheard my manager talking at the BAFTAs with Stark and Agatha’s name come up so I… I think she wanted my part and she’s pissed that I got it.”

Rio blinked.

“It makes sense. It’s the part she’d have been up for… other than yours but that was changed after the scripts went out. It was on The Black List five years in a row and it’s already getting buzz. Plus you’re going to get the Oscar so I’m sure she thinks that she could get herself in with Supporting on this one.”

Rio felt like her brain was on go-slow mode, like she’d swallowed an ambien without realising. But she couldn’t let on to Wanda that she was way off the mark. Agatha didn’t want her part. Agatha had no interest in being in the movie.

Wanda was still talking and Rio didn’t realise that she hadn’t been listening until she heard her name.

“… and then there’s you, Rio.”

“Me?”

“I’ve been thinking about you too.”

Rio shifted where she stood and frowned as the door opened and a familiar looking producer came in, shot them both a smile, and disappeared into a stall.
