Oh Agatha’s getting nervous…

Chapter 25: Oscar Night

Chapter Summary

The Oscars are here.

Rio is more nervous than she’s ever been in her life.

Agatha’s fear hasn’t yet died down.

Chapter Notes

Only good things happen in this chapter 🫡

See the end of the chapter for more notes

In 1929, in a private dining room in the Roosevelt Hotel on Hollywood Boulevard, the first Academy Awards was held. The first recipient of the Best Actress Award was Janet Gaynor, who was awarded for her work in three films and remains to this day the only actress to ever be awarded by the Academy in one single year for multiple roles.

Janet was a silent film star. She had big brown eyes and was having an affair with a fellow actor.

Two of these things Rio Vidal could emphasise with.

The silent part, however, not so much.

She’d spent the whole day talking. She was talking about everything and anything because she was excited - and Rio always talked too much when she was excited, or nervous, or lying - but also because the one person she most wanted to talk to she couldn’t.

And hadn’t since she’d had phone sex with her two nights previously.

Her mom and dad had arrived around midday the day before the Oscars and Rio, though constantly badgered by Alice not to eat or drink too much, and to avoid “if at all possible, Rio” injuring herself in any major (or minor) way, had spent the time since their arrival lounging around and regaling them with stories of Hollywood parties past.

It was a trait she’d inherited from her dad: to tell stories and do her best to entertain when she wanted to put someone at ease. Only the person she’d been trying to put at ease this whole time was herself.

By the time the actual day of the Oscars rolled around, Rio was practically all talked out, and no more at ease.

But Miguel was there to help with that. And dios mío, he was working his magic on his daughter.

“Jesus, Rio. Would you please come here.”

Rio didn’t hear Alice because she was bent double laughing at something her dad had said. And her dad’s laughter was even louder than her own so Alice just didn’t stand a chance.

“Ellos están cortados de la misma tela.” They’re cut from the same cloth.

Anna Vidal placed her hand on Alice’s shoulder and reached around her to offer a glass of champagne. “Dales diez minutos más, Alice. Este es un gran día para ambos.” Give them ten more minutes, Alice. This is a big day for both of them.

Alice grumbled but she’d always had trouble saying no to Rio’s mom so she took a sip of her champagne and watched as Rio snorted and her dad, with his rosy cheeks and watering eyes, slapped her back.

Alice’s phone began to buzz against her hip so she had to turn away from the father-daughter duo and answer the call.

That left Anna to rally the troops but there was little chance of that when Rio and Miguel were enjoying themselves too much.

“Mi vida!” Miguel announced the arrival of his wife with his arms open wide and his smile equally so as she’d moved closer to begin the extraction. “¿Como estas, hermosa?”

“Los dos le van a dar un infarto an Alice.” The two of you are going to give Alice a heart attack.”

Rio’s laughter picked up and she began to claw at her mom, eventually convincing her to turn from her dad’s hold to move into her own. “She is just being dramatic. We have mucho tiempo!”

Anna laughed and kissed her daughter’s temple which made Rio grin, a big, cheesy, Oscar-nominated grin.

“Comportáte con esa pobre mujer.” Behave for that poor woman.

Rio barked another laugh as her mom pulled out from her hold and held her cheeks in her hands, “Mija…”

Rio’s laughter died down and she nodded slowly and hummed as her dad gave her a “we’ve been told” look over her mom’s shoulder. Rio giggled again as her mom moved away and playfully tapped her dad’s cheek.

“Mala influencia,” Anna muttered as she moved away from her husband and unruly child and went back to her knitting on the couch.

“You’re in trouuuble,” Rio sang out to her dad who simply moved to kiss her temple in the same place her mom had and gave his daughter a tender squeeze.

“Behave now.”

Rio laughed again and slapped at her dad as he moved away, strutting his stuff in his daughter’s hotel suite to try his charms on his wife. Rio watched the little show, recognising, not for the first time, that she was a lot like her dad as she watched him turn on the charm with her mom.

Anna looked stern at first and then began to soften until eventually she was laughing into his arms and closing her eyes as Miguel kissed her cheek. But Rio’s enjoyment of this little spectacle was soon dampened by a tiny Asian woman with a big frown.

“Alice.”

“Are you ready to allow the professionals to get to work now?”

“Alice,” Rio said again, her grin now a permanent feature on her face. “Have I told you how beautiful you look today?”

“You’re so goddamn irritating.”

“I’ve been told.”

Alice shook her head but Rio caught her trying to hide her smile and she launched at her just as she turned away, “Lighten up!! Your best friend is nominated for an Oscar!”

Alice protested for a few seconds and then began to laugh as Rio’s excitement got her. Rio was like Gloria Estefan: but it wasn’t the rhythm that was gonna getcha, it was the goddamn enthusiasm.

In fact, that had been the joke that had made Rio and her dad laugh so hard in the first place.

“Holy shit, Rio.” Alice began to laugh harder as Rio clung to her and dragged her to the floor with her for no reason other than to encourage the laughter spilling from her friend’s mouth.

“Rio Elena Vidal!”

Even her mom middle-naming her didn’t stop her and it took her dad coming over with a wide grin and his hands held down to them as she squeezed the life and laughter out of Alice that made her relent and roll over. She caught his eyes and rolled her own as she accepted the help and was heaved up alongside her best friend.

“Tu madre te matará.” Your mother will kill you.

Rio just laughed as she kissed her dad’s cheek and turned to Alice with that same, omnipresent grin, “Okay, okay. I’m willing to behave now.”

Alice was still laughing and was a little breathless with it as she tugged Rio down into a hug and Miguel left them to it. “Jen called,” she whispered into Rio’s ear, her laughter softening until it dissolved, “Nicky wants to see you.”

“Nicky?” Rio asked in surprise, significantly louder than Alice had just been. She shot a quick glance over at her parents but they didn’t seem to have heard and turned her head back into Alice’s embrace. “With Agatha?”

“Jen’s allowing her ten minutes and no more. So go and make yourself look like you haven’t just been wrestling on the floor and I’ll go get them.”

Rio’s mouth suddenly felt dry, her stomach churning in knots, “Alice I’m in my robe and my hair is wet and...”

“I’m sure she’s seen you looking worse.” Alice pulled back with a grin brighter than even Rio’s had been earlier and rubbed up and down her arms. “Go. Hair and makeup. Now.”

Rio huffed but her smile returned as she picked up her lukewarm coffee cup and went through to the living space in the suite where her glam squad were ready and waiting for her.

She was greeted like royalty and she bowed to them before she accepted the hugs and kisses that were her due as the Oscar Nominee on her big day. The music playing was softer than she’d expected but she supposed they had a long day ahead and the dance tunes would come on later.

She was ushered to a chair opposite the window and handed a glass of champagne once her coffee had been stolen.

“Espressos only now,” her stylist warned, “very little food for the rest of the day too.”

Rio grumbled her assent but closed her eyes readily when serums and cooling balms were applied to her still shower-warmed skin. Someone was behind her already tackling her wet hair and someone else was by her feet applying more creams and lotions.

Her mind drifted as the talk picked back up around her and she enjoyed the idle gossip of a team she’d come through this season with and now knew intimately. They exchanged rumours of divas falling out with certain designers and discussed which man might wear something other than a regular tux that night.

And the gossip calmed her excitement and further quashed the nerves only just now beginning to show themselves in the pit of her stomach.

But the sound of her suite door opening stole her attention not five minutes later and Rio turned her head just in time to see Alice marching in with two guests.

Agatha was wearing a soft cashmere sweater and light jeans, her hair was damp and down over her shoulders and she had that movie star glowy skin that Rio always so envied. She looked tired. It had been two days and Rio already missed her desperately. And then, at her side and clinging to her hand was Rio’s twin, wearing Spiderman pyjamas and clutching something in his hand.

“Hey,” Rio beamed at them and she made a move to extricate herself from her helpers.

“We won’t keep you,” Agatha reassured, her eyes briefly darting to the squad now scrambling to untangle themselves from Rio as she stood from her seat.

“That’s okay we have plenty of time.”

Nicky smiled just a little but his gaze moved to the people behind Rio and he looked serious again, his cheeks flaming pink as he clutched at Agatha.

“Hey,” Rio said as she watched this happen in real-time, “you know who else is here? My mom and dad. Do you remember them? Mom’s got all kinds of snacks! Why don’t we sit with them for a bit?”

Nicky nodded and Rio stood quickly and turned to her waiting squad, “Ten minutes. I promise. Then I’m all yours.”

“It just looks so good all the time and I-…” but Agatha’s hand was taken from her own as her mom came over and stole the woman she loved without even asking.

“¡Ay, Agatha, ya estás guapísima! ¡Qué gusto verte! ¡Y a Nicky también! ¡Qué niño tan adorable!” Oh, Agatha, you look beautiful already! It is so lovely to see you! And Nicky too! Darling boy!

“He’s been practicing,” Agatha whispered in answer to Rio’s unspoken question, moving back closer again so their shoulders could bump.

“Adorable,” Rio whispered right back just as both Nicky and Anna looked up to her. She raised her brows in question and felt Agatha squeeze her hand and then pull away.

“Es más simpática de lo que parece.” She’s nicer than she looks.

Her mom was grinning at Nicky and nudged him gently to move forwards to Rio and Rio still looked at him curiously as he moved over, being strangely shy for someone who she’d been throwing about the basketball court not that long ago.

“I made you this,” he suddenly said, back to English, back to being serious as he unfurled his fist and held up a small green origami flower.

“For me?”

“It’s just like mama’s. Only green. For luck. And Celtics.”

Rio looked up as Nicky relaxed a little and smiled at her, twisting his hands together and rocking up on his tiptoes.

She heard her mom whisper something inaudible to Agatha and heard Agatha whisper back but Rio simply opened her arms out and pulled Nicky in for a hug, frowning even as she smiled.

“Thank you. I’ll keep it forever.”

“Just like mama’s.”

Rio nodded and swallowed thickly as she pulled back and held Nicky by his shoulders. “Just like your mama’s.”

“Mama said I could keep it today so it’s safe for when she’s back home.”

She couldn’t find the words to say as she stared at it but Agatha had moved closer and was ducking down to be on Nicky’s level too. She’d placed her hand on Rio’s back.

“Honey, I think we should go now. Rio has to get ready.”

Rio’s mom had moved in too, understanding well enough without having to be told that her daughter needed a second. And Nicky happily turned to her, showing off the little blue flower that was almost as precious as he was.

“You kept it?” Rio asked quietly, turning her attention slowly to Agatha now watching her.

“Of course.”

“Agatha, that’s…”

Agatha only smiled and made to cup Rio’s hand that still held the little green creation. “He’s worked really hard on making it a good one.”

Rio released a soft, incredulous laugh as she watched Agatha and was only just able to stop herself from leaning in to kiss her. “Can’t you get ready here? Squeeze in with us?”

“Ralph’s here,” Agatha muttered quietly, something in her expression changing even as she glanced over to check on Nicky who was now being entertained by Miguel.

“Right, of course he is.”

Agatha leant in then, her hand still cupped beneath Rio’s, her breath warm against her cheek as she lingered close and kissed her there. “I wish we could.”

Rio nodded and smiled tightly, making to stand and offer her hand out to Agatha who took it and held on as she looked back to Nicky. “Nicky, honey, let’s get going.”

“¡Ah! ¿Ya? ¡No! Quédate con nosotros. Seguro que tenemos mejores aperitivos.” Oh! Already? Stay with us! We have better snacks, I’m sure.

Rio rolled her eyes but her dad shot her a wink and she saw him glance at the hand that was still in Agatha’s. She blushed and dropped it.

“Nos encantaría, Anna. Pero tenemos que volver o mi jefa me mata. Y puede dar bastante miedo, ¿verdad, Nicky?” We’d love to, Anna. But we need to get back or my manager will kill me. And she can be pretty scary, right, Nicky?

This white woman who was brought up on the east coast with all sorts of privilege speaking impeccable Spanish to her Puerto Rican mother and sounding unbelievably sexy whilst doing it. Not to mention genuinely annoyed she couldn’t stay with them. She didn’t think she could be more in love.

Agatha looked a little panicked but hadn’t protested as Rio had practically dragged her across the suite. Blue eyes flashed to Rio’s hand as she clicked the lock and she whispered, “Rio. Not here. Not-…”

“I just want to talk.”

Agatha’s mouth opened and closed and Rio watched as she took a step back. Rio stepped forwards. “Agatha.”

“Rio, this looks so suspicious.”

Rio sighed quietly but moved closer again, “I won’t get another chance.”

Agatha blinked as Rio placed her hands on her face and held her still. She watched her for a second, searched for any protest that might make its way past Agatha’s lips, and seeing none coming, she closed the distance and kissed her.

The kiss was slow, the type of unrushed kiss with Agatha that Rio loved. They’d not had many of them. They’d certainly never had any where Rio’s family were so close by and Nicky was just behind the door.

It was a risky move.

But this was necessary. Rio needed it more than she could communicate, more than she could even admit to herself. And perhaps Agatha did too because she wrapped her arms immediately around Rio and held her to her as she kissed her back.

It didn’t last long. But Rio had achieved her goal of kissing the woman she loved on her big day. She’d tasted her tongue for all of a few precious seconds and felt her pressed against her.

And it had to be enough.

“That’s what you wanted to say?” Agatha asked quietly, now nudging their noses together with a smile tugging at her lips.

“Yes.”

Agatha laughed against her and Rio grinned as she stole another quick kiss. “Okay. We can go back now.”

“Fine,” Agatha murmured, kissing Rio once more before Rio pulled away. She checked her robe was in place and then stepped out again, schooling her face into a neutral smile. Thankfully no one was waiting for them on the other side.

Rio cleared her throat and touched her lips as she returned to where Alice, Nicky, and her parents were. She ignored Alice’s pointed stare and focused on Nicky instead.

“I guess I’ll see you soon?”

“For basketball?”

“For basketball.”

Nicky grinned and hugged her middle so Rio dropped down to hug him properly and he whispered “Good luck, Rio” and then went back to his mom.

“I’ll walk you out,” Rio said as Agatha kissed her mom’s cheek and took Nicky’s hand again.

Rio shot her mom a quick smile and pretended to ignore it as she heard her say to her dad: “¿Por qué no puede encontrar una mujer así?” Why can’t she find a woman like that?

“Jesus,” Rio muttered under her breath as Agatha laughed beside her, shooting her a grin as Rio walked them to the little hallway and to the door. That’s where they stopped, Nicky diligently placing his mom’s flower back in his pocket and Rio gently toying with her own in her hand.

“Mom was right. Your Spanish is better than mine.”

“Are you really that surprised?”

Rio rolled her eyes but smiled as she ran her free hand through her hair to stop herself from reaching out to Agatha. “I guess I’ll see you at the ceremony? And Nicky, I’ll see you on the basketball court soon, okay?”

Nicky nodded furiously, “I’d like that please.”

“Okay,” Rio laughed as she stepped to open the door. But a hand on her arm stopped her.

“Come and take pictures with me before you go? Jen can arrange with Alice.”

Rio nodded and looked around into bright blue eyes, “Okay.”

Agatha smiled and released Rio’s arm to let her open the door and she and Nicky stepped out into the hallway. They started down it and Nicky turned halfway up to look back at Rio and he smiled when he saw her still standing there. They waved at each other and then he and Agatha rounded the corner and were gone.

Rio closed the door and her eyes with it, resting her forehead against the cream wood as she took a second to just breathe now that Agatha and Nicky were gone and the only reminders she had of them were the soft scent of Agatha’s perfume in the air and the little paper flower in her hand.

“¿Mi corazón?” Her dad’s voice was soft and Rio turned to look at him and sucked in a breath at the sight of his questioning gaze. “¿Estás enamorada, cariño?” Are you in love, my darling?

Rio hesitated but knew there was no point in lying.

“Sí, papá.”

Miguel Vidal, a man who considered himself to be the luckiest man in the world because of his wife and daughter simply opened his arms out to Rio and gathered her in. He held her tightly as she held him and they remained quiet for a while before he said, in English, “Does she deserve your love?”

“Yes.”

“Then okay.”

Rio nodded against her dad as she pulled back and wiped quickly at her eyes for fear they were betraying her.

“Does mom-…?”

“I suspected at Christmas and asked her her opinion but… I’m not sure she’s caught on. She likes her though. Likes her a lot.”

Rio smiled a little and dropped her gaze to the scruff across her dad’s jaw that her mom was always trying to get him to shave. “You’re not ashamed of me?”

“I consider you the best thing in my life, mija, with your mother a close second. To be ashamed of you would be to be ashamed of myself. We can’t help who we fall in love with, cariño.”

Rio felt the promise of tears sting at her eyes but she managed to keep them at bay as her father cupped her cheeks and lifted her chin, “Go get ready, Rio. I’ll keep your mother occupied.”

Rio looked into the eyes of one of people who loved her most in the world. He had always been her constant champion, her partner in crime, a constant in a crazy world where everything was always changing but her father remained the same. She nodded, smiled, and stepped out of her dad’s embrace to head through to her glam squad again. Alice was waiting impatiently in her chair and shot her a tight smile as she went to replace her in the seat.

“Ready to rock and roll?”

She took a deep breath and nodded.

“Always.”

“I told your parents you were discussing a surprise for Nicky’s birthday.” Alice had leant in to whisper close to Rio’s ear.

Rio raised her brows but nodded slowly, catching on to Alice’s reasoning for her lie a little late.

“Don’t pull any shit like that again, okay? Not with the whole world watching, anyway.”

Alice kissed Rio’s shoulder as she settled in to be preened and prodded again and as her champagne flew to her hands, her feet and hair and face taken up by expert fingers, the atmosphere changed again. Everything and everyone became more relaxed.

And Rio zoned out with her little flower twirling in her fingers as she was transformed into a movie star.

An hour after Rio had said goodbye to Agatha, she was aware of her mom sneaking out the door. She returned twenty minutes later with news of the other camp along the corridor.

According to Anna Vidal: Nicky was reading on the bed, Ralph was taking a bath, and Agatha was having her hair done. And Anna had delivered them half of the snacks she’d brought for her daughter to enjoy so Rio was furious.

“¿Le negarías a ese niño su dulce regalo después de que te lo hubiera hecho?” You would deny that little boy his candy after he made you that sweet gift?

Rio grumbled but eventually agreed that, no, she would not deny Nicky some candy.

This agreement was mostly fuelled by the fact that she wasn’t able to eat any of her mom’s offering anyway, due to cakes and snacks being regularly physically taken out of her hand by her stylist even as her dad continually tried to sneak them to her. Then again, even if she had full control over her calorie intake that day, she was pretty sure she wouldn’t deny Nicky anything. Though perhaps she’d keep the pilones rojos to herself… protect his teeth, y’know?

What she was allowed was a restricted amount of champagne - two glasses only. So she sipped delicately, trying to make them last longer even as everyone around her indulged in whatever food or drinks they wanted.

It couldn’t dim her shine, though. Rio was practically vibrating with excitement. She’d made Alice place her little flower in the clutch she’d be taking that evening for fear she’d crush it in her hand as the closer and closer they got to the ceremony, Rio’s fingers became more and more active, dancing and twitching, finding everything and anything they could to fiddle with.

And she found she was talking even more than usual, occasionally switching to Spanish even when speaking to her English-speaking glam squad, and having to rapidly switch back in order to be understood. Her brain felt more alive than it had in months and she found it difficult to focus on anything at all.

The whole day felt surreal in the best way. Everyone was acting like Rio had already won, like she’d already accepted the award and gushed about each and every one of them in her speech. They were all lavishing her with compliments, kissing her hands when they got close.

The hours flew by and Rio had transformed from a regular woman in a white robe to an Oscar nominee in a white dress.

Versace had dressed her again, and as their new ambassador, she was more than happy with the choices they’d offered. She’d eventually settled on a off-white floor length gown, with dramatic sleeves that created an elegant, Grecian column effect. The sleeves formed pillowy arches over her shoulders. It meant her mom could no longer kiss her as often as she had been all day, much to her makeup artist’s relief. The bodice was fitted with a modest scoop neckline that balanced out the impact of her sleeves and there was a gathered belt of fabric just at the waist and above the smooth, straight skirt.

Her jewellery was minimal. She wore silver, instead of her usual gold. Statement round earrings hung from her ears and on her right hand she had a large diamond ring in the shape of a flower, the second piece of flora she would carry with her to the ceremony that night.

She had revealed herself to her parents with a flourish, a demure curtesy, and a beaming smile. Her mother cried. Her father clapped.

Rio tried not to cry with her mom when she hugged her gingerly for fear she’d crease her dress or smudge her make up on it. And she continued this tricky line of not hugging and not smudging as the music was turned up and someone - her suspicions were on Miguel - turned the room into their own personal dance floor.

Tears turned to laughter as her dad span her mom around and Rio clapped from the sidelines, everyone too cautious with her to let her join in the fray as the squad and Alice all jumped to try and outdo the Vidals.

But no one could.

Miguel and Anna had eyes only for each other and Rio had eyes only for them; her supportive, kind, wonderful parents.

“¡Mi vida, no!” Miguel protested as Anna danced away from him and was the first person to pull Rio up, careful to touch only her bare arms and not jostle the dress as she dragged her over. And Miguel’s protests changed in an instant because dancing with his wife was one thing but dancing with his daughter too? Heaven to his own heart beat.

Anna, who now was just about confident enough to wrap her arm around her daughter’s waist, had been outfitted by Versace too, a favour Alice had called in at the behest of Rio. Her dad had received the same treatment and looked handsome in his brand new suit as he confidently danced beside them with the arrogance of a man who had it all.

And Rio, she laughed as she danced, all her nervous energy evaporating as she allowed herself to be twirled by her father, hip-bumped by her mother, and swayed by the familiar rhythm of Dancing Queen.

Alice only called for calm when she began to fear they’d all gladly skip the Oscars for a chance to remain in this moment forever and as she shouted for order, for the first time in her career, Rio begged her to take photos for socials. She wanted to capture this moment. To freeze her mom and dad in this time, and share them with the world.

They posed together as any family might that consisted of an excited daughter and enthusiastically proud parents. And Alice was roped in too, a pseudo-adopted Vidal. Rio then posed with her squad, adding to the plethora of footage that Alice had already filmed when she was getting ready.

And miraculously, they managed to get her out the door without ruining either her makeup or her dress. Alice filmed Rio as she walked down the hallway to Agatha’s room and she whooped and hollered as Rio turned to wink and blow a kiss to the camera.

It was easy to be charming when you had someone to charm.

She didn’t have to seek out Agatha’s door because Jen was already standing just outside it, waiting for the arrival of Rio and her posse.

“Holy shit, Vidal.” Rio laughed at the classic Alice phrase that tumbled from Jennifer’s lips. “You could take someone’s eyes out with those.”

Rio rolled her eyes as she placed a delicate kiss to Jen’s cheek, careful as she did not to press too hard for fear she’d ruin her lipstick. “You look beautiful too, Jen.”

“I thought that went without saying,” Jen grinned back, her hand now on Rio’s side as she motioned inside with her head. “It’s been a rough afternoon but she’s excited to see you.”

“Why?” Rio asked urgently but felt her family arrive behind her and Jen shook her head once before she plastered on a very false smile for the Vidals.

“Hi!”

Rio stepped into the hallway and the first thing she spotted was the face of a little boy peaking out from around the corner. Her worries disappeared as she grinned at him and he slowly moved into view properly, his Spiderman pyjamas now replaced by a green sweater and dark pants, though he had dinosaur socks on which Rio thought really tied the whole outfit together.

“Well don’t you look handsome.”

“Thank you,” Nicky grinned as Rio walked over to him and she bent down to offer one of her sleeves to him, “You like my sleeves, kid?”

Nicky reached to touch one but Rio pulled back suddenly, “Ah! You got clean hands? Let me check.”

He held them out and she inspected them for a second before nodding seriously and offered her shoulder back to him, “Then go ahead.”

He touched the sleeve cautiously and squeezed it like a bouncy ball before he laughed, “They look silly.”

“¡Ay, qué tonta! ¡Son preciosas!” Silly! They are beautiful! Anna Vidal had arrived to defend her child, stepping around Rio to pinch Nicky’s cheek affectionately.

“Sí,” he uttered with a giggle as he batted her away, “Como Rio.”

Rio rolled her eyes but straightened up with a grin and turned her attention to the room beyond, “Where’s your mom?”

“She’s with daddy.”

“Right,” Rio said softly, and moved into the living area where Agatha’s glam squad were quietly gossiping and packing up. She eyed them for a second, noting the way they kept their voices so low that even now being in the same room as them she couldn’t hear.

But Oscar nominees never go unnoticed for long.

Rio was spotted and soon she was launched upon, praised, and she found herself laughing in the middle of the room at a not very funny joke from a makeup assistant who looked so timid and so mortified that she’d even made the joke in the first place that Rio laughed until everyone else joined in.

Rio then managed to retain their names in her brain for long enough to introduce them to her parents and after hands had been shaken and Rio was beginning to get anxious to see Agatha, Jennifer stepped in to dismiss everyone and instruct them to make moves to clear out and give them some space.

Rio remembered what her own makeup artist had told her once about Agatha and her camp being a little more tense than her own and this only confirmed the gossip as Jen huffed as she rushed them all off.

She said her goodbyes and as the room cleared she spotted an unfamiliar face in the room too and Rio smiled at the woman who looked neat in a little cardigan and plaid pants. She had dark hair and a kindly, round face with equally round eyes.

“Hi,” Rio said with a smile, “I’m Rio. I’m not sure we’ve met?”

“Lucy, hello. I’m Nicky’s nanny.”

Rio shook the woman’s hand. “Pleasure to meet you. I’m afraid I think my mom has given him a lot of sugar so…”

“Oh, I expect the crash will be big soon so don’t worry about it.”

Rio smiled but a door opening to her right made her turn and she saw Agatha standing there, and Rio Vidal suddenly couldn’t breathe.

“Holy fucking shit.”

Agatha was dressed in a black velvet gown with a sweep of the same fabric draped across her right shoulder that flowed dramatically out behind her. Along the edges of the draped fabric was a crystal fringe and the silhouette of the gown was tight to Agatha’s curves. Against her pale skin it looked rich, luxurious, old Hollywood.

Agatha’s hair was up in a twisted, loose knot. And her hair had been allowed to remain textured, alive. Not for the first time, Rio wanted to kiss her stylist.

Because this was her Agatha, only draped in velvet.

“Jesus,” Rio mumbled just as Agatha rushed towards her and her eyes had barely seconds to try and take it all in. But Agatha was close now and had wrapped her arms securely around her waist. She angled her body away from Rio, pressing their hips together so she could look her over and Rio almost whimpered for seeing Agatha looking like this up close.

She moved her hands, one to Agatha’s bare left arm, the other to hide indulgently beneath the draped fabric on her left. Her hold tightened significantly around Agatha and she felt Agatha respond in kind, her hands shifting and her fingers splaying across her back.

“Unorthodox to take pictures with the competition, no?”

Ralph’s voice was even more jarring than Rio remembered and she grimaced as her slipped past, not without touching her arm. Rio schooled her face as she turned her gaze to Agatha once more and for a brief second Agatha let her in.

This woman in her arms, holding her so carefully and so close, was flung out of time. Her blue eyes were bright and searching and Rio couldn’t look away from them. She showed her her sadness and Rio felt it in the squeeze of the hands still against her ribs, and read it in the blue eyes that had dropped to her lips.

“Ralph,” Jen snapped from somewhere behind Rio as Agatha fixed her face and pulled away.

“Come say hi to the Vidals. You missed them earlier, being in the bath and all.”

Rio glanced at Ralph, grimaced as she saw him checking her out, and just as she was about to turn to see him greet her parents Agatha tugged her hand, pulled her closer, and whispered against her ear, “You look so beautiful.”

“What’s happened?” Rio asked, turning her head slowly into Agatha, now just inches away from her. She ignored Agatha as she curiously touched her puffy sleeve.

“Nothing you need to worry about.”

“Agatha.”

“Baby.”

Rio rolled her eyes but smiled when Agatha moved her hand to hold her chin gently, “I haven’t heard a compliment yet.”

“I’m pretty sure ‘holy fucking shit’ is a good enough response to seeing you.”

Agatha just hummed, a smile tugging at her lips as she dropped her hand and just as Rio moved to place her hand on Agatha’s waist in an attempt to get closer again her mom arrived at their sides. Rio watched as Agatha turned her charm up a few notches and she took the opportunity to check her out properly now her attention was on her mother.

“Rio dice que estaré a tu lado.” Rio says I’ll be next to you.

“Sí, entre nosotros.” In between us.

“No parece que eso sea algo que a Rio le gustaría.” Doesn’t look like that’s something Rio will enjoy.

Agatha squeezed her side and answered before Rio could: “Me alegra que vayamos a estar juntos. Así podrás contarme más sobre Rio cuando era niña.” Well I’m pleased we’ll be together. It means you can tell me more about Rio as a kid.
