“Dooon’t,” Rio whined and batted at her mom’s hand, “Jasmine will kill you if you ruin my makeup.”

“Here,” Agatha said quietly, turning into Rio to brush over her cheek and fix nothing in particular as Anna laughed to herself and went to sit with Miguel.

The oxygen was sucked from the room as Rio looked up to meet Agatha’s gaze, and she had time enough to count four freckles across a perfect nose before Agatha pulled away.

“Rio.”

Alice’s voice shocked her back to reality and she released Agatha to turn to her manager, raising her brows at her expectantly, “Come on. We need to do this and then leave.”

Rio sighed and shot Agatha a quick smile, “Let’s go.”

Ralph had disappeared again and for that Rio was grateful. She hoped he’d decided to take a bath again and would drown in it.

From the corner of her eye she saw Nicky beside her dad and turned properly to see them, both sitting on the couch, Nicky with his legs swinging off the chair, both looking at the women with a mixture of awe and mild confusion.

“Hey, Nicky. Will you check I have everything in my purse?” Rio motioned to Alice to hand over her clutch and then pulled Agatha towards the window where they could get the best light and found that Agatha wasted no time in wrapping an arm around Rio as they turned to face Jen with her camera ready.

“I think this is lipstick,” Nicky was saying as he frowned into the clutch, his swinging legs now stationary so he could concentrate. “And this is… maybe lipstick too.”

“Mascara,” Jen corrected with an arched brow.

“A mirror,” Nicky continued and then looked up with a grin that Rio shot right back at him, “and your flower.”

“Good,” Rio said with finality, “means I have everything. Thank you.”

Agatha’s arm around her flexed and Rio didn’t dare look at her but instead moved to stand with her arm around her too.

“The sleeves, Rio, it doesn’t work. Your shoulder looks weird,” Alice called out, “Move beside each other.”

Agatha rolled her eyes as she stepped away and dropped her hold and Rio adjusted by brushing down her dress and making sure her sleeves hadn’t already lost their shape.

“Agatha, why don’t you sit and Rio can stand behind you.”

Rio laughed as Agatha huffed, “It’s not a photoshoot, Jen. This is just a couple snaps for us… our socials.”

Rio grinned at Agatha’s slip up and muttered, “Casual, Harkness.”

“Don’t call me that.”

“Well Jesus, Agatha,” Jen started but Anna had moved in between them, holding her hands up.

“¡Basta!” Rio bit down on her lip as she saw Jen’s eyes widen in shock. “Rio, conviértete en Agatha y gira la cabeza hacia la cámara. Sí, así. Más cerca, más cerca. ¡Sí! ¡Perfecto! Ahora, Jennifer, take the photo.” Enough! Rio, turn into Agatha and turn your head to the camera. Yes, like that. Closer, closer. Yes! Perfect!

Rio’s arm was around Agatha and Agatha’s was around Rio, their opposite hips pressed together, Rio’s heart thrumming in her chest. She reached the arm closest to the camera to wrap around Agatha’s waist too and Agatha responded in kind by holding her elbow.

If she just reached down with her left hand she could get away with… she dropped her wrist, let her fingers graze the fabric over Agatha’s ass, brushing over it slowly until she returned her hand to Agatha’s hip. She heard her gasp quietly, twisting in Rio’s arms to press against her fully under the pretence of pulling Rio into a hug.

“Inappropriate,” she chastised as Rio’s hold relaxed around her and she laughed as Agatha’s breath tickled her ear.

“Jesus, you two.”

Rio heard Nicky giggle from across the room as Agatha jabbed her side to make her really laugh and she pulled away, not meeting Agatha’s gaze as she extracted herself from her - to avoid more temptation if nothing else.

“Pose like normal humans or I will not-…”

Agatha rolled her eyes beside her and adjusted them confidently so they could pose again.

The new, more casual hold lasted all of ten seconds as they allowed their photo to be taken but Rio could have held it for weeks.

When they finally broke away they locked eyes with each other and exchanged grins and Agatha blushed ever so slightly as she muttered, “New phone screen for you?”

“Oh you wish.”

Agatha laughed as Rio pulled away entirely but she felt the fingers that grazed her hip as she went over to Jen to check the pictures. She raised her gaze subtly to check Agatha hadn’t followed and bit her lip before she muttered for Jen’s ears only, “They fought.”

“Yes,” Jen whispered back, zooming in to make sure her client looked as perfect as could be in the snaps.

“Is he sus-…?”

“No. Just an ass.”

Rio nodded, Jen’s answer not making her feel any better about the situation because Ralph being an ass was only marginally better than Ralph being suspicious. Mostly because Agatha was married to him either way.

She looked over and saw Agatha leaning over Nicky on the couch and had to do her very best not to stare at the way the fabric of her dress clung to her ass as she did. But she didn’t have long to fight against it because Agatha was straightening and motioning to Jen for her phone.

“Rio, come back here. We need a picture of the Boston crew.”

“Boston crew?” Jen asked suspiciously as she handed Rio her phone.

“Celtics crew, more like,” Rio corrected with a smile as she went to hover by Agatha as she sat down on the armchair and pulled Nicky into her lap. Rio assessed for a second and then went to lean over them both from behind the armchair so she could stretch her arm out and frame them in the phone.

“These fucking sleeves,” she muttered as she adjusted herself to not crush them against the chair or Agatha’s head and Agatha only laughed as she watched the little show in the screen in front of her. Nicky giggled too.

Once satisfied and done with her huffing, Rio looked up at the screen and though she couldn’t be sure, she thought she could see Agatha meeting her gaze through the camera. It made her heart stop, made her whole body feel warm, and as she hit the peak of her spiral, she snapped the photo.

Rio straightened to check it and lost her breath at the sight. There was Agatha, glowing and grinning at the camera, sandwiched - and clearly happily so - between Rio and Nicky. A rose between two identical, beaming faces.

“Show me, Rio.” Agatha asked with her hand held out to take the phone and Rio handed it to her, watching as Agatha and her son looked at the image.

Rio looked up as she heard her mom whispering something to her dad and caught Jen’s gaze briefly and saw something she’d never seen before in her dark eyes; Jen looked terrified.

Rio missed Agatha holding the phone back up and asking for another as she strode over to Jennifer and without meaning to she snapped her out of her daze. “Can we talk?”

“No.”

“Jen.”

“Not now, Rio.”

“Honey, one sec,” Agatha said behind them, ushering Nicky off her lap so she could make it to Jennifer and Rio as they faced off together in the centre of the room.

“What’s going on?”

“Nothing,” Jen and Rio said at the same time - one with more conviction than the other.

“Rio,” Agatha tried, reaching for Rio’s hand just as a door opened and Ralph appeared again, his bow tie hanging loose about his neck.

“Hon, could you tie this for me?”

Agatha shot Jen and Rio one last look and pressed Jen’s phone back to her before she moved around them and went to help Ralph.

Rio watched her go and turned to Jen who was already busying herself with her phone. She risked looking up at Rio only for a second and then the moment was gone and Rio knew she wouldn’t get the answers she needed that night.

But one answer was already in the room with her. Ralph was lifting his chin as Agatha swiftly fixed his bow tie and Rio knew with the right angle and the right amount of force she could quite easily snap his jaw.

“Mija,” Miguel said.

Thoughts of broken jaws and grateful Agathas dissolved in her mind as she turned to her dad.

“Are you ready?”

“Yes,” Rio grinned again, remembering who and where she was. “Let’s go.”

“Finally,” Alice breathed, moving to kiss Jen goodbye before she held out her hand to Rio to pull her into the hall.

Rio didn’t get a chance to say goodbye to Agatha but she waved at Nicky and shot Agatha a small smile as she disappeared out the suite and down the hall with Alice and her parents in tow.

The image of Agatha fixing Ralph’s tie burned itself into her retinas, carving it insidious promise that Agatha wouldn’t leave this man into her fragile hopes. But then her dad’s hands found her arms and he gave her a squeeze as he walked proudly alongside her and Rio saw herself in his eyes for a second and she became proud, tall, and unashamed.

The little group gathered back outside Rio’s suite to pickup her makeup artist who would be hanging around in the wings all evening for quick touch ups during ad breaks.

And then they made their way, a spectrum of nervous and excited, to the Dolby Theatre where the 97th Academy Awards were being held.

The journey to the theatre took longer than expected due to the heavy amount of traffic as the constellations of stars descended upon Tinseltown for the biggest night of the year.

But Rio and Miguel kept everyone entertained, Miguel by telling old stories that everyone had heard a million times before of Rio dressing up and putting on skits when she was younger, and Rio by constantly interjecting and correcting small details that her dad was now purposefully getting wrong just so his daughter could correct him and be distracted from the nerves he knew would be bubbling away in her stomach.

Eventually, they arrived on the entrance to the carpet. And nothing her dad could do now would help with the nerves that threatened to show themselves in Rio’s throat any time soon.

The excitement she’d been dealing with all day was now eradicated as the door was opened and the roar of the crowds hit her properly for the first time. Rio knew this would be different. She knew it would be more intense than anything she’d ever experienced, but there was knowing and experiencing. Two very different things.

She was ushered away from her dad by a lady with a black earpiece and a clipboard and she just about managed to squeeze his hand one last time before she was pushed forwards. She had to enter the fray first, her parents and Alice now second class citizens as far as The Academy and the fans were concerned.

She held her head high, kept her sights forwards. She saw the red carpet, the photographers, the people with clipboards, men in tuxedoes, women in red-soled shoes. She felt the fabric of her dress, the heavy ring on her right hand, the pinch of her new shoes, the change from hard sidewalk to plush carpet beneath her feet. She heard the screams of her name, she heard the frantic instructions shouted into headsets, the noise of car doors opening and closing. She smelt the perfume of a woman brushing past her, the soft scent of jasmine that was typical of L.A. She tasted the mint gum she’d recently removed from her mouth.

But her anxiety was still through the roof.

A hand found her lower back and she didn’t need to turn to know who it was. Her mom was now with her, flagrantly ignoring the previous instruction from the attendant to stay behind Rio. Her mom knew she needed her to.

Rio took a breath, finding more solace in that delicate reminder of her mom’s presence than the 5-4-3-2-1 method she’d just been trying to work through.

She felt braver as she stepped from her mom’s comforting hold and into the centre of the carpet.

But she’d never heard her name being bellowed so loudly before.

Cacophonous and overwhelming, she grinned through the noise, posing as best she knew how in every direction the shouts came from. But it didn’t take long until her chest began to feel tight with anxiety.

Alice stepped in when she noticed the twitch of Rio’s fingers and Rio tried to fight the threat of her widening eyes as she was pulled to the edges of the carpet and into the safety of the crowds.

“Holy shit,” she gasped out, finding her mom’s hand quickly as she tried to focus on her breathing.

“It’s okay,” her mom whispered soothingly, brushing a gentle knuckle down her daughter’s cheek, “you’re doing so well, mija.”

Rio nodded and breathed out to the count of four as Alice guarded her from the front and began to move her up the carpet. Rio’s heart rate began to slow again but she felt tense still, jittery, even, and she wished she’d been able to finish her last glass of champagne before she’d arrived.

“Rio, we’ve got the first few press go rounds now, feeling up to them?”

“Yeah, yeah, sure. Yeah.”

Alice eyed her suspiciously but Rio nodded again and pulled her mom in closer, “I’m fine, really. Just nervous.”

“Okay,” Alice said quietly, shooting Anna a quick smile before leading them both to the first interviews.

Rio’s reception was like that of a conquering hero and she beamed as she introduced her mom and dad to the interviewers and fell back into her professional mode of being able to answer questions easily, charmingly, fluidly.

Having her parents by her side helped too.

Most questions were soft-balled because Anna and Miguel were there and Rio time and time again got to stand and smile shyly as Miguel Vidal told everyone who would listen just how proud he was of his daughter.

But the first round of interviews soon ended and Rio was directed to the centre of the carpet again. The little interlude of interviews with her parents had filled her up again so it took time before she was circling the drains of fear once more. She sucked in a breath and held it as she posed, as she smiled, as she endured the barrage.

And then, out of the corner of her eye, Agatha was standing waiting for her turn.

Rio dared to look properly, exhaling the breath she’d been holding for too long, and she saw Agatha smile at her. Agatha’s whole face lit up when she caught Rio’s gaze and she did something that made the world seem okay again: she winked. And Rio laughed at the sheer relief that she felt so viscerally when Agatha was close, when she was shining her light on her.

And the shouts changed. They were asking for Agatha now. Agatha and Rio. AgathaRio. AgathaRio! AGATHARIO!

Rio held out her hand to the woman who looked calm and steady and found she didn’t have to wait long for Agatha to make her move to her.

They’d unknowingly already practiced how to stand together without Rio’s dress getting in the way. So they replicated the position they’d been in in Agatha’s suite, where they’d taken pictures just for themselves, and now allowed the world to see them as they posed together, arms so comfortable around the other that they didn’t even have to look as they slotted into one another.

“Alice said you’re anxious?”

Agatha spoke from the side of her mouth, muttering to Rio without moving her lips as best she could.

“Well I’m better now.”

Agatha laughed and used it for the photographers to capture even as she turned her gaze to Rio, “Because of me?”

Rio narrowed her eyes at Agatha and felt her fingers flex against her arm, “Pushing it.”

“Get a drink with me before you go in.”

But Rio could barely hear Agatha anymore because she’d looked up when she saw someone coming towards them and that someone just so happened to be Agatha’s husband.

Rio broke her hold of Agatha and smiled widely as Ralph approached. She raised up and kissed his cheek, and managed not to squirm when his large hand hit the small of her back, a little too low for her comfort but not low enough to cause a scene. She felt sick as she passed Agatha on to him but she was a professional, and these thousands of cameras wouldn’t lie if they caught her looking at all annoyed or reluctant.

“I’ll leave you with your wife,” she said with that same wide smile that felt like a betrayal to her very being.

But she had no choice.

Agatha squeezed her side and Rio turned to smile that same false smile at her before she stepped along the carpet and gave Hollywood’s most beautiful couple their space.

The second Rio was out of Agatha’s hold her chest felt tight again but it was different this time. It wasn’t that she was overwhelmed it was that she was jealous.

The cameras flashed as she continued to pose, moving every few seconds to make her way along the carpet. In a brief moment of relief between the persistent lights she looked up and caught sight of Jennifer not watching Agatha but watching her instead.

She looked pensive, almost calm, but the flashing lights meant that Jen was a flickering mirage and the only reality anymore was that Rio was alone on the carpet and ten feet to her left Agatha was tangled up with her husband.

Rio smiled and posed her way through the rest of the red carpet and soon found her mother’s warm hand back in her own as she left it. Alice was leading them both inside the Dolby Theatre and Rio had to choke down a few breaths just to feel human again. Her dad rubbed her back to soothe her.

Inside the lobby there were more attendants, more workers desperate to usher the stars and their parties to the right places. There were a few photographers around, and Rio was more aware than usual that her every move was being captured on film.

She kept her smile up until they found their way to the bar and once up against it Rio released her breath again, closing her eyes to focus her nerves back into the excitement she’d felt earlier.

“White is a bold choice, Rio Vidal. No red wine for you tonight.”

Rio turned to the familiar voice and grinned at the sight of Wanda Maximoff gliding over to her with a bright smile. She was in a structured black dress, her red hair swept back into an unfussy updo. She looked at ease, and Rio wondered if when people looked at her they could say the same.

She hummed as she accepted the delicate press of Wanda’s warm cheek against her own.

“Well don’t you look beautiful.”

“Likewise.”

And Rio meant it when she said it, because Wanda looked incredible in her dress and Rio took a second to appreciate it, and looked up to catch Wanda’s gaze with a now genuinely relaxed smile.

Wanda twinkled at her as Rio introduced her to her parents and she had to look away when she caught her mom giving her a look that she knew to mean: “what about her, mija?”.

She rolled her eyes and turned back to the bar to start passing around the champagne.

“So,” Wanda said conspiratorially, her eyes back on Rio now Anna and Miguel had cornered Alice to ask her more questions about the seating arrangements, “Got your speech?”

Rio barked a laugh and raised her brows as she gave her own champagne to Wanda and ordered another with a raised hand and a smile at the bartender. “Absolutely not. Alice thinks I’m crazy not to but I pay her to believe in me. You’re just being ridiculous. We both know it’s Agatha’s.”

“I believe in the power of Rio Vidal.”

Rio hummed as she accepted her freshly poured champagne and as she turned to cheers Wanda she saw Agatha enter the bar area and make a beeline for the little group, Jen by her side and Ralph trailing behind.

Wanda moved a little closer and Rio dropped her gaze from Agatha to glance at the redhead, seeing her tense as she also clocked Agatha Harkness striding over. Rio sighed quietly and bit down on her lip as Agatha stopped just beside Wanda and only just managed to shoot her a tight smile. “Maximoff.”

Maximoff, Rio thought to herself. Agatha had regressed in her acceptance of Wanda.

“Agatha! You look-…”

“You okay?”

Rio blinked and felt mortified before she just felt… comforted. She nodded, a smile tugging at her lips as she focused on Agatha even as Ralph appeared beside her, his hand curling around her hip possessively.

“I’m fine.”

“What happened?”

Rio glanced at Wanda and smiled a little, “Nothing. Just… the red carpet was intense.”

Wanda’s hand reached for her arm and Rio couldn’t help but turn her gaze to Agatha to see how she felt about it. She didn’t look pleased.

Agatha moved forwards, breaking Ralph’s hold, and slipped in beside Rio to get to the bar. And Rio felt her hand find her own and she had to pretend nothing was happening as she heard Agatha order and their fingers locked together, knuckle to knuckle.

Agatha’s cape would be a godsend that night. It hid her arm from view, Rio’s now tucked just beneath it too.

“You’d think you’d be used to it by now,” Ralph was saying opposite. “Though I guess it’s all new to you. I’ve been to, what is it, Agatha? Five of these. Piece of cake, really. Smile, nod, shake hands with the right people, ignore everyone else. Walk in the park.”

Rio turned to Wanda who was looking like she could smell something unpleasant as she looked up at Ralph. It almost made her laugh out loud.

Agatha’s fingers twitched and then her hand was dropped as Agatha turned with two new glasses of champagne in her hands. She handed one to Jen and kept the other to herself as she now leant back against the bar and Rio felt her knuckles graze her hip. Though it was Agatha’s left hand against her now - there was no protection.

Rio cleared her throat and in an attempt to change the subject she addressed Wanda: “When did you arrive?”

“Maybe ten minutes before you. Enough time to drink a shot of-…”

“Aggie, darling. Forget someone?”

Rio and Wanda both turned to Ralph and raised their brows and Agatha opened her mouth to say something but Anna Vidal jumped in. “Ralph, perhaps if you want a drink you can always ask.”

Rio watched as Ralph slapped his trademark grin on his face and placed his arm around her mother. She saw her dad raise his brows at her over her mom’s shoulder and felt Agatha press into her side.

“I’m a traditionalist, Annie. What can I say.”

“Anna,” Rio corrected flatly. “And being a traditionalist doesn’t mean-…” She felt Agatha grasp her fingers. She paused briefly and swallowed her words. “I’ll get you a drink.”

“No,” Agatha said firmly, her eyes trained on Ralph, “Ralph, best pick whatever scotch you want. We don’t have long before we have to go in.”

Anna Vidal smiled knowingly and Rio tugged at Agatha’s hand and made her turn to her. But Wanda spoke first and motioned to Agatha, stealing her attention from where it had been on Rio. “Agatha, who did your styling? It’s insanely good.”

Rio could have kissed Wanda for trying her best to diffuse the situation but she could only watch as Agatha turned perpendicular to the bar, and something happened that she wasn’t expecting. Agatha had released her hand and had instead moved as she’d turned to grab Rio’s ass.

The angle Agatha was now at, with her cape draped over her right arm so as to hide where her left had disappeared to, and where Rio’s back was against the bar, it would be impossible to spot.

Rio’s mouth fell open and she narrowly avoided dribbling the champagne she’d just gone to sip. But Agatha seemed unperturbed and Ralph was squeezing into the bar behind her, oblivious to his wife’s hold on Rio.

“Looking to steal him?”

Wanda missed the double meaning.

Rio’s mouth opened again and she saw a flash of panic in Wanda’s eyes. “C’mon, Agatha,” she managed to get out, “does it look like Wanda needs a new stylist?”

She motioned to Wanda’s dress and smiled at her, but her mind was on the hand still on her ass, wondering if it were a reaction to Ralph claiming he were in a ‘traditional’ marriage or if it was more about Wanda.

“Oh,” Wanda laughed, obviously deciding to brush off Agatha’s comment, “You’re just saying that because we’re about to be married and spend four months together.”

Agatha cleared her throat and hid it badly by taking a sip of her champagne.

Rio turned to her and smiled serenely, deciding she was in safe waters with Agatha’s secret but possessive hold on her, “Christmas wives.”

Agatha hummed and didn’t quite meet Rio’s gaze as she squeezed her ass and then pulled her hand away entirely.

Shit.

“Sweet,” Agatha said absently, turning over her shoulder to see if there was an exit strategy available to her which made Rio huff quietly. But she couldn’t reach back out for Agatha to return her hand to her so she remained silent and took another sip of champagne.

In the rest of the little group her mom was trying her best to speak to Ralph but looked pained as she was doing so. Her dad was watching him with interest and Alice was grinning at something Jen was saying.

Rio glanced at Wanda and then her mom, unsure who she should rescue first from both of their awkward situations. But she was closer to Wanda and couldn’t abandon her now.

“I still need to learn my lines,” Rio said casually, trying to salvage what she’d just pushed a little too far.

“Don’t go slacking on me, Vidal. Can’t show me up in front of Calderu.”

Rio laughed and rolled her eyes, “Her Majesty will be pleased with me, I promise.”

“Everybody’s pleased with you.”

Rio grinned and Agatha pushed off the bar suddenly, leaving her hand on it so when she leant around she was still in contact with Rio. “Should I leave the two of you alone?”

Wanda’s eyes widened and then she settled and smiled, and Rio thought she was doing a pretty good job of not looking intimidated by the three time nominee and one time winner. So Rio saved her. She moved and placed a hand on Agatha’s hip, “Actually, I should save my mom.”

Agatha didn’t protest when Rio applied pressure and pushed her back. As Rio brushed past she made eye contact with Agatha and saw her jaw was set, her chin raised, her eyes unreadable.

But she couldn’t say or do anything to help the situation. So she stepped around her, trusting that Wanda could hold her own for a little while as she got her mom’s attention. And hoping that without herself standing their as bait between the two, Agatha might go a little easier.

“Mom, we should finish these and go, okay?”

Anna nodded once, her lips pursed and she said: “Me alegro mucho de no estar al lado de este hombre.” I’m so glad I’m not next to this man.

Rio fought her smile as Ralph raised his brows and looked confused. “Okay so who will be acting as translator tonight? Hon?”

Rio turned her head and Agatha had moved in closer. Wanda had been caught by Jessica just arriving and for that, Rio was grateful.

“Lo siento por mi marido, Anna, Miguel. Se cree muy gracioso. Miguel, ¿me acompañas a mi asiento?” I'm sorry for my husband, Anna, Miguel. He thinks he's funny. Miguel, will you walk me to my seat?

Agatha’s voice when she spoke in Spanish was softer somehow, a lower register. And Rio watched her in surprise as she smiled at her dad and moved towards him. Miguel looked taken aback but thrilled to be asked so politely to be escorted by the most famous woman in the building.

As they linked arms Agatha turned over her shoulder to look at her and for a brief second Rio saw her softening before her eyes. She smiled and Rio smiled back as her dad and her heart moved off together, directed by Alice to a door that would take them to the main theatre.

“Allow me, senoras?”

Rio looked around at Ralph and almost laughed at his American sneer on “senoras” but his hand was now on her lower back again and this time she twisted and lightly pushed it away. “If you wouldn’t mind taking my mom? I’ll be right out.”

Ralph inclined his head, too arrogant or too stupid to be offended by Rio pushing him away. Anna only smiled politely as he offered his arm to her and Rio watched as they left to follow Agatha and Miguel.

An arm around her waist pulled her attention back even as Alice turned to her with a warning: “Two minutes. Then come through, okay?”

“Yeah, yeah,” Rio grinned as she leant back against Jessica who was turning her into the little group that had gathered.

She spent five minutes mingling, congratulating everyone on looking so beautiful, exchanging delicate cheek kisses so as not to disturb anyone’s makeup, and gossiping about who might win what.

But she knew Alice would be stressing. And she knew Agatha would be wondering if she were with Wanda. So she excused herself before she wanted to and walked alone into the theatre.

Inside the belly of the beast the air felt different, exalted, almost. Beneath the high, curved ceilings, down to the grand stage at the front of the space, rows upon rows of red velvet seats waited for their famous occupiers to arrive. Rio looked up at the balconies that lined the space and saw she was being watched already by their inhabitants.

She felt small here, a tiny pencil mark to be preserved in the annals of Hollywood history.

An attendant found her as she began her way down to the front row and he offered his arm to help. She gladly accepted and as they made their way he gushed over her and she felt shy about the attention but glad of the distraction as the filling theatre crowds turned their heads to see one of the Best Actress nominees make her way to her seat.

The attendant - a wannabe actor named Josh - squeezed Rio’s hand as he arrived with her at the front row and Rio turned to him, kissed his cheek, watched as he blushed an intense red to rival the seats themselves, and smiled as he hurried off to hide his face and tell his coworkers he’d just been kissed by Rio Vidal.

But Rio now had eyes for her dad who was standing with Agatha, laughing with her. It made her heart swell two sizes too large at the sight.

“Mija,” Rio turned, her mom smiled where she sat beside Alice. “How are you feeling?”

“Es como si no pudiera respirar, mamá.” A little like I can’t breathe, mom.

She didn’t want Ralph, standing nearby, his foot on one of the seats, leaning against his knee to chat to an unamused Jen, to understand what she was saying.

A hand on her lower back, more welcome and more familiar than Ralph’s had been, told her body to breathe normally again, and Agatha’s voice relaxed her heart. “Estás bien. Eres increíble. Eres Rio Vidal.” You are good. You are incredible. You are Rio Vidal.

Rio turned her head to Agatha, saw her smiling, her brows raised, almost teasing, but definitely reassuring.

“Mi corazón, tú y Agatha son las personas más bellas, talentosas y merecedoras de este edificio. Deslumbrarán como siempre.” My heart, you and Agatha here, are the most beautiful, most talented, most deserving people in this building. You will dazzle as you always do.

And Agatha moved away to hover near Anna as her dad moved in to pull Rio into a tight embrace. “Te quiero. Respira hondo y toma la mano de tu mamá.” I love you. Take deep breaths and hold your mom’s hand.

Rio smiled sadly, suddenly overwhelmed with regret that she hadn’t managed to get a seat for her dad in their row. But she kissed his cheek firmly, squeezing his arm as she did. “I love you.”

He smiled at her one last time, a great, big, proud smile, and then turned to kiss his wife, and disappeared off to find an attendant to take him to his seat.

The lights flashed and Rio turned from watching her dad disappear to see the rest of their odd little grouping begin to move to their correct positions. In the rush Agatha moved again to squeeze her side and Rio whispered to her: “Thank you for including him.”

“I like him,” Agatha said as she paused before her, her eyes darting about to check they weren’t being overheard before she focused in on Rio, “I like your family.”

Rio nodded and knew Agatha wasn’t lying. She smiled a little and watched as Agatha’s soft expression fell into something more mournful and she murmured, “I’ll find you when this is all over.”

“You’d better.”

Rio flashed a grin at her as she saw a photographer appear nearby and Agatha must have noticed him too because she pulled her hand away and turned to sit down. The last touch of Agatha Harkness was stolen from her because they were still a secret, still a thing to be hidden.

And Rio’s nerves morphed into nausea once more as she took her seat beside her mother.

She could barely register Wanda’s brother taking his seat beside her, was barely able to acknowledge his introduction and Wanda’s warm smiles. Because Agatha was the other side of her mom, but too far still, always too far.

The loud room was silenced just as Rio finally began to ease her racing heart. Her mom held her hand and that movement seemed to signal to the universe that Rio Vidal was ready to begin.

The lights dimmed and an eerie hush swept through the theatre. The cameras circled and the lights on stage twinkled their magic as the great curtains swept up and with a collective intake of breath and the swell of the orchestra, the show began.

Rio’s eyes were alert and wide as she watched it all unfold with a slick precision that was hard to miss in the live broadcast and easy to see from the front row.

The faint movements of the technical team behind the stage caught her eye every so often and she knew she shared with them the same nervous energy that made her grip her mom’s hand tighter with every passing second.

Every category was a reason to release some of that energy. She clapped and cheered with the room as she witnessed dreams come true and speeches that had only ever been delivered before to shampoo bottles and steamed up bathroom mirrors.

And then it was time for her category and she felt a shift in the theatre. The cameras were circling around and Rio felt herself tense as she locked her smile on her face.

Her mom moved beside her and Rio was glad of the excuse to look because she couldn’t stand the pomp and ceremony when it was focused on her. Her hand was being moved into the middle of her mom’s lap and Anna was reaching too for Agatha’s.

As Agatha turned to see she locked eyes with Rio and they exchanged grins as they both realised what Anna Vidal was doing.

She’d captured them both in her two hands and brought them together in her lap, allowing her hold to release and for Agatha to reach for Rio, and for Rio to do the same. Rio held Agatha’s hand like her life depended on never letting go and she turned to the stage as she felt her mom cradle their hands together, giving them at least some semblance of privacy as they were broadcast to the world.

Rio’s name was read out, a small speech given about her performance, about her confidence and ease on screen, a round of applause for her nomination. Agatha’s was read next. She was lauded for her captivating screen presence, for her dedication to her craft, for her generational talent. The room erupted for her too.

And then, when everyone nominated had heard their names and received with them the praises due a group of Best Actress nominees, all eyes fell to the golden envelope in the presenter’s hands.

The sound of it being opened was somehow magnified ten times over in the silence of the room.

Agatha’s fingers tightened impossibly around Rio’s. Her mom squeezed them both.

“And the Oscar for Best Actress goes to…!”

Rio bit her lip.

Chapter End Notes

Agatha was originally wearing a different dress but there was NO WAY I couldn’t put her in KH’s latest

Also it provided a handy dandy cover for certain things in this chapter

Again: mucho apologies for google translate Spanish

Chapter 26: The Best Actress

Chapter Summary

The Best Actress is chosen.

Rio indulges a fantasy and is groped by reality.

Chapter Notes

So sorry about the cliffhanger but obviously I was always going to do that!!

I’ve somehow (again) written so much for this chapter and also not enough… forgive me

See the end of the chapter for more notes

2021 | Alice & Rio’s Apartment

“Rio!”

“God, fuck! In a minute! I burnt the fucking-…”

“Jesus, Rio, you’ll miss it!”

Rio growled and threw the bag of piping hot popcorn onto the counter. The kernels burst from it like a buttery fireworks display and Rio growled again but turned her back on the mess to rush through to the living room where her friends were gathered on the tiny, uncomfortable couch and the floor in front of it.

“It’s insane to me that she’s a real person. Like, living, breathing, you know?”

Rio huffed again as she squeezed in between Alice and Wanda and moved one of the flat cushions to cradle in her lap.

“Popcorn’s burnt.”

“You tried your best,” Wanda reassured as Alice laughed, “We have beer. Don’t worry about it.”

Rio grumbled a little and wriggled to try and steal more space but was unsuccessful in her attempts as Alice nudged her elbow sharply into her ribs.

“Shh,” Carol hushed urgently, flapping her hand from where she sat on the floor. “They’re announcing it.”

Rio scowled as she reached over for her now-warm beer and settled back again to focus on the tiny television screen in the tiny apartment she shared with Alice.

The picture now showed five previous Best Actress winners all standing in a semi-circle on the stage. They all, in their own ways, looked glamorous, beautiful, confident. To Rio they were goddess of stage and screen and she’d seen their work more times than she could count.

Though, admittedly, she thought one of the group was overrated. But no one else agreed so she often just kept that opinion to herself.

This way of announcing the nominees and eventual winner was new, had only been done once before, and Rio felt it was a little too schmaltzy.

Each were taking it in turns to reel off some spiel about the nominee they’d been assigned to publicly compliment. And Rio leant forwards in her seat, feeling Wanda’s hand rub her mid-back, as the esoteric Lilia Calderu filled the screen.

“Agatha Harkness!” She announced, smiling indulgently as the Dolby Theatre erupted in applause.

The favourite to win. Rio’s favourite ever.

“If she doesn’t win, I’ll-…” Alice started but stopped immediately when Rio and Carol shushed her again.

“Your power knows no bounds,” Lilia continued, twinkling from the stage down at where Agatha must be sitting in the front row.

“Your understanding and control of the craft is a gift to us all.”

And suddenly the picture on screen changed and Agatha Harkness was there in all her glory. Rio bit down on her lip, felt Alice beside her lean forwards a little too.

Agatha was smiling, she looked modest, touched. The crowd around her was applauding Lilia’s words, confirming them to the world.

“She’s so fucking hot,” Alice muttered as Lilia continued and the camera stayed focused on Agatha.

“Your performance in ‘The Concert Pianist’ was nothing short of extraordinary, my dear. And you are extraordinary in everything you do.”

Agatha inclined her head and Rio dropped her gaze to her lower lip that was now pulled between her teeth. She’d seen that lip up close, almost felt it against her own four years ago now.

“You truly are the best of us,” Lilia continued and the theatre erupted again to confirm what everybody already knew: Agatha was the best.

“I’m so in love with her,” Carol said absently and Rio kicked her gently in the side, her eyes still trained on Agatha’s face as she beamed up at the stage before the camera moved to the next presenter.

“My culture is not your costume.”

“Oh, come on. Everyone’s in love with her. She doesn’t belong to you, Rio.”

Rio sipped her beer and muttered, “I wish.”

She felt Wanda’s hand move against her back and she relaxed a little, but kept her eyes on the screen as the showcase of each actress came to an end.

The main presenter appeared back on the screen and little boxes of each nominee appeared beside her, Agatha in the top most right hand side. She looked calm, a smile only just tugging at her lips, and Rio wondered if she actually felt it or if her heart was thudding as loudly in her ears as Rio’s currently was.

“And the Oscar for Best Actress goes to…!”

The four women in Rio and Alice’s little living room all inhaled sharply as the presenter slipped open the golden envelope.

Rio leant forwards.

“Agatha Harkness!”

Alice cheered and leapt to her feet beside her and Rio grinned at the tv, swerving away from Alice’s legs to get a shot of Agatha as she rose to her feet. She watched as she kissed the man she knew to be her husband and felt a jolt of something in her chest as she turned her head from his and accepted only the briefest of cheek kisses before she was in the arms of her director.

Rio laughed as Carol pushed and pulled at her knees and she placed her beer down onto the safety of the coffee table before she looked back up and watched now as Agatha climbed her way up to the stage, her red dress billowing out behind her as she did.

“Jesus she’s unreal,” Rio breathed out, and wasn’t aware of it but Wanda had pulled her hand away.

“Imagine how fucking lucky her husband feels. He’s such a dick. He stood on my foot at that mixer we went to last fall,” Alice said as she stole Rio’s beer and sat back down again. “I like her manager though. Mean in a sexy-…”

“Alice. Shut up.”

Agatha was now at the microphone, holding her new Oscar in both hands. As the camera zoomed in Rio noticed her blue eyes shining with unshed tears and she wondered how anyone got anything done with Agatha looking like that anywhere near them.

Even seeing her across the room at parties she felt struck dumb by her. And any time she’d felt like they’d locked eyes she’d almost collapsed on the spot.

“You really know how to make a gal feel special.” Agatha laughed modestly, taking a second to look out over the crowd of people on their feet for her.

Carol shuffled over and leant her elbow on Rio’s leg.

“I wouldn’t be here tonight without my incredible cast and crew. With all of your hard work and dedication to this little movie. I’m in awe of all of you.”

“She’s not in awe of anyone,” Alice scoffed, “she’s-…”

“Shut up!”

“I’d like to thank The Academy for recognising this movie that meant so much to us as we were making it. My fellow nominees who…”

Rio chewed on her lip and placed her hand on Carol’s shoulder.

“… you’re just a dream to be around. Thank you for making this experience so magical for me.”

Agatha looked down at the Oscar as the applause washed over the audience.

“To my husband…” she looked up again, and looked out to the crowd where the camera switched to a view of Ralph. He had a big grin on his face and Rio felt irrationally angry about someone so handsome. “I have no words.”

“If I were married to Agatha Harkness-…” Alice started and Rio shushed her again, stealing her beer back.

“Performing is something I’ve done my whole life. I live and breathe this craft and it means everything to me that I’m standing up here tonight.”

The crowd erupted and Rio shifted forwards a little, wondering why Agatha looked more emotional talking about her craft than her husband.

“I share this with my manager, Jen, who has been by my side since college. And everyone who sees themselves up there on the screen, or on the stage. Anyone who shares my dreams.”

The crowd applauded again and Agatha smiled, a dazzling, watery smile that made Rio’s stomach flip.

“Finally, before I go, if I may, I’d like to dedicate this to the love of my life, my son, Nicky. Honey, mama loves you beyond life itself. To the moon and all the farthest stars. I can’t wait to squeeze you so tight when I get home. Thank you.”

She raised the Oscar and nodded her last thanks to the crowd before she strode away to more earth-shattering applause.

The four women in the little apartment were silent for a while, watching Agatha Harkness as she was ushered from the stage. It was Rio who broke the spell eventually: “I actually might be in love with her.”

Alice laughed and Rio looked down as Carol smiled up at her, “I’m afraid she would never be interested. Did you see how handsome her husband is?”

“Yeah but he’s an ass,” Alice added in Rio’s defence. “Rio’s only a dick.”

“Great, thank you.”

“I think you’d stand more of a chance with her mean manager,” Wanda said with a grin, “I hear she’s on our team.”

“Hello what now?” Alice was suddenly back on the couch, eyes wide as she leant around Rio to get to Wanda.

Rio laughed and shoved Alice off of her and reconfirmed in her own mind what she had been suspecting since the moment she’d shared with Agatha in the bathroom: that maybe she stood a slim chance with Agatha. And the other thing she was now sure of, more so than anything before in her life, was that if she won an Oscar and the person she loved were in the audience, she’d have plenty of words for her.

2025 | The Dolby Theatre

“And the Oscar for Best Actress goes to…!”

The room was still, silent.

And all Rio could feel was her heartbeat so loud in her ears and the intense, steady pressure of Agatha’s fingers wrapped tightly around her own.

She knew that three rows back from her, deep into the tangle of bodies in plush red chairs, that Alice would be leaning forwards in her seat, her own hand probably crushing the life out of her dad’s.

She could picture the people at home all placing their bets on whether it would be Agatha Harkness or Rio Vidal who would take home the trophy. She imagined their snacks laid out before them, the cool beer in their hands, the soft pyjamas they probably wore.

She wanted to be them. Wanted to be watching this from afar, undetached, unimpacted by whatever name was read out from the little gold envelope before her.

But she was here. She was clutching the hand of the woman she loved. The eyes of the world were on them but their touch was just for them.

Her mom squeezed her hand, Agatha’s fingers twitched.

She sucked in a breath.

“Rio Vidal!”

Rio’s body went rigid, petrified by the shock. And the fingers that once clutched at Agatha were ripped open as Agatha and her mom moved.

Anna leant over the armrest and pulled her daughter into a hold so tight that it shocked Rio back into her body. She was breathing again, but stiff still, her eyes wide and her mouth hanging open.

She rose slowly from her seat, helped by the hands of those people who had run over to get to her. But one pair of hands disregarded the rest and pulled Rio into a hold so tight she lost her breath again.

“Agatha,” she whispered without knowing really what else to say. But she held on tight, ignoring the other hands that tried to pull her to them and from her.

“You have to go, Rio. You have to go.”

Agatha released her hold, loosening without letting go, and Rio stared wide-eyed at her, unsure why tears were forming in bright blue eyes. She reached for her cheek and Agatha smiled, let her do it, whispered the words: “Rio. Baby.”

A pair of lips found her right arm and Rio turned to see Wanda beaming at her as Agatha began to push at her waist, directing her away from the small crowd that had formed and up to the stage. Wanda managed to kiss her cheek too and Rio smiled absently at her, realising she was beginning to cry too as the familiar feel of Agatha’s hands on her fell away.

Two men darted out to help her up the stairs and Rio turned naturally to her right to accept the help of Wanda’s brother rather than the alternative option of Ralph Bohner.

She smiled at the man whose name she’d already forgotten and clung to him until she was at the top of the stairs and able to make her way over to the Oscar that was now hers.

The presenter squeezed her and kissed her cheek and she turned to her waiting audience.

The room was on its feet, all still applauding, some cheering. And Rio had seen this before but only through the lens of the television, only when she was one of the masses in their pyjamas, watching the glamorous, unreal famous people accept their golden statues.

But down in the first row were the people who grounded her. Anna and Agatha now stood, arm in arm, both grinning up at her, one openly crying, the other just about holding it in.

“Dios mío,” Rio began, unconsciously slipping into her mother tongue as she stared down at Anna and Agatha. Her brow furrowed in confusion as a tear slipped from her eye. It seemed unfair suddenly that she’d been given this award and yet had no say in where she stood. Because she wanted to be where they were. She wanted to be wrapped up in them.

“No sé.” I don’t understand. She tried again, her gaze now locked into watery blue eyes as they shone up at her. But Agatha was nodding, encouraging her, and she winked as her smile widened and Rio released a laugh, halfway between relief and disbelief.

She closed her eyes for a second and turned back to the audience still on their feet for her. “This is… too much for one person to handle.”

She felt rather than heard the ripple of laughter through the theatre and took a breath as she reminded herself that this was her one shot at it. That this most likely wouldn’t happen again.

“Mi primer agradecimiento se lo prometí hace mucho tiempo a alguien a quien he amado durante años.” My first thank you I promised long ago to someone I have loved for years now.

Love. not in love. She couldn’t say it.

Rio knew most wouldn’t understand her, some would be annoyed she was speaking Spanish rather than the traditional English, but she couldn’t help it. Her speech would be translated and dissected over and over again anyway.

This felt most natural. It felt most herself.

She took a breath and turned back to Agatha, her arm no longer looped with her mother’s but instead around her shoulders, holding her as she cried.

“Agatha,” Rio smiled around her name, watched as Agatha smiled at the sound of it too, her free hand moving to her diaphragm as if to steady her breathing, “You’re the best person, the best actress, the best mother. I…” and she felt the words choke her, felt how they swelled in her throat, how they prevented her from saying any more.

She’d made a promise years ago that she would tell the woman she loved how much she loved her, if she were lucky enough to have a woman to love. And she was. She had her. But only secretly. Only in the dark. So she settled for choking on her words instead, letting them dissolve in her throat and settle heavily in her chest.

She shook her head, trying to shake them away as she dropped her gaze to the award in her hands and let the applause for Agatha speak for her instead.

“And to the other best mother in my life,” she raised her gaze to her mom and grinned at her, laughing as she saw Anna shake her head at her and wipe quickly at her eyes, knowing as she did that she was on camera.

The crowd laughed with Rio as she took a second to steady and swallow down again the words that had almost escaped her earlier.

“Te amo. Tú y papá me habéis enseñado a amar y a ser amado. Y estoy aquí hoy gracias a ti. Te amo, mamá. Te amo, papá.” I love you. You and dad have shown me how to love and how to be loved. And I am here today because of you. I love you, mom. I love you, dad.

Through the applause again she heard a whistle and she looked up in the direction it came from. Her dad’s whistle. One she’d heard a million times before when she was on a generational run across the basketball court, when she was streaking ahead during track, when she was taking a bow at curtain call.

She grinned so hard she laughed again. “Thanks, dad.”

The crowd laughed with her and Rio knew she had them in her clutches, that for one brief moment in time the whole world was under her spell.

She took another breath and let herself take it all in, needing a second to calm her racing heart.

“I don’t accept this lightly. I know what a huge honour it is to even be amongst you all tonight. And I’m so grateful to be here. So hugely in awe of everyone. So thrilled to be here with my fellow nominees.”

More applause. Some hollering.

“Wanda, Jessica, Isla, Sylvia, and Agatha. All of you… it’s incredible to me I’m even considered worthy of being here amongst you.”

More clapping. She looked up and saw Agatha was frozen in place, the pale hand on her front now twisted in the velvet.

“My beautiful cast and crew, I love you all so much. I share this with you. I wouldn’t be here without your talent and support and joy.”

She tried to find them in the crowd but could only see the faceless masses and Agatha down at the front, still clutching her dress, still holding her mom, still beaming her teary grin up at Rio.

“I really should go before I say anything that’ll get me in trouble.” Not a lie.

Laughter. Her mom shaking her head again.

“Thank you for this. Thank you to the Academy. Really. I’m… speechless, thank you. Te veo.”

She held her award up and grinned at her audience and then turned to leave the stage.

Rio Vidal didn’t breathe again until Alice found her. She was aware she was being taken somewhere, aware there was a camera in her face, aware people were brushing her arms as she went past and smiling their congrats at her but she couldn’t take any of it in.

She smiled and nodded and grinned and laughed but she felt separate from it, so out of her mind with disbelief that she couldn’t feel her own body.

Only when a familiar touch grabbed her side and she was turned into the arms of her best friend did she understand what had happened.

“Alice.”

“Holy shit.”

“Alice.”

“Holy shit.”

“Alice.”

“No, Rio. Holy shit.”

“I’m going to have a panic attack.”

Alice pulled back with wide eyes and her tear-stained face and she held Rio firmly in front of her, nodding quickly as she assessed the promise in Rio’s words.

“Breathe with me,” she urged, taking in slow, obvious breaths so Rio could follow along. She did so and found her chest loosening after a while, her body giving into the adrenaline coursing through her veins as it quivered occasionally on Alice’s hold.

When Rio felt more in control she nodded and Alice pulled her back in for a hug and Rio was grateful she wasn’t making her keep to a tight schedule for once in their working relationship. She just held her, let Rio breathe against her, let her recover.

Rio pulled away only when she knew she could handle it and smiled dazedly down at Alice who still looked concerned. “Can you believe it?”

“Babe, I’ve believed it since we started this whole thing.”

Rio rolled her eyes and raised her arm to wipe away the lipstick on Alice’s face but Alice moved before she could and lifted her right arm to rub away the lipstick that Rio had on her.

“Agatha?”

“Probably.”

Alice laughed then, and it took over her completely. She almost bent double and Rio caught the laughter too and dissolved into it as if she hadn’t just been having a total crisis in her best friend’s arms.

They recovered together and moved together to the press rooms where Rio was applauded upon entering and cheered when she held her new trophy up for the world’s press to see.

“Rio! Congratulations!”

“Thank you,” Rio said with a laugh as she tried to find which of the press was now talking to her.

“Over here.” A man waved and she turned to him with a nod.

“Hello!”

“Hi. Your speech, was it a conscious decision to speak in Spanish?”

“Are you consciously speaking in English right now?”

There was a smattering of laughter and Rio smiled as she was directed to the next question.

“Congrats, Rio. Did you have any idea of the way tonight would go?”

“God, no. I thought it was Agatha’s all along.”

She turned to the next and smiled as she was congratulated again.

“You thanked Agatha first in your speech. We’ve had the translation through now. Do you consider her a mentor of sorts?”

And Rio laughed because what would Agatha say to this?

“A friend, first. But… I do look up to her, obviously. She’s twice the actor I’ll ever be.”

Another, and then another, and another, and Rio soon lost track of how many questions she’d answered. But they were all relatively innocuous, and she got away with mostly smiling and nodding and giving one-line sound bites for each publication and channel.

Alice was soon ushering from from the makeshift stage again and she left the room to more applause and soon found herself in another corridor where Jasmine her makeup artist was waiting to touch her up and make her photograph ready.

When her lipstick had been reapplied and her hair adjusted she was taken to pose with her fellow winners. The weight of the golden statue in her hand began to feel normal, began to almost anchor her down to the ground where she was still in danger of floating off into the clouds.

“Is that it? Please tell me I can get drunk now.”

Alice laughed as she pushed Rio along through another crowded area full of flashing cameras and people jostling for Rio’s attention.

“We gotta get the statue engraved, babe. Make it official.”

Rio pretended to be annoyed by this but really her name on an Academy Award was something she’d dreamt of since she was old enough to have dreams. So she grinned widely and made no more complaint as an attendant, after congratulating Rio profusely, took her over to the little area where there were hoards of other winners looking to get their metal made official.

Rio sidled up to the handsome Best Supporting Actor and exchanged comfortable small talk with him as she was handed a glass of champagne and photographed from every possible angle. She was so pleased, in that moment, that Alice had insisted Jasmine tag along with them that night.

But soon the award was back in her hands and now, amongst the details of the award, it read: RIO VIDAL.

“Holy fucking shit.”

She mingled some more, Alice telling her to relax and finish her champagne which she did in record time because she needed it and because she was desperate to see her parents and to get through all of this so she could find Agatha again.

Alice helped to extract her once she was done. She’d done her job and she’d done it well so she relaxed now and her grin became more soft as she swung her golden man through the hallways. That was, until Alice broke the bad news that the next room she was taking her to she’d need to be on her best behaviour for.

“A couple big journos, okay? Actually, there’s a third one and she’s a nightmare. But nothing you can’t handle.”

“Jesus. What? I thought I was done with the press.”

Alice sighed heavily and as they stopped outside the door she turned to Rio and held her arms, “You’ve got this. I believe in you, remember. Big deep breaths.”

Rio nodded and forced a smile, forcing it to turn into a grin wide enough to hide her fear.

Alice smiled back at her and turned to open the door. But she didn’t walk in first like she usually would to announce Rio’s arrival. She instead pushed it and held it and stepped aside for Rio to go in before her.

But Rio didn’t move. Because standing inside the little room were three of her favourite people.

Anna, Miguel, and Agatha.

“You bitch,” she muttered for Alice’s ears only but her best friend simply beamed at her and ushered her in.

“You have ten minutes. Go!”

Rio laughed as she made quick strides to launch herself at her dad, finding her mom’s arms around her almost immediately too. She cried in between them, felt her dad brushing down her hair and her mom rubbing her back.

“Nosotras estamos muy orgullosas de ti.” We are so proud of you.

Rio felt her mom grip her harder and she released a shaky laugh as she lifted her head to look at them both and grinned through their tears.

Alice didn’t even pull Rio away when Anna kissed over her daughter’s face.

Rio laughed again as she moved back and looked up to see the third person who’d been waiting for her. Agatha stood quietly off to the side, a faint smile on her face as she watched the reunion, her left hand clutching her right arm.

She looked shy, like she’d stumbled into something she shouldn’t be part of. But Rio wanted her here, she had to know Rio wanted her here.

“Ve a abrazarla.” Go hug her.

Anna pushed her daughter towards Agatha. But Rio didn’t really need the encouragement. She practically stumbled her way to her and paused when she was directly in front of her.

Agatha’s eyes looked glassy and Rio lost her train of thought for a second as she stared into them.

Neither of them moved.

“Did you schedule in this meeting? I’m an Oscar winner now. Very important. Very busy.”

Agatha smirked at her. “Alice gave me a special pass for tonight, superstar.”

“Is that right?”

Rio bit on her lip to hide her own smirk and turned to look over her shoulder at her parents, shooting Alice a look too. “Could we have a second?”

She watched as they all turned, her dad not without a squeeze of her arm, and left them to it.

Anna was the last to leave and had corralled the others before her and Rio turned back to Agatha missing her mom watching her for a second before she finally closed the door behind her.

“A special pass?”

Agatha pursed her lips, her gaze moved slowly down her right arm, seemed to linger there for a second, then dropped to the Oscar hanging from Rio’s right hand. “It’s actually a lifetime pass.”

“Lifetime, huh? Seems… official.”

Rio gasped quietly as blue eyes flashed back up to meet her own and Agatha grinned at her, teasing and wicked.

“We only have five minutes, Rio.”

“You just said a lifetime.”

Agatha laughed as Rio grinned. Agatha stepped forwards and Rio raised her chin as pale hands slid to hold her head, her thumbs brushing tenderly over her cheeks.

“How do you feel?”

“A little drunk, weirdly. A little emotional. Very surprised.”

“You deserve it.”

“I do?”

“Rio.”

“You’re not…” Rio grinned, watching as Agatha’s gaze honed in on her smile. “Jealous?”

“I’ll let you have this one. There are plenty more for me to win.”

Rio laughed as Agatha continued her movements against her cheeks. Her words were teasing but her face was soft and as Rio’s laughter died down she breathed in slowly, the soft scent of familiar perfume relaxing her even as her body quivered from the excess adrenaline still coursing through her.

“I’m so proud of you.”

Agatha smiled a little as she leant in to kiss Rio, capturing her lower lip and making Rio whimper quietly and it took her a second to get her brain in gear to be able to kiss Agatha back.

When Agatha pulled away she dropped her hands from her face and moved the cape part of her dress to wrap around Rio and they tangled themselves together, with Rio’s shining Oscar resting now against Agatha’s back.

“Your mom has been crying since you won.”

Agatha’s voice was soft and low against her ear and Rio smiled and turned her head into her more, blinking owlishly as she rested her forehead against Agatha’s. She took a deep breath.

“You looked pretty teary yourself from where I was standing.”

“You wish,” Agatha said with a grin as she angled up to kiss Rio. It was delicate, unassuming, and finished too quickly. But Rio smiled all the same as Agatha leant in again to kiss the corner of her smile, to press her nose in against Rio’s warm cheek.

“Did you like my speech?” Rio asked quietly, feeling her heart rate slow to a steady pace again in Agatha’s hold.

Agatha nodded against her, placing a kiss to her cheek before she pulled away to meet Rio’s gaze, “You looked incredible up there.”

Rio smiled and squeezed Agatha’s waist, moving her hand back to brush over the soft velvet against her hip. “It should have been yours.”

Agatha laughed and pressed her face in against Rio’s cheek again, falling into silence for a few seconds before she whispered, “It was always going to be yours. I wanted you to get it. Enjoy it.”

“And you’ll get the next one?”

“Oh, honey. I said enjoy it. Not get used to it.”

Rio laughed and Agatha grinned against her cheek, “I mean it.”

Rio exhaled a laugh and pulled back, finding it difficult with how tight Agatha’s hold was on her. “You can’t threaten an Oscar winner.”

“I have a special pass, remember?”

Rio rolled her eyes and held up her Oscar, moving it between them and beaming up at Agatha. “He’s handsome.”

“Mmhm.”

“Never been attracted to a man before.”

Agatha moved her arms down Rio’s body, linking her fingers over the small of Rio’s back where their hips pressed together.

“Has winning an Oscar awoken something in you that I won’t like?”

“I’m still a one woman gal, if that’s what you’re worried about.”

Agatha raised her brows and maintained eye contact with Rio as she leant in and kiss the statue on his back. “Then I’m okay with him.”

“Rio! We’re coming in!”

Rio rolled her eyes, the spell of Agatha’s gaze broken as the reality of where they were crashed down around her. Agatha pulled back and Rio smiled sadly as Agatha kissed her cheek quickly and then took a step back and brushed down her dress.

“Smooth,” Rio mouthed across at her and received a smirk in response just as the door opened again and Rio turned to greet her adoring parents.

She felt a hand on her side and a body briefly press against hers from behind as Agatha leant in to kiss her cheek again and Rio grinned because of it. “I’ll see you soon.”

She watched her leave, pausing briefly to hug her mom and kiss her dad before she hit the door, turned to smile briefly in Rio’s direction, and then left.

Rio felt like she’d taken her heart with her.

“Vidal!” Alice called, clapping her hands in front of Rio’s face to get her to snap out of it.

Rio rolled her eyes but smiled at her friend. “Yes. Ready. Let’s go.”

“Umm,” Alice said quickly, holding her hand up as she turned to shout for Jasmine.

“Really, Alice? We’re only going to the car.” Anna moved in to brush her thumbs over Rio’s cheeks and smile at her daughter. Rio huffed a little but closed her eyes as her mom began to fix her face until Jasmine could work her magic again.

“Lots of tears, huh?” Jasmine said with a grin. “Agatha didn’t look so polished either when she walked past just there.”

“No, babe. Home. Now. Whilst the going is good, come on.”

“Okay, cariño.”

Rio grinned against the back of Agatha’s hand and let it go reluctantly to do as she was told and disappear off into the night. Only disappearing into the night wasn’t as easy as it used to be. It took them almost thirty minutes to get away from the people wanting one last shot at the Best Actress before she left.

Even Wanda tried to cajole her into staying.

But soon, Rio was striding into her little house in the hills with her Oscar held high in the air.

“Yesssssss!” She shout-whispered, only at the last second remembering that her parents were asleep up the stairs.

Alice laughed as she surveyed her friend from the door. “Plenty of water, babe. Go to bed. I’ll see you in a week.”

Rio turned on the spot, “I love you.”

“I love you too, Rio. Proud of you.”

And Alice was gone.

Rio stood in the twilight dark entrance of her home bought with the first movie star paycheck she’d ever earned, clutching the trophy that meant her whole life was about to change. But she remained, as ever, all alone.

Chapter 27: A Week: Monday, Tuesday

Chapter Summary

Rio and Agatha get away.

Chapter Notes

smut, fluff, angst, gang's all here

See the end of the chapter for more notes

And Rio turned to Agatha and sat in stunned silence as Agatha stood and busied herself with serving. She looked at ease, unmoved by Rio’s incomprehension, focused instead on piling the plates with a meal Rio hadn’t had since she was last home.

“My mom told you,” Rio eventually deduced, her brain kicking into gear again as Agatha placed her bowl down before her on the placemat.

“Your dad, actually.”

Agatha sat down and Rio reached to tug her chair around some more which made Agatha look at her with a wry smile that Rio was soon leaning over to kiss away. “Thank you.”

They sat so that, every now and again, Agatha could reach to squeeze her hand - usually after she’d said something to tease Rio or when conversation lulled and she simply wanted to be touching her.

And Rio found that instead of trying to show off, as she usually might, she relaxed into it. She felt calm and less anxious than she had been for weeks.

“Okay,” Agatha said out of nowhere when they were both done with their food, soft but firm, “You wanted to talk.”

The concept of Agatha struggling to open up to her had weighed heavily on Rio’s mind for weeks now. The idea of her being frightened or ashamed or simply unwilling, was almost too painful to comprehend.

“You don’t have to be so nervous.” I’m nervous too.

Rio nodded, focused on Agatha’s fingers. Agatha was a great actress, the best of them, but a terrible liar.

“Ooookay,” Rio raised her brows as Agatha’s eyes flashed up to meet her own. “Then why do you look so scared?”

Agatha cleared her throat and dropped her gaze again and Rio, despite her smile, could have cried.

She chewed on her lip as she focused in on the pale fingers that tapped a rhythm on the stem of her wine glass. She didn’t want to spook her. “Why the name Nicholas?”

The question just came to her, stolen from an errant thought she’d had when she’d first met Nicky. It was something she was curious to know, but it wasn’t what she wanted to ask.

Though the lowball question, the excuse to talk about her son seemed to loosen Agatha a little. Her fingers stopped twitching, her jaw relaxed. “It means ‘victory’, or ‘victory of the people’. He felt like my one success. I wanted him to grow up and know that from the moment I knew of him, he was my hero.”

Rio’s chest ached with a desire to reach out to Agatha again. But she only smiled, only bit down on the corner of her lip.

“And not ‘Bohner’?”

“No,” Agatha said softly, “I never took it and no son of mine would either.”

“Is Ralph a Harkness?”

“No.”

Rio nodded and watched as Agatha’s fingers returned to their tapping. Nicky had relaxed her. Ralph had spooked her.

“Favourite ice cream flavour?”

“What?”

Rio inclined her head, “It shouldn’t be a hard question.”

“Pecan.”

A laugh escaped her and Agatha briefly looked scandalised. “What’s wrong with pecan?”

“It’s just… pecan. Mine’s chocolate.”

“Basic,” Agatha retorted, her lips twitching. Her fingers had stopped tapping. She was relaxing again.

“Okay, favourite colour?”

“Rio.”

“What?”

“I thought you wanted to talk.”

“I’m talking. Getting to know you. Relaxing you.”

“I’m not. I just want you to relax. This doesn’t have to be stressful.”

Rio raised her brows and tilted her head as Agatha adjusted herself. She moved from sitting with her legs crossed to her legs straight out before her, now parted to welcome Rio in. Maybe Agatha, in unstolen time, simply wanted her close.

“Like the lakers,” Rio said with a smile, remembering that first day in Agatha’s house.

“Mmhm.”

“What else do you want to know?”

“Tell me about your childhood.”

It had been an exploration of her decades at the top of every list of business heavyweights, the political power she wielded, the empire she’d built by being friendly with the most hard-line in society.

She already knew Agatha didn’t like to discuss her. She’d seen it in Italy - when the sun had been warm and Agatha’s reaction to her mother being mentioned had been cold.

“I was raised mostly by a woman named Isobel. She was from Mexico. She was a maid. I had nannies, of course. But Isobel… she was kind, and soft. She used to sneak me candy and every week she’d teach me ten more words. My mother didn’t want me to speak to the staff… but she wasn’t around a lot.”

“Yes.”

“I started performing in plays… Shakespeare, mostly, and my drama teacher gave me scripts and drove me to auditions when she realised I had something. But I could never book anything because my mother wouldn’t… anyway.”

“Then I went to college and got a boyfriend. I hadn’t kissed anyone yet. I hadn’t ever... wanted to. Not really, anyway. No one I ever thought I could kiss.”

But it was hypocritical. A bare-faced lie. Because Rio wanted Agatha to be tied to her. In another, happier moment she might have imagined Agatha walking down the street with a little red string attached to her wrist, tugging a willing Rio along behind her, the same red string circling her own wrist.

“It’s what it is.”

“That doesn’t mean it’s okay.”

“Is that enough?”

Rio frowned and turned her head to look at Agatha properly, watching her as she raised her hand to Rio’s cheek. “Enough what?”

“Talking.”

No.

Rio was quiet for a while, the volume of her ‘no’ getting louder and louder in her own brain until she eventually whispered, “Does she know you’re queer?”

Agatha looked away.

“I think so.”

Rio felt the fury burn her again and she had to grit her teeth to prevent herself from saying something she couldn’t take back. Agatha’s thumb moved down to brush across her lips as her gaze dropped to them. “Why are you reacting this way?”

Rio’s brows knitted together and she pulled back a little, watching as Agatha’s eyes flashed with sudden panic. “What other way would I react?”

“Surely the fact that I’m married is-…”

“Agatha.”

Rio sighed heavily and closed her eyes, trying in earnest to keep her temper at bay. “I hate that you’re married, of course I do. But I fucking hate even more that you’re married to a man that not only you don’t like but in a marriage that you were forced into by your bigot fucking mother.”
