“Ag-..?”

Rio’s question was lost as Agatha pressed their lips together. Fierce and heavy. Rio made a quiet noise against her and then came to her senses and kissed her back.

The kiss was initially firm but chaste until Agatha made it anything but. She pressed into Rio and wrapped her legs around her as they devoured each other with lips and teeth and tongue.

Until Agatha was clawing at Rio’s scalp, her hips beginning to rock desperately against her abdomen, her mouth relentless in its devotion.

Agatha tasted like red wine and something Rio couldn’t describe but that she thought of privately as heaven.

But Agatha pulled away long before Rio wanted her too, breaking the kiss with a strength Rio would never have had. And they panted into each others mouths, Agatha’s hips stilling even as Rio gripped them and held her flush to her stomach.

“I don’t,” Agatha began, barely able to get the words out for her heavy breathing, “I don’t need saving.”

Rio nodded, knowing Agatha was too proud to ever admit that her kiss had meant to opposite. “I know. Baby, I know.”

Agatha leant in and kissed her again, and Rio frowned into it, feeling the sting of Agatha clutching at the roots of her hair until she relented and broke away.

Rio blinked her eyes open again and saw Agatha already looking at her, saw the green in her dilated eyes, saw the flush across her pale cheeks. She kissed Agatha’s pouting bottom lip and sucked gently on it, pulling away reluctantly to look back up again.

“You’re safe with me,” Rio murmured as Agatha inhaled audibly, her eye lids fluttering closed at Rio’s quiet promise. “You always will be.”

“You’re doing it again.”

“Doing what?”

“Being too sweet.”

Rio smiled and Agatha’s lips twitched. They looked at each other for a while, until Agatha’s soft expression became more serious and Rio felt her heart thrum harder against her ribcage.

“Is it always this easy?”

“What?”

“Being with someone.”

Rio gasped quietly as Agatha brushed their lips together, barely a kiss, more an instinct.

“I think when it’s the right person it feels easy, yes.”

Agatha kissed her again then, slow this time, somehow sure. And Rio’s hold on her changed so she could rub Agatha’s back, brushing her hands slowly up and down, coming to a halt only when Agatha pulled away again.

“I’m tired,” Agatha said matter-of-factly, and it was clear on her face suddenly, the heaviness of her reality beyond the walls of their little sanctuary suddenly laid bare for Rio to see.

“We should go to bed.”

We.

This was the first night they could be that. Rio, a woman who so secretly feared she’d always be just a me, felt her heart stutter in her chest, feasting itself on the Agatha’s crumbs.

Rio released Agatha to let her climb from her. She took the hand that she held out to her. She walked silently with her, just one step behind, and arrived into the bedroom with her. Agatha let her go and disappeared into the bathroom and Rio found an old t-shirt she’d packed to wear and threw off her clothes to change into it.

As she waited for Agatha to return she heard her voice over and over in her brain repeating the things she’d clearly been telling herself after being raised like a pig to slaughter: “he was bland, vanilla, nothing”. But now this nothing man was the anchor holding Agatha down beneath the surface. Her mother was the unforgiving tide, churning without mercy, forcing her daughter deeper instead of teaching her how to swim.

“Hey.”

Rio startled and looked up. Agatha had appeared again, her hair up, her face shining from where she’d washed and cleansed. “You okay?”

“Yeah,” Rio said quickly, too quickly, that Agatha caught on and frowned as Rio stepped towards her. “Just a lot to think about.”

Agatha nodded and bit her lip as Rio kissed her cheek and stepped around her.

“We’re okay though?”

Rio’s hand was on the bathroom door handle, halfway to opening it as she turned back to Agatha with a frown, “Agatha, nothing you could tell me would make us not okay.”

Agatha smiled but it didn’t reach her eyes and she turned away before Rio could see.

When Rio crawled into bed beside Agatha that night she didn’t comment on the t-shirt Agatha wore that she’d clearly stolen from her bag, she didn’t say anything as Agatha silently manoeuvred them to entangle together, and she said nothing when Agatha began to draw soft circles along the small of her back.

But Agatha spoke when Rio finally closed her eyes: “You didn’t ask about Nicky’s middle name.”

Rio frowned into the dark, fighting to compute. “What?”

“His middle name.”

“His…? What is it?”

“River.”

Rio’s frown changed then as she raised her brows and slowly opened her eyes. Agatha was already watching her, already trying to gage her reaction. “River?”

“I met a woman once who was wild and brilliant and I wanted him to…”

“Agatha.”

“I just thought you should know. Go to sleep, Rio.”

Rio stared across at the woman before her through the dim, the woman currently wearing yet another piece of her clothing she’d just stolen. The woman who was raised in cruelty but was so far from cruel. The woman who was so tightly curled around her, trying to get closer, trying to melt into Rio.

“My love,” Rio whispered reverently, half dumbfounded, half desperate, “his name is River?”

“His name,” Agatha said slowly, tugging Rio’s leg until it was draped over her hip, “isn’t as important as you sleeping.”

She leant in and nudged their noses together, Rio’s frown as deep as ever. “Did you name him after me?”

Agatha nodded soundlessly, and Rio continued to stare, watching as Agatha grew shy and turned her face into the pillow.

Their first night together Agatha had said a week wouldn’t even be enough, a sentiment they’d both acknowledged since, and that Rio felt more viscerally now than ever before. Because how could any limited amount of time with Agatha be enough? With the feel of her against her, the scent of her floral perfume filling her lungs, the hypnotic blue eyes she would gladly drown herself in.

The soft, surprising ways she found to tell Rio what she was so desperate to hear, even without saying the words: “I love you too.”

And so, in the hopes that maybe she could make it clear where she stood in a night so fraught with confessions and thick with ghosts of Agatha’s past, she said: “I want you to know,” Rio murmured, moving her hand from Agatha’s back to rest on her cheek. “That if we made a go of this, a real one, then I’d be whatever you wanted me to be for Nicky.”

Agatha hadn’t raised her gaze yet and Rio wondered if it was because she’d already said too much, already revealed too much of herself. She gave her time. She let her sit in the silence for a while. And only when it became clear that Agatha wouldn’t, couldn’t, say anything, she pulled her hand back.

Agatha closed her eyes and Rio smiled sadly as she pressed closer, debating on rolling them over and pulling Agatha on top of her, wanting to feel the weight of her. Wanting to be the thing that supported her on this earth.

But she didn’t. She simply watched, counted the freckles on her nose.

“I love you.”

Agatha responded by rubbing her bare thigh. Rio let the motion soothe her, helping her brain to calm, her body to melt more into Agatha’s. As Rio drifted, Agatha slid her hand up to the bend at her hip and tapped gently, purposefully, four times.

Chapter End Notes

there would be something so synchronistic about evanora being spoken about properly and then...

Chapter 28: A Week: Wednesday, Thursday, Friday

Chapter Summary

Agatha realises what happiness is.

Rio realises too.

Chapter Notes

There is so much smut in this and it is so long I can only apologise

See the end of the chapter for more notes

WEDNESDAY

Rio woke with no thoughts in her empty head. But a lightly snoring woman in her arms.

Agatha Harkness was facing away from her, curled in on herself, her hair that had once been up in a neat bun, was now spread like wildfire behind her.

Rio was barely holding on. But she had her.

She lay still for a while, transitioning from sleeping to waking. The process was slow, a result of a long drive, a heavy night, and a bottle of red wine.

Sure Agatha was fast asleep still, she peeled away and slipped from the room.

When downstairs in the soft morning light she put on the coffee and tidied away the remnants of last night’s dinner.

Agatha was to be the chef for the week, so Rio could be the one who cleaned. She did so quickly, quietly, wanting Agatha to wake to a spotless kitchen and not have to witness Rio’s frustrated sighs when she couldn’t source the right locations for each thing she tidied away.

Agatha deserved a spotless kitchen. She deserved an easy life; a soft morning buried in the hills with someone who wanted to give that to her.

Rio debated going back to wake her. She considered bringing her a coffee or her best attempt at scrambled eggs. But it was still early. And bed was where Agatha could be warm and safe, away from the fears that plagued her.

So Rio took her own fears, alongside her mug of coffee and the large throw she’d stolen from the couch, and went to settle on one of the loungers on the balcony. It was cold, crisp. The morning air was relentless in its chill. And Rio tugged her knees close as she wrapped the blanket snuggly about her and cradled her coffee.

Over the hills she could see the famous bay, laid out like a painting. A Frisco fresco.

As she warmed herself, she thought of Agatha, snug in their bed. She thought of Agatha as she had been, back when she was in Evanora’s clutches. She thought of Agatha in Ralph’s large hands. She thought of Agatha wrapped in her own arms, where she hoped she always felt safe and loved.

She thought of Agatha as she was, as she is, as she would be.

And in thinking of her, she realised she loved her, not just the woman she knew, but every piece of her. Every past, present, future, her.

She took a sip of her coffee. She burnt her tongue.

She poked the tip of it to her top lip, feeling the cool air sting as it washed over it.

They were like two sides of the same coin, her and Agatha. Rio had been loved, endlessly, joyfully, unconditionally. And Agatha had been kept, molded, squashed, but certainly not loved.

And yet they both wanted it, and wanted it desperately.

Rio had found what she’d been looking for in Agatha. And she hoped Agatha had found what she had been looking for in Rio.

Because Rio would never keep, would never try to mold, would never squash Agatha. She would only love her the way she’d been taught. The way she’d dreamt about loving someone until those dreams had shifted into dreams of loving Agatha like that.

“Hey.”

Rio jumped, almost spilling her hot coffee over herself. She turned to see Agatha standing hesitantly by the door.

“Morning, mi corazon.”

She smiled with the grace of a person who was looking at something beautiful, something only for them to see.

Agatha seemed to deliberate before she moved, before she closed the door behind her. But then she hurried, tip-toeing along the cool floor of the balcony, rushing to dive into the space Rio had opened for her between her legs, beneath the blanket.

Rio chuckled as Agatha grumbled in the chill, curling herself beneath the blanket that Rio threw back over them.

“Here.” She passed her the mug so Agatha could warm her hands and soon placed her now free mug-warmed hand over Agatha’s stomach as she kept the blankets closed firm around them with her other.

“There was coffee on the side, you know.”

“I have yours now.”

Rio rolled her eyes but Agatha had leant back, had turned her head to kiss her cheek, and suddenly Rio had no problem sharing coffee.

“Did you sleep okay?”

Agatha made a soft noise from the base of her throat as she curled her legs up to get more beneath the blanket. Rio grinned, pressed her cold nose in behind Agatha’s ear and felt Agatha shiver as she muttered, “you know, I’m sure there are more blankets inside.”

“And deny you the chance to curl up with me? I wouldn’t do that to you.”

Rio huffed out a warm breath and Agatha hummed as Rio’s thumb moved slowly across her stomach.

Rio closed her eyes, the scent of the fresh coffee, the fresh air, Agatha’s perfume, it was ambrosia, and she was Tantalus. But she’d take her eternal punishment in exchange for just this, just this morning with Agatha.

There was nothing but the soft sound of birdsong nearby, the breeze in the trees, Agatha’s breathing, the soft movements of fabric when she began to sip the hot coffee. And Rio didn’t want it to ever stop being like this, just the two of them, just the wind and Agatha.

After another couple of minutes Agatha turned a little and offered the coffee up. Rio took it and was grateful she’d drank only half, and that she’d done so quickly, so it was still warm when Rio drank the rest.

“You should know,” Agatha said after a few more minutes of silence in that cool morning air. And her voice was soft, but carried in it something Rio knew she wasn’t going to like. “If ever I were to leave Ralph, my mother would bankroll him. He’d have her on side.”

So she’d been thinking about it. Thinking about leaving Ralph and how hard it might be. And though Rio felt sick about it, about Agatha’s own flesh and blood siding against her, she also felt a selfish sort of relief that Agatha was beginning to edge towards the idea of leaving her husband.

She sighed heavily, ducked her head down to rest her chin on Agatha’s shoulder and they both sat in it for a minute; Agatha in her fear, Rio in her fury.

“If it were ever to come to that, however hard it gets,” Rio kept her voice soft, conscious that the world around them was silent and they were they only ones disturbing the peace. “I’d be with you every step of the way.”

Agatha turned her head and Rio lifted her own up cautiously, watching as blue eyes turned soft and Agatha whispered: “I wouldn’t ask you to be.”

“I wouldn’t need asking.”

Agatha nodded just once and turned back away, taking the opportunity now to steal back Rio’s mug of coffee which was now cold. Rio sighed quietly, a happy noise, a contented one as she ducked her head back down and pressed a kiss to Agatha’s shoulder.

Silence wrapped around them again like the haar spreading its ghostlike fingers through the foothills beyond. Rio felt Agatha shiver against her and she tightened her hold on her, tugging the edges of the blanket they shared closer around them as Agatha pulled her legs up more towards herself.

“Why don’t you stay here and I’ll run you a bath?”

Agatha turned her head back into Rio again, curling her body around to lean against her more fully, her left shoulder now tucked below Rio’s right arm, her head against her shoulder.

“Just me?”

“I can join you if you’d like.”

“Stay here for a little.”

“It’s cold, baby.”

“Five minutes.”

Rio sighed, had no real fight in her about it, and simply brushed her hand up and down Agatha’s arm, knowing holding her like this was worth even frostbite.

Agatha began to toy with the fabric of her t-shirt, and it wasn’t long until she was lifting it, and making Rio gasp when her cold fingers found the warm skin of her side.

“You run hot.”

“And you are always cold.”

“Guess that means you need to warm me up.”

Rio laughed and pressed her face into Agatha’s hair, “That is that the bath was for.”

She felt Agatha’s hand move an inch or so up to her ribs.

“It’ll be a first.”

“A first what?”

“Shared bath.”

Rio raised her brows and placed a kiss to Agatha’s head. “Then I’ll make it a good one. Plenty of bubbles. Hot coffee. Some candles. We’ll use the bath with the better view.”

“Have you had many… baths?”

Rio smiled a little but had long since decided the only way to get Agatha to ask her what she really wanted to was to play dumb. “I prefer to shower but-…”

“Rio.”

“Sí, mi amor?”

“Have you?”

“Have I what?”

Agatha sighed quietly and pushed up, breaking Rio’s wall of warm around them. But this was better. Agatha was straddling her, and Agatha wasn’t wearing any pants.

“Have you had many shared baths?”

“Well,” Rio began with a growing smirk, “it depends what you define as-…”

“I’m frozen, Agatha. Can we go now?”

Rio’s hold was tight on Agatha’s hips and she clenched her thighs to keep the toy secure as Agatha controlled her descent and slowly took her all the way in.

Rio gaped at where she’d disappeared inside her, groaned as Agatha rocked her hips a little, and shifted to ensure she was tight around the toy.

“Fuck, you took that so fucking well.”

But Rio lost the ability to think as Agatha began to ride her. It was slow at first, Agatha using Rio’s shoulders for balance, her head thrown back with every roll of her hips.

God bless Pilates. God bless Agatha fucking Harkness.

Rio just watched, held Agatha steady, but let her take control, let her fuck herself on Rio’s cock. Let her bounce and roll and moan until she came when all Rio had done was hold her hips.

And Agatha whined as she adjusted, pressing her hips down as Rio pushed up. It was risky, her thighs were sore from the tension of making sure she kept the toy in place, but nothing slipped and the look on Agatha’s flushed face was worth it.

She was panting heavily, unabashedly, now clutching at Rio’s hair, resting their foreheads together.

“Such a quick trigger,” Rio teased with a dazed smile as Agatha rolled her eyes and slowly lifted off of her.

“Mm. So smug.”

A pale hand reached between them and Rio groaned quietly when Agatha pulled the toy from between Rio’s legs and tossed it aside.

“Good practice is to try to keep those off the floor.”

“I won’t be using it again.”

“You didn’t like it?”

“I want to see how much you liked it.”

It took another two orgasms against Agatha’s mouth for her to be satisfied enough to tug Rio back into the blankets with her. For her to close her eyes and tangle herself in Rio’s limbs.

And Rio was so punch-drunk when all she’d had was a sip of champagne.

Rio breathed Agatha in deeply, the smell of her perfume, the heady scent of sex, it all mingled together into something delicious, something precious. She allowed it to wash over her, to fill her up, to strengthen her resolve as she asked: “You told me before that Ralph had never made you come. But you came from just riding me. Did you lie before?”

She moved the hand that curled around Agatha’s ribcage slowly down to rest over her hip as she lifted her head to look at her. Agatha was shifting slightly, but didn’t look away when Rio met her gaze. “No. Sex with Ralph… it was uncomfortable. He takes a while to come and… I just never enjoyed it.”

Rio nodded, felt the fire ignite in her belly as she remembered a conversation from long ago: Ralph never tried.

But her eyes fluttered closed as Agatha raised her hand to brush her fingers across her cheek. “It was just always missionary, always perfunctory, always what I thought it should be.”

Rio shook her head and looked to Agatha again, seeing the confusion in the way her brow knit together, the way her blue eyes darted about Rio’s face. “I didn’t know.”

“If sex is ever, with us, not what you want. I want you to-…”

“Rio,” Agatha uttered quickly, sadly, “I will never not want you.”

And Rio hoped Agatha meant in every way, not just the naked and breathless ways. But Agatha didn’t say anything to clarify and let the words hang in the air as she continued to caress Rio’s cheek.

They fell asleep like that. Calm like that. At ease and warmed by the fire.

It was Agatha this time who moved them to the bedroom around one in the morning. Agatha who sourced their phones, noted they’d both died from lack of use and the forgetfulness of two women too embroiled in each other to bother with boring things like charging.

She tucked a half-asleep Rio in and this time rolled her over so she was over her, and they both drifted off tangled in one another’s arms.

Chapter End Notes

It’s so nice that they’re so happy 🥰

Chapter 29: A Week: Saturday, Sunday, Monday

Chapter Summary

A visitor.

A punishment.

A panic.

Chapter Notes

Let’s all hold hands

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Saturday

The sun was high in the sky as Rio reclined on the bed overlooking the hills with the bay beyond.

Agatha was there because of course she was.

Her pale, attentive fingers were running gently through Rio’s hair and the world was good. Their day was just beginning. Her coffee-warmed hands rested now, absently tapping out a soft pattern across her stomach.

Birdsong nearby was all that disturbed them.

And then Agatha’s hand moved from her hair to her shoulder and the light touch became firmer, somehow insistent.

And Rio woke with a start.

“Rio. Honey.”

“Five minutes,” Rio mumbled, tugging the sheets up to her face, intent on blocking out the soft light of the morning, wanting to be back on the warm balcony where no one needed to be anywhere in particular.

“No, baby, wake up. I need to go.”

Rio frowned some more, took a second, allowed the sheets to be removed from her face.

When had we become I?

“Wait, wait, I’m sorry. I’ll get up. Give me five minutes. I’ll shower, and-…”

Rio’s eyes were open now as she’d moved to scramble up, assuming Agatha was wanting to get going and Rio was holding her back. But Agatha was frowning, was looking desolate, distraught, even. She was already dressed in Rio’s white knitted sweater.

Rio rubbed her eyes to make sure she wasn’t imagining it. To make sure Agatha wasn’t pulling some cruel trick. To make sure what she was seeing was real: her happy, calm, satiated lover was suddenly looking torn apart.

“Baby.”

Rio watched as Agatha crouched down by the edge of the bed, felt the gentleness of that hand that had taken her own, the fingers that curled around her ankle as she sat up properly and swung her legs over the edge.

“I have to go without you. Jen tried calling last night but my cell was dead. I-…”

“What’s wrong? Is Nicky okay?”

“He’s fine.” Agatha sighed and dropped her gaze and Rio pulled her hand up to kiss over her knuckles.

“Then give me five, and-…”

“Rio, my mother arrived late last night.”

“I-…”

“I can’t bring you with me because… it would just be too hard to have you there with her.”

Evanora

Rio swallowed thickly, closing her eyes. She felt Agatha lean up, felt her squeeze over her calf, “I wanted a day for us. I really did.”

Rio believed her. But she didn’t understand why they still couldn’t have one. Why Agatha would let her mother get between them.

“I’m still coming,” Rio said firmly, opening her eyes to look down at a frowning Agatha. “I’ll still spend time with you both. I want to see Nicky. I want to be with you.”

For a second it looked like Agatha might give in. Her blue eyes disappeared behind dark lashes and she pressed her face into Rio’s thigh, giving Rio the opportunity to do as Agatha had done to her in her dream.

Rio let Agatha take a second, heard her breathe in slowly and exhale as she lifted her head again and Rio’s fingers that had been buried in dark hair were pushed away.

And as soon as she saw her face she knew what she was about to say.

“No,” Agatha whispered, moving her hand to reach for Rio’s free one. “No, I’m going alone.”

“Mi amor, I can handle your mom, okay? I can-…”

“I’m telling you no, Rio. I can’t have you there with her. I won’t.”

“Agatha.”

“Please understand this. Please just wait here and I’ll be back later tonight, okay? And we can pick back up where we left off. Just the two of us.”

Rio shook her head and felt the sting of rejection in Agatha’s request. She’d thought they were moving forwards, that Agatha inviting her to her day with Nicky was a positive sign that she wanted her involved.

That maybe there was room for her in her life.

But she didn’t want her to meet Evanora. She didn’t want her to meet the woman who’d birthed her but had not raised her. Her mother, not her mom.

“I want to come with you,” was all she could get out, all she could respond with as Agatha dropped her hold on her hands and reached to pull her down into a soft kiss, like the ones they gave each other when they were leaving for only minutes - only this time it would be a whole day.

“I know, baby. I know.”

Agatha smiled sadly and Rio watched as she pulled away, stood up, and left.

A great, unbearable ache blossomed in her chest now, its creeping tendrils constricted her lungs. It took root in her chest where it would insidiously suckle at her heart for the rest of the day, spreading its poison into her bloodstream, promising the fears that had dissolved with Agatha’s tenderness would come back again.

And Rio tried to breath in slowly, tried to calm it as she heard the front door open and close.

But Agatha was gone. Their day together wasn’t happening. She’d have to wait.

She waited by cleaning, by making their home spotless again. She tidied away the candles she’d laid out yesterday.

She organised the throws and blankets she’d gathered.

She took out the empty glass bottles that had been piling up through the week.

And then, after she’d showered and changed, she found her script and curled up to read through it.

She didn’t get very far. She read and she had to reread. So much so that after an hour of trying she only managed three pages. Reading about a happy family, instead of being with one, wasn’t the best cure for her ills.

Her mind was on that family. On Agatha and Nicky.

Her thoughts were constantly with Agatha, on the pained expression that had been on her face, on the fact that Evanora had forced them apart when she’d not even stepped into the room.

But another hour of failed script reading later and her phone lit up with a text from Agatha.

10:37am
Agatha Harkness: I’m home safe.

10:38am
Rio Vidal: Let me know if you need anything. Tell Nicky I said hey

Rio stared at the WhatsApp interface, watching it in the hopes that Agatha would read her message and respond immediately.

But the ticks went blue and she heard nothing back.

Rio worried all day. She even debated messaging Jen to see if Agatha were okay but she didn’t want Agatha to think she were interfering.

So she sat. She drove herself crazy. She tried to eat something, but stress prevented her from even that.

She did some yoga but even in downward dog her thoughts wouldn’t right themselves.

She showered again.

She eventually got so hungry she ate ice cream directly from the tub. And an apple - to try and get some vitamins.

And then, at around 9pm, her phone rang.

“Agatha? Are you okay? Are you on your way back?”

“No, Rio.” Agatha’s voice was barely a whisper, and Rio’s heart sank. “I have to stay.”

Rio nodded into the phone, feeling the roots that had buried in her chest flare with their earlier promise: this was it, this was all she’d ever get with Agatha. Four days of bliss before reality stole her back.

She bit her lip. She took a second.

“What’s happened? Is she-…?”

“She’s gone. She caught the five o’clock flight home. But…” there was a noise at the end of the line and Rio strained to hear more, to try and figure out what it was.

Then she heard the soft sounds of a door being closed.

“Agatha?”

Silence.

Soft breaths.

Another door.

The sound of fabric against wood.

A sharp intake of breath.

“She cut his hair.”

Rio stopped breathing. Agatha began to cry.

The soft sounds of her tears and ragged breathing made Rio freeze, made her heart constrict and stop in her chest.

She took a second, closed her eyes. The little boy with the big brown eyes and the goofy grin. His long hair that constantly fell in his eyes. The hair that Agatha was always brushing back for him. The hair that he touched when he was nervous just like Rio did.

“Nicky.” Rio said his name plainly, reverently, unable to think of anything else she could say.

“She took him,” Agatha gasped out, clearly trying to get a handle on her reaction. “Jen didn’t know what to do. She… she took him to the nearest salon and had them…”

But she didn’t finish her sentence.

And Rio was no longer frozen. Rio was no longer locked on the image of Nicky. On the boy who had her name and her face.

She’d moved on to Agatha.

“I’m coming.”

“Rio. No.”

“Too late. Absolutely not. There’s no way.” Rio was rambling now, scrambling about the place to find her keys. The fury of a thousand suns burning her up. Burning her fear. Burning through her inability to tell Agatha no that morning; her desire to fix, to hold, to protect flaring in her chest. “That bitch. That witch. I’m coming.”

And she heard Agatha gulp in some air, her breathing now ragged, now urgent, now transforming into broken, shaking sobs.

Rio was blinded by her tears as searched in vein for her keys. She couldn’t think. Couldn’t breathe. And then…

“Rio,” Agatha gasped out, a small squeak of a noise following her desperate plea. “I-… I need you.”

This made Rio stop. It made her clutch at her chest. It made the jagged branches of fear that had sprouted in her and now bore fruit perish - purged from her by Agatha’s entreaty.

“I’m coming,” Rio repeated, breathless as she rushed to find her keys. “Stay on the line. I’ll be there. I’ll-…”

She sourced them, discarded on a shelf by the door.

In her sweats and a worn-in black hoodie, one of those indestructible ones bought for $20 that lasted a lifetime, she left the house she’d called home for the week and threw herself into her car.

She cursed loudly as she tried to get the key in the ignition but her hands were shaking so violently it took three attempts.

“Rio.” Rio didn’t respond to her name, didn’t have the mental capacity to be able to think. Because all she could focus on was getting to Agatha, was soothing Agatha, was-…

“Por favor… por favor, ten mucho cuidado.” Please, please be careful.

Rio shook her head, grunting a little as the car kicked into life. It made a noise that Rio knew meant her little hybrid was doing the work of connecting to her phone to host Agatha’s voice instead.

She dropped her phone from where it had been sandwiched between her ear and her shoulder and it landed apathetically in her lap.

She barely glanced at the dash as she drove off, not bothering to put in Agatha’s address, and only focused on getting out, going down hill until she hit the interstate, and putting her foot on the gas the whole way.

Agatha didn’t say anything but Rio could still hear her catching her breath, calming herself as some whimpers escaped her in what she assumed to be her bedroom. Rio was biting down on her tongue so hard she thought she might rip it out and then…

“Necesito… cariño, necesito oír tu voz.” I need… baby, I need to hear your voice.

Rio shook her head again, swallowing the bile that had been swirling in her throat as she gripped the wheel.

It took a second. It took three more gasping breaths from Agatha. And then she whispered: “No es tu culpa.” It’s not your fault.

Agatha realised a soft cry and Rio was temporarily blinded by her own tears that she quickly wiped away, trying her hardest to look ahead, to not die before she could get to Agatha.

“Mi vida. No es tu culpa.” It’s not your fault.

Agatha whimpered quietly and Rio heard her sniff. She wasn’t holding back anymore and Rio had to wipe at her eyes again.

“Ya voy. Ya voy. Te amo. Ya voy.” I’m coming. I’m coming. I love you. I’m coming.

The soundtrack of Agatha’s tears spurred her on to push the car harder, make it go faster. It whined and groaned as Rio pushed it but she didn’t care. She had to trust it would carry her to Agatha. Rio knew she was being reckless, she knew if the roads weren’t as quiet as they were she’d be putting herself in a lot of danger but she couldn’t bring herself to care.

Because how could she not be speeding? How could she not be breaking every law to get to Agatha as quickly as she could?

Minutes past and Agatha’s breathing began to even out. She sniffed more frequently, clearly now trying to get a hold on herself. And Rio only stared ahead, only kept her foot down, only came up with ways in which she could kill Agatha’s mother.
“¿Por qué no llamaste antes?” Why didn’t you call earlier?

She didn’t mean for it to come out as harshly as it did.

Agatha breathed out, long and slow and loud and Rio could only imagine how close she was pinning the phone to her ear, how cold she would be curled up all by herself.

“Sabía que vendrías. Pero no estaba preparada. Tenía que concentrarme en Nicky y contigo ahí... perdería el control.” I knew you'd come. But I wasn't ready. I had to focus on Nicky and with you there... I'd lose it.
