“How…” Rio began, in English this time, her mind a jumble of questions and fears. “Is he okay?”

“I…,” Agatha followed her into another language, “He…” Agatha’s voice raised up an octave and Rio glanced at the screen. “Jen said he was crying in the chair. That she held his hand and he just cried.”

Rio nodded, her jaw set, her hands choking the wheel.

“Why did she do it?”

Agatha was silent, except for the slow breath she exhaled. “Punishment.”

“For Nicky?”

“For me.”

“Mi amor-…”

“Please,” Agatha said, a little firmer this time, “please concentrate on your driving. I don’t-…”

“I’ll be fine,” Rio said in as soft a voice as she could manage. “Go back to Nicky.”

“Will you stay on the line?”

Rio’s muscles went slack, and she sank two inches where she’d been sitting ramrod straight, the weight of Agatha’s request forcing her to bear the unbearable.

“Yes.”

She heard Agatha move then, heard a door open, soft footsteps, then another door, and the sounds of Agatha climbing back into the bed.

Rio glanced at the screen but didn’t say anything and only wished she’d been more insistent that morning. Only wished Agatha had let her. Only wished she could be on the bed with her, holding her together, telling her over and over again that this wasn’t her fault, that only her mother was to blame.

But she was with Nicky now.

And Rio was on her way to them.

Agatha was curled with Nicky and Rio was five hours away driving to their side.

Rio kept her foot down, her ears straining to see if she could hear anything from either Agatha or Nicky.

But within an hour she could just about make out Agatha’s soft breathing and she knew she’d fallen asleep.

She relaxed a little, safe in the knowledge that Agatha was safe, no longer cognisant of what had happened. Of what had been done to her son.

Of whatever reason she had for thinking Evanora had done it to punish her.

In the space between getting to Agatha and being with Agatha, Rio was able to run it all through in her mind. The late night arrival of Evanora. Was that common? Did she just show up? The decision to take her grandson to have his hair chopped off. The image of her standing over his shoulder whilst Jen - as hardline and unfeeling as she could sometimes appear - held his hand as he cried.

And then there was Agatha, who’d prioritised her son that day. Who was even now protecting him as he slept. Who had initially refused Rio when she offered to come. Who’d refused her again that evening. Who had, on the third time that Rio had said she would come, changed her mind and asked her to instead.

The tree of fear that had died inside her now became little seedlings of hope. Germinating in the rich soils of Agatha’s request for her to come, with her desire to have Rio on the open line for her even as she slept.

And the little hybrid that could charged to its destination, its driver barely concentrating on the roads, thinking instead of the woman she should never have let go alone into the claws of her mother.

She arrived outside Agatha’s gate shortly after one in the morning. She assumed she’d have speeding tickets waiting for her in a week or so but she’d pay any fine necessary under the circumstances. She disconnected her phone from the car. She clutched it tightly in her hand after parking up.

She walked the few hundred yards to the front of Agatha’s house.

She hesitated, unsure how to buzz without breaking the spell of the peaceful, sleeping house.

But someone knew she was there without her even ringing to be let in.

The gate opened for her, and Rio pushed it until she was inside and could see a figure in the doorway.

Jen.

“I didn’t… I didn’t know what to do.”

Rio hung up from Agatha and moved quickly, and before she could understand what she was doing, she’d thrown her arms around Jennifer Kale and let her cry silently into her shoulder.

It took a while for Jen to speak but when she did it was soft, and she was hiccuping slightly.

“He was so upset.” She sniffed and shook her head against her. “But Evanora… she wouldn’t take no for an answer. She’s his grandmother and Agatha… Agatha was driving… I didn’t want to panic her or scare her or…”

“It’s okay,” Rio breathed, staring blindly into the dark house ahead of her. “Nicky knows you wouldn’t-…”

“I wouldn’t. I know I… I love that kid.”

Rio nodded and she pulled away slowly, frowning up into Jen’s tortured expression.

“I shouldn’t have let her come alone.”

“She wouldn’t let me call you. She knew you’d come if you knew. She hasn’t cried or shouted or-…”

Rio sighed and closed her eyes and then something happened that she wasn’t expecting. Jen placed her hands softly against her cheeks. She held her head in place and Rio looked back at her, allowing herself to relax into it.

“I’m glad you came. Go and be with them. They’re in Agatha’s room.”

Rio smiled as Jen dropped her hold on her and she stepped around her into the warm house only to hesitate and turn back.

“Have you not slept?”

“I thought at some point I’d have to open the gate for you so…”

Rio moved back in, took Jen’s arm, kissed her cheek, “Go to sleep.”

She felt sorry for Jen, she really did. She appeared genuinely contrite, genuinely distraught. But she was also furious with her. Fuelled by the knowledge that under no circumstances, if Nicky had been left in her care, would Evanora have been able to lay a hand on him, or touch a hair on his head.

But then as she stared up into Jen’s eyes she registered something that Jen hadn’t said but that was abundantly clear. She was a black woman with no real claim on Nicky other than his mother’s word. And Evanora was a white bitch with bigotry in her heart and hatred in her veins.

There was nothing Jen could have done not without Evanora doing something heinous in return.

She smiled sadly, and in a whisper repeated the words she’d said to Agatha before: “It’s not your fault.” Jen only nodded, only motioned for Rio to go up.

The house was silent as she made her way to Agatha’s room.

The door was ajar and Rio cautiously looked into it, concerned any creak or sudden movement would wake the sleeping bodies in the bed.

But Agatha and Nicky slept on as she moved towards them.

Nicky was curled into his mama, his new haircut hidden under a beanie. And Rio smiled for it. Able to make out in the gloom the word ‘CELTICS’ around the base. It didn’t really match the Spiderman pyjamas that peeked out from where his body was hidden beneath the duvet but Rio thought he looked like the coolest and bravest little boy in the world.

And there there was Agatha.

She was in the clothes she’d left in this morning. Rio’s sweater still on, even as she was curled up below the sheets.

Even in sleep her brow looked a little furrowed and Rio moved instinctively to her side of the bed.

She climbed onto it and placed a hand cautiously on Agatha’s arm, moving so she was curled behind her, but with a few inches distance. Fearful Nicky would wake before his mom, Rio lay like this for a while, not touching Agatha nearly as much as she wanted to, but there all the same.

She fell asleep after what must have been over an hour of lying still, listening to Agatha’s soft breathing, her hand sliding down from Agatha’s arm to rest behind her on the bed when she did.

Sunday

“Rio?”

Rio woke with a frown, and instinctively raised her hand up to rub at her face but found a hand on her wrist stopped her from digging her knuckles into her eyes.

A small hand.

Nicky.

She looked up cautiously, blinking into the light of the morning and seeing Nicky, still in his hat that now sat a little crooked on his head, blinking back down at her.

“Hey, kid.”

He was leaning over Agatha and so Rio sat up slowly, pushing herself to lean on her arm against the bed so Nicky could relax back. She didn’t know what to say. But Nicky was speaking for her, clearly trying to keep his voice soft to avoid waking his mom.

“Did you hear what grandmother did?”

Rio nodded, watching as Nicky’s brow began to furrow and his big brown eyes began to fill with tears. She couldn’t stand it.

She moved quickly from the bed. The sleep gone from her limbs as she moved around to Nicky’s side and held out her hand. “Come here.”

Nicky obliged quickly, sensing the urgency in Rio’s voice, and trusting her enough to leave his sleeping mom alone in the bed. He took her hand and let her help him shuffle until his feet hit the floor. Now on solid ground they both looked to check on Agatha who lay still, and in looking at her properly, Rio saw her hand curled around her phone.

She wanted to stay with her.

But she had something else to do.

She took Nicky through to the en suite and closed the door behind them quietly.

Nicky wasn’t frowning anymore, instead toying with his fingers as he watched Rio with wide, curious eyes.

“What are we doing?”

Rio shushed him gently and began to search the drawers and the cupboards, finding, as she expected, that they were all arranged neatly, which made her mission easier.

When she found what she was looking for she turned to Nicky with a grin and held them up.

“We’re cutting my hair.”

Nicky’s mouth fell open and he stared up at Rio, his fidgeting fingers now frozen in place.

Rio’s delighted smile faded slowly into something softer and she sank to her knees before the little boy who had her face, but his mother’s fear.

“Hey, you know how we look a little the same?”

Nicky nodded slowly.

“Well I quite like looking a little the same as you. So if you wouldn’t mind…” She held out the small pair of scissors, gently handing them handle first. Nicky took them and frowned down at them.

Rio felt her heart this heavily in her chest, her instinct to protect Agatha’s son firing like never before.

“Hey,” she whispered gently, reaching to hold the hand that held the scissors. “Are you-…?”

Her words were lost as Nicky threw himself at her and Rio almost lost her balance for the force of him now hugging into her. She gasped and caught herself just before her head smacked against the counter. But she didn’t care. She’d take a hundred concussions if she could take away Nicky’s pain.

“Hey,” she murmured quietly, swallowing down the lump in her throat when she placed a hand on his upper back and felt nothing but the fabric of his pyjamas where before there would have been the feel of his soft, long hair. Evanora would pay for what she’d done. “It’s okay to be sad.”

Nicky nodded against her, his face pressed firmly into her shoulder. Rio held him to her until Nicky began to pull away. His eyes were wide and his cheeks and nose were flushed and in him Rio saw Agatha and for a moment she was speechless before she whispered, “Can I see it?”

Nicky sniffled quietly, one hand fisting the fabric of Rio’s hoodie, the other that carried the scissors raising up to pull his hat from his head. Beneath it Nicky’s dark hair was trimmed close at the sides, where the tapered edges softly faded into tanned skin.

On top of his head, the hair was a little longer, and Rio could only imagine had initially been styled until Nicky had hidden it beneath his comforting, soft beanie hat. A wayward curve of hair rested against his forehead, defying the forced neatness of the cut that was now shaggy and messy from sleep and the hat, and Rio gently tucked it back and smiled when it remained defiant and fell back into the place she’d pushed it from.

Nicky was still as he waited for Rio’s verdict and Rio took a second to process the change, to choose her words carefully, to not diminish his feelings but to not let on to her own.

“Still very handsome.”

Nicky smiled a little and Rio smiled right back. “So, will you help us look a little the same again? Mellizos?” Twins?

“Mellizos?” Nicky repeated quietly, and Rio felt him twisting the fabric of her hoodie.

“Twins.”

Nicky nodded and repeated quietly, “mellizos”, letting it roll around it his mouth, saying it again, making Rio smile at how seriously he was taking this new word.

“You got it. Now, I’ll show you where to cut, okay?”

Nicky looked up then, his eyes wider than before, his fingers unconsciously tugging at her hoodie.

“You want to?”

“Well, I’ve seen how handsome you look and I’d like to look that handsome too.”

“Girls can’t be handsome.”

Rio gasped dramatically, throwing her hand to her chest, “You think I’m not handsome?”

And Nicky grinned immediately, a dazzling, wide grin that lit up his whole face, and giggled with it. “Very handsome.” He tugged back and forth at her hoodie, holding fast to her still as he giggled.

“Good,” Rio nodded with finality, trying not to grin too much and keep up the faux-seriousness of the endeavour. She took away his hat and lay it on the counter behind her before she held her fingers up to a section of her hair and outlined it with them for Nicky.

“Here. Slowly, and gently, cut between my fingers, okay? Don’t worry about being neat. We can fix it later.”

Nicky nodded, his grin dissolving before Rio’s eyes. He looked serious again as he shuffled closer and released his hold on her. He held the scissors now with two hands. She held her breath as he opened them and held them to her hair.

But he stopped and Rio watched him as he stared at where he was about to make the cut. He looked nervous, his lower lip pulled between his teeth.

“You won’t be sad?”

“No, sweetheart. I won’t be sad.”

Nicky nodded again and stared for a little while longer at the place the small blades framed Rio’s hair. He sucked in a breath. Rio held hers again.

He closed the blades.

The sound of the cut made Rio want to cry. It wasn’t that she was particularly precious about her hair. She’d chopped it all off herself when she was fourteen which had resulted in an unfortunate pixie cut for a few weeks.

She had dyed it so she’d had a matching red streak in it with Alice when she was first in college.

And for roles she’d worn wigs, extensions, allowed hair stylists to do whatever they pleased with it.

But this felt like something other. Something more meaningful than any of those changes. More meaningful than anything she’d ever done.

With her encouragement, and gentle guidance, Nicky continued to cut until a good portion of her hair had fallen to the floor at their feet.

Nicky pulled back, looking horrified at what he’d done but Rio scooped the hair up and smiled as she held it out, forcing herself to believe the words she uttered. “It’ll grow back.”

Nicky nodded and touched the hair laid out in Rio’s hand and smiled at the feel of it. “Its longer than mine was.”

“Well, are you going to grow your hair again?”

“Mmhm. Mama said I could and no one will touch it.”

“Good. Your mama is very smart.”

“Very smart.”

“Well when we’ve finished cutting mine I’m going to start growing it immediately too.”

“Okay,” Nicky said, a shy smile now working its way up his face as he reached to touch the strands now hanging just below Rio’s chin. “We can do it together? Mellizos?”

“I’d like that. And you know what helps hair to grow?”

“Vegetables.”

“No, ice cream and basketball.”

Nicky giggled and shook his head, his hand now back to holding the collar of Rio’s hoodie. “No it doesn’t!”

“It does!”

And Rio grinned as Nicky continued to laugh, pleased her sacrifice had been worth it. She smiled as she gently took the scissors from him and confidently cut across the other side of her hair, realising at the last second that she probably should have used the mirror.

Nicky scooped up the hair that fell down and grinned as he held it up for Rio’s inspection. “There’s so much!”

Rio laughed at this, momentarily overjoyed with the change to the little boy’s demeanour.

But the door behind them opened and suddenly she wasn’t so sure anymore.

Agatha stood there, staring at them both with wide eyes and an unreadable expression.

Nicky turned with a gasp and beamed at his mother, holding up Rio’s hair like a tithe to a king. And Agatha stared down at it. Rio couldn’t get a read on her, couldn’t figure out what she was thinking.

She held the small scissors up and Agatha’s eyes darted over to them. “We need some help with the back.”

She threw what remained of her long hair over her shoulder and smiled hopefully, but secretly held her breath as she waited for Agatha to say something.

She did. Ten seconds after Rio had last spoken.

“Mama?”

“You cut your hair?”

It was an obvious question, and there was clearly an obvious answer.

Rio opened her mouth to give it when Nicky did it for her. “I did, mama.”

“We both did.”

Agatha looked at her son and then looked to Rio, and Rio caught on to how Agatha was feeling suddenly. She scrambled to her feet and tapped at Nicky’s shoulders, “Hey, I’ll get your mama to help with this and you can go wake Jen and get her to make us pancakes, okay?”

Nicky nodded and turned to deliver the hair back into Rio’s hand, smiling at her proudly before he slipped past Agatha and ran off to find Jen.

Rio only looked up again when she heard the bedroom door close and she shrugged a little, one hand holding the scissors, the other a fistful of her chopped hair.

“I didn’t really think I just… wanted him to not feel so alone.”

Agatha closed the distance between them and Rio briefly worried she’d read it wrong and that she was mad but her hands were on her face now, her blue eyes shining with the unshed tears she’d spotted a moment ago. And her heart sank, because mad was always much better than sad.

“You’re such an idiot.”

Rio smiled a little even as she frowned and she bit down on her lip as Agatha continued to stare at her, continued to fight against her own tears. Rio let her sit in it for only a few seconds before she spoke again: “I should have come with you. I should have-…”

Agatha had kissed her. Agatha was kissing her.

And Rio kissed her back.

The scissors fell into the sink behind her and her hand released the evidence of her fury at Evanora.

But Agatha kissed her through all of that. She kissed her until neither of them could breathe and when she pulled away she continued to nudge their lips together, continued to hold Rio’s face.

“You did it again,” Agatha eventually whispered, so low and so soft that Rio - so tired and so angry and so focused on Agatha’s lip against her own - almost didn’t register it.

“Did what?”

“You’re being too sweet too…”

“Let me be here for you. Let me be here for Nicky.”

Agatha shook her head but it wasn’t a refusal. She kissed her again, and then again, and then Rio felt the tears against her cheek that Agatha had been holding in for so long. She tugged Agatha closer into her, fisted the fabric of her stolen sweater, buried her face into her neck, and let Agatha cry.

By the time Agatha was done, felt brave enough to pull back, Rio had decided something: that she’d always be there if Evanora were to come calling. That she’d standing behind Agatha and in front of Nicky.

She raised her sleeve up to gently wipe at Agatha’s face, drying her tears for her as Agatha smiled a little, sniffing shakily. “We’re in a bathroom, you know. There are tissues.”

“What else are my sleeves for?”

Agatha sighed quietly and nudged Rio’s hand away to press her face closer again, her hands moving around to bury in the mess that had been made of her hair.

“Let me try and fix it. Alice will kill you.”

Rio smiled and pulled back to turn over her shoulder and glance at herself in the mirror. “Holy shit it is bad.”

Gentle hands began to turn her around and far from picking up the scissors to actually help Agatha instead snaked her arms around her and pressed against her again, nuzzling into the neck she now had free access to where her hair stopped just by her jaw.

“I can’t believe you let my seven year old son cut your hair.”

“He was upset.”

Agatha sighed heavily and Rio shivered for the breath travelling down her neck. “Did she apologise?”

“No.”

Rio moved her jaw, poking her tongue into her cheek, watching Agatha nuzzle closer through the mirror. She took a slow breath in and squeezed over the hands that had hidden themselves in the front pocket of her hoodie.

“Why did she do it?”

Agatha exhaled again, slow, soft. And through the mirror she now locked eyes with Rio, her sea blue irises shiny through the tears. “She’s always hated his hair. Always said it was too girly, not becoming of a ‘young gentleman’. But I’ve never left her alone with him, never let her… it’s always just been words, pointed comments. And Ralph always agreed. But never cared enough to do anything so I… I never thought she’d do it.”

Rio nodded quietly and lifted her hand back to hold Agatha’s head, “You couldn’t have prevented it.” Though her words were hypocritical. Because she believed she could have and so she understood some of Agatha’s guilt but she couldn’t let her sit in it. At least not alone.

“If I’d been here, Rio… If I…” but she stopped herself, sighed heavily and placed a kiss to Rio’s shoulder. Rio closed her eyes and took in a deep breath, letting Agatha kiss along to her neck, against her jaw, to her cheek. “Let me fix your hair.”

Rio nodded and opened her eyes again, feeling the loss of Agatha already as she pulled back and with gentle fingers brushed through Rio’s hair.

It never felt intimate, getting her hair cut, but then Rio had never had her hair cut by someone she loved before. And Agatha was silent as she worked, gently brushing through her hair with every trim of the tiny scissors. She watched her through the mirror as she turned her head this way and that to judge length, to adjust where needed and leave what was already too far gone.

By the time Agatha was finished Rio Vidal stared back at herself in the mirror, her dark hair smoothed down by gentle hands, the majority of it straighter than it had been, skimming the line of her jaw.

It had looked better. But it could definitely look worse.

But Agatha was taking advantage again of the easy access to Rio’s skin now and had turned her from her own reflection to nudge her chin up and kiss along the column of her throat.

Rio grinned at her eagerness, her eyes closed as she released a soft chuckle and Agatha captured the vibrations on her lips.

She pulled away just as Rio was beginning to worry she wouldn’t stop and she wouldn’t have the self-control to make her. And when she looked at Agatha again she looked calm, calmer than she had been before, almost as calm as she had been the previous night.

“Thank you. For coming, for being so good with Nicky, for… thank you.”

Rio smiled as she lifted her hands to cradle Agatha’s face, “Mi corazón estaba aquí. ¿Cómo no iba a venir?” My heart was here. How could I not come?

Agatha turned her head into Rio’s palm and kissed her there. Closing her eyes she remained still until she eventually whispered, “Will you stay today? Stay the night? We can take Nicky to school in the morning and drive back up together. Have our last night just us.”

Rio nodded and watched as Agatha turned to her again, and found that she had grabbed the fabric of her hoodie in the exact spot her son had. She melted into her and closed the distance to kiss her.

“I’d like that. I did, however, tell Nicky the best way to make hair grow was ice cream and basketball.”

Agatha laughed and the sound was like manna to her ears. “So I think that might be most of my day accounted for.”

“I’ll allow it.”

“Oh you will?”

Agatha rolled her eyes and Rio grinned as she delicately kissed her cheek. “We need to talk about you stealing my clothes, by the way.”

She slipped from her place at the counter and briefly tugged at the sweater Agatha wore.

“I have no idea what you’re talking about.”

“Oh yeah?” Rio paused halfway out the door. “Then why is your suitcase still unopened and I have no clean clothes left?”

Agatha lunged for her side and Rio yelped as she hurried back into the bedroom only to be tackled as she reached the next door and pressed, laughing and squirming, into it. Agatha’s hands were flying over her torso, tickling and teasing as Rio tried to push her away, tried to free herself from the torment.

It lasted until Agatha stopped, until they were both breathless and beaming. Until Agatha’s teasing turned to earnestness and she whispered: “I like to feel close.”

Rio’s smile faded to nothing and she arched her back as Agatha wrapped around her and Rio secured her arms around her neck. “Then take whatever you want.”

Agatha’s cautious blue eyes flashed up from where they’d been focused in around Rio’s nose and Rio smiled at the sight. She felt her racing heart slow to a softer rhythm, unbeknownst to her now in tandem with Agatha’s, both beating for the other, forever now moored together by something beyond comprehension and above this mortal plane.

“This hoodie looks nice,” Agatha said after a few moments silence between them, now tugging at the strings. Rio laughed and rolled her eyes, pushing Agatha backwards with her body but keeping her arms around her.

“It’s got your tears and snot all over it.”

“Then maybe I’ll let you keep it. I’m sure you’ll treasure it.”

Rio hummed as she kissed Agatha one last time before pulling away. “Come on. Pancakes.”

As they left together Agatha entwined their fingers, stealing Rio’s right hand to mix with her left. And the walk through the quiet house this time couldn’t have been more different. When she’d rocked up that morning she’d been boiling over with fury, and now the anger was simply simmering, cooled down by Agatha’s presence and Nicky’s smiles.

When they arrived in the kitchen Agatha squeezed her hand before dropping it and made a beeline for her son, who was swinging his legs from the stool at the kitchen island. Rio laughed as Nicky yelped and giggled as he received the penance for being apart from his mom for more than five minutes: many, many kisses.

“Jesus fucking Christ.”

Oh.

She’d almost forgotten the haircut.

Rio looked around and smiled in amusement at Jen’s shocked expression. “What the fuck-?!”

“Jen.” Agatha chastised as she moved away from Nicky and hurried to the pan to try and salvage whatever batter monstrosity Jen was currently burning. “Language.”

“Oh no this deserves language, Agatha. Have you seen her fucking hair?”

Rio scoffed as she took the stool beside Nicky. “Nicky says I look handsome.”

“Yes,” Nicky agreed, but his cheeks were pink and as Rio turned to him he looked shy. “Mirellos.”

“Mellizos,” Rio corrected as she nudged his shoulder gently. “We’re growing our hair out together.” Nicky nodded and looked serious as he whispered the word again to commit it to memory. “Mellizos. Mellizos. Mellizos.”

“Okaaaaaay, have you told Alice? You’re back to set on Wednesday.”

“Leave her alone, Jen.”

Rio smiled and slid back off the stool to go and pour two mugs of coffee, narrowly avoiding Jen’s outstretched hand as she went to touch her hair. “Hey. Leave it. No touching.”

She huffed. “You should call Alice.”

“I’ll call her later.”

She grabbed the coffee pot and felt a hand on her head at the same time she heard a small voice suddenly become a large one: “Hey! Don’t touch my mellizos!”

Rio almost dropped the pot in surprise and the kitchen stopped as three pairs of eyes turned to look at the little boy now standing on the highest footrest of his stool, his hands placed on the island as he frowned at the person who had touched his melliza.

“Honey,” Agatha cooed gently, moving the pan off the heat as she turned properly to Nicky. “She’s okay, baby.”

Rio swallowed and replaced the pot on the heating pad to move around Jen and sink back into her stool beside Nicky. He’d sat back now and was so red the tips of his ears were aflame, his doe eyes still wide and now teary as he looked to Agatha.

And Agatha pulled him into a tight hug as Rio reached to rub his back.

“I’m sorry, Rio.” Jen looked mortified, thunderstruck as she watched Nicky bury his face against Agatha. “And Nicky I’m sorry too. If you ask someone not to touch you… they shouldn’t touch you.”

Jen turned away then to hide the tears forming in her eyes and she finished what Rio had started and poured two mugs of coffee. Rio kept her eyes on Nicky and caught Agatha’s gaze over his shoulder and smiled sadly at her, catching the soft furrow in her brow.

“Here,” Jen said quietly as she placed the mug before her. As she pulled away Rio reached up to catch her wrist and held her in place, “Hey, will you call Alice? I should show her and… I think you need her today.”

Jen understood the peace offering and smiled as she slid Agatha’s mug across the counter as the mother and son duo broke apart. Nicky was still a little flushed and was staring at the counter but Rio reached to punch his shoulder and whispered, “Gracias, mellizo.”

She caught his eye then and Nicky smiled his little shy smile and the kitchen seemed to relax around them again. Jen began to make pains to gain some points and even offered to play basketball after breakfast.

Rio could only watch and smile as she ate the blueberry pancakes that were apparently Agatha’s specialty and Nicky’s favourites.

By the time she was on her forth - blind rage and driving through the night awakens an insatiable hunger in a person - Alice had arrived to the tune of: “Holy shit.”

Rio bundled her into a room to explain the situation and after a lot of language that Agatha wouldn’t have appreciated around her son, they eventually came back to the kitchen. Agatha and Jen had been talking quietly by the stove and Nicky had rushed off to find his jacket and sneakers.

“Everything okay?”

Agatha cleared her throat and turned to pick up her mug. “Fine. Alice? Language under control?”

“I mean, fucking hell, I guess so.”

Agatha rolled her eyes but relaxed slightly as Rio moved over to kiss her cheek, careful not to linger incase Nicky appeared again.

“Mellizos?”

“Cute, no?”

“What does it mean?”

Three voices together answered Jen’s question: “Twins.”

“Oh you are so corny, Rio Vidal.”

Rio rolled her eyes and ran her hand through her new hair as Agatha raised her hand to do the same and an excited little boy appeared in the room. “Mama!”

Agatha could hear the accusation in Nicky’s voice so turned to him with a smile, “It’s okay, baby. Rio said I could.”

Nicky relaxed his shoulders and nodded, looking to Rio for a second and waiting for her to confirm with a nod before he held up a basketball. “Can we play?”

“Sure, kid. Jen? Let’s go.”

Alice snorted only to be met with a scowl from Jennifer which made her shut up immediately. “Oh. You’re serious?”

“Oh yes.” Rio grinned as she dragged Jen out to the little basketball court outside, allowing Nicky to dictate how the game would go. It didn’t take long for everyone, including the watchful Agatha and Alice who had joined them, to decide that perhaps it was best that Jen sat out.

Nicky tottered over to her when she announced she was done as Rio went to fish the ball from the pool she’d managed to toss it into. He held out his hand to her, shyly wished her a “good game”, and within minutes was being run ragged by Rio and her expert drills and layups.

“Twins,” Jen muttered to Agatha as the three on the sidelines huddled together for warmth, Agatha a little ways away from the girlfriends pressed close. Alice had offered her her arm but Agatha had muttered something about, “Not being a touchy person.”

“It’s still weird,” Alice said softly, “She could easily be his mom.”

“Couple signatures and a court appearance and-…”

“Don’t,” Agatha whispered, tearing her eyes away from where Rio was teaching Nicky how to bounce the ball between his legs. “Stop it, Jen.”

But Alice was still stuck on the fact that her best friend had clearly had a secret baby, though she still couldn’t figure out when in their lives she’d been apart from her for nine months. “It’s like you took Rio, sprinkled a little of you, then added in more Rio and then-…”

“Can we stop?”

“It is crazy, Agatha. And… pretty romantic that she chopped all her hair off for him.”

Agatha blushed faintly, avoiding Jen’s knowing gaze and looked back over just as Nicky was charging towards her to celebrate his freshly learnt skill. Rio watched from the centre of the court, the basketball tucked under her arm, her nose and cheeks pink from the chill and exertion.

She watched as Agatha dropped down to hug her son, saw her whisper in his ear, and the turn as he pelted back to her and she was bestowed with a hug so tight she couldn’t breathe. She dropped the ball and hugged him back, and was about to let go when another pair of arms encircled them and a cool nose pressed into her cheek.

“You’re frozen.”

“Says you.”

“Mama, you are squashing me.”

Rio barked a laugh as Agatha pulled back and Nicky smiled up at her, still clinging to Rio but reaching for Agatha too.

“Okay. Inside. Warm showers. Then popcorn and a movie. It’s too cold for basketball.”

“It’s never too cold for basketball,” Rio grumbled as she happily followed Nicky back into the house, stealing Alice’s mug of half-drunk coffee as she went.

Rio was the last down from her shower. Mostly because Agatha had snuck into the bathroom she’d commandeered and had decided a good thing to do was to warm Rio up by making out with her up against the glass partition before she could even get into the shower.

But she thankfully didn’t push her luck. She left Rio suddenly hot and bothered and a welcoming warm shower now turned into a necessary cold one.

Agatha had left Rio some clothes outside the door just as she had the first time Rio had stayed over and Rio changed into them and breathed Agatha in through the collar of her sweater.

Perhaps sharing clothes wasn’t the worst idea.

Rio ventured down, last to arrive to the gathering of people in the den. Alice and Jen were curled up on one side of the large couch and Nicky was curled with his mom. Which left Rio to sit in between alone.

That was until a small hand reached out to take her own and Rio turned to see Nicky watching her cautiously, unsure what her reaction would be. And Agatha beyond him, eyes on the screen, remote in her hand, was smiling at what had just happened - Nicky having asked before Rio had arrived if Agatha thought Rio might hold his hand.

“Hey,” Jen stole Rio’s attention and threw her over a blanket. Rio caught it before it smacked her in the face and covered her lap with it as she relaxed back, already feeling the pang of being so close to Agatha and unable to touch her.

Nicky’s hold helped though.

Agatha settled on Jurassic Park without asking for anyone’s opinions on the matter. Something somewhere was pressed and the lights were dimmed and before Isla Nublar was even introduced on screen Rio’s head lolled to the side and she fell asleep.

She woke about an hour or so later, surprisingly warm, surprisingly without a sharp pain in her neck. A hand was by her jaw, the warmth of it tickling her skin but not touching her as deft fingers toyed with the edges of her chopped hair.

Agatha had moved over whilst Rio had been asleep. She’d somehow moved her so her head could be against her shoulder, so they could share the blanket, so she could keep Rio warm and comfortable as she slept.

As Rio shifted, Agatha’s light touch moved to her cheek, and Rio smiled as she moved a hand across to Agatha’s thigh and squeezed it gently, thanking her for moving.

She opened her eyes and she sat up more and looked over to see Jen similarly curled into Alice , similarly fast asleep. To Agatha’s right now Nicky sat under her arm, staring straight ahead and completely absorbed in the movie.

And beside her Agatha turned to look at her and whispered close to her ear, “You’re so warm.”

Rio smiled and rubbed at her eyes as she settled back into the couch more, now stretching her legs out in front of her. “It’s warm in here.”

She closed her eyes again and soon found that Agatha was moving beside her, stretching her own legs out to press beside Rio’s and the hand that had once toyed with her hair was now below the blanket, holding Rio’s as it held her thigh.

Rio fell asleep not long after that. Then Alice did. Then Agatha. Until finally Nicky was the last one standing, too enraptured in his raptors to do a silly thing like fall asleep.

But the movie ended and sleep won in the end too. He curled more into his mom who in her sleep curled more into him. And Rio, feeling the tug of Agatha even in her subconscious, pressed in behind her.

“Rio.”

Rio groaned quietly and pressed in where it was warm and soft and smelt nice.

But Alice’s voice was closer now, a hand on her side more insistent. “Babe. Wake up. You won’t sleep tonight. It’s still early.”

Rio huffed a heavy breath against Agatha’s neck that caused her to stir too and in moving she dislodged Rio and made her roll over to shoot daggers at Alice who simply smiled at her and made to touch her hair.

“No!”

Nicholas River Harkness, his namesake’s biggest defender, suddenly reached a hand to slap Alice away. Alice blinked, having not been privy to the earlier conversation, but dropped her hand as Rio grinned crookedly up at her.

“Thank you, Nicky.”

“You gotta sort that hair. Like immediately. You look insane.”

A huff beside her told her that Agatha was awake now and was turning over to throw her arms around Rio, leaning up onto her elbow to scowl at Alice. “Would you just back off.”

“Jesus, Agatha. She’s shooting in like two days.”

“Three,” Rio corrected with a yawn.

“Whatever. It’s important it’s fixed.”

“Someone will do it on Wednesday. I happen to think Nicky did a good job.”

Alice scoffed and Rio cracked an eye open and shot a grin in Nicky’s direction as he leant around his mom to get a look at her. Her smile widened and below the blanket she felt a warm hand slide up to her side.

She knew it was going to happen before it did.

She yelped and barked a laugh as practised fingers pressed in the soft spot between her ribs and her hip. And then something happened that Rio hadn’t experienced since she was a teenager with her cousins.

A pile on. A three person heap. Agatha was attacking her sides and Nicky was joining the fray because he was his mother’s son and Rio’s biggest fan.

Alice rolled her eyes but smiled as she moved away and Jen in the corner woke groggily to the sounds of squeals and shouts and huffed as she pulled the blanket over her head.

But Agatha let up so Rio could breathe. And she lay half on her, her grinning face against her cheek. Nicky clambered over and dropped his head to Rio’s other shoulder and Rio had never felt warmer or more love. She wrapped her arms around her love and her twin and sighed happily, turning to kiss one then the other.

Somewhere at the edge of the room she heard Alice muscle Jen to get up and leave them and Rio had never been more grateful to her friend.

She could hear Nicky’s soft breaths, feel Agatha’s gentle fingers lightly brushing over her hip, and she wondered if this is what having your own family felt like. One you chose, rather than were born into.

Rio had been lucky with the former, Alice was like a sister to her and as such was a good example of the latter, but this, Agatha and her son curled around her, was different.

“Nicky,” Agatha uttered quietly after a few minutes of them all absorbed in each other, “do you have everything for school?”

“Yes, Mama.”

“Okay, baby.” Agatha pushed up slowly and brushed her son’s cheek, her fingers reaching instinctually for the hair that wasn’t there anymore. “Go ask Jen and she’ll make you a snack, okay? Some fruit too though, please.”

Rio felt Nicky nod against her shoulder and then he pushed up and hurried from the room. Agatha’s hand moved from Rio’s hip to her sternum as she turned back to her with a soft smile, “What were you saying the other day about quick triggers?”

“Being ticklish and,” Rio glanced to make sure no one was around, “coming quickly are not the same things.”

Agatha hummed as she leant in to kiss her and withdrew her hand from below her sweater to run through her hair, using the motion to then run her fingers along her jaw. “Alice is right. It does look awful.”

“Thank you. That’s so kind of you to say.”

Agatha laughed and Rio continued to smile, grunting a little when Agatha moved to lay over her fully. She sighed as Agatha began to trace the line of her jaw again and in a softer voice than before she said: “Why do you think your mom was punishing you?”

Agatha’s lips parted and closed and Rio for a second could almost see the walls building up again. “I don’t want to talk about my mother.”

Rio gasped when Agatha ducked down to press a soft kiss to her throat, nuzzling in for a second before nipping teasingly at her and making Rio laugh. “Mi amor. We can’t. Don’t tease me.”

Agatha huffed quietly and flopped down properly over Rio, making her grunt again as she held her tight. “You’re still okay to stay tonight?”

“Of course I am.”

“Okay.”

Rio nodded and tugged Agatha’s sweater up to feel her skin.

“I still can’t believe you did it.”

“Mm?”

“Your hair.”

Agatha lifted up again to look down at her and moved her hand to tug at a strand of her freshly trimmed hair. “It’s incredibly sexy.”

“Didn’t you just say it was awful?”

Agatha grinned, “That too. But sleep in my room tonight?”

“Oh I thought there were rules about that in this house.”

“No more rules. Only you, under me, okay?”

Rio huffed playfully, “I suppose if I-…” but Agatha was nipping at her jaw, her hand snaking its way up to her breast when:

“Holy shit!”

Agatha practically jumped off of her and Rio scrambled to sit up, bright red as she saw Alice closing the door quickly behind her. “You’re like teenagers. Rio, Nicky wants to know if you would like the berries on your ice cream or beside your ice cream. I told him I’d best come check so he can protect his ice cream from Jen. Thank god I did.”

Rio laughed and rubbed the back of her neck as Agatha huffed, “That’s hardly the healthy snack I was going for.”

“Berries are healthy,” Alice shrugged, now clear of any fondling she opened the door for them. Rio smiled at her friend and made to follow Agatha out but Alice had stopped her, was reaching for her hair as Rio batted her lightly away.

“Can I call someone? Get them to stop by?”

“No, Alice. I want Nicky to know that-…”

Alice sighed and glanced to make sure they were alone before she said in a lower voice, “Have you discussed what happens after Tuesday?”

“No. I mean, no. Not really.”

“Is she leaving him?”

“Alice, I said no. I don’t know.”

“Are you not asking because you’re frightened of the answer or are you not asking because it’s easier to just live with the excitement of it all?”

“You think this is exciting for me?”

“No. I didn’t mean it like that. I just meant-…” but Alice sighed, stepped in and took Rio’s hand, “Look, Jen thinks she’s making moves in the background but is frightened to say anything in case-…”

“Hey,” Jen appeared in the room that led to the den and raised her brows at the two conspiring friends, “Everything okay? We have some melting ice cream for you, Rio. You should be honoured. I’ve looked after him all week and he didn’t ask for me to have a bowl. Just you.”

Rio smiled a little in Jen’s direction, saw her faux-cheeriness disappear briefly as she caught her eye but chose not to pry. This was a conversation she wanted to have with Agatha. And only Agatha.

“I’m coming.”

She took Alice by the arm and pulled her with her into the kitchen and saw that Nicky was jealously holding a bowl of ice cream under his arm whilst he ate from another. Agatha was dipping a spoon into the guarded bowl. Apparently there were exceptions to Nicky’s protection.

“Don’t tell me you’re eating my ice cream.”

“You snooze you lose.”

Nicky giggled and Agatha scoffed, now brandishing her spoon at Rio. “It’s my ice cream. I bought it.”

“I believe Nicky got it for me. Isn’t that right, kid?”

Nicky raised his brows and looked between Rio and Agatha and deliberated for a second before he said, “Maybe you can share. Mama likes pecan anyway.”

With a laugh Rio stole Agatha’s spoon and took the bowl that Nicky pulled back from, only to be grabbed back by Agatha. “Hey. Sharing.”

“Jesus,” Jen muttered as she eyed the two of them, Rio now squished between Nicky and Agatha at the counter, all three looking smug in their own way.

“How’re the lines coming along?” Alice asked pointedly, her dark gaze on the dark strands of Rio’s choppy hair cut. “All memorised?”

“Sure.”

“You’re a bad liar, Rio.”

“I’m a good actress, though. We’ll learn them tomorrow.”

“We?” Alice quoted back, glancing briefly at Agatha who was looking at Jen.

“Agatha said she’d-,” but an elbow to the ribs made her shut up as she passed the spoon to Agatha.

They weren’t supposed to be away together. Nicky didn’t know.

Rio cleared her throat, “Agatha said I could call her and we can run through them.”

Alice was still looking between Agatha and Jen, suspicious of what had just passed silently between them. Rio didn’t notice though, too intent on eating her ice cream, focused on the hand now holding her hip, on the brush of Agatha’s thumb against her skin.

After that the day went by slowly, like all good days should but rarely do.

Rio focused her attention on Nicky and Alice helped out where she could, being as big a basketball fan as both the other two were. They watched YouTube videos of old games, and both Rio and Alice took their turn teaching him techniques on the court that neither of them had really mastered but were enthusiastic about anyway.

They were occasionally called in by Agatha to make sure they were warm enough, that they’d had enough water and food, that Alice wasn’t freaking Nicky out by staring at her friend’s face reflected almost exactly on the little boy.

And during this time Agatha and Jen mostly stayed inside, doing what, or speaking about what, Rio could only guess.

All that mattered was that Nicky was now laughing more than he was frowning. That he joined Rio in calling Alice “pequeña Alice” and that the last thing on his mind was the loss of his hair.

Though Alice had playfully grabbed Rio after what she’d considered to be an illegal move on the court and Nicky and charged at her to ensure Rio’s hair wasn’t touched. Alice had quickly backed off and Rio had dropped down to pinky promise with Nicky that she was okay but how pleased she was that he was was looking out for her.

Nicky’s smile didn’t leave his face after that.

By the time dinner was served - early, so Nicky could eat with them and go to bed at a reasonable hour - Rio was on her last legs. Which is why Agatha’s hand on her thigh below the table was incredibly welcome.

Alice had decided to stay the night to be there when Nicky was home from school on Monday so they could play more ball and Agatha had even thanked her for it, suddenly a little more warm with Alice when she saw that Nicky was warmer with her too.

After dinner Rio and Alice did the dishes whilst Agatha helped Nicky with the things he’d need for school and Jen hovered nearby drinking red wine.

“So,” she said abruptly, clearly not very interested in the current topic of conversation - how short was too short for Rio’s hair.

“She told you about his name?”

Rio dropped the cutlery she was holding with a clatter.

“Whose name?”

“Nicky,” Rio said with a faint blush, casting her gaze over to Jen before she looked round at Alice. “His middle name is River.”

“That’s,” Alice began with a frown, now also looking to Jen, “a weird coincidence.”

“Apparently Agatha is a hopeless romantic, or maybe just a fucking loser.”

“Hey,” Rio snapped even as she blushed a little deeper and turned away from Jen just as Agatha arrived back in the room and Alice was still staring at her girlfriend with deep confusion across her face. “Agatha, did you name Nicky after Rio?”

Rio had her back to the room as she continued to load the dishwasher so didn’t get to experience the shock on Agatha’s face. But she heard the softness of her voice.

“Yes.”

“But he’s what? Seven? That doesn’t make any sense.”

Rio cleared her throat and was straightening up from where she had put the last of the dishes away when she heard the padding of soft footsteps and Nicky had entered room again. “All clean,” he announced quietly to Agatha, showing off his freshly brushed teeth.

“Good boy. Now say goodnight. And I’ll come and read with you in a sec.”

Nicky did as he was told and gave everybody quick hugs but Rio couldn’t help but feel he’d made theirs just that little bit longer. “Buenas noches, mi mellizo.”

“Buenas noches, mellizo.”

She smiled as she let him rush back, shot her a grin over his shoulder, and left the room.

“Again with the favouritism!”

Rio laughed and snatched up her wine from the side, comfortable enough now in Agatha’s home to jump onto the counter and swing her legs. “Learn to shoot a three-pointer and he might like you better.”

“I’ve kept him alive for a week. That’s worth more than being able to play a game.”

Alice gasped as Agatha moved to stand back between Rio’s legs. “It’s not a game, baby. It’s a lifestyle.”

Jen rolled her eyes as Alice kissed her cheek and rubbed her back. “You’re my favourite, if that counts.” As Jen grumbled Rio draped her arm around Agatha and kissed her temple.

“You’re my favourite. Nicky a close second.”

Agatha smiled and turned her head to press into Rio’s cheek as she raised up from having kissed her shoulder. “Sap.”

“So, Agatha? The name?”

Agatha hummed quietly as she turned from Rio to look at Alice. “What about it?”

“It’s Rio’s name?”

“Yes, I said that.”

“But-…”

Rio squeezed Agatha’s shoulder as she leant up, “Let her go and tuck Nicky in and we can talk about it, Alice.”

But before Agatha could pull away, Rio had made her turn her head and given her the kiss necessary before either of them left the room. Just because she could now. Just because she hoped their vacation habit would become a real life ritual.

Agatha smiled knowingly as she disappeared from the room.

“You,” Rio said pointedly, motioning to Alice with her red wine, “don’t tease her about this. She’s had a bad couple days.”

Alice made a noise of protest. “Who said I was teasing?!”

“I know you, Alice Gulliver-Wu. Be nice.”

Alice huffed and Rio was grateful when she heard Jen mumble to her, “She’s right. Go easy on the teasing later, okay?”

They all moved through to the more formal living room where Alice started a small fire in the hearth and Rio curled up in an armchair only to be told by Jen that was where Ralph usually sat. She grimaced and moved to the couch.

Agatha arrived after another ten minutes and went to sit back behind Rio. It wasn’t even a question that this would happen, more a reflex at this point. And Rio had simply sat forwards when Agatha moved towards her to allow it to happen.

“So,” Alice began before anyone else could determine the topic. “River?”

“Yes.”

Rio smiled a little and felt a hand sneak in beneath her sweater to touch her warm stomach.

“How did you know Rio seven years ago? She’d barely started out.”

“Chicago,” Agatha said simply, briefly leaning away to pick up the wine that had been left for her on the coffee table. “The improv show.”

Alice frowned and Agatha raised her brows as Rio turned her head. “I never told her.”

“Told me what?”

“Agatha met Rio at your little show,” Jen said gently, her gaze flitting between Agatha’s surprised face and Alice’s one. “They had a moment, apparently. I was only told about it a couple weeks ago.”

“A moment?”

Agatha shifted against Rio so Rio answered for her, “I was drunk. I flirted. We almost kissed but we were interrupted and… that’s that.”

“Something like that.”

“That’s…”

“Romantic as hell?”

Rio hummed quietly and Jen smiled at the two of them, “Who knew you had it in you, Harkness?”

“I won’t be disparaged.”

“Está bien, mi amor.”

That maybe, and here is where Rio’s hopeful heart skipped to, she she was already making moves to.

And Alice, ever the fixer for Rio, tried again. “You’re divorcing him?”

But Agatha had clearly said all she wanted to on the matter. She ducked down to kiss Rio’s shoulder and then from her position against it, her chin resting there, she looked up and said: “Ever thought about a career in journalism, Alice?”

Rio smiled a little and sighed out, feeling Agatha’s thumb now start to rub soft circles against her skin, a private act of reassurance.

“You two could be so good together. I’m talking career-wise. Imagine, Jen. Imagine what we could do. Two Oscars between them. It would be stratospheric.”

“Agatha already is stratospheric. She doesn’t need Rio.”

Rio scoffed and felt Agatha pull back to sip her wine. And as Alice and Jen fell to bickering about what Rio could or couldn’t do for Agatha’s career Rio settled more against Agatha, stretched her neck as Agatha leant in to kiss her there, hummed quietly as Agatha pressed in.

“What is it?”

“It’s really just yours?”

“Ralph and I have slept separately for years.”

Agatha had flipped their positions now and she was the one to lead Rio into the room, confidently tugging Rio to the bed. “You’ll have to wear pyjamas. In case Nicky gets up. But he seemed pretty-…”

Agatha turned because Rio had stopped moving halfway into the room, her eyes sweeping the space as if to spot anything that might indicate Ralph’s taste, Ralph’s things, Ralph’s presence.

“Oh? This old awful thing. Is it the style or the thought behind it?”

“Both.”

“Does she do it often?”

“Mm?”

“Just appear?”

Agatha didn’t need to ask who Rio was referring to. She shifted back and looked up at Rio, frowning a little as she did. “No. She usually just comes for the holidays.”

Rio hummed quietly and brushed a strand of brunette hair back from Agatha’s eyes. “Why do you think she was punishing you?”

Rio moved her hand back around to brush through Agatha’s hair again, taking a second to process before she spoke, the strain in her heart clear in her voice. “You’re not beholden to your mother, Agatha. Or your husband.”

“I want to be beholden to you.”

Rio’s fingers froze, halfway down the length of Agatha’s long hair. She hesitated, felt her breath be taken away, her waist grabbed, her heart sing.

“Agatha.”

“Will you promise me something?”

“Anything.”

“If…” Agatha’s gaze fell, it changed, it softened until it was gone. She closed her eyes, took a breath. “If this doesn’t work out between us, I’m not asking you to still see Nicky but if-…”

“Agatha.”

“No, please.” Rio moved her hand to Agatha’s cheek and felt the weight of her words settle in her stomach, making her feel suddenly cold despite the warmth of the bed. “Would you still be as you are with him? Still be-…?”

“Mi amor, why are you asking that? Do you want to break it off?”

“No. No that’s the last thing I want.”

Rio nodded, frowning as Agatha released her death-grip on her waist and instead moved to mirror the position of her own hand on Agatha’s face. “Then why are you asking?”

“If I can’t have you I want Nicky to have you. I can’t be the reason he-…

“Agatha.”

“I’m just saying. I’m-…”

Rio pulled away, extricating herself with difficulty from Agatha’s clutches. The reaction was immediate, the panic severe. Agatha tried to cling on and Rio, who’d been trying to lift up and hover to the side, was now tugged over her, clung to, tethered.

“Agatha.”

“Don’t pull away.”

“I wasn’t.”

Rio sighed quietly, feeling the fingers still clutching at the silk of her borrowed pyjamas relax even a little as she carefully eased her body weight fully into Agatha.

“I want you to leave Ralph. I want to sleep with you every night. I want you to be mine and be proud to be mine. And I want you to understand that I would never do anything to upset Nicky. Even if…” and here she faltered, herein lay her fear. “Even if this doesn’t work.”

Beneath her Agatha felt stiff, her body rejecting whatever comfort Rio was trying to give. But her hold loosened until her hands became soft again, until they buried in the uneven strands of dark hair about Rio’s head. Her lips were soft too as Rio kissed them, her tears soft as they fell, one by one, travelling down her cheeks onto what should be her marital bed but was instead the bed she slept in alone - unless Nicky was with her - or like now, where her heart in another form lay above her, providing reassurance but not respite from her fears.

“Deberías dormir. Descansa sobre mí y te abrazaré.” You should sleep. Rest against me and I’ll hold you.

Rio wiped away Agatha’s tears, kissed over the tracks, and rolled back over pulling Agatha with her until she could tuck her under her chin and begin the nightly ritual of brushing her fingers through her hair again.

Even as Agatha settled, even as her hold tightened and then began to relax as sleep began to take hold, Rio couldn’t relax her mind. In the dim she stared ahead of her, seeing on the nightstand the little bottle of pills she recognised from Italy. The bottle she hadn’t seen since Italy. It was evidence that in the nights they’d spent together since Agatha didn’t need her medication to sleep.

She allowed the little bottle to calm her racing mind. Agatha felt safe with her. Safe enough to leave her sleeping pills behind knowing she’d be okay to sleep with Rio there. A person in shark-infested waters wouldn’t break their raft. Agatha wouldn’t break it off. Surely, Agatha wouldn’t break it off.

Her fingers walked up the bed as Agatha’s breathing evened out against her, and below Agatha’s pillow she found the soft fabric she’d expected might be there. Her stolen shirt, now constantly kept close in every bed Agatha slept in.

Apart from their bed in Berkeley. Because Rio would be there instead.

She fingered the familiar fabric for a while and all she could think, all she could focus on was: Agatha loved her. She had to.

Rio fell asleep with her hand on her shirt and her arm around the woman who’d stolen it. In her sleep she dreamt again of Agatha, of the two of them curled together, only this time Nicky was there too: his hair was long once more, Agatha’s fingers dancing through it, they looked peaceful together, warm in Rio’s embrace.

Monday

“I gotta get up.”

“Mm?”

“Go back to sleep.”

“Mm.”

Rio yawned and huffed but the woman in her arms was suddenly gone and Rio curled in on herself to recapture the warmth.

The next time she woke she did so because she could feel eyes on her. She groaned quietly, rubbed at her eyes, and then blinked until the face came into view. Her face.

“Morning, kid.”

“Mama said I could come get you.”

“Mm’kay.”

Nicky grinned as Rio sat up slowly, continuing to frown as she stretched. “Did you sleep okay?”

She looked back around to Nicky and saw that he was still grinning - grinning so widely in fact that it made Rio grin right back at him.

“What?”

“Your hair!”

“My?” Rio reached to touch it and raised her brows, “What’s up with it, mellizo?”

“It looks-…” and Nicky giggled before he could tell Rio exactly how it looked. Rio hummed suspiciously and slipped from the bed to go and check in the mirror. She knew immediately why Nicky was laughing. Her hair was standing up in every direction. So messy that she wondered how she’d managed to do it when Agatha had been so tightly wound around her all night.

But then Nicky appeared in the mirror with her and his grin was as bright as anything so she decided she could live with a little messiness in exchange for keeping him like that.

Which is exactly why she found herself in the kitchen being laughed at by both Jen and Alice. Agatha at least had the decency to temper her laughter into a subtle smirk as she passed Rio a coffee.

“Sometimes it feels like you’re not even a movie star at all.”

Rio rolled her eyes at her manager and felt a hand pat her head gently and Nicky said with a grin, “It looks so silly.”

Rio scoffed and shot Nicky a wink as Agatha clapped her hands, “Okay. Get dressed, please. We need to leave soon.”

“Okay, mama!”

He ran round to Agatha and whispered something in her ear before he ran off and Agatha smirked as Jen eyed her suspiciously. “What?”

“He wants me to ask if Rio will take him to school.”

Jen rolled her eyes, “I can’t believe he prefers this,” she gestured vaguely to Rio who was now grabbing an apple from the fruit bowl, “over me. He’s had more ice cream than hot dinners this week!”

“Excuse me?”

Rio raised her brows and motioned to Alice to leave. Quickly. They got out the kitchen just as Agatha began to raise her voice and they both giggled like school children as they scurried up the stairs to get away before Agatha and Jen really got into it.

“Your hair looks crazy, by the way.”

Rio laughed as she left Alice to slip into Agatha’s shower and wash out the kinks and knots that had made her hair look less than movie star chic.

With towel-dried hair she changed back into the clothes she’d arrived in. Her hoodie had seen better days but wearing the sleeves that bore the tears of Agatha Harkness she’d been allowed to dry wasn’t exactly a hardship and felt more like a badge of honour.

The goodbyes to Jen and Alice were quick only Jen clung to Rio a little more than she was expecting and Alice made her promise not to chop any more into her hair. But soon Agatha, Nicky, and Rio were on their way to Nicky’s school.

Rio had been handed the keys by Agatha on the way out the door and had been told that it would be good practice, driving a real car before she owned one.

On the drive Nicky was keen to pick Rio’s brain about the upcoming Celtics games and he asked several times if she would come over soon to play some more. And in between the basketball chat he even asked if she would sleepover again but in his room so they could eat ice cream and tell scary stories.

Rio agreed to this readily and enjoyed that Agatha kept her eyes on her the entire time. Whenever she glanced at her she was smiling, a peaceful, calm sort of smile that was the balm Rio needed to calm any residual fear.

When they pulled up at the school drop off Agatha jumped out with Nicky and Rio put the car in park, happy to wait patiently for Agatha to return. Only she wasn’t expecting the door to be ripped open and a little boy to throw himself into her arms.

“Come back soon, please.”

Rio smiled as she squeezed Nicky closer, nodding against him, “Of course, mellizo. I’ll see you very soon.”

He pulled back and grinned at her, touched the strands of her mess of a hair cut and then clambered back down to earth to head in to school with his mom.

Rio felt the sadness creep in again as she watched mother and son walk hand in hand to the entrance. She noted how people looked Agatha’s way and how Nicky shrank into his mom’s side. She saw walking into the school’s open oak door the little family that she wanted to call her own.

Agatha came back ten minutes later, huffing a little with the rush of cold air that came from the slammed door. “I told his teacher to keep an eye. To call if anything… he seems okay. He seems…”

“Mi amor,” Rio reached for Agatha’s hand, making her turn to her, “I think the fact that he was bouncing around at breakfast this morning shows that he’s okay.”

Agatha squeezed her fingers and looked down.

“Why don’t we stay? I’ll get someone to go back to the house and collect our things and-…”

“No.”

Agatha looked stern suddenly, determined. “I want tonight.”

So Rio drove off, depositing Agatha’s clutching hand in her lap so she could manoeuvre them through the windy streets of the suburbs.

Until they were out of the greater Los Angeles area, the car was silent.

Agatha was staring ahead, her fingers only delicately toying with the fabric of Rio’s sweats, and Rio was concentrating hard on the road. Agatha’s truck was a lot different to her little hybrid.

“Have you seen Notting Hill?”

Rio raised her brows, glanced sideways at Agatha who was now looking at her.

“Of course. Used to watch it when I was sick.”

“There’s a scene in it. After Julia sleeps with Hugh for the first time. They’re in bed. And she quotes Gilda Radner.”

Rio began to frown, trying to remember the scene, unsure what the quote was.

“They go to bed with Gilda, and wake up with me.” Agatha answered before Rio could ask.

Rio sat in it for a second, kept her eyes on the road for a few car lengths. But she turned back to Agatha and saw she was still watching her, her tired eyes somehow cautious.

“Tell me you’re not worried about…? Agatha. I would take you in any form you came. I’d love you if you were a worm.”

“What?”

“A worm. It’s-…” Rio bit the inside of her cheek. “Never mind.”

Her hand dropped down to Agatha’s in her lap and she turned it over so they could lock their fingers together. “I want to be with you. I don’t know how I can be more clear about that.”

“I know. I don’t mean…” Agatha sighed softly and Rio glanced at her again. “I just have a complicated life. And yours…”

“Mine is less complicated. Which means I have space for whatever you want to share with me. And I hope you’ll share everything.”

Rio glanced again and Agatha was staring down at their hands.

“Besides,” Rio tried with a smile as she looked up to the road once more. “It’ll won’t take me as long to wash and dry my hair now so more time for complicated things.”

“I still can’t believe you did that.”

“And risk looking less like my twin? No way.”

“If you wanted to look exactly like him,” Agatha raised their joined hands to poke her finger at Rio’s scalp, “You should have cut it to here.”

“I don’t have the bone structure for that.”

Agatha snorted and Rio grinned as she pulled her hand to her lips to kiss it.

“You should try to sleep. You look exhausted.”

“Charming, thank you, honey.”

Rio hummed and shook Agatha’s hand across the centre console. “Sleep. It’s a long drive.”

“I’ll stay awake for you. Keep you company.”

“Mi vida,” Rio huffed, making Agatha’s head roll to look at her again, “Sleep. Really. It’s been a lot.”

“I’m fine,” Agatha insisted, rolling her head to face forwards again. “I don’t need sleep. I never sleep anyway.”

Rio raised her brows at this, having wanted to broach the subject of Agatha’s sleep for a while now, especially since spotting the little bottle of pills last night. “You sleep when you’re with me.”

“That’s different.”

“How?”

“If I’m asleep you talk less.”

“Oh very funny.”

Agatha smiled and Rio eyed her for a second before turning to the road. She tried to unwind their hands. Agatha clung on. “What are you doing?”

“Taking my hand back.” She let it go limp in Agatha’s hold and didn’t have to look around to know Agatha was scowling.

“Tell me why you don’t sleep.”

Agatha seemed to think on it and then said, “Hold my hand properly.” Rio closed her fingers.

“Chronic insomnia,” Agatha huffed, looking down at their hands now resting in her lap, her right hand covering them. “I take a pill for it.”

“You don’t with me.”

“I told you yesterday,” Agatha fingers twitched, the mood shifting in the car. “I like to feel close.”

“Mi vida. Talk to me about it.”

Agatha’s hold on her hand dropped and Rio found that instead Agatha was shifting closer, sliding her hold down to grasp her thigh. Rio tried not to look down at it, tried to focus in, hoped Agatha would remain still if she wanted to get them back safely.

But it was comfort she sought, nothing else.

“I,” she began quietly, “sometimes get night terrors. It’s not unusual for me to get sleep paralysis. The pills help me get to sleep but they don’t prevent them from happening. I don’t get them when I’m with you.”

Rio sat in it for a second, her thigh muscles flexing and unflexing beneath Agatha’s fingers. “Do you know why you get them?”

“At this point I’ve pretty much nailed it down to the psychological torture of living with my mother, marrying a man, and… not being with who I want to be with.”

Rio glanced across at Agatha, saw she was watching her carefully, felt the hand slip further round her thigh, “Have you spoken to anybody about it?”

“No.”

“Do you think it would help?”

“Can’t you take the compliment and leave it at that?”

“I don’t always sleep with you, Agatha. I’m not always there. I want to be. I want you to be able to-…”

“I’ve looked into it,” Agatha said quickly, and Rio felt her fingers flex, pull back, now toying with the drawstrings of her sweats. “I know the guy I’d go to.”

“Then why haven’t you?”

“Because I’d have to admit to things I… things that are only between us right now.”

Rio sighed quietly and as gently as she could she removed Agatha’s hand and placed it in a safer spot near her knee. “Will you ever admit those things to anyone but us?”

Agatha pulled her hand away and Rio looked round at her, seeing her turn to look out the window. “Jen and Alice know.”

Rio shook her head a little because it wasn’t the same. Jen and Alice only knew because Agatha had reacted badly in London, lost her usual control upon seeing a hickey on Rio’s neck, been too loud, too insistent in a locked bathroom.

It wasn't the same. It wasn’t the same.

She wanted to scream it.

“Saturday was one of the hardest days of my life. And all I could think about was how much easier it would have been with you there.”

Rio’s eyes felt heavy suddenly, as if they could bear the weight of Agatha’s words. But she kept them open, kept her focus on the road. And as they drove on she wondered why Agatha would say things like this, skirt around the words she really wanted to hear, never offer to ease the fear that Rio was always too ready to ease for Agatha.

“I said it would have been harder. But you’d have made it easier. And that’s. That’s hard in itself.”

Rio gripped the wheel. Agatha looked down at her hands.

“Why is it hard?”

“Because…”

Rio bit down on her lip, fearful she might break the skin.

“Because,” Agatha’s hand stole her own from the wheel, “if my life were me, Nicky, and you, it would be so…”

Rio’s heart fell to her stomach.

“But it isn’t.”

“It could be.”

“It could be,” Agatha repeated quietly as she entwined their fingers again and Rio glanced as she kissed the back of her hand.

She didn’t push the subject again.

They were quiet for a while; Agatha’s hold now unyielding, Rio’s thoughts now unwinding. They swirled and lengthened and twisted. But they never relaxed, never gave her a second of peace even as topics changed to how funny it was that Alice was so mad about her hair, how protective Nicky was, how guilty Jen felt.

And all Rio could think about was that Agatha wanted it to be her, Nicky, and Rio.

But that it had been months now and she’d still not confirmed it.

She’d still not said she was leaving Ralph.

She’d only held on, only hinted, only nuzzled closer.

When they eventually arrived back to the house Rio no longer had time to think. Agatha was insistent, was desperate. With their clothes off and Agatha’s mouth and hands on her the thoughts stopped.

She was fully in her body once more. Fully Agatha’s. And Agatha was hers.

Agatha was clearly intent on making sure Rio didn’t have time to slip into her anxiety. She was hellbent on keeping her occupied. Even when they took a break for Agatha to make them grilled cheese she had her hand down Rio’s pants, half touching her, half just letting her know she wasn’t done yet.

And Rio knew that there was a countdown timer ticking away in both their minds. She knew that Agatha was anxious. She knew that their time together was precious because they were together but also because it was still stolen time.

They fell into bed around midnight and Rio ached for everything Agatha had done to her that day. She kissed her way to Agatha’s collarbone, nipping at the hot skin there, the skin that she’d been allowed to mark earlier in a particularly possessive display on the couch.

“When do you need to leave tomorrow?”

Agatha grunted quietly as Rio pulled up and kissed her. “Not too late. I want to be home before Nicky goes to bed.”

“Mm’kay. I was wondering,” and Rio rolled off of Agatha, already seeing her pale slightly, “can we talk about us? About what you said yesterday to Alice? About… where we go from here?”

And Rio was surprised to see Agatha smiling. She was grinning, bright and easy, as if she’d just read the stage directions and they said: “she smiles, she looks at ease, as if everything was suddenly right in the world.”

“Okay.”

Rio didn’t question the sudden change because she was tired, herself happy, and Agatha was already ducking down to bury her face against her chest.

Rio fell asleep like that, tucked in, entangled, warm and comfortable.

Agatha, however, only remained still, only held on, her smile having faded the moment she’d pressed back in.

Around three am she woke Rio up. She did it by kissing her, by brushing her fingers over her back.

Rio grunted and groaned and kissed Agatha back but frowned, refusing yet to open her eyes. “What time is it?”

“Just after three, baby.”

“Three? Mi amor. What is it?”

Chapter 30: His Wife, Your Wife

Chapter Summary

Agatha reveals her secret.

Chapter Notes

Don’t be mad okay they’re just babies

See the end of the chapter for more notes

When Rio woke up that morning she woke up alone.

She’d barely slept but she’d eventually managed it around four in the morning when the sun was just rising and Agatha felt heavy and permanent in her arms.

She sat up slowly in the cold bed and groaned as she stretched her limbs and looked around for any sign of Agatha. The only thing she saw was her suitcase, standing tall by the bench at the end of the bed. Unopened still.

Agatha was in the kitchen, and when Rio went to hold her from behind and wish her a “good morning, mi amor”, she only hummed, only briefly touched Rio’s hand, only continued to make more coffee.

Throughout the rest of the morning Agatha was being distant, barely kissing Rio back when she went to kiss her. Their routine felt changed all of a sudden. The soft kisses between conversations, whenever they passed each other on the way to another room or to fetch more coffee, they were all one-sided.

Rio put it down to the fact that they were just a couple of hours away from leaving each other. Because Rio felt the pain of it so acutely that she was pushing it down, deciding that hiding behind their routine was the best way to go.

Clearly Agatha thought differently.

And something about the way Agatha had been so incessant yesterday. How she’d denied Rio the time to think. How she’d begged her to fuck her so insistently that there was no illusion of choice.

Rio would fuck her. Rio would put a baby in her.

But the hands that had been grasping and clawing yesterday were nowhere to be found today. In fact, Rio felt the absence of Agatha’s hands on her even when they were physically there. Because Agatha returned the hug she gave her when she pulled her in after taking her coffee mug to refill it. Agatha touched Rio’s hip when she squeezed around her to reach for a fresh glass. She nudged her foot when they sat together on the deck outside and drank their coffee talking about their journey ahead.

But that was it. Everything was gentle, everything was a goodbye.

By 10:30am Rio had packed her bag and was putting away the last of the clean dishes when something was set something in motion that couldn’t be stilled.

“Rio, I need to tell you something.”

Rio was stretching up at the time, on her tallest tiptoes to slot the plate into the floating grate that held its peers above the countertop. She froze, momentarily stationary in midair. Her fingers grazed the edge of the porcelain before they pulled away and in one slow, fluid movement she pirouetted until she was facing Agatha.

Agatha was wearing her hoodie, her black hoodie that bore the memory of Agatha’s tears. It made her look smaller somehow, maybe younger, but didn’t make her look any less terrified.

“This week has been,” she began again, her eyes darting down to Rio’s hands as they clutched the counter behind her, “It’s been the happiest I’ve felt in a long time. Other than Saturday when we were apart I… I need you to know that because what I’m about to tell you… I don’t want it to change that, to change what we could have.”

Rio swallowed and looked down at the floor, already sure that whatever Agatha was about to say would destroy her totally and utterly.

She’d known it in the way Agatha had been begging her yesterday, in the way she’d kept her occupied all night, in her strange absence this morning. The world had felt perfect for a few, shining, shimmering days.

And now it was dark again. And Rio knew she was about to be left alone.

“In London,” Agatha said slowly, “the night we all had dinner, the night you… that night… I slept with Ralph.”

Whatever Rio had been expecting, it wasn’t this. She’d perhaps thought that Agatha had simply changed her mind. That she thought Rio was cute and fun but not someone she wanted to build a life with. Or worse: that she loved her but she didn’t love her enough.

But, Ralph? Ralph she hadn’t factored into the equation. He’d been in her thoughts, yes, because he was Agatha’s husband, because he might try to stop a divorce or make a custody battle tricky.

“It was just always missionary, always perfunctory, always what I thought it should be.”

She’d been comparing them. She’d woken Rio on their last night together to compare her to her husband. The man she’d left her on her knees for.

“Rio.”

Agatha rolled her name off her tongue, accentuating the purr of it. She said it like it was hers alone to utter. And Rio would have given it to her, told everybody else not to call her it anymore. Left ‘Rio’ to be the sole property of Agatha Harkness.

It belonged to Agatha. Rio belonged to Agatha.

But Agatha didn’t belong to Rio.

She was leaving Agatha.

She would always turn back.

To love is to turn around.

Her words were raspy and free from the violence of her previous shouts but they hurt worse than anything Agatha had told her that day because Rio had wanted to hear them for so long. She’d been desperate for Agatha to say it out loud.

And now it was too late.

Rio turned away and left their home, leaving her heart fallen to her knees in desperation on the floor, her blue-red eyes staring up at the place Rio had just disappeared.

Agatha hadn’t followed her.

Rio had left the house with nothing but the clothes on her back and her phone wedged somewhere in her pocket. She fished it out and blindly tapped until she’d ordered an uber to take her home.

The uber arrived just as her phone flashed with a warning of ten percent battery. But Rio was on less than that. She clambered in, nodded politely when the driver confirmed her name, and proceeded to cry the whole way home.

The drive home was long, and interminably slow.

The traffic piled up around Bakersfield and Rio found herself irrationally angry at whoever had decided that the 5 would allow other people to drive on it when she alone suffered more than anyone else in the world.

But she got home eventually. A shell of her former self, but an alive one, because she’d just about managed to keep breathing, despite the agony.

But home didn’t feel much like it had before. Her soft couch wasn’t as welcoming. Her even softer pyjamas weren’t as comforting. The only thing that was as it always had been was the burn of the tequila as she practically poured it down her throat.

It was barely seven, and she was already drunk.

But drunk was better than aware.

Each thought brought with it the promise of pain. Each memory of Agatha was now laced with the keen sting of betrayal. But worse than what Agatha had done - worse even than the knowledge that when Rio had been on her knees for the woman she’d still chosen her husband - was the reminder of the absolute certainty she’d had that Agatha was it for her.

There was no one else. Just Agatha Harkness and the destruction she’d left behind.
