Rio had been fooling herself for years now that she needed a new woman every night to keep herself from being lonely. She’d tricked herself into believing she could function with situationships and holiday romances.

And then she’d met a woman she gave all that up for without even taking a second to think.

She’d fallen into blue eyes and had slipped deeper and deeper until she realised that Agatha wasn’t her salvation, she was her damnation.

The tequila helped but it didn’t cure.

She passed out on the couch and woke only when the heavy sound of a heavy fist on her heavy door jolted her awake.

“Jesus. Fuck.”

Rio had jammed her foot into the corner of the table leg in her haste to get to the door. The cursing continued as she hobbled over and without thinking she ripped her heavy wooden front door open.

There, on the doorstep, was Jennifer.

“No. Absolutely-,” Rio began, already closing the door. But Jen had reached a hand out, held the door open.

“Rio. Let me in. Please. Just let me come in.”

Rio applied a little more pressure but Jen didn’t let up. She stared at her, seeing the determination in dark brown eyes, and she relented. Jen stumbled as she did but Rio didn’t reach to help and only stepped aside to let her in.

“How much have you had already?.”

Rio scoffed as she closed the door and locked it behind her. She turned to follow Jen inside where she’d already taken the liberty of welcoming herself into Rio’s home.

Rio slipped past her and sat back on the couch as Jen picked up the half empty tequila bottle and inspected it. What she was looking for, Rio didn’t know.

“If you’re here to tell me it isn’t a big deal, then-…”

“I know what a big fucking deal it is, Rio. I’ve just spent the last few hours trying to stop Agatha from-…” but she stopped and shook her head, taking a few deep breaths before she said: “I’m not,” Jen whispered, placing the bottle back down and perching on the edge of the couch. Rio pulled her knees up to her chest. “She was supposed to tell you the night you spent together after the CCA’s. She tried-…”

Rio laughed bitterly and reached for the tequila. “Want one?”

“No. Rio. Listen to me.” Rio took a swig from the bottle and grimaced. “She tried to tell you at the BAFTAs but you were-.”

“Not hard enough,” Rio said as she cleared her throat and pulled her legs back to her chest, now cradling the bottle against her thighs.

“She tried. She knew she’d made a mistake immediately. You spooked her with that goddamn hickey and then-…”

Rio was shaking her head, fearing if she didn’t concentrate she might vomit.

“She made a mistake.”

“Yeah.”

“She loves you, Rio.”

“Apparently not,” Rio said quietly, her gaze dropping to the black label on the bottle. “Said I was too childish. Too young. Too immature for her to ever love me…. For this to work.”

“That’s… she told me.”

Rio paused where she was just about to take another sip and turned to Jen, looking at her for the first time since she’d arrived at the door.

“I’ve just been with her for the past five hours. She’s a mess. I’m surprised she made it home in one piece.”

Rio looked away again from Jen’s tired features and shook her head. “I don’t want to hear it, Jen.”

“But you need to. You need to understand-…”

Rio took another swig of tequila but the bottle was ripped away just as the burn hit her palate and the clear liquid sloshed down her front. “Jesus, Jen!”

“Don’t you dare try to drink your way out of this. You need to listen to me.”

Rio scoffed as she stood up, shaking out the front of her Celtics t-shirt to get the dampness away from her chest. “What else is there to say.”

“That she knows she’s fucked it, Rio. That I just had to put her to bed. That she’s smashed plates and yelled herself hoarse and couldn’t even keep it together when Nicky came to see.”

Rio shook her head and turned away but remained standing by the couch with the tequila hanging by her side.

“She’s a mess.”

“Was Nicky okay?” Rio mumbled, now running a hand through her hair and keeping her eyes anywhere but on Jen.

“What?”

“Nicky,” Rio said in a louder voice. “Did he… witness the plate smashing?”

“No.” Jen was frowning now, reaching slowly for the bottle and taking it from Rio’s hand. “No. Just heard it. But he saw her crying. She usually wouldn’t I don’t think but… she couldn’t stop.”

Rio only nodded as a wave of nausea washed over her and she closed her eyes to try and focus on not letting it overspill.

“Rio. She was angry and confused and-“

“She left me on my knees. I told her I loved her and she left me. I forgave her because… because I thought she still needed time but that she felt the same but-…”

“I’m telling you she does love you.”

Rio opened her eyes and saw that Jen was now standing. The tequila was on the coffee table again and Jen looked as though she were about to reach for her hand but something had stopped her.

“She said she doesn’t. That she couldn’t. And only when I was leaving did-...”

“Haven’t you ever met a feral cat before? They attack when cornered.”

Rio laughed and stepped away from Jen, intent on not being touched, and she sat at the end of the couch again. “She’s not feral. She’s-“

“Okay, a stray then. An abused cat. A frightened one.”

The nausea swelled again and Rio shut her eyes once more, her knees back against her chest.

“Rio, please. I-“

“It’s three in the morning, Jen. You should go home.”

“I’m not leaving until you change your mind about this.”

Jen was back on the sofa again, closer this time. Rio curled more into herself.

“She can go back to her perfect little life and-“

“Don’t be a dick, Rio. You know she doesn’t love Ralph.”

Rio bit down on her lip, the part of her that wanted to forgive Agatha at war still with the rest of her. The anger that she knew Jen was right and yet her Agatha had gone back to him again, would continue to go back to him, would never run to Rio when she was scared.

“She made me love her,” Rio admitted in a small voice, a broken one. “She made me love him.”

“Him?”

“Nicky. She let me believe that-… that maybe…”

But Rio couldn’t bring herself to say it. The hand that curled in her ruined hair flexed and tugged and the sharp pain at the roots made her whimper as fresh tears fell. Being a family with Agatha and Nicky had been a pipedream. Had always been a stupid, immature, fantasy.

Maybe Agatha had been right.

“Look,” and Jen reached out to place her hand on her knee.

“Don’t, Jen.” Rio’s voice was softer, and she twitched her knee away.

“She’s leaving him, Rio.”

Rio sucked in a breath, feeling the sharpness of the air as it hit her lungs.

“She told me tonight. What she said to Alice the other day was true. I’d guessed it already but… she’s still leaving him. Even if… she doesn’t want to lose you. But she thinks she already has and she’s still leaving him. She doesn’t want him. She wants you. And she’s…”

“Jen, please. I can’t talk about it.”

“You have to.”

Rio shook her head and rubbed her face with her hands. “I need some time. I told her I needed time.”

“She thinks you’ve broken it off. For good, Rio.”

Rio couldn’t answer the plea in Jen’s words. She could only keep her gaze down, keep her fingers still by twisting the fabric of her sweats. They were both silent for a while before Jen spoke again. Her voice was softer, somehow tentative. It sounded unusual to Rio’s ears.

“There’s something else. Something you’ll find out in a few hours anyway. Alice will get a call.”

Rio frowned and slowly turned to Jen who looked horrified that she was the one saying this.

“Agatha is playing Kate. She took the role from Wanda a few weeks ago. They’ve been hashing out the details and deciding how best to break the news but the call will come through in a few hours. Wanda will be on a flight to Atlanta a couple hours after that and Agatha will be at the read through with you tomorrow.”

Jen barely paused for breath during her little speech and Rio stopped breathing too. The betrayal hot and sharp in her chest.

The sting of Agatha’s manipulation of Rio, of Wanda, of the studio.

It was as if she’d been blind this whole time. Because Agatha as she knew her, as she was with her when they were alone was soft and gentle and perfect. And yet, and yet…

“No.”

“What?”

“No. She. No.”

Jen frowned more and turned more into Rio, “Rio. It’s happening. Agatha will be playing-“

“Don’t say it.”

Throwing herself from the couch she began to pace. “Wanda doesn’t know?”

“Not yet.”

“Alice.”

“No.”

“Jen. Does Alice know?”

“No. She’ll find out in a few hours.”

Rio rocked her head back and was horrified to find that, defying gravity, her eyes began to shed the tears that they’d been threatening since Jen had arrived.

“I can’t be her wife.”

“You have no choice.”

“I’ll pull out. I’ll pay the fine, whatever it costs I-…”

“Rio.”

“I don’t care Jen. Alice will get me out of it and I-.” But Rio had wheeled around, too distraught to care now about the tears streaming down her face. Only the look on Jen’s face stopped her in her tracks. She looked pained, as if this conversation were as tough for her as it was for Rio. Though Rio couldn’t imagine a world where it would be.

“Rio, it’s why Evanora did what she did to Nicky. It’s why she came down and-… she found out Agatha was playing a lesbian, that she’d campaigned to get it, it was punishment. It was-…”

“You can’t turn this around, Jen. You can’t make me-.”

“Look I know what she’s done is terrible, Rio. I know you’re hurt. But please try to see how much she’s changed, how much she’s trying.”

“No!”

The eruption came from nowhere. But it had been bubbling since Agatha’s revelation all those hours ago.

And before Rio knew what she was doing she was throwing the bottle of tequila across the room and watching it smash against the wall.

Jen jumped out of her skin, her eyes wide and fingers splayed in front of her but whether to protect herself or reach for Rio, even Jen didn’t know.

“Rio.”

Rio released a cry of frustration and Jen moved without her knowledge and before she knew it she was gathering her in her arms. Rio cried against her and Jen didn’t even complain as she ruined her silk blouse.

Agatha had lost it with her twice in the span of barely thirty minutes. She’d screamed at her all the things Rio had worried she might think of her. Though they were all things Rio knew to be untrue.

And she had said she loved her. But only at the last minute. Only when Rio had been practically out the door. Only when Agatha had one last shot at making her stay.

And now she was to be her wife. She would have to fake being married to her. She would have to be intimate and loving with her when the thought of being close to her again made her want to run. It made her want to hide. It made her continue to cry. It made her yearn.

By the time she’d calmed down enough Jen was able to half support, half guide her up to her bedroom. Rio didn’t protest when Jen peeled back the sheets for her and stepped aside to let her in.

“She loves you, Rio. She is a mess. But a mess who loves you. Sleep it off. And in a couple hours, when the news breaks, you might feel differently. Please feel differently.”

Rio rubbed uselessly at her eyes as they continued to stream with tears. Jen remained soft for her and it was almost too much to bear because the only softness she craved was from the woman who’d just broken her, and who she’d broken in return.

“I love her, Jen. I love her so-… so much. I thought she would never-…”

“I know. I know you do. She loves you too. Please believe that.”

Rio hiccuped quietly, using the sheets now to dry her face.

“She left me to go back to him. She-…”

“She was scared, Rio.”

“She could have told me. She could have used her w-words. She could have…”

“She needs time.”

“I’ve given her that. I’ve waited and pined a-and…”

Jen shifted on the bed and for a brief, horrifying moment Rio thought she was going to leave her.

“Agatha doesn’t lose it like this. She screams sometimes and she shouts but… never so bad Nicky would be aware. Never so extreme she destroys half her china. Give her some time, okay? Please let her work through it. Let her come back to you. Don’t give up on her.”

Rio just shook her head, pressing her palms so aggressively into her eyes she felt she might go blind.

The room was silent for a while and soon she felt the bed shift as Jen stood from it. Her fear had subsided now and she felt the need to be left alone - fitting, really. Alone was how she was best.

“If you need anything, call me. And please reconsider. Please don’t give up on her.”

A soft pair of lips pressed into her temple and Rio quivered as Jen pulled away and left her alone. From where she sat curled in on herself in the bed she listened to the soft sounds of glass being swept up until she heard her front door opening and closing.

Alone again, naturally.

In her drunken, broken state she managed to sleep.

But sleep came with terrors.

In them she saw blood-red eyes swallowing the usual green-blue. She saw pale hands curling until they were around her throat, and squeezing, squeezing until Agatha was standing over her and sobbing.

She had something in her hand.

Something blackened, something rotten.

And Rio realised as she clutched at her chest that it was her heart.

Agatha hadn’t taken it, it had been freely given, and it had been destroyed in the process.

Rio woke with a start, sweaty and alert, to the sound of her front door opening.

Her name being called.

The familiar sound of Alice’s heavy footsteps.

“Hey! Wake up! I’ve got incredible fucking news! I just had a call! RIO! You’re not going to fucking believe this but Agatha is your wife! Agatha is your wife!”

Her bedroom door opened.

Chapter End Notes

Sometimes relationships die

Chapter 31: The Read Through

Chapter Summary

Rio is faced with acting out everything she's lost.

Agatha tries in the only way she knows how.

Chapter Notes

FIRSTLY I read every single one of your comments on the last chapter and I am so sorry but also thank you I got too overwhelmed to respond to them but I loved them please keep them coming

SECONDLY sorry for what you're about to read

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“Holy shit.”

Rio couldn’t bring herself to look at Alice. She just stared somewhere around her black leather boots. They were well-worn, the leather expensive but rough in the places Alice’s foot had forced it to bend and stretch over the years.

And Rio was reminded suddenly of her equally well-loved duffel bag of clothes she’d left in the rented house up in the hills. She wondered if Agatha might have left it, or if she’d burn it, perhaps even toss it from the balcony.

Or maybe Agatha would be more careful with her bag than she was with her heart.

“Rio.”

Alice’s soft voice shook her to her senses and before she could even look up she found gentle hands on her warm cheeks and a sweet kiss to her brow.

She said nothing. Alice just knew.

Her arms wrapped snugly around her best friend and she pressed against her but no tears fell this time. She’d cried them all out. Alice was silent, giving Rio the time she needed to just be held, until eventually she couldn’t keep it in anymore and she whispered: “What happened, Rio?”

Rio told her everything. In soft, truncated sentences because the truth was too painful to be an eloquent soliloquy.

She spoke for almost ten minutes until her voice was fading and Alice, who had sat stoic and simmering the whole time, suddenly broke the silence.

“We can get you out of it. Let me make a call.”

“Alice,” Rio whispered, her chin resting neatly on her friend’s shoulder as she continued to cling to her. “We don’t have that kind of money.”

“We’ll find it.”

A slow warmth spread through Rio then, a burgeoning comfort that was the result of more than just Alice’s tight hold on her. “We’d never manage it.”

They sat for a while again, Alice calculating in her head how much money she could find across her three credit cards, two debits, and the small amount of savings she had, and Rio calculating something else entirely.

“Have you spoken to Wanda? Has she left for Atlanta yet?”

“She called when she couldn’t get you. She’s okay. She’ll be on the flight now. She wanted you to know-…”

But Alice stopped talking because Rio had pulled back and was looking suddenly stricken.

“She’s fine,” she repeated quietly, watching sadly as Rio began to pull away and slip from the bed.

“I should shower and-… and then we can go.”

“Hey,” Alice said in such a firm voice that Rio actually jumped as she hovered in the entrance to the bathroom. “I’ve got you. I promise I’ve got you.”

If Rio had any more capacity for tears she might have cried again. But instead she nodded once, shot Alice what she hoped was a reassuring smile, and then disappeared into the bathroom.

Her shower look longer than usual because the heavy thud of the water over her ears felt like white noise and allowed her to not think, at least, not think the worst of her thoughts, even for a little while.

She wondered when her whole body had started to ache.

She wondered when Agatha had decided on the night of the dinner in London that she was going to sleep with Ralph.

But even the heavy thud of the waterfall shower couldn’t stop the worst of it for long and like the suds going down the drain, Rio began to spiral: Had Agatha known all along? Had she planned a romantic evening for her and Ralph back in their suite?

Had she seen Rio be immature with Nicky, sharing a milkshake with him and taking him away from the boring adult conversation at the table?

Had she been turned off by her eagerness, by her desire to please, to help, to simply be with Agatha?

Had she decided before or after Rio’s tongue was in her cunt.

Had she thought of Ralph when Rio told her she loved her.

Had she scurried back to him and laughed with him about the pathetic woman she’d just left on her knees.

Tormented and tragic, Rio stepped out of the warm flow of water, towel-dried her body, left her hair, and stepped back into the room.

Alice was where she’d left her on the bed. Only now she was frantically tapping away at her phone, her brow so tight she looked like she was trying to solve an algebra equation on the tiny screen.

“We’ll be early but Patrick is meeting us. We can get you looking fresh in no time. Sort that hair out.”

Rio only nodded as she moved about the room to find an outfit for the day. She didn’t get very far. Turns out a heart burnt to ash means your processing power is off, not to mention your colour-matching skills.

Alice didn’t even tease her when she moved across to silently pick for her.

She chose a cotton navy button down, a pale brown sweater, and dark jeans; inoffensive, unassuming, comfortable.

Rio changed into them silently, allowed Alice to gently brush her still wet hair, for her to apply some moisturiser to her face, and then lead them out the little house.

“I’ve not yet spoken to Jennifer about all this but after the read through will you be okay alone for a while so I-…?”

“Jennifer? She helped me last night, Alice. Don’t… it’s not her fault. Besides, I’m not a flight risk. I promise.”

Rio closed the door and turned back to lock it just as she felt a hand curl around her hip, a sudden movement back into her that told her Alice had entered guard dog mode.

She turned to see what the issue was and saw a man standing not three yards away, looking more wary than threatening, and carrying a little box with an envelope tucked beneath.

“Who the fuck are you?”

“Alice.”

“I, uh, have a delivery for Rio Vidal.”

“Then deliver it,” Alice snapped and held out her hand in a ‘gimme’ gesture. The man hesitated briefly, his wide eyes flickering to Rio before he handed the smaller woman the thing he’d been paid an exorbitant amount to deliver.

Alice snatched the two items and rather than giving them to Rio to open she shooed the man away and then opened the box herself and stared down at its contents.

“From, uh, a Mr John Smith,” the delivery man said, still unsure but backing off slowly. “Parked just up the way beside the little red car. I couldn’t get any closer. It’s… the black one.”

Rio blinked at him, wondering if he’d had some sort of stroke because of the fright Alice had just given him but he looked frightened, not delusional. She managed to nod, managed to shoot him a slight smile, and he looked grateful for the dismissal.

“John Sm-…?” Alice started with a frown as he held up the little set of keys that had been resting on a tiny black cushion in the centre of the box.

“Agatha,” Rio said quietly, now looking down to the thing Alice was holding up.

“She… bought you a car?”

Rio cleared her throat, trying to focus on doing rather than thinking and snatched the envelope from Alice’s hand. She ripped it open and all breath was stolen from her lungs as Rio stared down at the contents of the envelope. The card was cream, embossed with a small, sophisticated A.H. in the top righthand corner and written across it in loopy, elegant penmanship were two words: I’m sorry.

The already heavy card began to feel heavier in her hands as she stared at the two words written across it.

“Rio?”

Alice glanced at the words on the page and Rio heard her suck in a breath but it sounded distant, as if she’d dropped down into a pool and Alice were somewhere above her, looking down on her, trying to reach to pull her out.

“Come on,” she said, “let’s go. I’ll sort this out with Jen.”

Alice took her wrist as she clung to the card still in her fingers and she dragged her out to her car. The only issue was, and Alice saw this before Rio did, Alice’s little red FIAT was parked just behind a shiny new Mercedes G Wagon.

As Rio stared up at it she noticed a large bouquet of flowers just visible through the windshield sitting on the passenger side seat and Rio suddenly wanted to vomit.

“Don’t look,” Alice warned quietly, hurrying them along until she could get Rio’s door open and force her inside.

But Rio had seen enough.

In college Rio had taken a class on trauma psychology. She’d thought it was interesting more than anything else, and certainly better than the ‘statistics in the real world’ option Alice had randomly gone for: “Look, the actor thing might not work out for me. I need to know numbers and shit as a backup.”

The class had been much more scientific than Rio had anticipated and mostly she’d quietly flirted with a pretty Psych Major in the back of the room but she’d picked up a few things: trauma is subjective, trauma can manifest psychically, trauma can create false realities, trauma can heighten the threat response.

But Rio didn’t register any of these things in her conscious mind as Alice cursed continually under her breath, as she jabbed at the screen on the dash, as the call connected to Jen and she started her car.

“Hey, she bought her a fucking car?”

“Good morning to you too, Alice.”

“Jen. I’m here with Rio now. She bought her a fucking car? What the fuck, Jen?”

Rio dragged her gaze away from the back of the gift before them and looked to the little screen where Jen’s name beside a little red heart sat. She counted ten seconds before she heard Jen’s voice again as Alice pulled off.

“I honestly don’t know what you’re talking about.”

“Jen. There’s a great big fucking Mercedes sitting in front of us right now. “

Ten more seconds.

“Alice, I didn’t… jesus. She had locked herself in her office by the time I got back from Rio’s. I… I didn’t know.”

“Fuck. If she fucking thinks-…”

“Alice,” Rio said quietly, shooting her friend a look and shaking her head slightly.

“Maybe let’s talk about this when we’re all together.”

“No, Jen. You kept the role switch a secret from me, you kept Agatha’s-… just explain.”

Rio looked down at the card now laid in her lap with Agatha’s handwriting staring back at her. She reached for it, let her fingers trace tentatively over the letters as she heard Jen release a frustrated huff.

“Look, car or no car… she’s so fucking sorry, Rio. She wants you to know-…”

“Did she plan it?” Rio said suddenly, her finger now tracing the ‘A’ of Agatha’s initial. “Had she already organised it? Before… before yesterday?”

“What?”

Rio huffed, closing her eyes as she clenched her jaw, “There’s a note here. It says ‘I’m sorry’. The car is… it’s a G Wagon and she mentioned that on our first day. I-… Jen was this all preplanned?”

This time Rio didn’t look at the seconds ticking down but she counted them in her own head and with each passing one she felt more and more faint.

“No, Rio. I mean, I… I don’t know. I don’t think so. I think she… she was hoping it wouldn’t get to this. I… Money can help things turn around pretty quickly, you know.”

Rio felt a hand suddenly find hers and she gripped Alice like her life depended on it. Alice didn’t complain as she felt her fingers being crushed.

“A fucking car, Jennifer?”

“Alice, Rio, I… she’s barely functioning. She’s barely…”

Rio had released a whimper, Jen’s words the trigger to make her remember the sight of Agatha clutching her chest on the floor of their Airbnb.

Alice’s squashed fingers flexed in her own and Alice glanced at her in panic before she said to Jen through the car: “Jen, I’ll see you later, okay? We need to talk.”

“Hey,” Jen said suddenly, a little firmer than before, “Alice, I don’t want-… I mean… we’re okay?”

Rio forced her eyes open again then because this question was for Alice and Alice was there for her, crushed fingers and all, so she could at least be present for her. She could at least try to protect her friend’s heart when she couldn’t do the same for her own. She looked across and saw Alice working away at her jaw, she saw the pain and indecision in her best friend’s profile, she saw the white knuckles that clutched the wheel.

“Dile que la amas.” Tell her you love her.

Because Rio knew the value in being told you were loved when the situation called for it, when it was all you needed to hear, when it wasn’t a last resort to get you to stay.

“I love you. We’re fine. We just… we need to work together. I… Jen, Rio is my priority here. Agatha can be yours but…”

“I know,” Jen said quickly, and the sound of her rushed words made Rio think that she’d been holding her breath. “I love you too. I… I’ll look after Agatha. You look after Rio. It’ll be fine.”

But something in the way Jen said those last words made Rio believe that she didn’t believe them. And Rio definitely didn’t either.

Jen hung up shortly after that.

The drive to the office building on sunset was large and obtrusive on the Hollywood skyline. All tall windows and white walls.

Rio and Alice got in with little fuss, some of the first to arrive due to their arrangement with Rio’s hairdresser to make her read through ready.

For Patrick, she managed to smile, managed to not look like she would rather be curled up with a fresh bottle of tequila in her hands. She made small talk and even managed to force a few laughs that sounded far from forced.

She was an Oscar Winner, after all. She could fake it once in a while. God knows she’d have to fake it when the cameras were on.

By the time her hair stylist had transformed her from a woman with wet, uneven hair to a fresh-faced starlet with a choppy bob that curled about her features in a way that looked casual but was really anything but, Rio felt even slightly more like herself.

When Patrick left them to it after making Rio promise she would never, ever again go at her hair with a pair of scissors, Alice finally asked the thing she’d been worried about since she’d walked in on her friend that morning.

“How’re you going to play it?”

“What do you mean?”

Alice had her emergency supply of products and was laying them out for Rio to peruse and use at her pleasure. She picked up a mascara and started to paint her lashes as Alice hovered by her shoulder.

“I mean with Agatha. Will you just ignore her? Because that wouldn’t look great with-…”

“No,” Rio said quietly, shooting her friend a quick glance through the mirror. “I’ll be polite. I’ll say hello. Read my lines and-…”

“Hey,” Alice uttered quietly, making Rio turn to her properly this time. “I meant what I said earlier. I’ve got you. One hundred percent. I’ll speak to Jen and make sure this goes as smoothly as possible. And I’ll move in with you so that-…”

“Alice.”

“You hate being alone. You hate being alone when you’re happy. I’m not leaving you alone when you’re… heartbroken.”

Rio turned away again, swallowed down the word she’d yet to use out loud. In the mirror she caught her reflection again and saw through the copious amounts of mascara she’d just applied, the blush on her high cheekbones, the soft rouge on her lips. She looked tired, unhappy, wrecked.

“I’ll get over this, right? This isn’t…” even as she was saying it she knew the answer, “this isn’t it for me?”

“No, babe.” And Alice looked conflicted too. She never was a very good actress. “It’s not.”

After gathering their things they went up to the seventeenth floor to find the room they would be holed up in for the next few hours. The building was a rabbit warren of corridors, glass-fronted office spaces, and large open plan meeting rooms.

But creatives always made themselves known.

As they stepped off the elevator they could hear the sounds of people greeting, people exclaiming, people laughing their best laughs in the hope to impress and ingratiate.

It was the same on film sets the world over. Everyone wanted to be liked. Everyone wanted to be popular with the cast and the crew alike.

Rio was usually no different. She was usually in amongst them, charming her way through the myriad conversations, through the late nights and the torturous waiting periods.

But today she just had to get through.

She had to greet everyone, smile for them, shake hands and kiss cheeks and try to remember names.

She had to not collapse when she saw Agatha.

The first person to greet her, or more like envelope her was Lilia. All shawls and bangles, she squeezed Rio tight to her and murmured close to her ear, “She’s here already. By the craft table.”

Rio swallowed as she pulled away but found Lilia’s hold hadn’t dropped it had simply moved to her upper arms. “Did she-…?”

“No, dear. But it’s obvious. To me at least.”

Rio could only nod, only swallow again, only feel the fear begin to rise in her chest as she starved into the kind, knowing eyes of the legendary actress before her. “Deep breaths. We’re family now. You can come to me any time.”

Rio forced a smile, felt herself nod, felt Lilia squeeze her arms before she was passed off to other people to hug and force smiles at.

She landed eventually in the arms of a tall thin man she knew to be Billy Kaplan. She’d met Billy a few times and found him to be charming in a harmless, enthusiastic kind of way. And certainly now as he hugged her tight she wondered how charming this wunderkind would be after the months they’d be spending together on set.

But then again, Billy was better than Agatha.

“I’ve been so excited to work with you! I genuinely have been counting down the-…”

“Billy, leave the poor girl alone. She’s not even in the room yet.”

Lilia shot her a wink and took her hand to pull her into the room.

It was a large space, one of the few rooms Rio had seen on their journey here that didn’t have floor to ceiling windows. All white walls with colourful art on them, and with a large oblong shape made up of tables in the middle.

Along the sides sat a plethora of extra chairs, most occupied already with people Rio guessed to be managers, agents, some underlings of the producers. A lot of the spaces at the main table were already filled and Rio recognised some of her fellow cast members from simply being in Hollywood. Some were new, though, and the first person that caught her eye was the smallest in the room.

James.

Her son.

Her fake son.

He had dark hair, dark eyes, and Rio supposed that if you squinted and tilted your head then they looked alike. And potentially to your average movie-going public he looked exactly like her. Both with the same colouring, large eyes, Puerto Rican.

But he wasn’t her mellizo.

His mom stood up just as the little boy did and in another way Rio found him to be completely unlike Nicky: he’d thrown himself at her, hugging around her middle before she could even say hello. He was smaller than Nicky, a couple years younger, but it was clear he had more confidence in his pinky finger than Nicky had in his whole body.

“Sorry about that,” his mom said sweetly, trying to pry the child away from the actress. “He’s so excited to be here.”

“Oh I’m excited he’s here too.”

James pulled away and grinned a grin that wasn’t Rio’s back at her. She smiled at him, ruffled his hair, and proceeded to give the rambunctious little kid as much attention as she could until her ankles began to ache from resting back on them and she made to extricate herself from the mother and son.

People were moving around her now, hands reaching out to touch her arm in greeting or simple acknowledgement of her presence in the room. Because Rio was now one of the big stars.

She had a goddamn Oscar. A movie star smile. She had everything she, or anyone else, could ever want.

Apart from the woman currently watching her from across the room. The woman talking to the director, Maria. The woman who she’d last seen collapsed on her knees with red eyes and her hand clutching her heart.

And Rio had spotted her the moment she’d turned away from the little kid.

She’d felt that strange pull she always did to go to Agatha, to be with Agatha, to get close to Agatha.

But it was coupled with something else now: something that felt a lot like heartbreak and much like a knife in her back.

Agatha’s gaze was intense, unfaltering, even as Maria Hill - herself an Oscar nominee (tragically rare for female directors) - continued to talk at her.

Rio could see the pain in her eyes, could feel her own reflected back at her. But she couldn’t trust it anymore. She couldn’t let herself trust it.

She looked away just as another hand found her shoulder.

“Rio Vidal! What a pleasure.”

Beside her a tall blonde with kind blue eyes had appeared. A woman Rio knew to be Pepper Potts. She smiled into the hug she was offered and despite the shelter of Pepper’s warm gaze she could feel another on her from across the room.

“I’ll be your intimacy coordinator! I think we have time together Saturday morning. Maria’s very diligent about making sure everybody feels as comfortable as possible so I’ll be working with you and Agatha to make sure we build a strong foundation of trust and security. But I know you’re friends so we should already have some great groundwork laid.”

Rio could only smile, only grin inanely, only nod and accept another quick hug from Pepper as the call was made for everyone to take their seats.

Agatha being her wife as a concept was bad enough. But Agatha being her wife in practise on screen? In the intimate moments of any happy couple; in the touches and hand holds and kissing, that was something else entirely.

For the past week she’d started to think that maybe her body had been crafted specifically for the purpose of touching Agatha, of holding Agatha, of keeping her warm at night, of making her moan, of making her feel safe.

But her body was useless to her now.

How could she start it up again and force herself to make it do all the things it was made for when it was all just for the cameras?

Rio moved blindly with the swarm, finding that all she had to do was spot Alice to know where she was sitting. But Alice was standing behind a chair that was next to the last person on earth she wanted to be sat next to.

She shook her head no as Alice smiled sadly and pulled her seat back for her. “I’ll be right behind you.”

The words weren’t comforting. Nothing could be comforting anymore.

Because the woman who for a while was the source of her infinite comforts was now the source of her destruction.

Alice squeezed her arm as Rio lowered herself down into the chair. There were still conversations happening around the room, still a din of chatter to hide the thunderous charge of her heart.

“Did you get my note?”

Rio dropped her gaze to the spread before her. There was a tall glass bottle of VOSS water, a can of Diet Coke, a pot of highlighters and pens for use on the script that lay before her with her name diagonally across the front page.

She sat uncomfortably straight, her arms framing the script, toying with the top corners of it as Agatha spoke again: “Rio, please. Can we-…?”

“I can’t,” she managed to whisper out, looking around to catch Agatha’s gaze. Her skin was clear of any visible makeup which meant Rio could see the smattering of freckles she’d loved so much she’d counted.

Her eyes were soft and tired and her lower lip, painted with a nude lipstick, was captured between her teeth.

If she’d looked like this two days ago Rio wouldn’t have been able to stop herself from kissing her, from pressing into her, from whispering the pain away with a soft “mi amor”. But that would have been then. This was now.

She inhaled slowly, saw Agatha’s gaze drop to her lips, saw the fluttering of her eyelashes as Rio murmured. “We just need to get through today.”

Two hands on both their shoulders jolted them out of the agonising moment where they simply looked at each other, and Rio felt the presence of Alice behind her suddenly even as Jen leant in to whisper between them.

“They’re taking pictures. This is a big deal. The two of you doing this is a big deal. Please smile, please try. Please.”

“Rio,” from her other side Alice had bent down to whisper only to her, “You can do this, okay? It’s what you’re built for.”

Rio knew Alice meant ‘acting’, hell, she may have even meant ‘being charming’, but she couldn’t have known that she was built for Agatha now, every part of her was shaped to fit a reality that was no longer available to her.

But she nodded as Alice squeezed her shoulder, as Jen did too, and then she did something she really should have won the Oscar for. She turned to Agatha and she smiled, a great big dazzling grin, and she released a laugh that sounded true, sounded perfect.

Agatha looked momentarily stricken, unsure, frozen. And Rio leant in, kissed her cheek without ever touching her lips to her, and tried not to breathe her in as she said: “Let’s just get through this. Please.”

Agatha made a soft noise as she pulled away and Rio felt her hand being taken above the table but she didn’t respond to it, ignored the whisper of her name, and pulled her hand away as Maria stood and called for order about the room.

“Welcome!! I’m so glad we’re all finally here together!”

Rio felt Agatha shift beside her, saw the way she lay her arm out parallel to Rio’s and noticed that at least Agatha hadn’t immediately put Ralph’s ring back on. That at least…

Her pale fingers were twitching.

“It’s been such a journey to get you all here today. This script has been so long in the making.”

Agatha’s left hand held something.

“God knows it’s not been easy.”

Rio couldn’t help it. She’d reached for it. Her fingers closed around two of Agatha’s and gently pried her hand open until she could see what she thought she’d seen.

“I know we will all work so incredibly hard to make this movie the best it can be.”

In Agatha’s open palm, as if it had blossomed from nowhere, lay the little blue paper flower Rio had made for her all those months ago. The petals were still neat, the lines still clean and crisp. This little flower had clearly been guarded, protected, allowed to remain in perma-bloom.

“But it’s not just about the movie. Some of you are playing a family. And I know this is cliché to say but I mean it: I want this set to feel like a family.”

Rio’s fingers remained curled around Agatha’s pinky and ring fingers, apparently unwilling to let go as Agatha curled them down to lightly hold Rio in place.

“Some of you know each other, others are strangers, but over this rehearsal period, I want us all to really bring our a-game. To be open to new experiences and new people and to do your best to make this an exciting and comforting environment for everyone.”

Rio looked up then and saw that Agatha was watching her. This was her Agatha. The one she always was when no one else was watching. She looked cautious and tentative and Rio frowned as she saw the green of her eyes only visible when close enough to count the four freckles on her nose.

“This is going to be a celebration of love, of family, of being there for one another even in our darkest moments.”

Rio turned away, she pulled her hand back, she returned her tingling fingers to the corners of her script.

There was no amount of acting that would get her safely through the next few weeks. She would have to ignore the piece of herself that still wanted Agatha, the piece that would gladly endure the endless torture of waiting for a woman who would never be ready.

She had to get through this.

“So! A starter for ten. Can we all go round, introduce ourselves, the part we’re playing in this little gang, and a fun fact? I know, I know, juvenile, but there are a lot of people and a lot of names and it’s good to get intimate fast. I’m Maria, Director, and I have three cats and one chinchilla.”

She sat down, there was a small smattering of applause and the next person picked up - a producer. Rio began to fidget and by the time it was Agatha’s turn she’d destroyed both top corners of her script.

But she smiled, she turned politely to Agatha, she looked softly curious, she felt deathly ill.

“I’m Agatha, I’ll be playing Kate Santiago-Caldwell.”

Agatha seemed at ease, confident now, and Rio was horrified but tried not to show it when Agatha transferred the flower from her left to her right hand and leant back to drape her left arm over the back of Rio’s chair.

It was so beautifully casual, so readily done.

Agatha continued without a pause: “And my fun fact is that I’m not really a thrilled about wearing reindeer sweaters but I wanted to do this movie because I wanted to work with Rio here.”

Rio swallowed and forced a grin as she met Agatha’s gaze which remained steady, still soft even as she knew everyone was looking.

“Hard to follow that,” Rio said with a wider smile to the rest of the table that felt false but received some laughs. “I’m Rio, I’ll be playing Dani Santiago-Caldwell. I am a huge basketball fan so if I’m ever late to a call time or you’ve just lost me listen out for the sounds of a ball bouncing and you’ll usually find me.”

More laughter. Maybe Rio was going to be okay at faking it.

The spotlight moved on. Billy beside her announced himself and gave a fun fact - it soon turned out that no one really had any actual fun facts to share until it was the turn of the actor playing Agatha’s older brother, a prick of an actor named Peter Quill who Rio knew to be as big a sleaze as any in the industry.

He’d announced that he was once peed on by a one night stand and found he quite liked it.

So much for a comfortable, family-oriented set.

Little James had been apologised to and Maria had called quickly for order again and they swiftly moved on.

But Rio hadn’t moved on. Agatha’s arm was still around the back of her seat and she didn’t know why Agatha hadn’t yet removed it.

Was it comforting to her? Having Rio close? She knew it used to be. She knew she stole her clothes in order to feel close even when she wasn’t there but this… did she think she was comforting Rio?

By the time everyone had looped back around to Maria - Maria had insisted upon including the other people around the room, the non-cast, non-producer types - an hour had past. And Agatha was still holding her chair.

Fresh coffees and juices started to be handed around upon one of the producer’s insistence and Rio found that only then did Agatha pull her arm back. And in the absence of it Rio realised something gut-wrenching.

Whether or not Agatha had put her arm there for Rio’s comfort, it had been comforting.

And now she was alone again, her fingers wrapped around a hot mug of coffee as she turned to speak to Billy by her left side and asked him if he really had seen Lady Gaga seven times in concert.

Time moved slowly from then on. Agatha didn’t return her arm to Rio’s chair. In fact, the only words they now exchanged were the words of their characters as the read through began.

It was harder than Rio had imagined, hearing Maria read out the stage directions that told of the touches between the two wives, the hand holding, the kisses. Everything felt like a threat, felt ominous, felt insurmountable.

She knew behind her that Alice’s eyes were boring into her head but it didn’t help to know she was there. It didn’t help that Agatha was occasionally bumping their knuckles together as they read their lines, it helped even less when Rio removed her hand entirely from the table so she couldn’t do it anymore.

Nothing helped. Nothing ever would.

Rio’s character was in almost every scene Agatha’s was. If she wasn’t speaking, she was leaning against the counter, holding Agatha against her. If she was sitting on the couch she was either tangled up in Agatha and her son or she was simply nearby, watching Agatha with the love described in the words on the page.

There was mistletoe.

There were soft declarations of support and love.

It was all too much to comprehend.

Rio disappeared into her fantasies in order to get through. Her ‘what ifs’. What if Agatha hadn’t slept with Ralph? What if she’d told her she loved her the moment she started to feel it, if she ever actually felt it?

What if Rio could reach over now and find Agatha’s hand resting patiently on her thigh for her to hold?

What if the thought of touching her, kissing her, lying in bed with her, didn’t make her feel like she wanted to die?

They broke for lunch.

Rio moved faster than she ever thought possible. She sequestered herself in with a group of other actors by the table full of hot and cold food. She kept her back to the room. She spoke when spoken to and smiled the whole time.

Alice disappeared to take a phone call only when she knew Rio was protected on all sides by an unknowing but willing blockade. People wanted to be near Rio - they just didn’t know they were also providing a protection service.

But Alice wasn’t long. When she came back she had a hold of her arm, she kept her grounded, acted as Rio knew she would as the best guard between her and the prospect of Agatha approaching.

But she didn’t.

Perhaps Rio bolting had been enough for her to understand that now wasn’t the time to talk. In any case, Rio didn’t look around to see how far away she was.

Billy seemed to have latched on to Rio at some point during the break for lunch. It turned out that he was thoughtful and observant as well as eager to please and genuinely quite sweet.

“What was that in Agatha’s hand?”

“What?” Rio felt Alice move a little closer, her hold on her arm dropping to her elbow.

“It looked like a fidget toy or something but then I thought, no! Agatha Harkness doesn’t have ADHD or anxiety or, like, any kind of mental health thing.”

“Not unless being a b-…”

“No,” Rio insisted quickly, jerking her arm out so Alice’s hold fell from it and she shut up, “it’s just a flower. Origami, I mean. Just… I don’t know why she had it.”

She felt Alice take her arm back again and she inhaled slowly, trying desperately not to think about the matching flower she had that sat pride of place on her nightstand. Nicky’s flower.

“Weird,” Billy said with raised brows as he turned to look over Rio’s shoulder at where Rio assumed Agatha to be. She hoped she wasn’t close.

“Ah, my children.” A hand on her side told her that Lilia had arrived and Rio relaxed just a little, now even more sandwiched in amongst the bodies of people who weren’t Agatha.

“Are we all having fun? Getting along?”

“Sure thing,” Rio reassured with an easy smile that she didn’t think Lilia quite bought. She felt her squeeze her side. “Have you spoken much to your wife? She’s over there with little James. He seems quite fond.”

Rio cleared her throat and in an attempt to look like looking at Agatha wasn’t the hardest thing in the world she turned around to see her crouched down on the floor, her hands held out as she played pat-a-cake with the enthusiastic little boy. If Rio squinted, with James’ back to her, it could almost have been Agatha and a younger Nicky.

Agatha looked up and caught Rio staring and she smiled hopefully as Lilia beside her said: “Why don’t you go get to know the boy? Bond as a family.” She lifted her hand up to briefly touch Rio’s hair and Rio raised her brows as she looked around at the old woman, seeing something close to mischief in her eyes.

“It’s a shame they couldn’t get Agatha’s.”

“What do you mean?”

“Well…” Lilia glanced at Billy and smiled kindly but then moved herself and Rio away from him, leading her into the more empty portion of the room. She lowered her voice, and Rio leant down to listen, “Part of Agatha’s deal negotiation involved talk around getting him involved. The studio,” Lilia cleared her throat as they moved past Pepper, “Stark was insistent she let them hire him due, mostly, to his being her actual son and looking exactly like your… twin.”

Rio looked up into Lilia’s dark gaze and raised her brows, “She said no.”

“Of course. The little boy is too shy anyway but… Agatha is well aware of the cost of all eyes being on her so she wouldn’t allow that for Nicholas either.”

“Nicky,” Rio corrected gently, the corner of her lip twitching involuntarily. “He goes by Nicky.”

“Nicky. And if I’m correct then the next few months she’s going to want to keep things as close to her chest as possible, the people she loves as protected as possible, you understand.”

Rio didn’t understand. How could she?

She instinctually pulled from Lilia’s hold. She blinked at her as Lilia frowned and looked down her nose at her, and Rio felt scrutinised in a way she didn’t like suddenly, in a way that triggered her anxiety even more than anything else that day.

“How do you know all this?”

Just as she took in an audible, sharp breath that cut her throat Lilia placed her hand delicately on Rio’s forearm. “People talk, you should know that. Agatha is of particular interest to the-…”

“Lilia,” Alice had joined them, her hand gently prying Lilia’s from Rio’s arm, “I think Rio-..”

“No, Lilia. What were you going to say?”

Rio gripped Lilia’s shawl about her arm and Lilia smiled so that Rio would feel placated but she felt anything but.

“Let’s go see your family, shall we?”

And despite feeling like she’d been forced to swallow a thousand knives, she obliged. Who could say no to Lilia Calderu with her decades of experiences and strange influence? Rio nodded, felt Alice’s gentle encouragement behind her move her along with Lilia. And Rio turned to look at their destination.

Agatha.

Agatha with the blue green eyes that pulled her in and drowned her every time. Agatha with the soft touches and open smiles.

Rio fell to her knees beside her without really thinking and James was pleased to have her there. So pleased in fact that he was back on his feet, his hands in Rio’s hair, and Rio almost recoiled but she allowed it and smiled because this was a child and he didn’t know any better.

He couldn’t know another little boy across the city had cut her hair, perhaps less neatly than it currently looked, but she’d allowed him to because she had wanted to protect him, to see him and his mother smile.

“You wanna show Rio what we just learnt?”

“Yes!”

James held up his hands and Rio settled onto the floor properly to let him play pat-a-cake with her. She felt Agatha settle close and was aware of an onset photographer circling nearby but she was grateful that Agatha didn’t push it. She didn’t lean in. She didn’t wrap her arms around Rio or rest her chin on her shoulder or brush her hair behind her ear.

But she found herself wanting Agatha to do all those things.

As she clapped the game with James she wondered how long it would take her mind, her body, to not crave Agatha. “Forever” echoed in her brain. “Forever” echoed in her bones. It flexed its syllables in her muscles, and she wondered whether it were true or whether it was a result of her immaturity, the immaturity Agatha had accused her of.

Either way, she soon became distracted by their new, fake son.

It turned out James was indefatigable. He kept going and going and going and what Rio had heard through the grapevine about this child actor had been true. He was full of energy, curious, bold, and much too sure of himself to be an easy kid to work with.

But Agatha had a way with him.

She was calm with him where Rio kept finding that everything she said or did he would take as fuel to his fire.

Rio could only watch, only pretend not to pine for the woman who calmed the boy with a gentle word or a soft promise, and soon James was back with his actual mom and Agatha and Rio were lifting to their feet.

Agatha stood first, fastest, and Rio couldn’t help but wonder if she’d hurried up in order to be able to turn around and offer a hand to Rio.

She couldn’t refuse it so she ignored it instead. Only when Rio was on her feet she locked eyes with Agatha and smiled slightly, feeling her throat tighten when she realised they were effectively alone again.

“Did… did you like it?”

Rio raised her brows, bit down on the corner of her lip, checked no one was looking and saw only Alice and Jen keeping a close eye. She sighed quietly. “Like what?”

Agatha looked pained all of a sudden, when for a flickering second Rio had thought she'd almost looked hopeful as her eyes darted about Rio’s face. “The car. Did he get to you before you left?”

Rio looked down at her feet. “I got the car, Agatha.”

“I… you… are we okay?” Agatha Harkness stepped closer and Rio realised something, something she hadn’t before.

The great, the talented, the world-famous Agatha Harkness was in fact just a teenager giving her crush a rose in the hopes they’d forgive a silly joke poorly told in homeroom.

The only difference was in this case Agatha was a millionaire with a stunted view of how relationships were fixed.

But the concept was the same; like hoping a leaking boat will take you home, tied together with ribbon and a prayer.

“Agatha,” Rio insisted quietly, betraying herself by matching Agatha’s movement and taking a step closer too. “That’s not how… a car can’t fix this.”

Agatha looked up at her and Rio knew she’d guessed right. Every cell, every atom of her yearned for the Agatha that looked at her now. So confused, so unsure, so desperate, that Rio wanted to just say all was forgiven and they could pick back up where they left off.

But she was her father’s daughter. She had his heart and she had her mother’s sense to try and protect it.

“Rio,” Alice said quietly, appearing just in time to save Rio from herself.

“Let’s grab a coffee and sit back down.”

Jen appeared at Agatha’s side too and the woman she was when she was with Rio disappeared into the actress she had to be today. The whiplash was extreme. Any sense of actual contrition, any desperation from Agatha disappeared and suddenly Rio was hit with the uncertainty of Agatha’s true feelings, as her soft Agatha disappeared with a pursing of her lips, a tension in her jaw, a hardening of her blue eyes.

Alice’s hold on her was fierce, and Rio could feel how angry her friend was simply by the strength of her hand on her arm. But now wasn’t the time to say anything. She caught Jen’s eye as they walked past and saw that she too looked furious and she knew then that perhaps the shockwaves of the fallout between her and Agatha would destroy more than just the home they’d created in each other.

Coffee was hard to come by when people wanted your attention. Rio dodged stupid jokes about it being Christmas “so early this year!”, she hugged producers she’d met but didn’t know the names of, she chatted to one of the writers about characterisation and backstory. But mostly she thought of the woman who’d disappeared from the room with her manager.

She thought of the car that had been a joke between them a week ago and now was a representation of everything they could have had, everything that would never be. And apparently the gas-guzzling bandaid Agatha had thought would fix everything between them.

Eventually everyone took their seats but there was a suspicious gap in the table and Rio kept her gaze down, pretending she was diligently highlighting her lines.

Maria asked if a runner could go and find Agatha and ten minutes later she appeared back in the room. Rio didn’t look up as she sat beside her. She didn’t say anything as she reached her hand out for the flower that lay just an inch away from Rio’s water bottle.

She didn’t say anything when Agatha began to toy with it in her delicate fingers again.

She said nothing when Agatha whispered a quiet: “Can we talk?”

Agatha didn’t say anything else that wasn’t her lines after that. They fell into a rhythm and it was clear to everyone at the table - including Rio - just what a get Agatha Harkness was.

She simply read the lines like everybody else. But she changed them, she adjusted her way of speaking. Her voice lowered to a different register, barely perceptible to anyone who either didn’t know Agatha or who wasn’t intimately involved in the craft of acting.

And the room might not have known Agatha as well as Rio did, but they knew acting. They knew good acting. And this was it. Agatha was good. Agatha was the best of them.

And she was barley trying.

There was a call to pause before a scene Rio knew was coming up that would be one of the hardest to film because of the subject of it, the intimacy of it. She reached for her bottle and knocked back her water just for a way to clear her suddenly tight throat.

Agatha beside her was tapping gently at the table and she didn’t know whether it was impatience or nerves that fuelled her as Maria demanded attention again.

“I think, yes. James, Marie, thank you so much for your time today. I’ll see you again tomorrow for costume fittings.”

She gestured to someone at the edge of the room and Rio looked up as the same runner who’d gone to find Agatha jumped to her feet to go and escort little James and his mom. The room applauded as they said their goodbyes and James beamed his confident grin and waved enthusiastically at Agatha and Rio and then bounced off with his mom.

God bless child labour laws, Rio thought to herself as she turned back to Maria.

“Okay, any of James’ lines can be read by,” she scanned the room for a victim, “Susan. Thanks so much.”

Rio saw this Susan blush a deep red and she felt a little sorry for her as she moved over to take James’ empty seat at the table.

She looked back down to her script again as Maria cleared her throat and read: “It’s dark in Kate’s old room. The room is still, quiet apart from Luca’s soft breathing. Dani enters and stops to smile at the sight. Kate is curled around their son, awake, but barely so.”

Rio took a breath, tried to pretend Agatha’s hand wasn’t suddenly just centimetres from her own, that when she’d placed it there the knuckle of her left ring finger hadn’t swiped across her skin.

“He’s nice like this,” she read, falling into the stage whisper she’d need for the scene.

“Too like his mama to be nice when awake,” Agatha uttered beside her, her voice equally soft.

“Dani rolls her eyes and moves to the side of the bed.”

“Room for one more?”

“You’ll wake him.”

“Dani just smiles and carefully slips into the bed, practised as she is at joining her family after a long day. She leans up on her elbow behind her wife.”

Rio’s stomach dropped.

“You okay?”

“It’s been a long day.”

Agatha’s finger twitched and Rio closed her eyes as it grazed the back of her own.

“Dani leans over, brushes the hair back from Kate’s face.”

Rio exhaled quietly and said: “We should have another.”

Agatha’s finger twitched again and Rio felt her heart swell impossibly in her chest. They were touching properly now, neither had pulled away.

“You want another baby with me?”

“Well, this bed can fit at least another two, don’t you think?”

Rio bit down on her lip as Maria read: “Kate smiles, rolls her eyes, shifts back to look up at Dani.”

“Two?”

“You don’t want to be outnumbered by crazy kids?”

“Kate lifts her hand from under the sheets and for a moment looks wistful. She touches Dani’s face.”

Agatha’s finger twitched against her own and as she spoke her next line Rio moved her hand away: “Only if they look like you.”

Agatha’s decision to make them wives, Christmas wives, fake wives, was suddenly cruel. It was beyond cruel. It was unforgivable.

These lines with Wanda would have been sweet, tinged with a little guilt that Wanda might still be harbouring a crush, but harmless for the most part. But with Agatha? With Agatha they were loaded, the gun cocked, the muzzle aimed directly at Rio’s heart.

“Dani smiles and leans in to kiss Kate.”

Rio stared at her line. She stared and stared until: “Rio?”

Maria had broken the scene to nudge Rio into action but Rio couldn’t bring herself to say it. She couldn’t bring herself to read the three words on the page. The three words that meant her heart was in pieces in her chest.

The three words that…

“Yo también te amo, cariño.” I love you too, honey.

Rio looked around at Agatha, saw that she was staring determinedly down at her own script, at the words of the line she’d just read that were written in English.

“Nice,” Maria complimented the surprise translation with a smile on her face. “They kiss again and Dani settles down behind her wife, reaching to envelope their son in her arms too.”

Rio was still staring at the words Agatha had translated for the whole room to hear, feeling the heat rise in her cheeks and the blood rush to her head.

Beneath the table Agatha nudged her knee.

She jumped, cleared her throat, felt the eyes of the room on her when she read: “We should talk about your mom.”

“There’s nothing to talk about.”

“Kate turns away properly and Dani follows the movements of her body. Kate is the sun, Dani stuck happily in her orbit. She pulls her arm back, and below the sheets she holds Kate even closer. Kate closes her eyes.”

“So… this baby thing?”

“Kate laughs.”

“Can we talk about it once we’re back home?”

“Mm’kay. Until then I’ll just think about you all cute and soft and pregnant.”

“Call me soft again and you’re not getting a-…”

“Hot and beautiful.”

“Kate turns and Dani shifts up to look at her again.”

“Do you think Evan was right?”

“Kate reaches for her wife, Dani leans into her touch and takes a second to respond.”

“No, babe. He’s just bitter because he’s a divorced prick stuck in-…”

“I’m serious.”

“So am I. You’re an amazing mother and an amazing daughter.”

“And wife?”

“Dani smiles, a great big cheesy grin that Kate catches with a wry look in her eyes.”

Rio somehow ripped the script she had been gripping tightly. “My wife is the best wife in the world. And we’ll get through these next few days together, okay?”

“Kate nods, her smile fading slowly as Dani kisses the hand still holding her face.”

“No podría hacerlo sin ti.” I couldn’t do it without you.

Rio stared at the purely English script, ripped the edge a little more, sucked in a breath.

“They kiss again, slower this time, and Kate sheds a tear but tries to hide it as she pulls away. Dani notices and as Kate turns she presses in behind her, holding her closer than before.”

Rio bit down on her lip, took just a second before she finally followed Agatha into her mother tongue: “Te adoro. Adoro lo que tenemos.” I adore you. I adore what we have.

“Kate closes her eyes, Dani presses in again. They fall asleep entangled as a family. End scene.”

Rio looked up from where she’d been staring at the word “love” on her page, unsure why she’d substituted it with “adore”, unsure why she was still ripping her script, unsure why the words on the page that she’d read before now hurt her so exquisitely it was like they’d been written across her skin with a blade.

“Incredible, ladies. Really. We’re so lucky to have you both and the chemistry. I mean…”

Rio could feel Agatha shift beside her and wondered where her previous bravado had gone. She hadn’t thrown her arm about her chair again.

There were more murmurs of “chemistry” and even a whoop from Billy that made Rio want to stab him in the ribs. But they’d moved on swifter than Rio feared they might.

The rest of the read was just as painful.

Kate and Dani were in almost every scene together and when Dani wasn’t with her wife she was talking about her wife.

Everything was Kate.

Everything was Agatha.

Rio had played the girlfriend roles before. She’d played a wife or two. But none of them were characters she envied - certainly not for who they were with.

But she found in the character of Daniela Santiago-Caldwell a deep connection through the lens of a woman who loved deeply, protected fiercely, and treasured the little family she had.

But Rio didn’t have that third thing.

A hand on her shoulder as the read through came to an end and the room erupted with applause shocked her back into her body.

“Babe, let’s go.”

Rio moved with the help of Alice pulling her chair out and was just turning to her when a hand on her wrist stopped her. Agatha stood slowly, her gentle fingers like spines poking through Rio’s skin, injecting her with the poison that turned her blood to liquid fire.

“Rio, can-…?”

“Rio! We haven’t had a chance to catch up!”

Agatha’s hold on her dropped and Rio found herself missing it immediately, as masochistic as she knew that to be. She turned to a smiling Maria and smiled too, accepting the hug that she offered.

“That Spanish turn, by the way. I’d like to get that in as much as possible. Little words, little phrases, you know. Anything that adds to the delicious chemistry you have.”

Rio watched as their director grinned at the two of them, oblivious and loving it.

Agatha just smiled, threw her head back and shook out her hair. The bravado was back. She was Agatha the movie star again and Rio was just numb.

“Thought it would highlight the love there. They’re alone. Why wouldn’t Kate speak to Dani in the language she knows her wife to associate with comfort and love? ¿Cierto, Rio?” Right, Rio?

Rio nodded stiffly, her smile now frozen in place, her eyes trained on Maria rather than the woman now watching her from just a foot away.

“It certainly did,” Maria agreed, and it became clear that despite her own pedigree, she was dazzled by Agatha just as much as anyone else in the room was. “Seeing you both during awards season too… I was so happy with the change when the higher ups told me it was even a possibility you might take over from Wanda.”

Rio’s smile dropped, her body suddenly felt tense even as soft fingers found her wrist again, began to dance over the sensitive skin there.

“Wanda would have been an excellent choice too,” she said as calmly as she could, suddenly aware that Jen had moved closer and Alice was now holding her sleeve.

“Don’t get me wrong,” Maria laughed out, “I’m pretty sure you could have chemistry with a lamp post but…” she gestured between the two of them and Rio pulled her wrist from Agatha, “it’s palpable. And I know the internet is already wild for you both.”

Agatha tried again, this time Rio felt her knuckles against her hip and she knew she’d hooked her fingers into her belt loop.

“We’ll give them something to go wild for,” Rio managed to force out, making her face form that easy smile again even as she felt sick suddenly, trapped by pale fingers and a traitorous heart.

Maria beamed and made her excuses before she kissed both Rio and Agatha, said a cursory goodbye to their managers and the four women were left alone.

Rio sucked in a breath, and Agatha moved in, her blue eyes suddenly directly in front of her, her left hand now mirroring the position of her right. She’d tethered herself to Rio and Rio didn’t have the strength to push her away.

“Agatha,” Alice warned darkly before Agatha, who’s mouth had opened to say something, was able to tell Rio what she wanted to tell her. “Rio and I are leaving.”

“Agatha,” Jen added softly, touching Agatha’s arm.

“Please, my love.”

Rio had never know a pain like it. Far from the agony of being left on her knees, a million times more torturous than knowing Agatha had slept with her husband and thought she was immature - a coward - hearing her call her “my love” felt like having her heart split in two with a subtle knife.

Soft in its eagerness to pry her open, gently slicing through the already battered and bruised root of her being, it felt like it cut through her deeper than any betrayal she could bear to name.

Alice was moving where she couldn’t. Alice was trying to gently pry the fingers of Agatha’s right hand from where they held fast to her without causing a scene. Alice was whispering, “don’t, no, don’t.”

But Rio found her voice, shaky and unsure as it was: “I can’t do this, Agatha. Please. Please don’t do this.”

“Agatha,” Jen tried.

“Agatha,” Alice tried too.

But Agatha only moved again, only dropped her hold when Rio did something that neither of them was expecting. Rio stepped into her, held her cheek, kissed her other properly this time, and as easy as breathing Agatha released her and Rio stepped around her and made her way quickly from the room.

The memory of Agatha’s skin against her lips made her breathless as she smiled and waved and hugged her way back out of the building.

She didn’t breathe again until she was in the front seat of Alice’s car. Alice didn’t say anything but she drove away fast, and for that Rio was thankful.

Without thinking she stole Alice’s phone from the centre console and tapped until she had it to her ear. There was time enough for one dial tone before she heard a voice.

“Hey. I’ve been trying to call Rio but-…”

“It’s me. Hey.”

There was a breath. And then both spoke simultaneously.

“Did you know?” “I had no idea.”

Rio laughed, and the sensation was alien but felt a little like relief.

“Are you okay?”

“Are you kidding? It’s freezing here. There’s actual snow on the ground.”

“Wanda, are you okay?”

Wanda sighed and Rio chewed on her lip, feeling the relief she’d briefly experienced disappear.

“I’m hurt. I’m upset. I’m disappointed. Honestly, I’m a little angry. Alice called me a few hours ago and told me what she’d done.”

“Are you angry with me?”

“No. Only with Agatha.”

Rio nodded and closed her eyes as she felt Alice’s hand settle on her leg. “Me too.”

“Yeah? You’re not thrilled she’s your wife?”

“No, I… it’s complicated.”

“What’s happened?”

“Nothing. I… It doesn’t matter.”

“Hey, remember it’s just business. I’m pissed but… the movie with Agatha will be… god she’ll elevate it beyond anything I could do with it. Besides, they went to her first, right?”

“Right.”

“Rio.”

“Yeah?”

“I’m stuck here for a while but, would be good to see you soon?”

“Yeah.”

“Hey.”

“Sorry, I’m just… it’s been a bad couple days.”

“Tell me about it.”

As Wanda laughed Rio found herself smiling just a little, “I’ll call you soon, okay? Keep warm.”

“Rio. Wait. Did… you didn’t know?”

“Wanda.”

“I know I just… know how much you like her.”

“She did this behind my back.”

In the silence Rio wondered what Wanda was doing, how she was actually feeling. But she didn’t have the capacity to take on anyone else’s hurt.

“I’ll call soon, okay? Or I’ll call Alice. I know how hard you are to get ahold of. But it would be good to see you soon.”

“You too. Bye, Wands.”

Rio hung up and replaced Alice’s phone back in the cup holder where she’d stolen it from.

“You told her what she did?”

“Yeah, sorry. When she called again earlier to speak to you I was pissed and you were in the middle of the read through and….”

“It’s fine. She deserves to know.”

“How’re you feeling?”

“Like I want to die.”

“Rio.”

“Don’t worry. I’ll smile, be friendly, professional. I just… when I look at her I forgive her.”

Alice was silent for a while before she said: “Jen says she’s still a mess. She’s gone practically nonverbal unless Nicky’s there.”

Rio turned her head to look out the window.

“Where did they go? Earlier? When she was late back?”

“She holed herself up in a bathroom… I think…”

“What?”

“Jen said she was vomiting.”

Rio screwed her eyes more tightly shut, twisting her fingers in her lap, still able to feel the ghost of Agatha’s knuckles against them.

“It’ll get easier. I promise. I’ll be around all the time, okay? I won’t let you be alone with her.”

Rio could only nod, only hope Alice knew she was thankful for her. The hand on her leg soon found her arm and Alice’s slim fingers were soon entwined with her own, filling the spaces that belonged to the woman with the hair as wild as the ocean of her eyes.

In silence they sped back to Rio’s little home in the hills. Rio’s heart, mutilated and aching, reminded her with every dull thud in her chest that she’d lost something she could never get back.

“Get rid of it,” were the first words she said to her friend when they arrived back at her house. The brand new Mercedes sat, untouched and offensive, a physical reminder of what she’d had and of what Agatha had done.

Alice only nodded, only tapped away at her phone as Rio led them inside.

The house was quiet and Rio simply disappeared up the stairs, stripped down to her underwear, and crawled into bed.

Sleep doesn’t come easy when mental pain manifests itself as an obtrusive ache that could be felt deep within Rio’s bones. She managed it only after what felt like an age of tossing and turning.

Beside her in the bed Alice had curled up around midnight to keep her company so she could have someone to wake to in the dark, lonely hours of the night.

And when they woke they woke together. They got ready in silence, with dark eyes watching Rio’s every move, Alice’s small hands close by to take Rio’s shaking ones as she drank her morning coffee and thought on the day ahead.

A day of figuring out how her character would dress; what a woman with a loving wife and a happy child would wear in her day to day life.

Every thought was on Agatha as Rio opened her front door that morning and as if the universe, cruel and unfeeling as it was, could hear her thoughts, she saw what had been left for her on her doorstep.

Sitting patiently for her to find it was her familiar leather duffel and on top a large Tupperware which in turn had a note sat above it.

Alice gathered the three things before Rio had a chance to.

The door was closed again.

Alice read the note as Rio opened her bag and saw all of her clothes folded neatly, the soft scent of Agatha’s laundry detergent filling her ravenous lungs the moment she’d pulled back the zipper.

She searched in it, looking for the one shirt she knew Agatha had but had never admitted to taking. It wasn’t there.

She closed the bag again, unable to breathe that delicious scent in without feeling dizzy with it, without craving more of it, wanting to swim in it or allow herself to drown.

Alice was still staring down at the note but Rio needed more time before she looked at it.

She turned her attention to the large Tupperware and saw a dozen perfect empanadas. Homemade. And if Rio were to guess she’d guess they had been made to her mom’s recipe.

Her stomach churned as she imagined Agatha, late last night, standing in her kitchen, making Rio something delicious, something personal, something full of care and love.

“Do you want to read it?”

Rio jumped and turned to Alice now holding out the note and with a shaking hand she took it from her.

In Agatha’s looping script she’d written: “Debería habértelo dicho antes. Por favor, déjame explicarte. Por favor, háblame. Te amo. Lo siento.” I should have told you earlier. Please let me explain. Please talk to me. I love you. I'm sorry.

Rio crumpled the note in her fist and for a second was silent before she said: “How am I going to get through this, Alice?”

Chapter End Notes

I'm sure filming will be totally fine and everyone will be a-okay

Chapter 32: Take This Ring

Chapter Summary

Rio is given something she doesn't want.

Agatha begins to cherish something she thinks she has.

Chapter Notes

I got this written way before I expected so have at it

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Rio crumpled the note in her fist and for a second was silent before she said: “How am I going to get through this, Alice?”

“With time, okay? One day at a time.”

Rio could only nod, only allow Alice to take her hand and steer her back out the door and away to set.

Agatha had to have dropped it off. She had to have been at her house, had to have driven there, had to have left Rio’s things for her with the note, with the empanadas, and decided not to knock for her.

She supposed she could be grateful for at least that.

But she couldn’t feel grateful for anything else.

There was a whole day ahead of her where she had to be smiley, had to be friendly and not tell everybody that she could barely breathe without it hurting, without wanting to just turn to Alice and say “fuck it” and find Agatha and let her destroy her some more.

Outside in the cool air between winter and early spring, Rio saw the space where Agatha’s first apology had been parked. She wondered where it had gone: if Alice had returned it to sender or if it were sitting unaccepted in some garage in downtown LA.

They drove in silence, with Alice’s hand occasionally twitching across to squeeze Rio’s fidgeting ones before landing back again on the wheel.

Rio’s mind was elsewhere again, back in the Airbnb, back watching Agatha breakdown, lash out, and breakdown again. But yesterday she’d been so tentative, so desperate, that she couldn’t get a hold on how she felt about it.

The overriding feeling was hurt.

But she was also angry, also confused, also unbelievably horrified that the woman she’d thought had feelings for her, who now was constantly claiming to love her, had fallen back into her husband’s arms the moment anything had become too real.

Agatha Harkness, a woman who was so in control, was so stroic, so put-together, didn’t have a handle on her own heart.

And so Rio Vidal, Delawarean, Celtics fan, showoff and party girl, stood no chance.

They arrived a little after nine in the morning to a quite set full of white trailers with signs on the doors that read ‘Costume A’, ‘Costume B’, ‘Director: Maria Hill’, and so on as far as the eye could see.

Rio supposed her own trailer must be in there somewhere but she didn’t have time to go and find it as Alice tugged her to ‘Costume B’ and they both stood back after she knocked on the door.

It was flung open suddenly and a woman in dungarees and a wide smile appeared before them. “Rio! And you must be Alice! Come in, come in.”

Rio smiled as much as she could and stepped in first and found herself enveloped suddenly, and without warning. “I’m Stevie. This,” Stevie pulled away to motion to the other woman just waiting to get her claws in Rio, “this is Frankie. Or Frank, whoever tickles your pickle.”

Turned out: Stevie and Frankie were exactly what she needed.

They were like two puppy dogs, bouncing about the place just thrilled to be there and thrilled to be dressing Rio Vidal.

The trailer was warm, there were snacks and drinks on the side, music playing in the background, and enough chatter that Rio immediately knew her thoughts would be blissfully drowned out as the day went on.

It was often the case that the costume department was the best place to hang out on set - second on to craft services - and seemingly that was going to be true again.
