Stevie had hugged her twice within the first five minutes because she “couldn’t remember if I’ve already hugged you?” and Rio had already been convinced to have a coffee and a pastry which was more food than she’d consumed in two days.

Alice settled into the corner of the couch and for once took her eyes off of Rio and allowed her to be manhandled by the chatty wardrobe team who went back over her measurements they already had scribbled down.

“Tiny,” Frankie announced as she pulled the measuring tape from around Rio’s waist, “long limbs, though. Should be an athlete or something.”

“Well, I-…

“Don’t get her started,” Alice warned from her position on the couch.

“Oh? I know you’re a Nicks fan. See you at the games all the time.”

“Celtics,” Rio corrected with a raised brow as Stevie moved back over to measure her bust, “Don’t insult me.”

Frankie only laughed and dropped down to measure her inseam. “Agatha is too? I’ll never forget the day those pictures went viral. My sister and her wife went fucking nuts over it.”

Rio shot Alice a look, but managed to maintain her cool as Stevie shuffled back over to scribble down the confirmation of Rio’s measurements.

“Made worse of course by the fact that kid of Agatha’s actually looks like your kid. It’s none of my business but I assume she got a sperm donor? That husband of hers looks nothing like him.”

Rio felt like someone had poured glue into her mouth, unable as she was to open it to deny this query to confirm that Nicky was Ralph’s, that neither she, nor anyone else had anything to do with it.

But Alice spoke for her, “He’s their kid. Though even I thought for a while that Rio had secretly given birth to him and just never mentioned it.”

Rio had enough brain power left to shoot Alice an exasperated look, one that was ignored and returned with a grin.

“He’s just got dark hair and dark eyes, that’s all.”

“No, seriously,” Frankie now said from her knees in front of Rio. “It’s uncanny. I was hoping we’d get him on the movie but we got James instead. Boy is he a live wire. Would barely sit still last week for his fitting.”

“Agatha has a way with him,” Alice said from the couch, making Rio shoot another look across at her.

“Well I guess she’s a mom. Knows how to speak to kids to get them to shut the hell up and sit down. Must do it on the daily.”

Rio felt a sudden flame ignite in her chest, a strange indignant spark at the mere suggestion that Nicky would be anything other than perfect. And before she could stop herself she was defending him: “Actually Nicky doesn’t need that. He doesn’t have meltdowns, he doesn’t have tantrums. He’s a good kid.”

“Sweetheart,” Frankie looked up at her with a grin, “trust me, every kid has their limit. Every kid has tantrums. Maybe Nicky hasn’t had one around you yet but…”

“Oh he will,” sang Stevie as she came back over and shoved another pastry in Rio’s hand, “James had two whilst we were with him. Hates the colour green, apparently. Wouldn’t wear the green reindeer sweater we had knit especially for him.”

“Jesus,” Rio muttered and in lieu of saying anything else or defending a child she probably wouldn’t get to see again, she shoved the corner of the pain au chocolat in her mouth.

The morning went by pretty quickly after that, with Rio constantly in varying stages of undress for the most part. But her body being moved constantly, clothes being thrown on and off, occasionally having the curtain thrown around her in the makeshift changing space by Alice when all that was left of her clothes were her bra and underwear, it all made everything feel that little bit better.

Or, maybe not better, but normal.

Around midday when Rio had forced half a baguette down her throat, washed down swiftly by some strong coffee, Alice had had enough of seeing her friend’s tits.

“Just fucking put it on,” she insisted as Frankie and Stevie exchanged looks where Rio now stood in dark grey joggers and her from-home bra.

“Do my tits offend you?”

“I just… Rio, goddamn cover up.”

Rio huffed, missed the second look exchanged between Stevie and Frankie and shoved the black cami Alice had handed her over her head.

“Happy?”

“Not really, no.”

Rio rolled her eyes and turned back to grab the sweater held out to her and proceeded to shove that over her head.

It took a second and then… Alice laughed. A great, big, boom of a laugh. More of an explosion, actually.

And Rio looked down at herself to see what was so funny.

Written across the black sweater were the words, in a bold rainbow font, ‘Make the yuletide gay’.

“Oh no, absolutely not. I’m not wearing this on camera.”

“Come on!” Stevie announced with a grin, clearly trying to hold in her own laughter where Frankie and Alice were already lost causes.

“Agatha has a ‘fa la la la la lesbian’ one.”

“That doesn’t even make any sense.”

Rio turned to the mirror and scowled at the sight of herself. She’d avoided the mirror most of the day and she couldn’t believe that now was the time she was utilising it. That now she was in this joke of a sweater, her hair mussed from all the on and offing she’d been doing, her eyes large and tired, and now was when she was taking in her appearance properly for the first time.

“I’m vetoing it.”

“No, noooo,” Alice trilled, “this is excellent payback for your tits being out all day.”

“You never usually complain.”

Rio began tugging at the sweater, wondering if it would look better in situ on the set and not whilst she was the only person in the room wearing anything remotely christmassy.

Stevie and Frankie (now recovered from their laughter) looked at each other again.

“Is Agatha going to wear hers?”

“Unclear, but got a message from her camp a second ago so Stevie’s going to head over there in a second. She’ll ask for you.”

Rio nodded, wondered briefly how Agatha would feel about wearing the word ‘lesbian’ across her chest, tried not to think about the last time she had a lesbian on her chest, and then disappeared into the little makeshift changing room just to be alone for a second.

It didn’t last long. Alice joined her almost immediately.

“I wasn’t offended by your tits. It’s just… You show off more when you’re upset,” Alice said softly as she tugged the heavy curtain across and Rio stopped where she’d been about to strip again.

“Or feeling vulnerable or-…”

“I get it.”

“I just felt like you were parading around-…”

“I wasn’t parading. Besides, do you know how far sex is from my mind right now?”

Alice didn’t need to know what she’d just been thinking.

Alice pursed her lips but said nothing else as Rio went to lift the sweater up and threw it onto the nearby clothes rail.

Alice handed her the next one and Rio checked it first to see if there were any jokes written across it but found only a reindeer and so reluctantly put that one on.

She stepped back out to be assessed and found that Stevie had disappeared whilst she’d been alone with Alice.

Frankie hummed and made Rio stand by the wall so she could take a polaroid of her to add to the now busy collection on the cork board at the far end of the space.

“Not sure on the colour on this one. There’s a blue version we could try…”

“Whatever works best,” Rio said with a shrug, a little pissed at Alice’s suggestion that she’d been parading.

She didn’t parade, she was just doing her job. And the easiest way to do her job in that moment was to let the costume department throw things on and off her body as quickly as possible which meant often standing around in a bra as she waited.

Besides, it was warm, she wasn’t exactly naked, she was simply doing her job.

These words went round and round in her mind as she waited on Frankie to source the second option for the reindeer sweater and out of the corner of her eye she caught Alice watching her closely and then she thought, perhaps, she was being a little unfair.

Alice had watched her like a hawk since she’d stepped into her room on Wednesday morning. She’d not left her side once. She’d even slept with her to make sure she was okay in the night.

She was looking out and doing a thorough job of it.

Rio cleared her throat and shame-faced looked down to her feet.

“Frank?”

“Yeah?”

“Did I make you uncomfortable being in my bra earlier?”

Alice stood from where she’d sat and Rio ignored her as she looked over at Frankie who had her back to her and was rummaging through the rails. “What? No. Easier to get things on and off.”

Rio nodded, cleared her throat and mumbled, “That’s what I thought.”

Alice had arrived by her side and turned her head with her hand on her cheek, “I’m just looking out.”

Rio smiled, nodded, briefly kissed Alice’s hand, “I know. I just wanted to be sure no one else was offended by my parading.”

Rolling her eyes Alice pulled away just as Frankie turned with the found sweater in her hands and cheered as she did. “Next!”

Rio took it and again disappeared for a second to herself, to breathe, to think.

But she stopped what she was doing when she heard it. Her new sweater was rouched across her chest, and despite the stuffiness of the trailer, her skin felt cold as she listened to the soft conversation happening just beyond the heavyset curtain that separated the changing area from the rest of the space.

Stevie had clearly arrived back.

“No, it was like… she requested it.”

“But?”

“I know, silent all morning and then-…”

Rio pulled the curtain back, stomach now covered by the navy version of the earlier reindeer sweater.

The two people huddled together in the centre of the trailer looked up, both wide-eyed and caught. In one set of arms there was a pile of small boxes, some an infamous light blue, others varying shades of black, brown, blood red.

“What’s happening?”

“I…”

Stevie, carrying the boxes, cleared her throat and went to offload them onto the countertop.

Rio looked on as they spilled over the area and then turned to Alice, and saw that she looked a little paler than she’d been when Rio had last appeared from behind the curtain.

“We have rings for you. Wedding rings, you know.”

Frankie looked a little startled and Rio slowly moved closer, wondering if in her semi-stupor through the morning she’d accidentally told everyone exactly how she felt about being fake married to Agatha Harkness.

“Rio,” Alice said softly, shaking her head just a little in a move Rio took to be a warning.

But her brown eyes were back on the little boxes that Stevie was now carefully righting and opening for her to see.

“We got lucky. We had a few in storage, some are loaned from different jewellers, some have been brought in from our personal collections of costumes. You have about two dozen all in all, all in her size.”

Rio raised her brows in surprise, felt her stomach drop. “Her size?”

“Yeah, so,” Stevie righted the final box and Frankie began to arrange them more neatly across the counter. “Agatha’s just suggested it might be cute for you guys to pick each others rings.”

“Oh, I…”

Is this what it felt like to simply die? To just stop all regular bodily functions, anything life-preserving, anything protecting you from simply… ceasing to exist.

“I was just saying to Frankie,” Stevie said with a smile, “Agatha’s apparently been basically mute all day and hasn’t really had many opinions on anything and then all of a sudden!”

Rio bit down on her tongue, staring now at the little box Stevie still held in her hand; the box she assumed must hold the ring Agatha had picked for her.

“So she could really rock silver or gold and she’s got long fingers so they could take a bigger ring. We’re gonna go trimmed nails too so I’d recommend-…”

But Rio still hadn’t moved, still hadn’t even looked properly at the selection of rings she was now being shown. Because picking a ring for Agatha meant something and right now everything meant too much.

“Alice, you pick for her,” she said in as calm a voice as she could. Dragging her eyes away from the box that she’d assumed held her own ring she turned to Alice with a pleading look in her eye, “Please.”

Alice moved over and only lightly touched Rio’s arm - nothing that would look suspicious - as Rio allowed Frankie to pick a little at her sweater, pushing the sleeves up to her elbows to get a look at it being worn in different ways.

“This is cute on you.”

But Rio was too distracted by the ring she’d yet to lay eyes on.

What would Agatha have picked for her? Something big? Something with a plain diamond? A coloured gemstone?

As Frankie was adjusting her collar she finally said, “Stevie? Which did she pick for me?”

Alice glanced at her over her shoulder as Stevie jumped to attention and grinned as she opened the box with a flourish and offered it up for Rio to inspect. “Gorgeous, right? She picked it immediately.”

Sitting upright in the cream cushion was a round diamond set against a gold band. It was a perfect cut, a perfect clarity, and Rio could only guess how many carats.

Stevie plucked it out when Rio made no move to and held up the gold band for her to try it on but tense fingers remained tense by Rio’s side and she didn’t raise them up.

“Pretty,” she managed to get out, turning away from it as Stevie tilted her head in question. “I’ll lose it or damage it if I wear it now. Keep it safe and I’ll try it on properly when we start shooting.”

Rio was saved the slightly perplexed look from her dresser when Alice turned around and held up a closed box, “Got it. This one.”

Rio only nodded, only followed the motion of Frankie’s hand as she silently asked her to stand by the blank wall so they could take shots of the blue reindeer sweater.

She posed, sans ring, smiled and tried to look like any normal person might who was trying on someone else’s clothes for the day. But now leaving the trailer with Stevie was the ring Alice had chosen for Agatha, the ring Rio would have to see every day from now on.

She’d have to watch as Agatha acted like her wife, dressed like her wife, wore a ring like her wife.

“Rio.”

Rio jumped, blinked away the daze she’d been in.

“There’s pyjamas on the stand, will you try them on please? Unsure if we want tartan or the navy ones. We’ll need to see what Agatha looks good in.”

Rio couldn’t bring herself to ask if that meant she’d be matching with Agatha. She could only go in behind the curtain, taking a second to just breathe until she heard the rustle of it open again and felt someone help her tug her sweater over her head.

“I went pear,” Alice said softly, now turning to fold the sweater, “gold. Maybe not her taste, definitely not yours, but… more than she deserves.”

Rio nodded silently, snatching up the tartan pyjama top first and allowing Alice to help with the lower buttons as she did the top.

“Trying to buy you with a fucking car and now a ring she hasn’t even bought I-…”

“Alice,” Rio started in the softest voice she could manage. “Please.”

Looking up she saw Alice freeze, saw her work her jaw and drop her hands from the middle button of her shirt. “I should have stepped in sooner, I should have-…”

Rio sighed heavily and without warning turned around to rip the curtain open and frighten poor Stevie who’d been piling the ring boxes back up.

“Frankie, could we have five, please?”

“Oh, uh, sure. I’ll just… go see how the others are doing.”

Rio nodded stiffly and just about managed a smile before Frankie was gone.

“You couldn’t have stopped me, Alice. And honestly, I wouldn’t have wanted you to.”

“What? Rio, have you seen yourself? Are you so out of it that you don’t feel-…?”

“I feel everything, Alice. I feel… I can feel the blood coursing through my veins and my heart lying broken in my chest but I… I had her. I had what my parents have. I had it for barely any time at all but I had it and I think that’s worth the pain of-…”

She’d wheeled around and something in her friend’s eyes made her stop. She slammed her mouth shut and swallowed thickly, “Am I pathetic?”

“No, no. No. You’re just… I forgot with all the one night stands and… you’re just a romantic. And I’m so fucking sorry that you’re hurting. I wish I could… God I want to kill her.”

Rio smiled weakly and rested back against the counter. “Please don’t. Losing her is one thing, having her die… I don’t think I’d ever recover.”

“You’ll recover, Rio. You’ll recover from this.”

“No,” Rio’s smile withered, barely having bloomed in the first place, “no, probably not.”

“Tell me again when, one day, you’re on the floor playing with a little baby and your wife is making you pollo guisado in the kitchen.”

Alice couldn’t have known that Agatha had made her that very dish on their first night together in their Berkeley home and Rio didn’t have the heart anymore to tell her.

A knock at the door though meant she didn’t have time to, even if she’d wanted to. Alice checked her over once before she went to open it and Rio swallowed when she saw who it was.

Agatha was stepping into the room, wrapped in a white dressing gown, her hair in a devastatingly chic messy up do, her face tired, her eyes only on Rio.

“Agatha suggested we test the way the pyjamas look together,” came Stevie’s chirpy voice as she stepped in behind Agatha. “Oh good, you went tartan first.”

Rio couldn’t breath as she watched Agatha drop her gown, watched as she moved towards her, watched as she stopped before her. Her usually bright blue eyes looked weary as they settled around Rio’s throat and Rio adjusted her posture to stand a little straighter, needing that inch or so she had on Agatha to feel even a semblance of power as she stood hopelessly before her.

“Frank, the tinsel,” Stevie was instructing from somewhere else in the room. Rio was aware that people were moving, was vaguely cognisant of Alice moving closer in her periphery, and Jen taking a seat on the couch, of Agatha’s team moving about to help, but all she could really focus on was Agatha as she raised her hands up under the pretence of fixing Rio’s collar.

“Hi.”

“Hi.”

Agatha was gentle, fixing something that didn’t need to be fixed, her gaze apparently still too shy to rise the few inches it needed to to match Rio’s. “Pensé… Solo quería elegy tu anillo, aunque fuera fingido.” I thought… I just wanted to pick your ring, even in pretend.”

Rio closed her eyes just as Agatha raised her gaze and the soft adjustments of her fingers paused.

“God, fuck, one of the boxes in back!”

“No! The other!”

“Rio.”

The sounds of everyone nearby searching for tinsel, of Alice reaching to pull Rio away from Agatha, they were all lost to her when she felt Agatha’s soft breath against her ear, heard the words she now whispered in even gentler Spanish: “Lo sent mucho, Rio. Por favor, créeme cuànto lo siento. Por favor, déjame compensarte. Quiero esto. Te deseo. Te amo.” I’m so sorry, Rio. Please believe how sorry I am. Please let me make it up to you. I want this. I want you. I love you.

At some point in Agatha’s speech, Rio’s fingers had found the hem of her tartan cotton shirt, and Rio’s face had turned unconsciously into the warmth of Agatha, into the comfort of her.

But Alice was clutching her now, gently tugging her away until their hold dropped and Rio felt the chill of a life where Agatha wasn’t against her anymore.

Rio didn’t look around to see what Agatha had done when she’d been pulled away but she accepted a bottle of water from Alice and drank down half of it just for something to do, something to feel that wasn’t the constant pull of Agatha.

“Got it!”

“Okay! Ladies! We gotta pose you. First in the tartan, then in the blue. I think the winner is gonna be tartan but… we can let Maria decide later.”

Rio allowed herself to be positioned back against the white wall and she forced herself to smile, forced herself to relax her shoulders and didn’t quite look when Agatha was moved to her side.

It was awkward at first because neither reached for the other. They both just stood there, two strangers now, though they’d shared so much and lost even more.

Stevie galloped forwards to drape them in tinsel and Rio remained silent as she let her hand be positioned on Agatha’s shoulder and felt Agatha naturally wrap her own around her waist.

“Frank, the ring?”

Rio felt her chest tighten when she realised what was about to happen and Agatha asked, “You didn’t like it?”

“I-…”

“Oh she hasn’t tried it on yet,” Stevie grinned and waved her hand through the air, turning to see where Frankie had got to.

“I didn’t think I’d need to until filming began.”

She shot a glance at Agatha and saw she was looking down at her feet, saw that she was working her jaw, saw the glazed look in her eyes.

The ring was placed on her finger as she continued to watch Agatha and she felt the hold of it as viscerally as she felt the arm still wrapped around her, the hand curling around her side.

“Perfect. Show them off for me!”

Rio turned back to smile at Stevie, and in doing so she splayed her fingers out as her hand rested on Agatha’s shoulder and Agatha moved in closer, holding up her hand for the wardrobe team to get a sight of.

Rio felt sick with it, felt horrified that this was how she would exchange rings with Agatha Harkness. But then again, it always was too good to be true. Always a luck only found in movies, for other people, not for Rio Vidal.

Stevie and Frankie, and now Agatha’s team who’d arrived to enjoy the show, were debating on whether either of them needed to have their hair changed or for some different lighting, some slippers or accessories.

And Rio sucked in a breath before she turned to Agatha, turning fully, making their bodies face one another. Agatha flowed with her, melting into the new hold without hesitation and Rio watched as her eyes flashed with something that she’d spotted briefly at the read through: hope.

“Necesito que dejes de darme regalos. Deja de decirme que lo sientes, que... me quieres. Necesito tiempo. Necesito... Necesito poder pensar. Apenas puedo...” I need you to stop giving me gifts. Stop stop telling me you're sorry, that you... love me. I need some time. I need... I need to be able to think. I can barely...

Rio paused, took a breath, was barely able to meet Agatha’s gaze when she finished, this time in English. “Please just, give me some time.”

“Rio,” Stevie was saying, and Rio turned to her but caught sight too of Alice and Jen eyeing them up from across the room, “Couch, please.”

Rio nodded and turned back to Agatha and saw that she looked paler than even before. But she pulled away instead of reaching for her like she wanted to and she went to sit in the middle of the couch. Stevie draped her in tinsel and Rio held it like a towel round her neck as she settled cross-legged in the centre of the couch.

She caught Alice’s eye and forced a small smile as she saw the death grip Alice had on Jen’s hand. It didn’t relax her to know that Alice was suffering for this too.

But then Agatha sat down and sat so far away that Alice’s suffering was nothing to her own.

Rio cleared her throat and threw one half of the tinsel over Agatha’s shoulder. She looked at her, waited until Agatha glanced her way, and then she smiled. And for the first time it didn’t feel forced.

Agatha, in her red tartan pyjamas with the gold tinsel draped haphazardly over her shoulder, looked as Rio had imagined she might on Christmas morning and for a second she allowed herself to pretend it was real.

So she’d smiled.

So she shifted back and took the tinsel and draped her arm over Agatha’s shoulder.

Agatha didn’t hesitate to move closer and Rio realised she’d sat far away because in her mind “time” meant “space”. But no time nor space would ever truly help Rio in the continuum of her fluctuating pain and desire.

So when Agatha cautiously sat in the space offered and leant fully into her side, she felt every tug of her heartstrings and every whisper of hope. Because Agatha in her arms felt right, it always felt right.

“Oh man, Rio. The internet will lose it when I post these.”

“Oh I,” Rio began, instinctively tugging Agatha closer.

“No, it’s fine. Post them. Give Jen the last say but…” and Agatha shifted to rest back more against Rio. “It’s fine.”

And as their two managers fussed and the stylists began to adjust their clothing and their bodies Rio thought that, with Agatha securely against her side, it might be. She inhaled her without thinking, she scrunched the soft fabric of her pyjamas in her longing hand, she pretended so hard it felt almost real.

Agatha moved her left hand to rest delicately on her knee and Rio, taking the bait without thinking, moved her own left hand to hold it.

The gaps between her fingers had been filled again. She still felt broken, but all her pieces were there.

The only difference was, Agatha’s hand now had a new ring.

It was yellow gold with a pear shaped diamond. It wasn’t right. It didn’t look right. It wasn’t what Rio would have picked for her.

But Agatha was still wearing it, hadn’t said anything against it, and now clutched at her as if she didn’t want to let go.

The first time they’d met, properly, years after their first introduction in a grimy bathroom, they’d sat in a similar position. Only Rio’s hand had been against Agatha’s knee, and Agatha’s hand had held her there.

Somewhere in the months since that moment they’d switched positions.

But Rio remembered the stress of that day, the fear that she was touching Agatha too much or being weird around her. She felt it still in her deepest self; the fear that she was being uncool when really she wanted to impress, to woo, the prettiest girl in the room.

Agatha’s hand was soft beneath her own and she found that she’d curled her fingers back on themselves to hold Rio’s in place. It was subtle, delicate, but enough for Rio to know that she wanted her there, that she wasn’t letting go.

“God the Vidalitas are going to eat this up.”

The tension snapped immediately and Rio exhaled sharply through her nose at the nickname sometimes given to a particularly staunch section of her fans. She felt Agatha squeeze her hand and saw Jen move over even though Rio’s dark eyes remained down on the diamonds blinking back up at her still.

“It’s a bit… do you look a little cosy, Agatha?”

Rio anticipated that Agatha would move away, that she’d shrink forwards or simply let go, but she stayed where she was. If anything, she held on tighter.

“Check the lighting’s okay, Jen. Other than that, I’m fine where I am.”

“Amaaaaaazing!” Stevie sang out, practically bouncing about the place to get the right angle. Rio remained still.

It felt as if the small gang of people now watching them and taking photos were intruding on their private time together. Only the last time they’d sat like this Rio hadn’t felt sick to her stomach that she’d only now have access to Agatha in a manufactured way, in a way that meant they’d have eyes on them always. In a way that meant the rings they wore were as fake as the smile that Rio was beaming at the camera.

And then it was done, they were told they could change to the blue pyjamas and Agatha was the first to move. She pulled up and turned around but held on to Rio’s hand and Rio watched her for a second, smiled a little as Agatha turned around and offered her free hand to help Rio up.

She’d done it yesterday and Rio had ignored it. But now, now their hands were already joined, now she wore a ring Agatha had picked for her, now she couldn’t refuse.

She took the offered hand and Agatha barely helped - because Rio was uninjured, barely in her thirties, and had no problem standing from a couch - but she held her all the same.

The chatter around them continued as the two small teams of wardrobe assistants debated on whether they should get snaps of the two stars in other outfits too. But it was lost to Rio as Agatha continued to hold on and said, “I can wait. I can be good. I… when you’re ready, I’d like to explain. Please. Please let me explain.”

Rio bit down on her lip, looked down at their ring fingers, felt her heart slip down into her stomach. Down, down, down, with no way up.

“Please.”

Rio looked up.

Up into Agatha’s desperate eyes, up into the face she’d memorised long ago. This was a woman she would have trusted with her life, who she had trusted with her heart.

“Okay. Just…” Alice was moving in, her hand on Rio’s side to guide her away. “Okay, Agatha.”

She released her hands as Alice led her to the makeshift changing area. Alice held the curtain back for her and Rio said nothing as she slipped inside and began to strip once the curtain was pulled again.

“What’re you doing, Rio?”

Rio couldn’t find the words to answer Alice so she chose not to.

She just allowed her to help her shrug her blue shirt on. She let her help with the buttons. She listened as she whispered quietly, urgently, “I know how hard this is. I know it’s so tough. But it’s been barely forty eight hours. You need to give it some time.”

“I’ve told her. I…”

“I just want you to be okay.”

Rio nodded and cleared her throat as she changed her pants over and turned then properly to look at Alice. She took a second and then leant in and pressed close to whisper directly into her ear, “Thank you for watching out. I’ve told her I need time. I think… I think she understands.”

She felt Alice nod, their temples now touching. As Rio took a second to breathe she felt Alice’s hand clutch at the thin fabric around her shoulder. “Will you be okay if I take Jen out for a bit? I haven’t had a chance to-…”

“Yes. That’s fine. It’ll be fine.”

Alice only kissed her cheek briefly and then pulled back the curtains for them so Rio could swap with Agatha. Unlike her, Agatha went in to change alone and Jen remained where she was at the counter.

“Is,” Stevie said with a wry smile, “is there something going on between you two?”

“Which two?” Jen said sharply, moving forwards a little as if moving would throw off the scent.

“Rio and Alice,” Frankie said breezily, rushing about the room to gather up the outfits they’d already decided would belong to Dani’s wardrobe.

“Excuse me?”

Rio almost smiled at Jen’s reaction, almost actually laughed at it. But Alice shot her a warning look and ran around Rio to get to Jen where she immediately held her wrists and moved them backwards.

It was adorable to watch and Rio suddenly wished she and Agatha had been accused just to see what Agatha might have done. Then again, best not. Best not have Agatha doing as Alice was currently doing, holding her wrists and pinning her against the counter.

Jen at least looked unfazed with Alice where Rio was sure she’d have been a blushing mess at the mere prospect of Agatha doing that to her.

At the idea that she’d ever be that fierce in her desire for her again.

She heard Alice muttering reassurances to Jennifer and so took it upon herself to respond in her stead: “We’re just friends. Alice and Jen are dating.”

“And why would you think Alice and Rio were dating?”

Rio shot Jen a look out of the corner of her eye and turned back to Stevie with her smile now firmly in place on her face. Now shaken of the image of Agatha holding her against anything she felt she had some leeway to tease just a little: “That would be all the kissing, r-…?”

Three things happened simultaneously: the curtain was ripped back, Jen exclaimed Rio’s name, Alice slapped her arm.

But Rio was only really interested in one of those things. Agatha’s jaw was tense, but she wasn’t looking at Rio. In her navy blue pyjamas she moved across to the couch again and silently took back the position she’d been in before.

“Wait, Agatha. We need the wall shots first for our board.”

“Here’s fine,” Agatha said curtly as she turned her gaze to Rio and raised her hand - her left.

Rio bit the inside of her cheek, an old almost-forgotten sensation sparking somewhere in her body but bouncing around so furtively she almost couldn’t name it. Though she knew logically what it must be.

Her tired, broken self was still attuned to Agatha. And Agatha looking murderous was never not going to do things to her. Her body was still desperate for Agatha, still turned on by Agatha. Only the ignition was a little tough, a little slow to fire.

She accepted the hand held out to her and settled back down beside Agatha. Only this time, this time Agatha was the one who wrapped her arm around Rio, though not across her shoulders like Rio had done to her. She instead held her waist, pulled her in close to her side, and stared straight ahead.

Rio delicately rested her hand on Agatha’s knee and for only the briefest of moments did it remain unheld. As Agatha’s fingers slipped into their rightful place Rio cleared her throat softly and Agatha glanced askance at her.

The fantasy of before had dissolved now; the mirage clear when Rio met Agatha’s gaze. Far from the tightness of her jaw, the strong hold of her fingers, her eyes remained soft, almost as if the strain of keeping them open was too much.

Rio wondered if she’d slept. She guessed Jen wouldn’t do what Alice was doing for her and wouldn’t curl up beside her at night. Agatha probably wouldn’t want it anyway.

And as much as Rio was hurting because of the woman holding her tight, she didn’t want to see Agatha suffer.

A couple shots were taken of them - none this time, where either managed to smile.

When they were asked to move to the wall, Agatha still stood first, still turned around. Rio accepted again and didn’t release her hand even as they stood next to each other and allowed the Polaroids to be taken of them in their matching costumes.

The wardrobe team were loud again now, after the awkwardness of the question earlier, and one of them had decided Christmas music would add to the atmosphere.

And Rio just stood, her hand in Agatha’s, their shoulders touching, her feet lifting each time a sock was put on or taken off, a slipper was added or removed.

She’d usually be participating in the nonsense by showing off that she could in fact hold a tune and knew all the lyrics to every single Christmas song that had ever been released. But holding Agatha’s hand and remaining silent was all she could currently manage to do.

“Okay!” Rio glanced over at Geri, one of the other wardrobe assistants helping Agatha. “We’ll go and get a couple of Agatha’s pieces and bring them back over just to check where everything will sit together and we’ll be right back.”

Soon the four women, one couple, two disasters, were left alone to the jaunty sounds of Feliz Navidad.

“I know you’re going through it but don’t joke about kissing my girlfriend.”

Agatha’s fingers twitched in Rio’s and Rio could only sigh, interrupted before she could speak by Alice. “It was a joke, Jen. God knows we all need one.”

Jen’s jaw twitched and then she relaxed it, seemingly with some effort, and Rio cleared her throat quietly as she stepped away from Agatha and released her hand. “I’m sorry. It was a lame joke.”

Jen nodded and Alice spoke again, “Everyone’s just… super fucking tense. That’s all.”

Rio scoffed quietly and went to sit back down on the couch, rubbing her hands over her face. She felt someone else sit down too and looked to see Agatha curling her feet beneath herself.

She looked small in her large sweater and Rio felt like reaching for her again but knew she couldn’t. She’d asked for time and Agatha was giving her space.

She had to make it easier for her to do so by not reaching out constantly.

She made a choice then not to touch her again. It was best for both of them.

No one said anything until the wardrobe ladies were back. It was a painful ten minutes but Rio didn’t raise her gaze anymore. She couldn’t bare to see Agatha still there, now just waiting for her.

But in her torment she soon swung back to the soft promise of anger that had been bubbling away in her stomach all this time - dormant, but ever-present.

She had waited for Agatha, she’d waited months for her, patiently, pliantly. And it pained her even now to see Agatha waiting what was less than three days.

Had it hurt Agatha to make Rio wait? Did Agatha really think that little of her? Did she really despise her? Was this all part of the trick?

“Rio.”

Rio’s head snapped at the sudden sound of Alice’s voice and she looked up to see everyone looking at her expectantly and saw that Agatha was in new clothes now, and Rio would have to do the same.

Doing preventing the thinking. She moved quickly and silently through three more outfits and each time allowed her photo be taken separately and together with Agatha.

The fifth such time they had to wait by the designated wall for the camera to be reloaded and Rio had had enough of silence. In the time she’d spend not thinking she’d also spent looking at Agatha, seeing how exhausted she was, how she kept her gaze down unless she were looking at Rio, or answering a direct question.

And so she cleared her throat quietly, leaning now as she was back against the wall with her hands behind the small of her back.

“Are you sleeping?”

Agatha cleared her throat and Rio glanced at her. “No.”

“Your pills? Are they not-…?”

“I’m not taking them.”

“Agatha. You’ll make yourself sick.”

“I’m fine, Rio.”

Rio shifted an inch, freed her hand and slowly reached for Agatha’s arm but remembered her earlier promise to herself and hesitated before she pulled her hand back and watched blue eyes close. “You don’t look it.”

Agatha laughed, a sad sort of laugh that made Rio want to cry. “So Jen keeps telling me.”

“Tequila helps. It’s helped me.”

“I have Nicky. I can’t get drunk.”

Agatha had said the words softly, barely above a whisper, but they triggered the memory of the accusation thrown at her not three days ago: “you’re a child, you could never be mature enough”.

She released a sigh and hid her hand back behind herself but Agatha had turned fully now, was watching her with a steady gaze. “How long, I mean, how long do you think you’ll need?”

“I can’t answer that.”

Agatha nodded and Rio could only watch as she turned away again. It didn’t take long for Agatha to be ushered behind the curtain once more and Rio was made to wait her turn before she could change.

It was farcical, really. The two of them constantly changing into different sweaters, into velvet dresses or silk shirts, into coats and scarves and gloves and hats, but both remained resolutely unchanged in their misery.

The other thing that remained were their rings. Rio was dressed up in more jewellery, or less depending on the outfit, but the rings on her left finger always remained the same: a gold band to symbolise the union, a round diamond to symbolise Agatha.

She watched too as Agatha was dressed up and down in a variety of jewellery for each costume and with each second of peace she’d always be toying with the ring that Alice had chosen for her, the ring she still believed was from Rio.

In these moments Rio couldn’t bring herself to look for long because any idea that Agatha was deriving comfort from the ring made her feel nauseous. But she was back to wanting to comfort her again, to tell her all was forgiven and all was okay.

But in those moments, those weak moments where she just craved Agatha, she thought of Agatha craving Ralph instead of her and she was able to look away, to stop herself reaching for her.

By the time they were on their tenth change both Jen and Alice excused themselves and Rio and Agatha were left alone with the wardrobe ladies. The atmosphere didn’t change but perhaps Rio felt a little less stifled.

It meant only one set of eyes were on her at all times rather than three.

Jen and Alice didn’t return for another hour and when they did they both looked shell shocked. From where Rio sat in one of the high chairs by the long mirror above the counter they looked as if they’d both been crying.

Not long after that they were released.

Agatha and Jen left, Jen giving Rio a quick kiss on the cheek and Agatha hesitating before she did the same. Only Agatha lingered, she held Rio’s hand, she said quietly: “I’m here, whenever you’re ready. Take… as long as you want.”

Rio could only nod, only look away the moment Agatha pulled back.

It took half an hour for her and Alice to leave after them. Rio was back in her actual clothes feeling exhausted and burnt out. The sun was setting so the sky was a glorious mix of pinks and oranges.

It was a calm night but the storm raged on inside Rio with no hopes of soon abating.

As they made their way across the lot Rio looked up and saw Agatha standing talking to Maria. She looked resplendent in the soft evening glow. The setting sun made it look as though there was a filter on her, a soft lens made to turn up the saturation and make Rio’s heart sing at the sight of the woman she loved.

Agatha turned to her, she paused a while, and then she waved at her, and Rio saw in the velvety light of the evening that Agatha still wore the ring Alice had picked for her and that despite looking exhausted she was still looking at Rio with that tender gaze.

As the last rays of sunshine sprinkled their light across the trailers and the tarmac, Rio left with her best friend and the woman who loved her watched her go, the ring she thought Rio had chosen for her turning round and round on her finger as if she were trying to hasten the clock until Rio was ready to talk.

Chapter End Notes

We're gonna have a lot more of Agatha trying and a lot more of Rio spiralling (its only been 3 days since the *horrors*, remember, they're both still deep in the suffering portion) but they WILL have a talk and Agatha will be honest, trust

Let's see how Rio's new 'no touching' rule works out for both of them huh

Intimacy coordinator next up

and just to reiterate for the people in the back: NO ONE IS PREGNANT but everyone is undernourished, dehydrated, exhausted, and heartbroken - enough to make anyone throw up once in a while

Chapter 33: Intimacy, Coordinated

Chapter Summary

Rio calls for reinforcements to help her with her heartache.

Agatha agrees to whatever Rio wants.

Chapter Notes

This chapter took me so long to write that I actually wrote two other (later) chapters before I finished this one

I’m concerned it’s not great but they can’t all be bangers and I can’t keep staring at it so have at it

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“Morning, sleepyhead.”

Rio huffed and buried herself beneath her duvet. Alice ignored this and tugged it back.

“Hello, Angel! Rise and shine, buttercup! Let’s go, bro!”

“What is wrong with you?”

Rio snatched the duvet back.

“What on earth could you mean, sweetums?”

“Alice!” Her shout was muffled, her mouth now buried under the thick coils of duvet she’d bundled back over herself.

“Get up, would you? I want to show you something.”

Rio groaned and curled up some more, “Sleep is the closest thing I have to-…”

“Don’t you dare say it.”

Rio huffed and felt the prickle of shame across her cheeks, “Fine, Alice.” She grumbled some more as she shoved the heavy fabric from her face and pushed herself into a sitting position. “Show me what?”

“I think it’s important you know how crazed the internet is about Agatha’s casting.”

“Jesus, Alice. Why?”

“Because,” Alice said in a slightly softer voice as she scrambled up to sit beside Rio in the bed, only just about convincing her to let her slip under the blankets with her. “Agatha’s getting a lot of heat from it. From what I can tell and from what Jen thinks-…”

Rio turned her head away when Alice offered her phone to her. She’d avoided any external influence on her thus far, she couldn’t give in now.

“Okay,” Alice said quietly, turning back to her phone as she blindly reached beside her to grab the coffee she’d made Rio earlier and pass it over to her. “I want you to have all the information, that’s all.”

“I don’t need any information.”

Agatha fucked Ralph. Agatha thought she was a child. Agatha had forced them together on a movie where they had to play wives.

What else was there to know?

“Well,” Alice said matter-of-factly, “Would you like to know that everyone is very excited to see you in a Christmas sweater with a kid?”

“Oh?”

Rio huffed out a breath and shuffled down the bed until she could lean her head against Alice’s arm. “Is that supposed to thrill me?”

“Fuel your ego maybe.”

“I doubt people are saying anything about me that doesn’t involve Agatha.”

“Well,” Alice said slowly, as she began to flick through her phone, all of Rio’s socials logged in and ready to go. “There are people who… are very pleased.”

Rio scoffed softly and carefully sipped her coffee. “Good, that’s all that matters.”

“Don’t be a dick. They don’t know. This is a huge win, you know. Agatha Harkness playing a dyke is insane.”

“Alice.”

“I know, I know it’s hard. I just, was hoping knowing how excited people are that it might make it even slightly easier.”

Rio groaned in response, now allowing the hot mug she was holding to burn the sensitive skin of her hands.

She was silent as Alice continued to scroll, occasionally tapping a quick message off to someone but otherwise flicking between Rio’s various social media profiles. She knew what she was doing and what Rio also knew was that she was falling right into Alice’s trap.

“Fine,” she said eventually and sat up, only just avoiding the tsunami of coffee that almost crashed over her swinging cup.

“Show me.”

She kept her gaze down to avoid Alice’s smug smile and kept her eyes trained on the images and tweets Alice had clearly compiled for her. It was a selection of praise for Rio, and she had to admit, she was grateful Alice hadn’t included any of the tweets or posts that included Agatha’s name.

Alice was trying to boost her ego via her fans.

It was sweet and not wholly ineffectual.

Rio took another sip of coffee once she’d had her fill of internet-based compliments.

But the warm glow could only last so long.

“Why is Agatha getting a hard time?”

“I leaked to the press that you were having an affair.”

If Alice had wanted to get Rio out of bed earlier, she really could have just said that.

Rio leapt from the bed, throwing coffee around like it was snow on Christmas and stood over Alice with a look that mingled horror and disbelief. “What the fuck, Alice?!”

Alice, now covered in coffee, blinked up at Rio from beneath her dripping hair. “Okaaaaay… not ready for jokes.”

“That’s not fucking funny.”

Rio stepped from the bed, her knee almost buckling from the height of it, and she stormed into the bathroom, slamming the door behind her.

“Oh come on! You don’t want to get back at her? Even a little bit? Rio!”

“No! Alice! I want to get back with her!”

But her words took her by surprise and she stopped and almost slipped where she’d been leaning into the shower to adjust the temperature.

Alice didn’t bother knocking before just barging in.

“You want to get back with her?”

“I want…” Rio sighed heavily, closed her eyes as she leant against the glass screen. “I want to rewind to a time when the biggest, worst thing was that she was married but unhappy and convince her that I could make her happy.”

“I think,” Alice said in a softer tone than before, “Babe I think she knows you can. Jen said-…”

“Don’t. Please. Just. I’m going to shower and then I’m gonna call my dad. Mom will be mad I haven’t called in over a week anyway and… and I need to speak to my dad.”

She could feel the indecision in Alice’s hesitance to leave but said nothing as she turned to the sink and grabbed her toothbrush. By the time it was carrying the toothpaste, Alice had gone.

In the mirror she saw a version of herself that she didn’t like.

She looked pale and tired and exactly like the kind of woman who would willingly allow her heart to be pummelled.

She didn’t look long.

She showered and changed into the clothes Alice had left for her in the bed - soft sweatpants and a grey t-shirt with a matching grey cardigan with a vintage argyle pattern. Her phone, plugged in and charging, again because of Alice, lay on the side and she unlocked it, ignored the little red circles that told her people were trying to reach her and instead dialled for her dad.

“¡Mija! ¿Dónde has estado? Tu madre se ha vuelto loca sin hablarte durante tanto tiempo.” Daughter! Where have you been? Your mother has been going crazy without speaking to you for so long.

Her dad’s voice was enough to make her have to fight back the tears. She must have breathed heavily, must have alerted him with a loud inhalation because Miguel’s tone shifted immediately: “Cariño, ¿qué pasa?”

It took a few seconds, and her hand holding firm against her chest to prevent her heart simply leaping out and slipping down the phone to her dad but she eventually managed to get out: “No le digas a mamá, ¿de acuerdo?” Don’t tell mom, okay?

And she told him. She told him everything. Minus anything a dad wouldn’t want to hear: exactly why she was on her knees, some of the more graphic details, Agatha’s request for her to put a baby in her, things like that.

And by the time she was done Alice was back in the room, ready to try and hurry Rio until she saw and heard what she was doing. Her mission to hasten soon became a mission to hold.

Rio clung to her friend’s hand as she clung to her dad’s soft words.

“Tienes un buen corazón. Tienes un corazón amoroso. Tu madre y yo te hemos amado con fervor, te hemos protegido, te hemos cuidado. Tenemos suerte de tenerte, mucha suerte. Pero, mi amor, Agatha no ha tenido eso. No la conozco mucho, pero tengo que creer que cualquiera a quien ames tanto es digno de ello. Eres mi hija, tienes mi corazón y te lo confío. Tómate un tiempo para pensar, para sanar un poco, para respirar y ve si después de hacerlo puedes dejar que ella te explique.” You have a good heart. You have a loving heart. Your mother and I have loved you fiercely, protected you, cared for you. We are lucky to have you, so lucky. But, my love, Agatha hasn’t had that. I don't know her well, but I have to believe that anyone who you love this much is worthy of it. You are my daughter, you have my heart, and I trust you with it. Take some time to think, to heal a little, to breathe, and see if, after you have, you can let her explain.

Rio hung up after agreeing to call her dad again that evening.

Alice kissed her face and dried her tears but said nothing as Rio soon led the way down the stairs, wondering why she ever thought acting for a living was a good idea when she could instead be in a normal nine to five watching a pretty actress with pretty blue eyes and wondering what it might be like to kiss her.

“We need to get your car back,” Alice muttered as she pulled away from the curb and drove off.

Rio just shrugged, her head lolling back on the headrest as she looked out the window, her mind elsewhere. “I’m not going anywhere near that house.”

“You’re rich now,” Alice laughed, “people can do things for you in exchange for money, remember?”

Rio blindly slapped at her friend and chewed the inside of her cheek, “Okay, will you arrange it? Might take myself off to the beach tomorrow night.”

“Wait,” Alice said slowly, “I’ll drive. That’s not a problem. I-…”

“Alice, I didn’t say I’m going to the beach with stones in my pocket. I just need some time alone.”

Alice was silent for a while which left Rio to imagine the tiny monkey in her brain that was clashing cymbals every time Rio even suggested she take some time to be alone.

“Fine. Fine. I just, I want you to be okay.”

“I know.” With a sigh she reached for her friend’s hand. “Are you okay? I’m sorry I was mute last night. Tell me about you. About Jen.”

Looking into Alice’s face now she saw hesitation and concern and once again Rio thanked the universe that Alice couldn’t act for shit. “What is it?”

“We’re moving in together.”

In the place Rio’s heart had once been something darker and insidious appeared. And it became clear in her best friend’s joy that the old Rio Vidal had been razed to nothing.

“Alice, that’s amazing. Why didn’t you say anything?”

She felt sick. She turned away from Alice.

“I was worried that… I want you to know that I’m here for you. Still. Always. We’re only going to make the move when everything is a little more easy.”

She wanted to cry.

“You don’t need to worry about me.”

“But I do. And Jen’s worried about Agatha. We fought about it.”

Oh good. Alice and Jen fight and they end up moving in. Agatha and Rio fight and Rio ends up wanting to die.

Fair.

Totally.

Utterly.

Fair.

“I’m so happy for you.”

“You, you don’t have to lie.”

Rio squeezed Alice’s hand.

“I’m truly, totally, utterly, thrilled for you.”

“Yeah?”

Rio looked over and Alice was crying the tears Rio wished she could shed. Only hers were happy and Rio’s were bitter.

“Of course!”

Alice pulled her hand away to wipe her eyes.

“She wants to make you guys talk and I said it was too soon.”

Rio turned away again.

“Do you want to talk to her?”

Her hands twisted and formed a complicated knot in her lap.

“I want this all to be over.”

I want to fight and end up moving in. I want to rage and end up married. I want to break down and die in her arms when I’m a hundred and happy.

“Tell me how I can help.”

Rio sighed, closed her eyes, said the thing she knew was right but that felt impossible to vocalise.

“Move in with Jen. Be happy with her.”

Alice glanced across at her but Rio remained with her eyes closed, no longer interested in a world where she could have been so misled.

“Rio.”

“I mean it, Alice.”

She forced her eyes open, forced herself to look at her friend, to give her an Oscar-winning smile, “You gotta be happy for the both of us. That’s all you need to do for me.”

Alice looked at her and the bitterness in her chest died in an instant. For a second she thought that maybe, just maybe she’d be okay. She had a best friend who loved her, a family who would do anything for her, and a motherfucking Oscar.

“Babe, you’re so full of shit.”

They locked eyes, and laughed at the same time; suddenly living didn’t feel as hard anymore.

Seven more times on the journey from Rio’s house to the set did Alice promise she wouldn’t move out until Rio was feeling better. Seven more times did Rio reassure Alice that that absolutely wasn’t necessary.

They agreed to disagree and Alice agreed that she’d stay at least a couple more weeks and Rio agreed that she’d keep the dying jokes to a minimum during that time.

But all through of dying dissolved in Rio’s addled brain as she stepped, for the first time, into her new trailer. Alice had clearly worked her magic behind the scenes.

“You’re a goddamn Oscar winner now. You get a whole bedroom in one of these bad boys and everything!”

Rio laughed as she took in the work her best friend had done to make the typically dry and beige space a cosy hangout for her. On the wall there was a basketball hoop with a bunch of mini basketballs sitting patiently in it for any downtime she’d have.

The couch in the middle of the space against the back wall was full of cushions and throws and dotted about the place were photos of Rio’s family, of her and Alice, of her and her friends.

“When did you have time to do this?”

“Didn’t I tell you earlier? Money means people will do things for you.”

Rio rolled her eyes and sent a light punch towards Alice’s shoulder. “It’s cute. It’s great. Thank you.”

“Well, I figured it’s going to be a long shoot. You deserve some comfort.”

With that, Rio found she could relax a while in her new on set home. These four walls would become, would have to become her sanctuary. But there was also a danger they could become her prison.

Rio moved around her new space, luxuriating in the largest trailer she’d ever been given, and in the thoughtful touches either the studio or Alice had added to make it feel comfortable. The bed was large and Alice, she assumed, had bedecked it with forest green sheets. The kitchen was well stocked with Rio’s favourite snacks and drinks. Upon closer inspection, even the bathroom had all her familiar products in it.

And Rio realised with a sinking feeling that she’d have to try hard not to make this a prison for herself. Because in here she could be comfortable and outside was Agatha.

Alice soon insisted on breakfast and ran out to craft services to fetch Rio a bagel and a fresh coffee and they ate happily together, with Alice leading much of the conversation and steering it towards basketball or the exact volume of Rio’s snoring from the night before (“loud, Rio, very loud”).

But it could only really last for so long and a knock at the door told them that fun time was over. Alice answered it and the sunny, bright Pepper Potts stepped inside the cosy space, her eyes taking in the basketball hoop and the added cushions before they fell to Rio.

“Morning! I like what you’ve done with the place!”

“All Alice,” Rio demurred as she stepped in to give Pepper a quick hug.

“Well it looks fabulous.”

Rio smiled and offered Pepper a coffee, which she refused as she took a seat on the couch.

“Alice, if you don’t mind, these sessions always work best when-…”

“That’s fine,” Alice said with a quick smile though Rio noticed it didn’t quite meet her eyes. “Rio, I’ll be around just call me when you’re done.”

Rio shot her friend a smile and then settled down onto the couch.

The room felt charged suddenly, and what was left of Rio’s heart sat solidly in her throat.

“So,” Pepper began with a slap to her thighs and a kind smile, “Have you done this sort of thing before?”

“Not with an intimacy coordinator, no.”

“Well I’m here to make this easier for everyone. We want to create a calm, easy environment where everything but a firm ‘yes’ means ‘no’, okay?”

Rio wanted to shrug just to see which way Pepper would interpret that but instead she nodded. “Yes.”

“Great!”

Pepper reached down for her notebook and pulled a pen out of her bag. “Now, sometimes I find that actors are more nervous about the stuff we’re talking about than actual sex scenes. How are you feeling generally about everything? This is all private, so you don’t need to worry about me blabbing to Agatha or Maria. I’ll be your advocate, but it all stays in this room, okay?”

Rio nodded, wondering again if a simple shrug would suffice as an answer though something told her it wouldn’t.

“I feel fine.”

Pepper nodded, looked down at her notebook and flipped a few pages. “Just fine?”

“Yes.”

“Okay,” Pepper uncapped her pen. “Is there anything outlined in the script you feel not fine about?”

Everything.

“No.”

Pepper hummed thoughtfully and scribbled Rio’s name down in her book. “So, all good with everything as written?”

“Yes.”

The next thing Pepper wrote Rio couldn’t quite make out.

“Easy,” Pepper said with a grin, finally looking back up at Rio. “That’s my job done.”

“Really?”

“No.”

Rio’s brief moment of relief died upon meeting Pepper’s gaze and she saw in her a woman who wouldn’t back down easily.

“Look,” she said slowly, “I’m fine with… it’s really whatever’s needed.”

“Rio, I understand the desire to placate or be amenable but-…”

“I really, just… am fine with everything.”

Pepper watched her steadily for a few seconds before she tilted her head, “I was told you were easy to work with, but there’s easy to work with and then there’s not advocating for yourself. Tell me, are you comfortable with everything as is?”

Rio swallowed, looked down at her hands, tugged unconsciously at her left ring finger. Her empty left ring finger.

Agatha had given her a fake ring to wear but she’d not given her any reason to trust anything she did. A fake ring meant nothing.

Her sleeping with her husband the night Rio had first said ‘I love you’, that meant something.

“No kissing,” she said quickly, hoping if she said it fast it might be missed, “no touching anywhere other than hands. No sitting together in a… always with someone in between, the kid or, whoever. And I’m not saying ‘I love you’. The bed scene. The more kids one, I want that out too.”

It was more demanding than Rio had ever been in her career, more exacting than she’d ever dared to be. But she’d done it, she’d said it, and Pepper had promised her discretion, so it felt safe to have done so.

Though she couldn’t figure out why she felt so sick all of a sudden.

She looked back up and to her surprise Pepper didn’t look surprised. In fact, she didn’t look much of anything.

But she nodded, she scribbled some notes down, she placed her pen carefully on the coffee table.

“Okay. We can work around these things. There are ways we can make them more comfortable for you.”

“No, I… take them out.”

Pepper cleared her throat and Rio wondered if she’d ever been told anything like this before, if she’d ever had to negotiate with an actor before. But as the concept of arguing a point triggered in her mind so did something else: “Have you spoken to Agatha yet?”

“We’re focusing on you for now.”

Rio cleared her throat and looked down at her hands again. She was suddenly playing with her ring finger and wondered why she’d never done that before and why now it felt empty all of a sudden.

“I don’t want to be difficult.”

“Like I said, the goal is everyone to feel comfortable. I’ll work with you until you do, okay?”

Rio stole her hand away to run through her hair and cleared her throat again. “What did Agatha say?”

“We’re focusing on you, remember?”

“No, I… right. Was she okay? Comfortable, I mean?”

Pepper reached back for her pen again, “We met this morning. She didn’t have a lot to say, and was fine with everything.”

“She wants to kiss me?”

God, she was pathetic. God, she hated herself.

“Has someone got a crush?”

No. She hated Pepper.

“It’s okay,” Pepper continued as Rio thought about how she could kill either one of them. “I thought I picked up on something at the table read and honestly I thought she was more into you but then again, she’s happily married, right?”

Pepper smiled a little and Rio thought that maybe of the two choices of victim in the room now she’d rather throw herself upon her own sword.

Or perhaps Pepper’s pen.

Whatever was pointy enough to get through to the black heart in her chest.

“It’s okay to have a crush, Rio. She’s a very attractive woman.”

Rio stood quickly, marching to the little kitchenette to grab a bottle of water just for something to do.

She hadn’t had a crush on Agatha since she was a teenager. When she was seventeen she’d seen her at her local cinema up on the big screen with those blue eyes and that perfect face and had then opened to see that face when the lights were out and her hand was between her thighs for many, many nights.

If only she felt the way her teenage self felt now; that she’d like to kiss Agatha but not that she’d die if she couldn’t ever be with her properly again.

“I don’t have a crush on Agatha,” Rio said carefully as she walked back over, water bottle in hand. “I just… I’m not comfortable with some of the stage directions, that’s all.”

Pepper nodded, not looking up but now flicking through her script. “Have you mentioned any of this to Agatha? From what Tony said I-…” She looked up then, her blue eyes a little wider than usual, perhaps due to her indiscretion. “Sorry, spousal privilege, I hear a lot at home I probably…”

“What were you going to say?”

“Just that,” Pepper cleared her throat and began to tap her fingers against her script, but Rio tried to keep her face neutral as she waited for the answer. “Just that Agatha was getting progressively… that she really wanted this part. I assumed because you were friends, that’s all.”

Rio nodded slowly, briefly thinking of poor Wanda now stuck in a snowy Atlanta doing pickups for her latest movie when she should be here, in the mild climate of LA, not making Rio feel like she wanted to die.

Those thoughts are what clinched it.

Agatha had forced her into this. She’d forced everyone into it.

So, no, she wouldn’t kiss her. She wouldn’t lie in bed with her and whisper that she wanted another kid with her. She wouldn’t wrap her arms around her in every scene or tell her she loved her.

“Take it all out, Pepper.”

“I can advocate for you, Rio. That’s no problem. Looking through it… most will just mean different shots, different placements, which I think we can work around. There is, of course,” and here she paused, here she tilted her head and put on her best school teacher voice, “we could use doubles for any of the scenes you don’t want to do.”

Kissing Agatha was one thing. Not kissing Agatha another. But watching a fake her kiss a fake Agatha, or worse, actual Agatha? Hell on Earth.

“No. I want none of it. Nothing.” Because I want all of it. Everything.

Pepper nodded and scribbled down some more notes. Rio just watched, now tossing the bottle between her hands.

“This afternoon the three of us will meet to discuss how we’ll be doing this. And later in the week we have rehearsal time to help choreograph but… looks like there won’t be much to choreograph.”

It was a lame attempt at a joke but Rio couldn’t bring herself to give a lame laugh.

“In the meantime,” Pepper said more gently, “I’ll be around if you need me or if there’s anything you want to discuss.”

Rio nodded. “Is that everything?”

“I’ll leave you to your morning.”

Rio stood to show Pepper out although it was pretty obvious where the door was in the small rectangle space of the trailer. When they’d said their goodbye she took her seat up again on the sofa and placed her head in her hands.

Twenty minutes later, Alice found her in the exact same position.

“You were supposed to call me when you were done. It was only when I saw Pepper by crafty that… It went well then?”

“Shut up.”

“Jen said Agatha’s not happy about it.”

“Yeah? Well she should have thought of that before she put us in this situation.”

Alice took a seat beside her but Rio had yet to move.

“We seem to be hovering around the anger and depression steps quite a bit…”

“Fuck, Alice. Can you stop trying to make jokes!”

Alice flinched as Rio’s hands flew into the air and she sighed heavily as she touched her friend’s knee, “It was more an observation.”

“Jesus.”

“Look,” Alice said a bit more firm this time, her hand following her words and squeezing Rio’s knee. “What can I do? What would make this better for you?”

“I dunno. Rewind time and prevent Ralph fucking Bohner from ever being born.”

“Well, my Time Machine is on the fritz right now but I’ll see what I can do.”

Rio smiled, a tentative ghost of a smile, but a smile all the same.

“I told Pepper to take out all the intimate scenes. No kissing, no cuddling, nothing remotely couple-y.”

Alice nodded slowly and moved her hand from Rio’s knee to her back, “In a big budget queer movie?”

Rio returned her head to her hands, “Jesus fuck.”

“Just something to keep in mind,” Alice said in such a soft voice that Rio wanted to smack her out of it. “Maybe you take them out for now but as shooting starts you can-…”

“Right,” Rio reasoned, though didn’t quite believe, “it’ll get easier. Maybe I’ll… yeah, yeah, okay.”

She felt scrambled again, torn between what was real and true and what could be, what should be, what she wanted.

The only thing that grounded her were her dad’s words from that morning: she had to take time. She had to let time heal as apparently it did. Though perhaps this wound wasn’t for healing.

Alice was rubbing her back now, being as gentle as she could with it, but Rio only wanted that gentleness she’d found in Agatha. She only wanted…

“When is our next day off?”

“Sunday,” Alice said with a slight lilt of surprise in her voice, “Next Sunday. So, dress rehearsals from tomorrow, which means-…”

“Over a week, Alice. I can do the math.”

“Right.”

Rio fumbled the number around in her brain, let it stretch and sink and twist until it felt okay, until it felt feasible.

“I’ll get through the week and then… then I’ll speak to Agatha. Properly.”

“Really?”

Rio nodded, feeling choked suddenly, “If I speak to her now. If I find out how he-… if she tells me what happened that night, what actually happened I’ll murder him, or myself maybe. I don’t, I…”

“Rio,” Alice breathed out as she attempted to pull Rio into her arms, “Rio, maybe we-…”

But Rio shook her head, wiping furiously at the tears that had spilled over. “Don’t. Please. I don’t want to be touched.”

Alice dropped her hands immediately but remained close and even that felt too much for Rio. Her body couldn’t take any more hands on her that weren’t Agatha’s - and she’d promised herself she wouldn’t even have those, she’d even made Pepper take it out of the script.

Alice was silent as Rio cried into her hands, but disappeared to fetch a box of tissues and handed them over when it seemed like Rio had cried herself dry.

“A week. It’ll be busy, and Agatha isn’t the only one here. There’ll be plenty of distractions and plenty of-…”

“Alice.”

Alice shut right up and cautiously reached to rub Rio’s back again. “You’re not alone in this, Rio.”

She didn’t know how she could possibly tell good, kind, helpful Alice that she’d never felt more alone in her life. That even though she was sitting in a trailer made out of the love Alice had for her, even though her hand was now rubbing soft circles on her back, even though her phone contained evidence of all the people in her life who’d reached out, and the frames dotted about the place contained their smiles, she felt totally, utterly, alone.

But her feelings of isolation and desolation only got worse as morning turned to afternoon and her meeting with Pepper and Agatha loomed larger.

Alice walked with her to the room in the main studio building and left her at the door, which she knocked, received a “come in, Rio!”, and entered.

It was a larger space than she’d assumed, brighter too, with a large window at the back and soft furnishings in the centre, it could easily have been a nice room, if it weren’t for the two people now staring at her as she moved further in.

“Rio!” Pepper, friendly as ever, moved over to hug Rio and Rio reluctantly hugged her back. But over Pepper’s shoulder she watched the woman who hadn’t moved to greet her but watched her with tired, cautious eyes.

“Good, now we’re all here.”

Pepper pulled away and Rio hadn’t realised she’d been using her as a crutch to keep her from falling down at the sight of Agatha so she swayed a little as she did. Agatha had twitched in her chair but Rio had looked away and missed it.

“Sit, Rio. Do you want a water?”

“No,” Rio said as she took the seat opposite Agatha. “Fine, thanks.”

“Great!”

God, Pepper being peppy was really not what she needed right now.

Rio kept her gaze on Pepper though, because she could feel Agatha’s on her and she couldn’t handle meeting it.

Pepper looked expectantly at both actresses but when neither responded she cleared her throat and continued: “Let’s get started then, shall we?”

Neither responded. Rio dared to look at Agatha and saw in her face a similar pain to the one she felt in her chest, in her stomach, in the fingers that briefly stretched on the arm of her chair as if to reach for her.

“So, a few notes. I’ve spoken to Maria and she’s comfortable with making the accommodations.”

Agatha’s jaw flexed and she looked away from Rio.

“First we have the car journey to the house. No issues there. Some handholding, so all good. Then the first kiss under the mistletoe at the door. We’re removing that.”

“Pardon me?”

Rio closed her eyes and dropped her chin to her chest.

“It’s,” Pepper began slowly, and Rio could only imagine what Agatha’s face looked like to make the positive Pepper falter a little. “Being replaced by a hug.”

“So we’re just going to hug under the mistletoe? That’s ridiculous.”

“Agatha.” Pepper tried again.

Rio looked up again, chewing on her lip now. Agatha was mutinous, her pale skin taught as she flexed and unflexed her jaw, clearly working something out.

“No that’s insane. Take the whole scene out. Who said no kissing?”

And maybe it was the look on Rio’s face or perhaps it was the way Pepper looked away but realisation dawned and Agatha said: “oh.”

She turned to Rio and raised her brows, her mouth still forming that perfect ‘o’ for a few seconds before she said in a soft voice: “You took it out?”

Rio cleared her throat and looked down at her feet, wondering if there were any possible way to suddenly make herself disappear. “Well. I…”

“Agatha?” Pepper was trying her best. “There are no rights or wrongs to how we do this. We’re working to keep everyone comfortable and to aid the creative process, okay?”

Agatha’s mouth opened and then closed and then repeated. Rio looked up then looked away. She cleared her throat and trained her gaze on Pepper, hoping she’d break the ice that had swallowed the room.

But upon seeing her stricken face, Rio realised with a sinking heart that she wasn’t going to be much help.

“Agatha,” Pepper tried again.

“No, no, we’re a queer couple it’s important we kiss. I-…” but Agatha had stopped herself and Rio wondered if she’d been about to go on a tirade and had chosen to do this calmly instead for fear of unleashing on Rio similar to the day this had all begun.

Or maybe she’d just said the quiet part out loud. “Queer couple”.

Blue eyes flashed as they met Rio’s and for the briefest of moments Agatha no longer looked like the shell of her former self she’d been these past few days. She was once again confident, arrogant, and determined.

“People will want to see it,” she continued, “It’s important.”

Rio looked away, frustrated beyond belief at Agatha’s reasoning, though she knew it to be true even Alice had said it earlier. It was important they represented a happy, healthy, loving queer couple in what was sure to be one of the biggest movies of the year.

But, still, churning resentment and confused feelings made her mutter: “Since when do you care about my community?”

Movement in her periphery made her look up and she saw that Agatha now looked impossibly more furious and her hand was running through her hair, making it look wilder than even before.

“I think,” Pepper began cautiously, “that we’ve got off on the wrong foot.” She stood slowly and Rio watched in trepidation as she approached Agatha. The brunette flinched when Pepper reached out to her arm and Rio had to look away again, wondering if Agatha would have flinched if she’d been the one to reach out.

“Agatha’s right,” she said before either of the other two could speak again, “It’s important people see it. We need to hold hands and touch and kiss like any other happy couple. We have a platform, a duty to give that to people.”

She kept her gaze on her hands as she said this, on the fingers in her lap that were twisting and tugging, pulling at each other just so Rio could rid herself of some of her nervous energy.

“Okay,” Pepper said calmly, though she wasn’t one of the actresses in the room so Rio could hear the strain in her voice. “Rio, why don’t we talk about this in private?”

“No,” Rio said far faster than she meant to. “It’s fine. Put it back in.”

She looked up then and saw that Agatha had moved over to the window and had her back to her now as she stared out of it. The tension in the room was tangible still, and Agatha turning her back on it only made it worse.

But Rio couldn’t take her eyes off of her, didn’t even notice when Pepper came to sit by her and was muttering to herself about running everything through the studio’s HR.

And as Rio stared, as her eyes followed the line of Agatha’s legs, as she watched the light tap, tap, tap of the toes of her right foot on the floor, she realised something she’d never truly thought of before.

Her community was Agatha’s community.

It had always been Agatha’s community. She’d just never reached out to it, never let it embrace her, and never embraced it back.

She turned to Pepper still muttering beside her and softly asked, “Do you speak Spanish?”

“What?” Pepper looked up, all confusion and stress, “Oh. No. Do you need something, or-…?”

“No, don’t worry.”

Pepper smiled absently as she turned back to her notes and Rio cleared her throat as she looked back around at Agatha, still stood leaning against the windowsill.

“También es tu comunidad. Te acogerían. Te amarían.” It’s your community too. They would embrace you. They would love you.

Agatha shifted slightly, and Rio saw her tense for a second before she turned to look at her over her shoulder. The cut of her jaw, the curve of her cheek, it was like crack to Rio. She longed to go to her and caress her face, to lean into her and feel her wrap around her, feel the hum of her throat as she kissed along it.

But no touching meant no touching.

And, besides, she wasn’t sure Pepper would appreciate the show.

“No necesito una comunidad.” I don’t need a community.

“Is everything… alright?” Pepper asked carefully because she couldn’t understand what they were saying but she could hear the emotion in their voices.

“Lo necesitas.” You need it.

Agatha’s jaw tensed more and Rio stood which made her turn properly, and Rio saw that she looked glassy eyed and she was now gripping the windowsill behind her so tightly her knuckles were white.

“Can we continue? I haven’t got all day.”

And she was gone again. Agatha had hidden herself once more.

Rio sat down, dropped her head down and held it in her hands, feeling the short strands that she still wasn’t used to as she ran her fingers through her hair.

“Okay, let’s, let’s take a breather and then we can go again.”

Rio nodded where she now rested her elbows on her thighs and kept her gaze down. She only knew Agatha had moved back over because she heard her come and take the seat opposite.

Pepper was flicking through the script she’d made notes on and Rio dared to look up. She saw Agatha watching her already, her eyes still glassy, her lower lip tugged between her teeth. But when she caught Rio’s eyes she turned away, visibly swallowed, and Rio felt her heart fall into her stomach.

“Agatha?”

Agatha looked around at the sound of her name from Rio’s lips and Rio suddenly felt like she had nothing to say to her, at least nothing that would make this right. She shook her head a little, dropped her gaze again and found herself staring at the floor once more.

“Okay,” Pepper said riffling the sheets like a newscaster on a particularly bad news day.

“Eres tan terco.” You're so stubborn.

“Rio perhaps we should speak in English now.”

Rio sighed heavily and looked up again. Agatha was looking away still, working her jaw as if she intended to break it.

“Okay,” Pepper tried again, taking Rio’s silence as agreement that they could continue, and in English this time.

“The next big scene is in the kitchen when-…”

“Actually, I don’t want to do this today. I’ll agree to whatever Rio is comfortable with.” Agatha stood up, her eyes trained on Pepper, “Whatever she wants.”

“Agatha,” both women tried, the blonde of the two following it up with, “The studio demands you have these sessions, Agatha.” Agatha was marching towards the door now, “It’s just agreeing to what we do in the scenes, it’s making everybody-“ Agatha had reached the door, “comfortable.” The door slammed behind her as she left.

“Well,” Pepper said as Rio stood up and began to mimic Agatha’s journey to the door, “that’s certainly never happened,” Rio reached the door, “before.” Rio slammed it on her way out.

To her surprise Agatha was just outside, her head against her hands as she leant against the wall and took long, deep, slow breaths. Rio watched in shock for a second and then moved silently and broke her rule by placing her hand against Agatha’s back.

Agatha didn’t flinch like she had with Pepper.

“I just need a minute,” Agatha said quietly, her voice hoarse.

The door opened again and Pepper appeared in the hallway looking concerned, “Is everything-…?”

“Fine,” both Agatha and Rio said quickly. Pepper blinked, and only when Rio nodded at her did she nod back and disappear back into their room.
