Rio’s hand had at some point curled into the fabric of Agatha’s sweater and she turned now to see the fist in the fabric and released it suddenly. “Do you need some water?”

“No.”

Rio pulled her hand away entirely and nodded but moved to stand against the wall beside Agatha, “I’ll just stand here then.”

It took a couple minutes but Agatha’s breathing slowly returned to normal and Rio felt her move beside her so turned to see Agatha had angled her head around to peek out at Rio from where it still rested against her hands.

“You don’t need to be here.”

“I’m preventing you from getting a huge fine from the studio.”

“I can handle a fine.”

Rio scoffed and for a fleeting moment she felt lightness surround them until Agatha had turned her head once more and was looking at her with those eyes. God those eyes.

Rio faltered, her body glitched, her mind blank because Agatha was still looking at her. She could feel her gaze flicker across her skin like an electric current pattering its way over her face, never settling, just constantly searching.

“Is it over?”

The current became dangerous suddenly.

“Do you want it to be?”

“No.” Agatha pushed herself off the wall and for a moment Rio thought she was going to turn, thought she was going to leave, but she simply stayed in place, tentatively reaching for Rio’s sleeve. “I’ve never wanted that.”

Then why did you sleep with your husband?

Why did you leave me?

Why did you say all those things?

Do you actually love me, Agatha?

“A funny way of showing that,” was what came out of her mouth instead. Barely a whisper but enough to make Agatha’s gaze drop. The downward tilt of her baby blues made the light that had been flickering in her irises stutter and then die.

Rio watched as she stared at her hand now clutching her sleeve, saw the tightness around her eyes that seemed to hold as she said, “Shout. Please. Shout at me. Scream at me. Hit me. But don’t-…”

“Hit you? Hit you?”

The second time Rio broke her rule was far worse than the first. Clutching at a loose sweater was one thing but stepping in and placing her hands on warm cheeks was entirely another.

But there was no stopping it. Rio wouldn’t have stopped for a stampede. The thundering of her heart wouldn’t let her. The blood boiling in her veins made her reckless.

But her hands, her hands were soft because they now held something precious in them again. Agatha had returned to them.

“Has he hit you?”

Some things aren’t consciously thought but done anyway: like breathing, like trying to tread water when drowning. And so Rio knew, instinctively, like a primal urge to stay alive, that if Agatha answered in the affirmative then she would kill Ralph Bohner.

She would gladly go down for his murder and spend the rest of her days in solitary confinement knowing that she’d put the bastard six feet under.

“Rio,” Agatha breathed out, her hands now clutching at Rio’s wrists, stepping into her space.

“No. Answer. Answer the question.”

Agatha breathed in shakily, and Rio’s thumbs began to move of their own accord, tracing the familiar line of Agatha’s cheekbones.

“Agatha I swear. I swear.”

“He hasn’t. He… no he hasn’t.”

Rio searched Agatha’s features for any sign of a lie but knew she could hide it from her if she really wanted to. Still, she knew in her heart that given the opportunity she’d murder the husband. She’d destroy his stupid, smug…

“Stop being…”

Rio raised her brows a little at the familiar request. Her dad had been right. Agatha had never had care thrown at her in her life, she’d never experienced the touch of someone who considered her to be worth gentleness, worth everything.

But the truth was more complicated than that because Rio felt far from gentle. She felt far from able to protect Agatha let alone show her the care she used to or that Agatha clearly needed.

She felt useless, pathetic, and like nothing, though she felt everything.

Her thumbs still tracing that same pattern over warm cheeks suddenly felt a tear beneath them, “Just please fight me. Please scream or-…”

Rio closed her eyes, felt Agatha tug at her, and when she opened them again Agatha was crying properly, silently, her face broken beneath Rio’s still gentle hold. “Why won’t you fight?”

“That’s not how this works, Agatha.”

“I don’t-… I don’t understand-… how are you not-… how is this not tearing you apart?”

Rio laughed then, a fake sound that seemed to rattle Agatha even as it pained Rio. “You think you haven’t broken me? You think Alice is staying in my house to keep me company? You don’t think that every time I see you I want to forgive you and let you crush me again and again?”

Her hold dropped and Agatha’s tightened, “How do you not see what you’ve done to me?”

“Rio I… I know I’ve… please…”

“I haven’t shouted because-…” and Rio thought she’d have to fight her off but she simply let go the moment Rio’s hands crossed over covered hers on her sleeves. “Because I… I can’t process the… Jesus, Agatha!”

She stumbled backwards, tripping over her own feet god knows how and landing unceremoniously, pathetically, on her ass. Agatha lurched forwards in an attempt to catch her before she fell but missed by a fraction of an inch.

It was so humiliating that Rio thought she’d blacked out for a second. But then strong arms were around her and she was being heaved up to her feet again and before she could question it she was standing once more before Agatha, her waist held, her coccyx aching.

And because Agatha held her, because she was warm and Rio didn’t want her to see her face, she pressed herself into her and the third time she broke her rule she broke it totally and utterly.

Standing in the middle of a corridor in the depths of a studio building, Rio Vidal gave herself over to Agatha Harkness.

If only Pepper could witness the intimacy on display; the way Agatha ducked her head down to hide herself against Rio’s throat, the way Rio buried her hands and her nose in Agatha’s hair and breathed her in properly for the first time since Agatha had told her the truth about London.

It was inconceivable that Rio could ever get over Agatha now. It seemed laughable that she had even considered that one day she might be able to say Agatha’s name or see her on the side of buses or on billboards and not yearn, not feel the pang of lost love.

Because as Agatha held her more tight than she ever had before she knew she needed answers more than she needed the time to heal, to process, to mourn what she’d lost.

Turning her face down she felt the heat radiating off of Agatha as she remained hidden against her, felt her breath so tantalisingly close to her lips, felt the need more than ever to turn fully and kiss her. But this one thing she managed to hold back on.

She inhaled sharply when Agatha turned into her and for a second she almost lost her one last thread of self control. They raised their heads together, and Rio’s hand fell back to Agatha’s cheek, her thumb just pressing on the corner of her lips, providing a slight barrier to stop her closing the distance fully.

Rio swallowed, watched with hooded eyes as Agatha turned the inch needed to kiss the pad of her thumb, watched as she turned back, nuzzled their noses together, breathed out heavily, hotly against her own parted lips.

“Agatha,” she choked out, her throat catching on the second syllable as if trying to prevent her from saying out loud the name of the person she wanted so desperately now. “Next Sunday. When we can have a full day together… We can talk.”

Agatha’s eyes fluttered closed and Rio’s thumb brushed in a downwards swipe, pressing against the pillow of her lower lip. She watched as Agatha kissed her there again, almost enveloping her the tip of her thumb with her upper lip.

“I want,” she tried, shifting a little as she pulled her thumb away, “I want you to tell me everything and… and be ready to. I can’t take-…” she released a breath and Agatha looked up at her, purposefully nudging their noses together again. “I can’t take anymore secrets.”

Agatha only nodded against her and Rio worried she wasn’t speaking because she didn’t want to promise something she couldn’t deliver.

But then Rio became distracted again, her mind torn between agony and giving up. And she looked, she properly looked at Agatha’s face. Her gaze swept over her makeup free, pale skin, danced along the barely there lines beside her eyes, at the downwards turn of her soft lips.

Up close Agatha looked more than exhausted, she looked bone-tired, and Rio wondered how she was still standing. She took a breath, and then said before she could think, “Did you sleep? Did you… did you take your pills last night?”

Agatha shook her head again, and Rio realised she was leaning more into her, and was being careful not to scare her hands away as they continued to cradle her face.

“You need to sleep,” she said quietly, feeling her voice crack beneath the strain of the hurt. “Agatha you’ll… you’ll make yourself…”

The sensation of it was magnificent; how her heart could be so broken and yet so alight with pain all in one go. Because Agatha wasn’t able to sleep without her, or without the medication she took to switch her brain off. And when she did sleep, at least without Rio, whatever haunted her steps, haunted her dreams.

She watched her for a second longer, took in all that was Agatha Harkness, tried to reason with herself, to fight off the urge to do what she so desperately wanted to do next. And Rio was a fighter, but she lost this battle.

She pulled away, dropped her hands from Agatha’s warm face, and kept her gaze on her as she shrugged herself out of her cardigan. It was warm and soft in her hand as she held it out to Agatha, no, pressed it to her chest. It wasn’t a gift, it was a lifeline. It had to be given.

“Take it. I know… I…” I know you like to be close.

She shook her head as she lost the ability to speak and Agatha’s left hand curled around her own on the cardigan.

“I… don’t deserve it.”

Rio closed her eyes, felt the pain again as fresh as ever flare up in her chest. But Agatha had the cardigan now. She had the piece of clothing that would smell like Rio, that would hopefully help her to sleep, and so she pulled away again.

She stepped back and in doing so felt the horror of being separated from Agatha once more.

But Rio stepped around her to head back inside and found Agatha had grasped her wrist and stopped her on her way. She turned to her, saw the way she still flushed the grey cardigan to her chest, saw the panic in her eyes. “I can’t go back in. I can’t be told what-… I just can’t be told how to touch you. Not by someone who isn’t you. Take out whatever you need, change whatever makes you comfortable. I’ll take whatever fine they give me for not finishing the session but I can’t be in there.”

Rio looked down at the hand that held her cardigan and saw the ring it wore glinting back up at her. It was somehow more offensive than seeing Ralph’s ring there. It looked like an empty promise.

A promise of something Rio could never actually have.

Something dark and angry inside of her wanted to tell Agatha it wasn’t her ring, that Alice had picked it, and to see just a modicum of the hurt that it might induce in the sea of Agatha’s gaze.

But she couldn’t bring herself to do it.

Not when Agatha didn’t think she even deserved the cardigan she currently held like it was her salvation.

She raised her gaze slowly upwards and saw that far from desperate, Agatha was now looking pale again, sick again.

Her lips parted and Rio looked down to them, remembered how they felt against her skin, against her own lips, and for a second forgot that she had ever been angry, or that she was even hurt.

Her hesitation allowed Agatha to tug her back a little, and when her next words came, the pain came back with them:

“I know you asked me not to say it but if it’s going to be over a week until I can explain then I need to tell you that I love you. I’m in love with you. And I think I’ve been in love with you from the very first time I laid eyes on you. I had Nicky and he has been my joy and the universe or whatever god there is gave me one extra piece of joy in my shitty, miserable life. Because he made my son look like you. I believe Lilia when she says… when she says he looks like you because his mother loves you. I know you need time and I want to give you it but I’m so frightened that time will mean… just please, please know how in love with you I am.”

Every time she said it. Every single time the words ‘I love you’ came tumbling out of Agatha’s mouth it felt like she was being stabbed. The pain was so intoxicating that even as the blade twisted in her chest she felt the need to press into it, just to feel more of Agatha.

“I need,” she sucked in a breath, “I need time.”

“I’m scared to give it to you.”

Rio nodded slowly, felt the twist of her sleeve as Agatha tightened her grip, “I know, Agatha. But I have to ask you for it anyway.”

Someone flickered and died in Agatha’s gaze then. It was something like reluctance, gasping its last before it perished and in sea glass there was now something like consideration, something biddable, and no longer as petrified.

Agatha nodded, one firm conclusion. She’d give it, because Rio had asked.

“Sunday,” Rio said slowly, watching as Agatha’s gaze fell from her again and landed where she now held her wrist. “I’ll come over in the morning and… we can discuss it.”

Agatha was silent still and Rio reached to take the hand that held her but held her loosely, as if keeping her there weren’t the aim, just holding on was all she wanted to do.

“Agatha?”

She looked up and Rio almost lost her breath at the sight of her looking so lost and so scared.

“Nicky will be with me. I’d send him to Jen but…”

“I’ll come over later then. I’ll come after he’s in bed.”

Agatha nodded again, that one sharp nod that told Rio she was finding words difficult.

“It is tearing me apart, Agatha. Which is why I need the week. I need time to… I don’t know. Think. Try not to want to die.”

Agatha didn’t nod this time.

She instead sucked in a soft breath and Rio felt her hold change. Her hand twisted further round her wrist and she was tugging her back close until Rio had taken a step forwards and Agatha had too.

It was so easy to fall into her, to allow her to bring her in. And telling her talking wasn’t necessary, that they could work through it by simply ignoring it, suddenly felt easy too.

But Agatha was swallowing thickly, her chin raising an inch or two as she spoke, “If you change your mind, will you tell me? If at any point… day or night you want to come over then… please, Rio. I’m so sorry. I want to explain. I want… Quiero ser buena para ti.” I want to be good for you.

Rio felt the hollowness in her chest again, but before she could respond the door opened and Agatha didn’t let go but Rio turned and saw Pepper standing there, looking awkwardly between the two of them, her gaze briefly settling on where Agatha held Rio’s wrist and where she still held the cardigan that Rio had been wearing earlier.

“I’m sorry, I… is everyone okay?”

“It’s fine. It’s fine.”

Pepper nodded and Rio felt Agatha release her wrist and she turned to see that her eyes, now far from Agatha’s own and instead those of the actress Agatha Harkness, were instead on Pepper.

“I’ll take the fine. And I’ll do whatever Rio wants.”

Agatha turned without a second glance in Rio’s direction and Rio was left standing there, watching as Agatha marched away from her down the hallway.

Chapter End Notes

Agatha is taking baby steps in trying to be better at this whole breakup thing and, no, she won’t be taking the ring off. She’s very method, okay?

Chapter 34: Boiling Over

Chapter Summary

Rio boils over.

Agatha keeps a lid on it.

Chapter Notes

I am once again neglecting my actual adult job for these two

See the end of the chapter for more notes

It became a habit, calling Miguel every morning, and every night.

Rio knew he’d be telling Anna everything but she didn’t really care. Her dad knew. And he was calm and patient and occasionally said things she knew had been given to him to say by her mom.

But those things helped too.

Everything he said helped. He listened so well and was silent with her when she needed to be silent but silent with someone.

He was soft with her and softer even with Agatha.

And she loved him more than she could say for that latter thing. Because Alice listened when she spoke, and was silent when she wanted silence, but she wasn’t soft on Agatha. Sometimes she needed her not to be, but sometimes, and that sometimes was becoming more and more frequent, she needed her to be.

So, Rio always felt a little more clear after speaking to her dad. The clarity didn’t last long but it was important that it was there.

Exactly three conversations with Miguel and two nights sleep since that first day on set after the doomed meeting with Pepper and Agatha, Rio didn’t see Agatha at all.

 

SATURDAY

It was the Saturday, the first day of semi-rehearsals. A day where Rio was mostly kept to Costume or Makeup. A day where she saw a few people from the cast but was mostly involved with the crew.

She knew Agatha was there, but that she was keeping away. During the one hour of the day where she didn’t need to be somewhere or try something on, she sat with some of the rest of the cast, but Agatha didn’t show up even show up then. But Rio felt the spectre of her the whole time.

Jen had approached her on her way back to her trailer after an afternoon of more costume tests and told her she’d been running lines privately with Lilia. But she’d also told her she’d slept, not for long, but that Agatha had had at least four hours sleep.

Upon hearing the news, Rio even found it within herself to congratulate Jen on the impending move with Alice. Jen had responded by pulling her in for a hug so tight that it had taken Rio a while to respond.

But she had.

And when she went home that night she cried for the first time in a while because the only way Agatha would have slept was with her cardigan.

 

SUNDAY

It was the next day that she finally saw Agatha again: precisely a week before she was going to rock up to Agatha’s house to talk.

The set was quiet and Rio had arrived early in her little hybrid with Alice in tow to get breakfast at crafty with Billy. But she’d seen Agatha just two trailers down, standing with Jen and she’d stopped so suddenly that Alice slammed into her back.

In the morning light Agatha looked like her old self. Her features were softened so she didn’t look as tired or drawn. Her shoulders were back, confident, and her eyes were focused solely on Rio.

“We can go say hi if you want?”

Rio twitched at Alice’s words, her body simply agreeing before her mind could catch up.

But she turned a second later, turned to open her own door, to hide away from those blue eyes.

“Do you want to talk about it?”

“No, Alice.”

“You don’t want to talk about the fact that you’ll be locked in a room with her today doing acting exercises and running lines?”

Rio was in the small kitchen area now, making a coffee in the French press, though she’d just put her other coffee down on the side. “I’ll pair with Billy for them.”

“C’mon, babe. You’re smarter than that. You know you’ll be with Agatha.”

Rio just shook her head a little and folded over the coffee bag. “I can’t do trust exercises with her.”

“You don’t think she’ll catch you?”

“Shut up.” Glancing over at her friend now kneeling up on the couch she saw Alice smiling. “Ass.”

Alice laughed and settled back onto her ankles, “So I have to ask you something.”

“Mm? Coffee?”

“No. I have to ask you how you’d feel about a lunch date with James, Maria, and Agatha.”

Rio stared at the plunger and before she’d even put water in it she started to push it slowly down.

“Babe? Rio? There’s no water in that. Babe?”

Rio didn’t stop until it was all the way pressed and she was simply compressing the fine grains of arabica grounds in a firm, dry disk. “When?”

“Tomorrow.”

“On set?”

“Yeah. Informal. He’s coming for rehearsals and Maria is keen you feel like a family.”

Rio scoffed more bitterly than she meant to and zoned out so much that she jumped when suddenly Alice’s hand was on her own as it continued to press down the now totally compressed coffee.

“Yesterday was a good day. And what did your dad say this morning?”

“Un día a la vez.” One day at a time.

Rio closed her eyes but all she could see was Agatha in the morning sun, watching her as she arrived so she opened them again and Agatha was gone. And she asked the thing that she’d asked her dad already that morning: “What if, when we talk, it’s clear she can’t move forward with me?”

Alice’s hold changed then and she turned Rio to pull her down into a hug. “Well then she’s a moron and a fucking loser. An even bigger one than she currently is.

Rio exhaled a half laugh into Alice’s shoulder but neither of them said anything else about it. Alice instead finished making Rio her third coffee of the day, though it was barely nine in the morning.

And Rio lost herself in the rhythm of throwing the little basketballs into the hoop, collecting them again, and throwing them right back.

By the time she was sitting in a room full of her fellow actors, chaperoned as always by the enthusiastic Billy Kaplan, she didn’t feel any better. Yesterday, not seeing Agatha, had been a strange kind of floating day.

She’d floated above it all, on another plane of existence where nothing really hurt but nothing really mattered. Only now, when she was to be locked in a room with her doing trust exercises and various acting exercises, did the pain really hit again.

Everything hurt and everything mattered.

“You smell good,” Billy whispered to her as the leader of the pack - an acting coach hired by the studio named Sue - began her spiel about trust and communication being the most important things about delivering a good and true performance. “What’re you wearing?”

Rio raised her brows, having zoned out a little and conscious only of the fact that Agatha had yet to arrive. “Uh, a perfume Alice got me years ago. Supposed to be wearing Versace but it’s something fancy. And French.”

“Rio? Could we have your attention please?”

Rio started and cleared her throat but nodded and nudged Billy accusingly.

“As I was saying,” Sue began again but was interrupted once more because the door opened and the twelve or so actors in the room turned to see Agatha Harkness stepping inside.

“Sorry I’m late, I didn’t want to be here.”

There was a light tittering of laughter, like a murmur of swallows fluttering in the early morning. It was always a surprise to Rio just how magnetic Agatha was. Perhaps because for so long she’d been right at the epicentre of that field of magnetism. But now, as she watched her saunter in, unbothered and unabashed about her distain for something she clearly thought was beneath her, she was struck by it once more.

Agatha, in her soft white button down, came to take a spot behind Rio, so close that Rio could smell her perfume, could feel her gaze on the back of her head as she turned around to focus in again on Sue.

“Right, I… yes. Where was I? That’s right.”

The spiel went on for another fifteen minutes until it was announced that they were all to walk in a random pattern around the room. Avoiding crashing into each other was the aim. Walking as their natural self was the simple ask.

Rio had done plenty of this sort of thing in her youth. She lived for this sort of thing. The joy of the collective, the embrace of the group as they fumbled and laughed and improvised together, she found it healing.

Or at least, used to.

Everyone was on their feet because god forbid an actor reject the chance to show off their instrument.

Rio began to walk, focusing on the task at hand, when she turned sharply she saw Agatha, alone in the set of seats that had been laid out for them all. She was leaning back, her legs crossed and her arms crossed over her body, one vertical where her fingers toyed with her lower lip. It was as Rio walked towards her, the route surprisingly clear, that she saw just how shattered she was.

Sue approached her but Rio had to turn to avoid crashing into Peter Quill and was suddenly distracted by the hand on her waist that was unnecessary and unwelcome.

By the time she’d done another loop of the space she saw that Sue had left Agatha alone and Agatha simply sat there, watching. It made Rio actually crash this time. Only she didn’t mind Lilia’s hands on her as much as she minded Quill’s.

“Watch it, dear. Can’t get distracted there.”

Rio smiled weakly, glanced across at Agatha again and saw that she was still watching, and then turned back to Lilia, “Sorry. Won’t happen again.”

“Oh I don’t believe you for a second.”

Rio moved on then, deciding for her own safety as well as others that she simply wouldn’t look at Agatha any longer.

It lasted all of five minutes.

Sue had called for everyone to stop where they were, for them all to pair up with whoever was closest - which for Rio was Quill. Only suddenly it wasn’t.

A soft brush against her sleeve told her that someone had moved even closer and she turned just in time to see Agatha standing there, her eyes not on Rio, but on Quill.

“I’m sure we can share her,” he said good-naturedly, though if Agatha’s stiff jaw told Rio anything it was that she didn’t want to share.

“Anyone ever told you you’re an ass, Quill?”

Rio cleared her throat and moved away from Agatha slightly and closer to Quill.

She felt Agatha’s hand follow her to her side, her fingers curling into the fabric of her sweater. It felt good, after everything that had happened, that Agatha was still protective, still possessive, and Rio found herself leaning into her a little despite the fact she’d just moved away.

“Love it when you talk dirty, Harkness. That husband of yours enjoy that mouth?”

“What I do with my mouth is no business of yours, Quill.”

At her side, Rio felt Agatha’s knuckles press into her.

“Wouldn’t mind if it were, though.”

He stepped closer and Rio felt Agatha stiffen and her hold on her sweater tighten as Rio moved a little in front of her. She couldn’t help but raise her shoulders a little, unconsciously giving herself another inch in height, allowing the constantly crackling fire of her anger to burn her sense away as she accused: “Trying to flirt with a married woman, Quill? Come on.”

“Still set on the girl thing, Vidal?” Peter, charming and handsome, but idiotic and sexist, tried his luck on Rio now, grinning crookedly at her. “Why don’t you flirt with her a little, see if you can make use of those beds in the trailers. I’d happily watch. Check for the chemis-…”

Maybe it was that the last few days had been the worst days of Rio’s life. Maybe it was that Quill had already pissed her off at the table read with his stupid comments in front of the kid. Maybe it was that Agatha had changed her hold to her other hip and was tugging her back. Maybe it was that she’d been plagued by visions of Agatha’s mouth on Ralph.

Maybe it was just that she needed to hit something.

So she hit Peter Quill.

It wasn’t the hardest she’d ever hit someone, but it wasn’t exactly soft either.

She got him square in the nose, a quick pop against the bridge, and he stumbled back a little as Rio was pulled back into Agatha and held firm against her.

“Rio, no, no-…”

The room went silent, and Rio could hear only her heartbeat, and feel only Agatha.

Her arms were crossed over her body, her left from her side to her right shoulder, her right angling down to her hip. It felt protective, like she was worried Rio would get hit, rather than worried Rio would hit again.

Agatha’s warm breath was against her cheek, and she felt her gasp quietly and pull her back more when Peter brought his hand up and with curious fingers he touched the nose he now scrunched experimentally. It looked like it stung, and Rio was glad at least of that.

“Ouch,” he muttered, briefly looking like the hurt was getting worse as his eyes watered and he looked at Rio, his jaw flexing slightly. “Suppose I deserved that.”

“Rio,” Agatha whispered urgently, tugging her back with her a couple more steps as Sue called for order and Lilia stepped between the puncher and her victim.

“Let me see,” Lilia instructed, making Peter tilt his head back so she could check if he were bleeding.

Rio regretted that he wasn’t. She regretted that she’d been neglecting her body by drinking too much coffee and eating not enough food. She was weaker than she usually would be. Tired and ineffectual.

A week ago she’d have broken his nose no problem.

But then Agatha’s arms constricted around her, forcing her to come back to herself, and she turned her head just an inch, and everything was Agatha, so her anger died with the brush of her nose against her cheek, and she felt only shame.

“I-…”

“Is everyone okay? What happened?”

Sue was back again, but Rio was distracted by Agatha now trying to turn her around, and when she managed it Rio was surprised by what she saw. Agatha looked pale and surprised but her hands were checking her over, as if she’d missed the part where Quill had attacked Rio too.

She dropped her hold to first check her hands, she then moved up her arms, held her neck, held her cheeks. It was frantic and soft and Rio couldn’t breath as Agatha stared at her, trying still to find where Rio was hurt, and see what she could fix.

“I’m fine,” Rio managed to whisper, feeling a shiver overtake her body as Agatha tried to search for the lie in her brown eyes.

“Let’s all take a break,” Sue announced quite quickly after she realised no one was going to tell her what happened. Only a few people had seen what Rio had done and Quill wasn’t exactly anyone’s favourite in the room.

Agatha lifted her gaze from Rio to glance over at Quill and then looked back again at Rio, her hands sliding back down until they found her hands again. “Come outside?”

But Rio’s whole body was vibrating now as the after affects of the adrenaline rush kicked in. Agatha only stepped a little closer, turned her head to kiss her cheek, squeezed the fingers that had just punched one of their fellow cast members.

“You shouldn’t have done it.”

She knew she was trying to reassure her, knew she was trying to bring her back down from the upper echelons at the very edge of her sanity. But she was struggling now to make sense of what she’d allowed herself to do, of how she’d lost it so quickly and cleanly that she’d assaulted a fellow actor for the crime of being a pig.

Rio could feel Agatha’s words against her cheek, could feel the lips that had been there now up against her brow, and she only had the ability to turn her hand over and lock fingers with Agatha, the only acknowledgement that she could give that she was still in there somewhere.

“Show’s over, everybody! Haven’t you heard of a little thing we like to call ‘stage craft’? Focus on your own partners, please!”

Lilia was shouting somewhere near her, warning people off what was left of the scene, making them all turn around for fear that Lilia Calderu would blacklist them from Hollywood altogether if they didn’t.

Rio would have been grateful, but gratitude was lost on her when she realised what the hardness in Agatha’s hand was and she glanced down to see the ring she’d given her shining back up at her.

“I’ll take her,” Lilia offered a second later, having left Quill now putting on a brave face despite the sting of his nose to stand beside Agatha and Rio.

“Agatha, stay here.”

Rio watched as Agatha looked momentarily stuck for what to say but then Lilia was tugging her away from her and Agatha let go, watching as Rio was led from the room by the woman in the shawls.

Rio was shivering again until she was out in the corridor, a good twenty feet from the door and Lilia had turned to her with a look that made Rio want to shrink down and die.

“You stupid girl!”

Rio flinched and in flinching she realised what she’d actually done.

“You cannot go around smacking people in the face when they say something idiotic.”

Rio grimaced and looked down at her feet, only vaguely aware that a door was opening somewhere near by.

“I didn’t break it.”

“Do you want a medal for that?”

Rio huffed as a voice said, “Are you okay?”

Glancing up again she saw Agatha, looking more concerned than angry, and reaching out to take her hand.

“The two of you,” Lilia was saying sharply, though she’d lowered her voice this time round, “Need to sort yourselves out. Rio can’t go round smacking people and Agatha, you can’t lock yourself away and hope no one will notice. You’re number one on the call sheet.”

Rio could hear Lilia, she could understand what she was saying, but her knuckles were suddenly against Agatha’s lips, and so she couldn’t really compute her words, not properly anyway.

“Are you listening to me?”

Agatha turned to Lilia, but held on tight still to Rio’s right hand. “He deserved it.”

“Punching people is-…”

“It won’t happen again.”

Agatha turned back to her as she’d made her promise and Rio had to fight the urge not to look at her because she was so close now, so visibly concerned that Rio was somehow hurt.

Only when Agatha’s hand was back on her cheek did Rio have no choice but to look up at her and in doing so she collapsed back an inch or two against the wall. Agatha only followed. She tilted her head and for a second Rio thought she might kiss her but then Lilia was breaking them apart.

“Go back inside.”

Neither of them looked away from the other but Rio nodded just once and Agatha reluctantly pivoted and marched back down to the door. She turned when she reached it and Rio smiled sadly at the sight of her looking back.

And then she was gone.

“Rio Vidal,” Lilia said firmly once the door was closed again, “We both know he is not the man you want to smack.”

Rio blinked and turned slowly to look at Lilia, “What?”

“Ralph. You want to smack Ralph.”

“I-…”

“There’s no use. It’s just us. But I’m telling you now, smacking anybody will not make things easier for either of you.”

Rio swallowed and looked back towards the door where Agatha would be just inside with that idiot. She wanted to smack everyone now. Just to feel something. Just to feel something other than the hurt that haunted her.

“Rio, you’re a smart girl. She’s a smart girl. When are you going to sort this out?”

“Sunday. We’re talking on Sunday.”

She turned back and saw Lilia analysing her closely, “Are you ready for it?”

“Does smacking someone in the middle of my working day make it look like I am?”

Lilia pursed her lips and Rio slumped back against the wall.

“He was an ass.”

“I heard what he said, I know.”

“He deserved it.”

“Doesn’t mean you should have done it.”

“I’d do it again if-…”

“Rio,” Lilia said in a softer voice this time, “If Agatha wants to protect her son, then you need to be there to catch her. If anyone gets wind of any violence…”

“I’m not violent! I just… Jesus fuck.”

“Look, I don’t know everything but I do know if she leaves that man and you want to be with her then you need to keep your hands to yourself and that temper under control.”

Rio rocked her head back against the wall and closed her eyes. She knew Lilia was right. She knew she shouldn’t have punched Quill but the idea of anyone making comments like that made her blood boil and her hands form fists.

“I don’t have a temper. I’m not a child.”

She almost choked on the last word though, because Agatha maybe thought she was. Perhaps what she’d done is just solidify Agatha’s accusation.

Agatha wanted to make sure she was okay, sure. But she didn’t want her as a partner. Not when Nicky was there.

And maybe, maybe, Agatha actually thought Rio would hit her. That’s why she’d asked two days ago. Because she thought it was a possibility.

That Rio might hit her.

She covered her face, an old habit from childhood; if she couldn’t see anyone, no one could see her.

The woman she loved had asked her to hit her, rather than not speak to her. And Rio, childish, immature Rio, had just hit someone else in front of her. It was a cruel joke of the universe, really. That Rio had been unable to control herself at the crucial moment where Agatha’s fears could either be confirmed or denied.

It made her feel sick that the words had even left Agatha’s mouth in the first place, but now she was sick with the fear that Agatha could potentially believe Rio would have it in her to use the hands that had been made to worship Agatha harm her instead.

“Whatever you’re thinking,” Lilia said from somewhere before her, “it’s not true.”

Rio scoffed but remained hidden.

“That girl in there… well I’ve known her a long time. She isn’t soft. She doesn’t hold or protect or care for anyone other than her son. And then you come along and suddenly she’s moving differently through the world. You’ve changed her. People like Agatha don’t change. But you’ve done it. I believe in many things, Rio Vidal, and one of the things I believe in is that some people were just made for each other. Not everyone was made for someone. But you were made for Agatha. I saw it the first time we met in Cannes. It’s written right there,” she took Rio’s left hand and traced her finger along her palm, “right there, etched into your very skin.”

Rio looked down at the place Lilia’s finger rested and remembered a time months ago when she’d done the exact same thing in a loud, busy party in the middle of the Cannes Film Festival. She’d seen nothing then and she saw nothing now.

“She needs you to be steady for her. And flying off the handle well-…”

“She was right,” Rio said quickly, raising her gaze to meet Lilia’s shrewd dark eyes, “It won’t happen again.”

Lilia nodded, sizing her up for a second, until she released her hand, “Let’s go back in. Indulge this crazed blonde with the idea that any of us need help with acting.”

They exchanged soft smiles, Lilia’s a little more broad than Rio’s as she nodded in the direction of the door and Rio obliged the silent instruction and took a breath as she went.

When Rio came back into the room she was relieved that no one even looked her way. She was an Oscar-winner with charm for days, but she wasn’t Agatha Harkness. She couldn’t command attention simply by showing up like she could.

Only she could command Agatha’s attention. From the corner of the room, resting against the opposite wall, standing before Billy, Agatha was watching her. She was scanning her over for any signs of hurt that she might have missed before.

And Rio could only look away for fear that she’d do or say something stupid. She joined the fray once more and saw Quill look over at her, saw him assess for a second before he winked and gave her that crooked smile again.

It meant he wasn’t angry, but she could also bet it meant he’d have no problem being an ass once more. Only this time she wouldn’t be able to hit him because of it.

But she smiled back, mouthed a silent, “sorry, dude”, and received only a fake punch to his own nose and an exaggerated mime of him stumbling back and ricocheting his head off of nothing in return.

She hated that guy.

But dumb meant he wouldn’t be pressing charges, so maybe she didn’t hate him as much as she could have done.

She’d come back into the middle of the same exercise and found that half the people around her were currently falling back or stumbling, depending on how much trust they had in their partner.

Her feet took her closer to Agatha even though her brain told her to walk in any other direction. But Billy was there too, so maybe her body just knew something her brain couldn’t yet comprehend.

“I’m stronger than I look,” Billy tried, in a tone that sounded an awful lot like pleading to Rio. He looked desperate, hoping he’d get his dream of Agatha trusting him enough to fall into his arms. Platonically, of course.

Rio caught Agatha roll her eyes and had to look away for fear she’d laugh and upset Billy. Once sure she could control herself she stepped up and placed a hand on Billy’s shoulder to get him to stop his unsubtle begging.

And once again her body took over before her brain could catch up.

“Let me. I’ll catch you.”

Agatha looked directly at her, and Rio felt unsure suddenly.

What if she dropped Agatha? What if she let her slip through her fingers?

Or worse.

What if Agatha said no?

“I know.”

Billy looked aghast and as Agatha eyed the distance between them and turned around to get into position, Billy whispered urgently into Rio’s ear, “I’ve been asking for the past ten minutes if she’d let me.”

Rio only smiled a little at the young actor and moved to where Agatha would need her to be.

Agatha turned once, checked she was there, and then looked back forwards again.

There she stood.

Agatha fucking Harkness.

Back ramrod straight.

Hair flowing down her back in graceful waves.

More talent in her little finger than anyone else in the room had in their entire body.

And she fell, light as a feather, stiff as a board, into Rio’s waiting arms.

She caught her effortlessly, Agatha’s head now against her chest, her body gently cradled and supported by Rio’s own. Agatha had released a soft gasp upon contact and Rio had not made any noise at all.

She held her, suspended between herself, her heels, and the ground for a few seconds, and then she raised her back up. She didn’t hover close or crowd her but Agatha turned around to her when Rio’s arms slipped from their favourite resting place.

There was a faint blush across pale cheeks.

“Now,” a voice near Rio announced, “isn’t that the thing.”

Rio glanced at Lilia and saw her smiling indulgently at Agatha and as she turned back to her she saw that Agatha was avoiding Lilia’s gaze but looking, as ever, at Rio.

“There!” Sue shouted with a clap of her hands, “Perfect! Everybody! As easy as breathing! Agatha, Rio, please, indulge us. Do it again.”

It was ironic, really, in Alanis’ definition: how a year ago, maybe less, Rio would have jumped at the chance to show off to the room that not only did Agatha Harkness trust her enough to let her catch her, but she, little Rio Vidal was the only one who could.

But now Rio couldn’t imagine anything worse than showing off about Agatha trusting her, about being able to catch her.

She wanted only to hold her in her arms and to be alone, so alone that neither of them were even aware that anyone else on the planet existed apart from them.

“Shall we indulge?”

Then again, if Agatha wanted her to, she sure as hell would show off about it.

“Okay.”

Agatha raised a brow at her, just slightly, barely a millimetre, but certainly a check, an “okay?” for Rio’s gentle “okay”.

Rio nodded and bit the corner of her lip. Agatha’s gaze dropped to the movement and then she turned away and Rio stepped back and prepared for the fall.

It happened again, beautifully, easily, and this time Rio was the one to gasp and Agatha was silent.

Rio held on a little longer as the crowd cheered and she lifted Agatha back up, and this time, this time Agatha spun around before Rio’s arms were again her own.

“Agatha Harkness and Rio Vidal everybody! Showing everyone how it’s done!”

But Agatha’s arms were around her neck, and Rio was now holding on for dear life.

Only Agatha wasn’t falling anymore. She was instead holding her so tight Rio felt like she’d never let go.

It was her chance. Her one chance to say something to Agatha. She had to make sure she knew, had to reassure if there was even the tiniest part of Agatha that would ever be worried about it. Because the woman in her arms was precious, beyond precious. She had to know that. Even if they would never work. Even if Rio had had all the joy of having Agatha she’d ever be allowed.

Even if Rio would be alone forever with her memories and the ghost of Agatha in her arms.

Agatha had to know that she was precious to Rio.

She sucked in a breath, felt Agatha squeeze her tighter, and said against her ear as the room dispersed again to try and replicate what the two actors alone had been able to achieve. “Jamás te pegaría. Lo que dijiste el otro día… no puedo sacármelo de la cabeza. Agatha, yo...” I would never hit you. What you said the other day… I can’t get it out of my head. Agatha I-…”

The woman in her arms broke away from her hold, and Rio almost fell.

Agatha had broken their embrace so suddenly, almost violently, that Rio choked on a breath. The room around them was still alive with movement, everyone still trying to emulate the trust that had just been put on show.

Rio was just holding on, her fingertips only able to tickle the fabric of Agatha’s shirt, let alone hold it.

And suddenly her hands were removed, and held. Rio looked down at them, at the wrong ring on Agatha’s left hand as Agatha said, “Sé que estas manos nunca podrían hacerme daño.” I know these hands could never hurt me.”

Rio felt tears sting her eyes the second Agatha squeezed her hand. She felt one fall and then be gently wiped away. And the room dissolved around them as their eyes met and the complex being before her unravelled just that little bit more.

She hadn’t said it because she thought Rio would hit her. She’d asked it because she couldn’t bear the silence, the time.

She dropped her gaze again as Agatha squeezed her hands and lost herself in the glint of the pear-shaped diamond that should never have been allowed to touch Agatha’s hands.

“Hey!”

Rio couldn’t look away from the ring winking up at her. Even as Agatha dropped her hands and Billy stole her attention. Even as Agatha turned to the man and her hand now lay at her side. Even as Agatha’s thumb began to twist it, making the diamond disappear and reappear at will.

It was a cruel magic. One that meant for a brief moment Rio didn’t have to see the wrongness of the ring, before it was back again, and treasured by a hand Rio wanted to hold, and by fingers which belonged between her own.

“Rio?”

Rio blinked and raised her gaze again to find that Billy was looking at her expectantly.

“What was that?”

“Want to do a trust fall?”

“Oh,” Rio said as Agatha moved away and Rio turned to watch her drift towards Lilia who was sitting down and talking to a newly arrived Maria. “Sure, kid. Whatever you want.”

Turned out, Billy wasn’t great at trust falls. His second and third attempts weren’t any better than his first. But Rio let him try. And he always apologised, which she appreciated given the fact that if he ever let her actually fall she might get an actual concussion.

She was aware of Agatha’s eyes on her the whole time.

Once she’d decided that allowing this to go on much longer might lead to some injuries, Sue called for calm in the noisy room. Rio turned to her and felt a sudden presence at her side and knew without looking that Agatha was back close again.

“Oooookay!” Another clap of her hands. “Let’s ramp this baby up. Trust is vital, but communication is essential.”

Rio felt Billy lean against her and mutter, “There are more Oscar winners in this room than-…”

“Mr Kaplan! You’ve volunteered yourself! Please come here.”

Rio fought a smirk as Billy groaned and went to the centre of the room to take Sue’s outstretched hand. His shoulders shrunk down as Sue turned him to look at her and now stood a couple feet apart.

“Meisner! I like to call it: Meisner’s Mirror.”

“Oh Jesus,” a low voice sounded beside her and Rio did smirk this time when she saw Agatha’s face.

“If I were you I’d be looking in the mirror all the time.”

Agatha turned to her in surprise and for a second Rio was just a girl flirting with another girl in the middle of class. And the trauma of everything that had happened between them both dissolved as she grinned across at the prettiest girl she’d ever seen.

“Ladies?”

Rio turned back but felt a finger brush the width of her hand as she did. She knew it was an acknowledgement of the flirt, but she couldn’t try to cash in. She couldn’t flirt again. She couldn’t allow herself to slip into the danger zone that led to forgiveness and inevitable heartache.

So ignored the touch, focused on what they were being asked to do. And enjoyed the fact that for even a brief moment, she’d been free of pain.

It was a simple exercise. A state and repeat type exercise done in acting classes the world over. You pick a partner, stand two arms’ lengths apart, then one makes a statement and the other states it back, directly reflecting it. The goal is to move closer when the feeling is right, to take the words of your partner and send them back using every emotion in your arsenal.

The result was usually that you had people trying to out act each other.

Rio could guess who Agatha would want to be with before she even stepped closer and inclined her head in a silent question. She smiled her assent, rather than giving it verbally, and they both assumed the position and waited for the word “go”.

They hadn’t decided who would make the first statement, who would determine the theme, but Rio already knew it would be Agatha.

And apparently Agatha did too because a second after Sue’s loud instruction to start she said:

“I miss you.”

Rio closed her eyes for a second, acknowledged the pain that she’d been so blissfully free of not a minute ago, then opened them again and reflected it back: “You miss me.”

“I miss you,” Agatha said once more, the corner of her lips twitching just slightly. She took a step forwards.

“You miss me,” Rio said a little louder, her chin rising, but she remained still.

“I miss you.” Agatha took another step closer and Rio’s gaze dropped briefly to the hand that had twitched in her direction.

She hesitated this time, weighing up her options.

She took a breath, then lifted her head again, forced a smile, took a step. “You miss me.”

Agatha nodded her head, her lips twitching again and in her eyes Rio saw an honesty that belied the acting they were both supposedly doing in the exercise.

A movement beside them made Rio look, and she saw Sue moving over through the other bodies all either moving towards their partner or remaining in place. Everyone had a different expression on their face. They were saying things as myriad and varied as: “I hate you”, “you’re wearing red”, “I hate the rain”, and “your shoes are ugly”.

But only Agatha and Rio weren’t acting.

And Sue had come to witness it.

“I miss you.”

Rio turned back and saw Agatha was closer again, a bright smile on her face, a familiar smile. It was the kind of expression Agatha so naturally gave when she’d spotted Rio across the room, across the red carpet, but only in the before times. Now she looked forlorn. Now she looked exhausted or hopeful or defeated.

It was the kind of smile that tugged at whatever string Rio imagined tethered her to Agatha. The kind of smile that made her move before she’d even spoken: “You miss me.”

“Incredible, ladies,” Sue whispered from by Rio’s right shoulder.

Agatha’s smile faded slowly as she remained focused on Rio and Rio sucked in a deep breath, felt her chest expand with it, and then her hand was full of Agatha’s again and she remained stationery as she said: “You miss me.”

She’d skipped Agatha’s turn, for no reason other than she wanted Agatha to know she understood what she’d been trying to say through the medium of the Meisner method.

Sue from beside her moved around and she saw a blonde head disappearing. Agatha took a second and then stepped closer and there were barely inches between them now, barely space to breathe.

But Rio’s eyes were back on Agatha, and Agatha’s lips were parting to say the familiar phrase she’d chosen to be used as their shared mirror. But Rio interrupted her, took a step too, said the words into Agatha’s ear, “I miss you too,” and then she stepped back.

She stepped back even as Agatha’s right hand had moved to her side to hold her. She stepped back and dropped the hold of her hand. She stepped back and placed a much distance between them as there had been before.

Her cheeks felt warm, her fingers tingling from where they’d held Agatha’s hand.

And the room was still loud, still vibrating with the buzz of people reflecting phrases back at their partners. Agatha remained silent, her lower lip tugged between her teeth, her eyes only on Rio. When Rio turned back, she didn’t look away, and Rio stepped closer, ignored Agatha’s hand as it reached for her own again and instead casually looped their arms together.

It was a means of being close without allowing herself to fall into her again. And Agatha allowed it, allowed the casual nature of the hold, took it gratefully in fact, and again mirrored Rio in the way she now turned to look out over the room and enjoy the sight of their fellow actors all stepping and speaking in the round.

The activity lasted less than two more minutes but Rio didn’t pull her arm back until Billy had skipped over to her again.

“We’re now going to read a couple scenes whilst keeping in motion, okay? You have to be in charge of your instrument but aware of your fellow actors. It’s about knowing where you are and where everyone else is. The basics of acting!”

Rio rubbed her temple, torn between laughter and disbelief, made worse by a complaining Billy beside her.

But she had no choice. She moved with the swarm as she fetched a script from the pile on the table and began to walk as she flicked through to find the right scene.

It took a few rounds of the room and a page and a half until she realised that two people apparently had a choice.

Agatha and Lilia were the only two sitting down. And no one had said anything. Because who says anything to Agatha Harkness? Who questions Lilia Calderu?

She knew Agatha often didn’t play well with others. Especially when it felt like play, and not work. So it wasn’t that much of a surprise that she’d chosen to sit this one out. Especially when she couldn’t partner with Rio in the exercise.

Lilia had probably played the age card, so no one could be mad at that. Though Rio had felt the strength of her grip earlier so secretly thought that Lilia would have no problem at all wandering around the room for a few minutes.

Rio adjusted her route as best she could once she’d noticed where Agatha was. She made sure to stay to the other side of the room. She had barely any lines anyway, so she could concentrate instead on not hitting anyone and not veering too close to Agatha.

The walking, the concentrating on other people, it gave her time to think.

She knew only one thing for sure: she was in love with Agatha.

The rest was still bouncing around in her mind like the people moving in a fluctuating current around her. Reverberating through her brain were the doubts she still had. The things that she didn’t trust, that didn’t make sense.

The fear she still had that Agatha thought she was childish, that she had meant everything she’d shouted at her, and that Agatha would crush her again.

But her dad’s voice was there now: “Confía en tu corazón. Confía en tu dolor. Confía en Agatha's.” Trust your heart. Trust your pain. Trust Agatha’s.

It helped. It calmed the furore.

The exercise ended after a little under half an hour.

Rio cleared her throat, felt one of the guys playing one of the doctors nudge her shoulder and smile at her. She smiled back. Sue was talking now, closing out the session with too much praise and not enough authenticity. But it was over, Rio could leave.

As she turned to, she found that she was already being hugged by the actor playing the doctor. She hugged him back and felt as she did a hand in her lower back.

“Rio.”

Rio turned, knew who she was about it greet, and saw Agatha’s eyes not on her but on the doctor actor. It took a second for Agatha to look her way but the time it took allowed Rio to look at her properly, to see the tiredness in her face, the dullness in her blue eyes.

If Jen had been right before and Agatha had actually slept a little then it was clear she needed a lot more sleep still.

Agatha looked around, and Rio knew it was only because the other actor had moved away.

“It was good to see you.”

Soft lips pressed into her cheek and before Rio could so much as close her eyes to submit to the feeling, Agatha had pulled away. She turned to see her march out of the room and avoid everyone who tried to get to her before she did.

But then Rio was descended upon. Without Agatha as a barrier to accessing her, she gave and received at least a dozen hugs before she was able to leave.

She walked through the lot in the direction of the wardrobe trailers. It was still early enough in the day that surely at least one of the team would be around still. In the week or so before filming started it was the crew who were the busiest. So it made sense to her when she spotted Stevie just a few hundred yards away stepping from the second wardrobe trailer.

“Stevie!”

The woman stopped in her tracks and turned. Upon recognising Rio she beamed and gestured to the two shoe boxes in her arms, “No rest for the wicked. How’s rehearsal?”

“A lot of trust exercises and walking around.”

“Yikes.”

Rio laughed. “But actually, I have a favour to ask you. Y’know those rings you had all in Agatha’s size? Do you still have them?”

“Oh. Uh. Maybe? I’d have to check. I can’t tonight but…”

“Here,” Rio said quickly, feeling as though suddenly getting those rings was urgent. “Can I give you my number?”

“Is this,” Stevie narrowed her eyes, “Rio Vidal, is this your way of giving me your number?”

Rio raised her brows and couldn’t figure out whether agreeing or saying no would get her those rings faster. “Aren’t you straight?”

“Well,” Stevie looked her over and shifted her weight on the spot. “Not every day a movie star asks for your number.”

“Technically I asked to give you mine.”

Stevie just raised her brows and Rio grinned, “So?”

“Back pocket.”

Rio moved around and gingerly fished Stevie’s phone from her back pocket and held it up expectantly. “Code is 728532. Add it in. I’ll text you if I find them. Though some may have already been sent back.”

“That’s fine,” Rio said quickly, wasting no time in inputting the code for fear she’d forget it already as Stevie started to jabber on about how fussy Billy was about shoes.

“Here,” she moved around Stevie and placed her phone back in her pocket.

“You’re smooth, Rio, I’ll give you that.”

Rio laughed but thought Stevie really wasn’t taking this request seriously. “But text as soon as you know, please. I’ve had a change of mind about her ring and want it to be right before we start shooting.”

“You actors and your costumes, honestly. But sure, I’ll reach out.”

Stevie winked as she left and Rio had to laugh at herself, groaning as she rubbed her hands over her face and stood for a while in the middle of the rows upon rows of trailers. If Stevie couldn’t unearth the rings again, she’d go out and buy one. She’d make sure Agatha had something that was from her, rather than Alice.

Agatha was getting comfort from a lie.

And Rio knew better than anyone how lies could destroy someone.

She had to get Agatha this ring. Had to explain. Had to hope she would accept it.

When she went home that night she went home to Alice, as usual. Only this was the first time she’d stepped into her house and truly wished she could be alone. She wanted to think some more, wanted to call her dad and pop a melatonin.

Instead she spent some time with Alice, told her about the exercises, and was honest about what she’d done to Peter Quill. The bad actress in the room couldn’t hide her feelings about any of it, but she tempered them, she softened them, and Rio was grateful for it.

When she managed to swallow down some of the dinner Alice had made she called her dad, she took a melatonin, and just as she was settling down to sleep her phone buzzed:

9:07pm
Unknown number: Hey, it’s Stevie!! I found the rings. Stop by tomorrow morning xx

Rio fell asleep with a flicker of hope quivering in her empty chest.

 

MONDAY

Rio was awake before even Alice was.

Which wasn’t unusual.

It was unheard of.

And it turned out Alice didn’t appreciate this role reversal. She hated being woken up more than Rio did and she grunted and grumbled more than Rio did.

So much so, in fact, that Rio was being chased from the room with a pillow after the second time she’d called Alice “her sweet little sleepy friend”.

It had made her cackle, despite eventually getting a mouthful of pillow when Alice finally caught her. But it was worth it because when she’d eventually dragged Alice to set and made it to the second wardrobe trailer, Stevie was already there sipping on a steaming mug of coffee and singing idly to the radio.

“Knock knock,” Rio announced, grinning as best she could in the still early hours of the morning. “You’re an angel, you know that?”

“Yeah, yeah, tell me something I don’t know.”

Stevie winked at her and lazily heaved herself up from her chair to motion for Rio to come in and follow her to the small pile of ring boxes she’d laid on on the coffee table.

“Your wish is my command. Turns out we’d only actually returned one of them and it was an ugly amethyst ring that belonged to Geri anyway.”

Rio hummed quietly, pretending to care as she began to open each box individually and inspect the contents.

“They’re all her size but not all rings are created equally so we do have some additional sizers if she needs one to make it fit.”

Rio hummed again, now opening a small red box with an asscher cut ring inside. She lifted it out and watched it glint in the light for a while before replacing it and continuing her search.

“So,” Stevie said conversationally, watching Rio curiously now as the actress continued to check each box with a look of great concentration on her face. “About my number?”

“Hmm?”

Rio was opening a dark green box, it looked a little battered, she assumed whoever had owned it or wherever it had been borrowed from would have called this box “well-loved”. But the ring inside was pristine, was a brilliant cut emerald shaped diamond adorning a plain gold band.

She held it up to the light as Stevie said, “Was it a come on? I mean… I was thinking about it last night and-…”

“It’s this one,” Rio said reverently, her attention only on the ring. “This is the one.”

In Rio’s mind she was already picturing the way it would sit on Agatha’s finger. It was a much larger diamond than the one she already wore, a shape that would suit her better, a ring that felt more Agatha than any Rio had seen.

A ring she wanted to give to her and see her wear proudly.

“Right,” Stevie said, shaking herself out of her train of thought, “Great. Feel free to just take it and get Agatha to bring the other one back. We’ll sort it all out.”

Rio nodded absently, the farthest thing from her mind now being Agatha’s reaction when Rio asked her to swap the rings. She replaced the ring in its box and held it securely in her fist as she turned to Stevie with a genuine smile this time. “Total angel.”

“That’s me!” Stevie laughed a little, her cheeks slightly flushed as Rio pressed a kiss to both of them.

It was only when Rio shut the door to the trailer as she left that she vaguely registered what Stevie might have been trying to tell her. She paused in the chill of the morning, one mind to go back and explain, the other to let it lie and not bring it up again for both of their sakes.

Her second instinct won.

Back in her own trailer she found Alice waiting on her, two mugs of coffee on the side, and a foil-wrapped bagel that she ignored in favour of the coffee.

“Let’s see!”

Rio threw her the box, blew cool air over her coffee, and watched as Alice inspected the ring. “Okay,” she admitted after a little while of looking at it from every angle and watching it catch the light. “It’s more Agatha. Fine.”

Rio rolled her eyes and shuffled closer to Alice on the couch, holding out her now warm palm to take the ring back.

“I hope she takes it.”

“Jen says she only takes that damn ring off when she’s home with Nicky.”

“Ralph’s not back?”

“No. Pretty sure he’s not back for a while.”

Rio nodded, distracted by the light refracting off the diamond in the palm of her hand, “I told her once I’d buy her a ring bigger than his.”

She whispered the words, her mind elsewhere entirely, back in a grimy bathroom in Chicago where her memories were hazy but the feeling was anything but.

“I think it’s one of the very first things I said to her.”

Alice was silent for a minute before she uttered: “Would you marry her? Right now, if she asked? If she weren’t married?”

“In a heartbeat.”

“Then why are you waiting? Why aren’t you talking to her now when-…?”

“Because I still have to hear why she did it. I have to hear why she slept with Ralph, why she left me, just how much of a child she thinks-…” Rio sighed quietly, creating a fist around the ring and letting the sharp edges of it cut into her palm.

“I need to… I need to not break when she tells me all of that. Because I want her. So badly. And if I break, then I might not be able to hold her.”

“Rio,” Alice whispered like a sigh, and Rio turned to her friend with a sad sort of smile.

“I just need to be as ready to hear what she has to say as possible. I’ll be ready by Sunday. I will be. If she still wants me then-…”

“I’m fucking furious with her and I’m a little worried she’s still-…” Alice sighed heavily and seemed to think better of what she was going to say, “but even I can’t deny that she so obviously still wants you, Rio.”

“Maybe. But I thought she wanted me when she went and fucked Ralph so what do we know.”

Alice sighed heavily this time, and held Rio’s fist that still held the ring. “Eat your bagel, you have a long day of hair and makeup ahead of you. Plus you need to learn your lines. I know you’re not off book, Vidal. Big scene to run through tomorrow.”

Rio rolled her eyes and eventually managed to eat half her bagel, hide away the new ring, and make her way over to the hair and makeup trailer.

Inside she found it to already be full of movement, noise, and activity. There were four chairs along the row of mirrors all framed with bright, unforgiving lights.

The first two chairs were occupied by Billy and Lilia, and the fourth chair, way at the back of the space, housed Agatha.

Everyone looked around when Rio walked in and Rio managed a smile as she squeezed Billy and Lilia both in the shoulder and was then swept up into a hug by the lead hairstylist, Brett, with whom she’d worked before.

“God you look like shit. Has Alice been neglecting you or something?”

“Fuck off,” Rio laughed as over Brett’s shoulder where she stood on her tiptoes to hug him, she caught Agatha’s eye.

She pulled back, grinned up at the man, “It’s your job to fix me.”

“Trying to make my job harder, huh? No snacks for you.”

Rio rolled her eyes as she was directed to take her seat and greeted two new assistants as they came to take her coffee order and begin piling up the products that had already been chosen for her hair.

She focused on herself, on the people helping, on Brett as he began to finger through her hair, muttering to himself and throwing orders and requests in every which direction until he met eyes with Rio through to the glass.

“Was this Maria’s choice? Who made you cut your hair?”

Rio cleared her throat quietly, suddenly aware of Agatha just a few feet to her left.

“I did it for a friend’s son.”

Not technically a lie, but also quite a big lie.

“What?”

“He had a hair cut he didn’t like, a shorter one, so I… cut my hair.”

Brett eyed her for a while to see if she was taking the piss but when he saw just plain honesty in her large eye, and a little embarrassment, he slumped his shoulders. “Well, that’s sweet, hon. But ruins what plans I had for you. Cute braids, fishtails…”

Rio only hummed quietly, and as Brett turned to speak to his nearest assistant she turned to see Agatha and saw that she was staring down at her hands, spinning the diamond as fast as she’d ever seen it.

The rest of the time in the chair she focused on laughing when Brett made a joke, talking when necessary, and otherwise she kept her attentions on the script Alice had delivered to her about an hour after she’d arrived.

Billy and Lilia were done before Rio and Agatha were and Rio was done only shortly after Lilia left.

In the whole time she’d been there - three hours now - she’d not spoken to Agatha and had mostly been able to avoid looking at her too.

But as she left she smiled at her, received a smile back, and Rio left with the heaviness of a ring not on her person but already weighing against her soul.

 

TUESDAY

Tuesday came with it a bout of bad weather and a bad schedule for Rio.

Through the wind and the rain, she had to stomp her way to Studio B for some rehearsals with Quill, Billy, and Agatha.

There had been a murmuring that James might be there too but the child liaison officer charged with his wellbeing had suggested there was no need to rehearse the heavy scenes they were due to run through with a child present.

It would be cruel and unnecessary, which is exactly how Rio had felt this last week had been.

Her role for most of these scenes was to be a foil to Agatha’s character Kate. The dynamic was that whilst Kate was “the strong and stoic one”, Dani was her more “emotionally intelligent and calm” wife. She mostly had to react to Agatha, mostly had to temper the Quill’s character, Andrew’s, anger at her.

She mostly had to stand by Billy and advocate for him, the youngest of the three siblings, Jules.

It was an emotionally complex scene, one of the longer ones in the movie, and would be shot a bit like a play. Maria was keen for it to be shot without any cuts or breaks in the action, which meant they had to be word perfect before they could even think about shooting.

And Rio was yet to memorise the whole script, but she had this one section down. Potentially because it was one of the more intense ones that didn’t require her to be discussing more kids with Agatha or telling her she loved her.

The day was intense.

Quill was obnoxious and ribald and Rio thought often about punching him again. But he seemed to have at least learnt his lesson that joking about Agatha and Rio fucking with him watching was off-limits.

Rio wondered how long that would last after a particularly bawdy joke about blue balls.

Whilst she had to concentrate hard to remember her lines, wanting to not be the one actor in the room who had to keep checking over and over again, she still had time and bandwidth to marvel at Agatha.

She was off-book.

She didn’t so much as glance at her script.

She delivered each line as if it were the first time she were ever saying it.

She was phenomenal and Rio had a feeling that if she’d never heard of or met this woman in her life up until now, she might have fallen head over heels from the sheer magnitude of talent on display.

But the other actor in the room, the youngest of the group, was struggling a little. Billy was also not off-book. And where Rio was mesmerised by Agatha, so was he.

Billy fumbled with every line that came after one of Agatha’s. He enthusiastically tried to continue on until Maria had to, most of the time, call cut to get him his line checked.

Rio felt sorry for him during these moments but mostly she felt grateful it wasn’t her needing the extra help.

As they rehearsed and rehashed, she found her energy waning, and noticed that Agatha, too, by only two in the afternoon, also looked on her last legs. It happened so suddenly, that one minute Agatha was all dazzle, and the next minute, she was pale, and the mistakes were slipping in.

They stopped for lunch just after Agatha’s fifth mistake of the day and Rio watched as Agatha picked at her food and instead chugged coffee. She recognised her own behaviours in that of the older brunette and in doing so felt sick.

The only words Rio said to Agatha all day were these: “please eat”.

She’d whispered them close to her ear as she’d stood from the table to go and fetch another drink and when she’d returned with it Agatha was making more of an effort with her food, but avoiding eye contact with everyone, including Rio.

After their late lunch, the afternoon went a little smoother in terms of performances. Agatha was again back on track and even Billy managed to make it through a whole run of the scene without needing his lines called out to him by the script supervisor.

It was long, it was gruelling, and by the time the sun had set and everyone was released to go home, Rio wanted to crawl into her bed and think of nothing but blue eyes as they once had been, not as they now were.

 

WEDNESDAY

The pre-agreed day for lunch with James, Agatha, and Maria had arrived.

Rio wasn’t happy about it.

She couldn’t imagine Agatha was happy about it. But at least it was the only thing she had scheduled in today. Which meant, much to Alice’s delight, that she could spend most of the morning actually trying to remember her lines.

Lunch had been arranged at a local restaurant rather than the set for reasons still unclear to Rio. Alice had been waxing lyrical about Maria’s wanting everything to be as “natural” and “easy” as any regular family, and so “naturally” and “easily” she’d chosen an regular restaurant.

So Rio turned up the last of the lot and found that when she arrived at the restaurant there were already paps waiting outside. She ignored them as she walked inside but wondered if they’d been there for Agatha’s arrival or if they’d arrived only after they’d got wind of Agatha Harkness dining with her director and two costars. She didn’t have time to dwell as she was led to the back of the restaurant where her little fake family plus Maria were sitting and it felt anything other than regular.

James was the first to spot her and exclaimed which made both Agatha and Maria turn to her and stand from their seats. James reached her first, keen to hug and be hugged before anyone else.

And Rio was charmed by it because who wouldn’t be charmed by a small boy enthusiastically wrapping his arms around your legs. She managed to untangle him and hug him back and found herself, to her great surprise, being called by him (again, enthusiastically), “mama Rio!”.

It took her a second to process this and she must have pulled a strange face because little James laughed his big laugh and Rio blushed slightly.

“Rio! So glad you could make it!”

Now the way Alice had told her of this invitation, it hadn’t exactly sounded like she’d had much choice in the matter. But she restrained herself from pointing this out as she gave Maria a quick one-armed hug, and the director then gently pried James away from her so she could turn to Agatha.

Unlike the other two hugs, this one was warmer, the only natural one of the lot. And Rio was smiling already by the time Agatha murmured against her ear, “He’s calling me ‘mama Aggie’. How do I not kill a five year old?”

Her smile turned into a laugh as Agatha kissed her cheek quickly and pulled away. Agatha’s expression was serious until suddenly it wasn’t and Rio wanted to take her hand and pull her from the restaurant to just keep her to herself.

But Agatha was clearly the stronger of the two, and she grinned and winked before she turned back to take up her spot at the table beside James and diagonally across from Rio’s empty seat.

“So,” Maria announced happily, “isn’t this cosy.”

“Cosy cosy!” James announced as he picked his crayon back up and continued to make the big swipes of blue across his colouring book.

“Cosy,” Agatha agreed with a hint of sarcasm that Rio caught but Maria clearly didn’t.

“I’m so so keen that we’re all aligned on being as much a family as possible.”

Agatha cleared her throat and Rio watched as her pale fingers, notably sans Alice’s ring, tapped at her water glass.

“Easy,” Rio said absently, choosing to bluff her way through the meal as much as possible. “The script’s good and we trust you to direct us so it’ll be fine.”

Agatha cleared her throat again and Rio couldn’t help it when she added, “Plus Agatha’s just lost the Oscar to me making her a four time nominee, one time winner. We’ll be fine.”

Agatha’s brows shot up in surprise at the dig and Rio smirked at her, not missing the slight twitch of her lips as their eyes met.

Maybe the meal wouldn’t be so bad after all.

“It truly is such a gift to have you both. Obviously with Wanda on board initially, I was excited too but this combo…” she trailed off and gestured between the two women and Rio wondered if she’d feel differently if she knew the truth. But she said nothing and only smiled some more.

Before they ordered Maria was the person making the most effort at the table.

But then Rio didn’t really mind this because all she had to do was nod at the right times and smile when absolutely necessary. The rest of the time? The rest of the time she could watch Agatha. She could make eyes at Agatha. She could map the lines and curves of the face she knew and loved so well.

Agatha didn’t look away whilst Rio did this. Their light converged, twin stars burning with a brilliance owed not to life, but to death. Something about not having been able to be herself with Agatha, not being able to truly enjoy seeing or being with Agatha, it had changed her, changed the both of them.

Perhaps their before selves had died together in their last moments spent in that house in Berkeley. And now there was just after.

They were different now.

They could be better now.

“No creo en el destino, mija. Pero creo en ti. Creo que ya sabes lo que quieres. Y cuando estés lista, y cuando sepas que ella también, serás mejor y más brillante que nunca.” I don't believe in fate, my daughter. But I believe in you. I believe you already know what you want. And when you are ready, and when you know she is too, you will be better and brighter than ever.

Her dad’s words rung in her ears as she looked into those oceanic eyes.

She just had to get through the next few days and keep a steady head until Sunday, especially on Sunday.

“Rio?” Her dad’s voice died in her brain as she turned to Maria, “How do you feel about that?”

Oh shit.

Her fucking dad. His fucking stupid, fucking kind, fucking-…

“It’s not in mine or Rio’s contract to do that,” Agatha said suddenly, “at least, it isn’t in mine. And I know Alice isn’t an idiot so she wouldn’t have agreed to it either. Christmas away from home for press would be ridiculous.”

Rio blinked, looked at Agatha and saw that she’d shot her a meaningful ‘you’re welcome’ look.

“Why would,” Rio cleared her throat and turned to absently roll back a stray crayon towards James. “I mean, why would you-…?”

“To promote the whole holiday season,” Agatha said sharply, though Rio knew well enough that the sharpness wasn’t aimed at her. “I agreed up until five days before Christmas. I’m sure Rio is the same, and if not, I’d renegotiate my contract to cover her too.”

Rio looked up from where James had considered this crayon rolling thing a game and was now rolling three crayons at once in her direction. She blindly grabbed them as she watched Maria splutter on her soda and lime.

“Really, Agatha. It took so long to get you on board I-… no, I mean… it was just an errant idea.”

James started up again: “Mama Rio! Crayon pleeeeeaaaase!”

Rio turned back to him and one by one returned the crayons, this time not rolling them. She heard Agatha take in a heavy breath and just knew she was about to offload something on Maria so took her turn instead, “Did you invite us here to negotiate contracts with a five year old present so we might be softer?”

“I mean…”

Rio looked up, but not at Maria, she looked at Agatha, and Agatha? Well she looked incandescent.
