“You know what?” Rio asked quickly, her eyes still on Agatha, her hands now held up like a wall as James continued to roll his crayons at her and giggle every time they smacked her palms. “Why don’t we order some ice cream for James and then head on out? I won’t discuss contracts without either Alice or a lawyer and neither will Agatha.”

As Maria spluttered some more, Agatha turned to look at her. Her jaw was still tight, her eyes hard and unreadable for a second before she nodded and turned back to Maria again.

“Sounds like a plan,” Maria said lamely and Rio barely glanced at her before she looked back at James and caught the last of his crayons in her hand.

“Sound good, buddy? Would you like some ice cream?”

“Excuse me just one second,” Maria left for the bathroom as James began to bounce in his chair and the four year old was suddenly in danger of knocking over his water before Agatha expertly reached for it was the nonchalance of a mother.

“Ice cream for you, mama Aggie?”

Rio noticed Agatha’s jaw twitch and she had to hide her smile for fear it might twitch in her direction too. But Agatha managed to say a soft, “Not for me, honey.”

“Mama Rioooooooo?”

Unsure when she’d been designated “mama” still, Rio nodded and watched as James bounced even more and tried to climb over the table to her until Agatha gently pulled him back.

“Christmas,” she was saying as she pulled the little kid into her lap to try and isolate his excited limbs, “in a foreign country all to celebrate a movie is so insane I can’t even-… argh!” James had discovered Agatha’s hair and decided he liked it more than his crayons.

“James,” Agatha said patiently as Rio watched her try to gently disentangle his hands from her hair. She grimaced again and Rio moved from her seat to go help. Turned out all James really needed to stop doing whatever naughty thing he was doing was a distraction. And Rio was happy to oblige if it meant Agatha could keep her hair on her head rather than ripped out in clumps by the little boy.

She leant over them and lifted James from Agatha and shot Agatha a quick glance before she marched over to the bar with the boy on her hip. With his hand in her own to prevent at least one of them from grabbing her hair, she was able to make an order of two small ice cream sundaes and then head back to the table by the time Maria was back.

The two women were sitting in total silence.

“So,” Rio said as calmly as she could as James was placed back in his seat. “Where’s your mama, James?”

“She’s coming in an hour or so,” Maria answered for him and Rio glanced up to make eyes at Agatha at this announcement. It meant only one thing: a whole hour to sit through this so-called “family bonding lunch”.

James had already proven himself a handful and Maria wasn’t exactly anyone’s favourite either. Especially as far as Agatha was concerned.

But they managed to struggle through some small talk, some basic discussions about filming, and all paid as much attention to the boisterous boy who was so unlike Agatha’s actual son and Rio’s mellizo as they could.

Agatha remained mostly silent throughout the rest of the lunch, and only really smiled again when James’s mom came to fetch him and the boy was gone, Rio’s sweater was ruined with the imprints of sticky, chocolatey fingers, and Agatha’s somehow remained pristine.

“How did you get here, Rio? Agatha and I took a car. Join us?”

Rio agreed, because it was easier than to make excuses. Besides, she thought perhaps she might save Maria’s life - or at least dignity - if she were a buffer between her and Agatha in a shared car.

Maria paid the check and confirmed the car was just outside so they gathered their things to get going. Only, by the door, with Rio being ahead of the pack, did she spot before the others what awaited them. She stopped and felt a hand on her lower back she knew already would be Agatha’s.

Reaching behind herself to take it she held on tight as she marched with her outside into the small crowd of photographers gathered to capture the photo of two Oscar-winning actresses and their Oscar-winning director.

A wave of panic flooded her chest that hadn’t been there when she was alone. She didn’t know why, didn’t have time to process, but felt it more viscerally than she had in a long while.

If she’d had any time at all to stop and think she might have recognised that the last time this panic had coursed through her it had been when she was trying to get Nicky safely through the hoard of paps that had awaited them in London.

Rio didn’t let go of Agatha’s hand until she had opened the car door and stepped back for Agatha to climb in first. The look Agatha gave her when she stepped around her made her hesitate before she climbed in after her. But Agatha wasn’t having it. She wouldn’t allow it. She’d grabbed at Rio’s lapels and pulled her in after her, making her stumble into her on the back seat of the large SUV.

Maria came in just as Rio was blushing and righting herself and Agatha only released her hold on her when the door slammed shut.

Clearing her throat Rio could feel her heart blocking her airways and it wasn’t until Agatha leant around her, one arm coming up to rest behind her head on the seat, the other to tap at Maria, and crossing over Rio’s stomach, that she could breathe again.

Agatha wasn’t subtle about her care for Rio anymore. At least, not to Rio’s mind.

She’d barely spoken to Maria since the contract negotiations incident, and yet now she was actively engaging her, asking about characterisation during a hospital scene, all so she could have her arms around Rio who sat between them.

Rio could thank her only by pressing their thighs together, and as Agatha remained encircled around her she felt her anxiety begin to calm to that same dull thrum that had been ever-present over the last few days.

Agatha only pulled back when they pulled to a stop in the studio’s parking lot. Maria had stepped from the car already and just as Rio had turned to follow her out, Agatha had taken her hand and made her turn around.

“You okay?”

“Fine. Yeah. Fine.”

She knew Agatha didn’t believe her but she was okay with that. And Agatha released her so Rio could give Maria a quick hug, shoot Agatha a smile as she stepped out onto terra firma, and then disappear off into the maze that was the studio set.

 

THURSDAY

Thursday was a day that started off with Anna Vidal, rather than Miguel.

Rio had called her dad’s phone and found a much softer, more feminine voice at the other end of it. But her mom hadn’t let on that she knew why Rio was calling, and she hadn’t mentioned that she knew all of what she’d been talking to her dad about over the past week.

She simply asked how she was, told her she loved her, and passed the phone to Miguel.

After what was a quick ten minutes where Rio found that just listening to her dad talk about the work in the garden he was going to do was able to ground her, she hung up and went to work with the ever-present shadow that was Alice.

Their day was a hectic one, with lighting tests and walk arounds planned on set. It meant that Rio had to be present, had to be constantly listening to her director as she pointed out shots, called out instructions, and placements and costumes were adjusted and tweaked.

It was one of those days where Rio was able to become better acquainted with the crew. A camera guy she knew from another set, but didn’t remember the name of, became a boon through most of the day.

He made sure to help her find her mark if she’d lost her concentration for a moment and drifted too far over. The boom operator, too, was familiar to her, but she soon realised only because they’d met at a party years ago when they were both trying to get their foot in the door.

And so the day was easy, for the most part. She didn’t see Agatha, though she knew she was somewhere doing something.

Her thoughts remained mostly quiet, and she wasn’t in deep despair for more than the few seconds of thinking time she had between new set ups or the time it took to move between the different sets already constructed for the shoot next week.

Set-life was busy now, constantly humming with activity. And Rio, and her fellow actors, were no longer the real focus. The crew now were the important ones.

Things were needing lit, built, and planned. Everything was on a tight deadline, everything was late, everything was urgent.

So by the time Rio was done for the day, no one paid much mind to her slinking off with Alice and heading home. It was whilst at home, whilst in the quiet comfort of her house in the hills, that the thoughts came back, louder and more virulent than ever.

She spoke through them with Alice, laid everything out on the table as she cradled her beloved barolo to her chest and stared at the ring sitting erect in its little cushion in its little box.

“I just don’t see what was wrong with my choice.”

Rio huffed quietly, unable to rehash the same conversation over and over.

“She thinks it’s from me.”

“And? Let her.”

“Alice, please. I need to give her one that-…”

“Rio, babe-…”

“I’m not discussing it anymore, Alice. I can’t stand to watch her fucking twist it and touch it like it’s this magical thing that brings her comfort when actually…”

She huffed and slammed the ring box shut. “I just can’t watch it anymore.”

They didn’t discuss it any further until, in the darkness of Rio’s bedroom, with Alice laying just a couple feet away, the subject was raised again.

“I’m worried she’s manipulating you into crawling back to her. That maybe it’s all a show to get you to acquiesce and just be her piece on the side, always just waiting for her to choose you.”

Rio swallowed in the darkness, “I’m worried about that too.”

She felt Alice move beside her but remained where she was, staring up at the black ceiling. “Then why-…”

“Because I have to believe I can’t love someone this much and be fooled so completely. I have to believe in every look and every touch and know that she does love me. And so I’m giving her her comfort back. I want her to have comfort through this. Because my dad, and you, are mine, and she has Jen and Nicky… but she won’t sleep without me there and she won’t…” she swallowed and released a noise that made Alice reach for her arm, “I need to give her this comfort, Alice. At least until I can get the truth on Sunday.”

They didn’t speak after that.

Rio barely slept.

 

FRIDAY

In the morning, Miguel talked her down from a near panic attack, and Alice held her as he did.

All week she’d been talking herself up to doing what she knew she had to and now the day was finally here where she promised herself she’d do it and suddenly… she’d panicked.

What if Agatha had laughed in her face? What if she’d said “I’m a method actor, moron” and thrown Rio’s new ring in the trash? What if, worst of all, she’d taken it as a sign that Rio was petty and immature, because she’d been unable, when first asked, to simply pick a ring?

Miguel was good. Miguel talked her round, reminded her that Agatha was being patient, was listening to Rio, and going only as far as Rio would now allow. He told her that the Agatha he’d met was a woman who respected her so much that she’d spent the day with her family, choosing to speak to them in their language, choosing to wait for hours with the simple hope that she might catch even a glimpse of her.

He reminded her of something he’d been saying all week: “Hacemos cosas divertidas cuando tenemos miedo.” We do funny things when we’re scared.

But now the scariest and worst thing had happened to the both of them because Agatha had been scared and now Agatha was trying to be brave. So Rio could be brave too. She could fix her mistake, and wait for Agatha to fix hers on Sunday.

By the time she was on set she was feeling more at peace, having foregone any caffeine for fear she’d was already too jumped up to handle it.

She left Alice at her trailer and walked the few yards to get to Agatha’s where after taking a few deep breaths she knocked lightly and then stepped back.

Jen answered the door within seconds and Rio wondered if Alice had warned her that she would be making a visit.

“Hi,” Rio said, smiling a little. “Is Agatha-…?”

Agatha must have heard her because suddenly she was behind Jen, her hand on her arm to move her out of the way so she could see Rio better.

Her blue eyes cast out behind her and Rio knew she was checking to see if Alice had tagged along with her. She was glad she hadn’t allowed it.

“Can I speak to you? In… privately?”

Her gaze flitted over to Jen and she saw she looked torn but Agatha answered for her and Jen only looked over her shoulder at her: “Of course. Come in.”

Rio smiled a little and stepped up and into the trailer, only to have Jen hold her wrist gently and shoot her a questioning look that Rio answered with a small nod. Jen left then, closing the door quietly behind herself.

Agatha’s trailer was different to hers. She’d gone with more of a colour scheme than Rio had. Where Rio’s was a jumble of colours with the simple aim of being cosy and warm, Agatha’s was much more of a theme.

She had browns and beiges, interspersed with some deep reds throughout. It wasn’t hard to miss that she also had pictures up, just like Rio had, only hers were of Nicky.

This was a place where Ralph didn’t exist.

As Rio took in the space she was aware of Agatha moving back on perch on the edge of the couch. She’d cleared her throat and in an unguarded voice said: “You’re ready to talk, honey?”

Mellifluous and soft, Agatha’s question caused her chest to ache suddenly, and Rio had to physically turn on the spot, had to take a slow breath in and an even slower one out before she said: “No, I… it’s… it’s something else.”

She turned back around and saw Agatha looking pale again, her hands twitching in that familiar way as she toyed with the ring on her left hand.

“I… it’s… that. I want to talk about that.”

She gestured vaguely to Agatha’s hands and Agatha immediately closed her eyes, immediately stopped the spinning and instead gripped her finger instead. “Okay. Okay. I wondered if you might ask me to… I just… it just makes me feel…”

“Agatha,” Rio whispered urgently, already knowing what Agatha was thinking. She moved over then and sank to her knees before her, reaching gently for her taught hands and carefully beginning to remove the ring. “It’s not…”

She stopped as she heard Agatha suck in a sharp breath as the ring was hovering over her knuckle, and decided she couldn’t be the one to remove it. She gently pushed it back down into place.

Her hands fell then, naturally landing on Agatha’s knees, finding their place without her thinking.

She took a breath, saw Agatha begin to spin the ring again, and lost all control of her words when she said: “That ring isn’t from me. It’s from Alice. Alice picked it for you. I couldn’t bring myself to do it and now you’ve been wearing it and I think you’ve been wearing it because you think I picked it for you but I didn’t. You’re not method. You don’t go method. So you must, you must, be wearing it because you think it’s mine and, and Agatha…”

She raised her gaze up and found Agatha’s eyes were closed, her lips parted, her brow furrowed. She looked as if she were concentrating hard, but on what, Rio didn’t know.

Rio raised up slowly and lifted her hands from Agatha’s knees to instead cup her face, and in doing so Agatha opened her eyes.

Rio’s front was pressed against Agatha’s legs, and the stretch was almost uncomfortable, if it weren’t done for the sole reason of trying to give Agatha some comfort.

“I just couldn’t bear to pick you a wedding-… I…”

Below her arms Agatha was removing her ring, creating a fist around it, her eyes still on Rio. “It’s okay. It’s stupid anyway. I just-…”

“It’s not stupid,” Rio said quickly, pulling back to uncurl Agatha’s fingers around the ugly ring that she’d hated since she first saw it. “This one just isn’t right for you.”

Agatha sucked in a shaky breath and Rio turned to place the shiny offender on the coffee table. She’d return it to Stevie later, and made a mental note to check in on Alice’s taste before she ever bought a ring for Jen.

“If you’ll let me, a couple days ago I chose you a different ring. One I think suits you better, one I-…” but in looking around again, she saw that Agatha was struggling, that her face had collapsed down and her head with it.

So Rio sat up again, and she lifted Agatha’s face to see her eyes. She didn’t want her to hide, couldn’t bear her hiding anything anymore. “Will you let me? Give you another ring?”

It took a second, a second of just staring, a second of losing herself in Agatha’s hypnotic blue eyes. But Agatha had moved her hands cautiously to hold her wrists and sucked in a breath before she said, “I don’t want something you don’t want to give me, Rio. I shouldn’t have forced it. I shouldn’t have-…”

“I want to give you a ring, Agatha.”

Before Agatha could say anything else she pulled her right hand away and as she was reaching down into her pocket she felt the soft brush of Agatha’s lips against her left palm. She stopped to look and saw something that she’d never get over. Agatha was pressing her whole face into her hand, nuzzling into it as though she’d woken in the middle of the night and Rio was the soft, cool pillow beneath her head.

Rio’s fingers curled inwards, holding Agatha in place. And the woman just turned her head more, pressed closer, cradled Rio right back as she held her.

Rio’s free hand curled around the metal that was warm now, having been carried around in her pocket all morning. She bit the inside of her cheek and as she did, Agatha slowly turned back to her, her cheeks flushed as if she’d been caught.

“I hope you like it,” she said lamely, aware now of their positioning, that she was on her knees brandishing a ring.

Agatha blinked slowly and to Rio it looked as if she were suddenly nervous but she turned to look at the ring held out to her and she bit down on her lower lip when she saw it.

She didn’t reach for it though and Rio didn’t know what to do so she stood slowly and Agatha’s eyes flickered back to her in panic, watching as she stood to her full height.

After a second, Agatha stood with her, and she held her left hand out, splaying her fingers so Rio could slip the diamond onto her ring finger. It was the perfect fit, the perfect match, and looked more at home on Agatha’s hand than the pear shaped diamond ever had.

They both stared at it, Agatha’s fingers now curling gently around Rio’s hand, and Rio toyed with the diamond, making sure it was perfectly straight on Agatha’s finger.

The moment was heavier than Rio was expecting. The ring carried more meaning than she could bear. But she found she wanted it to mean even more than it did. She wanted to be buried under the weight of the diamond.

She wanted it to add weight to Agatha’s hand so that every time she held it she knew she was hers.

“Christmas wives,” Agatha murmured, her voice taking on a soft timbre as Rio looked up to meet her gaze. She looked calmer now, as if the new ring had tempered whatever tempest was raging behind sea-blue eyes.

Her lips twitched a little, curving up into a timid smile, and Rio’s eyes fell to them and she hesitated for a moment, torn between kissing them and smiling back.

Agatha must have felt Rio’s indecision because her smile faded and she leant in to instead kiss Rio’s cheek. It was so close. So damn close to the corner of her mouth that it had to be deliberate.

But Agatha wasn’t pushing. She hadn’t pushed Rio, or tried to, since the arrival of her bag and the empanadas. But Rio found her wanting to now. Because if Agatha simply kissed her then Rio wouldn’t be living with the torment of wanting to and keeping herself from doing it constantly.

She wanted Agatha to make the decision for them both. To decide that everything was fine now, that they would be okay, that they would keep kissing and be together forever.

Though she knew that would never work.

And she wanted this to work, so she had to wait.

In two more days she’d have her answers and she’d be able to make a decision.

In her heart’s secret whispers she knew the decision would always and forever just be Agatha. But secrecy and whispers weren’t good enough anymore. She had to pick Agatha loudly, and Agatha had to pick her the same.

So as Agatha pulled away Rio was able to smile because she had hope burning away in the cradle of her chest.

“Christmas wives,” she echoed back to Agatha, letting the two words float between them and into the universe as a half-formed wish.

“I should go,” she said quietly, watching as Agatha’s face fell a little but she managed to incline her head in acknowledgement.

Rio looked away before she could change her mind and stooped to steal back Alice’s choice of ring. It felt cold and wrong in her hand so she shoved it deep into her pocket, took one last look at Agatha, and left her alone in the middle of the trailer, spinning her new ring.

That night, Rio spoke to her dad for over an hour. He mostly listened, he mostly let Rio talk and talk and talk. She spoke of having never wanted to be settled, of never thinking she would. She asked if when Miguel had met Anna it had been like a lightning strike or a slow tide pulling them in.

She said she was ready for it. Ready for it all.

And in two days time she wanted to hear all of what Agatha had to give. She wanted the bad and the good and everything in between.

Chapter End Notes

Thank you so much for all the love, comments, tweets, ngls I’ve been getting recently. This author is very moved by all of them.

Nicky up next.

Chapter 35: NRHV

Chapter Summary

Nicky arrives on set.

Rio moves from panic to pride to pining, and continues to circle all three.

Chapter Notes

This is basically a chapter about how Nicky might look like Rio but he's got Agatha in there too... quite a lot of her actually

I'm posting it now because I'm hoping it'll make me write faster ahead of Christmas... we'll see

See the end of the chapter for more notes

After giving Agatha her ring, Rio slept like a baby.

For the first time in days now, she woke up feeling, even slightly, refreshed.

Alice didn’t know what to do with herself. But Rio didn’t mind that Alice had backed off a little in the time it took them to get showered and changed and head to set. She’d spent the evening with her rehashing the scene in Agatha’s trailer.

Alice had cried at one point and Rio had found that she’d had to be the one to comfort her for a change. Alice had never really admitted why but Rio had put two and two together and got to five.

For years Alice had endured Rio’s revolving door of women, and now she was going out of her way to give her fake wife the perfect fake engagement ring, even as her heart lay broken in her chest.

And her best friend had cried about it. Yeah, she got to five pretty easily.

But she’d dried Alice’s tears, then recounted the entire story again to her dad, and she’d fallen asleep exhausted and feeling a little better than she had been the night before.

So the journey to work didn’t feel quite as tough. The walk to her trailer with her cup of coffee didn’t feel so painful. The sight of Agatha’s trailer, just two down from her own, didn’t sting nearly as much as it usually did.

Perhaps this is what her dad had been talking about. “El corazón tarda en sanar, cariño. Pero cuando sane, lo sabrás.” The heart takes time to heal, sweetheart. But when it does, you’ll know.

She took half an hour to just relax, bothering Alice by stretching out on the couch and taking most of the space. Her task today was to be around for when she was needed, if she was needed. Maria had designated this a “free day” for rehearsals of any and every scene she wanted testing before they moved into filming the next week.

Rio would be needed in the afternoon, but not the morning. Only it still meant she had to hang around in the morning “just in case”.

It was bullshit.

She hated days like these. She hated the waiting and the lounging. She wanted to be moving and doing something. And perhaps it was the fact that she’d had a full eight hours sleep but she needed to get out of this trailer.

Now.

“I’m going to find that basketball hoop one of the guys told me about.”

“Which guy?”

Rio scoffed but shot her friend a look. She didn’t know “which guy” but she knew he was friendly and carried a walkie talkie. So crew. A friendly guy on the crew.

“It’s down the back of the lot,” Rio settled on as she swung her legs over the couch. “Are you coming?”

“No, I think I should stay and hold the fort down. You know… be the adult.”

“Come on! A few hoops? A quick game? Alice!”

“Jesus, you have a good night’s sleep and you become a monster again.”

Rio laughed and went into the little bedroom off the main living space to source the basketball she’d spotted there earlier in the week. “You want me to wither away?”

“I want you to eat a good breakfast first, please. I saw you pushing your food around last night. And you keep ignoring the very specific bagel I have delivered here every morning.”

Rio huffed and began to bounce the ball as she came back into the room. Using the rhythm of it to calm herself for a few seconds before she caught the ball and without warning tossed it to Alice who only just managed to catch it.

“Fine. A bagel and then a game?”

“I’m not playing with you.”

Rio rolled her eyes but made strides to the wrapped bagel on the side. “Are you really going to hold the fort down or are you going to call Jen over and fool around in my bed?”

She didn’t need to turn around to know Alice was blushing. She took a large bite of her lukewarm bagel as Alice said: “I would never fool around in your bed.” There was a pause as Rio chewed, “The couch on the other hand…”

Rio almost choked on her breakfast but managed to swallow before it got lodged properly in her throat. “Pervert.”

Alice laughed as Rio continued to eat, hunched over the sink like a gremlin. But she finished the bagel in record time and washed it down with her now lukewarm coffee. It settled heavily in her stomach. So heavily that she stomped back over to Alice and lay down on the couch again.

“I ate too much.”

“No you’ve been eating too little for days. You need to stop that.”

“You know I-…”

“Don’t eat when stressed, yes. But… it’s been a long time. Your mom’s been texting me to check in on how much you’re eating.”

Rio sighed and hid behind her hands.

“Remember what you told me about how you felt about seeing Agatha not eating?”

“Mmm… shut up.”

“Well you need to eat too.”

Rio grumbled and dropped her hands from her face. The ceiling above was an off-white, and bore the small circles of lights that gave either too much light or nothing at all. She counted every bulb until Alice interrupted her.

“You wanna talk about tomorrow?”

“No. I wanna digest and then I’m going to find that hoop.”

Alice hummed and Rio closed her eyes. The concept of tomorrow was another reason for Rio wanting to get some of her newfound energy out.

She wanted to run the court until she couldn’t breathe, to jump and shoot until her legs ached and her arms felt like jello. Anything to not think about the nerves that were beginning to bubble away now that “Sunday” had turned into “tomorrow”.

She couldn’t lie around anymore.

She threw herself up and scooped the basketball up from the side. “Last chance, loser. Want to come?”

“No, I’ve already text Jen that I’ll soon have an empty couch.”

Rio rolled her eyes as she went to the door and turned to Alice as she opened it, “Phone’s in my pocket. But if on the off-chance I don’t answer it,” it was Alice’s turn to roll her eyes, “I’ll be at the back of the lot. Northwestern corner, apparently.”

Alice hummed her goodbye and waved Rio out the door. She stepped out with a grin into the cool air of the bright day. Two steps and then her feet were on the floor, two breaths, a turn, and then.

“Rio!”

Her heart stopped. She knew that voice. She knew that if she turned to the right and looked down two trailers, she’d see the little boy with the same face as hers.

She hadn’t been prepared for it. She hadn’t been remotely prepared for it.

She swallowed, realised she’d been stood still for longer than was normal, and then her body began to simply carry her away even as, on the wind, another call sounded.

“Rio!”

Rio kept stepping, kept putting one foot in front of the other.

She’d counted five of them and then came the third shout, accompanied by heavy, frantic footsteps.

“Melliza!”

Rio stopped what she was doing. She stopped moving. Stopped breathing.

She turned around.

Nicky was charging towards her, wearing a green Celtics sweater with the hood bouncing along behind him. He looked desperate, his eyes wide even as his brow was furrowed, and Rio dropped the ball in her hands to catch him as he crashed into her.

The impact, on her heart more than her body, was immediate. Nicky was clinging to her, breathing fast and heavy, and Rio clung to him back.

“Hey, mellizo.”

She kissed the side of his head and pulled away to crouch properly and look up at him, fix his sweater properly about his neck, hiding her panic in the gentle adjustments.

“You didn’t stop.”

“No, sweetheart. I’m sorry, I was…” Agatha came into view then, stopping just beside Nicky and placing her hand on his head. “I didn’t hear you, I’m sorry.”

She could feel Agatha’s eyes on her as she dropped her hands to Nicky’s arms and smiled as best she could, “I was just off to shoot some hoops. You wanna join?”

Nicky was eyeing her, his frown still in place, his shrewd brown eyes more discerning and probing than she’d ever seen them. They made her feel ashamed; ashamed she’d turned away, ashamed she’d kept walking, ashamed she’d lied about it.

“You want me to?”

“Sí, mellizo.”

Rio raised her gaze to Agatha then and saw that she too was focusing on her son but that she looked at Rio when Rio looked to her. Agatha gave a tentative smile and Rio looked back to Nicky.

She knew Agatha knew she’d heard him.

She knew Agatha knew she’d walked away.

She cleared her throat quietly and tugged gently on the strings of Nicky’s sweater.

“This new?”

“Mama said I could have an early birthday present. Rio, why did you not stop?”

Rio frowned a little, feeling the heat rise in her cheeks. Her mind began to swirl and make her feel dizzy as she balanced on her toes and continued to fiddle with the strings of Nicky’s sweater.

“Honey,” Agatha said softly, now crouching down to be level with Rio, “You know Rio would never ignore you. She’s your melliza, right?”

It was worse that Agatha was lying for her too. Much worse.

But Rio swallowed, and looked up into the face that was so like hers but much more innocent, much softer. “Lo siento, mellizo,” she breathed out, “I didn’t hear.”

When she smiled a little Nicky’s shoulders relaxed and he briefly looked to his mom before he turned back to Rio and nodded cautiously, his little hand reaching to touch her hair. “Okay.”

“Okay?” Rio said softly, trying to perk herself up and swallow down the panic that still threatened to consume her, “You want to play some ball?”

“Sí, melliza.”

“Okay,” Rio smiled, glancing at Agatha but purposefully avoiding her gaze, “That okay, mama?”

She bit her lip, flushed the bright pink she’d been fighting off earlier and cleared her throat. Out of the corner of her eye she could see Agatha fighting a smile, “That’s okay with me. I have to go rehearse though so…”

“He can stick with me all morning. I don’t think I’m needed until this afternoon but have to hang around just in case. Alice said she’d reach out if I’m needed.”

Rio cleared her throat and stood quickly and for a second the world span and she felt like she might be spinning with it but she remained standing and soon Agatha was standing with her, an anchoring hand on her back.

“You sure? Jen said-…”

“Oh, I think Jen has plans with Alice.”

She looked up then and caught Agatha’s eye, and found her arching a brow and smirking just a little. She felt her fist the fabric of her shirt in her hand and as Nicky ran away to fetch the ball back Agatha lowered her voice, suddenly serious, and asked, “You ignored him?”

“I…,” Rio began, searching for the right words and deciding on the truth, “I panicked.”

Agatha glanced at where Nicky was and looked back as Rio added, “It won’t happen again. You know I-…”

“Rio, I should have warned you. His nanny got sick and… I had to bring him. I figured he’d be in my trailer all day.”

“I’m pleased he’s here.”

“Are you?”

Agatha wasn’t mad, at least, she didn’t look it. She instead looked… nervous?

Rio only had time to nod because Nicky was back with them and had the basketball cradled to his chest with his right hand seeking Rio’s left. “Can we go?”

“Yes, kid. Let’s go.”

“Ah!” Agatha dropped down to place several quick kisses to Nicky’s cheek and made him squirm happily as she tugged his hoodie a little closer around his neck. “Be good, keep warm. Stay close to Rio, okay?”

“Yes, mama. Close to Rio.”

Rio smiled and wasn’t expecting Agatha to then sweep up and pull her head against her own, her fingers clutching at her hair as she whispered against her ear so Nicky couldn’t hear, “there’s no one I’d trust more with him than you.”

Rio swallowed as Agatha pulled away and when they met eyes she felt something lurch in her chest that was different to panic. It felt a lot like pride. And as Agatha pulled away it turned into pining.

She turned to Nicky, and saw him watching her closely, his brow still more furrowed than it should be for a little boy but she steered him in the direction she thought they should be going and left Agatha to watch them leave.

This was fine.

Totally fine.

It was just Nicky.

Agatha’s son.

The boy she’d been told was on this earth because Agatha had wanted Rio so much she’d had sex with her husband and… manifested a boy exactly in her likeness.

Totally, utterly, fine.

She cleared her throat, willed the panic and pining away.

“Early birthday, huh? When is your birthday?”

“In two weeks,” Nicky said proudly, his frown disappearing all of a sudden as he trotted alongside Rio and dropped her hand to hold the ball up to her. “I turn eight.”

“Nooooo,” Rio laughed, “you’ve got to be closer to eighty two.”

Nicky laughed, “That is so silly!”

Rio hummed and bit the inside of her cheek, pleased Nicky had done a one eighty since he’d first collided with her.

“Okay, kid,” she announced as she tossed the ball between her hands and Nicky hurried alongside her, “very serious decision to be made. You wanna play with me to see how many hoops we can get as a team or you wanna play against me and see who gets the most?”

“Umm,” Nicky said with a deep frown as he lifted his hand up to tuck it around Rio’s elbow. She stopped throwing the ball. “With you. I wanna see if we can get to a thousand.”

“A thousand?!”

“Si!”

Rio laughed and glanced down at Nicky with a smirk, “Oh, easy! We are so gonna hit a thousand!”

But a noise behind her made her glance over her shoulder and Nicky looked too. Little James was hanging off his mom’s hand, having just stepped from his own trailer, straining to get to them.

“Mama Rio! Mama Riooooooo!”

Something like dread settled in the pit of Rio’s stomach as a little hand gripped her elbow tighter and a small voice said, “Mama Rio?”

Rio cleared her throat and looked down into wide brown eyes and saw that all the joy had disappeared from Nicky’s soft features in less than the time it had taken for James to sound her name. “He’s playing Luca, mine and your mom’s son in the movie.”

“Oh.”

Rio didn’t have time to explain further as a cannonball of a child flew its way towards them, his mother trailing along behind. James threw himself at Rio and head butted her in the process but didn’t seem to notice.

Nicky stepped back a little and Rio, a little winded, transferred the ball to one hand so she could reach for James with her other. “Well, hey kid.”

“Sorry about that!” James’s mom caught up with them and gently pried her son off of Rio. “He gets so excited, you know.”

“Oh, I know.”

James was practically vibrating in front of his mother, doing a strange sort of jig on the spot. Nicky just watched him with a look of slight distain on his face and Rio took his hand back and squeezed it.

“This is Nicky, James. We’re just going to play some ball and-…”

“Oh you’re a sweetheart for asking!”

Rio blinked, wondered where she’d even remotely asked anything, but it was too late. Clearly his mom wanted a rest. “He’d love to! Get some energy out before later, you know.”

No, Rio didn’t know. But she was suddenly left alone with two little boys - one still bouncing on his feet, the other now pressing into her side.

“Right,” she took a deep breath, “let’s go then.”

She turned them around, motioning with her head for James to follow. And he did. Until he got bored and decided running ahead was more fun.

“Careful!” Rio shouted after the tearaway and found an echo from beside her as Nicky tried to help: “Be careful! Rio says be careful!”

But James just continued to run and Rio had to stop herself from rolling her eyes or simply leaving him to run under he tired out as she shouted after him again to make him change directions and follow them to the little basketball court at the very edge of the lot.

They were behind the big studio building now, and dotted nearby were some lights and other equipment that usually lived on the sets, placed here for safekeeping. The court was a half court, but more than big enough for Rio and the two boys to get some of their energy out.

She hoped.

Thankfully, no one was there and little James had actually followed and was now streaking towards the hoop. The whole time Nicky had been silent, the pep in his step gone now, his small hand clutching at Rio’s.

“Okay!” Rio announced, being used to herding small children around but ones that she actually had love for because they were family - or Nicky - and not one very small brown-haired boy who was cute but a handful.

She wished Agatha were here. Agatha would know what to do.

“No rules, just fun. We wanna score as much as possible to get to a thousand.”

She turned to Nicky and grinned as she offered him the ball, “You first. Let’s see those skills, kid.”

James was rushing his way back over as Nicky began to dribble the ball and Rio intercepted him and swung him under her arm so Nicky could bounce around and take a shot at the hoop.

James squealed in midair as Nicky took a shot.

Rio placed him down again as Nicky scored and she hollered her appreciation and ran over to shake Nicky’s shoulders, “Champion!!”

Nicky laughed as he turned to Rio, his grin back again, but shyer this time. “So silly.”

“No, so talented!”

There was a noise of exertion and Rio looked around to see that James had flung the ball away and was giggling as he watched it.

Rio did roll her eyes this time.

“James!” She left Nicky as his grin faded and went to the smaller boy’s side. “That’s not how we play, okay? You gotta throw it to me or Nicky. And I’ll try and help you shoot, okay?”

“Okay,” James agreed as Rio turned to where the ball was slowly rolling away. “Will you go fetch it for me please?”

“Okay, mama Rio!”

James ran after the ball and Rio sighed as she went back over to a patient Nicky, waiting quietly in the middle of the court. She smiled at him and he smiled back and Rio went to drape her arm over his shoulders as she said: “Maybe you can help James shoot? Teach him what you know?”

“Okay,” Nicky agreed quietly, holding tight to the back of Rio’s shirt. “Why is he calling you mama Rio? You’re not his mama.”

“He’s little,” Rio said quietly, watching as James began to toddle over with the ball in his hands. “It’s sometimes easier for younger actors to keep the pretend going.”

Nicky nodded but Rio caught his frown as James arrived before them and bounced the ball heavily by his feet. Rio caught it as it came down again and said: “Right, James, let’s get you a basket. Do you know how to dribble?”

The worst question to ask an overactive child, it turned out.

“No!” Rio bellowed suddenly and then laughed as James sucked his spit back up.

Nicky did not laugh.

“C’mere,” she pulled away from Nicky and led James to the hoop and offered him the ball once more as Nicky followed her over and hovered by her elbow. “Want to take a shot?”

James grinned as he took the ball and seemed to think about it for a while before he simply threw the ball in the opposite direction and began to giggle again. Rio huffed softly but knew a reaction was exactly what James was after so she bit her tongue.

“James.”

She left him to jog over and find the ball and when she returned, James was still delighted and Nicky was still frowning.

“You’re being naughty,” Nicky accused as James laughed some more and patted Nicky’s forehead which made Nicky stumble back and Rio bend down between them, moving a hand to hold Nicky’s shoulder.

“Okay. No more throwing away, alright? We want to play.”

“Okay!” James said happily and Rio eyed him for a second before she turned to give Nicky the ball, “Your turn, champ. Show us what you got.”

Nicky smiled shyly and bounced the ball and Rio held James back where he’d been trying to slap it away but Nicky had turned and was about to get it closer to the hoop. He took a shot and missed this time but Rio cheered all the same and only released James when Nicky had turned back around with his frown in place.

“He distracted me,” he accused as Rio sighed and kissed Nicky’s temple. “He’s annoying.”

“I know,” she said quietly, watching James purposefully kick the ball every few feet as he tried to pick it up. “But it’s important to play nice.”

Nicky nodded and Rio noticed his lips pursing slightly as James ran back with the ball now held out before him, “Mama Rio! Mama Rio! I got it! I got it!”

“Well done, kid.”

Rio took the ball and released a soft ‘oof’ as James flung himself at her afterwards. She patted his back and laughed, “Okay, are you gonna play properly now? Not throw this away?”

“Yes yes.”

“Good.”

Rio nudged James gently off of her and watched the following happen in slow motion:

James took the ball.

James grinned at her.

He shouted, “Mama Rio!”

He turned with the ball.

He ran straight to the hoop.

He threw the ball directly behind it.

Rio closed her eyes for just a second and when she opened them she saw that Nicky was already running after it.

“James!” Rio shouted again, watching the little boy descend into giggles as the ball rolled away. She sighed, wondering how she’d be able to deposit James quickly back with his mother.

Rio watched Nicky go for a second before she went over to kneel before James and plead with him: “Hey, this is Nicky’s game too. You can’t keep throwing the ball away, alright?”

“S’funny,” James gasped out between giggles and Rio rolled her eyes as she turned to see Nicky’s progress back to them.

He was running with the ball held in his two hands, his little brow furrowed, his lips tight, his brown eyes fighting back the tears that were clearly threatening to overspill.

“Hey,” Rio exclaimed, spinning properly to open her arms out to the boy. He dropped the ball the moment she did and threw himself against her with so much force that Rio almost lost her balance.

“What’s wrong, kid?”

James beside them had stopped giggling now but was nudging at Nicky’s arm and announcing, “He’s cryyyyyiiiiiing!”

Rio frowned as she held Nicky tighter to her with one arm and used to other to point in the direction of the ball now slowly rolling away. She snapped without meaning to, and only held tighter to Nicky: “James, go fetch the ball and bring it back.”

“He-…” Nicky began between soft sniffs and the tears that were soaking Rio’s collar. “He, he… k-keeps throwing it a-and… I want… I want…”

Unaffected by Rio’s chastisement, delighted giggles escaped James as he rushed after the ball and Rio saw him continually kick it in his attempts to catch it again. But she was rubbing Nicky’s back now, trying to calm him down as he hid against her.

“He’s stupid! I-… he… he…”

Rio pulled away even as Nicky tried to cling on and she gently wiped his tears first with her thumbs and then with her shirt as she pulled it up to dry them.

“It’s okay, Nicky. He’s being-…”

“He’s stupid!” Nicky shouted properly this time, wheeling around and stamping his foot with his fists at his sides when James cackled as he finally captured the ball and tossed it further away.

“S-stupid! I hate him!”

Rio stood and squeezed Nicky’s shoulder as she marched past him to grab James and scoop him up into her arms. “Absolutely not,” she said firmly as James squealed now he was in the air, squirming as Rio kept a firm grip on him.

“Now we’re either going to play nice or-…”

“I’m not playing with h-him!” Nicky had the hiccups now. “I hate you, James! I hate you!”

“Baby,” Rio cooed softly, feeling the panic begin to rise in her again now James was cackling where he sat against her hip, his sticky hands playing with her hair, and Nicky continued to cry in front of them.

“Rio is m-my melliza! Go!” He ran forwards and tried to push James out of Rio’s arms which made James giggle more and Rio have to angle him away. “Go! Away!”

“Mama Rio! Mama Rio!”

“No! No! No!”

“Nicky, sweetheart,” Rio gave in on Nicky’s third attempt to get James out of her arms and with some difficulty she lowered the smaller boy to the ground and disentangled his hands from her hair. “Be gentle. He’s only little.”

But this wasn’t the right thing to saw to another little boy unable to control his frustration anymore.

James was still giggling, watching Nicky in amusement as Nicky stomped his foot again and pressed his little fists into his streaming eyes, “H-he’s r-ruining i-it.”

Rio now had a hold on the back of James’ shirt so he couldn’t run again but with her free hand she pulled Nicky back in and hugged him close, letting him cry it out against her shoulder as he made fists in her shirt.

“Está bien, cariño,” Rio whispered into his ear, “Te tengo, mi mellizo.” It’s okay, sweetheart. I’ve got you, my twin.

Nicky nodded a little against her and Rio held him tighter, briefly looking up to see some of the crew who’d been nearby taking in the sight of an Oscar-winning actress fighting for her life with two very different little boys.

“James,” Rio said in as gentle a voice as she could muster as James began again to play with her hair, “Let’s take you back to your mom, okay?”

“Hmmmmm,” James hummed, “no stay with mama Rio.”

Nicky sniffed loudly and lifted his head to place his wet, snotty face in against Rio’s cheek. He reached around her to push at James’ grabbing hands and huffed out a hot breath against Rio’s skin. “No. You can’t. N-no. Go back to y-your mama.”

“Mama Rio!” James gigged again and Rio released her hold on him to help disentangle his fingers from her hair, aware that where one boy was being gentle and the other was not, they were still now both very much tugging at her hair.

“Come on, let’s go find your mom.”

“Chico estúpido,” Nicky muttered under his breath as he stopped trying to push Nicky away and instead clung to Rio as she stood. It almost made Rio smile. Almost.

But now she had both boys by her sides, one still trying to dry his tears with the hand that wasn’t gripping Rio’s and the other now skipping as he chanted “mama Rio” over and over again.

Rio glanced down at Nicky and saw his brow was still drawn, his lips pursed, and he looked more like his mother than she’d ever seen. It was clear he was fighting himself to not say anything to shut James up but silence could only last so long for him when James belted out one last “mama Rioooooooo!”

Nicky ripped his hand suddenly from Rio’s hold and made Rio stop and turn as the little boy she’d only ever seen calm and happy, sometimes serious and mature, had a full on meltdown in the middle of the lot.

“STOP IT STOP IT SHE IS NOT YOUR MAMA SHE IS MINE RIO IS M-MINE STOP IT!”

That shut James up.

Rio released the thunderstruck James and ducked down to lift Nicky into her arms. He was bigger than James so it required more effort but he didn’t fight or wriggle like James had and instead began to sob against her more violently than he had before.

She held his head against her neck and shushed him gently as she turned to James and with more ferocity than before said, “Come on. Now. We’re taking you back to your mom.”

James kowtowed and took Rio’s outstretched hand and Rio walked with them both until they arrived at James’ trailer. She let go of James and let him knock, aware now that there was an audience of cast and crew alike all watching the little show as Nicky hid himself against her and James climbed the three steps up to knock on his door.

As they waited for his mom Rio tugged Nicky’s hood up over his head to give him some more comfort and privacy. His mom answered shortly after and for that, Rio was grateful.

“Mom mom mom!” James chanted as he wrapped himself around his mom’s legs and Rio exchanged a pointed look with her.

“They had a disagreement,” she explained, “James wouldn’t let Nicky play.”

The mother looked a little abashed and swallowed as an Oscar-winner glowered up at her, “Right… I’ll… have a word.”

“Please do.”

She turned away and walked as quickly as she could with Nicky still cradled in her arms. She got to Agatha’s trailer, five down from James’ and didn’t even knock before walking in.

“What the fuck?!” Someone shouted from the bedroom and Rio rolled her eyes as she slammed the door shut behind them. Jen appeared not two seconds later, and Alice tow seconds after that. Rio didn’t even blink as she asked, “Where’s Agatha?”

“With… with Maria. She’s rehearsing. What happened?”

Rio shook her head silently as she moved over to gently encourage Nicky to sit on the sofa. But he didn’t seem to want to leave the safety of the nook he’d created for himself so she straightened up again for fear she’d topple over.

“Nicky? You okay, buddy?”

Nicky didn’t respond to Alice and Rio just paced, rubbing his back as he began to calm down and his breathing slowly evened out. When he moved his head so he could peak out from beneath his hood and blink around at Jen, Rio spoke again. “It’s just us. Just me, Alice, and Jen.”

Nicky nodded against her and Rio felt sick as she gently lowered him to the floor and this time he allowed it. When he was on his own two feet he fisted at his eyes and Rio sank to her knees before him. “James is just a little kid, Nicky. But I’m sorry he ruined your game.”

“This is about James?” Jen interrupted, her wide eyes still full of panic and Rio knew she was half a mind to either call an ambulance or call her client.

“I just wanted,” Nicky sniffed and Rio brushed his hair back from his forehead, pushing his hood off in the process. “He made me a-angry.”

Rio nodded and scanned over the face that was so like hers, doing her best to wipe away the tear tracks that lined his soft cheeks. “I know, sweetheart.”

“I h-hate him,” Nicky admitted again as fresh tears began to fall and Rio pulled him back in for a hug. “I h-hate that he h-has my mama and I h-hate that he has y-you and I h-hate that he c-calls you m-mama Rio a-and…”

Rio shushed Nicky softly and over his shoulder as she stroked over his hair she mouthed ‘Agatha’ at Jen. Jen nodded and grabbed Alice's hand to pull her with her to disappear and quickly and quietly from the trailer and Rio sighed out heavily as Nicky cried some more.

“You know it’s all pretend, right? Your mama is only your mama, not James’. And I’m not anybody’s mama. I’m just-…”

“My m-melliza,” Nicky said with a hiccup as Rio rubbed his back.

“Yes. Your melliza.”

It took a couple minutes but Nicky’s tears calmed again and just as Rio was pulling back to dry them properly the door burst open and Agatha appeared looking frantic and afraid.

She’d fallen to her knees beside them before Rio could even say anything and Nicky flung himself into her arms as Rio rested back against her ankles and smiled sadly at the sight.

“What’s wrong, honey? What happened?”

Nicky sniffled and spoke in a muffled voice as he pressed into Agatha and Agatha’s wide eyes swung round to watch Rio. “H-he k-kept being s-stupid and we couldn’t p-play properly a-and then he he kept calling Rio m-mama R-Rio. I h-hate him. I don’t want, I don’t want him to call y-you mama.. I don’t w-want… R-Rio is not his.”

Agatha’s eyes closed as Rio reached out to squeeze Nicky’s shoulder and she felt the sickness she’d felt earlier. Because Nicky was still so upset and because there was nothing she could do about it. Maybe she'd done everything wrong. Maybe she'd not protected him enough, maybe she'd not shown him enough care.

“Baby,” Agatha tried quietly, “baby, I’m no one’s mama but yours, okay? No one is taking me away from you.”

Rio dropped her hand and slowly, and as silently as she could, she stood to give the little family their space. She went and sat on the edge of the couch, scratching absently at her damp neck to rid herself of the uncomfortable itch that comes from irritated, warm skin.

She kept her gaze down on the floor, going over everything in her mind and wondering if there was something she could have done better. Should she have intervened earlier before Nicky got so upset? Should she have been firmer with James or simply refused to let him play?

Agatha was talking to Nicky softly where they still sat on the floor together and Nicky was whispering back but about what, Rio didn’t know.

“Rio,” Agatha called out, making Rio turn to them both and see that Nicky was leaning against his mom but looking over at her too. “Nicky wants to ask you something.”

Rio raised her brows and watched as Agatha gently encouraged Nicky to turn properly and Rio followed the movements of his little fist as rubbed at his right eye.

“Can you come back please?”

“Come back?”

“Here please.”

Rio glanced at Agatha and saw her attention was on her son still so she couldn’t gage how she felt about this, but then she saw her swallow thickly and she dropped her gaze to the floor.

“Please?”

Rio moved slowly across and fell to her knees again in front of Nicky, waiting to see if what he wanted was something what would hurt her so intensely that she didn’t think she’d recover.

It turned out it was.

Nicky was already turning around to hug his mom again and he glanced over his shoulder at Rio, and Rio just knew he wanted her to join. So as Agatha raised her arms to welcome her into the embrace she sucked in a sharp breath and pressed in close.

Rio’s heart hammered in her chest as she looped her own arms around Nicky’s little body and Agatha’s larger one. The two women sandwiched the little boy between them and Rio instinctively pressed her face into Agatha’s cheek, closing her eyes as she felt Nicky wriggle to get comfortable and then settle as the pressure of the hug relaxed him down.

They remained still like that for a while and Rio wondered why they’d never done this before. Why she hadn’t insisted that her day start and end with a hug like this.

She’d have driven miles and miles to get to this. She'd have swam through shark-infested waters, or fought a million demons, just to get to this.

She’d have endured hours of James screaming just to collapse into Agatha’s embrace with her son sandwiched comfortably between them.

But Nicky needed to breathe almost as much as he needed the comfort and he began to wriggle again until Rio pulled away and Agatha’s hold on her relaxed and then fell as she sat back on her ankles.

Nicky followed Rio’s movements and sat back against her lap as she settled against her own ankles and he turned to look up at her with that familiar serious expression as she held him gently around his middle.

“If you are pretend married then I think you should be my pretend mama too. Not James’.”

Rio raised her brows and looked up at Agatha for a second who suddenly looked pale again. But Rio cleared her throat, put on her best smile and said, “Oh yeah? What happened to being your melliza?”

“You can’t have my mama without me too.”

You didn’t ask about Nicky’s middle name.

What?

His middle name.

His…? What is it?

River.

The pain was unlike anything she’d felt since those unbearable minutes when Agatha was shouting and Rio’s heart was freshly breaking.

Nicky was looking up at her with those molten chocolate eyes and she could only smile, only squeeze him a little tighter, only lean into the touch of his hand as he reached back and up to hold her cheek.

“I suppose that’s true.”

“Say it please.”

“Nicky,” Agatha said softly, shuffling closer to reach for Nicky’s knees, “Why don’t you go get cleaned up and we’ll get some lunch, okay?”

Nicky nodded and Rio let him go so he could run away to go and wash his hands and face and suddenly they were alone for the first time since the Rio had swapped Agatha’s ring. Agatha placed her hands on Rio’s knees now and said in a quiet voice, “What happened?”

“James kept screaming and giggling and he wouldn’t play properly and Nicky was being so good and so helpful and then he just… he started to cry and I held him but James wouldn’t stop and Nicky got so angry and…”

“It’s okay,” Agatha reassured quietly, shuffling closer until her hands were no longer on Rio’s knees but on her thighs, and sliding ever up until her fingers were curling around her hips, “he’s okay. You’re okay.”

Rio swallowed quickly and hid her face in her hands before Agatha reached out to remove them and held Rio’s face instead. “Thank you for… he feels safe with you. I know you make him feel safe.”

Rio only nodded, only sniffed softly and turned her head into Agatha’s palm, placing a kiss there when she shouldn’t have.

A noise told them that Nicky had arrived back but neither pulled away in time and a confused Nicky padded over, looking between his mom and Rio with a deep frown on his face, “What’s wrong?”

“Nothing, mellizo.”

“Mama?”

“Nothing, honey. Rio was just upset that you were upset.”

Rio smiled a little and Nicky continued to frown, “Maybe… maybe we can play more after lunch? Just two mellizos.”

“She has to work, sweetheart.”

“With James?”

Rio shot a glance at Agatha and Agatha smiled softly and reached to take Rio’s hand, taking Nicky’s in her other. “Yes, honey. But why don’t I take you home and we can-…”

“No, mama. I want to stay. Can we please stay?”

Agatha swallowed and nodded and Rio bit down on her lip as she said, “Well, why don’t you hang out with your mom and when I’m done I’ll come say goodbye before we all go home?”

“No,” Nicky stamped his foot a little, his brow furrowing even more, “No I want to stay with you. I won’t see you again for- for-…” his brown eyes filled with tears once more and Agatha dropped Rio’s hand to pull her son to her again.

“Honey. You’ll see Rio again.”

“No she always says she’ll come over a-and she d-doesn’t.”

“Nicky.”

“J-James sees y-you m-more.”

The floodgates opened again and Rio didn’t know how to respond. But Agatha did. Agatha settled down more on the floor and as she held Nick with one arm she reached for Rio with her other. Rio hesitated even as she was tugged closer and for a little while didn’t know where to sit but she settled by Agatha’s hip and sat with her legs at ninety degrees so Agatha was against her back one and Rio could reach for her opposite hip.

Nicky sniffed and turned to look at her, his frown gone this time, his expression helpless. Rio shuffled closer until she just bent her knees up and wrapped her arms around the two of them. It was a little awkward but it was worth it.

“I promise I’ll come see you more. I want to. If you’ll let me?”

She found that in her attempts to rub Nicky’s back she was simultaneously rubbing Agatha’s now but she couldn’t stop herself, wouldn’t have stopped for the world.

“Okay, mellizo.”

Nicky was quiet, quieter than he had been all day and Rio frowned because of it, felt sick because of it. She moved her hand up to brush the hair from his head again and said with an equally soft voice, “Why don’t you come watch me work this afternoon? Your mama can sit with you and you can see how… how with James it’s just pretend.”

“It’s not pretend with me?”

“No, mi ángel, it’s not pretend with you.”

Nicky nodded and flung his arms around Rio’s neck and she laughed in surprise and heaved them both over backwards and held Nicky firmly to her as he giggled.

“You’re silly,” he accused and Rio knew he was going to be okay when he did. She hummed happily and placed a kiss to the top of his head just as Agatha moved to sit beside them and looked down. Somewhere her hand brushed Nicky’s back and found Rio’s on the way and they linked fingers over the little boy.

Something was swirling in Agatha’s eyes that made Rio tug at her gently, made her motion with her head, and Agatha took the hint, she climbed over them both and lay carefully down so Rio could lift her arm and Agatha could rest her head against her shoulder.

They knew how to hold each other.

Even from the beginning.

Rio’s body just knew where to be for Agatha’s.

There was stillness for a second, and then, Nicky scrambled to get a look at his mom and Rio was reminded of the time they’d been in this exact position on Agatha’s couch. Only this time Agatha’s hand rested demurely over Rio’s top, she wasn’t tracing soft patterns over her bare abdomen, she wasn’t nuzzling into her neck.

Rio closed her eyes and felt the weight of the two over her for a while, Nicky’s hand had found her hair and he was righting the wrongs of James’ fingers through it from earlier, and Agatha had reached up to turn her face gently, to force her to look at her, and when she did she mouthed: “Thank you.”

Rio smiled a little and Agatha shifted up as her fingers continued to dance song Rio’s jaw. And as she watched Agatha’s eyes dilate and move about her face, she forgot the horror of the last few days.

All that mattered was Agatha was here in her arms again.

And Nicky was too.

Agatha moved again. She skirted up to lean over Rio properly, using her hand on the floor as a ballast as her other continued its soft exploration of her jaw. Rio turned her head to watch the movement and stared up at her silently, desperately.

“I think if you were married to mama not in pretend she might be happier.”

Rio closed her eyes at Nicky’s soft words, felt Agatha’s touch stop, then move down her throat until her hand simply rested against her clavicle.

She wondered if she could feel the insistence of her heartbeat.

“Honey,” Agatha said quietly, “why do you say that?”

“You never smile with daddy. And daddy never cuddles us. Mommies and daddies should cuddle.”

Rio swallowed and forced herself to open her eyes and looked up at Agatha who was now clutching her collar. She looked pale again, her whole face suddenly tight.

“Nicky, honey… it’s more complicated than that.”

Agatha gaze darted across and met Rio’s and Rio sucked in a breath at the intensity of it, at the desperation in her blue eyes. She swallowed and cautiously said to Nicky as she stared up at his mother, “Nicky I’ll always be around to play ball or for cuddles or…”

But she stopped herself because Agatha had looked away.

And she didn’t want her to.

She reached up even as everything was screaming at her not to and her hand found purchase on the back of Agatha’s head. She made her turn, and pulled her until Agatha’s elbow gave in and she was laying back against her.

Agatha’s cheek was against her shoulder, her fingers now curling around the collar of her shirt for just a second until she brought it down.

This time her hand did find the warm skin of her stomach and Rio’s closed her eyes as she felt the two settle into her again, settle closer. Two of Agatha’s fingers had slipped below her shirt, resting their warmth over hungry skin.

It was the most intimate thing that had ever happened to Rio. It was secret, had to be, because Nicky was so close. And Agatha’s touches, always private, always a secret, even when they were alone, always carried shadow with them.

But this touch, this touch was secret, but instead of feeling like shadow, it felt like safety.

Agatha exhaled a heavy breath and Rio shivered for its brush over her skin.

But the reaction, the reaction hadn’t been what she’d expected, or what she wanted. Agatha had stiffened and paled rather than said something even remotely like: “yes I want that too!”

Though maybe she couldn’t. Ralph was still Nicky’s dad. He was still his dad. He was still his dad. He was still his dad. He was still his dad. He was still her husband.

“Rio?”

Rio blinked, her body twitched in shock, and she stared up at Agatha who was now above her again, having moved whilst Rio was spiralling.

“Lunch? What do you want?”

Agatha’s fingers were swirling, moving back and forth and round and round and god Rio couldn’t think.

“Want?”

“To eat, honey?”

Rio frowned and Nicky patted her head, “Are you sleepy?”

“I…” Agatha pulled her hand away and Rio’s brain stumbled over itself. “A little, kid.”

She caught Agatha’s eye and in looking, they exchanged more than words could ever say.

Agatha pulled back fully after only a few seconds. Rio watched as she turned to Nicky and asked him to run across to Rio’s trailer and knock for Jen. She remained still as the little boy did as he was told. She sucked in a breath as the trailer door closed and Agatha, with patient hands, encouraged her to sit up.

“I’m sorry you had to… he’s not been himself. I've not been able to hide... I....”

Rio looked down at the hand now in her own, at the space where yesterday Agatha’s new ring had been.

“Don’t apologise.”

“No, I need to. This morning must have been… Rio he loves you so much. You’re his hero and he wants…”

Rio swallowed, filling in the gap where Agatha had stopped herself: a family.

“Ralph doesn’t play? Doesn’t cuddle him or-…?”

Agatha shook her head, a reluctant acknowledgement.

“I’m sorry I walked away.”

“You turned back, that’s what matters.”

Rio exhaled slowly and closed her eyes, Agatha’s hold on her hand dropped as she did and instead she felt her hand on her cheek, her lips against her other one and Agatha whispered, “Tomorrow, I want to tell you everything. Not just… not just what happened that night, okay?”

Rio looked back to her, pulled away an inch or two to be able to see the fear in such soft blue eyes and she nodded as the door opened again and Nicky, followed by Jen and Alice arrived inside.

“What’s up? I’m being ordered around by a kid now?”

“Not ordered,” Nicky muttered quietly as he made his way back over to Agatha who was now standing and pulling Rio up with her.

Rio cleared her throat when she was back on two feet and absently brushed down her thighs just for something to do.

“Lunch?” Alice asked hopefully, “We have maybe thirty minutes before call time.”

“Actually,” Rio said as she cleared her throat and now ran her fingers through her wild hair - Brett would die if he saw how messy it currently was due, mostly, to James’ sticky fingers and Nicky’s gentle twisting. “I need to do something.”

“What? No, Rio,” Nicky said from where he stood in front of Agatha, “I want to have lunch with you.”

“I know, kid, but… I promise, you’ll see me in a few minutes and it’ll be worth it, okay?”

Nicky frowned a little but nodded and Rio kissed his temple quickly before ushering Alice out the trailer and shooting Agatha what she hoped would be a reassuring smile.

Outside she gasped in a breath and Alice looked to her in alarm.

“When did the kid arrive? And why does he look more and more like you every time I see him?”

Rio shook her head, now tugging Alice away from the trailer and in the direction of the costume department.

“Shh. I just need… need some distance… fuck me.”

“What happened? Rio, what’s…?”

“I had to take James too and Nicky… he lost it. I’ve never seen him lose it before. He’s been crying like… all morning and…”

She cleared her throat and only dropped her tight hold on Alice’s sleeve when a member of the crew walked past them and she realised she must look insane dragging her manager along like that.

“He got so mad at James. He was calling me fucking mama all morning and Nicky just…”

“Holy shit. I mean… no prizes for guessing why he lost it.”

“Shut up.”

“Agatha’s not the only jealous one in that family.”

“Shut up.”

Alice sighed and grabbed Rio to make her stop. “Look, the kid loves you. He’s young. He doesn’t understand. He wants you around because you’re fun and give him attention and, let’s face it, Ralph’s a shit.”

“A cunt,” Rio corrected.

“Right. A cunt. Anyone can see you’d be a better parent than Ralph. Agatha knows it and Nicky clearly does too. But… babe, don’t let that blur your vision. You can’t be fooled into forgiving her because her son loves you.”

Rio sighed and ran the fingers of both hands through her hair, taking just a second to let that notion sink in.

“We’re talking tomorrow. That’s a… that’s a tomorrow issue. Right now I just want to make sure he knows he’s… he knows I’m here for him.”

“Right,” Alice said slowly, eyeing her friend up suspiciously and clearing her throat, “and how are you going to do that?”

Rio turned and motioned to Trailer B that belonged to the Costume Department and Alice raised her brows, “Getting him a ring too?”

“Shut up. There was a sweater that matches mine in there. It’s green. James wouldn’t wear it. Nicky would like it.”

She marched off before Alice could say anything else and within two minutes Stevie had enthusiastically greeted them both and was rummaging in the back for the sweater, having promised it would be large enough to fit Nicky and Rio could have it.

Rio looked around the space, trying to think of anything else she could do to make the afternoon a safe space for Nicky, knowing he’d have to face up to James being there again. She poked around in drawers and fished in the little pots of off-cuts and various costume paraphernalia around the sides and then she made a choice that didn’t even feel like a choice, it was so naturally made.

She found a piece of white card and grabbed a sharpie from the side and wrote in large letters ‘NICKY’ and underneath in slightly smaller ones ‘mellizo’.

“What’s that for?”

“A name for the back of his chair. He can have mine.”

“You’ve never given me a name for the back of your chair.”

Rio ignored Alice as she grabbed a pair of scissors the card to size. “You are not a cute little boy. You are a pain in the ass.”

“That’s it! I’m moving out!”

Rio laughed as she held up the final product and waved it in Alice’s face. “Yeah right. Then you’d actually have to sort out your shit and confess to Jen that you’re the messiest person alive.”

“She’d love me anyway,” Alice huffed as she tried to snatch the card still waving near her face.

Rio snatched it back.

“We’ll see.”

Rio grabbed a glitter stick from the side as Alice hovered over her shoulder. “You should let me write it. Or get one of the-…”

“Stevie?”

Rio looked up and Stevie turned around, “Could you write Nicky’s name on the back of here, please? Gonna just assume you have better writing than me.”

Stevie laughed as Rio showed her what she’d already done and then did as she was asked, “Voila!”

Rio grinned and admired her handiwork. “God I’m glad you fixed it.”

Rio hurried then, grabbing the sweater and placing a quick kiss to Stevie’s grateful cheek, and rushing over to the sound stage to finish her little project. She attached Nicky’s name to the back of her own seat and gently folded the sweater in the centre of it. It wasn't much, but it was something.

“Rio!”

Rio looked over and saw Alice very obviously thrusting her head in the direction of Agatha and Nicky now walking onto set through the large studio doors.

Nicky was pressed as close as he could be to his mama’s side and looked serious about the whole thing until he spotted Rio and he released Agatha’s hand to run to her. He smashed into her and Rio laughed as he did, taking the smack to her stomach with the pride of a woman who had a little boy who loved her.

She ducked down to hug him back and whispered in his ear, “Only special people get to be on set when we’re rehearsing, you know.”

As Nicky pulled back to grin up at her Rio grinned right back, and was blinded for a second by his likeness. But a hand on her arm made her look up and Agatha was there, and Rio was truly blinded.

Agatha was framed by one of the large studio lights and looked ethereal in the glow. As Rio raised herself to stand again she felt that same dizzy way as before, but this time it wasn’t panic.

“Where did you go?”

Rio smiled a little as Nicky moved back closer to Agatha as people around them began to move and the set became busier suddenly, Rio motioned to her seat, which she’d dragged over to be next to Agatha’s.

“Well, I wanted Nicky to have his own seat and there was a green sweater the right size in the costume department that matches one of my sweaters so I thought that maybe Nicky would like to have that.”

As Alice moved over and held up the sweater for Nicky to admire, Rio turned to see Agatha’s reaction and bit her lip when she saw her eyes cloud over and her gaze become hooded and heavy.

“I don’t deserve it.”

Rio sucked in a breath, and answered the only way she could: “Nicky does.”

Agatha nodded and they both turned to Nicky. Rio’s chest ached but as Nicky turned around to her, now perched in the high-top director’s chair clutching his new sweater, the ache in her chest dulled.

Pain could wait.

She knew she’d feel more than enough of it tomorrow.

“Like it?”

“Mmhm.”

Rio grinned and had just enough time to give Nicky a quick hug and receive a soft “thank you” from the boy before a PA ran over and she was ushered over to set. Waiting for her was James, Maria, and a couple of the crew ready to jump in where needed as they rehearsed the scene.

Initially, Rio kept her attention on James, occasionally having to dip out of character to ask him to not call her "mama Rio" and instead just "mama", and to focus on the few lines he had.

She’d worked with child actors before and most were either scarily well-behaved, or just kids who reacted naturally to what was said to them or what was in the scene. All were usually challenging in their own ways, but none as challenging as James.

He was still full of energy, still keen to refer to her as “mama Rio!” instead of just “mama”. He still wanted to bounce about instead of simply walking from mark to mark but eventually, with a lot of cajoling and breaks in between rehearsing, he calmed down.

And the little terror that was James turned out to be a pretty good actor.

He had large brown eyes and an expressive face and when Rio talked to him he looked at her like she’d put the stars in the sky.

But it took a while to get to that. It took a lot of Maria and Rio both trying their hardest until they could get anything remotely useful out of him by way of rehearsing or acting.

And Rio just kept thinking about the little boy watching them next to his mother and how much easier all this might be is she were working with Nicky now instead of the little boy with the mile-a-minute attitude.

She never looked around to see how Nicky was feeling about it all, never wanted to check in on Agatha’s feelings either. It would be too hard to concentrate if she knew either were struggling for whatever reason.

But when, after over two hours, it was declared that they were done and James jumped into her arms to celebrate, Rio made the mistake of turning to look over.

At some point Nicky must have moved into his mom’s lap because now Alice was in her seat. Agatha was whispering something in Nicky’s ear and Nicky was frowning down at the floor, toying with the green sweater he’d just received in his hands.

Rio turned back, placed James down, watched him run off to his actual mama and then focused in on Maria who had some thoughts on the scene.

Twenty minutes later she returned to the little group at the edges of the set waiting for her and plastered a grin on her face as she did.

“Are we ready to go?”

“We sure are,” Alice said with raised brows at Rio, trying to communicate something that Rio couldn’t quite grasp.

Nicky slid from Agatha’s lap and cleared his throat quietly and Rio watched as he waited for Agatha and wouldn’t look up at her.

“It’s just pretend, mellizo.”

“I know.”

Rio cleared her throat, unused to being shut out by the boy with the big brown eyes.

Agatha met her gaze and smiled a little but Rio couldn’t bring herself to smile back anymore so she said to Nicky, “Tell you what, will we go back to the court and have a quick game before we leave?”

Nicky did look up then and Rio saw that he looked hopeful suddenly and she felt her shoulders relax. “Can we?”

“Of course! If it’s okay with your mom.”

“Who am I to stop the two best basketball players play basketball?”

Rio smiled and Nicky’s hopeful expression turned into a grin, which softened only when he spotted Maria marching towards them and he shrunk back a little towards Agatha.

“Agatha? Can we borrow you? I need to get some more set ups sorted for your seen with Quill.”

Agatha rolled her eyes but huffed her ascent and ducked down quickly to kiss Nicky, “Stay with Rio, okay?”

“Yes, mama. Stay with Rio.”

Agatha squeezed Rio’s arm as she walked past and Rio inhaled her perfume as she did. A little hand found hers almost the second Agatha had stepped away and Rio smiled as she turned to Alice and Jen who were looking at her expectantly, “Can you take Nicky’s sweater? We’ll be an hour or so then we’ll come back.”

“Make it two?”

Rio had to try not to laugh at the expression on Alice’s face as she nudged Jen’s side but she nodded and hid her smile as best she could. “Two it is.”

They left the set as a foursome then peeled off so Rio and Nicky could go back to the court and find the ball they’d left there and Jen and Alice could make the most of some time alone in Rio’s trailer.

Nicky relaxed the further and further they got away from the set and by the time they were on the court he was running around like he might if they were on his home court, safe and secure in the knowledge that he had Rio’s undivided attention.

“He shoots!” Rio shouted, “He scores!”

She mimicked the noise of the crowd as best she could and ran around in circles as Nicky cheered and charged for the ball.

The two mellizos both relaxed fully in the rush of playing their favourite game with their favourite person. They bounced well off of one another and celebrated even the misses until they were both sweaty, flushed, and beaming.

Rio had the ball now, hamming it up a little. She dived and dodged around Nicky and then, it happened.

It happened so fast.

Rio bounced the ball, forgetting for a second where she was and who she was playing with and it flew through the air until it hit the wall not far behind the standalone hoop and came flying right back.

Nicky jumped for it and time slowed down.

He’d thrown himself upwards, managed to wrap his arms around the ball, and as he came down he came down at an angle, falling back to earth again with his feet thrown out before him.

Rio dived.

She caught him.

The pain was instantaneous, but she had Nicky in her arms.

She yelled out at some point, but either his name or through pain, she wasn’t sure. But something else had happened too.

As Nicky had slipped on his way to the ball, so had the ball from his hands. The momentum of it had carried it straight from his grasp and hurtling towards one of the big, expensive, studio lights.

The crash was sickening, the damage, irrevocable.
