But Rio had Nicky. She’d caught him before he’d smacked his head on the hard concrete and so a little bit of smashed glass and a grazed knee was nothing to her.

“¿Estás bien, mellizo?”

Rio was panting, from fear as well as exertion, and helped Nicky to right himself before she flopped back onto her ass on the ground to inspect her knee. It looked angry, and worse than it now felt, but she’d ruined her leggings and huffed quietly to herself.

“I’ll fetch mama,” Nicky said seriously as he looked between the glass on the ground and Rio’s injured knee, his cheeks flushed a deep crimson.

“No, baby. I’m fine. Are you okay?”

As she pushed herself up to stand she heard voices behind them and saw Nicky’s eyes go wide and his red face pale slightly. She turned and he pressed himself into her side, his arms immediately locking around her as two members of the crew rocked up to see what had happened.

“Ahhhh, Jesus Christ!”

Rio cleared her throat and delicately peeled Nicky’s hands away from her so she could move forward towards the first of the men. Nicky hovered close by still.

“My bad. We were playing and-…”

“Shit, a movie star comes in with her kid and fucks shit up for the rest of us. Do you know how much these things cost?”

Rio bristled, and maybe it was that the guy had just insulted her, or maybe it was that Nicky was close but she felt incredibly defensive suddenly, but either way she snapped back: “Well shit let me get my calculator out.”

“Listen, lady, I don’t care how famous you are, you can’t go round-…!”

“Hey!”

The man blinked and so did Rio and they both looked down at Nicky, still clinging onto her side but scowling, “It was an accident! Do not shout at her!”

“Jesus H fucking Christ. You think this is shouting kid? You think this is-…?!”

“Hey!” It was Rio’s turn again and this time she stepped in front of Nicky, holding him behind her back, “Watch your fucking mouth when you speak to my kid, okay? Now point me in the direction of your supervisor and I’ll sort this out, you arrogant, condescending piece of-…” Nicky grabbing the back of her shirt made her stop just before she spat the word “pig” at him but he’d got the picture.

He squared his shoulders and raised his chin and stared her down for a few seconds but when Rio didn’t give he nodded his head in the direction of the studio building. “He has an office in there. Third door on the right. Harvey Kent.”

Rio nodded stiffly, eyed him for a second longer before she turned around and ushered Nicky off before her, muttering under her breath about sexist pigs and their fucking stupid faces.

“He was mean,” Nicky said with a deep frown and his hand now clutching Rio’s. “He was mean to you and me and I’m telling mama and she will be so mad.”

Rio smiled tightly and just as she’d pushed the door open to the studio building she spotted a PA nearby and shouted him over. “Could you grab Agatha? Bring her to Harvey Kent’s office? Urgently?”

The young man nodded and Rio smiled as best she could before she turned to walk with Nicky to the third door on the right. She knocked and wriggled Nicky’s hand to try and get a smile out of him but he was too serious for that, too ready for his mama to come and stand up for the both of them.

“Come in.”

Rio cleared her throat as she opened the door and stepped into a small office, clearly a makeshift one for the purposes of being close to the set. Harvey Kent, in a blue suit and thick glasses, sat behind a busy desk and looked incredibly pissed off already.

“Harvey? I’m Rio Vi-…”

“Vidal, yes. You the kid who’s playing her son?”

Nicky just frowned and shook his head so Rio answered for him, “This is Nicky Harkness.”

“Agatha’s?”

“Yes.”

Harvey nodded thoughtfully and stared at Nicky for longer than Rio liked. “Anyway, we’re here because there’s been an accident. One of the lights got smashed and-…”

“Which?”

“Pardon?”

“Which light?”

“Umm, the big one. One of the big ones, just outside the,” she gestured vaguely behind her in the direction they’d just come from.

“Smashed?”

“On accident.”

“Let me guess, by Harkness’s kid?”

“No,” Rio said a little more firmly now, “by me.”

“Melliza,” Nicky whispered, tugging at Rio’s hand, but she ignored him.

“I’ve come here as a courtesy more than anything. And one of your workers was incredibly-…”

“Will you sit?”

Rio raised her brows and looked around at a small couch by the wall.

“Why would I sit?”

“So I can make a phone call and you can be here for when I’m done.”

“I don’t take orders.”

“That’s why I asked.”

Rio frowned deeply, weighing up her options here. She didn’t know how big of a deal smashing one of those lights really was and she’d already slipped through the net when she’d smacked Quill so maybe…

“Sit, please.”

Rio cleared her throat and motioned for Nicky to go ahead and take a seat. She sat down next to him and squeezed his hand gently, trying to give as much reassurance as she could. Harvey picked up the phone and eyed Nicky for a while which made Rio lean over him slightly, blocking him from view.

“You okay?”

Nicky remained silent but frowned and nodded slowly, both his hands now toying with Rio’s fingers. “Your mom will be on her way, okay? We’ll sort it all out.”

It felt like being called to the principal’s office - something that had happened with relative frequency in Rio’s youth. As the producer spoke purposefully and aggressively into his phone Rio squeezed Nicky’s hand and kept close, assuming (rightfully) that the principal’s office feeling was a new one for him.

“It’s okay, you’re not in any trouble.”

Nicky only nodded, only looked at her with those big brown eyes and squeezed her hand right back.

“So,” the producer interrupted and turned back to the twins in the couch. “We’re not exactly insured for activities other than specifically filming related-…”

The door opened suddenly and Rio didn’t have to look to know the only person who wouldn’t bother knocking on an executive producer’s office door.

Agatha had let herself in, wearing a Christmas sweater and sporting her new ring on her finger. She made eye contact with Rio, looked down to her grazed knee, and then looked at the little boy squashed into her side.

“What the fuck is happening?”

“Oh, Agatha.” Rio always found it fascinating how people reacted to Agatha versus how they reacted to her. Harvey hadn’t stood when she walked in the room, but he certainly was standing for Agatha right now. He hadn’t even looked slightly nervous when Rio had arrived, but he looked nervous now.

“Why do you have my son and my wife sat here like they’ve done something wrong?”

The word ‘wife’ hit harder than a basketball to a glass screen. Nicky had moved a little closer and Rio glanced at him to see if he were reacting to the designation but he seemed simply focused on remaining close, his wide eyes now on his mom.

“They smashed a light. We simply wanted-…”

“And who is ‘we’? You’re insured up to your eyeballs. And even if you’re not, that’s your own fault.”

Agatha turned her attention back to the two on the couch and Rio saw the stress working its way to her jaw. “What happened?”

“Mama I didn’t mean to.”

“I threw the ball too hard and Nicky tried to catch it but he slipped and it went in the wrong direction.”

Agatha nodded once, “An accident.”

“Yes.”

“Yes, mama.”

Agatha’s gaze dropped briefly to Rio’s knee again before she turned back to Harvey. “Never haul my son into your office again. Under no circumstances, you hear me?”

Rio adjusted then, unconsciously transferring Nicky’s hand to her other so she could wrap the arm closest to him around him. Agatha was leaning over the desk now, knuckles white as they held her weight and the force of her anger.

And Rio chewed on her lip, trying to focus on the worried little boy beside her rather than the overwhelm that came from knowing Agatha had designated her her wife in her brain and was wearing her ring.

“The insurance,” Harvey began, “it won’t cover activities outside of the filming day.”

“So dock it from my pay.”

“Agatha,” Rio said quickly, shifting forwards so that Nicky panicked and reached for her, meaning shifting, but not moving away, was all she could do. “My pay.”

“No,” Agatha said sternly, but not looking at Rio. “Take it from mine. And be thankful I’m not escalating this to Stark.”

Rio bit too hard on her cheek and twitched as the sharpness trickled through the pain receptors in her mouth. But Agatha was moving now, keeping her eyes on Harvey until the last second when she was straight again, turning to the two of them and holding her hand out.

Nicky didn’t hesitate to hurry to her but he kept his hold on Rio and tugged her to her feet too.

As Nicky took his mom’s hand and Rio now stood the other side of him they made eye contact. Agatha’s fury had died somewhere between turning from Harvey and Nicky’s hand reaching her own.

But her expression was unreadable.

Behind them as they left the little office Harvey was already back on the phone and to Rio’s delight he sounded a lot less sure than he had done before Agatha had arrived.

“You hurt your knee,” Agatha observed as they made their way back onto the lot.

“Rio caught me,” Nicky offered by way of explanation. “I fell on accident but she caught me before I hit the ground.”

Rio shot Nicky a smile as he grinned up at her and felt Agatha watching her too but she didn’t look around to check. “Can’t let the best basketball player I know get injured, can we?”

“Silly,” Nicky confirmed as his step became a little peppier and he visibly relaxed as they walked as a trio to Agatha’s trailer.

Rio released Nicky’s hand when they got to the door and was just about to make her excuses when Agatha said: “Did you clean it?”

“Clean-…?”

“No, mama. We had to go sit with that mean man first.”

Rio smiled and ruffled Nicky’s hair as Agatha motioned with her head to the door, “I’ll help you clean it.”

Rio wasn’t an idiot. She knew following Agatha and Nicky into Agatha’s trailer was a bad idea, no, a terrible idea, but she followed anyway, as idiots tend to.

Nicky pulled her to sit down on the couch that was visibly more expensive than her own.

Agatha had disappeared into the little bathroom and Rio squeezed Nicky’s hand. “You doing okay?”

“I’m okay. Are you?”

Agatha emerged carrying a small first aid kit and Rio watched her as she took a seat in the coffee table before her. “Todo bien, mellizo.”

She watched as Agatha began to silently rifle through the little pack and tilted her head as Nicky shuffled to his knees beside her and whispered too loudly against her ear, “If it hurts you can hold my hand.”

Agatha in front of her smiled to herself and Rio grinned as she turned to Nicky and was almost nose to nose with him, “I would like that.”

Nicky grinned right back and settled back down again and Rio this time tucked him under her arm as Agatha shuffled forwards and took hold of Rio’s calf to bend it forwards.

It felt strangely intimate, even with Nicky beside her. But Agatha didn’t look up and remained focused on the task at hand, which helped Rio somewhat with her racing heart.

Agatha snipped the already torn fabric of her leggings and Rio bit her lip as with a gentle touch she peeled the fabric back properly to expose her knee fully.

“Is it sore?”

Agatha glanced up as she spoke, her hands now back on Rio, her thumbs framing the graze.

“It’s just grazed, Agatha. It’s fine.”

“Nicky,” Agatha said gently, turning her attention away from Rio to look at her son. “Rio is trying to be corajuda,” she smiled a little when from the corner of her eye she saw Rio frown, “but this will hurt her okay so hold her hand real tight for me, honey.”

Nicky, who up until this point had been quite content in Rio’s hold, watching his mama, now looked serious, and tightened his hold on Rio’s hand to make sure she knew he was there.

“It won’t be that bad,” Rio accused with that same frown, knowing full well that the pain she’d been in these past few days meant that she could handle anything.

Just apparently not antiseptic wipes.

“Motherfu-…!”

“Rio!”

Rio grit her teeth and looked at Nicky who had scrambled up to look at her, his hand stolen from her own to place on her cheek in the aftermath. “It’s okay. Mama will kiss it better. Won’t you, mama?”

Nicky turned with his hand still on Rio’s cheek and Rio looked too to see Agatha watching them, her hands still cradling the sides of Rio’s knee. Rio could feel Agatha’s fingers twitch a little and she bit down on her lip as she witnessed something she wasn’t expecting.

Agatha raised her brows at her.

She was asking permission.

And the bouncing boy beside her meant she couldn’t say no. So she nodded, just once, and Agatha hesitated for a second before she pressed a firm kiss just above where the graze was.

Rio had thought that maybe she’d fake it or she’d ghost her lips over her skin but Agatha had done the opposite. She pressed her whole face against Rio’s thigh, making sure she felt her, and whatever magical properties her kiss might have would work double time with the fierceness of her kiss.

“Better?” Nicky asked proudly, clearly not doubting for a second the healing nature of his mother’s lips.

Rio shot him a slightly bewildered smile, “Better.”

“Good.”

Agatha’s hands were still warm as they framed her knee and she looked back down to her and noticed the flush on her cheeks. “I won’t put a bandaid on because it’ll need to breathe but before bed tonight you should-…”

“I know how to take care of a-…”

“Stay with us tonight! We can help!”

Rio looked back to Nicky and smiled softly as he settled carefully back into her side, his large eyes focused on his mom.

“Baby, Rio has her own home.”

“She can have ours too.”

Rio chewed on her lip and watched Agatha as she cleared her throat and began to pack the little first aid kit away.

“Has James been?”

“Been where, mellizo?”

“Your house?”

Rio shifted back a little to get a better view of Nicky and saw him frowning down at her knee. “No, sweetheart. James has never been to my house.”

“I’ve only been once. And you weren’t there. But mama said you would be and-…”

Rio hummed thoughtfully, knowing Nicky was thinking about Christmas. “I was working, Nicky. I would have been there if I could.”

“It was a surprise, remember?” Agatha added as she zipped back up the pack. “Rio didn’t know we were coming. It was bad luck, honey.”

Rio watched as Nicky processed this for a while and then she said, “Tell you what, why don’t you come over soon? We can make those tostones my mom taught you how to make? I’m not as good as her but I can make-…”

“Will James be there?”

Rio actually laughed, because it was just so absurd to her that Nicky would even worry about… and then it clicked why she was actually laughing. He was Agatha’s son. He was jealous just like his mom. Alice had been right. He was jealous of anyone else laying a claim to her and… and that was hilarious.

But Nicky’s little face suddenly became tight and he scowled up at her, wrestling to get away from her and off the couch.

“No, Nicky! No! I was just-…”

She’d laughed because this mellizo, this twin of hers, was suddenly Agatha’s twin. He was jealous and angry about something he had no need to be worried over.

The irony, of course, being the only one in the room who had yet to lose it over jealously, at least properly, when she had every right to given what Agatha had done to her with Ralph, was Rio.

“Baby,” Agatha said softly as Nicky stomped his foot and his hands formed fists at his sides.

“Do not laugh at me!”

Rio shifted to the edge of her seat and held out both hands to Nicky, her laughter now stopped as she smiled hopefully at the little boy. “I'm sorry, Nicky. It's just... You are so like your mama.”

Nicky blinked, confusion taking over for a second which meant he relaxed a little and was able to quickly rub at his eye. “How?”

Rio cleared her throat, kept her hands out to Nicky, now more of a surrender than a reaching out. “Well,” she could feel Agatha’s eyes on her, knew she had to tread carefully. How could you tell an impressionable little boy that his mother also didn’t like to share? “Your mama is very passionate too. Apasionada, sí?”

Nicky nodded slowly, now looking down at Rio’s fingers as she wriggled them, “And that’s good. You should be.”

Nicky nodded again and sniffed as he buried a fist against his eye again, “I don’t want you to play with James.”

“How about this,” Rio offered cautiously, “Every week, we can schedule in some mellizos time, okay? Just me and you. And maybe your mama if she wants to learn how to really be a baller.”

Agatha scoffed and Nicky’s lips twitched just a little and Rio knew then that she’d cracked him.

“She isn’t very good.”

Agatha gasped dramatically and Nicky’s tentative smile grew up his face as Agatha dived at him and began to tickle his sides. “What did you say about your mama?!”

Nicky squealed and began to writhe as he tried to bat Agatha away and despite the joy of the moment, despite the fact that both Agatha and Nicky were happy, beaming, in fact, Rio felt hollow suddenly. She felt outside of the bubble more than she ever had.

Because Nicky wanted her in it, and she wanted that too, but she still had to talk through everything with Agatha. She had to keep a cool head and listen to her tell her everything about why she’d willingly taken her heart and then willingly crushed it.

“Rio?”

Rio jumped a little, having drifted to the most painful part of her mind, but a hand was on her good knee, and she turned to see Agatha looking up at her expectantly, her brown eyed boy looking the same.

“Come here please,” Agatha echoed the words of her son from earlier, and Rio couldn’t refuse her as she slid down to sit back against the couch.

It was a pile on then. Nicky hit first and then Agatha. Rio burst out laughing as Nicky giggled into her ear and dug his knee into her stomach. She felt winded, but she felt light, honoured that the two precious people in her arms were the jealous types and that they were jealous for her.

The pain shifted again, turning to pride once more.

She squeaked as Nicky’s knee dug in a little more and then barked a laugh when lithe fingers found her side and dug in there too. “No! No! Get off, get off!”

Nicky laughed more as he pulled away and Rio rolled her eyes as Agatha found a way to tug him into her lap instead, leaving Rio to recover and clutch at her stomach. “¡Matones!” Bullies!

“¿Qué? No entiendo…” Nicky’s giggles died as he whispered the words, shy about his lack of understanding.

Rio just turned to him with a smile and reached to brush the hair back from his face, “It means “bullies”.”

Agatha ducked her head down to kiss Nicky’s shoulder and then murmured something in his ear that Rio missed but that made him grin. Rio leant back more against the couch and tilted her head in question at the two of them, “What?”

“Mama says I shouldn’t learn Spanish from you because you’re not very good.”

Rio’s jaw dropped and she turned to glare at Agatha, “Oh? Is that right?”

She just shrugged and smirked against Nicky’s shoulder.

“Hmm.”

Nicky giggled and Rio clicked her tongue, “No tostones for your mama, Nicky.”

Agatha gasped and Rio knew she was playing up to it as Nicky wriggled happily in her arms. When their eyes met Rio couldn’t help but grin at her, for the mother she was, and how it made her chest ache and the rest of her feel things inexpressible around a little boy.

“One tostone,” Agatha pouted, making sure Rio could see it as she rested her chin on Nicky’s shoulder.

Rio hummed, drawn to that soft lower lip that she’d bitten and tasted more times than she could count but never enough times to satisfy the need she felt now. “No.”

“Please?”

Rio laughed as she raised her gaze up a few inches to meet Agatha’s eyes and saw in them a glint of something she’d missed in the week and a half they’d been in this strange limbo together. They were teasing, sure, but there was something else there, something else that if Nicky weren’t currently between them, Rio would have liked to have explored.

Agatha’s hand shot out and she was careful to touch the skin of Rio’s injured knee, but skirting around the graze and Rio knew instantly that Agatha had realised what Rio was thinking. She knew exactly what she was doing.

Rio swallowed and fought the blush that threatened to grace her cheeks as Agatha’s finger began to circle the graze.

“No. No tostones for you.”

Agatha’s lips twitched a little and she stopped pouting but Rio had torn her gaze away from the danger zone anyway and Agatha had pulled her hand back, tucking it around Nicky instead.

“I’ll get my tostones,” Agatha said softly, more of a promise than a whisper and Rio decided the next batch she made - inevitably burnt or soggy as they would be - she’d gift them all to Agatha.

A knock at the door interrupted her thoughts as she was deciding what else she’d like to gift to Agatha and they all looked round when both Jen and Alice stepped inside.

“So, you’ll never guess who just got a furious call from Harvey Kent.”

Rio rolled her eyes and turned to lean back properly against the couch, “Surely not you, Alice?!”

“Hah fucking hah.”

Rio laughed a little and rubbed at her face as she felt Nicky reach to pat her shoulder. “It was an accident.”

“Well who the fuck plays fucking basketball-…?”

“Do you mind speaking like that in front of my son, Alice?”

Alice blanched and Rio smiled a little at the sight of it, pleased she was no longer being chastised.

“Fine. I’m just saying it was-…”

“It was an accident, Alice. What’s he worried about?”

“Apparently insurance or some such shit - sorry, Agatha - but I just said-…”

“She said he should go fuck himself-…” Jen added before Agatha made a noise of objection and dramatically clamped her hands over Nicky’s ears.

“Oh, he’s heard worse from you lately.”

Rio raised her brows and in turning to see Agatha’s reaction to this she saw Alice blink across at her in shock. Agatha looked briefly mutinous but then schooled her expression and cleared her throat, “thank you for the support, Jennifer.”

Jennifer rolled her eyes and to try to bring the mood in the room back around Rio said: “I’ll pay it, Alice. If they can’t get the insurance then-…”

“Absolutely not. Jen, I’ll be paying it.”

“No,” Rio insisted, shooting Agatha a look, “It was my fault. Take it out of my-…”

“Rio,” Agatha had reached a hand out to her knee and had turned around to look at her sternly, “Let me pay to get rid of the problem for you.”

Rio’s jaw flexed, as she recognised Agatha’s go-to move: paying for things to make them go away. But this wasn’t a G-Wagon, and she wasn’t as raw anymore. She watched her for a second and then she turned back to Alice and in a louder voice than before she said, “Alice, call him back. Tell him I’ll pay for it. Go. Now.”

Alice looked shocked for a second because Rio wasn’t the type of boss to order her about but she nodded and turned and went to do as she’d been told.

Agatha removed her hand from Rio’s knee and Rio stood up.

“Rio,” Nicky said quickly, looking up at her with wide eyes, “don’t forget your promise.”

Rio smiled and ducked back down again to place a quick kiss to Nicky’s warm cheek. “Never, mellizo.”

Nicky smiled, back to being shy now there was a third adult in the room, and Agatha tightened her hold around him which made Rio look up at her. She looked nervous suddenly, and couldn’t quite meet Rio’s gaze.

Rio hesitated for a second, heard Jen calling her name, and finally, reluctantly, she pulled away without saying anything. Their cosy, familial bubble had been burst. Rio squeezed Jen’s arms as she walked past and she stepped out into the early evening with her heart, as battered and bruised as it was, sitting curled up on the floor of Agatha’s trailer, by the couch.

As she marched back with Alice to her own trailer, the pain settled in her chest again with its own mellizo: panic.

Chapter End Notes

The Talk is up next

I'm sure it'll be totally fine and no one will get hurt or upset

Chapter 36: Talk Tonight

Chapter Summary

Rio and Agatha talk.

Chapter Notes

*Dakota Fanning voice* PAIN

See the end of the chapter for more notes

7:37pm
Agatha Harkness: You can come over.

Rio put her phone down and her head between her knees.

Maybe being alone wasn’t a great idea. Maybe having Alice with her would have been a better idea. Maybe having a hand to hold or someone to slap her out of it would have been better.

She thought about calling her dad again. But she’d already spoken to him for an hour that morning.

She knew he wouldn’t mind, that he was endlessly patient, but she couldn’t bring herself to do it. If she spoke about it she’d cry again. And she had to be together. She had to remain in tact if she were going to get through this.

She’d been ready for hours now. She’d showered around midday after a particularly intensive workout. She’d then changed into three different outfits until she settled on a long-sleeved black jersey top, and dark jeans.

It wasn’t flashy, but it was comfortable, and she needed comfort right now. She wanted as much comfort as she could get.

Her hair was brushed and her face makeup free - she had to be ready to cry after all.

It wasn’t how she wanted to look for Agatha. She wanted to look so devastatingly gorgeous that she’d combust when she saw her. But perhaps that was a dream from a different day. Now it was about remaining upright, remaining alive.

Agatha’s text went unanswered in her inbox as Rio drove to her house buried in the most expensive part of town. She parked not too far away but didn’t move for fear she might collapse if she tried.

This had to go well. And by ‘well’, Rio meant she had to not have a breakdown, she had to not lose it, or lose herself.

Only when she felt strong enough did she step from the car and make her way down to press the buzzer for the gate. She was let in before she could even take a breath. Perhaps it was a sign that Agatha wanted this over and done with.

Maybe she wanted Rio in and out faster than you could say: “I slept with my husband, sorry.”

Rio stepped up the path, feeling heavy with every step she took, feeling sick with every step she took.

But Agatha was in the doorway, looking pale and standing in a plain white t-shirt and light jeans. It was frustrating that she looked beautiful. That she always looked so beautiful.

Why did she always look so damn beautiful?

“Hi.”

Rio stopped before her, momentarily thunderstruck and unable to think of what to say. But Agatha seemed to understand and she took a step back, motioning for Rio to enter through the space she’d just made for her.

Rio did, silently, barely able to keep upright, let alone anything else.

She stopped just inside the door, felt the absence of what Agatha’s greeting might have been under different circumstances. A hug, a kiss, any kind of contact.

Agatha liked contact. She liked to touch her and be close.

And now they were lightyears apart.

“I sent Nicky to stay with Jen. I thought that maybe…”

Agatha didn’t finish what she was about to say but Rio could guess: Maybe I’d shout. Maybe you’d shout. Maybe we’d both shout.

She just kept breathing and followed Agatha through to the kitchen. On the side there sat a lit candle and a bottle of Barolo, already open, already being left to breathe.

Agatha cleared her throat as she approached it and lifted it with the two large glasses.

“I have anything else if you want something different?”

Rio still couldn’t speak so she just shook her head just once. Agatha smiled, more of a gesture than a feeling, and turned to the little breakfast nook that Rio had sat at so many times before under vastly different circumstances.

She let Agatha take her spot first and she sat at the top of the table, at the bottom of the inbuilt L-shaped bench. Rio was still for a while before she slid in to the back part of the bench, making sure there was at least two feet of distance between her and Agatha.

She stared at the grain of the table and lay her hands out before her.

Silence filled the room, loud and unbearable, until it was broken by Agatha pouring the wine into the large glasses and the sound of her sliding one over to Rio.

When she did, Rio saw that her ring was on, that she was wearing a fake engagement ring chosen for a movie role, in her own home.

It made her heart stutter, momentarily forgetting what it was supposed to be doing, as her chest heaved with the unbearable longing she now felt.

“You’re wearing your ring,” she couldn’t help but say, the first thing she’d said to Agatha since the trailer the day before.

“I… I felt like…” Agatha stole her hand back and hid the ring from view, “I just felt like I needed it.”

Rio didn’t look up, didn’t even raise her gaze when Agatha hid her hand. She just kept staring at the table before her, at the hands that had just now decided to start shaking.

Her whole body was shaking. She couldn’t stop herself. It was incessant, it was embarrassing.

Whether it was a misfire of adrenaline, the fear that this was it for them, or something else entirely, she didn’t know. She just knew she was shaking and that it made her more mortified than she’d ever been in her life.

She sat on her hands.

“Rio,” Agatha said quietly, and though Rio didn’t look up at her name she tilted her head slightly, a kind of acknowledgement that she could hear her, though she wasn’t able to respond.

“If you’ll let me, I want to tell you everything. I… I want, I want you to know everything. Everything there is to know about… about me… Is that okay? Do you need anything before I start?”

Rio knew she only needed one thing.

Or her body did.

She lurched up suddenly and scrambled from the bench, blocked by the table before her until she suddenly wasn’t and she could tear through to the bathroom where she slammed the door, was just able to lock it, and into the waiting mouth of the toilet she vomited her guts up.

It was mostly bile, mostly nothing at all.

But she wretched and wretched until she could wretch no more.

Her body collapsed against the bowl when she was done and she breathed heavily, raggedly, and wiped at the tears that had fallen.

This wasn’t how she wanted this to go.

She’d been preparing all week for this. She’d been convincing herself all week that she was ready, that she could handle it.

And suddenly, when faced with it, she’d never felt less prepared in her life.

She sucked in a slow, steadying breath and eventually dragged herself to her feet. She cleaned up after herself and rummaged until she found some mouthwash and rinsed her mouth with it.

In the mirror she saw the shadow of the woman she’d once been and she wiped at her tear-stained face, ran her hands through her hair, and then went back out.

By the table Agatha was standing now, looking panicked and fearful but Rio didn’t meet her gaze as she silently slid back into her seat and raised her glass to knock back the large glass Agatha had poured for her.

When she was done, Agatha said nothing as she refilled Rio’s glass but Rio didn’t touch it after that.

Some wine was fine, but she had barely eaten for days now, and she didn’t want to be drunk.

They were silent for a couple of minutes and out of the corner of her eye Rio could see Agatha toying with her ring. She wanted to reach for her hand to make her stop, to make her hold her instead, but she stopped herself and sat on her hands once more.

“I’ve known I was gay since I was about eight. Or maybe,” Agatha began in such a soft voice that Rio finally had to look up at her. “Maybe not exactly, but it was around then that… I knew I was different.”

Rio swallowed, having not realised that when Agatha had said “everything” she meant everything.

“I had what I know now was a crush on one of the older girls. And then when I was a teenager, I had a crush on a friend. I felt good whenever she looked at me, it felt nice to hold her hand, I…”

Agatha shook her head and Rio suddenly felt the urge again to reach for her.

“My mother had been telling me for as long as I remember that… that something was wrong with me, that I had a badness inside, that… that I’d been born evil. So I hid it. I hid it as best I could. I think she knew, I think she knows… I’ve never been sure.”

“Agatha,” Rio said quietly but Agatha only shook her head again and raised her eyes to meet Rio’s. She looked broken, but she shook her head once more and Rio only nodded, and remained silent.

Agatha took a sip of her wine and continued.

“I made sure I was friends with the right people. I blocked anyone who I felt was beneath me. I no longer held any hands or harboured any crushes. I was a straight A student, head cheerleader, top of all my classes. I went to the right college and even went to Juilliard. I had one boyfriend and then I had a husband.”

Rio looked down again, swallowed the bile that rose in her throat.

“Throughout all of it I knew I was… I knew I was gay. I just ignored it, pushed it down, wilfully suppressed. And it was working. It was working so beautifully and then…”

Rio looked up again and saw that Agatha was looking at her now.

Her eyes were that glassy way they got when they were full of tears she was reluctant to yet shed. She looked hopeless and terrified once more.

“And then I saw you. And I just… I… I fell in love.”

Rio had to look away again. She had to close her eyes and take a deep breath because they’d barely started and how the ever-living fuck was she supposed to get through this without having a breakdown?

“Rio, I… I know how this sounds… I know I sound insane but the moment I saw you on that stage I just… it was like I’d been hit by lightning, or, or, stabbed right through the heart. You left me…. You left me completely and utterly-…”

“Please,” Rio managed to get out, feeling her now-numb hands fizz back to life as she pulled them from under her thighs and dug her knuckles into her eyes, “please, Agatha this is…”

“I need to tell you, Rio. You…” She heard a noise and looked down to see Agatha’s hand reaching for her across the table, “Please, please let me explain.”

Rio released a long, slow breath, allowing herself to shrink down into the back of the bench. Agatha didn’t say anything until Rio nodded and then she slowly pulled her offered hand away and started again in a slow, soft voice: “I just fell so hard and so instantly. And when I cornered you in the bathroom it was the first time I’d ever… I’d ever lost control like that.”

Rio swallowed thickly, transporting herself momentarily to the grimy bathroom in downtown Chicago where they’d first met. She could smell the bleach that still didn’t hide the stink from the drains. She could feel the hard, cold stall door against her back, she could taste Agatha’s warm breath against her lips.

“Rio?”

Rio opened her eyes and blinked across at Agatha, and saw that she looked concerned and her hand was held back out to her again.

“I need you to know that from the moment I saw you I… I’ve loved you.”

Rio released a quiet sort of whimper and Agatha leant closer, bit didn’t move from her seat. Rio didn’t take the hand held out to her. It was still so early. They’d barely begun. If she held onto her now, she’d never make it through.

When Agatha realised Rio wouldn’t take her hand, she slowly pulled back.

She visibly swallowed and she placed her hands around her glass instead.

“I couldn’t stop thinking about you after that. I searched everywhere for you. I even bought tickets to shows you were doing but I couldn’t bring myself to… I didn’t trust myself to go.”

Rio closed her eyes again, thinking back on the twenty-something Rio with the big ego who would have died if she’d seen Agatha Harkness rock up to her show again. She’d have collapsed on the spot if the bathroom incident had happened again. She’d have combusted if Agatha would have so much as touched her.

“It was a month after I saw you that I saw Ralph again. I… it was the first time we’d had sex without a condom. We’d been married for almost five years and… hadn’t really had sex since our wedding night. I was angry. I wanted you and I couldn’t have you and so I had… I had him instead. It was the first time I’d cried during sex. I thought of you, of how your hands had felt in mine, of how you’d smelled up close, of…”

“Agatha, please don’t.”

Agatha nodded and cleared her throat quietly, “And… and then just over a month later I got sick. Every morning I was so sick and I knew I must be pregnant. It felt cruel at the time. The one time I’d ever allowed him to… anyway. I was hung up still. Hung up on you and all through my pregnancy I thought of what you might be like if you were there, if…”

“Jesus, Agatha, please, it’s… it’s too…”

“Rio, you need to know this. Please I might never get to… I might never get to tell you, please let me tell you.”

Rio could barely stand it. She wanted to tear her skin off, she wanted to burn her eyes out, she wanted to claw and claw and claw until she could get out.

Agatha didn’t say anything for a while, she let Rio sit in her struggle. She let her digest it and churn it in her stomach, until, eventually, Rio nodded again.

Agatha took a deep breath and she started speaking once more: “Ralph wasn’t interested unless someone asked. He lied about coming to appointments with me. He lied about rubbing my feet at night and feeling the baby kick. He… I carried Nicky alone and when I needed to, I thought of you, of who I thought you might be to me. I thought about your smile and your big brown eyes and your soft skin and then when Nicky came along he had all those things. He has those big brown eyes and that goofy grin and-…”

Rio looked up then, her expression far from goofy, her brow instead practically concave as she looked longingly at the woman who’d just about cracked the most tragic of smiles as she was describing her son.

“I… at the hotel, after the CCA’s, I asked you how you felt about what Lilia had said about Nicky inheriting the face of someone I love. I believe it. I know it’s so ridiculous, I know it can’t be real but… it has to be. I’ve clung to it all these years.”

Rio shook her head and hid her face in her hands. She just needed a second, a second to not see or be seen.

And Agatha gave her that. She gave her ten, twenty, thirty, and then, she spoke again.

“We’ve lived mostly by ourselves. Ralph usually stays on the east coast or in his condo downtown. Nicky has never really had a father but he’s had me. I’ve tried to put everything good into him and I think that-…”

“You have,” Rio said suddenly, dropping her hands to see that Agatha’s tears had overspilled now and she was wiping at them with shaking fingers. “That boy is… Agatha, he’s perfect. You made a perfect little boy.”

Agatha audibly swallowed, a soft squeak of a noise, and she sniffed as she looked down into her glass of wine.

“We made a life for ourselves. I worked and I came home to Nicky. That was it. Ralph comes home for the holidays or for a red carpet or if my mother…”

She sighed and wiped quickly at an errant tear, “It’s my mother who forced it. Who suggested it. The marriage, I mean. Ralph comes from good stock. He’s tall and handsome and-… any woman would be lucky to have him.” She spat the last words, said them with such bitterness that Rio bit down on her lip as she watched Agatha gather herself, gather her thoughts.

“Only he’s selfish and stupid and he couldn’t care less about Nicky. You know what he said when he found out about his hair? He said: ‘good. Perhaps now he’ll …’.” But she stopped herself, clearly unable to finish what exactly Ralph had said.

Rio clenched her teeth so hard she thought she might break her whole jaw.

“Nicky knows he’s not interested. He’s smart and sensitive enough to understand that. But I’ve tried to give him enough love that he would never feel without. I’ve done everything in my power to be the opposite of my own mother.”

“Nicky is evidence that you have been,” Rio said slowly, trying her hardest to relax her tense body. “He’s incredible. You’re an incredible mom.”

Agatha sniffed quietly and wiped at her eyes.

“Sometimes I… I used to think when he was little and I saw you across the room at parties, I used to wonder if you’d ever been with a woman who had kids before. If it was something you wanted. If it was something you would ever want to take on… but I never… I never let myself think too much about it. It was too painful to think about. What might have been, what could have been… an actress rocking up one day saying, ‘hey I only met you once but I’m in love with you and anyway here’s my kid with your exact same face let’s shack up’.” She scoffed derisively and Rio went right back to chewing on the inside of her cheek.

She tasted blood.

“Anyway. As you started showing up more and more and your name was being said practically everywhere I went I… I thought I’d be okay. I thought I could handle it and then… then you were at the Hollywood Reporter shoot. Just sitting in that makeup chair, just feet from me. And then you were talking to Wanda and I just-…”

Wanda.

And Rio suddenly remembered another betrayal. The betrayal of the role taken from under Wanda.

But Agatha was still talking and her brief foray into anger at her died immediately upon her next words: “I wanted to ask you to come home with me. I wanted to hold your hand during that photoshoot and lean down and ask you to come into the makeup trailer with me. I wanted to see if you wanted to kiss me. I wanted to see if-…”

She stopped herself and Rio watched as she closed her eyes and breathed out heavily, “I just wanted you to see me and I wanted to be around you. I felt more alive than I’d felt in years that day.”

Rio looked down again, remembered the anxiety she’d had that day, back when Agatha made her nervous, not sick.

“And then Cannes… when I saw you in the lobby and I was with Ralph. It made me so ashamed. So ashamed that this… this stranger… was going about her life, was just living her life, and there I was, with a husband I hated, having spent the last eight years thinking about her.”

Rio hid again. She had to. She raised her hands and breathed out against them, covering her whole face in the process.

It was so much worse than she’d feared it would be.

If everything Agatha was saying were true then how, how had she done what she’d done?

How had she gone back to Ralph when surely Rio had given her everything she’d wanted?

It made no sense.

And in the confusion, it hurt like hell.

“I agreed to the vacation in Italy because I couldn’t help myself. I wanted the chance to be closer to you. I wanted to see if I could drink wine with you and flirt a little and see if you’d respond. I wanted to spend the day by the pool with you and casually lean over and kiss you and have you kiss me back. I spent that whole time so desperate and so, god, so fucking out of my mind for you that I could barely think straight. The night, the night you woke up and I was on the balcony, I was just thinking about how this could have been my life. Maybe I could have convinced you to fall for me. Maybe this could have been a trip we were on together, just to get a few days away. and then you wrapped your arms around me in the bed, and I… I had to make you turn, had to hold you instead. Because if you held me then you’d let me go. I couldn’t bear the thought of it so I held onto you and it was the best…”

Agatha was crying now, properly, and Rio shuffled forwards to reach up and dry her tears. Agatha allowed her, sniffed softly, turning her head into Rio’s hands, “I hadn’t slept so well since I was a child.”

Rio bit down on her lip, her thumbs now brushing back and forth across Agatha’s cheek as she held her head. Her eyes were closed, and Rio scanned over her features, over the dark bags under her eyes, the hard lines of the lips she was pursing, the curves and junctures of her beautiful face.

It felt like the first time she was truly realising that she wasn’t the only heartbroken one.

“I wish you’d said something.”

Agatha nodded slightly, her hands raising to grasp Rio’s wrists as she opened her eyes. “I was so scared. I thought maybe that would be enough. That I could live with… with just knowing how it felt to hold you.”

“Agatha,” Rio breathed out, her own tears now beginning to fall, “Agatha, I don’t understand. Why are you saying all this when… when you left me. I told you I loved you and-…”

Agatha sucked in shakily, and her told flexed on Rio’s wrists as she stared across at her. “I’m trying, Rio. Please, I’m trying to explain.”

Rio nodded slowly, torn between believing Agatha and believing that she was just spinning a narrative, a story, to make her feel sorry for her, to soften her defences and pull her in once more.

But she believed the look she was giving her now.

She believed those watery blue eyes and those soft hands that bore her ring and held her like she meant something.

And so she began to pull away, only she allowed her hands to be held now. She let Agatha hold her. And Agatha, sniffing softly and visibly in pain, began to talk again.

“The day you came over… the day we kissed, I hadn’t planned it. I’d decided I could have you in my life. Because the thought of you not being in it was too painful, but that we would just be friends. I thought I could handle that. And then I saw how you were with Nicky, how good you were with him and how he just opened up-… I…”

Blue eyes disappeared again as Agatha squeezed them tightly shut and Rio had to duck her head down to not see it. She squeezed her own eyes to try and stop the tears but it was no use anymore.

Everything hurt. Everything felt hopeless.

“You just,” Agatha began again, once she had a handle on her shaking voice, her hands now not just holding Rio, but gripping her, “you were so good with him and he loved you immediately and I… I needed to kiss you. I needed to feel, even for a second, even if in kissing you my world would burn down… I needed to feel how it would feel to have you, to really have you because it was all I wanted and all I-…” she gasped softly and shook her head.

Rio kept hers angled down, her eyes now open but staring blindly at their joined hands.

“I just wanted you so badly. I couldn’t bear not to touch you anymore. I wanted to feel your skin on mine and your lips on-… Rio, I was just… I just needed you. And when we, when you kissed back, when you… I lost it totally. I knew I couldn’t go back to not kissing you.”

Rio shook her head and closed her eyes, imagining that night now, how nervous she’d been, how shocked and how desperate she’d felt.

It had felt like a fairytale. Like fiction.

Especially now.

She swallowed and slowly raised her gaze to meet Agatha’s and saw before her a totally broken woman, a woman who was now reaching further up her arm, clutching at her sleeves, trying to pull her closer.

“Please know how badly I wanted you. Please… please understand how you’re it for me. How when I came over that next day I said I was there to make the mistake properly but I… I wanted to touch you and taste you forever. I wanted you to want me too and I-…”

Agatha dissolved again, crumpled completely and pulled her hands back from Rio to hide herself.

But Rio was too far gone to notice. She’d hidden her face as soon as she had her hands back. She whimpered and cried into them until she felt Agatha reach for her again, until her hands were being peeled away and until she felt Agatha beside her on the bench, soft and tender as she pressed her face into her cheek and cradled her head against her own.

Rio cried still, turning into her, until they were two broken women, staring up at one another, breathing each other’s air, tasting each other’s sorrow.

Rio swallowed thickly, felt Agatha lean in, nudge their noses, and then lean in more.

But she pulled back, put some distance between them and dropped her head down. Agatha didn’t move for a second and then her hand was back on her cheek and she was pressing a firm, lingering kiss to her crown.

“This hurts so much, Agatha,” she admitted even as Agatha still pressed into her hair, “why are you making this hurt so much.”

Agatha breathed in sharply, changed the angle of her head to be able to speak, and when she did Rio felt the brush of her words against her. “I’m sorry, I’m so sorry. I need to tell you everything. I want you to know because I’m so… I’m so scared this will be it and I will never get to tell you how much… I’m so sorry.”

Rio shook her head, trying to clear her mind, trying to be rational, to think even slightly with her logical self. But she feared she was lost. She was so lost in all of this that she couldn’t think of anything that didn’t hurt.

The words her dad had spoken to her all week, those loving, kind words that she’d used to get her through to this day, were all gone now. She couldn’t find them in the labyrinth of pain.

Everything was Agatha. Everything was losing Agatha.

She lifted her head slowly and wiped at her eyes with her light sleeves and to do something she reached for her wine and took a large gulp and heard Agatha shift beside her.

She’d moved away, she’d given her space.

Rio cleared her throat as she stared down at the stem of the wine glass and toyed with it absently, her fingers pink and damp from hers or Agatha’s tears.

“The night in London,” Agatha started slowly, her breathing uneven as Rio closed her eyes again. “You’d been so good with Nicky and I’d missed you so much. When we left the restaurant you were so angry and so protective and I felt, Rio, I felt so ashamed and so, so fucking furious with myself that I couldn’t give myself to you. That I couldn’t let Nicky have you. Because you… you were so intent on protecting us and Ralph never… he never cared… he never tried and-…”

As Rio looked up Agatha closed her eyes, “I was such a coward. Such a coward. All I could think of was how perfect you were and how bad I was. How I’d been stealing your goodness and giving you… giving you nothing back. That I could never give you anything back because I… I’m a coward.”

Rio gasped quietly as the repeated word fell into place, as it wriggled its way into her memory and slotted into the words shouted at her in anger, in desperation: “You’re a COWARD, Rio! A COWARD!

“I felt,” Agatha whimpered, “I felt as though… I needed to let you go. I felt as if it were the kindest thing… that you’d grow to hate and resent me anyway and then… then you were on your knees for me a-and I… I was selfish and I wanted… I wanted you one last time. and I needed to hear it, hear you say you loved me just once… and then I thought… I thought that would be it. That I could live forever with the knowledge that once… that once you had loved me. And that I’d felt what it was to be truly loved a-and…”

Agatha shook her head again and Rio was now wiping furiously at her own face, trying desperately to see when all she felt was tears.

“I wasn’t, I wasn’t, I-I wasn’t good enough.”

“You could never be enough!”

The pain was visceral now, like being stabbed again and again.

“A-and then I went back a-and Ralph… he… I knew what the worst thing I could do was. S-so I did it. I let h-him… I slept with him a-and it hurt and I hated it a-and… I needed to punish myself. I had to punish-…”

“Agatha,” Rio sobbed out, her whole body trembling now, her whole self utterly broken, “Please… Please don’t… I can’t hear anymore, I-… p-please.”

“You h-have to understand, please, please, Rio. I did it to h-hurt me, I didn’t… it was never to h-hurt you and I… I realised as soon as-…”

“Agatha, please… please stop…”

“I… I knew what I’d d-done only after I’d done it a-and that I wanted… Rio… I… Quería ser valiente. Q-quiero ser valiente.” I wanted to be brave. I w-want to be brave.

Rio’s mind was a tortured thing. A desperate, screaming thing. She could no longer hear Agatha, not really. The words were registering only as gashes against her soul. She was being torn open and ripped apart with every syllable.

She buried her head in her hands again, sobbing audibly because she couldn’t hold it in anymore. And then Agatha was around her. Agatha was holding her and she couldn’t pull away. She didn’t want to.

The woman who’d torn her open was now holding her together.

“Rio Rio Rio,” Agatha began to chant her name, whispering it against her hair as she sobbed into her. She clung at her shirt, making the clean white fabric now a mess of snot and tears. And Agatha held on, she held her so fiercely that Rio’s violent sobs made Agatha vibrate, and they shared the pain of them, as they shared the pain of this.

It took minutes, but Agatha didn’t relent in her hold. She didn’t loosen her grip or pull away. She just kept saying Rio’s name until it morphed into “lo siento, mi amor, lo siento” whispered over and over again.

As the sobs became hiccups Rio pressed her face painfully into Agatha’s chest. She wanted to dissolve into her. She wanted to live in her skin and feel her blood pulsing through her veins. She wanted to know the whisperings of her bones and the echoes in her heart.

She wanted her wildly, unrelentingly, despite the pain she was in, perhaps because of it.

A rumbling in Agatha’s chest told her that she was now taking in deep, heavy breaths and Rio only pressed closer as Agatha began to speak properly again.

“I was s-so angry a-and so scared I-… I made the worst mistake o-of my life and I wanted… I knew I had to tell you. I knew I-I needed to tell you i-immediately and then…”

Agatha’s swallow became a squeak as Rio had begun to shift against her. She was pulling up and hiccuping as she did. But she wasn’t pulling back. Her face was now glued to Agatha’s skin, trailing its misery in thick wet lines up her chest and along her throat, up until the bridge of her nose was against the corner of Agatha’s jaw and she could breathe in her perfume as she spoke, “Please don’t Agatha.”

It didn’t sound like her voice. It was deeper and more gravelly than she’d ever heard it. Perhaps Agatha’s words had slashed through her vocal chords too. Perhaps every part of her had been decimated and now she was just a shell, just a broken heart barely beating.

She raised her hand from where it still clutched Agatha’s shirt to hold Agatha’s cheek and she lifted her head up and looked properly into Agatha’s blood-red eyes and saw her own pain reflected right back at her.

“I hate hearing…” She took a breath and Agatha whimpered quietly, fighting her own tears as they freely streamed down her face. “I c-can’t hear anymore, A-Agatha. I l-love you so much. I can’t… I can’t… please don’t make me please don’t make me.”

Another sob wracked through her body unexpectedly and Agatha pulled her back into, holding her head to her own and pulling her so Rio was crying against her face. It wasn’t clear whose tears belonged to who.

But Rio couldn’t breathe for the pain she was in, for the pain she knew Agatha must have been in the night she felt she deserved to be punished rather than to be loved by her.

“Rio,” Agatha breathed out after Rio’s sobs died again and she was instead just hiccuping and clutching at her. “Rio,” she said again, this time making her intentions clear as she manoeuvred pliable Rio into her lap and Rio curled around her, hiding her face against her neck.

Agatha held her until the hiccups slowed, until Rio was breathing audibly, until her clutching became holding.

“W-when I saw…” Agatha started cautiously, rubbing Rio’s back as she spoke close by her ear, “The next morning… when I saw that bruise on y-your neck I… I panicked… I was so afraid it meant you… you already had one foot out the door and I… I couldn’t do it. I couldn’t…”

Rio began to pull back then and Agatha gasped and clutched at her, but Rio only wanted to rest their foreheads together, blindly seeking more closeness even as she had her knees either side of her hips, her hands buried in long, wavy hair.

“I…” Agatha tried again, “I couldn’t tell you when I thought… I thought… a-and then,” Agatha’s breath was warm and familiar against Rio’s aching face, and the feel of it helped soothe the sting of her words. “A-and Jen found out. She heard us. And I had nothing to lose anymore e-except you so I told her. I told her that for eight years I’d pined, that I’d n-named Nicky… I’d given him your name… and I told her, my love, I told her what I’d done.”

Even this close, even so close Rio could count every freckle, Rio saw Agatha’s whole face crumple. I wanted to be good for you. I wanted to make you feel good. To show you h-how much I cared and wanted you and wanted you to… to want me too.”

Rio closed her eyes, looking back on the night she’d thought was just fun, was just romance and sex, when really Agatha had been trying to prove something to herself, all the while keeping this terrible secret from Rio.

It was damp and sticky but she was warm and familiar and god Rio had missed her body so much.

This perfect woman had been placed with an unfit, unfeeling mother. She’d been made to feel less than her perfection. She’d become warped in her view of herself. She’d been so neglected that even when given the love she so desperately wanted she’d turned away, and punished herself for it.

“I love you,” Rio croaked out in defiance of Evanora’s hold on her daughter as her fingers trailed down damp cheeks and lined up along a quivering jawline. “I love you with everything I have, a-and everything I am. And I will never love anyone else. I will never be able to. I was made only for you. And I think, Agatha, mi amor I think that you were made only for me.”

Agatha was crying more now, shaking beneath Rio as she absorbed her words.

“I am sorry you were frightened. I am so fucking s-sorry you slept with him to p-punish, god, to punish yourself for… fuck. For…”

She gave up, closing her eyes as she tried to steady her breathing again. “You have h-hurt me more than I can… more than I can bear…”

“Agatha,” Rio whispered, feeling the panic rise in her too like a rising tide sinks that all ships.

Rio nodded, because she knew. Agatha had tried to get a reaction that wasn’t just Rio leaving. She’d tried for a reaction that would prove in some twisted way that Rio cared enough to give one. But Rio had cared so much she’d had no choice but to leave.

Maybe you could-…” she swallowed and Rio moved back an inch to take in her face properly, to watch the struggle as she went to ask the question, “maybe you could live with us.”

Agatha Harkness was everything Rio Vidal had ever wanted.

She’d lusted after her since she was a teenager. She’d fallen as much in love with her as it was possible to through a screen. And then she’d met her and she’d tumbled into actual, true love without even realising.

And so hearing this, hearing that Agatha wanted her to move in, that she loved her enough to want her with her and her son, under every other fathomable circumstance it would have been a joyous, wondrous thing.

But now it felt something else.

It felt not joyous, and not wondrous.

Rio dropped her head down and heard Agatha as she whimpered in pain. She moved her hand to clutch briefly at Agatha’s shirt and then she released her and she began to pull away.

Agatha didn’t fight.

She managed to stand on shaking legs and she wiped furiously at her face with her sodden sleeves. She took a deep breath and in doing so she turned back to Agatha who had crumpled where she sat. Her head was against the knees she’d pulled up to hug close to her chest and she was crying silently as Rio spoke.

I-I’ve told him e-everything and I have listened to him a-as he told me… Agatha as he told me that you were frightened a-and we do strange things when we’re frightened. She gasped, loud and deep.

Her dad’s voice was back, accompanied by her mom’s face as she rolled her eyes at her husband’s latest flavour of beermat philosophy. And Rio almost laughed as her parents’ filled her up again, and then their memory faded to blue eyes so desperate and so despairing.

She had to go back. She had to hear everything Agatha had to tell her.

And then she had to process. Then she had to push through the pain.

Because she loved her, god she loved her.

She had a choice to make that could only be made when she had given Agatha the chance, every possible chance, to tell her everything she needed to know.

With warm water she splashed her face and dried it with a nearby hand-towel. The fabric was soft and welcome against her raw cheeks and swollen eyes. She looked in the mirror only when she was clean of tears and what she saw made her grimace.

Her brown eyes were glassy and seemed now too large for her face. The whites were riddled with angry red veins though Rio felt only pain; she had no energy for anger right now. Her eyes blinked and was slow, like her body was slowly shutting down, like it was trying to preserve itself for what was to come.

She had to look away, she had to turn from her pink nose and blotchy, irritated skin. She had to go back to Agatha and face into this once more.

With heavy feet and a hollow chest, she did.

Agatha was sat on the very edge of the bench, her head in her hands, but she straightened the moment Rio came back and she looked frightened, even more so than before.

“I still have questions,” Rio husked out, moving some distance away to sit at the kitchen island. The stool wobbled as she, with unsteady limbs, climbed onto it.

“Okay,” Agatha said, turning to watch her, her posture still hunched, closing in on herself, “Anything.”

Rio was raw and emptied out but the only way out was through so she asked: “How did it feel?”

Agatha’s brow twitched but Rio didn’t elaborate and Agatha only nodded, understood what she was being asked as Rio clutched her hands in her lap.

“It hurt. I… it hurt and I knew, I didn’t want it.”

“Did he… Agatha, did he force you?”

Why hadn’t she considered it? Why had it never crossed her mind?

Agatha was silent. Silent for perhaps a second too long and Rio stumbled from her seat as Agatha stood suddenly and they stared at each other; two cowboys, unarmed.

“I did it willingly, Rio.” It cut so deep it was almost as if Agatha’s whisper had suddenly become a shout. “I didn’t say no. He didn’t force it.”

Relief flickered briefly but like a candle in the wind died upon its birth and the reality of Agatha again choosing Ralph, choosing Ralph to punish herself as she now knew, settled back in her bruised chest.

She didn’t sit back down.

Agatha didn’t either.

“Did he… did you use protection?”

Agatha’s mouth opened, her lower lip quivered, and then she said: “Yes. He wore a condom.”

Rio nodded and looked down. She could feel her palms sweating as they hung loosely by her sides. The thought of Ralph being inside Agatha was making her feel sick again but the thought of him coming inside her, the even slight chance that he could get her pregnant again, it was too much.

Her brain was whirring with so many thoughts and so many images of Ralph, tall, handsome Ralph, rutting over Agatha that she couldn’t help the next question that slipped out: “Did you kiss him?”

“Yes.”

Rio nodded, her gaze down still. Agatha’s legs were still in view, the pale hands that twisted and twisted the diamond ring on her left hand.

“Since we’ve been together… since we started this… was that the only time?”

“Yes.”

“Did you sleep with him after?”

“No. I… I showered and went to my own bed. I couldn’t sleep. All I could think of was telling you. Was getting on my knees a-and-…”

Rio had scoffed, had raised her hands to cover her face as the absurdity of Agatha’s statement washed over her, “I waited for you all night, Agatha. I… I waited for you to come back to me.”

“I-I know. I… I should have come to you. I should have told you immediately. I… I knew immediately, Rio. I had been so angry and then I was just scared. So scared I’d fucked it up. That I’d lost you because I…”

Rio shook her head and dropped her hands again and looked back up to Agatha. She’d stepped closer at some point, her left hand now reaching towards her through the distance. “I convinced myself I’d lose you anyway and I wanted to hurt myself because the thought of you deciding you’d leave me was… I couldn’t bear it. And then as soon as I’d forced it. As soon as he was off me and-,” Rio had squeaked, whimpering as she swallowed her tears, “I wanted to take it back. I wanted you. I wanted you to… I just wanted you.”

Rio closed her eyes and took a blind step backwards until she collided with the island behind her. She needed the reassurance that she wouldn’t fall because she felt so unsteady.

“Tell me why, why you’d think I’d leave. I need to understand, Agatha. I need-…”

“I’m older than you,” Agatha gasped out as if she’d been waiting for this question, “I have a son. I’m not out. I wasn’t ready to be out. I’m married and I hadn’t…”

“Yes. Yes I’m leaving him. I… I saw how good you were with Nicky and I just kept thinking that if you turned around and said you wanted a kid of your own you might… you might want someone younger. You might want your first kid to be with-…”

“The problem with that, Agatha,” Rio said in a voice that had found its strength again, and she opened her eyes once more, “is that I love your kid. And I know he isn’t mine. I would never force it… but I want him to be. I’d-…”

“I know,” Agatha murmured, “Rio, I… I know that, I know that. I just… I was so scared. At night I kept convincing myself you’d be happier with-…”

Rio gasped quietly and Agatha’s eyes flashed as the dots connected and colour filtered into the picture. The colour red. “Wanda. It’s Wanda, isn’t it? You thought… Agatha, that’s so…”

“You were playing her wife, you are the same age, she has no responsibilities, no baggage, she’s softer than I am, she’s-…”

Rio just shook her head and the psychology of Agatha Harkness was laid bare before her. It was complicated and twisted versions of the truth, but she now understood how she’d come to those conclusions in her mind and why she’d stolen Wanda’s role.

“Christmas wives,” she concluded quietly, watching as Agatha nodded at her, as she took a step closer. "It's why you hate her. I knew you were jealous but...

Rio deflated, glad of the solid presence behind her that meant she wouldn’t collapse, at least not physically.

“You could have a life with someone so much easier than me. Someone who isn’t-…”

“I want you!” Rio shouted suddenly, exploded where she stood, her hands flying up as if catapulted by her cry. “I love you! I would take hard and painful over anything anyone else could give me because it would be with you!”

“You are.”

Rio nodded and cleared her throat quietly, “It’s a big step.”

Agatha was looking at her now, a slight frown on her face, “But I want to take it. I want the world to know you’re-…”

“Agatha, are you coming out just for me?”

Agatha swallowed said nothing. She closed the door and turned away and Rio moved slowly around the island, “The past few days… Agatha I’ve noticed the change in you.”

Agatha had lived her life in fear and misery, with only Nicky for light. Then Rio had stepped in, and perhaps the light had shone brighter, but creatures used the the dark cower back into it - and Agatha had done just that.

Only without Rio, the dark had soon become less a comfort and more a curse. And now Agatha was raging against it, but in a quiet, soft way. She was no longer screaming. She was digging in, making a home, making plans, so if Rio ever turned back, she’d be ready for her.

It would have been so easy to collapse into her, to give in.

But she didn’t, at least not yet.

You had that pink shirt and those cowboy boots… your hair was,” she gestured vaguely, “all wild and… and I just, I went back to see it three more times.”

The spell broken as Agatha twisted her hand and the stone disappeared.

Rio looked up and Agatha was chewing on her lip, seemingly lost in thought as the grilled cheese flipped.

“That was a bad movie.”

Rio smiled a little and Agatha looked round at her, her own soft smile on her face.

“You saw it four times?”

“And a million more whenever I closed my eyes.”

Blue eyes dropped a few inches to Rio’s grinning mouth and Rio stepped a little closer. “I was a teenager with a raging crush and then… then a twenty-something, with a raging crush, and then I met you and… you became real… and…” she reached out and touched Agatha’s arm, “then I guess I just kept falling.”

Rio raised her brows and was about to answer when the smell of burning filled her nostrils and they both turned as Agatha lifted the pan off the heat and cursed softly.

“It’s okay,” Rio reassured as she went to grab a plate. “I like it a little crispy.”

In the cupboard she noticed the pile of plates was severely lacking and a voice filtered into her conscious as she fished one out: “She’s smashed plates and yelled herself hoarse and couldn’t even keep it together when Nicky came to see.”

She cleared her throat and made her way back over to Agatha with the plate.

She knew she’d have to ask.

But maybe it would be easier once they’d both had a bite to eat.

“We’re sharing this, by the way.”

Agatha scoffed but Rio raised her brows and didn’t move an inch as she stared her down. Agatha eyed her for a moment after placing the sandwich on the plate and put the pan back on the side. “You think you can intimidate me?”

“I think you want to share this grilled cheese with me.”

Agatha scoffed again, her jaw flexing, but then she nodded, a tiny, infinitesimal movement but enough to make Rio turn, seek out a knife, and take a seat at the island where Agatha moved to sit beside her.

“I made it for you.”

“Well it’s nice to share.”

“It’s hot, Agatha,” Rio prompted.

Agatha whimpered and then hissed and it looked like it took a lot for her to just swallow down the mouthful of molten cheese. When she managed it Rio smiled and slipped from her seat to fetch her wine and bring it over to her.

“Serves you right for being so stubborn.”

“Thank you,” Agatha whispered as she accepted her glass and took two big gulps. “It’s your grilled cheese.”

Rio said nothing as she gingerly peeled the pieces of bread apart and watched the steam rise. She just stared at it for a while, allowing Agatha to watch her in the process.

Despite everything, despite finally getting some answers and some she certainly didn’t like, her body felt calm now. She was in a familiar place, with her familiar person.

Agatha was her person. She’d found her through the screen, and then after a show, across rooms, in this very home. She’d continue to find her through lifetimes and into eternity.

Agatha didn’t reel back again, she instead chewed quickly, and watched Rio as she turned the sandwich towards herself and took a bite that overlapped Agatha’s.

Agatha took the bite, having each time, before Rio even turned the sandwich to her, opened her mouth as an offering.

And this time, with little bread or cheese to play with, she accepted the tips of Rio’s warm fingers between her lips too. She let Agatha suck a little, met her darkening gaze as she did, and then pulled her hand away so Agatha could swallow, and so Rio could breathe.

“We shouldn’t do that,” she whispered quietly, watching Agatha part her lips and lick the grease from them. “It’s a bad idea.”

“Stay tonight,” Agatha responded, reaching out to hold Rio’s arm, “Stay. Please.”

Rio couldn’t say no, didn’t want to say no, so instead she just picked up the second half of their now shared sandwich and held it out to Agatha again.

Agatha hesitated, looked to Rio, seemed to weigh something up, and then her mouth fell open once more. Only this time she didn’t lean in. Rio leant into her.

They were silent until the sandwich was gone but this time Rio made sure she got the last bite. As she chewed, Agatha watched her, she leant closer, she touched her leg, “Stay. Please, my love.”

Rio cleared her throat quietly, feeling her mouth suddenly go dry despite the excess amount of butter and cheese she’d just consumed. “I shouldn’t.”

“You don’t want me?”

Rio sighed and closed her eyes, feeling the journey of soft fingers as they crept up to her hips and twisted themselves around her belt hoop.

She needed to be able to think again, needed a distraction from the thoughts of Agatha’s willing mouth and her grabbing hands.

Agatha looked confused and then, and then… her face relaxed, she looked calm, and her lips even twitched just a little as Rio saw the exact moment she settled on the secret she would give.

“I like to stand on your right side. Because I like to hold you with my left hand. Because holding you feels important. It often feels like the most important thing I'll do all day.”

As far as Rio Vidal was concerned, you could burn your roses, you could crush your diamonds, you could rip up your sonnets, because this, Agatha believing that holding her was important, so much so that she consciously stood so she could hold her the way she wanted, in her left hand, her dominant hand, was the most romantic thing anyone had ever said to her.

“Rio?”

“I… yeah…” Rio cleared her throat, unsure whether or not it was good to know this as her thoughts flew back to Agatha’s fingers as they twitched where they still held her. Agatha’s gaze flitted down to Rio’s lips and back up again.

“What else? What else do you want to know?”

She had to dive back in or she’d give in to a warm mouth and talented hands.

“Are you still angry? With yourself, I mean?”

“Yes.”

Chapter 37: Interlude: London

Chapter Summary

A snapshot from Agatha’s POV from leaving the restaurant in London to… realising what she’s done.

Chapter Notes

WARNING: some of the content in this chapter might be upsetting to people so please read only if you feel up to it.

Agatha has sex with Ralph and whilst everything that happens is technically consensual, it is not pleasant - definitely not for Agatha and maybe not for the reader.

If you choose not to read a tl;dr is just Agatha’s spiralling the night she leaves Rio on her knees.

See the end of the chapter for more notes
