She needed it desperately. Her one chance, her one chance of ever hearing it from such perfect lips, from such a perfect woman. Because she’d never hear it again, not when Rio realised how cowardly she was, how twisted and broken she was.

And then Rio said it, plainly, easily, as if Agatha hadn’t asked for anything hard or complicated.

Agatha realised then just how bad she truly was. Her mother had been right all along. She didn’t deserve the goodness she’d been siphoning out of Rio. She didn’t deserve her care or her tenderness.

She didn’t deserve her love.

“I love you. I’m in love with you.”

Agatha sucked it in, let the words disseminate in her body, filtering down to her ungrateful heart. She closed her eyes and felt Rio lean up, and try to tug at her, whispering her name, and making Agatha gasp in shock at the sudden pain of it all.

But she deserved it.

She deserved the pain that came from making Rio love her, making her say it.

She was still holding Rio, her left hand still curled softly around Rio’s chin, her other moving to hold Rio’s arm, just to anchor herself. Just to feel something that wasn’t this exquisite hurt that thrummed from deep in her bones.

“I need to get back,” she managed to get out, dropping her hands and blinking shamefully down at the woman still on her knees for her.

“Just stay a little longer.”

“Nicky’s alone. I need to get back to him.”

Rio was nodding and Agatha flexed her jaw as she turned to leave but she stopped when she heard Rio again: “It hurts. It hurts to see you with Ralph. To not be able to-… it hurts.”

Agatha turned to look and felt the sting of it all again, felt the desire once more to scream, to rage, to throw herself into things just to feel the physical hurt of it.

Punishment.

She needed punishment.

But Rio was pulling her down now and Agatha couldn’t find it in herself to stop her. She was pulled into her lap and Agatha’s hands moved of their own accord to Rio’s hair, and there they remained, softer than before, purposefully softer than before.

This had to be it.

She had to end it. She had to let Rio go.

But her body wouldn’t let her, at least, not yet.

She wrapped herself around Rio, watched the subtle movements of her face, brushed her thumbs carefully over her skin.

The woman she’d loved for all these years, had given herself completely to her, and yet… and yet… she couldn’t give herself back.

A tear fell from her eyes and Rio reached to take it but she couldn’t allow it anymore. She had to stop the softness. So she pulled back, undeserving.

She stood and stumbled as she did.

“I need to go.”

She didn’t look back around as she left.

On the journey back to her room she let her anger grow. She let it grow until it consumed her and punishment was all she could think about. She needed to purge herself of the voice that sounded a lot like Rio’s that told her she could be good enough, that she was good enough.

Because she knew she wasn’t. She never would be.

When she managed to get back to her suite she went straight to check in on her son.

Nicky was tucked up comfortably where she left him, his fist thrown above his head, his hair splayed out behind him on the pillow, his lashes fluttering with the cadence of his dreams. He was precious, untouched by the bad Agatha had inside of her. And as she watched him she hoped something Lilia had said to her long ago were true: that children are made from love above all else.

And the only person she loved other than her son was the woman she’d just left on her knees in the dark.

How long she stood in the door watching Nicky she didn’t know, but the spell of peace was broken when a firm smack jerked her to her senses and she turned around into Ralph’s grinning form. His large hands were behind her and grabbing the ass he’d just smacked. He smelt like whisky and wine and Agatha tried not to recoil when she felt the press of him against her thigh.

Everything with Ralph was aggressive even when he was being slow, and she grimaced when he slurred down at her, “trying to romance you, Agatha. Can’t a husband expect romance once in a while?”

He leant in and the stink of his breath became almost overwhelming and Agatha would have pushed him away, she would have called him a pig and marched off to her room but she wanted to try, to try once more to be the woman she’d been before Rio had shown her a way out.

She wanted to hide again.

So she hid.

She hid in the punishment that would be sleeping with her husband.

She hid in Ralph’s mouth, with his aggressive tongue, she hid in his too-large hands that groped as they stumbled together to Ralph’s bedroom. Nothing felt right, nothing felt good.

But hiding was good. Hiding would keep her and Nicky safe. Safe from heartache and safe from longing.

She was on top of Ralph now, had angled her body away from his erect penis, unwilling to be near it for longer than absolutely necessary. But Ralph was insistent, as always, he rolled them over and landed on her hair but didn’t apologise for it.

She strained beneath him, trying to remain silent with Nicky just at the other side of the suite. She suddenly wanted this done, this whole thing to be over. But the word ‘no’ died in her throat as Ralph’s wet mouth hit her now bare abdomen.

He was so close to where Rio had just been, so grossly different, that it shocked Agatha back into her body. It made her strain and tug until Ralph was back up over her and his tongue was attacking her mouth.

She reached down between them and fumbled with his belt and then his zipper and then, when his boxers and pants had been hurriedly thrust down his thighs, he began to thrust against her, uncaring about her expensive jeans that would now have to be incinerated for being tainted so.

“Condom,” she managed to insist, “Ralph.”

He grunted and threw himself from her and left alone on the bed Agatha stared up at the ceiling.

She deserved this. She had to take it. This was the life she’d chosen. The one where Rio loving her was a fantasy. One she had to free Rio from.

So when Ralph came back, she didn’t say no.

In her frenzy she managed to get her hips up, to push her pants down, and Ralph didn’t wait much longer than that.

It hurt. It always, always hurt.

Even how ready she’d been for Rio, how desperately she’d have taken anything she would give her, with Ralph she couldn’t relax. It was like her body just outright refused him, denied him, hated him.

“Fuck.”

His hot breath was against her cheek, one of his hands back where it tugged at her hair on the pillow, and he continued to thrust, heavy, desperate jabs inside of her. The discomfort was familiar and therefore almost comfortable.

But the last time she’d had sex with Ralph, well over a year ago now, she’d had nothing to compare it to, it had just been something she’d done every so often, as infrequent as she could make it, just to shut him up, just to uphold the name of ‘wife’.

But now Rio had touched her. Rio had shown her what desire was. She’d set a fire alight in her that burned even when she wasn’t around because Agatha was always thinking of her, and therefore always desiring her.

Ralph grunted and Agatha couldn’t hold back her grimace. She just lay still, allowed it to happen, thought of Rio and how she’d left her. Thought of the way she’d looked up at her with those big eyes she sometimes lost herself in. The eyes that she wanted to drown herself in.

But Ralph was still moving on top of her, and Agatha realised that the man who took a while to come would take even longer because he was drunk. He was grunting with every thrust, his large body fit but inflexible, every movement was like trying to pilot a barge into a marina.

Ralph adjusted and yanked at her hair and though it was accidental Agatha grit her teeth and pulled her head aside. She managed to free her hair before she settled back.

Ralph was grunting more now, making deep noises of exertion or maybe pleasure - Agatha had never cared enough to figure it out. But he was getting louder and Nicky was close so Agatha spoke for the second time since she’d left Rio.

“Shut up. Nicky’s here. Shut. Up.”

She slapped his shoulder to get his attention and Ralph cursed as he stopped, “Kiss me. Be my wife. Kiss me.”

He was hot above her. He was sweaty in a clammy way. He stank of the alcohol he’d consumed and the cologne he doused himself in everyday. He was everything Rio wasn’t. Rio was warm rather than hot. If she was ever sweaty it was sticky and enticing rather than damp and slimy. She always smelled vaguely of bergamot, rose, patchouli from her perfume. Agatha could still smell her on the shirt she’d stolen from her and she thought of it now, hidden under her pillow in the next room.

And Rio was sensitive to what Agatha needed, willing to give her anything even before she asked for it.

The fury that had fired in her chest before fired again, fired so bright she couldn’t see, all she could feel was the badness she’d been born with.

So she kissed her husband. But it was more an attack than an actual kiss. She attacked him with a ferocity that had their teeth clashing and her hands tugging so aggressively at his hair that his hips stuttered.

She hated him. Hated him being above her, inside her. Hated that she’d allowed it. That she was married to him.

Because Ralph had a response from Agatha, for the first time since one time almost eight years ago, Agatha had done more than just lie there, Ralph came faster than usual. Though he’d still taken his time. He came with a groan into Agatha’s open mouth, and Agatha could have cried for the protective latex barrier that stopped him spilling himself inside of her.

Thank god she’d stopped him before he’d put one on. Thank god she’d insisted. Thank god. Thank god. Thank god.

Ralph went limp above her but hadn’t had the decency to pull out.

Agatha started to slap him, turning her face completely away from his large head now buried in her hair. He pulled away, manoeuvring his large form away from her until he collapsed onto his back beside her, once again landing in her hair.

She rolled over and freed herself and silently left the room after tugging her underwear and pants up. She was sore between her thighs and aching all over, but she moved with the speed of a woman with no aches either of body or heart.

She went through to check on Nicky. He was asleep in the same position as before, his mouth now open as he dreamt.

She closed his door again, softly, as quietly as she could.

After that, she went to shower and turned the dial on the temperature all the way down, then up, then down, then up again, and so on and on and on until she physically couldn’t take it anymore. She wanted to purge her body of the feel of Ralph and found that wasn’t difficult.

What was more difficult, what was impossible, was ridding herself of Rio’s touch.

Neither the shock of cold nor the scald of hot could help her to rid it from her skin. Every inch of her that Rio had ever touched, ever caressed, ever worshipped, now belonged to the woman she’d left in the dark.

Rio Vidal had somehow tattooed herself all over Agatha’s body.

But more than that, she was woven into the material of her soul. And knowing that now, knowing that she’d done the bad thing, the worst thing, there was nothing to do but collapse onto the floor of the shower.

Her knees hit the hard tile harder than she meant them to. The pain ricocheted through her body, sending waves of agony through her that piled up until her eyes streamed and her head hung low.

She placed her fingertips shoulder width apart on the wall and kept her head down. It was quiet now, almost silent in the en-suite bathroom connected to her room. The only sound was her shallow breathing and the steady drip, drip of the water from her hair into the shallow pool around her knees.

It hurt. Everything hurt.

Rio was a good thing, a solid thing, a perfect thing.

Agatha had met her once, fallen in love, and then built her up in her head so much that the real Rio Vidal couldn’t possibly compete. And then it turned out she did. She was everything Agatha had fantasied she would be, everything she’d dreamed she’d be, but more than that.

Because in none of Agatha’s fantasises or dreams had she allowed herself to imagine that Rio might love her, might be in love with her. The magic woman she’d met in the bathroom eight years ago in her fantasies was into her, was willing for her, maybe cared for her, but never loved her.

Love from a woman like Rio was something she hadn’t believed she could ever expect.

Only Rio, the real Rio, she gave it so easily. She was always warm, always happy to see her, always so good. And all Agatha did was take. She siphoned all that goodness, all that love out of her. Unable, or unwilling, to give it back. Because she was a coward.

And now she’d done the most cowardly thing she could think to do. She’d run back to the arms of the husband she hated because being with him was easier than the vulnerability of opening herself up to Rio, of telling her everything she felt.

Every second of every day was laced with the love she had for her.

She saw it in her son as he grinned his big-toothed grin at her.

She saw it in the sight of her own hands, the hands that didn’t touch anyone with any care or tenderness unless it were Rio, or her son.

She saw it in the way Rio looked at her.

She’d punished herself in the worst way possible.

Because only now did she realise, did she understand that losing Rio was the one true punishment. The one she couldn’t bear.

Rio was all she wanted. Just Rio. Just good, perfect, Rio.

In the solace of the bathroom, dripping wet and shivering, Agatha Harkness made a choice; she chose Rio. She chose the fear that Rio might never forgive her for what she’d done. She chose that one day, Rio might turn to her and tell her she was too much, or not enough. She chose to be left desolate and broken if Rio ever left her.

Only now she feared it was much too late.

Rio would never forgive her for what she’d done and Agatha would never forgive herself.

But she chose to be brave. She had to call her lawyer. She had to tell Rio.

Chapter End Notes

For those not on Twitter: I said before that Ralph is basically Clark Kent but I’ve finally found MY Ralph and it’s Chris Carmack but basically any tall, handsome, blue eyed man will do

aaaaanyway are we all looking forward to Christmas Day?

Chapter 38: Thirteenth Station

Chapter Summary

Rio loses something precious.

Chapter Notes

MERRY CHRISTMAS

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“Rio.”

A gentle hand shook the sleeping woman, tentative at first, then gradually growing in insistence.

“Babe. You gotta wake up for me.”

Rio groaned quietly, too tired to realise that she’d gone to bed alone so waking up to someone in her room should have been a surprise. She slapped at the hand that shook her, tugged at her blankets, kept her eyes closed.

Her body had been ravaged, her mind still trying to soothe itself down from the intensity of the talk she’d had with Agatha only hours before.

“Despierta. Por favor.” Wake up. Please.

Rio screwed her eyes tighter shut, scowling as she began to slowly wake, the shaking not abating and the Spanish alerting something in her brain that English could not.

“Rio, it’s your dad. Please.”

And Rio’s eyes opened only to find something she wished she could unsee. Because she’d never seen that look before on Alice’s face but she knew immediately what it meant.

“No,” she said more firmly than she expected to. And Alice didn’t flinch, didn’t pull back from her, just continued to watch her with that same stricken expression.

“No, don’t. Not-…”

“Rio, he died about an hour ago.”

Miguel Vidal had died four hours after he’d hung up from his daughter. He’d crawled back into bed with a smile on his face and told his wife that Rio was to be okay. And if he weren’t mistaken, that they would someday soon have a daughter-in-law and a grandson.

He’d died at peace.

Rio Elena Vidal had been born in the spring, the miracle baby to a couple who desperately wanted her. She’d been brought up knowing she was loved and in knowing that, she’d had endless confidence as she was sent out into the world to become her own woman.

Even in her teens she was close to her parents. When she shouted at her mom she would return to her, crying and sorry for what she’d said. When she was short with her dad, she’d apologise within minutes for upsetting him.

And they, equally, couldn’t be mad long at her.

Anna Vidal was careful, discerning, a perfect wife and a perfect mother. Miguel Vidal was less careful, more joyous, and louder in his happiness. And that was just it, they were happy.

They loved each other no more or no less than any other happy family.

The Vidals weren’t special but they were lucky; not every family is a happy one.

And so just as they had all once been happy, Rio Elena Vidal was now broken.

She’d called her mom after crying in Alice’s arms and found out that her dad had died peacefully in his sleep of a suspected heart attack. It was a cruel trick from a cruel universe to take the man who loved so well by making the very engine of his greatest gift the very thing that took him from those he so generously bestowed it upon.

She took the first flight she could get to Delaware with her manager who’d packed for her as Rio threw on some clothes and tried to make her body move even when she felt she couldn’t.

Alice made calls to the studio to tell them Rio wouldn’t be showing up to work. They were generous in their response: they gave her three days.

Rio hadn’t responded to this news at all and Alice hadn’t tried to make any conversation other than to comment on the gate they were to wait at or the fact that she’d arranged a car to take them straight to her mom’s house when they landed.

No paparazzi found them. Fans who spotted Rio were respectful enough to see a mourning woman when they saw one so stayed away.

All Rio could think about was her mom all alone in the little house discovering her dad, being alone when she’d called the ambulance, being alone when she’d tried to call Rio and alone when she had to contact Alice instead.

Because that was devastating, but thoughts of her father being gone were simply unbearable.

It took a little over seven hours all in to get to her childhood home: a neat little four bed, two bath. And when she was there she saw the cars of the people she knew to be her aunts and cousins. Her mom at least wasn’t alone now.

When she stepped over the threshold she smelt cooking, heard the familiar sounds of her family squawking and squabbling and the confusing jibberish that was produced when native Spanish speakers spoke to native English speakers.

Her littlest cousin able to walk was the first to greet her - a little girl of two whom she lifted and cuddled close as she walked further in to find her mom.

Hands found her, soft whispers in Spanish were graced upon her, but she held it together until she found the woman who shared her grief. Anna Vidal was where she expected her to be. She was by the stove, her eyes on whatever was bubbling away in the pan, her face pale, tired, and drawn.

“Mamá?”

Rio placed her cousin down as her mom turned to her and Anna Vidal for the first time that day began to sob. Rio gathered her mother in her arms and held her through it, unable to contain her own tears as she cried for a loss too great to bear alone.

The two women by the stove were soon piled upon by other soothing hands and Rio and Anna were carried through the next three days with the steadfast comfort of their family. They were neither left alone for longer than five minutes, neither allowed to do more than they wanted to, and neither left without a hand holding their own.

Rio remained in her childhood home until she had to leave. Alice had booked her the latest possible flight back to Los Angeles and held her hand all the way home.

Alice held her hand in bed that night and in the car to set the next morning and she only released it when, at Rio’s request, she left her at the door to the hair and makeup trailer to enter alone.

The bright lights and the soft music reminded Rio of a time when she had been happy. A time when she would sing along to make her hair stylist laugh, a time when her dad was alive.

But her reminiscing lasted only in the seconds it took for hands to be on her from seemingly all directions. The make up and hair styling team all downed tools and abandoned their charges to get to her. And Rio was held together by expert hands as she swallowed down her tears and said: “Really, guys. Did you miss me that much?”

But the joke didn’t really land. Lips and hands found her cheeks and Rio allowed the soft murmurings of whispered condolences to wash over her as she was directed to her seat at the end of the trailer.

But someone was in the way of that.

Agatha was there, stood tall amongst the others, her blue eyes shining and bright where Rio’s brown ones felt dull and lifeless.

It would have been so easy to fall into her. It would have been so easy to give herself to Agatha, to ask her to carry her, to carry the pain of it. But she couldn’t do that. Giving herself over to her would mean admitting it, letting the world know exactly how broken Rio Vidal now was.

So she stepped around her, she allowed her middle and forefingers to graze the soft skin of Agatha’s left wrist, and then she pulled away and took her usual seat with Brett hovering behind her.

Through the mirror she looked up to Agatha and saw that she looked so hurt by her avoidance but she forced a small smile, she nodded once, and she took her seat back just feet from Rio.

Th past few days with her mom, Rio had been neck deep in funeral arrangements, in making sure her mom was comfortable with her paying for everything, was comfortable with Rio having to leave again before the weekend, was comfortable in the house where her husband had died.

She’d been surrounded by people constantly. She’d been in enveloped in the arms of her family and yet she’d only wanted one person throughout it all.

Alice had told her every day how often Agatha had called.

“Every hour, Rio.” / “Five times this morning, six this afternoon.” / “Rio, she’s not stopping, please can you take her call.”

But Rio could never face it.

She wanted Agatha there through it all but she’d been unable to have her. She couldn’t explain it to herself. Perhaps it was simply that the last conversation she’d had with her dad had been about her hopes for the future; how she’d hoped Agatha would be a big part of it, her whole future.

And now he was gone, and the shred of hope she’d had for her and Agatha had disappeared with him.

Brett tried his best with her. He spoke and laughed and joked but eventually he went silent. Rio just stared straight ahead. She just stared into her own eyes and willed the time to go faster so she didn’t have to be around so many people, so she didn’t have to be seen by them.

Good old Brett must have known she needed that too because he was quick with his work. Rio was done within an hour. Her face had been painted to not look so pale and her hair had been teased to give it life where it had been hanging limply before.

She thanked him quietly, accepted the hug he gave her, and then she made strides to leave. Only, she’d been held back. Agatha had held her back. Agatha had turned in her seat and taken hold of her arm as she’d tried to step past.

“Lamento much tu pérdida.” I am so sorry for your loss.

Rio could only stop, could only look at her for a second before she had to turn, she had to leave. She left the trailer and went straight to costume where Frankie and Stevie had already been warned by Alice to not try.

They hugged her silently, dressed her the same, and let her go without gushing to her about how horrid they felt for her. It was better that way, it made it easier to get through the day.

Rio arrived on set early, she took her sides and went to read them quietly in the corner whilst she waited on everyone else. She hadn’t learnt her lines. She didn’t know what scene they were running.

She just knew she had to be there, rather than in Delaware.

Alice soon found her again and quietly handed her a coffee, quietly held her hand until she was called to shoot. Agatha was in the scene, a kitchen setting, a scene where Rio really just had to smile, had to react rather than act, and at one point had to drape herself around Agatha from where she would be perched on the countertop.

They ran through shots, checked marks, waited for lighting and camera to be ready, for last minute touch ups, and then Rio took her spot. She watched as Agatha took hers too, watched as she looked up at her just before Maria called for action, and felt the soft pull of blue eyes across the small set.

“Action!”

Rio let it happen around her, she straightened her back, drank her coffee, leaned with the nonchalance of a happily married woman who had a father who wasn’t dead.

The actors moved around, said their lines, and Rio reacted where she had to, moving for the first time properly only when Agatha was in front of her, when she had to cup her cheek and grin at her faux-pouting face and say: “So bossy, my love.”

Agatha, as Kate, rolled her eyes and then turned and slumped back between Rio’s legs as she remained on the corner counter.

Rio dropped her arm about Agatha, holding her over her chest as Agatha’s hands held her arm. It was a move Rio had had to discuss alone with Pepper, one she hadn’t much thought about at the time. But now it was the most intimate she’d been with Agatha since the before times. Since before Miguel had left her.

And it hurt like hell.

Agatha was drawing soft patterns on her forearm that Rio just knew weren’t character-driven. They were for her, and her alone. And Rio rested the side of her jaw against Agatha’s head as the scene went on, as Agatha acted with the others and Rio just had to be there, just had to play the role of ‘wife’.

When “cut” was called and Maria came in with notes for Billy, Agatha turned slowly in her hold and the hands that had once been on her arm were now settled behind Rio as Agatha loosely held her around her middle.

“Are you okay? I’ve been trying to-…”

“I know, I-… I couldn’t. I just couldn’t.”

“Okay,” Agatha said quietly, nodding as Rio closed her eyes and tried to not let the tears break free. “Rio, is there anything-…?”

“Agatha?”

Maria’s voice cut through the moment and Rio opened her eyes in time to see Agatha turn around and look at Maria. She felt Agatha become stiff against her, felt her now suddenly so different to the Agatha who had just been gazing up at her.

But then she was turning back, then she was soft again and she asked, “I’ll be one sec, okay?”

Rio nodded, watched Agatha leave her, and closed her eyes again.

She had a job to do, two days to get through, and then she could be home again. Then she could be with her mom and her cousins. Then she could mourn properly.

Agatha was back before she knew it, and she only knew it because her arms were around her again and Agatha was whispering, “I’m here. I’m back.”

Rio sighed as she placed her hands gently on Agatha’s arms and in the firmest voice she could muster she said: “Please don’t. I need to get through this, Agatha. Just two days and then… If I fall into you I won’t be able to-…”

She didn’t finish. But Agatha didn’t need her too.

She nodded, she looked devastated, but then she turned around again.

Agatha didn’t try to talk to her again after that. Her fingers, whenever they could, found their way back to her in the scene. But she remained what Rio could only describe as professional, but not detached.

It was as if she were giving Rio exactly what she’d just asked for but letting her know she was there still in the soft patterns against her skin, in the hovering close even when she had moved away to talk to Maria.

In a pause between filming Lilia had tried to move over but Agatha had intercepted. Rio caught the look in Lilia’s dark gaze as Agatha physically moved between them and she knew Lilia knew what Agatha had done for her.

Agatha became a guard dog and a soft place to land all in one.

Everyone else left Rio alone and Rio wondered if Alice had been spreading the not-so-subtle word too. Even Jen kept her distance until after the call was made for Rio to be able to leave for an early lunch and as she stepped off set with Alice she heard a quiet voice calling her name.

“Hey, I wanted to say, just how sorry I am. I know, I mean, I only met him briefly but… Agatha always spoke so highly of him.”

Rio could only nod, her body and brain now too numb to it to even feel the sting of her dad and Agatha being mentioned in one sentence.

She managed a smile in Jen’s direction and then left with Alice.

“Just this afternoon, then tomorrow,” Alice reminded quietly, holding Rio’s arm all the way back to her trailer. “Flight’s at eight tomorrow night.”

Rio said nothing as she stripped from her costume in the middle of the living space, left Alice to hang it up, and then went to crawl into her bed. She curled in on herself, and simply stared at the wall ahead of her.

Alice would come fetch her when she was needed but until then, Rio could just wallow. She could just think of her dad and everything he’d done for her over the years. She thought of his booming laugh that came out only when it was her who’d told a joke. She thought of his rough hands and how they always squeezed her hand whenever she needed it, before she needed it, when she was nervous or frightened, or worried.

She thought of his wink. Of his ancient polo shirts that had lasted through all the years of her life but that he wore as if they were new and expensive.

She thought of how he loved her mom, how he loved her, and then… outside the room she heard a door being knocked, she heard voices, she heard Agatha.

“Rio,” Agatha’s voice, shaky and unsure, sounded through the closed bedroom door. “Honey. I… can I come in? Please?”

Rio sat slowly, rising from where she’d been curled on her side in the bed. Her fingers clutched the thin sheets and she stared at the barrier that hid her from Agatha’s view.

“Please,” Agatha’s voice came again, a slow, sorrowful plea that went unanswered by Rio.

Because she couldn’t answer it. She had to get through this day. Had to finish it without breaking down. And if she allowed Agatha anywhere near her when the cameras weren’t on she’d collapse.

“Agatha.” Rio heard Alice’s voice on the other side, “She just needs to be alone.”

There was a soft noise against the door and Rio wondered if Agatha had placed her hand on it more violently than she meant to, but the reality was she’d rested her forehead against it, unable to leave just yet.

“Por favor, Rio?”

“Agatha.”

Rio looked down at her knees as she listening to Alice ushering Agatha out the trailer.

There was silence for a while and she almost let herself believe that Agatha had let herself be pulled away and then: “Estoy aquí. Siempre estoy aquí si me necesitas.” I’m here. I’m always here if you need me.

Rio raised her hand up to her mouth to muffle the sob that escaped as Alice won the war and she heard the sound of Agatha being led out of the trailer and the door close behind her.

Rio sobbed silently where she sat, for her dad, for the woman who was trying but that she couldn’t allow to hold her.

And then, half an hour later, she had to have her makeup and hair redone, she was back on set, she was doing her job.

Agatha was true to Rio’s request. She didn’t approach again.

Rio was in the background of scenes, doing things in the kitchen or lounging on the sofa. It didn’t help with her thoughts. But it helped that she didn’t have to be near Agatha.

She knew now if she touched her she’d crumble. She was far from the woman who had promised her not days ago that she was strong enough to carry her and her son.

Rio could barely hold herself up.

The next day Alice had managed to get her out of needing to be on set. It was Friday, the day before the funeral, and so they’d taken the early morning flight back to Delaware instead of the one late in the evening.

Rio had spent the day with her mom, walking through everything with her, quietly holding her hand when her usually strong and fiercely independent mom needed her to - which, now, was all the time.

Rio had barely slept during this time, kept alive only through coffee and the small cookies Alice kept slipping her whenever she looked or felt particularly weak. By the time Saturday rolled around Rio held never felt worse in her life.

The night before, her father had been laid out in an open casket but Rio had refused to see him. It had caused an argument in the Vidal family home, the likes of which it hadn’t ever seen before. But Rio held firm, held true to her belief that no good would come from her seeing her beloved papá like that.

She’d crawled into the guest bed with her mom that night and apologised for the fight they’d had. Anna hadn’t been able to sleep in her own bed, given what had happened in the early hours of Monday morning.

It was the first time she’d slept properly, but her mother’s soft apology back, the gentle feel of her hand on her side as she lay beside her, it all helped. It didn’t heal, though, nothing did.

On Saturday morning Rio dressed in a plain black a-line dress. Alice helped her with her hair, which, short as it was, now had a bit of bounce to it thanks to a miracle brush gifted to her years ago by her stylist and Alice’s patience with the hairspray.

She just about managed to endure putting on makeup and a crimson lip, slip on heels, and just before she was about to step from the room Alice had called her back and held up a little bag. “I bought some of your jewellery. Finishing touch?”

Rio acquiesced and stepped closer, allowing Alice to adorn her fingers with a couple rings and put some earrings into the four holes empty in her two ears. But the final piece, the final piece Rio stopped her on. Alice had brought from home the emerald necklace Agatha had bought Rio for Christmas and it took Rio a second of just staring at it before she silently nodded and let Alice drape it around her neck.

She glanced at herself in the mirror then, touching the green jewel reverently before she made her way down the stairs to wrap herself in her warm jacket before she was ushered out to the black car awaiting her and her mom.

They drove in silence, both clutching each other’s hands, both staring straight ahead. If Miguel had been there he’d have found a story to tell to break the tension. But he wasn’t, so the tension endured.

The funeral procession took them to their parish church in downtown Wilmington: St. Paul’s. Rio had grown up in this church, she’d whispered between the pews, hidden behind the tall white columns that lined the long nave, and climbed up to the bell tower to look out over her city.

The priest greeted them as Rio’s eyes followed the coffin as it was hoisted by her uncles and male cousins from the hearse. She heard the condolences but couldn’t respond properly as she stared at the wooden box she’d bought for her dad.

Anna ushered her inside, held her hand in the narthex, and softly whispered to her daughter: “Mi querido, tu papá está aquí contigo. Está aquí con nosotros. De acuerdo?” My precious, your dad is here with you. He is here with us. Okay?

Rio kissed her mom’s cheek and wiped the lipstick she’d left there but had no time to say anything else because the priest was back, the organ was sounding, and they walked in through the double oak doors to the church of Rio’s childhood memory.

She closed her eyes for the first few steps, relied on her mom to guide her for the journey, as she had done so well through her life. The incense and the rousing sound of “Abide With Me” sang in Spanish hit her and filled her with such unnameable nostalgia that she felt the first tear fall before she was even halfway down the aisle.

But they made it to the top and with a lowered head she saw her father’s coffin being presented before the altar.

Rio didn’t take her eyes off of it for the entirety of the Mass. Even as she stood with her cousin Mateo for the readings and held his hand as she bowed to the altar, her eyes strayed back to where her dad’s head would be.

Mateo squeezed her hand.

She made it to the lectern and managed to make out the words before her on the page. They’d chosen to have the Mass given in Spanish and so the Bible before her was a Spanish one, turned to Ecclesiastes. She toyed with the thin ribbon of a bookmark and began to read: “Para todo hay un tiempo oportuno, y todo lo que se quiere debajo del cielo tiene su hora.” For everything there is a season, and a time for every matter under heaven.

She read confidently, because reading that way would make her mom, and her dad, proud. She read even though the tears kept threatening to overspill. But she got through it, through each verse until, “Tiempo de abrazar, y tiempo de abstenerse de abrazar.” A time to embrace, and a time to refrain from embracing.

She’d looked up then, her wide eyes taking in all those who loved her father for the very first time. It was a large church, and the pews were full, so full that even in the aisles off the knave there were full benches of mourners.

But amongst them, in the sea of black, there was a flash of light.

Rio’s lips formed the next words and she heard herself say them: “Tiempo de buscar, y tiempo de perder.” A time to seek, and a time to lose. But all she could really focus on was that Agatha was there, wrapped in a woollen jacket, tucked in one of the very last pews, sandwiched between people she didn’t recognise.

The refracted light from one of the tall stained glass windows had coated Agatha in shifting reds, blues, and golds. Agatha was now half flesh, half luminous narrative.

She looked down again and continued to read, but could think only of the woman who had travelled across the country to sit silently in the back of a cold church just in case she needed her.

Rio finished her reading, felt Mat reach for her hand and squeeze it. She waited by the side until after he was done with his, and then he walked her back to her seat and Rio took her mom’s hand again and she focused in on her dad.

The Ave Maria is where she broke down. Her mom had to hold her through it. Something about the softness of that prayer, a petition to a parent, made the pain surge with the tremendous amount of loss she felt.

She could never speak to her dad again.

A lapsed and mostly (miraculously) guilt free Catholic, Rio didn’t believe in God. But she believed in the goodness in people. She’d grown up with a loving family, had plenty of friends, had felt the touch of women who cared for her, who’d maybe even loved her.

God had only ever really come into the equation much later, much more recently. God was present in a pair of sea blue eyes, in the woman sat below the colour-bleeding window of the thirteenth station of the cross.

The scene that sent its fragments of light over Agatha was of a deity surrendering to human hands; hands of mercy and hands of grace. It was grief rendered into glass, doctrine that had been told for centuries, now shrouding Agatha in its fragments.

Proof of God was in the woman who now sat silently waiting for her, the woman who had been bathed in light, illuminated so Rio had been able to see her. The gold haloed her hair, the royal blues adding dignity where Agatha never lacked, the wine-rich reds caressing her solemn frame. Rio’s grief-stricken mind took her back to her dad, to his words on Agatha, “tal vez seas luz para ella, y ella ha sido incapaz de ver,” perhaps you are light for her, and she has been unable to see.

She cried some more.

When Mass was ended Rio walked with her mom back down the aisle, following her dad who was carried again by her uncles and cousins. On the way out she knew where to look this time and kept her eyes open unlike when she’d first walked in.

Agatha was standing, four rows from the back, two in from the aisle. She looked magnificent as she watched Rio and Anna with a soft frown, the delicate smile on her face making her look fragile even as she stood tall in her expensive coat.

Rio had to look away, had to focus on the next step: a private interment with the priest, and a few members of the family. Everyone else would be ushered back to Anna’s house with Alice, Mateo, and her Tía Elena all in charge of the food, the drinks, the guests.

Alice, dear, on-it, Alice, appeared just as Rio was about to step into the car with her mom.

“Did you see her?”

“Yes. Did you know she was-…?”

“I didn’t think she’d show. She’s been calling and calling. She must have got the details from Jen but-…”

“It’s fine, Alice. I just… it’s fine.”

“Okay,” Alice smiled sadly and pulled Rio down to kiss her cheek, “he’d have been so proud.”

Rio laughed as her eyes filled with tears again. “You know he’d have made a joke about being fancy enough to have an Oscar winner at his funeral.”

“Two, actually.”

Rio smiled and squeezed Alice’s arm, “I’ll see you later.”

“I love you, you know.”

“I know,” Rio said, returning Alice’s earlier kiss with one of her own before she slipped into the car and took her mom’s hand again.

“Yo también la vi.” I saw her too.

Rio glanced at her mom and nodded slowly, looking down at their joined hands. “I didn’t ask her to-…”

“Entonces su presencia aquí significa más que si la hubieras tenido.” Then her being here means more than if you had.

They were silent after that. Rio didn’t know what to say anymore. Her dad would have. Her dad would have known. But now she was on her own. She’d have to know what to say herself or else live in the silence and be okay with it.

Laying her dad to rest was unlike anything Rio had ever imagined. She’d known this day would come, of course. Every child does.

Every child with loving parents dreads this day, has sleepless nights over this day, treasures Christmases and birthdays because they may be the last they get to share with their parents. And there’s some comfort in knowing that parents dying first is how it should be.

It is the natural order of all things.

But it doesn’t make it any easier. And Rio had no way to process how wide and far-reaching this loss was. It trickled into her bloodstream and with every pump of her heart that was so like her father’s it reminded her that he wasn’t here.

By the graveside her family left her and her mom alone to mourn privately for a while, and then Rio left her mom, left her to speak with the man she’d built a life and a family with, and watched from a few feet away as she saw her own grief mirrored tenfold in Anna.

Her mom came back into her arms and Rio cradled the smaller woman close and in doing so, for the first time in their lives, they swapped roles. Rio became the caregiver, the protector of her mom’s heart and her grief.

They held each other until their tears ran dry.

Now there was nothing else to do but to go back to their home, Anna’s only, and Rio’s childhood, and speak with everyone who was there to wish them well in their hour of need.

Rio stepped from the funeral car and looked up at the busy little house in the quiet street. She could feel the vibrations from the overflow of the guests huddled in there for warmth and comfort on the early Spring day.

Anna pushed the door open first and could barely squeeze in which meant the taller Rio really stood not much chance at all but they both made it. The guests of honour couldn’t possibly left to grieve alone in the cold.

Rio blindly thanked everyone for their condolences and as she slowly pushed her way through to the living room she found who she was looking for. It was clear that Anna and Rio were no longer the main attraction.

Standing by the fireplace, holding a glass of white wine and looking a bit perplexed was a movie star. She wore a black suit with a high collared, crisp white shirt. Prada, if Rio were to guess. Her hair was loose and wavy but swept over one shoulder to show off her tight jawline and the gold, square earrings hanging from her ear.

But Rio’s eyes had been drawn to something else. Something that surprised her but didn’t shock her. She was wearing her fake engagement ring again.

She looked up and saw lips form her name but she just stood still, unable to approach or do anything other. So Agatha came to her. She watched as she gave her wine to one of Rio’s cousin’s who’d been hanging off her every word, saw as she slipped through the group that had gathered around her, and blinked as she stopped just before her.

“You shouldn’t have come.”

Agatha’s face fell instantly and Rio closed her eyes for a second as she felt her touch her hand, “I… Rio, I just wanted…”

Rio breathed out and looked down between them at the hand that held hers and carried the ring. It blinked apathetically up at her, oblivious to the dull ache it caused in Rio’s chest.

“I’m sorry,” Agatha murmured softly, “I shouldn’t have worn it.”

She must have seen Rio staring at it, staring at it still. And as Agatha moved to remove the ring Rio reached for her hand to stop her. “No. Don’t. It’s fine.”

She looked up again, and then around at the crowd making the small living room seem even smaller. Everyone was looking at Agatha but Agatha only had eyes for Rio.

“Come with me.”

She turned from Agatha, trusted she’d follow, and after some squeezing and pushing she made it to the stairs in the hall.

The walk up to her bedroom felt endless. She could hear the whispers of her family and her dad’s friends as they left them all to stop and stare at Miguel Vidal’s daughter and her friend, Agatha Harkness, as they climbed the stairs to the first floor of the little house.

Rio led Agatha silently to her bedroom and left the door open for her to follow her in, hoping she would without much protest.

The room was the smallest in the house, because Rio always liked cosiness much more than she liked space - even as a child. She had her medals and trophies lined up on the shelves along the wall, a small wardrobe in the corner at the end of the little twin bed, and a desk just about squeezed in between the bed and the opposite wall. That was all she needed. She’d lived in this room from zero to eighteen, and now any time she came back home.

She took a seat on the end of her twin bed and waited until Agatha had closed the door behind herself to speak.

“How did you know where to come?”

“Alice told Jen.”

Rio nodded silently, staring down at her hands in her lap. Agatha hadn’t moved, not yet anyway, she just stood by the door.

“I sent flowers to your mom but I, uh, I didn’t know what to get you.”

“I don’t need-…” but Rio had looked up at the wrong time because Agatha was pulling from her breast pocket something familiar, something thin and neatly folded. She held it out and Rio’s eyes began to stream at the sight of her old favourite shirt, held in a shaking pale hand.

“I took this from you. I… knew it was your favourite. I needed, I… there’s no excuse. I just wanted to feel you with me when you weren’t there and I was too ashamed of that to ask. I want you to have it back in… the hopes that it’ll bring you some comfort.”

Rio bit down on her lip and tore her gaze away from the little cowboy throwing his lasso across the lapel. This shirt had once been evidence of Agatha’s love for her and now, now perhaps it was that again.

“I can’t… Agatha I can’t…”

“I know. I’m not here for any reason other than to make sure you’re okay.”

Rio pressed the heels of her hands into her face, her throat felt tight, like she couldn’t breathe or like she’d forgotten how to, but she could still smell Agatha’s floral perfume, and that was enough for her to want to try to breathe.

“I’ll leave if you ask me to. I just needed to make sure you were okay.”

Rio released a slow breath, unashamed of its depth as it shook. She slowly moved her hands from her eyes and wiped at them quickly, sniffing as she did. “You shouldn’t have come.”

“I’m sorry.”

“No don’t… don’t say you’re sorry just…”

And Rio made the mistake of looking up. Agatha was standing before her, standing just in front of her childhood desk, wearing her perfectly tailored Prada suit, her eyes soft and her face open.

“I can’t… I can’t deal with… with what’s going on with us right now.”

“I know.”

“Agatha, I mean it. I mean-…”

“Rio, I know. I’m here to make sure you’re okay. I’m not expecting anything or hoping anything. I just…” and Agatha took in a slow breath, her pale fingers reaching behind her to touch the small desk. “I just wanted to see you and let you know that I was here for you. If… if you need me. I’m here for you, not for us.”

Rio shook her head, forcing herself to look away from the person she needed most. “You should have called. I’d have told you to-…”

“I did call. Several times.”

Rio shook her head again, “I… fuck, I haven’t been on my phone. I couldn’t face it.”

“I know.”

Rio groaned and went to sit on the edge of her bed, “You should have called Alice.”

“I did.”

Rio dropped her gaze to the floor and cleared her throat, “Fuck. Right, she told me as I was leaving the church.”

“She told me not to come.”

Rio released an exhale somewhere between a laugh and a scoff and she dared to glance up again, “I’m assuming Jen did too?”

“Yes.”

Rio bit down on her lip as she kept her eyes on Agatha, watching the way she stood so still as if she moved she might frighten Rio away. She kept her gaze on her for a few seconds before she motioned to the space beside her on the small twin bed.

Agatha moved over without saying anything and sat about a foot away from Rio. The bed creaked as Rio remained frozen in place.

“I liked him a lot,” Agatha said after a few seconds of silence. “He was kind and good with Nicky.”

“Thanks,” Rio said quietly, frowning down at her hands in her lap. “He was the best of us.”

Agatha didn’t say anything for a while and Rio closed her eyes to try and focus on something that wasn’t the immense feeling of loss in her chest. “Are you leaving tonight?”

“In the morning. I couldn’t get a flight tonight.”

Rio nodded blindly, her fingers twisting and twisting in her lap until a gentle hand on them made them still. “I made you something.”

Rio turned slowly, her fingers adjusting to hold Agatha’s hand before she could stop them. Between devastation and softness she looked at Agatha’s face and wanted to cry for her being here suddenly.

“What?”

“I…” moving her free hand to the inner pocket of her jacket again she produced a scrunched up piece of paper. It was light green and looked like nothing at all. But she held it out like it was precious, like she was proud of it. “The flower, remember? I couldn’t get it quite right so this is the best of them and it’s still not… it’s a flower. For you.”

Rio pulled both hands from beneath Agatha’s gentle hold on them and scooped up the little ball of paper. Whether it was because she knew what it was meant to be or because she was so affected by Agatha’s confidence in handing over this ball of scrap paper, she began to see the creases of where the petals were - stronger than the folds Agatha had made in error but that were still visible. She touched the centre of it delicately, half expecting it to crumble completely in her hand. But it didn’t, it remained together, surprisingly strong, though misshapen and messy.

Rio turned to Agatha and leant in slowly, grateful Agatha didn’t move at all as she pressed a soft kiss to her cheek. Agatha felt how she always felt, she smelled how she always smelled, but something was different. She’d changed. Or perhaps Rio had.

Rio pulled away and kept her gaze down, unwilling to look into the blue eyes that haunted her still. She looked instead at the gift still cradled in her right hand.

“Nicky wanted to give you your jersey back,” Agatha said softly, “he wanted to be here too. Said he could play basketball with you to make you smile.”

Rio swallowed and wondered whether even Nicky could cheer her up now. Her little cousins had provided at least a little light in the darkness but then again, they weren’t made in her image, they weren’t Agatha’s son.

But kids didn’t belong at funerals. Kids didn’t belong around death and grief and Rio knew Nicky was so sensitive, so gentle, that he’d inevitably be upset if he saw how broken she was. So distance was best. Agatha had made the right choice not to bring him. And Rio was glad he wasn’t there.

Rio bit down on her lip and wiped quickly at her eyes as they filled again with tears. “I can’t believe you’re here.”

“I couldn’t not be.”

“Agatha,” Rio breathed, still unable to look up, “it hurts to see you like this. And right now my whole body hurts. Everything… everything hurts and I-…”

“I don’t want to hurt you, Rio.”

“Can’t you see you already have?”

Rio looked up then and saw what she’d been trying to avoid. Agatha’s eyes were full of tears, the blue now sparkling back at her, making her feel sick again. “I made a mistake.”

“Don’t,” Rio said quickly, standing and placing the flower on the bed where she’d just been sat. “I can’t deal with it. It’s too much, Agatha.”

Behind her, Agatha looked down at the abandoned gift and picked it back up again, toying with it gently in her hand. Rio reached her old desk and stared down at it, taking comfort in the little girl she once was who’d carved her name into the wood. She traced her finger over the ‘R’ and tried to calm the tide of unresolved anger and confusion that was bubbling just below the surface, hiding the broken heart underneath.

“I know you don’t want to talk about it,” Agatha uttered after a few more seconds of heavy silence, “and I promise I didn’t come to discuss it. And this will be the last thing I’ll say on it. I’ll… I’ll leave you with your family. But you should know that I’ll wait however long it takes. I came here only to make sure you were okay. Alice has only been giving me vague updates and… I had to see you.”

Rio closed her eyes, her finger just on the apex of the ‘I’.

“Rio,” Agatha’s voice sounded a little stronger this time, and the bed creaking told Rio she’d stood up. “I’m so sorry for your loss, I really am.”

A wave of Agatha’s perfume hit her as the brunette moved to lean around and Rio opened her eyes just in time to see a pale hand placing the flower on the side next to her crumpled cowboy shirt. She turned her head to watch Agatha leave her childhood bedroom and when the door closed behind her she fell to the floor in tears.

The door was opened again not two minutes later and Rio knew immediately whose arms had wrapped around her. She sobbed into Alice’s shoulder, clutching at her friend until she could breathe again, disrupted only by soft hiccups that came every few seconds.

“It’s okay,” Alice kept repeating as she stroked through Rio’s hair, holding her as close as possible.

“Has she… gone?”

“Yes, I think so. Not before she sent me to you.”

Rio whimpered and pressed her face closer to Alice’s shoulder, aware her shirt was now sodden but not caring about it one bit. After a while Alice spoke again, pulling away to look at Rio and wipe gently below her eyes, “Did she come here to get you back?”

“No, she… just to make sure I was okay.”

Alice nodded and Rio avoided her gaze as she moved to extricate herself from her friend. The clarity that comes after a cry hit her solidly in the chest and she moved to stand and begin fixing herself in the mirror. Although there was no hiding her bloodshot eyes.

“I can make excuses for you, you know. If you want me to?”

“No. I need to be there for my mom. I should get back.”

Rio turned back to Alice only when she thought she looked passable enough to be seen though her cheeks were flushed and her eyes were still bloodshot. But she wasn’t crying anymore and everyone would excuse her because it was her dad’s funeral, in any case.

Together they went back down to the wake and Rio found that far from the reception she’d expected, no one was much interested in her. And it didn’t take long to find out why.

Squashed in by the fireplace in the living room, Rio spotted Agatha standing with a baby in her arms and her mother by her side, cooing down at Rio’s newest little cousin. Anna’s hand was on Agatha’s shoulder and she seemed to be the instigator of this little scene.

It felt like it had been facilitated just for her. Like her mom had read her mind and handed Agatha a tiny baby with a shock of dark hair. Like she’d made Agatha look calm and serene amongst her admirers as she cradled the child.

She was the Pietà in the window. She was the colour in the glass. She was the mercy and grace of mournful hands.

Around them the familiar faces of her aunts and cousins were all beaming at Agatha, all trying to get close, all speaking over each other for her attention. And as usual her uncles and male cousins were on the periphery, talking about sports or something but turning every now and again to look at the movie star by the wall.

No one but Agatha had looked up when Rio entered the room and she looked a little guilty when she caught Rio’s confused gaze but her mom clearly said something to her and had taken her attention again and Agatha was drawn back into Anna Vidal’s clutches.

“I thought-,” Rio began but Alice interrupted already, “I guess it’s hard to say no to a widow.”

Rio nodded and maintained eye contact with Agatha, watching as she bounced the tiny dark-haired baby expertly in her arms. She was a natural at it. A natural mother, born to be one. It was clear in how she was with Nicky.

And now, for the first time, Rio saw her with an actual baby. The sight was overwhelming.

Rio bit her lip and turned from the crowd to slink off into the kitchen seeking wine. Lots of wine. Alice traipsed after her and it didn’t take either of them long to find what they were looking for.

“I guess it’s not often you have a movie star in your house,” Alice was saying as she poured Rio a generous glass of red.

“I have an Oscar.”

“Yeah but you’re just Rio.”

“Thanks so much. My dad just died, you know. Could be a little softer.”

Alice smiled up at her and Rio smiled back, dropping her gaze quickly before she felt the promise of tears once more.

“I brought a little treat for later. Something to help you sleep.”

“Mom will kill you.”

“That’s fine, so long as you get some rest.”

Rio smiled into her wine as she took two large gulps but almost choked on the second when her mom’s voice filled the little kitchen, “Mija, getting drunk at your own father’s velatorio.”

Rio spluttered and slapped her own chest, “It’s my first wine. I’m not exactly-…” but her words were cut short when Agatha appeared just behind her mom, having given back the baby cousin of Rio’s she’d been holding.

“Hi. Estaba a punto de irme y entonces…” I was just about to leave and then-…

“¡Tonterías! Te quedas. Tenemos espacio y mucha comida.” Nonsense! You’re staying. We have room and plenty of food.

Over Anna’s shoulder Agatha caught Rio’s eye and she hesitated for a second before she nodded and looked back down to the woman now holding her at her shoulders. “Okay, gracias.”

“Teach my daughter to improve her grammar whilst you’re at it,” Anna said with a smile over in Rio’s direction. Rio rolled her eyes and moved to settle against the corner of the counter top, taking another small sip of wine.

Anna left the small kitchen and as soon as she did, Rio hopped up onto the side, something her dad always allowed but her mom did not. She was now left with Agatha and Alice and was aware of them both watching her with interest, one making the move to stand closer than she had been before.

“Where are you staying?”

Rio glanced at Alice, now beside her against the counter, she looked tense and so Rio reached out to take her hand.

Agatha’s gaze fell to the movement as she answered: “The Marriott by the airport.”

“Not very glamorous,” Alice said archly as Rio turned her head to look out the window. Outside the grass was dewy, a deep green in the bright of the day. It reminded Rio of endless spring days spent running around the lawn with her dad. Her grip tightened and whatever was said in the room was lost to her as she disappeared into her own mind.

Around her the kitchen began to fill and Rio was unceremoniously battered about, manhandled out of the way by insistent hands looking for food or more drink and she found herself slipping into the yard before she even knew where she was going.

Alice came with her and Agatha too.

The cold air was refreshing and Rio luxuriated in the sharpness of it against her bare arms until a jacket was placed over her and she turned to the culprit, seeing Agatha now standing in her crisp white shirt, looking anywhere but at Rio.

Swallowing down her gratitude, Rio turned away and looked back out over the lawn, her memories now gone, her mind stuttering its way back to reality as she gripped the lapel of the borrowed jacket with her free hand.

“Rio, you’ll freeze out here.”

“Go back in,” Rio said quietly, not looking around at Alice, “I’m fine.”

“I’ll stay with her,” Agatha said from just over Rio’s shoulder and Rio closed her eyes as she felt Alice touch her arm and heard the door close behind her as she went back in.

“You must be cold.”

“I’m fine.”

“I was leaving Rio and then your mom-…”

“She can be persuasive,” Rio said with a shrug, letting Agatha know she wasn’t mad at her.

“Must be genetic.”

Rio raised her brows and turned to see Agatha smiling, a sad sort of smile that looked wistful. “If it were we wouldn’t be in this mess.”

Turning back around Rio knocked back the rest of her wine.

“I was angry.”

“You’ve said.”

“I wanted to-…”

“Hurt me, I get it.”

“No.” Rio turned as Agatha stepped closer, her face firm for the first time that day, her eyes bright again, “Never you. Me. I wanted… I wanted to…”

“I’m sorry,” Rio said quickly, “I know. I know. We just… can’t talk about this,” Rio said in a low but urgent whisper, “Please. I can’t.”

Agatha’s jaw flexed briefly but she nodded and dropped her gaze to Rio’s free hand, her own fingers twitching by her sides and drew Rio’s attention to them. Her pale skin looked practically blue now in the cold and Rio reached for them instinctually, curling her warmer hand around them to bring them up to her lips where she kissed Agatha’s cool palm and murmured, “You shouldn’t have come.”

Agatha sucked in a sharp breath and Rio’s gaze dropped to the mauve lipstick she’d worn for the occasion. The colour was new, or at least Rio hadn’t seen it before, and she found herself transfixed on it as Agatha’s lips formed the words: “I want to make sure you’re okay. I want to be here in case you need me. Please.”

The door opened behind them and Rio turned with Agatha’s hand still held up close to her lips and saw her mom standing looking at them with a small smile on her face. “Mija, entrada.”

Rio hesitated, watching her mom’s dark eyes travel to the hand near her face and the blazer over her shoulders.

“Agatha, ¿te quedas esta noche? Me enojaría mucho si nos dejaras.” Stay tonight? I would be upset with you if you left us.

“Mamá.”

“Sin argumentos, Rio.” No arguments, Rio.

Rio sighed quietly and brought Agatha’s hand down so it hung, still held, between them and Anna turned to leave the two of them alone again.

“I won’t stay if-…”

“She’ll insist,” Rio said quietly, “Alice is in the spare guest room. You can share with her.”

Agatha nodded silently and Rio shot her a quick glance before she stepped around her, unaware or unconcerned that she was still holding her hand.

“Rio.”

She felt Agatha tug at her from where she now stood just two feet behind her and Rio’s other hand rested on the door handle.

“I want to make it right.”

Rio froze where she stood, halfway between Agatha and the grief she felt in her bones.

But Agatha hadn’t moved either, she simply held the hand that still held hers and after a few more seconds of silence Rio said, “I need time, Agatha. My dad I…” she sucked in a breath and felt Agatha squeeze her fingers, “I can’t think about anything else right now.”

Agatha released her hand and Rio didn’t look back as she stepped into the warm house. She squeezed past various members of her family and disappeared back to her room to change.

Her funeral clothes felt stifling. She could barely breathe for the black that clung to her body; for the reminder of her loss. In the mirror she looked just as she had that morning only with her eyes a little less bright and Agatha’s expensive blazer over her shoulders.

She tugged at it, felt the rich fabric between her fingers, and in adjusting, in luxuriating in the feel of it around her body, she felt something hard against her chest. Lifting the right side of the jacket she fished in the breast pocket and pulled out a pair of glasses. She’d seen them before, but only in her tiny phone screen one night weeks go now.

She turned them over in her hands. They were large, metallic aviators, and as Rio tried them on she realised that if her vision were this blurry suddenly then Agatha must need to wear these much more than she did.

She took them off, folded the legs back delicately and placed them down on her desk. It was the perfect metaphor, really. Agatha had the tools she needed to see better but kept them hidden, used so seldomly that even Rio, who had seen so much of her, been allowed access to her deepest secrets, had only seen her in them once.

She shrugged Agatha’s jacket onto her bed and slipped from her dress to change into dark sweats and her favourite cowboy shirt that now smelt of Agatha.

As she was about to leave her eyes caught the discarded glasses and she pocketed them. She returned to the gathering downstairs and found herself soon on the floor beside her favourite cousin, leaning against his side as they sat together against the wall.

“She’s like ridiculously hot.”

“Yes, I’ve heard.”

“Like… I’d let her fuck me if she wanted to. With her fucking Oscar if that’s what she wanted.”

Rio laughed despite herself, only nudging Mat gently in the ribs when the littlest of the Vidal cousins ran past with chocolate all over her face.

“She’s married.”

“Still. Movie stars aren’t monogamous. They don’t have to be. They’re better than us.”

“Does everyone keep forgetting I’ve won an Oscar?”

“No, unfortunately not. Your mom mentions it every time I see her.”

Rio smiled and began plucking at the fabric over her knee, “Well this movie star is only into one girl at a time.”

“Liar. You’re not the relationship type.”

“Maybe I’ve changed.”

Rio’s centre of gravity was suddenly shifted as Mateo lifted his arm from beside her to wrap around her and he tugged her into his chest, managing to seamlessly ruffle her hair as he did.

She screamed out and wrestled with him, escaping only when he released her with a grin. “Not changed enough to be able to get out of a headlock.”

“Ass.” Rio huffed as she tried to flatten down her hair and turned her attention to the child now running full pelt at her and she scooped her up, protecting her from smacking into the wall. Her attention was down on her cousin as Agatha walked in the room and she didn’t spot her until she was once again child free.

“Like,” Mat muttered beside her as Agatha made her way over, carrying what looked like a plate full of cookies. “Isn’t that just every man’s dream.”

“Hey,” Agatha said as she stopped just before them, her crisp white shirt now rolled up to her elbows, the top two bottoms undone, “Your mom said you hadn’t eaten anything.”

“So you’re bringing me cookies?”

“It was better than wine.”

“I’d rather the-…”

But Mat beside her was rushing to his feet, “Agatha. I’m Mateo. Rio’s favourite cousin, and second biggest fan of yours.”

“Second?” Agatha asked curiously as she raised her gaze from Rio to the man now before her.

“Yeah, Rio first, obviously. Beats me only because she wants to f-…”

“Jesus, Mateo.”

Agatha’s soft smile had grown across her face and Rio scowled at the sight of it, “She does, does she?”

“He didn’t even finish his sentence.”

“I filled in the blanks.”

Rio huffed and pulled her knees close to her chest as Agatha went to sit beside her, and held out the cookies, “Cookie?”

“I said I wanted wine.”

Mateo was back on Rio’s other side and reached across for a cookie, “Agatha Harkness doesn’t fetch you things. People bring things to her. Alice will fetch you wine.”

And Mat shouted for Rio’s manager just as Rio laughed and relented in her stubbornness and took a cookie. “I like him,” Agatha muttered from the corner of her mouth, smiling a little when Rio glanced at her. “You just like being complimented.”

“Ever thought about the girl thing, Agatha?”

Rio choked on the cookie she’d just taken a bite out of and found two hands slapping her back as she leant forwards to try to dislodge it.

Only once she was righted again, cheeks flushed and eyes wide, did Agatha respond. “No. But if I had, I think your cousin here would have a fair shot.”

Rio narrowed her eyes at Agatha and then looked to Mat, “You can’t just ask people if they have ever thought about-…”

“Why not? I just told you I’d swing for Agatha if she asked.”

“Flattering, thank you.”

Rio rolled her eyes and huffed a little as she leant her head back against the wall, “You’re supposed to be nice to me today.”

“I’d say the biggest movie star in the world saying they’d go for you if they had to is pretty nice,” Matt whispered loud enough for Agatha to hear too.

“Thanks, Mateo.”

“Just explaining.” He looked at Agatha with a grin, “Usually breaks for chocolate ice cream or something when she’s starving though.”

“Fabulous, thank you, Mateo.”

“You want some chocolate ice cream?”

Rio rolled her head back where it rested against the wall and looked at Agatha in surprise. Matt leant further around to do the same and raised his brows at the movie star.

“You’re offering my big cousin ice cream?”

“Do you want some?”

Rio was a little taken aback by how unmoved Agatha was by her cousin’s teasing and she found that she couldn’t speak for a second, shocked by the care mixed into the offer, “No, thank you. I just had a cookie.”

She thought of her dad, of the relief she’d heard in his voice that last night. “Estoy orgullosa de ti, mija. Ahora, duerme. Sueña con todo lo bueno que te mereces. Sueña con Agatha y con lo que te espera cuando estés lista. Te amo.” I'm proud of you, daughter. Now, sleep. Dream of all the good things you deserve. Dream of Agatha, and what will be waiting for you when you're ready. I love you.

She thought of what he’d say if he say her now, sandwiched between her cousin and her future. Maybe he’d simply smile and wink, maybe he’d come over and kiss both of Agatha’s cheeks and welcome her to the family.

Maybe he’d tell a story so mortifying that Agatha would laugh for days and Rio would feel warm with affection and embarrassment.

Maybe, maybe, maybe.

Maybe if he hadn’t died Agatha wouldn’t even be speaking to her. Maybe the universe where Miguel was alive was the only one where they would work it out.

She felt Agatha’s hand on her thigh again, anchoring her to reality so she didn’t slip into the darkest recesses of her mind.

“Rio,” Agatha murmured, her free hand moving to Rio’s thigh, which didn’t help her breathing situation.

“Sorry, Rio. I didn’t mean-…”

Rio laughed and leant her head back against the wall, her hand automatically moving to Agatha’s to hold it, “You’re such an ass.”

Mat grinned and nudged her arm, “I think I’d win the wrestling matches now though.”

“Don’t count on it,” Rio muttered as she closed her eyes and interlocked her fingers with Agatha.

“I’m not sure it’s appropriate to wrestle at a wake.”

Rio smiled at Agatha’s comment, squeezing her hand as it rested against her thigh, “Thank you for the advice, mi amor.”

The world stopped then as Mat beside her gasped and Rio opened her eyes to turn to him, his eyes wide and his mouth open even wider. “I knew it.”

“Mateo.”

“Rio it’s okay,” Agatha said from the other side of her. She leant over slightly and Rio sucked in a breath. Mateo’s eyes flashed with excitement as he turned his attention to Agatha and Rio turned her head too, staring straight ahead to keep both of them in her sights.

Agatha’s words hit harder than Rio had expected them too. But she couldn’t deny them. Technically Agatha was correct. Technically they were friends.

“Damn,” Matt said with a laugh, “because I was about to say how hot the two of you would be together and how Rio would be so losing her shit if she thought for even a second that she-…”

“Okay, thank you, Mateo.”

Both Rio and her cousin turned to look at Agatha, both with equal amounts of surprise and curiosity across their faces. “I told your aunt I’d look after Rio today but she’s holding my hand pretty tight so would you be a doll and go and fetch her some chocolate ice cream for me?”

Rio scoffed and was about to say something when Mateo nodded and jumped up, “Sure, Agatha Harkness.”

And Rio watched him go with a scowl, not believing that he’d just fallen under Agatha’s spell so easily.

“You okay?”

“No,” Rio admitted, watching her cousin practically hop to the kitchen. “No, I’m not.”

“Is there anything I can do?”

Leave forever. Stay forever.

“No, Agatha.”

Agatha nodded and Rio thought she’d remain silent but she asked quietly: “Have you really not been eating at all?”

“I’m fine.”

“Rio.”

Rio sighed heavily and shrugged her shoulders, “I just don’t feel like it.”

There was a beat of silence where Rio had shuffled forwards to land on her knees and lean across for an open bottle of red wine on the coffee table. She grabbed it and filled the glass she’d been sharing with Agatha and then leant back but found when she did that Agatha’s arm had been outstretched and she was now sitting in the crook of it.

Her body reacted before her mind could and she curled into her, turning herself a little to lean back properly into Agatha’s side.

It felt normal, nice, and even as Agatha’s hand curled around her hip and her fingers splayed to hold more of her than she’d held in days it still felt good. Perhaps she’d had too much wine, perhaps grief had dulled her other senses, or maybe being held by Agatha Harkness would always feel good.

Even if she’d broken her heart. Even if Rio should know better than to relax into her. Even if they needed to take it slow.

“This okay?”

Rio ignored the question because she knew Agatha already knew well enough that it was. Rio instead offered Agatha the glass first and Agatha took it, took a sip, and handed it back.

“Hey, here-…” Matt had appeared before them again, had faltered when he saw how his cousin was now sitting curled into the most famous woman in the world, how their fingers were overlapping around the shared glass they now held together.

Rio didn’t look up, Agatha did.

Mateo smiled a little, his shoulders dropping from where they’d been up by his ears. “¿Cuánto tiempo, prima? ¿Cuánto tiempo llevas guardando este secreto?” How long, cuz? How long have you been keeping this secret?

Goddamn fucking Mateo and his goddamn fucking incurable need to pry.
