“¿Mateo? Quiero mucho a tu prima. Pero estoy casado, no lo estaré por mucho tiempo más, pero necesito protegerla, a ella y a mi hijo. ¿Puedo confiar en que no dirás nada?” Mateo? I love your cousin. Very much. But I'm married, I won’t be for much longer, but I need to keep her safe, her and my son. Can I trust you won't say anything?

Rio felt as though she were suddenly made from glass, as though she might shatter any second. Miraculously she was able to raise her gaze to look up at her cousin, to see how he might take this. His favourite actress and his favourite cousin.

He didn’t need to know that they weren’t together, that they were still figuring things out, that every time Rio touched Agatha now she felt like she might die.

Because Agatha was claiming her, was confessing her love, was asking for help to keep Rio safe.

And suddenly the glass transformed into sand, and Rio wanted to spread herself over Agatha. She wanted to bury herself in the woman in every and any way she could. But staying pressed into the crook of her arm would have to do for now.

And Mateo watched, he crouched down, he held out the generous portion of chocolate ice cream he’d sourced for Rio.

“Tu secreto está a salvo conmigo. El tío Miguel querría que hiciera todo lo posible por ayudarte...” Your secret's safe with me. Uncle Miguel would want me to do everything I could to help...

He’d trailed off, biting on the corner of his lip. Rio turned to him again and smiled gratefully, sadly. “Thank you.”

As she took the bowl from him she squeezed Mat’s hand, watched him walk away and shoot them both a wink over his shoulder, and then they were alone again, and suddenly Rio didn’t feel so sure about being practically in Agatha’s lap.

Perhaps she was overstepping.

She made to shift away but Agatha had changed her hold to hold her tighter and Rio gasped quietly when she felt Agatha’s thumb just ghost over the skin at her hip. “I haven’t been able to,” she began softly, and if Rio didn’t know about better she might think Agatha was going to cry, “hold you through… any of this. And I don’t want to overstep but I don’t think I’ll get another chance so…”

Agatha turned to her and Rio saw that her eyes were filling with tears, her cheeks a soft shade of pink. “Please let me.”

Rio pursed her lips and nodded, soon settling back down to focus on eating her ice cream. As the cool of it began to chill her body, Agatha pulled her in closer, draped the hand that held their shared wine across her, protected her from the cold.

Grief, like anything, expands and wanes without warning. Only this was the first time Rio had felt any reprieve in her pain. Agatha holding her was the most comfort she’d felt in days now. The soft, tender circles she was drawing against her hip were all she focused on as she continued to eat the ice cream and lean back against her.

At some point Agatha’s fingers stretched across her hip and she felt them come into contact with the hard shape in the pocket of her pyjama pants and Agatha soon was pulling out her own glasses from Rio’s pocket.

“My jacket,” Agatha concluded softly as Rio turned to watch her hide the glasses in her hand and place them in her own lap.

She stared for a second, watching Agatha curl her fingers more around the frames before she said: “You’re ashamed of them.”

“Not ashamed, just-…” Rio had reached for them, found them easy to steal from beneath Agatha’s hand that simply opened up for her as she touched it. She lifted them then and hung them from the opening of Agatha’s shirt. The pad of her forefinger had just grazed her chest as she placed the glasses there and stolen the breath left in her lungs.

She was staring, she knew she was. But how could she not? How could she possibly force herself to look away from Agatha when she’d been in the depths of despair for days now and the six inches of pale, freckly skin on display were the one fragment of joy she’d experienced this whole time.

“Rio?”

Rio blinked and silently sat up, breaking Agatha’s hold on her.

“Where are you going?”

“I just… I just need a minute.”

She heard Agatha say a soft ‘okay’ behind her as she strode from the room and made it to the bathroom just in time to gasp in a heavy breath as the tears began to fall from her eyes. She locked the door and cried silently for her dad, for wanting him here, and for wanting Agatha to never let go.

There was a gentle knock some time after Rio had begun to wipe away her tears with the toilet tissue and Rio opened to door to see Alice standing expectantly. Rio stepped back and Alice stepped inside.

“Agatha sent me.”

Rio nodded and sniffed quietly, brushing away her tears still, “She told Mateo. He saw us sitting together and she told him.”

Alice nodded and reached for some tissue to help Rio with her tears. “Always did like that kid. Apart from that one time he got to drunk at that after party.”

Rio laughed at the memory of Mateo spilling red wine all over the cream carpet of a Director’s living room and crying over it in the cab home. She’d grown up with that boy. She knew he’d protect their secret.

“You okay?” Alice asked for what must have been the millionth time that day.

“No. Not even slightly.”

“Why? Someone die?”

Rio rolled her eyes but couldn’t help but laugh at her best friend and then groaned as she caught sight of herself in the mirror looking like the mess she felt. “Jesus.”

“You have looked better.”

Rio huffed and went about splashing water on her face, and wiping herself down with a nearby towel.

“I hear she’s staying?”

“Sharing with you.”

“Yeah, we’ll see how long that lasts.”

Rio rolled her eyes again and nudged her friend as she turned back to her, “In my twin bed? I’m not an animal.”

“No, but you’re vulnerable and you like to be close to people. You like to be close to Agatha.” Alice eyed her closely, her gaze skirting over her face before it fell to her shirt, “I thought you’d lost that. I hate that thing.”

“Shut up,” Rio protested as she nudged her friend. “I love it.”

“Hideous,” Alice said, and jumped quickly away from Rio’s slapping hand. She winked as she disappeared and Rio sighed as he did what she could to fix her face and leave the solitude of the little bathroom to join the others again.

The house was so quiet now, and back in the living room the remainder of the visitors were gathered. Actually, really just one visitor: Agatha.

Her mom and Alice were on the couch and Agatha was sitting in an armchair off to the side, cradling the glass she’d been sharing earlier with Rio. It was strange to see Agatha so casually draped in what was her dad’s favourite chair, in her little house, on her normal street, in a town that didn’t often see movie stars come to visit.

Agatha belonged where the glamorous people were. She belonged under the lights, surrounded by fancy people in their fancy clothes. And yet here she was, surrounded by normal people in their normal clothes, looking not one bit out of place.

Rio took a seat between her mom and Alice and saw Agatha shift a little where she sat. She wondered if she’d wanted her to squeeze in with her instead. But that would have been only possible in another reality, another time.

They made casual small talk, Agatha and Anna holding down the conversation mostly. All in Spanish, all very polite, all very normal.

Agatha spoke a lot about Nicky and Anna asked a lot about him. They talked about the movie and how filming was going. They discussed Agatha’s flight over and how lovely the Mass was. They talked about Rio’s mad cousins and the cute baby.

And when the talking was exhausted, they turned to the television and watched some black and white movie that meant nothing to Rio or anyone else in the room.

Through it all, Rio kept looking to Agatha. She kept checking on her, looking to see if she were uncomfortable or upset or bored. But she was none of those things. She looked, more than anything, happy to be there.

And Agatha kept checking on her too. Or just looking, Rio reminded herself. Agatha was just looking, just taking everything in. But their eyes kept meeting and Rio’s heart kept struggling inside her chest, fighting against muscle and bone to get to Agatha.

Another life, another time, didn’t matter anymore. Because as the movie went on and as Rio spent more and more of her time looking at Agatha instead of the screen, she wanted to move across and sit with her. She wanted to pull Agatha into her side and hold her like Agatha had held her earlier on the floor, as she’d asked her cousin to help her protect her.

But she didn’t move, she just looked, just watched, just sat mesmerised by Agatha Harkness in her house, in her dad’s chair, there for her.

By the time everyone agreed that they should be in bed, Rio was beyond exhausted. She clung to the banister as she climbed the stairs and huffed to herself as she rummaged for clothes Agatha could borrow to sleep in.

Anna had provided Agatha with a toothbrush and a towel for the morning and when Rio went in to deliver clothes for her she found Agatha waiting alone at the bottom of the double guest bed she’d be sharing with Alice.

She was still in her shirt, still in her expensive pants, still wearing her fake ring, still looking more beautiful than Rio could even comprehend.

“Here, these should be okay.” In no world did Rio really think a ratty ‘University of Delaware’ t-shirt and plaid pyjama pants would be considered ‘okay’ for Agatha but she had little choice. “I’ll be fine.”

Rio rolled over. Then she rolled the other way. Then the previous way. Then back again.

She was too hot, too cold, too awake, too tired.

She huffed and threw the covers off.

Now she was definitely too cold.

She climbed out of bed, taking a second to think, her bare feet on the familiar old carpet, her head in her hands. She would just go and see, just go check on her best friend and the woman she was sleeping with. It was a kindness, really. Making sure they were comfortable in her parents’ - no, her mother’s - home.

The other was on the far side of the bed, and was moving to sit up. Agatha was awake.

“Agatha?” Agatha turned to her. “Will you get in, please?”

“You weren’t asleep.”

“I told you I haven’t been sleeping.”

“Alice’s snoring not help?”

“I tried them on. You’re blind. I must just be a blur to you.”

“A very beautiful blur.”

“Are you too hot?”

Rio was. She was burning up. But she shook her head and Agatha tucked her arm more round her, making whatever heat Rio was feeling before rise by a couple degrees. But she said nothing as Agatha held her. She kept her eyes closed and focused on breathing her in instead, wondering if it were possible to breathe someone in so deeply that your body could remember them so that when Agatha was gone again she could simply conjure her up once more and live forever with the memory that she’d once been close, that she’d once been held in the arms of God.

Her mind began to drift as she focused on her breathing, on retaining a memory. Rio wondered if they’d have held each other like this if things hadn’t turned so sour. Or if Agatha would be bolder, more confident, more free. Maybe they’d be naked, for nothing other than to feel the other against their skin. Maybe Agatha would make her come until she passed out, just to help her get some rest. Maybe Rio would allow herself to cry against her. Maybe Agatha would cry with her. Or maybe they’d have both just be able to get some sleep, because Rio felt like she’d lost a part of herself, but Agatha as she had been, as she could have been, would have held her together.

Rio turned, unable to handle the heat any longer. And Agatha moved in tandem, relinquishing her hold to allow Rio the freedom of movement. Rio moved back up the pillow and Agatha adjusted to press around her from behind.

It was cautious at first. Then Rio reached for her hand and tugged it more around herself and suddenly Agatha was confident again. She knew how to hold her. She snuck her arm beneath Rio’s head on the pillow and curled her legs behind hers. She pressed her nose in to the back of Rio’s neck and Rio shivered for the feel of her warm breath against her skin after so long of not feeling it.

“Try and sleep,” Agatha whispered, her nose brushing up gently before she placed a tender kiss to the base of her neck. “I’ll be right here.”

Rio nodded against the pillow, squeezing her eyes closed as she felt Agatha press her face against her and she knew she was breathing her in still. She wondered if she’d missed the way her skin felt, the way her skin remembered the scent of her perfume even if she’d neglected to wear it for a couple days. She wondered if Agatha were thinking of how they might be if things hadn’t gone so wrong.

Her thoughts turned to ghosts in her mind as she drifted off, her fingers entwined with Agatha’s as she cradled her hand against her chest.

When she woke, she woke alone.

She turned slowly to see if Agatha were even in the room anymore but the cool of the mattress beside her and the empty, still room, told her she was long gone.

Rio sighed heavily and sat on the edge of the bed. Her head was sore again. She felt heavy all over, the comfort of last night leaving her mind and body with the horror of Agatha having left her without saying goodbye.

The horror of waking up with a dead dad.

She grabbed her sweatpants from the side and made a mental note to tidy up her shit spread across the room before her mom saw and got mad.

Her steps were heavy on the stairs but not heavy enough to drown out the sound of voices coming from the dining room at the back of the little house. She frowned as she rounded the corner and arrived in the doorway and was surprised to see Agatha there back in her suit.

Only this time there was something noticeably different. She was wearing her glasses. Agatha looked tired but surprisingly relaxed as she sat opposite Alice at the table.

Rio hesitated in the doorway as Agatha smiled at her and Alice turned to see her. “Hey. Thought you’d sleep through breakfast.”

“Morning,” Rio said quietly, moving to pull out the chair beside Alice. “Mom made pancakes?”

“No, Agatha did.”

Rio looked up and saw Agatha was watching her and she looked away again, deciding pouring herself some coffee from the pot was a good distraction from the intensity of her blue eyes.

“Mom allowed that?”

“She loves me.” / “She likes her more than me.”

Rio arched a brow as she placed the coffee pot down again and heard Alice clear her throat.

“Where’s my mom?”

“Kitchen. Your aunt called.”

“Sleep okay?”

Rio glanced up at Agatha as she sipped the lukewarm coffee and had to look away again for fear she’d be caught out by Alice. Though she knew Alice had probably already guessed what had happened the night before.

“Fine. You?” Rio swallowed down another gulp of coffee and silently stabbed a pancake with her fork and brought it to her plate.

“Fine.”

Rio glanced up and saw Alice exchange a look with Agatha. “I’m not a zoo animal, I can’t be spooked.”

“We’re worried,” Alice said softly, watching as Rio cut a piece of pancake with her fork. “They’ve moved the schedule around for you.”

The piece of pancake floated in the air between the plate and Rio’s mouth. “Alice. Please don’t call in any favours.”

“Maria wanted to do it,” Agatha said, speaking for the first time since Rio had arrived. “It was all her.”

Rio swallowed the pancake and was briefly surprised at how fluffy it was, how delicious it tasted with the sweet blueberries baked in.

She washed it down with the bitter coffee. “I’m not a charity case.”

“She doesn’t think you are, honey.”

Rio looked up then, having just put her mug back down. She caught Agatha’s gaze and felt lost in it, momentarily transfixed by the light in her eyes.

“Are you sure you don’t want a couple more days here?”

Alice’s voice broke the spell and Rio glanced at her friend before she looked back down at her breakfast. “No. Working will take my mind off of it. I need the distraction. How was the schedule changed?”

“No speaking scenes. You’ll just be needed for reaction shots or background presence.”

Rio nodded as she stabbed at the pancake, “Okay.”

She was aware that she was being watched as she continued to eat but she didn’t look up again, too worried she’d make a fool of herself or shout for reasons she couldn’t rationalise even to herself.

So she kept her gaze down, kept herself eating until the pancake had disappeared and her coffee was gone. She cleared her throat as she reached for more coffee.

“I’m going to drive Agatha back to her hotel and then take her to the airport.”

Rio nodded and cleared her throat again as she stretched her arm out to rest on the back of Alice’s chair. She knew Alice was asking her if she was going to come and knew Agatha probably was going to ask the same thing but she couldn’t bring herself to agree.

“Okay.”

But Alice did ask and Rio looked over to her, and was almost swayed. “Are you coming?”

“No. Best not.”

She glanced up at Agatha who was looking down at her coffee mug, her hands wrapped around it. Her own gaze fell to it too and she stared at the empty ring finger on her left hand and wondered why Agatha wasn’t wearing her ring anymore.

“We should get going,” Alice said after a second, turning to look at Agatha too.

Rio moved her gaze to her empty plate and felt something she hadn’t felt in a while: she was hungry. She hesitated and then reached across and snagged another pancake for her plate.

“Maybe,” Agatha said quietly, and Rio could hear the nervousness in her voice, though maybe Alice couldn’t. “Maybe we can wait. Just a little.”

Rio didn’t look up but she could feel Agatha’s eyes on Alice, could have drawn the look she was giving her, the look that said: ‘shut up, she’s eating. She’ll be alone if we leave. Let’s stay with her’.

No one said anything until Rio was done with her second pancake and she’d clattered her fork on the plate.

“More coffee?”

She glanced up at the pot Agatha was offering her and shook her head, deciding to leave the lukewarm coffee left in her mug. She stood to leave the table.

“Rio.” “Honey.”

Rio stopped in her tracks and looked around at the two people who had just tried to call her back.

Alice looked concerned but Agatha looked bereft.

“Alice,” Agatha said, “Can I have a second?”

Rio stuck her tongue in her cheek and watched the indecision writ large across Alice’s face. She turned to Rio for permission and when Rio nodded she stood, kissed her friend’s cheek, and left.

“I’ll check on your mom and then wait in the car, okay?”

Rio smiled as much as she could and waited until Alice had left before she turned to leave after her.

“Rio.”

Rio stopped at the door and held onto the frame, hearing Agatha walk up towards her and stop just behind her.

“Will you be okay?”

Closing her eyes Rio gripped the wooden frame and drew in a heavy breath.

“You’re wearing your glasses.”

She heard the slight creak in the floorboards where Agatha had moved that bit closer. “You like them.” It wasn’t a question, more a statement of fact. Rio liked them; Agatha wore them.

“You should wear them if they help you see, not just because of me.”

She heard Agatha move closer. “It’s only really when I’m tired or for close up if I’m reading a lot.” She took a breath and then: “Will you be okay?”

“I’ll be fine, Agatha.”

“I’ll stay, Rio. If you want me to. I’ll stay.”

“You shouldn’t have come.”

“I know,” Agatha admitted quietly, “But I had to. I couldn’t just…”

Rio turned then and saw that Agatha was much closer than she expected her to be and she felt sick because of it. And the sickness increased when Agatha moved closer still, and her hands were on her arms, and she was leaning in. Rio swallowed thickly as she backed more into the door frame and saw in Agatha’s wide lenses a vague reflection of her shell of a self.

Agatha pressed a kiss to her cheek, a gentle, tender kiss that made Rio reach for her and pull at her until Agatha was holding her and Rio was breathing her in again.

“I want you to stay. I… I want you to stay.”

Agatha nodded against her temple and Rio frowned as she tightened her hold on Agatha. “But I can’t let you.”

Rio’s breath was taken away from her as Agatha tightened her hold and she gasped as Agatha pressed into her. Suddenly everything was Agatha, and for a second her body made her mind forget. It was just her and Agatha. Just the two of them.

But it was over before it begun. Her brain remembered. Her body forgot. Agatha was pulling away and Rio wasn’t able to stop her.

“I’ll see you tomorrow?”

Rio nodded and looked down, focusing somewhere around Agatha’s midsection. Agatha didn’t move for a while and then her lips were back on Rio’s cheek and Rio closed her eyes to not have to witness Agatha pulling away again.

“Will you call me? If you need me?”

Agatha’s breath was against her cheek still. She hadn’t pulled away.

“Agatha.”

“I know.”

“Kiss me.”

Rio opened her eyes, and was surprised by what she saw before her. Agatha looked pained suddenly, her brow furrowing and her lips parting slightly. Her blue eyes were wide beneath her glasses and she shook her head just a little, even as her gaze dropped to Rio’s lips. Rio’s heart began to thunder in her chest, so loud she feared Agatha could hear it, would be horrified to know how much Rio wanted this, needed it even.

“Rio,” Agatha exhaled her name, breathed it out like a prayer.

Rio closed her eyes again and waited, waited for Agatha to leave or to laugh. But she didn’t.

Instead, she whispered, “Rio, I can’t do that.”

She hadn’t been expecting the softness. A rejection, maybe. A loud, purposeful “NO”, but not the tenderness of Agatha’s sigh, the sadness laced in every syllable.

She opened her eyes again and she looked across at Agatha, saw the way she looked up at her beneath hooded, frowning eyes. “Not while you’re grieving. I can’t.”

“Please.”

“My love,” Agatha breathed out, now changing her hold to lift Rio’s face, watching her in the way she did sometimes when it looked like she was cherishing her. “It wouldn’t be right. I want us to be right. I want-…"

“I asked you to.”

Agatha went silent and it was Rio who ducked her head and tried to lean in but Agatha had a hold on her and Agatha wouldn’t let her.

“Please?” Rio whimpered quietly, mortified to hear herself begging as Agatha just continued to watch her with those sad baby blues.

“I love you. I love you so much and I wish… but Rio, I can’t. Not while you’re so early in your grief. I don’t want you to want it just because…”

Rio closed her eyes, felt the steady brush of Agatha’s thumbs along her pink cheeks and lifted her hands to wrap around her wrists. It was too mortifying to stand, too mortifying to look at Agatha.

She felt her lean in and kiss her cheek again, misplacing her thumb to do so.

“Rio?” Agatha’s lips still nudged at her cheek and so Rio didn’t respond, only kept close, kept her eyes closed.

“I need to go, okay? I… I need to go.”

Rio nodded and kept her eyes closed because seeing Agatha leave wasn’t something she could handle. But another precious kiss was suddenly pressed to her cheek and Rio whimpered quietly for it, and for a brief moment, Rio forgot her dad was dead, and thought only of Agatha.

Fully hers, fully soft, fully ready and willing to simply hold Rio through it. To kiss her pain away until it was numbed and she could breathe again.

But Agatha pulled away again and Rio didn’t look.

She let Agatha walk away, heard her reach the hall and then she followed her out and grabbed her arm as she went to open the door. “Wait. Just… wait.”

She ran, taking the stairs two at a time and, when back in her little bedroom, she peeled off the shirt she’d slept in - the gift Agatha had brought her, her favourite cowboy shirt. She folded it, replaced it with a nearby, discarded sweater over herself and then ran back to Agatha.

She found her exactly where she’d left her and, panting softly, she held up the shirt she hadn’t even bothered to fold.

It seemed stupid now, juvenile, even. That she was giving Agatha Harkness, the most famous, most talented of them all, a crumpled up cowboy shirt that she’d been wearing all night. But Agatha took it from her, and looked down at it like it was precious.

“I can’t take this, Rio. I gave it back to you to-…”

“Take it. Take it back. It’s yours now.”

Agatha sighed quietly and swooped in to wrap her arms around Rio, making her gasp, making her whimper. It felt good just to be held by her again, just to be pressed so closely they became one person. One ever-living, ever-breathing thing.

But Alice outside beeped her horn and Rio began to pull away so Agatha could go out to her. Agatha hovered for a second, she hovered and she kissed Rio’s cheek again and held her close.

“Call me. Please. Whatever you need.”

Agatha kissed her cheek again, this time her kiss was softer, the tip of her nose now trailing a path until it collided with Rio’s and Rio tried again, she turned her head and raised her chin only to find Agatha retreating.

“Okay,” Rio whispered as her eyes fluttered open and she felt strong hands slide from her hips to hold her over her ribs. “I’m sorry. You said no.”

“Rio,” Agatha sighed out, her breath tickling Rio’s lips as she spoke, “You have no idea how badly I…” Rio shifted a little, but Agatha moved too, and the distance between them remained. “I’ve fucked everything up. Let me do this right. At least this.”

Rio couldn’t find the words to say to tell Agatha that the only thing that felt right was that she wanted to kiss her, was that she needed to. But they were taking things slow. They were being steady for each other and Rio knew, in the deepest caverns of her heart, that kissing Agatha couldn’t relieve the pain of losing her dad.

So she agreed, she found the words that meant she wanted Agatha forever, not just for now, and she breathed them into the distance between them: “Thank you.”

Agatha pulled away. She left the house and down the path to the sidewalk she kept looking back, she kept checking on Rio, or checking if she’d follow her, Rio didn’t know. But she turned every two steps. She turned around with that same look of pain on her face, that same concern.

Rio sucked in a breath as Agatha got into Alice’s car and she felt her chest expand with it, her lungs ache with the push of it.

She stood in the doorway to her parents’, no, her mom’s house, and watched as Agatha and Alice disappeared. She turned back then, closed the door, and found herself alone.

Chapter End Notes

sorry

(And thank you for the translation help from whiskersinthedark!!)

Chapter 39: Full of Woe

Chapter Summary

A week.

A weak Rio.

Chapter Notes

Everyone okay after 38? Good.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Alice was gone for almost an hour and in that time Rio felt what it truly was to be alone. Anna found her sitting in her room after hanging up from her sister and held her until Alice came to take over.

Rio didn’t cry but she didn’t say anything either. Her head was all over the place: with Miguel, with Agatha.

The only thing she did was spin a crumpled piece of paper around and around in her hands. It span like her washing machine mind. Round and round and round.

She lost herself in the paper petals.

Neither Alice nor Anna asked why or what it was.

But Rio didn’t let it go all morning. When she eventually showered she left it on the side and picked it up only after she’d dried herself enough to not let it dissolve into mush. By lunchtime, Alice had grown too curious and asked: “What is that?”

Rio had only answered: “A gift.”

Leaving Anna was the hardest thing she’d ever had to do. When she’d left before, after three days of grieving together, she’d had the knowledge that she’d be back soon. But when she left now, she had only a gruelling shooting schedule to face into, and no family around her.

But Alice was family. And Alice held her hand the whole way to the airport where she had another little gift waiting for her.

Paps.

The paps had found her, or followed her, or scouted her out. There were five in total, though Rio didn’t bother much to count.

They all shouted for her but she kept her face down, kept her cap tugged tightly over her brow, kept her hand firm in Alice’s.

“They were here for Agatha too. At one point I thought she was going to swing for one of them,” Alice was saying as they took their seats at the Gate. She looked stressed, looked tense, and Rio could only squeeze her hand in reassurance as she said: "Fucking vultures. I thought they'd have some fucking decency. Leave you alone, you know? Who stalks a grieving woman?!".

Rio nodded but said nothing and only continued to toy with Alice’s smaller fingers. She was frowning down at them, wondering how the press had found her in her hometown. But then again, two Oscar winners arriving to a funeral in the suburbs of Wilmington was probably the opposite of a slow news day for the city.

“How was she? When you left with her?”

“We didn’t speak.”

“At all?”

“No.”

“Excuse me?”

Rio looked up suddenly, blinked stupidly into the face of a stranger who was smiling hopefully down at her.

“I’m so sorry for your loss.”

Rio tried to breathe, really she did. But the breath was stolen from her lungs as the next sentence came out of this stranger’s mouth. “Can I get a selfie?”

“I think not,” Alice spat, and Rio knew she wanted to add a curse in there too but had held herself back. “We’re not doing-…”

“It’s okay,” Rio gasped out, already making to stand up on her wobbly legs. “A quick one, sure.”

Alice muttered something indecipherable as Rio lifted her chin and forced a smile on her face. In the little phone screen she saw her pale face and her dull eyes. She’d never looked less like herself and she marvelled at the idea that anyone would want to keep this momento of her. She was a ghost. And she hated ghosts.

“Thank you so much!”

Arms were flung around her neck before she could stop them and Rio stumbled a little, but the woman was attached to her so followed as she did. “Hey!” She heard Alice shout from beside her but not knowing what to do she tentatively tapped the stranger’s back. “Sure.”

A gentle tug on her jacket helped Rio to pull away and the stranger just beamed as Rio could barely keep her smile on her face.

“You’re being filmed,” Alice muttered to her as she sat back down, now with Alice’s arm securely around her shoulders. Rio didn’t look up after that. She kept her head down, kept her eyes on the hand she’d stolen back to hold and held her breath until their flight was called for boarding.

A couple years ago, when everything was beginning to pick up fame-wise, Miguel had asked Rio what it felt like to be known everywhere she went. At the time she’d said something akin to “oh, like nothing at all!”. But even then she’d known it was a lie.

Fame felt like a cage that kept getting smaller. It felt like Rio were trapped and no one was listening. Even when she screamed.

Her dad had listened. Her mom listened. Alice sometimes listened. Agatha didn’t need to listen. She just knew.

Agatha had been in cages all her life and Rio’s, well hers was new. Hers was decorated with gold and starlight. But it was still a cage.

They boarded the plane. Rio with her invisible cage around her still, her hand between the bars holding Alice’s. People looked her way as she went to her seat but she ignored them all and sat with her eyes aimed down.

“Cuando regresemos, ¿puedo usar tu teléfono para llamarla?” When we get back, can I use your phone to call her?

Alice shifted beside her and Rio bit on her lip. “Why not on your cell?”

“I haven’t… I haven’t checked it since…”

“Okay,” Alice said quickly, “okay, okay, of course.”

They remained silent for the rest of the flight. Rio slept. Sleeping was escaping so she forced it upon herself. Alice guarded her throughout, unable or unwilling to let anyone get any sneaky pictures of the grieving Oscar Winner if she could help it.

Landing in LAX brought with it more fuss and more paparazzi. Rio held onto the peak of her Celtics cap and kept her head down, and when they made it out to the car she breathed again. Heavy, slow breaths helped to calm her racing heart as it rattled in her ribcage.

“They’re getting fucking worse,” Alice muttered as she fished in her purse for her phone.

Rio said nothing as she accepted it and tapped in Alice’s passcode before finding Agatha’s contact. She ignored the plethora of notifications Alice had everywhere. Her inbox had an angry 1,789 in a red circle and her WhatsApp read an egregious 131.

She hated that every word in each of those messages would be related to her.

Ignoring the noise, she opened up Alice’s contacts and pressed Agatha’s name.

It took two dial tones before she answered.

“Alice? What’s wrong? Is she-…?”

“It’s me.”

The line went silent for a few seconds and Rio frowned as she stared straight ahead, twirling her hair around her finger.

And then: “Rio.”

“I just-…” / “Are you okay?”

“I’m fine, a slight headache but…” Rio swallowed, “I just wanted to call and… thank you for coming.”

Silence again. Movement.

“Nicky’s here. Do you want to come over? We’ll come and get you.”

“No, I just wanted to thank you, that’s all.”

Another few seconds of silence. “Rio? Is Alice staying with you tonight?”

“No. I’m sending her home.”

“I’m coming to get you.”

Rio laughed, her eyes closing as if they couldn’t bear the sound. “I’m fine, Agatha.”

Agatha was silent again and Rio took a few deep breaths before she said, “Anyway. I’ll let you get back to Nicky.”

“My love,” Agatha sighed, “Rio. Can we please come and get you?”

Rio turned her head slightly when Alice came into view. “No, really. I’m fine. I’ll see you tomorrow.”

“Rio, wait. Will you call me tonight? If you need me?”

Rio nodded and then shortly after said, “Sure.”

“I mean it, Rio. Call me. Whenever. I wish… I wish I could take the pain away. I wish I could feel it for you. I… Rio, please let me come and get you.”

Rio rubbed at her temple and felt a familiar sting as tears threatened to fall. “Agatha,” she choked out, “I’m fine.” Maybe if she said it often enough she eventually would be.

Agatha sighed quietly, “Did the paps get you?”

“Yeah.”

“Me too. Jen’s already called to try and keep your face out of the press. I don’t know how much it’ll help but…”

“Agatha, I’m fine. It’s fine. These things happen.”

“No. They don’t get to profit off your grief, Rio. That’s not how-…”

“Agatha,” Rio whispered, finding Alice’s hand as it rested on her leg, “Give Nicky a hug from me, okay? I’ll see you tomorrow.”

Silence. One beat. Two. “Call me,” Agatha said in that soft tone again, “Please call.”

“Okay.” Rio hung up.

She returned the phone to her manager and said nothing for the duration of the trip, just listening to the soft pad of Alice’s left thumb as it tapped away at her screen.

Back home, the quiet house in the hills felt larger than usual and strangely empty. Rio made up for it by draping herself in a heavy sweater and stealing her biggest and comfiest blanket for the couch. She curled in on herself and buried most of her body as snugly as she could just just her head was visible, the rest of her swaddled beneath.

She called her mom as soon as she was comfortable enough. Just to check in. Just to make sure she was still there, still alive, that she still had one, living, breathing parent.

Alice had been busy texting or emailing or messaging someone somewhere about Rio so they hadn’t spoken for a while. And after speaking to Anna, Rio was beginning to slip into the embrace of sleep when Alice finally broke the silence.

“I’m going to suggest something, okay? And I… don’t want you to freak out.”

Rio raised her brows, her eyes down on the floor. “What, Alice?”

“Why don’t you… call up one of your friends and…”

Rio frowned into the dimly lit room, her brain bouncing about through a list of names as she tried to make sense of what Alice was saying.

“Gotta get under someone to get over someone, you know?”

Slowly, and blinking into the light, Rio sat up. She stared at her best friend who was doing everything she could to not look at her. “Are you suggesting if I have sex I’ll forget that my dad just died?”

“I-… no, I mean, yes, I mean… I know that’s not exactly what that phrase means but… it’ll take your mind off of it. Just for a couple hours. Just until you-…”

“Alice.”

“Okay! Okay!” Alice stood with a huff and her hands held up in surrender, “Just a suggestion.”

“Yeah the most fucking stupid suggestion I’ve ever heard!”

Alice grimaced and turned away as Rio continued to stare aghast at her. It was clear she knew she was in trouble because she didn’t look around again for a while until she eventually tried, “Would Agatha maybe-…?”

Rio scoffed and threw herself from the couch, struggling for a while with the blanket. “Holy shit, Alice. Did you get high or something when I wasn’t looking?”

Her legs took her to the kitchen and her hands found the tequila before she could think much about it.

“It’ll get you out of your head. Hell, I’d offer if it weren’t for Jen and if you could get me drunk enough!”

“Fuck off, Alice.”

“Listen to me,” Alice was in the room now, hovering somewhere nearby but Rio was too busy pouring to care much about how close she was or what she had to say. “I’m trying to help. You hate being alone. You like attention.”

Rio slammed the tequila bottle down and in the near future she’d just be grateful her right hand had done it rather than her left - the glass with a healthy pour now in it would have surely smashed into pieces. “She wouldn’t fucking kiss me. Okay?! Wouldn’t kiss me. I don’t want anyone else. I want her and she wouldn’t kiss me. She just looked at me like-…”

Alice was behind her now, trying to make her turn.

“She looked at me like I was going to break. Like I…” she turned and found soft hands on her wet cheeks, “like I was broken and Alice… Alice I promised I could carry her. I promised… I…”

“Babe,” Alice said shakily, her own tears beginning to fall as she watched her friend disintegrate before her eyes, “I-… I know it hurts. God I know it hurts so fucking much, Rio. Try to breathe. Just breathe for me.”

Rio squeezed her eyes shut and felt her body being pulled into Alice’s smaller one. She felt the press of her lips against her temple. She felt the tug at the back of her sweater and the soft pull into a warm body.

She felt everything and nothing, all at once. She was alone even when Alice was there, even as she clung to her. It was unbearable, the loneliness. Living in a world where her dad wasn’t was impossible.

She sank into Alice and together they clutched and clung and slipped onto the floor. Together they cried. Together they grieved the loss of a father and a father figure. But Rio, Rio held as tight as she could but still felt adrift, unanchored to even the woman who wouldn’t let go.

“I can call her,” Alice said after an hour of being on the floor. They were now beside each other, Rio’s hand tangled in Alice’s, her other clutching her empty tequila glass. “I’ll get her to come over.”

“No. She has Nicky.”

“Clean yourself up and he can come too.”

Rio scoffed quietly, “He can’t see me like this, Alice.”

Her hand was empty suddenly and Rio blinked at it, wondering what had just happened that meant she was now staring at her own palm.

“That kid,” Alice said suddenly, shocking Rio into looking up, “loves you. He adores you. And I don’t fucking like-…” Alice huffed and pressed the heels of her hands into her temple, “Actually I think she’s a jumped up fucking-… god but that kid, Rio. He fucking adores you and you adore him and… and if you asked then-…”

“I can’t see him, Alice.” Rio sighed heavily, choosing now to look at her empty glass rather than her empty hand, “He deserves me when I can be my best. Not when I’m-…”

“Look,” Alice huffed, “I don’t fucking trust her but if she didn’t kiss you then… then maybe she’s better than I thought.”

Rio scoffed, “didn’t you just want me to-…?”

“A recreational fuck not to make love or to, I don’t know, build a house together or some shit. But… shit I can’t believe I’m saying this but… her showing up was, fuck Rio it was romantic as hell. Her not kissing you? When you’re grieving your dad? Fuck me. Just… fuck me.”

Rio shook her head and lifted her sleeves to wipe roughly at her eyes, “I can’t have her see me like this. Her or Nicky. Don’t. Don’t call her.”

“Rio,” Alice elongated her name, making the two syllables double as she spread the ‘o’ like a sigh.

“You know she wants to kiss you. You know she wants-…”

But Rio was standing already, grabbing the tequila from the side and marching back to the living room.

“Babe! I don’t fucking like her. I don’t trust her with you and I don’t think she’s fucking-…” Alice released a scream of frustration as Rio simply poured her drink, knocking back half of it before she’d even sat on the couch. “I’m not saying it happens often but maybe I’m wrong. Maybe she is good for you. Maybe she’s-…”

“Stop it, Alice. I asked her to kiss me and she refused.”

“Did she also sleep with you all night? Hold you? Tell your cousin she loved you and wanted to keep you safe? You and her son? Rio. Get a grip, please.”

Rio knocked the rest of her tequila back and looked up as Alice’s phone lit up on the coffee table. ‘AGATHA’ came up on the screen and she felt her battered heart fizzle in her chest, broken as it still was. Alice was nearer now, frowning down at her, but she caught the phone light too and picked it up before Rio could tell her not to.

“Hey.”

Rio swallowed.

“Yeah. I’m here.”

Rio looked down at her hands, flexing each finger one at a time.

“No, I, I asked her. Agatha, I-…”

Rio turned her hands over, beginning the same the other way, “No, she’s… no. Agatha, I’ll call you later, okay?”

Rio sighed and closed her eyes.

“Jesus, Agatha, look.”

Rio blindly reached her hand out and a second later felt the weight of the cell in her hand. “It’s me.”

She heard Agatha inhale, “Rio. I’m coming. Alice hasn’t been answering my calls and she doesn’t sound-…”

“Don’t. Please. I can’t have Nicky see.”

She heard a voice in the background, “Jen’s here, honey. He’ll stay with her and-…”

“I can’t, Agatha. Please. Not tonight. Please.”

“Quiero estar allí. Quiero verte. Quiero abrazarte. Por favor.” I want to be there with you. I want to see you. I want to hold you. Please.

Rio couldn’t believe she was saying no again but she shook her head, pressed her fingers against her chest and sucked in a breath as she said “No, Agatha.”

There was a different sound in the background and Rio heard something muffle the receiver and then she was back and she was saying, “Can I come see you tomorrow? Before work? I’ll come to your trailer. I’ll bring breakfast. Whatever you want. Get Alice to tell Jen and I’ll bring it. Homemade, store bought, whatever.”

“Whatever I want?”

A crack appeared in the form of a smile as Agatha said in a soft voice, “Anything. But, Rio, call me. I’m right here. I’m waiting for your call, okay? Whenever you need me. Jen’s staying so… if you need me to come I will.”

“Is that something I need to break to Alice?”

The crack widened and Rio’s face practically split in two as Agatha responded with: “She’s little. You can handle her.”

Rio laughed quietly and looked across at her little friend. “She is pretty little.” Alice scowled.

“Not much taller than Nicky.”

“He’ll grow though.”

“He’s made you a card, you know. Wrote it himself. Didn’t even ask for any help. If you don’t keep it up on your fridge then you’ll be answering to someone a lot bigger than Alice.”

“A lot? Jen?”

Agatha laughed and Rio bit down on the inside of her cheek.

They were both silent for a few seconds before Agatha asked: “You sure I can’t come over? Just for a little while?”

Rio sighed out, letting all the air leave her lungs before she slowly brought it back in. “Waffles. With chocolate and banana. But the proper kind. Not the sauce. Proper melted chocolate. Milk.”

“People don’t usually say no to me, you know.”

“Did you get all that? I can repeat it if-…”

“Waffles with proper melted milk chocolate and banana. And a definite no on me coming over?”

Rio smiled a little and shook her head, “I’m going to get drunk and fall asleep on Alice.”

“On?”

“With.”

Agatha cleared her throat and Rio raised her brows as she waited for her words. “Fine. Call me though. If you… if you want someone to sleep on.”

“You’ll allow that but… I can’t kiss you?”

Agatha sucked in a breath and Rio chewed on her lip, suddenly twisting her hair desperately.

“It’s different, Rio.”

“Is it off the table? Completely?”

“No. I… no. Never. Just… no, you know it isn’t.”

Rio nodded and went silent as she span her hair around and around.

“Let’s talk tomorrow? Over waffles?”

“Okay.”

“Go easy on the tequila.”

Rio cleared her throat and then said, “Okay.”

She handed the phone back to Alice before Agatha could say anything else and watched as she held the phone to her ear the brought it down again. “She hung up. So. I’m staying here?”

“Looking after me whilst I’m drunk, yes.”

“You’re working tomorrow.”

“I’m in the background of a Christmas movie. I can be hungover.”

“There’s buzz about this, you know. There’s-…”

“Alice I could not give two shits about awards right now.”

“I know, I know. Sorry.” Alice leant forwards and poured Rio a much smaller glass than she’d been pouring herself.

Rio smiled a little and toasted before she knocked back the clear liquid that burned her throat. “I should have kissed her the night we… the night before dad. Maybe then she’d be here. She’d kiss me and it wouldn’t hurt as much. Or, or would still hurt the same but she’d be kissing me which… which is better.”

“Why didn’t you?”

Rio reached for the bottle again and doubled the previous pour. She blinked before she sipped and felt the fluffiness that came with the promise of impending insobriety.

“I wanted to make sure I was ready. I wanted to make sure I-… that I would be strong for her. That I could take a night to sleep on it and in the morning I’d kiss her in that damn trailer. That I’d have one last night alone preparing for a life with her. And then-…” she shook her head and knocked back the rest of her drink.

Alice, during this time, had picked up the bottle so Rio couldn’t fill her glass so quickly. “I just want her, Alice.”

“And Nicky?”

“And Nicky.”

Alice nodded slowly and Rio tapped her nails along the thin glass. It sounded like bells.

“Are you ready?”

“Yes.”

Rio sniffed quietly and wiped the underside of her nose with the back of her hand.

“So, in two weeks he’s served. That’s, what? Six months? Six months until she’s single and, custody, Rio, you know that might take longer.”

Rio nodded, the bells still sounding.

“It’s a long time to-…”

“I’ll wait. However long it takes.”

She reached for the bottle and Alice reluctantly gave it over. “And you trust her?”

“She told me everything. She told me-…” Rio shook her head as she poured the tequila, mentally cutting herself off after this one.

“I told my dad. Alice I told him I was hopeful. I told him. I told him… to expect her and Nicky at Christmas.”

Rio hiccuped suddenly but she didn’t know whether it was the alcohol or the sobs trapped somewhere in her diaphragm.

Alice moved in again and pulled Rio against her. In her hold now she still felt alone. Still felt adrift, unmoored, floating.

But Alice held on until she felt a little less of it. She kissed her head and ran her fingers through her short hair until Rio was saying something she’d been keeping in since the news broke: “I’m worried I killed him.”

She felt rather than heard Alice suck in a sharp breath and she pulled up to look round at her. In her friend’s eyes she saw only pity.

“Rio, that just isn’t true.”

“All week, Alice. Longer than. I called him every day and-…”

“And he loved hearing from you. You think your dad wasn’t thrilled that his little girl needed him? Rio, that man loved speaking to you, he loved you so much. Your mom told me how excited he was that night. How hopeful he was.”

Rio shook her head and looked away, chewing the inside of her cheek.

“I should have called him everyday. Even when I had nothing to tell him.”

“He loved you anyway. I’ve never seen a prouder man than when you won the Oscar. Than when he saw the way Agatha looked at you when you came back from winning. Rio, he loved you endlessly. And that last call… you sent him to sleep happy.”

Rio sucked in a shaking breath as Alice whispered, “He died happy, Rio. He… he loved you so much.”

Alice was right, somewhere, a tiny part of her knew she was. But the grief still felt endless. After all, a single buoy in an endless ocean was no salvation.

Rio allowed herself to be taken to bed and when she washed her face and brushed her teeth she heard Alice on the phone but she didn’t question it. She didn’t know who she was talking to or what she was saying. She assumed Jen, she hoped Agatha.

By the time she was in bed, curled inwards on herself and buried beneath the blankets, she felt exhausted. Alice held her hand an after a few moments of silence she'd said into the dark room: "I'm sorry about what I suggested earlier. I know it isn't that simple. When I lost mom I was too young to understand and I know all grief is different but... maybe it was easier for me to lose her so young. I didn't know what it was to love her then. I just did, you know?"

Rio shifted where she lay and turned to look at her friend in the darkness.

"What I mean to say is, I'm sorry. I have my own issues with Agatha and... encouraging you to sleep with anyone, including her, isn't going to help you." Rio shifted a little again, squeezed Alice's hand. "Anyway. I lied earlier. I told her in the car I'd kill her if she broke your heart again."

Rio leant up and pressed a kiss to Alice's temple and in doing so all was forgiven. She turned away then and after a while, she drifted off into a fitful sleep.

She woke a couple hours later with an arm thrown over her stomach and soft breathing against her temple. She was on her back now, frowning against waking. The arm around her moved and a warm hand hit her abdomen and rubbed it gently.

Her head turned and she felt the breath she’d felt against her skin closer this time, whispering across her lips. In her sleepy haze she blinked her eyes open and saw deep pools of dark blue looking back at her.

“Agatha.”

“Don’t be scared,” Agatha said gently, as if there were a world where Rio would ever be frightened of this woman. She nudged their noses together and Rio made a soft noise at the contact. “Go back to sleep, Rio.”

It must be a dream, she thought. It was Alice in the bed with her. Little Alice with her snoring and her propensity to take up as much space in the bed as she could manage.

Sighing away her fantasies she allowed sleep to creep in, slowly, starting along the edges of her consciousness. The pressure of a hand across her stomach felt fuzzy now, with sleep stealing the strength of it.

The warmth of soft breath across her face felt like a lullaby to a fading mind. Rio fell asleep with the comfort of someone waiting for her, someone ready to soothe her if waking came again.

Rio remained peacefully asleep for the rest of the night.

 

MONDAY

In the morning, Alice was nowhere to be found. The bed was cool beside her and the side Alice had slept on remained surprisingly neat, as if she’d not been in the bed at all.

She traipsed downstairs and huffed with every step she took. Her head hurt. A dull, familiar throb.

“Morning, sunshine!”

Rio grunted and made for the coffee pot before she even looked Alice’s way.

“Sleep okay?”

Rio grunted again as she poured out the much-needed elixir and sighed after taking a big sip that burnt her tongue.

“You didn’t snore last night. So better than I usually would.”

Alice laughed behind her and Rio turned to raise her brows expectantly at her, her mood descending so suddenly it even took her by surprise.

“What?”

“Good to know Agatha doesn’t snore.”

Rio blinked and stepped closer, only to slop the hot coffee down her white pyjama top. She cursed and hissed as the warm fabric soaked her chest and she tugged frantically at it to flap away the heat.

“Shit. What?”

“She said you woke up. You don’t remember?”

Rio was too busy flapping to catch the amusement in Alice’s tone. Which was for the best because her head was still thumping and her shirt was still soaked through.

“Alice. She was here? I… what?”

Rio’s coffee-brown shirt was a lost cause now and Rio grimaced as she looked to Alice, a mixture of indignity and confusion. “Alice.”

Her friend sighed and shrugged her sweater from her shoulders to throw it across to Rio. Rio turned as Alice spoke and replaced her wet shirt with the dry sweater.

“I called her after you fell asleep. You were that twitchy way you get when you don’t sleep well. She came over immediately. Actually,” Rio turned around, now in dry clothes, “she answered after one ring. And she must have broken a few traffic laws because-…”

“Agatha was here?”

The hand on her stomach. Alice would never have held her like that.

The brush of her nose. Alice wouldn’t sleep that close.

Agatha.

Agatha.

“She had an early call time so had to leave before you woke up but she stayed all night. I’m not sure she slept though.”

Rio sighed so heavily it turned into a groan as she pressed the heels of her palms into her eyes. “I thought I dreamt it. Dreamt her.”

“So you do remember?”

“I remember waking and thinking she was there but… I was so tired. I was drunk still probably. I didn’t know.”

Warm hands curled around her wrists and Rio could see again and what she saw was a sad facsimile of her usually smiling friend. Alice looked genuinely distraught and it made Rio’s head thump more readily.

“Hey, breakfast, remember? You’ll see her at breakfast. I… Rio, go take a shower and I’ll have coffee ready for when you’re done.”

Rio did as she was told and thought only of the woman who’d left her house in the middle of the night to slip into her bed and hold her in her sleep. She wondered if Agatha had slept at all and hoped only that she had, that she’d managed to rest, that she had taken as much comfort from the act as Rio had.

As had been the habit since Miguel died, Rio and Alice didn’t speak on the car ride to the lot. Rio was too in her head still, too enmeshed in her pain. Nothing Alice could say would pull her from it so she didn’t try.

When they got to Rio’s trailer, with Rio giving the bare minimum in terms of greetings and smiles to the few members of the crew they passed on their way, it was back into the new routine.

Rio curled up on the couch, she read her sides for the day, checked over call times, and then threw one of the mini basketballs in the air, bothering Alice with the repetitive noise of it being caught.

It was quiet. It was miserable.

Thirty minutes after their arrival and a hundred toss ups later, there was a knock at the door. Rio didn’t miss a beat of the rhythm she’d developed but Alice jumped and went to rip the door open and shouted a very un-Alice-like: “Agatha!”

Rio’s head turned and the small plastic ball fell onto her face.

Agatha was standing in the doorway to her trailer holding a tray piled high with waffles and little bowls of fruit. Rio saw her glance at Alice and then hone in on her.

As Rio sat up properly Agatha placed the tray gently down on the coffee table before her and with tired eyes she looked up and said: “Waffles. Real melted chocolate. Banana.”

Rio forced herself to look away from Agatha and instead to look down at the tray. In amongst the food, exactly as Rio had requested it, was a single stem of what Rio knew to be Hummingbird Sage.

She reached for it as Alice spoke for the first time since she’d shouted Agatha’s arrival. “Are you staying?

“No, I need to head to set. I’m already late.”

Rio was turning the flower over in her hands, watching the bright pink petals as they wiggled with every movement. Her eyes darted back to the tray and on it, below where the flower had been, she saw a card waiting for her and on the envelope in a child’s handwriting was the word ‘Melliza’.

Rio sucked in a breath as Agatha needlessly explained: “It’s from Nicky. He’s desperate to see you but… I said just a card for now. Maybe soon.”

Rio didn’t respond and only opened the envelope to view the card in question.

The card turned out to be homemade; a piece of A4 paper folded in half. On the front it had a pencil drawing of two people with brown hair, one holding a basketball and both with big, identical grins. It was clear that the two illustrations of happy Celtics players were in fact Rio and Nicky, smiling from the centre of a big green heart.

“God that kid is not an artist.”

Rio slapped Alice’s arm before she traced her finger along the smaller Nicky on the paper and looked up at Agatha who was watching her carefully. “Still definitely not a Bulls fan?”

“Definitely not.”

Rio laughed and Agatha’s lips twitched a little but she didn’t yet break a smile. Rio soon looked back down again and opened the card to read Nicky’s message.

‘Rio,

Siento mucho lo de tu papá. Él fue muy amable conmigo y me gustó su risa.

Ven a jugar pronto. Te extraño.

Con cariño, Nicky.’

I am very sorry about your dad. He was very nice to me and I liked his laugh.

Come play soon. I miss you.

Love from, Nicky.

Rio looked up, and saw Agatha gnawing on her lower lip as she waited for her response. Alice gave hers first: “Well he’s better at spelling than-…”

“He wrote it himself. Came up with the words. Just needed help with the spelling. He wants to get better at Spanish so I’ve got him a tutor. He wants to talk to you when no one else can.”

Rio was ignoring Alice, looking only at Agatha, who looked nervous suddenly, like she’d said too much. She looked terrified and unsure and she broke eye contact only to look down at the card and motion as she said: “Look at the back.”

Doing as she was told, she turned the card around and saw another green heart, smaller this time. Inside it were the initials: N, A, R.

Below that Nicky had signed his artwork with a scribbled “Nicholas River Harkness” in the bottom corner.

Alice was silent this time.

“Thank you,” Rio said quietly. In her peripheral vision she saw Alice move and in front of her Agatha shuffled on the spot.

She folded the card back over and stood, keeping her eyes on the floor. Only when she’d made it over to Agatha did she look up again. Agatha was looking down at the card held by her side and her lip was tugged back and chewed so hungrily that it looked like it might be sore. Rio reached for it, cradling Agatha’s chin as her thumb encouraged her to release, to relax her jaw.

She kissed her cheek and Agatha’s hand found her hip as she turned into her little.

The door opened and neither jumped back but Rio slowly pulled away to look at the arrived Jennifer and found Agatha’s arms snake around her, her temple resting against her cheek as she held her close.

She took in a deep breath and allowed herself to press her nose into Agatha’s hair and breathe her in, closing her eyes into the embrace.

“Interrupting something?”

“No,” Rio said calmly as she sucked in a steadying breath. She felt strong when with her, strongest of all when touching her. No longer unmoored, simply, tethered. “No. Just breakfast.”

Jennifer eyed her suspiciously before her eyes flickered to Agatha and she announced: “If the koala could let you go for a second then we need to get you to set.”

Rio said nothing, deciding she’d only let go when Agatha did. But far from being released she was instead being told in the form of a close whisper: “She’s just pissed she can’t cling to Alice all day.”

This made Rio smile, made her turn her head more into Agatha, made her so dazzled by her gaze that she missed Jen approaching and tugging Agatha back a few inches. “Hey. Work. Let’s go.”

Agatha looked briefly pissed but schooled her face and slapped Jen away to remove herself from her grasp. “They won’t start without me.”

“That isn’t the point.”

Rio was looking back down at the card again rather than focusing in on the argument before her and opened it up to read Nicky’s message once more as she felt a kiss to her cheek and shortly after another but from a different pair of lips.

“I’m here too,” Jen said in an infinitely softer tone than the one she’d just been using on Agatha. “If you need anything.”

Rio looked up and managed to smile at Jennifer who did look, at least as far as Rio could tell, genuine in her offer. By the door Agatha stood waiting for her, that same look of concern on her face again, that same hesitance that appeared every time she left Rio now.

They looked at each other but said nothing as Jen slipped out of the trailer after kissing Alice and Agatha soon followed behind.

With the door closed and Rio and Alice now alone again Rio went to sit back down and ignored the waffles in favour of placing the stem of magenta flowers in a cup of water on the table.

“I know what I said last night,” Alice said cautiously as she moved over to crouch before the table and get in Rio’s sightline. “About not trusting her. And I don’t. I don’t know if I ever will. But it is clear that she loves you. So, I’m no Miguel, but I’ll trust you enough for the both of you, okay?”

Rio placed the card down and rubbed over her face, letting her fingers cover her mouth as she processed for a second before she spoke: “I think we’ll be okay, Alice. Don’t you?”

Alice seemed lost for words for a while, deep in the tranches of her mistrust and her desire to soothe rather than scare. Eventually she nodded.

“You’ll be fine.”

Rio hid her face again, and the morning went on as quietly and as miserably as it always did. She wasn’t called to set at any point, just left to linger. She was Miss Havisham in black leggings and a band tee.

After a couple hours of bothering Alice with her basketball, she took herself off to bed and Alice took herself off to find Jen. Rio wondered as she curled beneath the blankets whether she’d always feel this way.

She had enough friends to have experienced the loss of a parent through other people. Hell, Alice had lost her mom when she was young so she knew what grief looked like.

But grief cannot be understood through a looking glass. Grief can only be understood when it burrowed its way into your life. When Death came knocking and the person you loved answered.

Rio had been half asleep when she’d heard the soft knock on her bedroom door. She’d assumed Alice, but when she’d grunted her permission to enter it was Agatha who’d stepped quietly into the room.

Rio sat, mortified, blinking hurriedly to chase waking.

“Sorry, no one answered the door but I thought… well I thought you’d be in here.”

Rio nodded and ran a hand through her hair, only managing to make it messier than it already was. “I’m not needed for a couple hours so I just-…”

Agatha had stepped closer, had closed the door behind her, Rio gulped. “Can I stay with you? Just for a bit? I have about thirty minutes before they need me again.”

Rio shuffled a little and Agatha took another step closer, her fingers twitching a little at her sides. “Can I…?”

Rio nodded silently, watching Agatha with cautious eyes as she perched on the edge of her bed by her hip. Her back was stiff, her jaw tight, and Rio could feel the nerves radiating off of her even before she reached to take her hand and found her fingers cold from the spring air.

“I’ve had a word with wardrobe and…” Agatha turned their hands over, “if it’s okay with you I’m going to wear your shirt in some scenes.”

Rio frowned, half focused on the fingers now caressing her palm, half on the way Agatha’s eyes remained soft even as her body sat rigid on the edge of the bed, “My shirt?”

“The cowboy one.”

Rio’s heart leapt in her chest and she stared up at Agatha who’d now dropped her gaze and was focusing on the soft movements of her own fingers against Rio’s palm. “I-… why?”

“It’s just in the scenes where we’re being… just lounging around or-…”

“Agatha?”

Agatha looked up slowly and Rio bit her lip, “I gave it to you. It’s yours. You don’t need my permission.”

“I want it.”

Rio nodded slowly. “You have it.”

Agatha dropped her gaze again and Rio watched as her brow furrowed a little and the soft touches against her palm became continuous circles drawn in the centre of it. Rio let it happen for a few more seconds, just Agatha’s circling touch and the silence around them before she asked: “Will you lie with me? I’m so tired and I can’t shake this headache.”

Agatha didn’t even acknowledge the question. She just began to move and like two magnets with opposite poles they moved together until their poles aligned again and Agatha was in the bed behind Rio.

Brown eyes closed as Agatha wrapped herself around her. She felt the chill of her forearm as it rested over her own and wrapped around her middle. She felt the way Agatha’s other arm snuck below her pillow to gain more access. She felt the soft brush of her lips as whispered: “I’ll stay until I have to leave.”

Rio’s little trailer was cold and so even the throw Alice had provided over the bedsheets hadn’t really helped to keep Rio cosy. But Agatha did. Agatha curled around her, pressed close and tight to her body, brought more warmth than made sense given how cold her paler body actually felt.

Agatha’s arms were cool, her nose was cooler still, pressed against the back of her neck. But Rio shivered, not because of the chill, but because Agatha had raised her head slightly and the tip of her nose drew a line across her skin. It was like a provocation to feel, to be back in her body when for days now she’d been so in her head where everything hurt and nothing made sense.

She turned around and into Agatha, and raised her hand to brush back a strand of brown hair from Agatha’s cheek. Agatha looked flushed, and her cheeks felt warm now to the touch.

“Are you comfortable?”

“You know I am.”

“You feel warm.”

“I’m perfect.”

Rio shifted a little and moved her fingers down Agatha’s cheek until she tapped the tip of her nose just once. “Too warm?”

“Rio.”

“Mm?”

“I’m fine. You feel cold.”

“I’m fine. Just tired. I have a headache.” Rio felt her lips twitch in her attempt to smile and watched as Agatha just frowned across at her. She moved her hand away from her face and instead reached behind her to wrap her hair around her fingers and in that way toy with it, tying Agatha to her. Tethering.

“You’ve been eating?”

“Agatha.”

“It’s just a question.”

Rio took a deep breath and watched as Agatha’s lashes fluttered when she exhaled slowly. “I had pollo guisado yesterday. This morning I had one waffle and-…”

“You don’t need to tell me everything.”

Rio actually smiled this time and Agatha smiled too, which drew Rio’s attention to her lips. She shivered again. Agatha tightened her hold on her.

“I’m eating,” Rio sighed out, closing her eyes to reject the temptation. “I promise. I’m just tired.”

“And warm,” Agatha said quietly, and Rio opened her eyes again.

“I knew you were too hot.”

Rio untangled her fingers from Agatha’s hair and was in the process of pulling away and throwing the blankets from them when Agatha made a noise of protest and suddenly they weren’t lying together anymore so much as wrestling in the bed.

It started innocently enough. Agatha simply tugged Rio back and Rio denied her. Then Agatha’s fingers sought the sensitive parts of Rio’s sides that made her squeal. Rio’s body was soon near-convulsing as she writhed around in her attempts to get Agatha away from her.

Laughter filled the little trailer for the first time in days and only when Rio’s cheeks were a deep red and tears were streaming down her face did Agatha relent.

“That! W-was! CRUEL!”

Rio’s arms were crossed over her body, protecting herself from any more vicious attacks. But Agatha looked satiated now. She looked smug and happy and Rio only laughed out a groan as she rolled away from her, only to be chased again but this time with hungry arms instead of prodding fingers.

“Noooooo! Come back!”

Another burst of laughter from Rio and then she gasped.

She was on her back now, panting to the sky. Agatha was over her, her palms down either side of her head and her knees either side of her hips. Agatha looked dazed, hypnotised.

They both stared at each other. Rio feeling warmer than before. The good kind of warm. The right kind. Her head didn’t hurt anymore.

Rio was the first to move, because she couldn’t help herself and Agatha seemed frozen in place. She put her hands on Agatha’s thighs and swallowed thickly as she continued to stare up at her. But Agatha’s eyes had closed, as if Rio’s touch were a trigger. She was breathing out slowly through her mouth, visibly trying to calm herself down.

Before Rio could register anything else, Agatha had moved from above her and was instead moving back to her side, her arm now loosely thrown across her stomach to maintain her hold, but barely.

She’d snuck down to kiss her shoulder and Rio knew it was a denial, but a gentle one.

Grief was undignified so without a hint of shame because she had none left, Rio questioned, “If I asked again, would you kiss me?”

The words hung like a guillotine in the air until Agatha released the tied rope and said: “No.”

Rio closed her eyes and placed her hand on Agatha’s arm, “Is there going to be a time limit to this… this decision?”

“I want to make sure that-…”

“I’ll never be over my dad dying, Agatha.”

“I know.”

“I’ll never be over you.”

Agatha kissed her shoulder again and soon said, “If… if Miguel were still here… would you want to kiss me?”

The answer was yes. It was always yes. Even when she’d been broken and battered by what Agatha had done it had been yes. When she’d taken the time to try to heal before speaking to Agatha it was yes. When she’d been at her worst, at her smallest, at her weakest, yes. Built back up, healed by time and Agatha’s steadiness, yes.

Agatha was inevitable. Wanting her was forever.

But a life where Miguel was alive was one she couldn’t bring herself to speak on. So she said nothing and Agatha only held her a little tighter.

Rio didn’t know how to function anymore. Everything tumbled around in her mind until the ache was back and even the arms around her couldn’t keep it at bay.

“Do you want to talk about it? About your dad?”

Rio shuddered out a breath and Agatha tightened her hold.

“I got too lucky. We were too lucky. Too happy.”

“Rio.”

“I loved him so much and now I… I don’t know where to put it all.”

She turned onto her side sniffing and wiped at her eyes with the side of her fist, feeling Agatha’s hold tighten again, until their bodies were completely flush, until her own breathing felt like Agatha’s.

“It doesn’t have to go anywhere. It hurts so badly because you loved him so well. And he loved you the same.”

Rio sniffed, a big snotty, disgusting noise. Agatha just clung to her like ivy to stone, patient and immovable.

“It was me,” Agatha said after a while, when the only thing that had been breaking the silence were Rio’s sniffles and the sounds of her as she moved against the blankets to wipe at her eyes. “I lied at breakfast the other day. Alice didn’t know. I got Maria to change the schedule. I’ve moved my scenes up so you can do less for as long as possible.”

Rio sniffed, swallowed, made a high-pitched noise with the contraction of her throat.

“You’d didn’t need to do that.”

A warm breath was exhaled across the back of her neck and Rio shivered for it, moving her damp hand down to clutch at Agatha’s where it held her shoulder, below her jaw.

“If it means you get some rest, some time to breathe, then I’m happy to do it.”

Rio sighed quietly, closing her eyes as the battery of her brain began to slow to a steady rhythm again. “That’s better than a car, I suppose.”

She couldn’t see it but she could tell Agatha was smiling when she said: “You still need a new car.”

“I love my car.”

Agatha scoffed a laugh and Rio cracked a smile as she ducked her head to place a wet kiss to Agatha’s hand. “Thank you.”

“What for?”

“Moving the schedule, caring if I have a crappy car.”

“Crappy now, is it?”

“Shut up.”

Rio felt Agatha’s smile this time. She’s pressed her face into her neck and Rio’s heart thrummed so loudly in her chest it drowned out the dull ache of her head.

Rio squeezed her eyes closed and focused on the feel of Agatha, on the warmth of her face, the tight hold of her hand, the curve of her body around her. It was a tether to the person she used to be. The people they used to be.

The couple she hoped they could still be.

Agatha’s time with her was soon up and neither said anything as Agatha moved to turn Rio onto her back, to look down at her with those ocean eyes. The thumping in her head seemed to echo the words “stay, stay, stay”, but her lips couldn’t form them.

So Agatha kissed her cheek, tasting the salty sorrow painted there, and she left without another word.

Rio curled in on herself after that, her headache preventing her from sleeping again.

That afternoon Rio was needed for background. Which meant she was mostly in her pyjamas chosen for her by the costume department. She traipsed about from mark to mark, only really vaguely aware of the action going on around her.

It didn’t matter anyway. She was set dressing more than anything else today. Agatha had apparently made sure of that. Billy was the main focus, had the most lines, was doing the most for the camera. Quill was there too and had attempted to give Rio an awkward hug when she’d first arrived. She’d accepted it only because she was still grateful he hadn’t made a stink about the punch.

Billy kept close to her between setups and seemed to understand that she didn’t really want to chat. Or else, he just really loved to talk. He spoke of a million things and nothing all at once. The noise of it almost drowned out the grief but didn’t help with the constant, dull headache Rio had been suffering from all day.

She called her mom when she got home, after saying goodbye to a reluctant-to-leave Alice. Speaking with Anna helped. Her mom told her of all the casseroles she’d been receiving from neighbours, she asked about filming, whether Rio was eating.

She asked about Agatha.

Even as she lay her head down on her pillow that night and inhaled the persisting scent of Agatha against the pillow her head continued to throb.

 

TUESDAY

Rio didn’t see Agatha all day.

She wasn’t there in the morning and she wasn’t there in the afternoon. It turned out that Agatha had to be on location for some shots and Rio didn’t need to be there. Which meant she spent the day hanging around her trailer in abject misery.

Alice almost punctured the mini basketballs to stop Rio from maniacally tossing them up in the air just for something to do.

Agatha did call though, five times.

Alice spoke to her each time and only on the final call before Rio was released for the day after doing nothing more than waiting around and smiling into the camera for one shot, did she answer.

“Alice can you-…”

“It’s me.”

“Oh,” Agatha uttered quietly, “Rio. How are you?”

“I’m fine.”

“How’s the head?”

“Never had any complaints.”

“That isn’t funny.”

Rio smiled down at her knees but she knew it wasn’t. “It’s fine, just a little sore.”

“Have you been drinking enough?”

Rio rolled her eyes at this, her smile fading pretty quickly. “Yes, Doctor Harkness.”

“It’s just that Alice told me-…”

Rio threw her basketball at Alice’s head. It hit her with a surprising slap for such a small plastic ball.

Alice glowered at her as she interrupted Agatha, “I promise I’m drinking enough water and eating enough food. I’m just tired. I feel like I need a banana bag or something.”

Agatha was silent for a while before she said: “Can I come over tonight? Either just me or with Nicky? I’ll make you whatever you want.”

It was tempting, beyond tempting, but energy was hard to come by these days and all Rio had been thinking about - other than Agatha - was crawling into bed the moment she got home.

“No, I… another time, maybe.”

“Okay.”

Rio could hear the disappointment in Agatha’s voice but before she could say anything else Agatha was speaking again. “I’ve been meaning to ask you. I know it’s a lot and I know it might not sound like-…”

A noise on the other end of the line let her know that Agatha had been distracted, that her attention was now floating away from Rio and the mystery “a lot” question. Rio waited impatiently for her to return and ask it but all she got was: “Rio, I have to go. I’ll see you tomorrow? Will you call if-…?”

“I need anything,” Rio finished for her, twirling her hair around her finger, “Yes. Goodnight, Agatha.”

A noise. A crinkle of static on the line. “I love you.”

Agatha was gone.

 

WEDNESDAY

One of the more unusual things about growing up Catholic was that it brought with it a certain penchant for the superstitious. In essence, superstitions are inherently unCatholic but then Rio was never very pious anyway.

She had an aversion to walking under ladders, she avoided stepping on cracks where possible, and she believed that magpies should be respected. Vocally, if at all possible.

On this particular Wednesday, even after speaking to her mom for almost an hour that morning, she felt worse than she had all week. Alice told her it was because she’d gone to bed hungry again but Rio felt it could only be because Agatha’s lingering scent on the pillow had lingered its last and disappeared entirely.

And of course, another reason was that Wednesday’s child was simply full of woe. Rio had been born on a Friday, born to be loving and giving. And so she’d never paid much mind to Wednesday’s curse. But she gave it attention now, and felt its curse with every step she took towards her trailer-shaped prison cell.

For some unknown reason, she’d woken up with the words repeating over and over in her head until they became an ear worm that buried deeper and deeper the longer the day went on.

Wednesday’s child is full of woe.

Perhaps it was her brain’s way of distracting her from the constant thoughts of her dad. Perhaps it was her brain’s way of having a little joke, of telling her today would be a bad day - not unlike any of the other days she’d been having recently.

A poem she’d heard as a child, come back to haunt her as an adult. No amount of Hail Mary’s would absolve her of this burden.

So Rio spent the morning with her one line of poetry, her little basketballs, and her little Alice.

Jen had stopped by around ten to announce that Agatha was tied up shooting but that she would come over at lunchtime. She looked like she was delivering the news under duress but managed to smile at Rio anyway.

By the time Rio had run out of energy for the day and her ear worm remained happily swimming around like the harbinger of doom it was, she was more than ready to be left alone to sleep.

The usual happened. Alice left her to find Jen and Rio tucked herself in in the hopes that Agatha would soon arrive and soon wrap her cold arms around her and silence her new, repetitive friend.

Only when Rio was eventually woken it was by a hand that felt different to Agatha’s, though no less cold.

“Dear, don’t you think it’s time you joined your friends?”

Rio blinked heavily, rubbing quickly at her eyes as if to hurry her waking as she sat with some difficulty amongst the pile of blankets on the bed.

“Lilia.”

“We’ve missed you, you know. You’ve made quite the impact across the hearts and minds of our little group.”
