Rio frowned and ran a hand through her hair, once again making it messier than it had been before. “What do you-…?”

“Come! Have lunch with us. I know it’s hard but it’ll help, I promise.”

Rio groaned quietly and if it had been Billy or anyone else she’d have refused but Lilia had a way about her. A stern but fair matriarch who wouldn’t take ‘no’ for an answer - especially when she thought ‘no’ was the wrong answer.

So Rio extracted herself from the bed and after briefly checking herself over in the mirror she grabbed a light sweater and followed Lilia over to craft services where she found what looked like the whole production taking their lunch.

Since the funeral it was more people than Rio had seen in one space. She felt shy suddenly and shrunk in on herself as people greeted her, some with genuinely happy faces and some with that awful pitying look she’d never get used to.

Full of woe. Full of woe.

Rio went up to get a plate of food, not paying much attention to what she was ordering but just knowing she should eat something so she grabbed a bag of Oreos for good measure and went to take her place beside Billy.

It felt awkward. Incredibly so. But Billy was on a roll about a date he’d been on the previous night and Lilia kept throwing comments her way to encourage her to join in and so soon it all felt… normal.

Her ear worm went silent.

She was halfway through her food when she caught sight of the one person missing from this gathering. Agatha had hurried into view, looking, as far as Rio could tell, panicked.

She straightened slightly as if the extra inch or two would help Agatha to spot her. Inevitably, it did.

Agatha strode over, almost knocking one of the background artist’s trays out of their hands. The actor looked mortified to have been in Agatha’s way but Agatha barely batted an eyelash as she made a beeline for Rio.

“I-… was looking for you.”

Rio nodded silently, staring up into wide eyes even as Lilia stood and held her hand out to Agatha.

“Sit, sit. I stole Rio away to get her out of her little nest.”

Rio smiled meekly up at Agatha as she moved over to sit down diagonally opposite her. It felt strange now to have her so close but not be in touching distance. And seeing her around other people, sitting at craft services when Rio was pretty sure Agatha would rather be caught dead than here under any other circumstances… it felt surreal.

Rio picked up an Oreo from her plate and handed it across to her. It was a peace offering. A, “sorry I wasn’t where you expected me to be and you panicked”, offering. Agatha eyed it for a second and then took it. As she bit into it Lilia said: “Lovely! We’re all together. Isn’t this wonderful?”

Rio had been too busy watching Agatha nibble at the cookie to notice that Lilia was expecting a response.

“Oreos are delicious,” Rio said with a smile, watching as Agatha took an age to chew her first mouthful.

“They’re disgusting and full of crap,” Agatha retorted only a second before she took her next bite.

“Then why are you eating it?”

“Oh,” Lilia said with a grin, “I think we all know the answer to that, Rio Vidal.”

Rio raised her brows and turned to Lilia and out of the corner of her eye she could see Agatha, blushing through her frown as she made the Oreo finally disappear.

Rio flailed for words until Billy put her out of her misery and said: “Do you usually eat in your trailer, Agatha? I haven’t seen you here before. Maybe, maybe we could do alternate trailer lunches or something!”

Rio had to fight her smile as she saw Agatha’s eyes swivel to Billy and look across at him like he had suggested they have a giant orgy or something. To save her answering Rio handed her another cookie.

“Anyway,” Lilia interrupted gallantly, “isn’t it dear little Nicky’s birthday soon?”

Agatha was watching Rio as she bit the Oreo in half and it was when they locked eyes again that Rio suddenly had a thought. A curious one born of that strange pull towards the superstitious.

“What day were you born?”

Agatha raised her brows, “April twenty first.”

“Taurus,” Lilia said perceptively, “Stubborn, loyal, steadfast, attuned to the physical.”

Agatha shot Lilia a glare but Rio just ignored her.

“No, I mean, I know that.” Rio cleared her throat, she’d known Agatha’s birthday years before she’d even met her. “What day.”

Agatha’s face relaxed again as she turned back to Rio and she watched her in thought for a second before she said: “A Wednesday. Why?”

Rio couldn’t help the gasp that escaped her lips and for a second she malfunctioned, her brain sputtered to a halt and then became a kamikaze.

Full of woe. Full of woe.

“Rio?” Agatha was moving now, coming round the other side of the table to crouch down by Rio’s side. Agatha’s hand rested on the table to support herself and her other sat on the small of Rio’s back.

“It’s nothing. Sorry, just this-… nothing.”

Full of woe. Full of woe.

She turned and forced a smile at Agatha, seeing the concern swimming in blue-green irises, and Lilia spoke up again: “Children born on Wednesday are typically intelligent, good and quick learners, gifted in the art of persuasion, again, loyal-…”

Had she known this already? Had she somehow deduced the day of Agatha’s birth? Had her broken, wretched brain been repeating ‘Agatha, Agatha, Agatha’ to her all day and she’d not even been aware?

She swallowed, turning her head from Agatha beside her but placed her shaking hand over hers on the table.

“Thank you, Lilia. I… was just curious, that’s all.”

Agatha’s fingers twitched below her own but she knew she wasn’t about to pull away. She took a breath as Lilia watched her curiously and the hand on her back began to draw soft circles there.

“Do you want my seat, Agatha?”

Rio kept her gaze on Lilia who seemed to be thinking quite hard about something as she felt Agatha and Billy swap places and suddenly the hand that had been on her back was now on her thigh instead.

“The old nursery rhyme?”

Rio blushed a little and nodded at the old woman. “Just… had it in my head all day. I’m not sure why.”

Agatha, Agatha, Agatha.

Lilia hummed as Rio reached below the table to take Agatha’s hand.

“Nursery rhymes, small poems, songs, ditties, are passed down usually from mothers to children. They’re short and repetitive, they rhyme, all so they can be remembered and given to the next generation. We get comfort from them because they remind us of our mothers, of our childhood.”

“Um,” Agatha said suddenly, “What nursery rhyme?”

Rio cleared her throat and squeezed Agatha’s hand, “Monday’s Child.”

“I don’t know it.”

Rio sighed quietly and turned in her seat to look at Agatha. It felt ridiculous that this was happening, that she’d made a big deal out of an errant line from a random poem that every child in America had inadvertently memorised without even meaning to.

Every child except one.

“It goes through the days and each day… each day is a different thing.”

Agatha arched a brow and Rio knew it was an encouragement to finish her thought.

“Wednesday’s child,” she said in a softer tone than before, “is full of woe.”

Agatha nodded slowly, because it was what you did when people told you a fact, even if you didn’t believe it. A flicker of surprise had sparked in blue eyes and then died just as quickly as it was born. Clearly she didn’t put any power behind children’s poems, clearly her miserable, Presbyterian upbringing held no space for silly things such as superstition or poetry.

Her mother had no love in her heart and no desire to pass down joy, love, poetry of any kind to her child.

Full of woe. Full of woe. Agatha. Agatha.

Rio was choking on the line now, feeling it cut off the oxygen needed to feed the worm in her brain. But Agatha was looking at her steadily, ignorant of the reason for Rio’s reaction and therefore calming it.

“Okay,” she said in a tone just as soft as Rio’s. “And what day were you born?”

Agatha was placating her, she knew it when she heard it. She knew it by the soft upturn of her soft lips, of the way she squeezed her hand in secret. But it helped, it made it seem not embarrassingly silly but just… silly silly.

“Friday.”

“And that is?”

“Loving and giving.”

Agatha smirked and reached to steal another Oreo as if to play it off. “That right?”

Rio laughed, and in doing so freed her throat, and swallowed down the air she needed to think straight. Agatha had breathed sense and life into her. She moved their joined hands into Agatha’s lap so she could release her hand and wrap her fingers around her thigh instead. Agatha pushed her hand a little further up and shot her a look as her lips closed around the Oreo.

“Feeling better?”

Rio hadn’t held Agatha like this in so long. She hadn’t felt the thrill that came from being allowed to, from allowing herself to. The dull ache in her head seemed to vanish as she smiled at Agatha and Wednesday’s child began to glow.

“Oh I think she is,” Lilia answered for her and Rio huffed in response and stole the other half of Agatha’s Oreo.

Where belief and faith merged in Rio’s mind, everything came down to the turn of Agatha’s lips as she watched her, the feel of the fingers now tracing along the back of her hand, the warmth of her thigh.

The tether tugged. The tether transformed. A road now. A road to Damascus.

“So lunch,” Billy conjectured, feeling left out of the conversation and trying to turn it back to the most important issue here: could he get an invite to Agatha’s trailer. “We’ll swap lunchtimes in everyone’s trailers?”

Rio smiled a little as Lilia picked up the loose threads of conversation and went back to picking at her food, aware only of the absent ear worm and the warmth of her fingers curled around Agatha’s thigh.

Her headache had dissolved; whether from eating a full meal or having Agatha so close she couldn’t be sure. But it was gone and Rio felt far from the woe she’d been focused on all day.

Time with Agatha could only last so long and soon she had to leave to go back to hair and makeup ahead of filming. With a quick kiss to the cheek and a soft squeeze of her shoulder she disappeared from them and Rio watched her go, feeling Lilia’s gaze on her the whole time.

Eventually Alice found her and told her they were free to go home early so Rio gathered her things from her trailer and followed Alice out to her car.

She dropped her off and Rio lounged around the rest of the afternoon, called her mom, made herself a small dinner, developed another headache, and went to bed at nine, all poetry and rhymes gone from her brain.

 

THURSDAY

Rio’s headache was still present by the time she woke and it took a long while for her to force herself from her bed and into the shower. The only saving grace was that the poem that had haunted her steps yesterday was a distant memory now, shrouded by grief again.

She knew Alice would already be downstairs so she tried to rush herself. She tried to go faster, to make her body move. But the weakness was back despite everything she’d done to try to prevent it.

She’d been right about Alice. Her coffee was poured and Alice had a smile on her face, but still, that enduring pain.

The journey to set was quiet again. Only when they were in the trailer and Rio was checking her sides for the day - a small number, she saw she’d be in a scene with Agatha - did Alice begin to talk.

“So,” she said and Rio could her the nerves in her voice even as she placed her sides down and began to peel away the foil of the bagel left for her on the side. “Jen and I were wondering,” she cleared her throat as Rio took a bite, “if you’d want to come over for dinner soon?”

Rio was glad she’d taken a mouthful of food because it gave her time to process rather than just giving a flat ‘no’. She swallowed heavily and cleared her throat, “Oh?”

“We think it’d be good if-…”

“Would Agatha be there?”

“No,” Alice uttered cautiously, “We’d do it separately. You, and then Agatha and Nicky another night.”

Rio nodded and picked a bit of bacon from her bagel. “Okay. Sure.”

“Really?”

Rio nodded again, picking now at the bread, “Yes. Nice. Normal. Things going back to normal. All good.”

Was the bacon she’d just swallowed lodged in her throat? It felt like it was. She cleared her throat twice but found it wasn’t moving. Something was stuck there, hard and insistent. Her eyes began to water for the feel of it, for the feeling of being choked.

“You okay there, babe?”

“Fine,” Rio husked out, slapping her chest and coughing. “Just… something stuck.”

Alice moved over and instead of providing the Heimlich like Rio thought she should she instead sat down beside her and rubbed Rio’s back. “Things going back to normal don’t mean… don’t mean that we’ll forget Miguel, Rio. Or you. We won’t forget you either, okay?”

Rio gasped as though she’d been actually unable to breathe and Alice threw her arms around her as she began to cry. It was the first time in three days now. The tears fell as if they’d been waiting for the dam to burst: thick and numerous.

Alice held her through it until Rio’s headache was so bad she had to crawl into bed and her bagel sat forgotten and cold on the side. The only thing Alice could do was to leave pain relief and water on the side and go to find the First AD to ensure they had enough time for Rio to sleep off some of her misery before she had to show up and do her job.

Rio could afford an hour to sleep. After that, she was up again, and Alice was ushering her to hair and makeup. Her reception was as cheery as usual and Rio fumbled her way through the small talk whilst clutching her water bottle as if hydration were her big issue.

Costume was much the same. Stevie was waiting for her with her costume in her trailer and she made the same small talk with her as handed her her reindeer sweater and sweatpants to change into. She helped, too, with her jewellery. The final piece of it being the ring Agatha had picked for her.

The hold of it around her finger was, this time, somewhat of a comfort.

Her task today was to sit on the couch reading until Agatha arrived and took precedence over her book. It was easy. She had no lines. She just had to sit, pretend to read, wait for Agatha to come, and hold her close when she did.

It was a travesty she had to even be on set. But Agatha would be there and in between set ups she might even be able to hold her a little longer.

Agatha was behind the dolly cam talking to Maria when Rio arrived. She was in her own costume: a burgundy plaid shirt and jeans. Her sleeves were rolled up to her elbows and her hair was in a messy bun. And Rio realised how much she missed her in the first two seconds of seeing her.

Her head hurt a little more and she sipped at her water as she was taken over to the couch and situated by the First AD. It didn’t take long for her presence to be noticed by others too and it was Pepper who made it to her before either Agatha or Maria.

“Rio! How are you? I’m so sorry to hear about your dad.”

Rio smiled and nodded, taking the book that an assistant was now handing her. “Thanks, Pepper.”

Unfortunately for her, the kind blonde dropped down to her knees before where she sat on the couch. “If you need to talk, I’m here for you. And if any of the work you’ll be doing now feels-…”

Rio heard her name suddenly and turned her head to see Agatha marching towards them, looking less than happy that Pepper was there. She looked even less happy that Pepper had her hand on Rio’s knee.

“I mean it, Rio.” Pepper said with a soft smile as she turned back to her. “Anything you need, okay? I’ll let Agatha take care of you for now.” And to Rio’s surprise just as Agatha arrived Pepper winked and stood to leave.

“Agatha!” Pepper was beaming and held her arms open but Agatha ignored them and did a perfect pirouette to sit down beside Rio’s thigh on the edge of the couch.

“Pepper.”

She found Rio’s hand, turned it over, linked their fingers.

“Now, I’ll be in video village if anything comes up. But simple scene. Rio, we’ve discussed it already but Agatha-…”

“Consider the intimacy coordinated,” Agatha replied drolly. Rio squeezed her hand.

“Right,” Pepper said, clearly still struggling with how to deal with Agatha. “Well, anything you need!”

Rio smiled as she left and glanced at Agatha’s profile as someone came over to adjust her hair, “You can be nicer to her, you know?”

“I hate being told how to-…”

Agatha huffed and didn’t finish her thought because they were surrounded now. Maria had arrived too and was finishing off orders, making sure everyone knew their shots, that Agatha was on her mark, that Rio was draped on the couch just so.

There was safety in being told what to do. Comfort in it. So Rio allowed herself not to think, to sink into her body as best she could, to let Maria tap each of her limbs into place. Only it didn’t last long. Agatha was back over and instead of tapping she was holding, touching, guiding.

“Here,” she instructed, moving Rio until she was more satisfied with her position. Maria looked a little put out but given the state of her relationship with Agatha after their lunch date fiasco, she said nothing.

Rio only kept her gaze on Agatha’s face, pleased the makeup artists had painted her minimally so she could count every freckle on her nose as she finished her adjustments.

“I can slot in easier this way.”

Rio only nodded, only met Agatha’s gaze with a semi-smile, and then watched her as she left.

She raised her book, tried to relax her tired body and waited for ‘action’.

The scene was so simple. Dani was reading, Kate entered all het up and annoyed. She took a seat against her wife, let her envelope her, let her calm her. Dani simply read around her, held Kate close, soothed her just by being there.

The parallels weren’t lost on Rio as action was called and she pretended to read. Agatha soon arrived, not quite huffing but certainly in the region of it. She raised her gaze, raised her brows, watched in slight amusement as Agatha made herself at home between her thighs, in her arms.

She sighed as Agatha turned her head against her jaw, as she positioned herself so she could continue to read.

“Cut!”

Rio arched a brow and heard Agatha grumble but not sit up.

“Back to one!”

Rio laughed as Agatha actually huffed and threw herself off the couch to march back.

They went again, this time Agatha made a show before she sat down. She looked down at Rio until she looked up and shot her a scowl before she dramatically slumped into her and this time grabbed her hand and held it against her stomach.

It was a better take, a more character-driven take.

Rio placed a kiss to her temple, squeezed her hand, and breathed out heavily, making a show of being calm even around her grumpy wife.

They did this several more times. Each time Agatha changed it up. Each time Agatha brought something new to the dynamic. She kissed Rio’s jaw, she pressed into her neck, she placed her hand under her sweater.

Each time Rio just had to react, just had to follow Agatha. Each time she felt better and better about what she was doing. She wasn’t just acting with Agatha anymore. She was acting with one of the greats, with one of the best.

Every single take was new. Rio didn’t know what Agatha was going to do. Maria tried for direction but Agatha never took it. She adjusted it, even if she did. She made it her own.

She raised a hand to Rio’s cheek when Maria had called for less touching. She sighed heavily when Maria had called for a smile. She curled her legs up when Maria wanted them lying down.

But every time it worked. All the takes were useable because Agatha knew what she was doing and Rio knew how to react to her.

Eventually, they were done. Rio was dismissed for the day and Agatha was kept back for more shots. They parted with a quick but close hug and as Rio stepped off the set she felt the return of her pain.

It was when she arrived home that night that her evening routine of Anna, food, bed, was interrupted. She’d been about to turn off the lights, about to try and sleep, when her phone had lit up.

Usually she’d ignore it. She’d barely been on it for days now. But Wanda’s name shone bright up at her and for some unknown reason she answered.

“Wanda. Hey.

“Hey, you. Is there a reason you’ve been avoiding me?”

“Wands, I really haven’t-…”

“I know, sweetheart. Look, I’m so sorry about your dad. I really am. I can’t even imagine-…” she sighed and Rio rubbed at her temple, “Look. Alice said you don’t really want to talk but I have to do press in New York next week so I’ll be in Boston at the weekend and well, I’ve colluded with Alice to get us tickets to the Celtics game.”

Rio laughed a little and stretched her neck back. It was good to talk to someone separate from the misery, someone who was happy to speak to her regardless. “And why would you do that?”

“Selfishly? Because I want to see you. Unselfishly? Because you need a friend.”

Rio hummed, “I’m not sure I’m in the mood to be-…”

“Look, your usual seat. As much alcohol as I can get into you. And afterwards I’ve dinner booked for us and Jessica, she wants to see you too. It’ll be nice, quiet, fun. It’ll take your mind off of things. Say you’ll come.”

Rio groaned this time but nodded and only realised she hadn’t said anything when Wanda asked: “Babe? You there? You gonna come? Support your team and make your friend happy?”

Rio laughed, “Yes. Yes to both. I’ll come.”

“Good because I’ve already paid for your flight out on Saturday morning. Alice got your hotel, so you owe me one drink and Alice maybe two.”

Rio scoffed but somewhere in her chest she felt a slither of light seeping through the darkness. “You’re forcing me to Boston?”

“Well, asking, technically… but! I’d really like you to come. We don’t have to go to the game if you’re not up to it. Come see me, come see Jessica. We can have a few drinks, you can cry and I can be the shoulder you cry on. Say yes.”

Rio groaned again as she stared up at the dark ceiling above her. “Yes, okay. I promise I’ll come.”

“Good. I’ve emailed across your flights so just show up at the right time and I’ll see you at the hotel.”

Rio sighed as she rubbed her face, “I’m really not-…”

“I’m not asking you to be your usual party animal self. I’m just asking you to show up, okay? We can take it easy or go as hard as you want. Whatever you feel like.”

The idea of escaping for a day or two was appealing. She couldn’t outrun herself but perhaps she could outdrink herself. Maybe even shout so loud at the game she lost her voice and would no longer have to make small talk with people offering their condolences.

“Okay, Wanda. I’ll be there.”

“Good. Sleep tight. I’ll see you in a couple days.”

Rio hung up. Sleep didn’t come for her that night. Something else did. Something that felt different to her usual misery. Something that settled in the pit of her stomach and crept all the way to the base of her throat.

 

FRIDAY

“Up!”

Rio groaned and rolled over in the bed, trying to escape Alice’s grabbing hands.

“Last day then your trip. Come on. You sleep at work anyway.”

“Kept that quiet,” Rio accused groggily.

“It’s a good surprise! A nice one.”

Rio huffed and the morning didn’t go much better from then on. Rio’s headache was worse than ever and she couldn’t figure out why. She’d been drinking plenty of water, she’d eaten a normal amount the day before, she’d not even had any alcohol.

And still she suffered. She wondered if it were her grief, making the journey from her heart to her head to spread the pain so she could withstand it. But she’d long since decided that her body couldn’t control itself at the moment. Her brain and her heart just did what they wanted.

The trip to work, as usual, was silent, and Rio was more grateful for it today than ever because her head was still sore, still all over the place, still drowning in her grief.

In the trailer she found her ball and didn’t even bother to check her sides before she went about throwing and catching it, making Alice scowl and her brain quieten.

After a while Alice prompted her to go to costume, to hair and makeup, and eventually to set. She was to spend the morning taking publicity shots. This usually involved being posed in various embarrassing positions but by some act of grace from God, she was simply sat or stood by a Christmas tree having to look various degrees of melancholic. This, she knew, she could do.

When she was done and back in her sweats in her trailer she took up her usual position with her little ball again and went about the rest of the morning annoying Alice with it.

But ten minutes after they’d arrived back there was a soft knock at the door and Alice went to answer it.

“Hi Alice.”

Rio froze where she was on the couch and looked up to see Agatha standing about two foot down below Alice.

“Can I come in?”

Rio sat up straight, actually thinking about her posture for the first time that day - which was saying something because she’d been on camera for four hours that morning.

Alice made a noncommittal noise and stepped back so Agatha could enter and Rio forgot how to breathe. Agatha looked nervous. No, she looked terrified. Her hands looked tight by her sides and her jaw was working overtime as she stepped into the centre of the room and stopped just before the coffee table.

“Hey.”

Rio raised her brows and cleared her throat. “Are you okay?”

“I’ve been meaning to ask you all week but-…” Agatha looked at Alice, “I was worried you’d say no but Nicky really wants you to come and-…”

Agatha took a deep breath and the look on her face made Rio’s head sear with a sudden pain unlike any she’d felt all week. But there Agatha was, looking more like she was standing before the gallows than before Rio.

“I don’t want to pressure you. I don’t want… I… I’m sorry I’ve left it so late. It’s Nicky’s birthday tomorrow and he wants you to come to the Celtics game with us.”

Rio looked down and wondered if she’d ever felt the hair stand on edge at the back of her neck before. Because she certainly felt it now.

She reached behind herself to rub at it, to try and calm her racing heart, her rising levels of panic, the thrum, thrum, thrum of her throbbing head.

“Actually,” she breathed out after a few seconds, “I’m already going.”

She watched as Agatha raised her brows and looked to Alice before looking back to Rio. “You are?”

Rio cleared her throat and looked for the first time to Alice since Agatha had entered the room. She looked tense, as if ready to spring if Rio gave her the instruction. But far from asking her to attack she instead motioned with her head to the door in a silent plea for Alice to leave them alone. When she did, she did so only after shooting Rio a meaningful ‘I’ll be right outside’ look.

Rio sighed when the door closed and looked back to Agatha. Quick was best. Quick and easy. Like ripping off a bandaid.

“Don’t read into it, okay? I-… I’m going with Wanda.”

Any meteorologist worth their salt could tell you the differences between a regular thunderstorm and a cyclone, of which they are varied and myriad. But one of the main differences is the time it takes for the storms to brew.

A thunderstorm, for instance, is formed quickly from rapidly rising air and matriculates into a storm within minutes, or hours. A cyclone is different and can be left to steep for weeks before it’s strong enough to explode into the atmosphere and reap destruction in its path.

Agatha looked a lot like she was the latter as she span on the spot and those pale hands raised to run through hair which suddenly looked wild, suddenly thicker, longer, as if the static radiating from her anger had inspired it.

Rio knew Agatha had her problems with Wanda, knew she always had, and so this explosion had been building and building and suddenly Rio was in the eye of the storm.

“Agatha.”

The woman before her was taking deep breaths, still turned from her, still with those fingers buried deep in the thickets of her wavy hair.

“Agatha. We’re just friends. I haven’t seen her for a while now and-…”

“Are you staying over? In Boston? With Wanda?”

Each preceding question felt harsher than the last. And Rio cleared her throat as she stared at Agatha’s back. Agatha had only be soft with her lately. Only so soft something she felt like she’d melt in Rio’s hold.

And now she was a raging inferno, now she was hard and angry and Rio had to swallow down her panic at the sight of it.

“Yes.”

Rio looked down at her hands then, unable to look at Agatha anymore, to cope with her being so angry she was practically incandescent.

“We’re having dinner with Jessica after the game and-…”

“Who the fuck is Jessica?!”

Rio inhaled a sharp breath and looked up to see the storm billowing in bright eyes. “Jessica Dyson. She was nominated with us. She-…”

Agatha made a noise and threw her hands in the air and just like that she began to pace. Rio squinted at her and tried to focus to avoid the lights beginning to blind her as she felt a piercing pain her in temples.

“We’re all just friends.”

Her vision blurred and for a second she couldn’t see anything but a flash of light. The room was silent for a while and Rio brought her head to her hands. Closing her eyes didn’t help.

“Jen told me what Alice said to you.”

“Pardon?”

“She told me she encouraged you to get under someone. Is that what this is? Wanda? Jessica?” Agatha made a noise that sounded a lot like she was choking. “Both of them?!”

Everything felt hazy, everything felt too much, too real. It was as if someone had turned the saturation up suddenly.

Her head was throbbing and even as she tried to look up at Agatha she felt like she couldn’t see her, so bright were the lights in her trailer. “Agatha I don’t… Agatha I don’t feel…” the earth tilted on its axis until hands were on her and a familiar scent filled her lungs.

“Hey, hey. I’ve got you.”

Rio squeezed her eyes shut and took several deep breaths until the sharpness dulled a little and she opened her eyes to see the storm in blue eyes was now dissipated. All that was left behind was the destruction to show that it had once been there, had once been great and terrible.

And now was soft and small.

“What’s wrong? What happened?”

“I’m not sleeping with Wanda. I won’t sleep with Wanda. Or Jessica. I-… Agatha there was one kiss, one tiny, inconsequential kiss that happened-…”

Agatha pulled away and their tether that had just become a lifeline became taught and frayed. But it held on.

“Agatha.”

She was pacing now, her shoulders high and her fingers tight. “When?”

“Agatha.”

“Tell me when.”

Rio shook her head and snapped, “Two days after you fucked your husband.” She winced at the strength of her own voice and placed her head in her hands again.

That made Agatha stop. That made her turn. That made the temperature in the room drop a couple degrees.

Agatha’s face was, for the first time in a while, unreadable. Juilliard had done a number on her; she was acting her way out of a breakdown.

Agatha’s irises were storm-born as she stared at Rio but she couldn’t quite make their eyes meet. Agatha wasn’t allowing her to. She just kept staring straight ahead, keeping her gaze on Rio’s right shoulder. The storm and its warning had dissolved again until Agatha asked in a quiet voice: “Punishment?”

“Agatha.”

Rio sat up a little, the warning flash of a migraine threatening her still. But she squinted through it and managed to raise a hand towards Agatha, “Can you come here?”

Agatha hesitated, looked as if she might refuse for a second, and then took strides closer and stopped just before Rio, allowing the tips of Rio’s fingers to only just graze the line of her pants. “It wasn’t punishment. I’d never punish you. She just… wanted to kiss me. So I let her. Just once. It was barely anything and it’ll never happen again.”

The floating colours began to form behind her eyelids every time she blinked and she knew she didn’t have long.

“Agatha, please. I-…”

Agatha stepped closer and Rio could slide her fingers until they curled around her hip. She raised her other hand and found it missed Agatha’s body entirely, her vision now so skewed she had no real depth perception.

“Rio,” Agatha whispered, moving closer again so that this time Rio’s hand didn’t miss. She gripped Agatha’s hips and raised her gaze up to look at her but saw only a fuzzy version of the woman.

“I don’t want anyone else. Haven’t I…? Haven’t I made that clear?”

Agatha’s hands found her face and Rio closed her eyes, now seeing the flashes behind her eyelids.

“There’s nothing between you?”

Rio sighed quietly, trying to focus on the soft brush of Agatha’s soft thumbs, “No.”

Silence filled the room for a little while and Rio tightened her told, trying desperately to see through the colours now swirling, now flashing their promise of more pain at her.

“Are you courtside? I want to be with Nicky on his birthday. I…” she winced and Agatha dropped to her knees.

“What is it?”

“A migraine, I think. It’s just stress. Just-…”

“Come to bed, Rio.” Agatha was whispering now, but Rio couldn’t figure out why. It was just the two of them. Just the them in the small trailer. No one could overhear.

“You need to be in the dark,” Agatha continued quietly, now tugging at Rio to make her stand. And Rio moved with her, she closed her eyes and trusted Agatha would guide her.

When the soft feel of the bed behind her knees let her know she was there safely she lay back and felt Agatha remove her shoes and socks. Her lips pressed against the bridge of her foot and then Agatha was moving above her again, helping to tuck her in.

“I’m fine,” Rio insisted even as she squeezed her eyes tightly shut and felt the lights ricochet about her skull. “Agatha.”

Unable to concentrate properly she couldn’t place the noises now happening around her but when she opened her eyes the room had been plunged into blackness. A small dip in the mattress beside her meant that Agatha was close again and she squeezed her eyes shut when she heard her whisper: “I’ll be good tomorrow. I’ll be good.”

“Mi amor.”

“Sleep, Rio. I’ll get you some pain relief and-…”

“Agatha it was barely a kiss.”

“I know.”

“Focus on sleeping. Nicky will be disappointed if you’re not there. I want you there.”

Rio nodded blindly and reached out, managing to curl her fingers around Agatha’s shirt. “We’re just friends.”

Agatha inhaled slowly and then: “And I can be nice to your friend. I promise.”

Rio nodded and found it hurt to do so. Agatha moved back, she pressed a kiss to where it hurt most on Rio’s temple and then Rio felt the bed shift and she was suddenly alone again.

Sleep didn’t come easy but it came. Only a gentle hand in her shoulder and a soft voice nearby woke her two hours after she’d fallen.

“Rio.”

Rio groaned quietly, feeling the tension around her brain as she became more aware. The lights were gone; it was dark behind her eyelids.

“Honey, I’ve got you some drugs. You want to wake up and take them?”

“Better be the strong stuff.”

She heard Agatha snort quietly, “As strong as it comes.”

Rio groaned quietly and rubbed at her eyes.

“Feeling better?”

“A little fuzzy but okay.”

“Take it anyway. It’ll help.”

Rio huffed as she struggled to sit and held her hand out to receive the small pill Agatha offered. “Thanks.”

She took the water held out to her too and knocked back the pill with it and grimaced as it slipped down her oesophagus. Agatha was watching her with caution in her eyes and it took her a second to register something else about the woman perched beside her.

She was wearing her shirt.

“You’re filming in it today?”

“Yeah. Laundry scene.”

Rio smiled a little, reached to touch the collar and remembered the scene from the script. “With James?”

“Sí.”

Rio laughed and the grimaced when she found it hurt her to do so. She dropped her hand from Agatha’s shirt. “He as much energy as usual?”

“I’m working on it.”

“Magic touch?”

“Something like that.”

Rio nodded and bit down on the corner of her lip as Agatha met her gaze. They both went to speak at the same time and both smiled shyly at the other as they did.

“About earlier-…” / “I’ll get him-…”

“You first,” Rio offered gently, “I was just going to say about Nicky’s gift.”

Agatha eyed her for a second and the said: “I don’t like her. I don’t trust her. I don’t like her near you and I don’t think…” she sighed heavily as Rio’s brow began to furrow and her hand found its way to Agatha’s collar again. “I don’t think… I just… I don’t want-…”

“Agatha? We’re just friends. I said yes to Wanda because it’s an escape. It’s a weekend off. A weekend away.” She thumbed the thin fabric of the shirt and looked down at it. Agatha had been styled with a necklace to match, one with a small diamond on it and Rio reached to touch it, “But I’m glad you’ll be there. Unbelievably so.”

Maybe she was bothering Agatha by toying with her necklace because Agatha reached to take her hand and in doing so stilled her fingers. “It was a push present,” she said quietly, “from Dani to Kate.”

Rio raised her brows and with it her gaze to look up at Agatha, “For having Luca?”

Agatha nodded and Rio looked back down at the little diamond and for a second her mind went blank before she asked: “Did Ralph get you one?”

“Three months on my own.”

Rio cleared her throat and shifted a little closer. The dull ache in her temple had dissipated now, replaced by the familiar ache in her chest. “Dani’s a good wife.”

“I think you’d be better.”

The lifeline became a tightrope then. The way ahead, tethered together or not, was treacherous, but they were all that held the other up.

A soft gasp escaped Rio’s lips as she looked back at Agatha and saw her eyes swimming with unshed tears. She reached to brush her cheek but Agatha was already pulling away, already standing from the bed and clearing her throat loudly.

“Alice is just outside I’ll-…”

“Agatha.”

Agatha was making strides to the door and only stopped when: “Mi vida.”

Rio crawled out of the covers and knelt at the bottom of the bed, as close to Agatha as she could be without stepping off. “Can I kiss you? Please?”

Agatha Harkness had her head against the door, her hand curled around the handle, and a tear falling silently down her cheek as Rio waited patiently for her to turn.

It took a few seconds but Agatha did turn. She turned and moved close so that Rio could lean up and grapple at Agatha’s hips as her face was held and tilted skywards. Agatha looked torn, halfway between agony and hope.

As Rio’s fingers slipped beneath the shirt that used to belong to her Agatha leant down and pressed a kiss to Rio’s warm cheek. She gasped as she leant into her, breathed out her woe against her, and then left.

Chapter End Notes

Guess we’re all off to a ball game soon ???

Chapter 40: Dropping The Ball

Chapter Summary

A basketball game in Boston.

Chapter Notes

Wanda fans! Your fav is back.

Wanda haters! Your enemy is back.

See the end of the chapter for more notes

The flight out was nightmarish.

Rio was alone in the airport apart from the photographers who seemed to organically spawn everywhere she turned before she got airside. Even when through security she could feel cameras aimed at her from the unsubtle fans who pointed their phones in her direction.

She kept her head down, her headphones in, and even the classic disguise of a celebrity trying to be subtle - a cap - on the whole time. Clearly an Oscar now meant she was fair game to anyone she came across.

She was approached by a handful of people in the queue to board and as quickly and politely as she could she took selfies with them. Only when a woman offered her condolences for her dad did she feel truly uncomfortable about this.

It was kindly meant, and politely done, but still a stranger speaking her dad’s name to her felt like an intrusion. Smiling, she’d thanked her, posed for the selfie, and returned to having her head down and her music back on.

After boarding, the first steward to greet her also offered his sympathies and Rio couldn’t help but feel queasy as he reached for her hand and squeezed it. For years now people had known her name, or at least recognised her face and asked, “do I know you from somewhere?”. Occasionally she’d had her arm grabbed or people stand too close for pictures, but people didn’t often take her hand, or reference her parents by name.

Clearly things were different now. She was public property.

She thought of Agatha as she buckled herself in and switched her music to something more mind-numbing, all sounds and no words. Agatha Harkness had had her name in lights for at least as long as Rio could remember.

She’d been seventeen when she’d first been aware of Agatha, and she was creeping ever-closer to thirty three now. Half her life Agatha had been famous. And because of Evanora, Agatha had been a name people knew since her birth.

In spending time with Agatha and Nicky she’d seen how intense the response to her was. In being on the red carpet with her she’d seen how desperate the press were for her photograph, for her smiles.

Her idle, music-numbed, mind took her back to the hired hand Agatha had needed just to ensure her and Nicky had safe passage from the car to the stadium and she hoped she’d have one again. Nicky was not only little but he was shy too and Rio, confident and an adult, still struggled with the attentions of crowds. She could only imagine the fear that sensitive Nicky felt when in the midst of the furore around him and his mother.

Somewhere over Nevada Rio asked for a red wine and settled in for the rest of the flight with her rhythmic music and her hopes for the reunion with her twin and his mom. Wanda being there would be difficult. A disaster waiting to happen, probably.

But she’d survived the worst thing. She could survive this.

Her head still hurt, even the red wine couldn’t cure that. But it was a new reality - one where her dad was dead, Agatha wouldn’t kiss her, and her head hurt. She just had to get used to it.

She was papped again when they landed in Boston. The swarm was larger here and Rio wondered if it was because Agatha had already been through the concourse and they were waiting to see if anyone else would grace their fair city for the game.

She never used to be bothered here. Boston was always a safe space, a space for Celtics and beer and her dad. A space where people recognised her but bought her drinks rather than shoved their cameras in her face.

She made it out to the chill early-Spring air and shivered as she waited on a cab to take her to her hotel where she’d drop her bag, call Wanda, and head to the stadium. It didn’t take long for her to arrive and even before she checked in she found Wanda waiting for her in the lobby all smiles and warm hugs.

“God, I’ve missed you.”

Rio sighed into the embrace and hugged Wanda as tightly as she hugged her. “You too.”

As Wanda pulled away Rio couldn’t help but smile back at her, finding the grin sent her way to be infectious, despite the agonies of her mind, body, and soul. “Check in, then we’ll grab a drink and go?”

“Great,” Rio confirmed, shouldering her trusty duffel before heading up to the desk to check in with Wanda waiting for her in the lobby.

In her comfortable room she washed her face, applied some more make up and then tied her Celtics scarf securely around her neck. From her duffel she pulled out a smaller crossbody bag containing the gift she’d wrapped for Nicky.

It had been a last minute call to a store to source but she hoped he’d like it. If he didn’t, well, she’d look like a massive loser but it was a risk she was willing to take.

When she arrived back in the lobby she found that Wanda was no longer alone. She was standing with two other people; two strangers. One was a tall man with floppy hair and a big grin, the other was a short woman with corkscrew curls and pink cheeks.

All three of them looked around as Rio got closer.

“Oh my god! Rio Vidal! I mean! Agh!”

Rio blinked and looked to Wanda for help as the woman jumped at her and pulled her down into a hug. Wanda gently helped to pry her off as she said, “This is Jerry and Tabitha, Rio. Fans of ours.”

Rio hummed and nodded a little but said nothing else, and was silent as they took some selfies and eventually, after what felt like far too long, the couple left them alone.

“Jesus,” Rio muttered as Wanda took her arm and steered her in the direction of the outside world.

“Cornered me before I could escape,” Wanda explained with a sigh. “I saw the pictures of you at the airport in Delaware. They’ve been worse lately?”

“Unimaginable.”

Wanda nodded and looked with Rio up and down the street to see if they were about to be descended upon again. Thankfully, they couldn’t see anyone.

“Come on. Quiet, cosy, dive bar it is. No one will find us.”

Rio only smiled and they jumped in a cab. Wanda filled the silence and it wasn’t annoying, it wasn’t cloying or maddening that she was doing so. It was done because Rio’s thoughts were too many. Too many to funnel into one, coherent thread of conversation.

So Wanda picked up the slack. She spoke of filming in the snow in Atlanta. She spoke of the cast and crew and the bar they’d discovered near the Coca Cola Museum. She spoke about things that weren’t death or grief or sleeping with your fuckass husband.

By the time they made it to the bar and Rio had secured herself a pint of whatever lager was on offer, she felt a little better.

“Oh shit,” Wanda said suddenly, blinking across at Rio as she removed her jacket in the booth they sat in. “Should I have worn something green?”

Rio raised her brows and looked down at Wanda’s brown sweater, then down at her own green Celtics hooded sweatshirt. She rolled her eyes as she removed her cap and reached to place it on Wanda’s head.

“There,” she said with a wry smile as she ran her hands through her hair to shake out the telltale signs of cap-wearing. “You’ll fit right in.”

Wanda just rolled her eyes and adjusted it on her head. She batted her eyelashes over at Rio as Rio took a sip of her pint. “Beautiful?”

“You know you are.”

Wanda hummed and her smile faded somewhat as she turned the conversation to the thing Rio had been dreading. “Do you want to talk about it?”

She looked down at Wanda’s hands curled around her own pint glass, at the silver rings that decorated her fingers, at the deep red polish across her nails. Her throat felt tight.

“No, not really.”

“Okay,” Wanda said calmly, watching Rio closely for any take-backs. “Will we talk instead about stealing people’s jobs?”

Rio’s brown eyes flashed up suddenly and she looked momentarily spooked before she saw that Wanda was smiling again.

“I’ll get her back, you know.”

“Has she apologised?”

“No.”

Rio nodded and took a sip of beer.

“You know Deadline called me ‘Wendy Maximoff’?” Wanda began rummaging in her back beside her until she had her phone in her hands and was suddenly showing Rio a screenshot. A tweet from Deadline.

Agatha Harkness is replacing Wendy Maximoff in Maria Hill’s seasonal drama ‘Let It Snow’.

The film centres on a family as they contend with the matriarch’s terminal illness and intense sibling rivalry during the holiday season.

Rio Vidal is also attached.

The pictures chosen for the announcement were in black and white: Wanda and Rio together from a photoshoot a couple years ago and Agatha all alone.

Rio sighed.

“I know it’s a good part, Rio, but is there another reason she took it?”

Rio stared down at the frothy head on her pint and blew gently, watching the bubble part for her. Wanda was silent as she watched and then said: “Is it serious?”

Rio kept her gaze down, kept her eyes on the bubbles as they filled the hole she’d just gently blown. She could feel Wanda’s gaze on her, her eyes boring into her brain to try and figure out exactly what was going on between her and Agatha.

But even Rio didn’t know now.

All she knew was that Agatha was it for her but that they weren’t together. That they might never be together.

“Rio,” Wanda encouraged with a gentle sigh as she reached for her hand.

“It’s nothing,” Rio said eventually, glancing at Wanda’s hand. “There’s nothing going on. I’ve told you before. She’s married.”

Rio pulled her hand away, trying not to be cruel about it, trying only to be able to keep her emotions from getting the better of her. She was soon to see Agatha, soon to see Nicky, she had to keep her head straight.

“Rio.”

Rio sighed and ran her fingers through her hair, looking anywhere now but into green eyes.

“I’d never judge you, you know.”

“I-…” Rio huffed and shook her head, crossing her arms defensively over herself as she turned to finally look at Wanda. She trusted her. More than most of her friends. But this wasn’t her secret to give. “I like her. I do. But nothing is going on.”

Wanda smiled sadly and Rio felt the thrum of her head as she watched her friend pretend to believe her.

“Okay. Okay. Just seems like when you were absolutely off your face and the only think you could talk about was her I’d think you were-…”

“Wands.”

“Look I know back at that luncheon thing you said nothing was happening but-…”

“Wanda.”

“But, her actually taking my part and then-…”

Rio sighed and pinched the bridge of her nose, “Jesus. Look. It’s nothing. Nothing at all. Please can we drop it.”

Wanda sighed now, “I just think that someone like Agatha Harkness-…”

“Can you keep your voice down? Holy shit if someone overhears, Wanda.”

Wanda blinked and looked around at the near-empty bar. Rio rolled her eyes as she turned back to her with a ‘seriously?!’ expression on her face.

“Fine,” Rio sighed in defeat, “She’s hot. I… she’s hot.”

“Everyone knows she’s hot, Rio.”

“I-…” Rio groaned and rubbed her face, instantly regretting it and rummaging in her bag to find her compact. “It doesn’t fucking matter, okay?”

“She came to your dad’s-…”

“I don’t want to talk about that.”

“Babe,” Wanda said gently, reaching across for her. “I’m sorry. I just meant that… well, she’s actually a bitch.”

Rio’s eyes snapped up from where they’d been focused in on the table between them, all graffitied and sticky. Someone had written ‘FUCK TERFS’ and she couldn’t help but agree. But then Wanda said that.

“She’s not a bitch.”

Maybe she’d said it too harshly because Wanda looked taken aback but managed to school her face as she said: “I like her, okay? But she’s not known for her friendliness and I’m convinced she took my part. Partly because it’s awards fodder and partly because… well, you.”

Rio cleared her throat and looked down at her beer again, forcing herself to relax her posture. Wanda was moving on to different topics now and Rio knew she was doing it for her own benefit as well as Rio’s.

She didn’t know whether Wanda still had a crush on her. She hoped she didn’t. She assumed she didn’t. Wanda was, not unlike Rio of old, a big flirt. She could have anyone she set her sights on and often did.

Wanda was just a bit more subtle about it, and less voracious in her appetite.

Topics pivoted all over the place and Rio began to relax a little. The throbbing of her head died as she got into the swing of chatter again. She was soon able to contribute more than just hums and head nods and even smiled a few times at Wanda’s stories, or added her own commentary to them.

By the time they’d finished their drinks they had to hurry off to the arena to be there in enough time to get their seats, get more drinks, and be ready for the start of the game. Besides, Rio was anxious to see Nicky, and even more anxious to see Agatha.

The crowds outside the arena were crazy and Rio and Wanda being amongst them didn’t go unnoticed. Wanda was a little taller but Rio was more determined so she pulled them both through until they could find an attendant to get them to their seats unharmed.

The way down the steps of the bleachers felt like a mile when she had the two people she most wanted to see waiting at the end for her. She nervously ran her hand through her hair, hoping she didn’t have hat hair when she finally saw Agatha.

A soft whisper beside her reassured her that she looked great and she turned to smile at Wanda and adjusted her cap for her.

At the bottom of the steps, now on the court side, she turned and looked up to see the figure of Agatha Harkness and the little legs of her son swinging where his mother was leaning around to talk to him.

She bit her lip in anticipation of the reaction and only hoped it would be a positive one. From both people involved. As she stepped closer she cleared her throat meaningfully and watched as Nicky leant around Agatha to look up at her and his dark eyes widened in surprise.

“Nicky,” Rio breathed out, and then grunted when a tiny body collided with her own.

“MELLIZAAAAAA!”

The birthday boy had thrown himself at her, winded her, and screamed louder than she’d ever heard him scream before. But she laughed as she wrapped her arms around him and just about managed to crouch before him to hug him properly.

Rio breathed him in, and felt her entire body relax as he clung to her. She felt the pull of home as she held him close, the comfort that family brought.

“You’re my surprise?!”

Rio chuckled as Nicky began to jump against her, wriggling enthusiastically as she pulled back to look at him. “Is it a good one?”

“Only the bestest one!”

Rio laughed again as Nicky threw himself back at her and she almost lost her balance.

Above them now Agatha was there, looking amused as she surveyed the reunion. Rio grinned at her and then made a soft noise of surprise of her own as Nicky jumped so violently that she fell back and only just managed to support herself from collapsing entirely.

“Nicky! Nicky!”

Nicky was blushing now, whether from the exertion, the excitement, of the fact that everyone was looking at them, Rio didn’t know. He was happy, and that’s all that mattered.

“Mama said I had one more surprise for my birthday. It’s you! I hoped it would be but when you weren’t here I thought it wasn’t and then!”

The pain Rio had been in these past two weeks vanished the moment Agatha crouched down beside them and her hand found Nicky’s shoulder and Rio’s knee. “Honey, you gotta let Rio breathe.”

“He’s okay,” Rio said with a genuine smile as she looked back up to Nicky, a few inches below him where she crouched, holding his sides as he kept his arms around her neck. “I’m excited to see him too.”

“Oh my god!” Wanda shouted and it made both Rio and Nicky turn to her in surprise. Agatha turned a second later and squeezed her knee in the process. “You look so handsome with your short hair!”

Nicky shifted on his feet and a slow blush crept across his cheeks as he nodded and said: “Thank you. Just like Rio.”

Wanda raised her brows at this statement as Rio stood to her full height again and watched as Nicky reached to take her hand and stood a little closer to her. Wanda looked momentarily stuck and then she smiled again, her brows raising hopefully as she crouched down before Nicky and opened her arms out to him.

Rio knew before Wanda even asked what was about to happen.

“Could I get a hug from the birthday boy as well?”

Rio turned her head then and Nicky reached with his other hand to toy with Rio’s fingers. He looked cautious and seemed to be thinking hard about whether or not he wanted to give Wanda a hug as both Rio and Agatha stood framing him like two bodyguards and their charge.

Nicky didn’t move and Rio was just about to step in when Agatha did instead.

“Wanda! How rude of me.”

Rio almost fainted as Agatha moved forwards and pulled Wanda into a rather aggressive hug. Nicky had moved now his mom was no longer beside him and stood before Rio, and Rio naturally held him against her, feeling him toy with her fingers still as he watched his mama hug the red-headed stranger.

Rio was surprised by her own reaction to seeing Agatha hug Wanda. She felt surprise, sure, but a sense of pride too? Maybe? Something else warm at least.

“Rio,” Nicky whispered through the noise of the arena, his neck craning back as Agatha was pulling back from Wanda. Rio bent down to let him whisper in her ear, “Why is this lady here?”

“She’s my friend, mellizo. She’s really nice, I promise. You met her before, remember? In London?”

“Do I have to hug her?”

“No, baby. Only hug people you want to hug, okay?”

“Okay,” Nicky said with a soft frown as Rio straightened up and kissed the top of his cap. “Mama says that too.”

Rio smiled and looked up as Agatha was turning back around, looking a little pale but keeping up her smile, and Wanda behind her was beaming a great big, shell-shocked grin. It made Rio laugh, which made Agatha roll her eyes as she swooped in to kiss her cheek.

They were on show now so she didn’t linger and Rio didn’t turn into her, didn’t seek out her warmth like she usually might. Instead she smiled widely and raised her brows as Nicky wriggled between them, “Feeling friendly today, Agatha?”

“Trying to,” Agatha offered back with a tight smile and Rio couldn’t help it when she pulled her hand from Nicky’s hold and wrapped her arm around Agatha’s middle to pull her in for a hug. She sighed into it, heard Nicky giggle as he was squashed between them and Agatha wrapped her arms properly around her.

“People are watching,” Agatha muttered, and Rio sighed again as she pulled back a little, and smiled at Agatha who looked softer again, a pink flush across her cheeks.

Rio nodded and pulled away properly and found a little tug on her shirt as she did that suggested Agatha hadn’t actually wanted her to pull away. But she was ducking down again, and whispering in Nicky’s ear, “You want a beer, kid?”

“Noooooo!”

Rio laughed and shot Agatha a wink as she took Nicky’s hand and pulled him down into the seat beside her usual one and Wanda moved to sit on her other side.

From then on Nicky began to talk a mile a minute and Rio found that she started to relax for the first time whilst not horizontal with Agatha, hidden away in her trailer. Nicky was bouncing in his seat, his eyes on Rio or the court as he asked questions and probed for details about the game ahead.

Rio could actually feel her body shrink a couple inches. She’d been so tense and so uptight that she didn’t even know for the past two weeks she’d been physically exhausting herself by constantly tensing her muscles.

Nicky was so excited and it was infectious, so Rio became excited. And Agatha and Wanda smiled through it, Wanda through being mostly ignored even as she kept trying to engage Nicky in conversation and Agatha through keeping quiet but keeping an eye on her son and Rio.

“We can,” Rio was saying, “go meet the team, if you want? It’s your birthday, they’d be so happy to see you.”

Nicky froze and stared up at Rio for a couple seconds before he turned to Agatha with those wide eyes that meant he was nervous but not too afraid to immediately say no. “Can we?”

Agatha raised her brows and chewed on her lip. She was just reaching across Nicky to get to Rio when Wanda leant over and spoke suddenly, “If you’d feel more comfortable, sweetie, you can hold my hand the whole time.”

Rio’s eyes darted up to look at steely blue and then down again to watch Nicky as he turned to look around at Wanda. He watched her for a second and then in a small voice said, “No thank you.”

Rio smiled a little and turned to Wanda with raised brows as she whispered, “He’s shy.”

“No, he just loves you and his mom. And that’s okay.”

Rio rolled her eyes and squeezed Wanda’s arm before she leant in to whisper to her, “Maybe now’s the time to try again with Agatha?”

Wanda was the one to roll her eyes now but Rio felt her ear being cupped and Wanda’s warm breath against her as she whispered, “You’re so mommy right now, Rio Vidal.”

Rio’s eyes widened a little and she felt Wanda’s thumb brush her cheek as she pulled away and met smiling green eyes. But it lasted all of two seconds because little arms had suddenly wrapped around her neck and a body collided with her back and she knew Nicky was trying to get her attention.

But he wasn’t the only one. Agatha was crouching down before her, appearing out of nowhere, and had her hand on Rio’s knee again. Rio’s hands were on Nicky’s arms but her gaze was down on Agatha as Wanda smiled in pleasant surprise and moved back from her.

“Drinks?” Agatha asked with a tight smile, her grip of Rio’s knee a little harder than it needed to be. “Rio, Nicky, and I can go get them.”

“Just us,” Nicky whispered close to Rio’s ear and made her smile even as she looked across to see Wanda’s reaction and saw that she was fighting for her life to look as nonplussed as possible.

She sighed quietly as she turned back to Agatha. “Remember last time? We should send an attendant.”

Nicky hugged her tighter and Rio raised her brows at Agatha, wondering if she would risk the rush of the crowds just to get away from Wanda for a few minutes.

“Well,” Agatha said after a second of clear indecision written across her face. She was still gripping Rio. Hard. “Maybe an attendant, then.”

Rio hummed quietly and moved her hands from Nicky’s tight hold to his legs. “Shitty red wine for everyone? Sorry, Nicky,” she added as she held him more firmly and shuffled in her seat to pull him with her as she stood.

Agatha raised her brows and her hand had fallen from her knee to now rest around her ankle as Rio stood with her son on her back and jumped a little to hitch him up more comfortably. Nicky giggled against her ear, neither bothered by her cursing or by the fact he’d just been hauled into the air.

“You’re heavy, mellizo.”

Rio looked expectantly at Agatha and watched a sly smile grow up her face as she released her hold on Rio and stood. She was directly in front of her now. And close. Deliciously close. She reached up under the pretence of fixing Nicky’s cap.

“Pretty sure you can lift me,” she muttered as Rio jostled Nicky again.

“Carry mama too!”

Rio rolled her eyes and was turning her head back to side-eye Nicky when Wanda hopped up again to join in the little trio. “She totally could. Carried me in that photoshoot, remember?”

Rio, right now, would rather not have anyone be reminded of the time she’d done a photoshoot with Wanda for Cosmopolitan. She’d had to carry Wanda on her back in the same way she was currently holding Nicky. Wanda had been heavier than Nicky, obviously, but that wasn’t the problem. The problem was that Wanda had been wearing a mini dress and heels so the thought of Agatha knowing about the shoot, let alone having actually seen it made her blood run suddenly cold.

“The one with the tiny little dresses and heels?” Agatha asked, her eyes on Rio, checking for a reaction. Or, perhaps, some form of apology.

Fuck, Rio thought.

“Yeah!” Wanda exclaimed with a grin at Agatha’s question, “She held me for like, I don’t know, a long time!” A soft laugh followed her words as Wanda clearly got roped back into thinking Agatha was interested in anything she had to say.

Rio knew different.

She knew the look in her blue eyes meant that she’d absolutely run out of patience and kindness for her. Which was unfortunate because the game hadn’t even started.

“Baby,” she wanted to say, “mi amor, it meant nothing. Jump into my arms now and I’ll carry you in them with your son on my back.”

“That was a long time ago,” Rio said instead, watching now as Agatha’s gaze was downturned and she was focusing somewhere around where Nick’s knees were by her sides.

“Bet you could still do it,” Wanda grinned and before Rio could stop her she’d stepped in and draped an arm around her, simultaneously hugging Nicky too. She heard Nicky’s soft gasp near her ear and before he could say anything she moved away, making it subtle enough that Wanda wouldn’t be offended, but far away enough so that her hand fell and Nicky simply held on tighter to her.

There was silence in the group for a second, Wanda oblivious to how close to the danger zone she currently was and Rio completely aware of it.

“Let me go find someone and ask for drinks. Nicky wants his wine.”

“Noooo,” Nicky giggled, back to being contented as Rio shot Agatha a quick glance and turned to go in search of a member of the arena staff. “No, soda please!”

Rio just hummed happily and bounced Nicky as she walked along the busy courtside row to find an attendant. Behind her she knew she’d left Wanda with a coiled cobra but she had no choice if she wanted to get them drinks before the game began.

Nicky had changed his position on her, moving his head from her left side to her right and Rio didn’t know but could only guess he’d done it to hide from the people they were walking past. The precious cargo on her back tightened his hold around her neck and as she swallowed she felt the press of his arms against her throat.

He was nervous.

The attendant was close so Rio hitched Nicky up a little and called for his attention, aware now that some fuckwad in the crowd was calling for Nicky. She held him tighter.

“Hey,” the kid turned to Rio and grinned, showing off his braces. “Can I order with you? We just want-…”

“Oh, I, uh, maybe, I, uh, maybe need to, uh,” Rio blinked as the kid with the braces blushed a deep crimson but her mind was half on that and half on someone still shouting for Nicky.

Her windpipe was being crushed.

“Y’know what, nevermind,” she croaked, and turned around to walk Nicky back to the safety of his mom. Nicky shuffled against her, his hold now so tight Rio could feel herself turning purple. And she knew she must have at least looked a little flushed by the look on Agatha’s face as they arrived back and she moved quickly to help loosen Nicky’s hold.

Rio coughed and cleared her throat as Agatha whispered, “Nicky, honey, it’s too tight.”

“He’s fine, he’s fine,” Rio reassured quickly, aware Nicky was scared so not wanting him to feel upset too. She stepped closer and pressed her cheek to Agatha’s to speak into her ear, her voice a little croaky. “Someone was calling for him. His name.”

As she stepped back she gave Agatha a pointed look and saw concern across pale features. “Rio,” Agatha was saying as Rio moved back to gently encourage Nicky to put his feet down on the seat and let go, “did you get the guy?”

“What’s happening?” Wanda stood up, looking between Rio and Agatha as Rio continued now to gently convince Nicky to let go and Agatha was frowning down at her where she still crouched.

“It’s fine. He was just a kid, couldn’t have got us booze anyway. I’ll go.”

She managed to release Nicky’s arms from her neck and turned to help him jump down from the seat just as two pairs of hands found her arms and she now stood with Wanda and Agatha holding her right arm and Nicky clinging to her left.

It would be the dream scenario if Wanda just let go and the crowd disappeared.

“I’ll go with you,” Wanda offered with a smile as Rio turned to her.

“No, I’ll go I-…” but Agatha clamped her mouth shut, clearly suddenly realising what Rio already had; that she wouldn’t leave Nicky alone with Wanda. “No. Get someone else. Or we’ll just-…”

“It’s fine, Agatha. Wanda and I will go.”

“Rio,” Nicky began to tug now as Agatha’s grip tightened and she felt the similarities between them both exacting against her arms. “Don’t go. Stay. Send the lady, okay?”

Rio sighed quietly and felt Wanda’s gentler hold drop from her arm as Agatha kept hers tight. She wanted it to stay like that forever. But as she focused on Nicky and ducked down to speak directly to him Agatha cleared her throat and released her.

“Honey, her name is Wanda. And I’ll only be five minutes. I’ll be back before the game begins and I’ll bring you a hot dog and popcorn, okay?”

Her hand now free she could cup Nicky’s cheek and smooth down the blush she found there with her thumb. “I promise. Five minutes.”

Nicky’s frown spoke volumes but he nodded and Agatha was with him before Rio could say anything else. She was straightening as Agatha took her hand and made her pause for a second, “Be careful, okay?”

Agatha’s hand was cooler than her own. She’d felt it before against her arm, but in her had now it felt like ice. But her gaze was warm, her gaze was that soft way it became when it was just the two of them; when they didn’t have thousands of witnesses to their every move.

Rio smiled and inclined her head to let Agatha know she would take care, that she would be careful. She didn’t pull away until Agatha dropped her hold and she could turn around to offer Wanda her smile instead. Wanda returned it tenfold and Rio relaxed just a little as she took her by the arm and pulled her in the direction of the food.

As they moved Rio became aware of shouting in their direction again but this time it was their names and no longer Nicky’s. She could still feel his hold around her throat and it made her unable to respond to Wanda as she asked: “Is Nicky always this shy?”

She thought of her dad then, and felt the tightening around her throat more viscerally than even before. She’d once held her dad like that. She’d relied on him to keep her safe when she was little and even when she was older. And Nicky had Agatha to keep him safe but he sure as shit didn’t have a dad to do it.

Far from the pain in her head the agony was now back in her chest.

Nicky clutching her was a reminder of what she wanted, what she so desperately, hopelessly craved. Agatha. Nicky. The both of them.

Her dad. She wanted him back.

“Rio,” Wanda prompted suddenly and Rio blinked and was immediately back in the room. They were in the thick of it now, and Wanda was now tugging Rio in front of her, holding her sides through the throng.

Rio managed to smile her apologies as people moved out of the way for Academy Award Winner Rio Vidal in the line for the concessions. Rio grimaced every time someone asked for a photo but always acquiesced, allowing them to always ask for a second one if they wanted it with Wanda too.

They moved slowly to the front because of it but eventually, after many photos both asked for and taken without permission, they made it back out with Rio carrying a holder of drinks and Wanda with the hot dog and popcorn.

“It’s cute, y’know,” Wanda was saying as Rio was concentrating more on not falling than anything else. “How obsessed with you he is.”

Rio rolled her eyes and shot Wanda a look, “Shut up. He just likes basketball, and his mom knows nothing about it.”

“Not true,” Wanda said with a grin, “When you disappeared with Nicky I asked her who her favourite player was. She knew the whole team and their stats. It was…” Rio blinked and briefly lost her balance, only just correcting herself and narrowly avoiding spilling a whole load of red wine over the steps, herself, and the man beside her in his seat.

“Like she’d swallowed ‘Celtics for Dummies’ or something.”

Rio cleared her throat and blinked down at where she could see Agatha sitting leaning over Nicky, clearly deep in conversation with him. Wanda couldn’t be right; Agatha knew nothing about basketball.

Then again, if anyone were going to swallow ‘Celtics for Dummies’ simply to be able to have a conversation with her child about his favourite team, it would be Agatha.

Wanda continued to chat to her but Rio wasn’t really listening as they continued on their way to the floor. Around them people turned to look, some pausing their own conversations to do so, and others taking their cellphones out to snap a picture.

It was worse than it used to be, that was for sure.

When they were finally down with Agatha and Nicky again, Rio was surprised by the reception, or lack thereof. Agatha had turned to witness her safe arrival and Nicky sat staring at his knees beside her.

It was only as Rio went to hand Nicky his soda that she knew something was off. “Mellizo? Your soda?”

“I’m okay, thank you.”

“Honey.” / “Sweetheart.”

“Hey, Nicky? You want your hot dog or popcorn first?”

Nicky looked up at Wanda and Rio watched as she smiled and Nicky frowned. Agatha had her hand on his head and whispered something in his ear that made Nicky nod a little and swallow before he said, “Hot dog please, thank you.”

Rio bit down on her lip as she turned her attention to the wine she had by her feet and began to pass that out first to Wanda, then to Agatha. Wanda had taken hers with just a smile and Agatha had taken hers without one.

It made Rio pause, unsure what had happened between her leaving and returning. But she lifted her own wine from the holder and placed Nicky’s soda down by his feet and just as she was turning to slide the holder beneath the seats Agatha said: “Honey, why don’t you tell Rio what else you got for your birthday?”

Rio looked to Nicky who was still frowning, two bites now through his hotdog. There was a little mustard on his chin that Agatha gently wiped off as Nicky kept his gaze down and his brow furrowed. “New sneakers and a bike.”

“A bike?!” Rio gasped dramatically and brown eyes darted up to look at her and a flicker of a smile tugged at Nicky’s lips.

“A green one.”

“No way.”

“Yeah, and it’s got black handles.”

“Woah!” The flicker grew into a flame as Nicky looked up properly this time and grinned proudly at Rio as she asked, “How fast does it go?”

“So fast!”

Rio laughed at the sight of Nicky’s face all lit up and his hot dog held up to emphasise just how fast his bike went. And Agatha was smiling again, looking relieved more than anything as Rio took her seat back beside Nicky.

“You’ll come see it soon?”

“Of course! You can show me how fast you can go.”

Nicky nodded enthusiastically and Rio hummed her pleasure before she ducked down to look below the seats in search of the her little black bag she’d abandoned earlier.

She found it and ripped it out to hold it triumphantly up for Nicky. “Here! I got you a little something.”

Nicky’s eyes bugged out as he accepted the small wrapped package from inside the bag. Over his head Rio caught Agatha’s eye and smiled, receiving a wink back.

Rio exhaled slowly, her frantic heart relaxing to a steadier rhythm.

Agatha moved in closer, peaking over Nicky’s shoulder now to get a good look. Rio felt Wanda do the same over her own shoulder and she held her breath.

Nicky turned the small gift about in his hands for a while and then gingerly began to rip the wrappings. Rio had never been the best at wrapping gifts so she was a little embarrassed that there were so many pulls for him to easily slip his small fingers into. Even so, he went slower than Rio had ever seen a kid when unwrapping a gift.

She blinked across at him as he finally, finally, revealed the box and held it up before his eyes. It was a small box, and in opening it, wide eyes the colour of warm caramel looked down on a green and white Casio Baby G Watch.

Wanda’s hand was on her arm and the grip of it helped her not to faint. She’d never been this nervous giving a gift before.

Rio cleared her throat and cautiously asked, “Do you like it? I wasn’t sure but then…” she swallowed again and the pulled the sleeve of her sweatshirt back to reveal a matching watch on her wrist. “I thought we could be matching.”

Nicky blinked and Rio thought he was going to tell her that, no, he didn’t like it, that, no, he didn’t want to be matching, but instead he leapt up and made her grunt as he threw his arms around her neck again. He only narrowly avoided whacking Wanda with the box.

“Me encanta, melliza!”

Rio breathed out a relieved laugh and met Agatha’s proud gaze as she squeezed Nicky to her, “Sí, mellizo? ¿Me lo pongo?“ Shall I put it on?

Nicky nodded against her and then pulled back. Rio took the gift from him and extracted the watch as Nicky held out both wrists and frowned between them. It took rio a second to realise what the problem was and she looked up to Agatha as the actress leant in and whispered something into his ear and Nicky nodded and then held only his left wrist up. “I’m ampidextris.”

“Is that right?” Rio shot Agatha an amused grin and Agatha rolled her eyes with a laugh before she leant in to kiss her son’s cheek. Rio gently attached the watch to his wrist and adjusted it for comfort as Agatha corrected him.

“Ambidextrous, honey.”

“Ambi-Ambidextrous, ambidextrous, ambidextrous,” he diligently repeated to himself.

“Feel okay?”

Rio watched with a grin that matched Nicky’s as he held up his new watch to admire it. “¿Cómo se dice: watch?”

“Reloj,” Rio uttered proudly, watching as Nicky brought his new reloj down to hold beside Rio’s.

“Reloj,” he whispered to himself, watching the seconds tick by on both faces. “Reloj, reloj.”

“Your Spanish is getting good, mellizo.”

Nicky raised his gaze up and beamed that toothy grin, “It is?”

“Mmhm. You’re already better than me and soon you’ll even be better than your mama.”

Nicky giggled as Agatha took hold of him and tickled his sides, “Nooooo!”

When she’d given in and finished the attack with a quick kiss and adjusted his now wonky cap, Agatha said: “Tell Rio why you’re learning it.”

Blue eyes flashed up at the request and the look in them told Rio that she might need to hold onto something. Wanda’s hold was no longer enough. She reached to hold the back of Nicky’s chair for support and dropped her gaze down to Nicky’s in anticipation.

Nicky was panting softly and smiled as he adjusted his cap again and looked back around at Rio. His eyes briefly darted to Wanda still leaning around her and then he looked back up and said quietly: “it’s a secret. Just for us.”

Rio raised her brows and watched as Nicky shuffled a little in his mom’s hold and then made grabbing hands at her to encourage her to move closer.

“It’s okay,” Wanda’s calm voice reassured beside Rio, “I won’t listen.”

Rio glanced around as she pulled away and reached briefly to give her a reassuring squeeze before she turned back.

She shuffled closer and allowed Nicky to wrap his arms around her head and whisper into her ear: “I know you’re very sad and I want to speak to you in Spanish so you when you miss your dad he can be here too. When I miss mama I speak to her on the phone and it helps so I…” Nicky faltered a little and Rio knew he was trying to fit such the two big, confusing concepts of grief and death, into his soft words, “I want you to still be able to speak his words with me, okay?”

Nicky’s hands were tangled in Rio’s hair. He was being gentle but he held her firmly, making sure she was close, that his words were just for her to hear. And Rio was glad he couldn’t see her face as he said them because her eyes were filling rapidly with tears and there was no stopping them as one slipped onto her breath-warmed cheek.

From her position she’d placed a hand down by Agatha’s hip to steady herself. The chair wouldn’t do. Her thumb was trapping the fabric of Agatha’s pants against the side of her knuckle and she was glad of the small piece of Agatha she got to hold. It felt like it was holding her whole self together, keeping her steady.

She turned her head enough to peak below Nicky’s cap and look into his round, earnest eyes.

“Okay?” He asked again softly, and Rio realised he was asking her permission to continue to learn her dad’s language, to use it to talk to her, and keep his words alive. She couldn’t think of anything that would make her dad happier.

Nicky’s gaze dropped to the tear across her cheek and he began to frown.

“I made you sad.”

“No, mellizo. You made me very happy. You make me very happy.”

Nicky continued to look concerned and so Rio smiled as best she could to try and reassure him. His frown continued.

A hand found Rio’s suddenly and the hold she had on Agatha’s pants was broken but having her hand being held was infinitely better anyway. Suddenly a second face was close by and Rio’s smile relaxed into something just a little more genuine.
