“You know what Rio’s papa said to me at Christmas?”

Rio raised her brows and caught Nicky as he turned his body to face inwards, his back to the court.

“What, mama?”

“He said,” Agatha whispered as she squeezed Rio’s hand, “That you reminded him of Rio. That you were smart and kind and he would be so proud to have a grandson just like you.”

Rio sucked in a soft breath and Agatha squeezed her hand again. She watched as Agatha’s gaze moved round to rest on her and she felt dizzy suddenly, as though she’d fallen from a great height and Agatha had been there to catch her.

“I liked him a lot,” Nicky whispered as Rio kept her eyes on Agatha, searching for the lie, for the gentle fib in there that had been woven just to reassure a concerned little boy. It wasn’t there. And then Nicky said something else, something that made another tear slip from Rio’s wide eyes.

“It’s okay to be sad, mellizo. We are here. We love you when you’re sad just as much as when you’re happy. Maybe more. Mama says because you’re sad you need more love so we can-…”

But Nicky didn’t get to finish his promise because Rio couldn’t bear it any longer. She dived at him. She lifted him into her arms and held him so close that he gasped, then giggled, then buried into her. Over his shoulder Rio squeezed her eyes closed and focused on the tight hold she was receiving back from Nicky, one the cold hand that had found her lower back, of the love she felt radiating around her.

Her dad would be proud to have Nicky as a grandson. He’d said it the day he’d met Agatha. The day he’d met Nicky.

He’d known all along.

She breathed out slowly and released her hold, letting Nicky settle how he wanted against her, letting him lean his side against her front so he could see Agatha and he could hold Rio’s watch-bearing arm and match it with his own.

She watched him for a second and adjusted his hat and then turned to Agatha and smiled, finding she was already looking at her. “Es cierto,” It’s true, Agatha whispered for her ears only.

Rio nodded and placed her chin on Nicky’s head as he began to press the buttons on her watch, making it beep and flash randomly. “Lo sé.” I know.

She felt a hand on her arm and turned to Wanda then, saw her holding up her wine and smiling, “To Nicky’s birthday?”

Rio turned as Wanda reached across her to hold her glass out to Nicky and Agatha. In Nicky’s sudden reaction, in his tensing suddenly where he sat, in the deep frown that appeared as he raised his head, Rio realised the reason why he’s given her the cold shoulder. He didn’t want Wanda there.

For a few, brief moments, he’d forgotten she even was. And now he remembered again, remembered that Rio had brought a friend to his birthday surprise. He stopped playing with her watch.

She made eye contact with Agatha and saw in her gaze the truth of it, that she didn’t want Wanda there any more than her son did.

“To Nicky’s birthday,” Rio said as cheerily as she could, now wrapping an arm around the little boy’s waist as she held him and slipped behind him to grab her wine. Nicky didn’t pull away and Rio was about to say something else when Agatha leant in and said: “To Nicky’s birthday.”

Rio toasted with the other two glasses and squeezed Nicky’s arm. She took a sip of wine and then ducked her head down to whisper to him, “You okay, mellizo?”

“Is she your wife? Like, in not pretend?”

Rio frowned and looked up to shoot a glance at Agatha and saw that she was trying to pretend she wasn’t but she was clearly listening closely. Sighing, she ducked her head back down and whispered, “No, mellizo. I don’t have a wife.”

Nicky nodded and toyed with his new watch. “She’s pretty and she is wearing your cap.”

“She is. And very nice. She didn’t have any green with her today, that’s all.”

Nicky considered this for a second and then asked: “Prettier and nicer than my mama?”

Rio bit the inside of her cheek and pulled back as Nicky frowned up at her. Around them the crowd was beginning to make more noise and Rio knew she didn’t have long to reassure the little boy with the big brown eyes.

“No, baby.”

“Then why is she here?”

“She’s my friend.”

Nicky blinked and in his eyes Rio saw him processing in real time, the cogs slowly turning until he eventually said, “She took you away from me. Twice.”

The cogs then kickstarted in Rio’s brain, as slow as Nicky’s had looked. She tried to think back to when she’d last been with Wanda and had Nicky there too. And the answer was right before her, in the sight of piercing blue eyes as she looked up to see Agatha no longer pretending not to listen to them. The last time had been London.

The morning after Agatha had slept with Ralph.

Rio had spilled red wine over Wanda and they’d gone up to her room after bumping into Nicky and Agatha in the restaurant. Nicky had met Wanda before but so, so briefly. No wonder he didn’t remember her, at least, not initially. Rio hadn’t much focused on Nicky that morning because she’d been more focused on the fact that the night before Agatha had left her on her knees.

But Wanda going away with Rio now to get drinks had reminded him of the last time they’d met. It had reminded him that the last time he’d seen Wanda, he hadn’t then seen Rio again for days.

Looking at Agatha now she knew she was thinking about that too.

Swallowing her pride she looked down at Nicky and forced a smile, watching as his gaze remained on her, and his brow remained tight. “But I always came back.”

“I don’t think you should be friends with her.”

“Nicky,” Agatha said quietly as Rio asked a soft, “Why not?”

“She’ll take you away from me and mama.”

“No one ever could, mellizo. I’ll always come back. Even if I’m gone for a little while. I always come back.”

Nicky couldn’t have known but a great squeeze happened against Rio’s throat and down to her heart. She wanted her dad suddenly, wanted the one person who could never come back, even as she promised the little boy she always would.

“Nicky, honey, the team is about to come on.”

Rio glanced up again and saw Agatha looking that soft way she always did, her arm now reaching to snake around Nicky and overlapping Rio’s. Nicky turned from his melliza and looked to his mom before he pulled away from both of them and he clambered around in Rio’s lap, swinging his legs around to face forwards.

“Mama, come closer.”

Agatha heeded the instruction with raised brows and took up Nicky’s empty seat beside Rio. Wanda, unaware of the conversation that had just happened and that she was now not wanted by two of the party, leant over and grinned at Nicky, “How’s the new watch?”

“Good, thank you.”

Rio sighed out and kissed the back of Nicky’s head, wrapping her arms around him loosely as he returned his attention to the court and to the hot dog placed back into his hands by his mom.

Rio rested her cheek against Nicky and tried to turn her attention to the roar of the crowd and the music now heralding the arrival of the Celtics but a soft voice in her ear stole her attention away: “He loves you.”

Rio changed the cheek that rested against Nicky and was horrified that as she looked round at Agatha she could feel the threat of tears prick her eyes again. In her arms sat the jealous, shy little boy that Agatha had made from scratch. And in her sights was the woman who had made him, the only woman Rio ever thought about, had ever truly wanted, had ever truly loved.

Agatha’s mouth opened and closed again and Rio knew what she wanted to say but couldn’t with so many eyes on them so she forced a smile and she turned back to the arena with Agatha’s silent “I love you” floating between them.

By the time the game had begun, Agatha had taken away the evidence of Nicky’s devoured hot dog and wiped his hands clean for him and Rio had moved to the edge of her seat with the little boy.

Nicky was clinging to her arms when he wasn’t reaching back to pull her head forward so he could speak to her and Rio could only hope it meant she’d been forgiven for allowing herself to be taken away by Wanda.

Agatha’s thigh was against her own and Rio knew she wouldn’t pushed for more when there were so many eyes on her but she wondered whether Agatha was thinking of reaching out. Maybe she wanted to rub her back when Rio visibly tensed as shots were taken, maybe she wanted to kiss her every time Rio celebrated, maybe she wanted to sit beneath Nicky in her lap and be held by her as she held her son.

The first quarter flew by and the Celtics were up already which meant that Nicky was clapping quietly along to the music played during the break and Rio collapsed back in her chair and laughed out her relief, flexing her arms up to work out the tension.

“Thank fuck.”

Agatha cleared her throat and Rio grumbled an apology and peeked an eye open to see Agatha smiling as she fixed Nicky’s cap on his head. Rio watched as Wanda then wriggled the peak of the cap gently to make him turn back to her as she motioned her own stolen cap. “Twins!”

Rio held her breath as she watched Nicky’s profile. He was frowning again, weighing something up in his mind, and quietly, hesitantly, he said: “I already have a twin.”

Wanda was game though, a perpetual positive person, and typically very good with kids. She smiled still and barely batted an eye, “That’s right. Rio is your twin.”

“Melliza.”

“A very beautiful one, just like you’re very handsome.”

Rio felt Agatha press her leg closer against her own. She pressed right back.

Nicky was blushing now, hiding his face from Wanda with his head downturned and Rio sat up to wrap her arms back around him, “Very handsome.”

“Rio is handsome too,” Nicky mumbled, “Girls can be handsome. Rio said so.”

“That’s true,” Wanda agreed readily and Rio knew she was pleased she was getting some words out of Nicky now. “She’s very handsome.”

“Not as handsome as my mellizo,” Rio sang out as she ducked around to kiss Nicky’s burning cheek. Nicky giggled and squirmed and suddenly Rio felt a hand slide in against her stomach and Agatha was encircling her son too, leaning around him to kiss his other cheek and add with an edge to her voice: “Both very handsome.”

Rio knew Agatha wouldn’t wrap her arms around her in any meaningful way and so Rio couldn’t do it to her either. But this way, both folded around Nicky, was good too. It felt familial. It felt natural.

It felt like safety.

But Rio didn’t have long to enjoy the moment as Nicky giggled and Agatha pressed closer. The game was starting again and they had to pull back to watch it. But Agatha’s hand was now against the back of Rio’s chair as she sat forward in it again.

She was holding her. Just with enough space between them to avoid suspicion.

And then there was a voice against her ear, a soft question: “Have dinner with us?”

Rio raised her brows and allowed Nicky to grab her hands and haul them into the air as the team moved back onto the court. She watched Agatha, saw the shyness in her gaze and the way she couldn’t quite make eye contact and, as easy as breathing, whispered a soft: “Okay.”

Agatha did look up then. She looked up and met Rio’s gaze and Rio just knew that they were being watched from every angle. That phone cameras were pointed at them, that the world would witness the way Rio Vidal looked at Agatha Harkness like she’d stop time for her.

But she didn’t care.

She turned away only when Nicky wanted her attention again and threw herself back into the game with him as best she could.

Despite trying to concentrate she now knew she had to deal with breaking the news to Wanda that she was ditching her at the last minute. But she had to do it without Nicky realising it hadn’t been the plan all along.

So, as the play went on she leant over slightly to get her attention and whispered against her ear: “I’m going to have dinner with Nicky for his birthday instead tonight. Is that okay? You’ll still have Jessica?”

Wanda turned to her and in her eyes Rio saw a flash of hurt that made her frown and feel suddenly guilty but Wanda smiled and the hurt was gone.

“Of course. I wouldn’t want to deprive your twin of his favourite person.”

Rio hummed quietly and leant her head against the back of Nicky’s as Wanda rubbed her back affectionately. She made a mental note to send Wanda flowers or something. Perhaps a woolly hat to keep her warm in the cold of Atlanta. Wanda winked at her and she felt nothing for it the way she had when Agatha had done the same earlier.

But she loved her. She was grateful to her. Perhaps if she hadn’t asked her to come today she wouldn’t now be here with Agatha and Nicky.

When she turned back to the game she could feel Agatha watching her but she focused in again - for Nicky, if nothing else.

She time was called on the quarter Agatha made a move that made Rio turn to her. But she hadn’t been aiming for Rio. She looked at ease, free. And Rio found herself staring at her again as she playfully wrestled the little boy into her lap.

“C’mere,” Agatha grinned as she tugged Nicky to her and stole him from Rio’s grasp. Nicky clearly didn’t mind this and he laughed as Agatha tickled his sides and Rio grinned at the sight, feeling for the first time in days now, a genuine sense of peace as she watched them.

But it didn’t last long.

There’s a song, attributed sometimes to Kurt Vonnegut but created by the director Baz Luhrmann and taken from a hypothetical commencement speech by Mary Schmich. It’s convoluted mythology is at odds with its simple, repeated instruction: “Wear sunscreen.”

It’s a song that’s more of a guide through life, a song where, depending on who you are as a person, different lines will stick out to you.

One that comes to Rio’s mind now as she turns to Wanda is: “The real troubles in your life are apt to be things that never crossed your worried mind; the kind that blindside you at 4pm on some idle Tuesday.”

Only it wasn’t Tuesday, it was Saturday.

Saturday in TD Garden in downtown Boston. A Saturday spent beside the family Rio wished she had and with thousands of people who knew her name but not her heart.

A Saturday where, upon Wanda’s warning of “heads up!”, Rio looked to the jumbotron and saw an unknown couple surrounded by a frame of pink hearts.

Rio stared at it, a sinking feeling in her stomach as the view changed and the whole arena erupted.

There she was, wide-eyed in her Celtics sweatshirt, Wanda beside her in her stolen cap and genuine grin. And, worst of all, just to the edge of the frame was a suddenly pale Academy Award Winner holding her confused young son.

Rio watched as if she weren’t herself, as if the Rio Vidal on the screen were someone other than the Rio Vidal it was happening to. Wanda’s hand was on the other Rio’s cheek. The other Rio had turned. And all the actual Rio saw were smiling green eyes.

Wanda was leaning in, tilting her head.

All she felt were soft lips as they pressed to her own, the feel of Wanda’s nose squashing into her soft cheek.

All she felt was a small hand grasp the back of her collar.

All she knew was the weight that comes with guilt and sinks your soul to the bottom of your stomach.

The crowd was going wild all around them and Rio pulled back, forcing a smile at the woman who’d just kissed her, vaguely aware of Nicky as he threw himself on her back again. The crowd were hollering and Nicky was leaning over Rio to reach for Wanda.

The jumbotron had moved on now but the foursome by the court side hadn’t.

Nicky was now trying to push at Wanda, his right arm tight around Rio’s neck again. But it was no use. She already couldn’t breathe.

“Nicky,” she gasped out, feeling the absence of Agatha’s help behind her. Her thigh was no longer pressing int her own.

She managed to take Nicky’s flailing hand and heard him make a soft noise of protest against her ear. “It’s okay, Nicky. It was just pretend.”

She managed to turn her body around and tug him into a tight cuddle. It took a second but she felt him relax against her as he sat side on, his arms tight again around her neck, his whole face hidden where he pressed in against her and his cap protected him from view.

Rio took a breath and then glanced at Agatha and saw that she looked almost green as she stared down at where Nicky’s legs were curled together. Her fingers were so tight against the fabric of her jersey that she looked like she were trying to rip it in two. Rio stared down at the ‘4’ emblazoned on it.

They were a long way away from the last time they’d been in this arena together. Back when Rio had realised she was in love. How poetic, she thought bitterly as she raised her gaze to watch Agatha work her jaw, that now she was here realising that she would lose Agatha.

She couldn’t say anything because how could she make this better? How could she say “I had to”, “I didn’t know”, “it just happened”, when all she really wanted to say was “Kiss me. Now, in front of your son, in front of the world.”

Instead she reached for Agatha’s hand, and found Agatha pulling away from her.

She swallowed, a soft, high-pitched noise escaping her as she returned her hand to Nicky and finally Agatha looked up. She was smiling, but she looked unlike the Agatha she knew. She was far from the free and easy woman who’d just been tickling her son. Far from the woman who’d pressed as close as she’d dared and asked Rio to have dinner with them.

She’d put her mask back on but beneath it Rio could see the venom pooling.

She wanted to know what she was feeling, wanted her to scream or cry. And then, she let her in, maybe five second’s worth of feeling, but it was enough.

Her eyes were everything like the sun. They burned bright and dangerous and Rio saw in them the fiery inferno of her own personal hell.

But Agatha looked away again and instead reached for Nicky but Nicky refused to move.

“Honey,” Agatha whispered, now leaning behind Rio to speak directly to him, trying to see his face. “Come here.”

It was far from the playful pull that had happened earlier. Instead now it was a jealous take back. She didn’t want Rio to have Nicky anymore.

Nicky twitched in her hold and then she released him as he began to struggle to pull back and suddenly she could see everything that she felt in a face that was so like hers. Nicky still had his arms around Rio’s neck, Agatha’s hands on his calves, his wide eyes on his mama.

“I want to go home.”

“Melizzo.” / “Honey.”

“Just us,” Nicky clarified as the crowd cheered for something happening around them.

“You don’t want to see the rest of the game?”

“No I hate pretend I don’t want it anymore.”

“We’re not pretend, Nicky.” Even as she said the words she knew she shouldn’t have because Agatha beside her froze and Nicky frowned as he looked up at her.

The shouts got louder then and just as Nicky was about to open his mouth to speak Rio was jostled urgently by Wanda beside her and she turned to her wide eyes before she looked up to see exactly why people were shouting.

On the big screen again was the actress Rio Vidal and her mini-me cuddled up against her. Agatha had clearly followed her line of sight too because she was now looking up at the screen and putting on her best movie star grin as the crowd went wild once more.

Rio watched herself smile as Nicky looked up from beneath his cap and winced at the sight of himself so large and so public. He turned into Rio and hid over her shoulder as the image of three movie stars and a shy little boy remained for the whole arena to see.

Wanda’s arm was around Rio’s back but Agatha hadn’t done the same.

They’d once been tangled up together at an after party, Agatha possessively touching her in ways Wanda could only dream of. She’d had her hand on her neck, her thigh, and she’d leant in so close under the pretence of a whispered conversation that Rio still remembered the ghost of her breath against her lips.

But now she simply sat and smiled. Back then she’d been Rio’s. But this was now.

Rio’s fake smile widened on the screen and then it was gone.

The camera had moved on but Rio, Nicky, and Agatha, still had not. Wanda was laughing, a joyous, unfiltered sound beside her, but Rio was focused on the tight hold of Nicky, on his shoulder pressed so firmly against her windpipe, of the absence of everything Agatha.

“Are we gone?”

“Sí, mellizo.”

Nicky pulled back again and Rio adjusted his cap as Wanda announced: “I think I might enjoy basketball?!”

Rio shot her a small smile as Nicky turned to her, swivelling and dropping his hold on Rio to do so. Nicky’s hand found her hair instead and he breathed in shakily before he said, “Y-you can’t take my melizza away today. Rio is mine and mama’s and I want her here for my birthday.”

Nicky was shaking, it was evident in his voice as he tried to raise it above the noise of the crowd so Wanda could hear, and evident in his body that shook against Rio. His little hand clutching her hair near the base of her scalp tugged her a little with every forced word. Rio held him closer, tried to calm him as best she could.

“Y-you can stay. Because you… because y-you like basketball. But you cannot h-have her.”

Rio’s head begs to throb. Violently. She looked to Wanda and saw that she looked so taken aback she was lost for words. But she nodded and managed a surprised smile and that seemed to be enough for Nicky as she settled more against her again.

The trembling was dying down, but Rio kept her hold tight.

“Well done, honey,” Agatha whispered so only Nicky and Rio could hear as Nicky turned back to them both with a sad frown but nodded at his mom’s words.

“And then we will leave and n-not be in pretend, okay please?”

Agatha kissed Nicky’s cheek but said nothing and Rio smiled sadly as she said, “Never pretend with you and your mama. Never, okay?”

Nicky nodded and lifted up to whisper into her ear, “You can kiss my mama, if you want. I think it would be okay.”

“Nicky,” Rio said, feeling her heart beating rapidly against her ribcage, “No I cant.”

“You don’t want to? It wouldn’t be pretend, I-I know it.”

Agatha had moved closer again and she was suddenly pulling Nicky from Rio’s hold and placing him down to sit between them. Agatha was using her own son as a barrier. The little boy looked up at Rio and stared beseechingly up at her, motioning now to his mom with his head, but Rio could only shake hers, could only smile sadly as she fixed his cap again.

“It can be confusing,” Agatha was saying as Rio broke eye contact with Nicky to look up at her, her hand resting gently atop his head, “Knowing what’s pretend and what’s not.”

Rio knew, even though Agatha was looking down at her son, that the words were meant for her. She just had to suck them up, had to swallow down the guilt and fear she felt, and had to turn back to the court as the players began to step back up.

Wanda beside her started up a conversation about the game, completely unaware of the catastrophic consequences of her actions. Together they’d managed to confuse a sensitive little boy and trigger the fight or flight response of an equally sensitive adult.

Rio leant forwards as the game began and with one hand twisted and twisted and twisted her hair whilst her other was taken by Nicky, now too sat forwards in his seat. Even Nicky’s continued hold on her didn’t stop the fear that was coursing through her veins.

She wouldn’t be leaving with them. Now Agatha wouldn’t want her to. Agatha might never want her near her son again.

Agatha might never speak to her again, might never look.

The dull pain that she’d been suffering all week crept back into her brain and Rio had to fight hard to concentrate, to look directly ahead, to fight off any and all signs that soon she’d be seeing flashing lights.

Breathing became difficult the longer she sat there. It was like there was a weight on her chest and with every passing second someone was adding to it. Nicky was still engrossed in the game but even his enthusiasm was somewhat subdued as the time ticked on.

Every so often, Wanda would lean around Rio to talk to Nicky. She tried with comments about the game, with compliments to his sweater, to the way he wore his new watch, but nothing elicited more than a soft “thank you” or “yes” from the little boy.

During these times Rio didn’t dare look around at Agatha, knowing if she did the weight would become too much and she’d be destroyed.

It was only as the game ended that Rio found herself moving.

The crowd roared for the win and Rio jumped up with them, Nicky by her side and quite literally jumping on the spot as he celebrated. Rio laughed at the sight, a second of joy peeking through her bleak reality, and she hauled him into her arms until she felt him being torn away.

Agatha was resentfully tugging him into her own arms and who was Rio to stop her?

Nicky didn’t seem to think anything was wrong so happily hugged his mom as Agatha kept her gaze down, the hardline of her jaw telling Rio everything she already knew.

“That was awesome!” Wanda shouted close by her ear, making Rio turn into her for the pain it caused to her already throbbing head.

“Yeah?” Rio couldn’t think of anything that was less awesome.

Wanda grinned as she placed her borrowed cap on Rio’s head and shook out her mane of long, red hair.

Rio just stood there. Useless. Pained. Wanting to die.

“Yeah!” Wanda flung her arm around Rio’s neck and Rio had no fight left in her anymore and no excuses to pull away. So she simply stayed still as Wanda swung herself around and cupped her mouth as she whispered into Rio’s ear. “I was really hoping you’d come out tonight, you know. I could take your mind off things…”

Rio sucked in a breath and looked up just in time to catch Agatha’s eye. She looked away immediately. But that wasn’t the point. The point was that she’d been watching.

Rio closed her eyes and turned a little into Wanda to whisper, “If you’re getting at what I think you’re-…”

“It’s just an offer. On the table. If you wanted it.” Wanda placed her hand on her stomach.

Rio sighed quietly and bit down on her lip. She pulled enough back to look at Wanda and was about to shut her down as gently as she could when Agatha spoke again. Rio turned immediately to look at her.

“We’re going,” she announced, holding Nicky’s shoulders as he stared with the deepest frown Rio had ever seen on him at the hand across her stomach. Rio felt sick suddenly, the idea of Agatha just leaving making her begin to sweat.

She made to step forwards but found Agatha was already meeting her halfway, already pulling her in for a close but impassive hug. She felt her breath against her ear, felt Nicky between them wrap his arms around her middle, heard Agatha’s harsh whisper: “Don’t follow us. Enjoy your dinner with your friend.”

“No,” Rio all but vomited out, trying to grab Agatha as she pulled away and tugged Nicky along with her.

“Mama!” Nicky protested as he was being led by Agatha who’d swept down to grab their jackets but not paused otherwise. Only, Nicky was struggling as he walked before her, turning around to look back at Rio and looking as confused and devastated as Rio felt.

She could only silently panic and watch as Agatha and her son disappeared into the crowds.

Wanda was tugging her arm, making her turn around and Rio raised her brows at her as Wanda said: “Why are they rushing away so soon?”

Rio knew the first answer to the question, it was as simple as a kiss. But there was another answer too, another, much worse answer that took Rio’s muddled brain far too long to come up with.

The crowds.

Agatha was trying to get Nicky out before the crowds became too heavy, too grabbing, too much.

She whipped her head around and saw nothing of Agatha or her son and the panic she’d been trying to keep at bay earlier flared again. Nicky was upset already. He’d be terrified now.

She turned to Wanda and as gently as she could she pulled away from her, “I need to go. I’ll see you later? Will you text me when you’re with Jess? And home safe?”

“You never answer your texts anyway.”

“Text Alice,” Rio offered absently as she went to grab her jacket and scarf and swung them on with her bag over the top. She kissed Wanda’s cheek and was about to turn when she was grabbed back.

“Rio, are you sure you won’t come out with us? The way she just left…”

Rio felt like she was swallowing down stones as she nodded, as she stepped back in and kissed Wanda’s cheek again, less rushed this time.

“I’m sure. I’m sorry. Thank you for… for taking my mind off of it all.

Wanda smiled her calm smile and Rio knew there were no hard feelings. She kissed her cheek again and then turned towards the masses of people making their way to the exit.

At the very top of the steps she could just about make out the back of Agatha’s head but she was so far away it could have been anyone. She ran to catch up. Only there were so many people now she couldn’t possibly get there fast enough.

Her name was being called from all directions but she ignored each request, each insistent hand, and finally managed to break through just as the funnel opened up to the main concourse inside the arena.

She spotted Agatha’s head again, saw the tense way her shoulders were raised, watched as people tried to get at her. It pushed her forwards, made her struggle through until she was just feet away from the mother and son.

She wasn’t in touching distance yet, wasn’t close enough that her voice could be recognised through the din.

But something happened before Rio could get closer. Agatha had turned around. She looked more frightened than Rio had expected. She was paler too.

She was looking for something, her panicked eyes darting about the place until they landed on Rio. Rio was close enough now to see Agatha take a sudden breath in, to watch as her brows shot up at the centre as if questioning what she was seeing. But Rio didn’t stop until she was close enough to count the freckles on her nose and to trap an equally panicked Nicky between them.

“I hired a guy,” Agatha began to explain, her breathing heavier than usual, her cheeks pink from the stress. “But-…”

“Agatha?! Agatha Harkness! Oh my god! She’s here!!”

It took half a second for Rio to make a decision. She bent down and heaved Nicky into her arms, wrapping one arm under him and the other raising to cradle his head so he could hide against her. The suddenness of the movement and the desperation of Nicky’s limbs clinging to her knocked his cap clean off his head but the swarm was closing in so it was sacrificed for the greater good.

Agatha briefly touched Rio’s hand that held her son’s head and then she nodded and turned and Rio followed close behind. Nicky was panting fast against her neck and choking her with his fear again but she kept her eyes on Agatha.

As they moved through, Agatha held one hand out behind her, holding it as if Rio would be capable of taking it.

At one point Rio had to push a guy away from reaching for Nicky’s head to ruffle his hair and Agatha must have sensed her stopping because she turned around and grabbed Rio’s hand and began tugging her along instead.

It was frantic and frightening but Rio kept her gaze on Agatha. Only Agatha.

They made it through.

Once outside, the crowds weren’t as tightly packed together so there was room enough to manoeuvre. Agatha’s grip on her hand remained vicelike, fierce.

But made it to a small opening and only then did Agatha turn properly to check on Nicky who was cowering and sniffing now, practically trying to crawl into Rio’s skin.

“Honey,” Agatha whispered urgently, trying to pull Nicky from Rio as Rio moved to encourage him to drop his legs. “Honey we need to go. You need to let go.”

“Nicky,” Rio began just as hurriedly, trying so hard to help but not wanting to hurt the boy. “Mellizo. It’s just us. Go to your mama for me.”

Nicky began to move, loosening his grip so that Rio could help him down and Agatha caught him as his legs hit the floor. For half a second their eyes met and Rio saw the fire back in sea blue. She saw the fury that Agatha had only just been able to keep under wraps and she felt her heart shatter and her head throb again.

“Mi amor,” she tried desperately, just as shadows covered them and Agatha turned from her.

A group of five men had approached from the side and without thinking, both Agatha and Rio stepped closer to Nicky, their hands crossing over one another to keep him protected.

“Don’t suppose we could get a group pic with you, ladies? Not every day you meet two such good looking movie stars.”

Rio had felt nauseous before but now she wanted to vomit. She held Nicky a little closer and was about to snap something when Agatha did it for her. “My son is with me. Get away from us.”

The man snorted and held up his hands in mock surrender but Rio knew he’d try again if they hung around so she grabbed Agatha’s arm and motioned with her head for them to move.

They walked quickly then, both still guarding Nicky as he jogged along between them. Agatha took the lead, moving as best she could through the crowds until they were in sight of a black SUV. There were photographers nearby, stationed out to see the celebs leaving the game.

A convoy of other SUVs suggested they weren’t to be the only victims of the paparazzi assault but Rio couldn’t care less about anyone else’s fate right now.

As they got closer Nicky dropped his head more and the shouts began.

It happened again. Amidst the “Rio! Agatha Agatha!” There were also shouts of “Nicky! Kid! Hey kid!”

Rio couldn’t control herself as after the fourth time of hearing the little boy’s name from a stranger’s mouth she yelled back: “Shut the fuck up!”

But they made it though again. The men had pressed in, clearly trying to rile Rio up once more. But she was focused now, focused on getting Nicky into the car as quickly and safely as possible. And Agatha had turned to her when she’d shouted.

She’d looked… grateful.

Ten more seconds of jostling and then Agatha made it to the door first and clambered in, turning halfway to accept her son into safety.

He felt lighter than usual as Rio helped to lift him into the car. His little body weighed nothing as she delivered him into his mother’s arms.

And then he turned, he reached for her, but Rio had to step back so the door could be shut.

Maybe it was the look on her face or maybe it was that she’d let go but without anyone saying a word, he knew immediately.

He screamed for her. A noise so violent that it made no sense in coming from such a tiny body. Over and over again he screamed her name but Rio had to close the door, had to watch as Agatha held him tight, as she kept her face forwards and her arms around her distraught little boy.

He was too young to understand.

“Rio! Rio! RIO! M-MELLIZA!”

As the door closed Nicky’s yells didn’t cease but they were muffled now, blocked by the metal and plastic barrier between them. Rio could see movement inside the car but only the shadowy figures of her loves hidden from her sight.

The man hired to guide the two back to the car was nowhere to be seen still. Rio was left alone, turning from the car that safely held her heart.

Chapter End Notes

A couple people guessed this would happen. Sorry.

It feels really bad right now but would you believe me if I said there is now light at the end of the tunnel?

Chapter 41: Taste the Rainbow (Part 1)

Chapter Summary

Agatha puts Nicky first.

Chapter Notes

Yes, the title is important

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Rio was ten paces away from the car.

Ten lonely steps.

Eleven.

Twelve.

It gave her time to think, time to process. Time to decide that she’d spend the evening alone in her hotel room, that she’d figure out to how grovel tomorrow, but for now she needed darkness, and she needed tequila.

She could hear her name being called from different directions but it wasn’t until a hand curled around her arm that she responded to any external stimuli. She twisted her arm upwards to release herself and strode on.

“Rio. Turn around.”

A man came at her from the front just as arm snaked its way around her from behind, tugging her backwards without her consent. Though the person now controlling her movement, now turning her around, now walking beside her with her arm around her didn’t need to wait for the verbal cue.

Agatha had come to get her.

Agatha was marching her the now thirteen paces back, opening the door for her, pushing her into the back of the car and into the clutching arms of her little son.

Rio hadn’t been able to compute the journey back, the arrival of Agatha. So Nicky crying against her didn’t get a reaction. She just sat there, her arms limp at her sides, her heart somewhere in this car, but unable to tell her what to do.

It took the slamming of the car door and a barked order from Agatha at the driver to “take us home, now,” for Rio to come back into her body.

She wrapped her arms around Nicky until she felt Agatha leaning around, “Seatbelts. Now, please. Nicky.”

Nicky tightened his hold briefly and then released Rio but not before shooting her the saddest look Rio had ever seen. Her heart, now found, broke inside her chest.

Agatha was leaning over her, ignoring her completely as she helped a sniffling Nicky with his belt.

Rio just sat there. Unable to speak or say anything.

Once Nicky was secure Agatha sat back and Nicky broke the silence by saying: “You left.”

Nicky sniffed loudly and Rio looked down at him but didn’t make a move. His eyes were wide and red and he was fiddling with hands in his lap as he stared up at her.

“Nicky,” she started to say just as Agatha reached across her aiming for the buckle of her seatbelt. But if she were strapped in she couldn’t get to Nicky. Not properly anyway.

She pushed Agatha’s hand away and turned properly in her seat only to hear her name being snapped from behind her. But she ignored it. She ignored Agatha and took Nicky’s hands in her own as a pale one curled around her shoulder and forced her back against the seat.

Agatha was leaning over her now, her eyes wild with fury, her lower jaw jutting out as she stared at Rio and reached blindly for her belt. She fumbled, unable to see where she was reaching but Rio grabbed her struggling hand before she could grab the belt, forcing her to stop.

“No. No. I’m fine. I’m fine.”

Agatha didn’t just stop what she was doing. She froze. Her hands that, back in the arena, had been cold, were now warm, fuelled by the fire in her gaze. Rio realised that the blue eyes that so often reminded her of the ocean were now the blue of complete combustion.

She was beyond fury, and Rio felt beyond hope.

Agatha was just inches away. So close that Rio imagined she could feel the heat from her flushed cheeks, the burn of her fiery gaze.

Nicky had looked up, confused, still sucking in shaking breaths. He reached for Agatha’s arm and asked a cautious: “Mama?”

But Agatha was moving again, diving for Rio’s belt buckle. Only Rio moved too, wrestling it out of Agatha’s hands and making a confused little boy even more confused as his mother and his melliza wrestled beside him.

Rio grunted with the effort of it. And Agatha, Agatha gnashed her teeth and managed to overpower her, eventually ripping her hands away coming down hard on Rio’s chest, pressing her firmly against the back of the seat.

Rio was gasping for breath, her chest rising and falling with Agatha’s splayed fingers across it. The tip of her ring finger was in the hollow of her throat and Rio could feel the heat of it. So attuned to Agatha now that she could feel the twitch of it, the infinitesimal movement that told her Agatha was torn between caressing and strangling her.

They stared. Rio’s eyes wide in shock, Agatha’s blue eyes still flaming their fury at her.

And then… “Lo siento, mi vida.”

Rio whispered the words, still trying to catch her breath, still trying to calm her racing heart.

“Mi vida,” Nicky imitated quietly, reaching his hand out to touch Agatha’s arm. If either of the two women locked on each other looked around at the little boy beside them they’d see the panic in his eyes.

But somethings can’t be turned away from.

Agatha began to move again, the hand not on Rio’s chest still curled around her belt buckle. She went to move it and Rio’s hand snapped out and stopped her even as Agatha applied more pressure to her chest.

“Mama,” Nicky said just as softly as his repeated words of Rio’s.

Rio sucked in a breath and relaxed her fingers so Agatha could pull the seatbelt over her and lock it in at her hip. Her hand had moved from her chest now but she still felt the pressure of it, the memory of Agatha’s palm pressed tight to her sternum.

Rio closed her eyes, felt Agatha leaning over her fully now to get to Nicky. She wasn’t pressing against her but Rio knew what her body felt like, knew how it would feel if she were.

Nicky sniffled and Rio turned slowly to look at him, seeing Agatha gently wipe his tears with her sleeve. “Mi vida,” he said quietly again, sniffing as Agatha pulled away and sat back properly.

Rio turned then to try and catch Agatha’s gaze, to get a read on the situation. But Agatha didn’t look up. She simply locked her own belt in and blindly reached across Rio for Nicky to take her hand.

Rio sat between them, her eyes down on the arm that now lay across her but barely made contact. It was Nicky again who broke her from her silent reverie.

“You left us.”

Rio turned and first glanced at the way Nicky was toying with Agatha’s fingers and then looked up to see his wide-eyed gaze.

“I-…”

“Rio went back to find your cap, honey.”

Agatha moved her arm just a fraction of an inch to press into Rio’s stomach. It felt like a warning.

She nodded, swallowed, forced a smile worthy of her academy award. “And then your mama came and told me you could just have mine. I didn’t mean to scare you, mellizo.”

To pay heed to her lie she removed the cap from her head and placed it on Nicky’s but the little boy still looked uncertain and he looked down at his mama’s hand as he said: “Is Wanda going to come over for dinner too?”

“No.”

Agatha’s tone was firmer than she’d ever heard it around Nicky and Rio watched the little boy glance at his mom before looking back to Rio. “Good. I want just us. Tres patitos.” Three ducklings.

“Patitos?” Rio asked curiously as she took a shot and gingerly lay her arm over Agatha’s to cradle the joined hands. Agatha didn’t move away.

The pressure on her chest lessened.

“I…,” Nicky glanced up at her from beneath his cap. “I just learned the word.” He sniffed, “I like the way it sounds. Pah-tee-tohs. And… and…,” he reached his other hand to cover Rio’s, “And ducklings stick together and are cute,” Nicky said as if it were the most obvious thing in the world though something about this fact made him suddenly shy. He sniffed again and kept his head down now. “Plus mama said you are always warm so… so we can cuddle you for warmth just like ducklings do. Patitos.”

“Your mama said that?”

Nicky nodded as Rio turned to look at Agatha and saw she had turned her head completely to look out the window. Rio brushed her thumb over the back of Agatha’s hand. She still didn’t turn around.

There was silence for a while before Nicky said, “Mi vida is nice too. It sounds nice.”

Agatha cleared her throat and Rio chose to say nothing.

“Mi vida,” Nicky repeated quietly, testing the words out for himself again. “Maybe after dinner we can watch a movie like we did before? Be all cosy. Just us three.”

Rio kept her smile up and nodded.

Nicky’s eyes were bright again as he looked up at her, his cheeks still pink, “Will… you stay? Will you, will you stay with us please?”

“I’ll stay for dinner, mellizo, but then I need to go back to my own hotel.”

“With Wanda?”

Agatha pulled her hand away then and Rio looked around to see if she’d turned yet but she kept her gaze obstinately out the window. Nicky tugged her arm and she reluctantly turned back, “Melliza, why do you keep leaving?”

“She won’t, Nicky.”

Agatha was back again. Her voice was thick with fury and as Rio looked around to her she saw her ocean eyes were tempests once more. “She’ll stay with us. With you, for your birthday, won’t you, Rio?”

Rio’s mouth went dry when Agatha met her gaze and she felt waves of panic wash over her. Her suspicions had been confirmed. Agatha had dragged her back for Nicky, and Nicky only.

“Yes, of course.”

She turned back around to Nicky and saw he looked concerned again, looking across at Agatha’s lap where she sat with her hands squashed between her thighs.

“Mama,” Nicky said quietly, straining against his seatbelt to try to reach for her.

“Nicky,” Agatha chastised quietly, moving to lean around so he sat back, “Sit properly. It’s not safe.”

“Rio’s here,” Nicky responded, “It’s okay now. Tres patitos. Ready for pizza and movies and ice cream!” He nodded encouragingly and wiped quickly at his nose as he said after a second of deliberation, “Mi vida.”

Rio swallowed and reached for Agatha’s hand but apparently without Nicky’s in between she just wouldn’t allow it. Agatha had pulled back, moved her hand to brush through Nicky’s growing, messy hair instead.

“Dos patitos y Rio.”

Never in her life had Rio wanted to be a duckling. Never before had she thought about how cute they were. She’d never considered their attributes: the fact that they followed one another, that they huddled together for comfort and warmth, that their entire worlds were tied to their little brood.

But now, as Agatha excluded her, she longed for the inclusion. She wanted to be a duckling, cuddled with her others, giving them her warmth.

“No,” Nicky protested for her, straining again against his seatbelt. “Mama, tres. Three. Three ducklings.”

Agatha didn’t say anything as she pressed Nicky back into his seat and Rio remained silent also. She couldn’t exactly say anything. Though she considered quacking.

“Tres patitos,” Nicky muttered, frowning as Rio held her hand out to him and he took it.

Rio smiled a little as Nicky’s fingers curled around her own. Agatha was back sitting properly, her gaze out the window once more as Nicky said: “What is ‘mi vida’?”

Rio chewed on her lip for a second and shot Agatha a look to see if she’d turned before she looked back to Nicky and said: “It means, ‘my life’.”

Nicky nodded slowly and looked down at their hands as he repeated the words to himself over and over. “It does sound nice,” he concluded quietly and Rio said nothing else as he toyed with her fingers.

The car became silent then, just Rio and Nicky frowning at their joined hands and Agatha looking again out the window.

It had been ten minutes all in until the car pulled up outside, not a hotel, but a building on a residential street. Rio leant forward to look out the window and check if it were a boutique hotel or else she’d missed the facade a few car lengths back. But she didn’t see anything to suggest a hotel was anywhere near.

Agatha was leaning across her again, making her pull back. But Agatha didn’t seem to even notice that she was there, instead helping Nicky with his belt as the door was opened.

“Honey, climb over,” Agatha had her arms out to Nicky after having stepped out of the car and Rio remained still as she waited for him to clamber over and out onto the street. She followed shortly after and watched as Agatha marched hand in hand with her son and Nicky looked over his shoulder to make sure she were still there.

Rio tipped the driver and then followed behind, hovering just out of reach of Nicky’s seeking hand until he said loudly: “Rio! Come here please!”

Rio hurried to take his hand then and the boy frowned as if he were frustrated with the lack of expediency.

They were in Beacon Hill, a historic, quaint suburb and Rio was surprised when Agatha let them in to the double-fronted door of the building and said to Nicky: “Welcome home, honey.”

“This is… your place?”

“Yes.” Agatha said absently, helping Nicky to remove his jacket and cap as Rio stood and stared at Agatha.

“Rented, you mean?”

“No.”

Rio blinked. She stared.

Nicky went to reach for the middle button on her jacket to help her out of it. “Hurry, Rio. We have to go see my room.”

“Uh,” Rio began to help Nicky’s littler fingers and quickly removed her coat, hanging it in the nearby hook as Nicky bounced on the balls of his feet and Agatha stood nearby, not exactly looking at her.

She swallowed and removed her scarf, taking her time in draping it over her jacket on the hook. Her fingers skimmed down the fabric, wondering if there was any way she could get Agatha to speak to her with Nicky around.

Turning back around she looked to Agatha first. She wished she hadn’t.

Agatha’s face was downturned, her jaw still as tight as ever. Rio thought she might have stayed behind if Nicky hadn’t reached for her hand after taking Rio’s as he began pulling the two adults along behind him like his personal chaperones.

“You bought this place?” Rio asked as they were pulled along, her eyes darting this way and that through the hall on their way up to Nicky’s room.

Agatha didn’t answer and also didn’t look at her but Rio stared at her as they walked the stairs, journeyed through the hall, and then made it to Nicky’s room.

“Do you like it?!”

Nicky’s room was painted a sage green, not quite Celtics green, but the basketball hoop on the wall and the Celtics bedspread helped to tie the theme together. Nicky dragged Rio further into the room and pointed out all the important bits until he turned around and beamed at Agatha who’d been left to stand by the door.

Agatha relaxed, at least, her face did, and she dropped down to her knees to motion for Nicky to come close. For a second Rio let herself believe everything was okay.

Agatha was Nicky was always softer. Her softest self. She looked at peace when he was near, but especially when he was in her arms. The sight of it allowed Rio to play some of the pretend Nicky was so worried about.

Pretend everything was fine.

Pretend she had a place in the hearts of these two.

Nicky was pulling back and Agatha held his face as she kissed each of his cheeks and smiled as she rested their foreheads together. Pretend dissolved as Rio suddenly felt like she was intruding. Like she shouldn’t even be in the property, let alone the room.

She mumbled a soft apology and went to step towards the door but stopped in her tracks when she heard Nicky call her back and say: “Tres patitos?”

Rio closed her eyes and felt torn suddenly, torn between turning and faking it and leaving and living with the knowledge that she’d denied Nicky his birthday wish. Perhaps she’d remained still for too long, perhaps her indecision was obvious, but whatever the reason, Agatha was speaking this time: “Tres, Rio. Uno, dos… tres.”

Rio turned cautiously and saw two faces looking up at her, one of hopeful enthusiasm, the other cautious, almost suspicious. She sucked in a breath and dropped down to her knees, holding her arms out like Jesus on the cross.

“Quack quack.”

Nick laughed as he shuffled his way across and wrapped his arms around her but Agatha stayed still for a while, and Rio knew she was thinking hard about her next move. She sucked in a breath and then raised an arm to her from where it had been around Nicky.

Maybe pretend for one night was okay.

Agatha met her gaze properly for the first time since the wrestling match in the car then and Rio mouthed to her, “Mi amor, please.”

She didn’t move for a few seconds. And then, much slower than her son, she moved in.

Rio felt like she could breath again when Agatha pressed into her, trapping Nicky between them and wrapping her arms around her. Nicky giggled contentedly but Rio could have cried for it. Hope, as flighty as it still felt, wasn’t completely lost.

“Tres patitos,” Nicky murmured after a while, releasing a contented sigh as Rio turned her head more into Agatha, taking advantage of the proximity and Nicky’s inability to see them. But Agatha turned her head, pressed closer so their cheeks were together but Rio had no other access.

“¿Es tan mala besando como actriz?” Is she as bad a kisser as she is an actress?

“Mi vida,” Rio begged quietly as Agatha pulled away.

Only she hadn’t been quiet enough because Nicky looked up now he was free to do so and repeated: “Mi vida.”

Rio looked at him and reworked her face into a smile whilst Agatha stood from the floor, “Come on, drinks and snacks before dinner.”

Nicky jumped up and hurried after his mom and Rio remained crouched on the floor. In her line of sight was a chest of drawers, sitting proudly with framed photos of Nicky and Agatha, with little basketball figurines and even a miniature Celtics shield. The signs of a life, of a family, were all about the room.

Rio was the only piece out of place.

“Rio.”

She turned too fast and fell onto her ass. Agatha was in the doorway, looking tense and hesitant. Her sea-blue eyes took in the sight of her on the floor, simply staring up at her. She shifted on the spot and then took a step closer.

“I got you back for Nicky.”

Rio swallowed and nodded, her heart was blocking her airway so she couldn’t speak.

“You told me you’d never hurt him.”

Rio scrambled then, rushing as quickly as her tired body could make her go. She reached Agatha and didn’t hesitate to hold her face, just as Agatha didn’t hesitate to hold her waist. But it looked more like she was doing it to keep her steady, than for any other reason.

“I won’t. I promise. I love him I want-…”

Agatha dropped her gaze to her lips and from the devastation on her face Rio just knew she was thinking about Wanda. About the kiss.

“Kiss me. Please. Kiss me. I don’t want anyone else. I just want you. I’m so sorry.”

Agatha breathed out, and Rio gasped, a sharp, sudden inhalation. She wanted to breathe Agatha in, wanted to survive only at the behest, at the grace of the woman she held before her.

“No.”

They locked eyes again and for a second Rio felt like all was lost. She’d lost Agatha. She’d only ever have her in pretend.

Only ever Christmas wives.

But then Agatha moved her face, she dislodged Rio’s hold on her and she pressed her face into the palm of Rio’s right hand. Rio gasped softly, watching it for a moment, trying to memorise the way Agatha’s lips parted as she breathed her hot breath against her. She could make out the pattern of her freckles, the curve of her eyelashes.

She couldn’t lose her. She had to try, had to make her listen.

Rio stepped closer, resting her forehead against Agatha’s temple. She took a breath and then whispered: “I love you.”

Agatha gasped quietly, her lips parting and closing against Rio’s palm.

The throbbing of her brain that had plagued her since Wanda’s lips had pressed into her own dissipated as Agatha held her closer. She was nuzzling now, tracing her lips and nose down until they found the sensitive spot on Rio’s inner wrist.

The touch made Rio shiver, made her duck her head down to try and take what Agatha wouldn’t give her.

But Agatha had pulled away.

She wasn’t looking at her now, wasn’t touching her. “There’s a spare toothbrush in the bathroom down the hall. Use it. Come down for drinks. I’ll pour you a wine.”

Agatha was gone.

Rio ran her hands through her hair and breathed out until her body was empty of air. She felt the dizziness of it, sat in it for a few seconds, and then went to do as Agatha had asked.

In the bathroom down the hall she not only brushed her teeth, but she used to mouthwash she found too.

Agatha wanted rid of any memory of Wanda and she had no problem complying. The kiss had been chaste, she’d touched her lips, felt the warmth of her cheek. But she hadn’t tasted her on her tongue, didn’t know the warmth of Wanda’s mouth.

She’d tasted Agatha, she knew the warmth of Agatha. She knew the way Agatha was so ready with her moans whenever she got the chance to roll her tongue against hers.

Even if she had tasted Wanda, she’d have easily been able to scrub her away. But Agatha? Even a she place the toothpaste on the brush she could taste her, she could feel her touch.

She blocked it out, finding it too difficult to think about. Her headache intensified.

Only when she was minty fresh did she head back down the stairs to find Agatha and Nicky. The condo was bright and airy with high ceilings and white walls. And she soon found herself in the family room where Nicky was showing off his watch to his mom on the couch. Before them lay two glasses of wine and a soda.

“Rio,” Nicky said excitedly when he noticed her arrival, “Come show mama.”

Rio moved across and sat on Nicky’s other side, only to have him complain under his breath and shuffle into his mom’s lap. He motioned for her to move in and when she did he sat across both of them and held out his watch for inspection.

“Mama, maybe we can get you one too.”

“Not really my style, honey.”

Rio remained silent as Nicky pressed buttons on both their watches and looked instead around the room. Agatha had never mentioned that she had a place in Boston. She’d stayed in a hotel before. But this place, it had pictures of Nicky everywhere, even one of Jen and Agatha on the sideboard.

It was lived in. Or at least looked it.

“When did you get this place?”

She turned as she asked the question and found that Agatha was already watching her. She looked calmer again, but sadder too. Rio shifted and turned her body more, doing her best not to dislodge Nicky.

“When I got the season ticket.”

Rio raised her brows and smiled just a little, hoping to tease Agatha out of her shell inch by inch. “So you’re rich rich?”

Agatha’s brow twitched but she didn’t smile and Rio sighed quietly as Agatha turned to heave Nicky off of their laps and onto the couch. As Agatha leant to grab the glasses of wine Rio reached to hold her, draping her arm over her stomach.

“Agatha.”

Agatha was leaning back with the wine in her hands and she turned to Rio and in a single breath she said: “Sigo imaginándolo.” I keep picturing it.

Rio nodded and twisted the fabric of Agatha’s jersey in her fingers for just a second before she pulled away and took the wine offered to her. In handing it over, their fingers overlapped and Rio looked up again to meet Agatha’s gaze.

Their eyes locked once more and Rio felt her heart trying to pull itself from her chest.

She couldn’t get a handle on how Agatha was feeling. She was angry, without a doubt. But she was hiding it, or at least suppressing it, for Nicky’s sake. But beneath it, beneath the waves of fury in her stormy blue eyes was something else, something a lot worse than anger.

Rio felt her head burst with pain for the possibilities.

“Mama? Melliza?””

They both turned and Rio took her glass properly from Agatha’s hand as Nicky knelt up on the couch and grinned, “Is it pizza time yet?”

“Honey, it’s pizza time whenever you want it to be.”

Agatha pushed herself up and Rio forced herself to focus in on Nicky. The very least she could do was to be present for him now. God knows she’d seen him cry enough to last a lifetime.

“But first will you show me your bike?”

Nicky readily agreed and Rio put her wine down and spent the next twenty minutes rummaging through her brain for anything she could say about bicycles. But it turned out Nicky didn’t need that much encouragement.

With Rio’s help he sat on the bike and pretended to pedal as fast as he could go. Rio laughed. She cheered. She praised the speed that Nicky’s little legs could take him whilst she held the bike steady.

And when Nicky was out of breath and so pleased with himself that he was practically glowing, Rio helped him down and turned to find that they’d had an audience almost the whole time.

“Pizza’s on its way,” Agatha announced when she realised she’d been caught. “And Rio, Alice is trying to reach you.”

Agatha’s face was impassive but Rio still felt the keen sting of her words and she nodded once, swallowing down her panic as she said. “I, uh, doubt my phone is even charged can I…?”

With a nod from Agatha, Rio stepped forwards to accept the phone held out to her as Agatha said: “Nicky, honey, go pick a movie to watch in the den, okay? Whatever you want. Rio and I have to do something first.”

Rio’s stomach began to churn as she followed Agatha through to the kitchen. She gripped her phone so tightly she wondered if perhaps she could snap it in half and therefore have an excuse not to make the call.

But Agatha left her for a second and Rio collapsed back against the counter, counted to ten in her head, and then looked down just as ‘Alice’ lit up the screen. She swiped to answer as Agatha came back and placed her wine by her hip.

“Hey.”

“Agatha, I swear-… Rio.”

Rio closed her eyes and sighed out heavily, “It’s everywhere?”

“Are you fucking kidding me?! It’s all over the internet, Rio. Did you think for a second it wouldn’t be? What the fuck! I mean, what the fuck! I’ve had Wanda’s agent on the fucking phone and I-…”

“It just happened, Alice. I-it just happened it-…”

She looked up and saw Agatha leaning back against the counter opposite. Her own glass of wine was beside her. It was empty.

“It’s a fucking clusterfuck, Rio. Six months ago if this had happened then, great! But now Jen has been screaming at me and Agatha barely said a word when I got her a second ago and-…”

“Alice,” Rio tried quietly, watching as Agatha turned from her as she poured herself another glass of wine. “I’m sorry. I should have-…”

“I mean it’s not like you could've done anything!” Alice was ranting now. “What? Pushed her away? Stuck your tongue down Agatha fucking Harkness’s throat?!”

Rio closed her eyes again, wishing she’d done exactly that.

“It’s fine, it’s fine. You’ve always been friendly with Wanda. You’ve always been close! It’s just that. Just that. We’ll let the fucking rumours swirl and-… fuck, Rio. Is Agatha there? Is she… holy shit if Jen’s taken this badly then-…”

Rio looked back up and saw that Agatha’s glass was empty again, she was wiping her mouth with the back of her wrist, her eyes somewhere near Rio’s knees.

Rio couldn’t make herself speak, she just stared ahead of her, let Alice continue to rant in her ear about ‘fucking vultures’. And then, Agatha looked up at her. She looked lost and unsure and Rio stepped forwards but Agatha just shook her head.

“They got you shouting at the fucking paps too. Rio you gotta not do that. You know how-…”

“They were shouting for Nicky.” Rio had found the voice again. “Of course I was going to-…”

The phone was snatched from her clutches and Rio blinked as she looked at the woman who’d taken it.

“Was it you?”

Rio heard nothing on the end of the line, and simply stared at a furious Agatha Harkness, somehow two inches taller than usual, somewhere radiating anger. She was so close now, so close that it felt like a biological imperative for Rio to reach out to her. She clutched at the sides of her jersey and Agatha didn’t push her away.

“Alice,” she insisted when still there was no answer, “Alice did you set up the jumbotron? Did you-…”

“Agatha,” Rio whispered, watching as blue eyes flashed to her own. But before either of them could say anything else she heard Alice’s voice again, distant and tinny.

“No. Holy shit, no. The kiss cam just-… holy shit Agatha it just happens. I didn’t set-…”

Rio didn’t hear the rest because Agatha had pressed the phone back to her. Rio took it and after a second of looking at her Agatha turned, grabbed her glass and the bottle, and left her alone.

Raising the phone back to her ear she heard Alice calling out to see if anyone was there.

“She’s so upset, Alice.”

“Hey. Hey. It wasn’t-… I mean, shit, Rio. Shit. You went back with her. She got you to come back, right? I saw the pictures of her grabbing you. Is that what it was? It’s not clear. They’re all fucking out of sequence but Nicky wasn’t there so I-…”

“She brought me back because Nicky wanted me not because-…” Rio released a soft sob and hid her face in the hand Agatha had pressed into only minutes ago.

“Rio,” Alice said more urgently. “Rio, take a breath, okay? Deep breaths.”

Rio nodded and did as she was told, feeling her lungs expand and contract with each one until she’d taken five and Alice spoke again: “I’m handling this on our side. The PR will work itself out. Two friends having fun at a basketball game. I tried-… I told Jen it would help with any eyes on you and Agatha during the divorce but-… she can’t hear it right now. She’s worried about Agatha and Agatha won’t answer her calls. I don’t know why she answered for me.”

Rio nodded slowly, still trying to take deep breaths. “Babe, try and talk to her. Try and tell her how you feel.”

Rio nodded again, sucking in another breath until she said: “It isn’t Wanda’s fault. She-…”

“I mean it is a little.”

“I… if she knew about, about Agatha,” Rio felt light-headed then because right now it didn’t feel like there was anything more to know about her and Agatha. “If she’d known she wouldn’t have-… I couldn’t tell her I just-… I mean, I-...”

“Look,” Alice said in a voice that Rio knew as her ‘I’m going to lose it in a second so please listen’ voice. “I know she’s a good friend. I know that-… I know she wouldn’t have done it if-… Jesus fucking Christ. It was just a fucking bad idea and right now whether she meant to or not it-… Just fucking talk to Agatha, okay? Try to. You both want this to work. Holy shit my fucking girlfriend is going to explode with how much she wants this to work. So talk to her. Try to, I don’t know, reassure her. But, Rio. Yourself first, okay? It’s a miracle you’re still standing.”

Rio shook her head and pressed her lips tightly together when the threat of tears suddenly washed over her. She’d rather be a puddle on the floor but have Agatha than be still standing without her.

Rio made a soft noise as her throat contracted and then Alice said: “Get your girl back, Rio. I know you’re grieving. I know what I’ve said about her before and I know I… I’m sorry I set this trip up. I thought it would do you good to get away. Wanda’s fun and she’s easy to be around and I just thought… I fucked up.”

“You didn’t,” Rio gasped out. “I just… I just need to talk to her, Alice. I-…”

“She won’t want to lose you. Don’t think you’ve lost her. I told her I’d kill her if she broke your heart again so she’ll be too worried about that to actually-…”

Rio released a soft laugh and wiped quickly beneath her eyes.

“I’ll work on Jen. I’ll sort everything with the press. But I’ll come and get you if you need me to, okay?”

“What if this is it? What if-…?”

“She pulled you back. She-…”

“For Nicky. Not because-…”

“Rio, please listen to me. She fucked up. She did. And I fucking hate that she did but everything she’s done since-… just please try to breathe, try to not spiral. She loves you. You love her, right? It was just some stupid fucking kiss and you’ll get through this.”

Rio sighed out heavily and nodded. Alice was silent for a while and then: “Is your head bad again?”

Rio sniffed and nodded, realised Alice couldn’t see her, then cleared her throat. “Yeah.”

“Take some pain meds. Drink plenty of water. I’ll get you in with your doctor when you’re back, okay? And please, call me if you need me.”

Rio nodded again, said a soft goodbye, and hung up. She remained in the kitchen until her breathing was even, until she was sniffing less, and until her tears were dry. Her wine helped with the crying.

She took her glass and went out to find Agatha and Nicky and saw them curled up in the middle of the large sofa together. Agatha didn’t look her way but Nicky did and he grinned where he’d been tucking into a bowl of m&ms.

“Before dinner?!” Rio scoffed as she sat down a couple feet away from them both. “That doesn’t seem right.”

“It’s okay on my birthday! You can have some too.”

Rio took a handful, though she’d never felt less like candy, and sat back against the cushions. It didn’t take long for Nicky to shuffle closer under the pretence that he was sharing his candy but Rio soon felt a small hand slip into her own and she squeezed it as the choice of movie, Spider-Man: Into The Spiderverse, started.

They watched in silence for close to ten minutes until the buzzer went and Agatha moved away to go and get the pizza. When they were alone Nicky whispered to Rio: “Pizza is my favourite.”

Rio laughed and raised her brows, glancing up again when Agatha arrived carrying two big pizza boxes and two smaller ones on top.

“Pizza for ducklings!”

Rio shuffled to the edge of her seat as Agatha bypassed them and went to the kitchen to sort the food. Nicky ran after her and left Rio alone, staring down at her wine. She remained like that until the room was busy again with Nicky yapping about his love of pepperoni and potato wedges and Agatha with the dark cloud she now carried over her head.

They all settled around the coffee table and Agatha handed out plates and napkins. Nicky dug in and Rio grabbed a small slice and found as she bit into it and focused back on the screen another, larger slice was slapped onto her plate.

Agatha didn’t look up at her as Rio looked over. She was looking straight ahead watching the cartoon as she ate her own slice. Rio knew why she’d done it but it didn’t make the food any more appetising.

But she ate. She finished the two slices, a handful of wedges, another handful of m&ms. She drank down her wine.

Agatha said nothing the whole time. Only Nicky spoke, repeating lines from the movie or reacting to the more exciting scenes. He sometimes asked Rio if she were enjoying it, if she wanted more m&ms.

And Rio responded but her heart wasn’t in it. Her head still hurt and she could feel an ache in her chest but there was nothing she could do. Not with Nicky so close.

Eventually they piled their plates and moved back to the couch. Nicky settled happily against Agatha and was so full and content that he didn’t reach for Rio who sat just a foot or so away.

She toyed with her hands, twirled her hair, chewed the inside of her cheek.

Perhaps if she’d told Wanda she was seeing someone, an unnamed someone. Perhaps if she’d turned her cheek at the last second. Perhaps if she’d been more forceful, been more exacting in her words and in her actions.

Wanda didn’t know. Wanda couldn’t have known what she’d done. She was angry at Agatha, sure, but her career wasn’t worth her anger. She wouldn’t have done it if she’d known for sure anything was happening.

Rio knew that. She trusted her friend. But the longer she sat with Agatha and Nicky just out of reach the more her anger built. She was suddenly angry at Wanda and furious with herself.

The energy it took to keep her alive at this point wasn’t enough to keep her rational, keep her hopeful.

“Rio,” Agatha’s voice was soft beneath the intensity of the action on screen. “Will you squash in? I need to go make a call.”

Rio turned and nodded, accepting Nicky into the crook of her arm as she watched Agatha grab her phone from the side and disappear off. Nicky didn’t even blink when she left but Rio kept her eyes on the door to the little den and held her breath until she was back.

It took well over half an hour, well over the time Rio could actually hold her breath, for Agatha to return. She looked tense, much more so than when she’d left. But she didn’t look Rio’s way when she sat back down.

Rio reached across for her, needing just to see her eyes, just to know Agatha was in there somewhere, hidden beneath the fury.

Agatha didn’t turn for a while, but Rio’s hand remained on her shoulder, her fingers curling to scrunch the fabric of the sweater she’d changed into when making her phone call. Rio thought she wasn’t going to look but eventually she did.

Rio sucked in a silent gasp at the sight of her pale face. She looked tense still, her features carved from marble as her eyes darted about Rio’s face. She was looking for something, unable to rest her gaze on her.

Rio squeezed her shoulder and mouthed: “I’m sorry.”

Agatha didn’t acknowledge it, her eyes settling on Rio’s mouth as she repeated the words again, and then again. Agatha’s eyelids looked heavy all of a sudden and then her eyes disappeared behind them.

Agatha hiding from her always hurt. But this time it hurt so exquisitely that Rio saw a flash in the corner of her vision. She flinched and pulled her hand away to pinch the bridge of her nose and try to fight off the threat.

“Rio,” she heard movement beside her, felt Nicky shift against her. “I’ll get you some meds.”

Agatha had moved away and Rio felt her cheeks heat from embarrassment, even as Nicky leant up to touch one. “You okay, melliza? Too much candy?”

Rio managed a smile as she continued to pinch her nose, “Something like that.”

Nicky shuffled back when Agatha arrived back in the room and she heard her stopping in front of her, felt her lean in, heard her soft whisper: “Take them then go to bed.”

“No,” Rio’s eyes opened then and she looked first to a stern Agatha and then a concerned Nicky. “No. It’s Nicky’s birthday. I’m staying up. I’ll be fine just… a long day.”

Nicky settled back and watched as Rio quickly took the offered pills and swallowed them without the water. Agatha straightened from where she’d leant over and watched her for much longer than necessary before she clapped her hands together.

“Nicky! Off! Off the couch!”

The noise should have made her feel worse but there was something distracting about Agatha’s comically deep frown and pursed lips as she barked orders at her now giggling son.

“Upstairs! Blankets! As many as you can carry! Quick! Before I start the movie again and you miss the final fight!”

Nicky ran from the room screaming his ‘nooooooo!’ and Agatha relaxed herself instantly and dropped down before Rio, her frown gone, her concern back. “No te estás cuidando a ti mismo.” You’re not looking after yourself.

It wasn’t a question, just a fact.

But Rio was distracted because Agatha’s hands were on her knees, her thumbs drawing small concentric circles. Rio wondered if Agatha even knew she were doing it.

“I’m doing my best.”

“It’s not good enough.”

Rio opened her mouth to respond but found she was being choked again. Only Nicky wasn’t to blame this time. Her breath hitched as she tried to free the blockage in her airways and she made a choking sound that made Agatha kneel up suddenly.

She pressed her front against Rio’s shins and leant forwards to adjust her sweater, pulling it closer about her. Rio was fighting hard to breathe normally, reminding herself over and over that she wasn’t choking. The garrotte tightening about her throat was imaginary but the pain in her head was very real.

A pale hand moved from her collar to her throat and as Agatha’s fingers brushed across her skin Rio was suddenly able to breathe again. Sea-blue eyes were looking down at where her fingers were still caressing the column of Rio’s neck and Rio swallowed thickly before she whispered: “Agatha, please can we talk?”

Agatha looked up and for a second Rio thought she was going to agree when her hand moved to brush a strand of hair from her face but then the heavy footsteps of Nicky stumbling back could be heard.

Agatha didn’t look away or flinch even as Nicky dropped four heavy blankets on the couch beside them. And Rio didn’t look either.

“Blankets!” He announced happily and then made a soft “oh” sound, and whispered, “Sorry, melliza. Do you feel better?”

“She’s better, baby,” Agatha reassured as she finally tore her gaze away and smiled for her son. “Let’s finish the movie, then you can pick the next one whilst I get us all ice cream, okay? But get comfy first.”

Nicky agreed readily and suddenly Rio was being manhandled - not by Nicky, by Agatha. She was moving her legs to curl up onto the couch, placing a cushion by her side, moving her torso so the angle was more comfortable. She moved her as if Rio were a rag doll, as if she were completely incapable of free movement.

And as she stared up at Agatha’s impassive face, she was.

She was practically hauled to the very centre of the couch where she sank more into the cushions and Agatha settled Nicky in between them.

The whole time she didn’t look her way, didn’t say anything, but she made sure she had enough blanket to cover her and when Nicky began to wriggle she gently calmed him and whispered something to him that Rio didn’t quite catch.

Nicky settled then, tucked again under Rio’s arm. Just as Agatha leant to press play on the movie he whispered, “I like when it’s just us.”

After ten more minutes of cartoon action, something miraculous happened.

Rio felt the brush of cool fingers along the back of her hand and it took her a second to register but she slowly turned and Agatha was looking straight ahead, her fingers now gone from Rio’s hand. Rio reached across, barely a few inches, until she found Agatha’s hand again and she slowly turned it.

When their fingers interlocked Rio felt her airways open again and the headache she’d been suffering suddenly lessened.

Agatha didn’t look at her. She didn’t flinch, didn’t blink, when their hands became one. She just stared straight ahead.

But Rio relaxed with the solid comfort of Nicky curled against her and Agatha now softening enough to hold her hand. It didn’t feel hopeful, but it felt right. It eased the excess of worry that had caused her head to flash, warning of an overload.

When the movie was over Agatha released her, giving instructions to find another movie as she strode from the room in search of ice cream. Rio helped Nicky to choose and by the time How To Train Your Dragon was loaded, Agatha was back with a tray of ice cream.

Rio counted eight bowls and looked on in confusion as Agatha pushed the pizza boxes aside and placed the tray in the centre of the table. “Birthday boys get to choose their toppings.”

“And Rio too!”

“Yes, and Rio too.”

Before them were bowls of various sizes with various contents. The first two had generous helpings of chocolate ice cream, the third contained m&ms. Then there were mini peanut butter cups, actual peanuts, pretzels, broken bits of chocolate. And then, Skittles.

“Skittles?” Rio asked curiously, wondering how they fit into the theme of the offerings.

“Skittles,” Agatha confirmed as she reached across to take a few and drop them into her mouth.

“Mama likes Skittles.”

Rio raised her brows at this and glanced at Agatha who was now apparently too interested in the Skittles to notice. Rio knew she was avoiding looking at her again. But Rio noticed that she was picking rummaging through them, avoiding at least one of the colours.

She cleared her throat and asked, “What are you doing?”

It was Nicky who answered, already guessing what Rio wanted to know: “Mama doesn’t like the purple ones.”

Agatha didn’t look up, just kept fingering through the candy as Rio said: “Your favourite colour is purple.”

“I don’t like the taste.”

Rio raised her brows but said nothing as she slumped back against the couch, patiently waiting for Nicky to be done piling his bowl high with toppings, barely noticing that he was also putting one spoonful of everything into Rio’s bowl too.

“There you go,” he announced happily, settling back himself as Rio kept her gaze on Agatha.

Rio glanced at her own bowl, then Nicky’s, then looked back across to Agatha’s and reached across to grab a handful, aiming for the section of the bowl with more purple in it.

She added the Skittles without a word to her ice cream.

Agatha turned with a frown as Nicky announced: “Oh no, Rio! Skittles are not chocolate!”

It made Rio laugh and she scooped up a big spoonful of ice cream with as many Skittles as she could catch and held it up to a horrified Nicky and an unamused Agatha. “To your birthday?”

“Rio,” Nicky said calmly, as if Rio didn’t quite understand, “Skittles are not chocolate.”
