“But they are delicious and chocolate ice cream is also delicious sooooo.”

She put the whole thing in her mouth, narrowly avoiding wincing for the cold shock of it on her palate. She crunched. It did not go well together.

“Okay,” she said with a mouthful of food still, “Not good.”

Nicky giggled and Rio grimaced dramatically as she made a show of finishing her mouthful. Which, admittedly, the more she chewed the more she was brought round to it. But as she finished off her bowl she made sure to avoid the rest of the Skittles.

Nicky, somehow, finished first. He jumped back up onto the couch and Agatha with him. Rio took a little longer to finish and piled up two bowls.

“Leave them, Rio. I’ll get them later.”

Rio paused and then settled back on the couch. This time, as Nicky burrowed close, Rio relaxed into it immediately. Her hands were cold so she wrung them together beneath the blankets until Agatha reached for them.

They stilled.

When Rio looked at her she looked back.

“Your hand is cold,” Agatha whispered as the movie played on, her eyes on Rio as she cradled her left hand in both of her own.

Nicky shifted against her and muttered, “more blankets, melizza.”

Rio pulled a second one over and Nicky reached over to tuck her in by her side. It felt good, she realised as Agatha squeezed her hand and ran her nails along the inside of her forearm, to be looked after like this.

Casually.

Calmly.

As if it were the most natural thing in the world.

Agatha had looked away again and Nicky was focused in on the movie so Rio settled back more, allowing herself to relax. She rested her head back against the couch and, not interested in cartoon dragons, focused instead on Agatha.

If she had a brain cell to spare to think about it she may have been mortified at what she was doing. But she didn’t, so she wasn’t.

She simply watched her as she focused in on the screen, as her jaw twitched occasionally. She watched as she settled back a little more, a little closer.

She watched as she absolutely, positively, did not look her way.

Her brain was whirring still, but slower, her thoughts now more at ease with the sight of Agatha soothing them until she simply fell asleep.

“Rio,” Nicky’s light voice helped to rouse her, “Rio it’s bedtime.”

Rio blinked slowly and found that her vision was blocked, not by the lights, but by Nicky’s face about an inch from her own. He grinned when she opened her eyes properly and continued to whisper: “Mama said to leave you until the movie was done and she’d put away the dishes.”

Rio grunted and Nicky threw himself at her, taking advantage of her slow movements so he could get a proper hug. Rio grunted again but this time from the knee that hit her stomach and she just about managed to right herself as she wrapped her arms around the little boy and asked, “¿Qué es esto, mellizo?” What is this?

Nicky was silent for a second before he whispered, “I lied. Just a little though.”

Rio frowned as Nicky wriggled back and his grin had morphed into a deep, guilty frown. “Mama said not to wake you at all but I wanted to ask you a question.”

Rio rested her head back against the couch cushions and grinned lazily, knocking a stray lock of hair back from his forehead. “Then I’m glad you woke me. What is it?”

Nicky hesitated and then blurted out: “Will you be here tomorrow? When I wake up? I want you to be here a-and I don’t want you to leave please.” He looked shocked at himself but Rio just kept up her grin.

“Mellizo.”

“Honey, what did I say about waking Rio?”

Nicky’s eyes widened and then he dived under the blankets and shouted from beneath them, “I am already in bed!”

Rio laughed, a louder and more joyous sound she hadn’t made all night. Agatha rolled her eyes and made to move towards them so Rio did the only sensible thing she could do in the situation and she threw the blankets over herself too.

Nicky gasped and then giggled.

They were alone in the semi-darkness for all of two seconds. Just two kids, one little, one big, and their identical grins.

“Ah hah! Neither of you are in bed!”

Agatha had ripped the blankets off of them and Nicky squealed as he tried to clutch at Rio, hoping his mom would just give in and let him stay up. Rio was laughing again, holding the boy securely.

“It’s late, honey. Come on, you-…”

“No, mama. Please I want to stay up just a little bit more.”

Agatha pursed her lips and Rio smiled as she turned to kiss the side of Nicky’s head. “Tell you what, if you go to bed now, in the morning we can go on a big bike ride, okay?”

Nicky froze in her hold and Rio raised her brows, glancing at Agatha who knew her son so well that she was already standing with her hand out. Not demanding anymore, just certain.

“We can?”

Nicky pulled back, his eyes wide and hopeful. “You’ll stay? You stay all night and then all day?”

“If you’d like me to.”

Nicky went a little pink suddenly and he nodded, lost for words, in either language.

He shuffled back, thinking that ‘now’ meant ‘right now’ or Rio would go back on her word. “Okay okay okay okay,” he repeated as she scrambled from the couch and the blankets to get to Agatha and her waiting hand.

Rio smiled at the sight and was leaning her head back again when the twosome stopped at the door and Nicky had turned back around to her, his frown back and his lips now in a pout. “But just us, okay? It’ll be just us?”

Rio opened her mouth to respond and then closed it again, feeling that same wave of sadness crash over her as she watched Nicky try to process his concerns. She slid to the edge of the couch and opened her arms out to him.

For five painful seconds he didn’t move. And then the kamikaze of love that was Nicholas River Harkness crashed into her. She scooped him up, squeezed him tight, and as she lowered him back down again she whispered: “Sólo nosotros. Tres patitos.” Just us. Three ducklings.”

Nicky nodded against her and she felt him sigh heavily as if this little boy had been carrying the weight of the world on his shoulders. He nestled in and Rio had no intention of letting him go until he was ready.

But then, “Honey? Rio’s not going anywhere but you need to go to bed.”

Rio smiled as Nicky wriggled against her objectionably, “Even birthday boys need bedtime.”

Nicky grumbled but eventually pulled back. He shot a Rio look as if to make sure she was serious and then hurried off to his mom.

“Hasta mañana, mellizo.”

Nicky hesitated as Agatha began to walk with him from the room and in his best imitation he said a soft: “Hasta banana, melliza.”

Rio bit the inside of her cheek, trying her best not to laugh at Nicky’s attempt. He was close. He was trying. She didn’t want him to be shy about it.

She watched the two figures until they disappeared and then collapsed back into the couch.

Rio had been here before. Three times now. A triptych of waiting. A triumvirate of Rio Vidals all anticipating the executioner’s swing.

She’d sat on three couches waiting for Agatha to return to her. In this very situation, with this very same sinking feeling in her stomach. Agatha had always been taking care of Nicky, always left Rio waiting with no earthly idea as to what to expect when Agatha returned to her.

But this time, this third time was the worst.

Because she’d had a day where it was clear to anyone who paid enough attention that they could be a family. They could be a happy family.

If Rio hadn’t royally fucked it up. If she’d been strong enough or thinking enough, she could have prevented this.

She looked down at her hands and stretched out her fingers, twisted them about each other, tried not to think of her dad and what he might say to her. Something patient, something kind.

Her thoughts spiralled until Agatha appeared in the living room again. She’d been in there alone for over thirty minutes. Rio’s eyes flickered to the clock on the wall and to her surprise she realised: no, an hour.

She’d sat stupefied by fear for an hour and hadn’t even realised.

Time bends to no man and Rio blinked up at the hands that told her time had flown through her suffering. Maybe the universe, after destroying her so completely, was beginning to wink in her favour.

“I wanted to make sure he was asleep,” Agatha said quietly, and Rio turned to see her stock-still by the door, her eyes a clear sea of fury as they stared down at the floor.

Rio stood, watched for any sign that she was reading Agatha wrong. But Agatha hadn’t moved and she didn’t move even as Rio walked towards her. Only when she was a foot away did she turn and step into the hall.

Rio, always having been good at finding her mark, followed Agatha silently until they made it up to what must be her bedroom. She stepped in after her and watched with trepidation as Agatha closed the door quietly and stood against it.

Rio watched her as she placed her forehead against the wood, as her fingers splayed along the pine. Her mouth moved as if to speak, but she couldn’t find the words.

Finding her mark was one thing, knowing her lines entirely another.

“Sit,” Agatha said quietly, her voice an octave lower than usual, deep enough that Rio felt a chill run through her blanket-warmed body.

She took a seat at the edge of the bed and held her breath.

Agatha turned around.

Chapter End Notes

What’s that? Light? A tiny, furious glimmer?

Chapter 42: Taste the Rainbow (Part 2)

Chapter Summary

Agatha and Rio reach the end of the rainbow.

Chapter Notes

Buckle up, folks

See the end of the chapter for more notes

“Sit,” Agatha said quietly, her voice an octave lower than usual, deep enough that Rio felt a chill run through her blanket-warmed body.

She took a seat at the edge of the bed and held her breath.

Agatha turned around.

“She took advantage of you.”

Her voice was deep still, as if the words were pushed up from her gut, instinctual, exacting.

She began to pace.

“Agatha.”

“No. She took advantage of you. You’re grieving, you’re vulnerable, god you’re practically catatonic!”

“Agatha.”

“No. She took advantage.”

Rio made to move from her position on the bed. Twice now she’d tried. She kept bobbing up like a buoy in the middle of treacherous waters but she always sank back down again, sucked beneath waves of panic.

Agatha was still pacing, her mind clearly firing in every direction as her hands moved about in conjunction with her thoughts.

It reminded Rio of a Catherine Wheel, sparking off in every direction.

“And she did it in the most public place, a place where I couldn’t step in. I couldn’t push her off. I couldn’t-… Agh!”

She flung her hands up and stopped in her tracks. She was clutching now, her fingers buried deep in her hair at her scalp, her head tilted up towards the ceiling. And Rio watched, she watched Agatha take in deep breaths, watched her try to calm herself.

Inside her own chest her heart was cantering ahead of her thoughts. She couldn’t contain it, couldn’t make it slow or steady or stop. It felt like it was trying to vibrate its way across the space to Agatha. She’d felt this before. The pull of her heart’s desire to sink in to the other woman’s chest and nestle there. Beat there. Live there.

Rio could only imagine it would be happier with Agatha. That her heart, running now on fumes, at least deserved the comfort of Agatha. Even if her body couldn’t follow it. Even if she were left hollowed out whilst her blackened heart beat for her, for Agatha.

The thrum inside her body built to an unrelenting thunder as Agatha paced and seethed before her.

Cautiously, unsure if she should even try, she said: “Agatha.”

Agatha shook her head in response, her hands falling limply at her sides now. “No.”

She still wasn’t looking at her, and Rio bobbed up a little again, still unsure if she should go to her.

The rustle of the sheets made Agatha turn, made her look at Rio for the first time since they’d entered the room. Her eyes were wide all of a sudden, questioning. She seemed to falter for a second before she released her words with the remnants of the breath in her lungs: “I don’t want you to see her again.”

At her sides, Agatha’s hands that had once been limp were now angular, taught. Her whole body was tight, and as Rio took a breath in she saw that Agatha was no longer looking at her. Instead she was staring at the floor, working her jaw like she wanted to break it.

She hesitated, fisted the sheets at her sides.

“Agatha.”

“No.”

“Agatha,” Rio breathed again.

“No.”

“Agatha.” Rio tried once more, unable to say anything else, not knowing how to fix this. Not knowing whether to agree or to argue. Her fingers that had been clutching the fabric of the bedspread at her side twitched and then curled back in on themselves.

She was digging her nails into her palms now. The pain helped. It was different to the pain she’d been living with these past weeks.

“No.”

Agatha was staring at her again, meeting her gaze, and in the seconds it took Rio to utter her name once more a fire sparked to life behind blue eyes.

“Agatha.”

“No.”

Rio didn’t understand, she couldn’t make her mind settle on any words she could say. Nothing that could help. Just “no no no” repeated in her brain, in Agatha’s voice, laced with her own pain and Agatha’s anger. She tightened her clutches on the bedspread, dug her nails in deeper, swallowed down her fear.

“Mi amor.”

Without knowing it, Rio had hit on the trigger needed to make Agatha move. She stormed forwards, and didn’t stop until she was in Rio’s lap, one hand gripping her jaw, the other clutching her hair and tilting her head backwards.

Rio didn’t have time to register anything except the soft weight of the woman above her, the pain of her jaw and scalp as she held her viciously. She whimpered without meaning to and her hands flew from the bed to grab at Agatha’s upper back.

Agatha was silent and Rio couldn’t speak.

Agatha’s irises were slivers of light now, shining brighter because of the blackness that almost consumed them. In her eyes Rio saw nothing but fury, emphasised by the tightness of her brow, the jutting of her clenched jaw.

Her hold on her tightened briefly and Rio whimpered again, clutching now rather than holding Agatha.

Agatha shifted, raising her hips a little to rise higher above Rio. She was looking down at her, and Rio could no longer tell what she was thinking. She didn’t know what she wanted. Rio couldn’t give her anything.

Agatha’s breathing was heavy, and her fingers flexed against her jaw as she husked: “Ask me.”

Rio whimpered at a sudden squeeze and release. She didn’t know what Agatha wanted her to ask her. She couldn’t think, could barely breathe. So she remained silent.

Agatha sneered at the lack of response, her thighs closing in on Rio’s hips as her hold tightened again, “Ask me.”

Rio began to pant. The pain of Agatha’s hold caused her cheeks to flush and her hands to grip Agatha tighter but she still didn’t understand. Only, Agatha’s eyes dropped to her lips and something sparked in Rio’s broken brain.

She gasped out, Agatha’s hold relaxed just slightly, her eyes still that same obsidian with an aquamarine frame.

She could speak. She found her voice and asked the one thing she’d been wanting to ask these past two weeks. No, her whole life. The question she didn’t want to hear a ‘no’ to.

“Mi amor,” she breathed out, barely able to make the noise, “kiss me.”

Agatha’s hold shifted then, her grasping fingers relaxed, the hand that had been holding her hair now cradled her head. Her other hand, holding her jaw, now caressed her there as her eyes moved about her desperate face.

Rio whimpered, her body vibrating now beneath Agatha’s. The need to rise up, to grasp at her just as tightly as she was being held was overwhelming. But her body was no longer her own.

Her heart had abandoned her and because it now sat reliant on Agatha’s lifeblood, on her acceptance of it, her body remained still, waiting.

“Again.”

Rio didn’t hesitate this time.

“Kiss me, mi vida, mi corazon, mi alma.”

Agatha gasped quietly, her body reacting with it. She shifted her weight, moved to sit up more on her knees so Rio’s hold dropped to her waist. She was fully above her now, a goddess before a lowly pilgrim. Rio’s head was still arched back, Agatha’s fingers sliding into her hair.

Agatha’s own hair had fallen in thick curtains about her face and Rio’s lungs filled with the scent of her, hungrily trying for more with every breath she took.

Whether Agatha was looking for something, or waiting for something, she didn’t know. She only knew she’d look forever, she’d wait forever.

It happened slowly, as if they were stuck in time. Rio saw the moment Agatha decided to kiss her. Her lashes had fluttered, her breath had hitched almost imperceptibly, and her thumbs, now back and laid over her cheeks, had made their presence known.

A whimper trembled between them, born of Rio and swallowed by Agatha. But Agatha was nuzzling now, nudging their noses together. Rio wondered whether she was making sure she could stand it, that Rio wouldn’t simply disintegrate beneath her.

She could feel the warmth of their coiling breath between them, feel the promise of lips she’d not tasted in almost a month. Her hands confirmed their hold on Agatha. She held her more firmly, wanting her to know that she was all she wanted.

And then, flung out of time, Agatha kissed her.

Her lips enclosed Rio’s with a delicacy she’d hadn’t been expecting. It was a moment, a kiss, to be savoured.

Agatha reared up after a few seconds, raising her hips against Rio, pressing into her chest and breaking the kiss entirely. Rio gasped as she did, trying already to reach to kiss her again. But Agatha was too far above her, was leaning down but not close enough.

“Ask. Again.”

Agatha’s hands had pushed back again into her hair, her nails now scraping her scalp as she forced her head further back. Rio gasped for the sharp pain of it, baring her teeth briefly at the shock.

“Mi vida,” she managed, “kiss me.”

Agatha didn’t bother with the softness from before. When she kissed her this time there was no nuzzling. She didn’t hold her steady.

She kissed with the hunger of a starved woman. A woman who hadn’t been fed for a month. She kissed Rio until she’d ripped moans from her, until she made them crash back into the bed.

They broke apart on impact and Agatha allowed it only so she could reposition herself. She moved down and found Rio’s jaw again, holding her there until she found a better place to grasp as she rested her body weight over her.

“I won’t share you,” she breathed, her fingers curling threateningly around Rio’s throat.

Rio was panting now, one hand around Agatha’s wrist, the other wrapped around her waist. “No. No. I’m yours, I-…”

Agatha squeezed and Rio gasped.

But Agatha released her, allowing her fingers to linger where they’d just clutched. Her blue eyes were darting across her face now, never settling, never resting too long on one particular feature.

It was like she were scanning her, to preserve her in her mind or to search for something else, Rio couldn’t be sure. But she’d moved back, moved up, was now seated over her hips.

Her hands were steady and purposeful as they slid below Rio’s sweater and found the thin tank she wore beneath it to guard against the chill of the Boston springtime. Her fingers moved beneath that too. It was barley a barrier but Agatha clearly took offence to its existence.

“In future,” she said in that low voice again that told Rio she was fighting to push the anger away, “I don’t want to find one of these,” Agatha tugged at the tank, “beneath anything.”

Agatha’s hands were cool as they lay now across her stomach, making Rio shiver from her need for them to be other places, to do more.

She swallowed as Agatha pushed her hands tantalisingly slowly up her abdomen to her ribs and traced her thumbs along the underside of her bra.

“Why?”

“Why, what?”

Rio couldn’t really think on the what of anything right now. Agatha’s touches had changed to a tight hold around her ribs and she was leaning over her again, applying just enough pressure to let Rio feel the weight of her without it hurting.

Rio’s breathing was shallow, and though she hadn’t quite acknowledged it herself yet, for the first time since the arena, she was pain free.

“Mi amor,” she tried quietly, unsure what to do with the hands that just lay beside her on the bed.

Agatha sneered, “I want access. Even a layer is too much.” Rio gasped as Agatha dug her nails into her sides without warning. “I need access to you.”

Rio nodded silently, finally making her arms work as she grabbed Agatha’s. “You have it, always.”

Agatha pulled her hands down again, sliding back to sit against her hips. And Rio’s hold fell to Agatha’s thighs. “Agatha.”

“No.”

“Mi vida,” Rio insisted making to sit up and realising she was weaker than she used to be because it took far too much effort. But then her arms were around Agatha and Agatha’s arms were around Rio’s neck. And she felt strong again, stronger than she had in days.

“Yo soy tuya, angel.” I’m yours, angel.

She brought Agatha in closer, explored her back above her sweater, watched as Agatha’s eyes surveyed and studied her again. It took a while, ten breaths, until Agatha spoke once more.

“Creí que te había perdido.” I thought I’d lost you.

The sneer was gone, replaced by a deep frown, by downturned lips. And Rio inhaled slowly, as Agatha’s hands came to rest at her neck again, no longer forceful, simply holding her. “It was just-…”

“No,” Agatha insisted, “Before that. Because of… I thought I-…”

“Agatha.”

Chapter Summary

Nicky gets his bike ride.

Rio and Agatha begin to face the reality of the next few months.

Chapter Notes

“No,” Agatha said quickly, panic laced in her voice, “No, we’ll stick to side streets.”

Rio raised her brows and looked up at her but Agatha just shook her head and Rio’s stomach sank. Two Oscar winners with a little boy on a bike might be too exposed in the common. Rio’s hold on Nicky tightened a little as she thought over their options.

Potential exposure in the common but Nicky able to go as fast as his little legs could carry him or slow and steady along the side streets where there was less chance they’d be hounded but no chance for Nicky to ride free.

Agatha seemed to be struggling with the same thoughts so Rio tapped Nicky’s back and said: “Mellizo, see that lamppost up ahead? Ride over to it for me, but stop there and your mom and I will be just a sec. Go steady.”

She released him after he readily agreed and watched as he started shakily and then straightened his course and made his way to the place she’d pointed out. She stopped Agatha by grabbing her arm.

“Hey. It’s too crowded? You’re worried we’ll be spotted?”

“I just… I don’t want to ruin his morning if people…”

“We’ll be there. Right there with him. I’ve got my cap on, he’s got his helmet, everyone’s all bundled up. It’s not the perfect disguise but if we don’t go, even for a little while, he can’t go fast. And, Agatha, that little boy really wants to go fast. I’ll keep up with him, I promise. I’ll run with him and-…”

“You’re not able to keep-…”

“I might be a little slower than I used to be but I have enough reserves to keep up with him, I promise.”

Agatha looked around to where Nicky was and Rio stepped a little closer, making sure she wasn’t so close that anyone looking out of the windows of the surrounding buildings would think too much of it.

“I promise.”

Agatha nodded, slowly turning back to Rio with a tired smile. “I suppose this will be some exercise. Technically under the banner of looking after yourself.”

“With the added bonus that Nicky will be the happiest boy in the world.”

Agatha’s smile turned into a grin and she rolled her eyes as she took Rio’s arm and tugged her towards Nicky who was waiting patiently for them by the lamppost.

“Did you watch me?”

“Yeah! You’re so cool!”

Nicky grinned his gap toothed grin and Rio gave hers right back.

“So,” Agatha clapped her hands to steal her son’s googly-eyed attention away from Rio. “The common we must go!”

“Really?”

“Yes, honey. You can go faster there but only if you promise not to go too fast or too far. Rio’s going to keep alongside you, okay? I want you in my sights at all time.”

“Okay, mama.”

Rio grinned at Agatha and, as a trio, they all walked towards the busy road that separated their quiet portion of Boston from the common. It was a cold Sunday morning and Rio could already see that it was getting busier the closer they got. But she and Agatha were flanking Nicky now, letting him ride slowly but steadily between them.

They crossed at the lights and Rio kept her face forwards her but eyes alert to ensure no one had either clocked them or was already approaching. It didn’t take long for some gasps to be heard nearby but for now, no one came near.

The entrance to the common was open, for the most part. And they were on the side closest to the frog pond so both women let Nicky go ahead a little, with the warning to be careful and to not yet go too fast.

His take off this time wasn’t as unsteady and Rio grinned at the sight of him speeding off, paying heed to his mother’s instruction to be careful. Agatha looped her arm into hers and squeezed her as she whispered, “Thank you. He needs this. He deserves this.”

Suddenly people glancing their way didn’t seem so bad. Agatha was clinging to her arm, Nicky was riding happily ahead, pausing every so often to stop and look back at them, and they could be mistaken for any other happy family.

Other than the fact that occasionally someone took a photo of them.

“There’s a coffee stand not too far up ahead,” Rio said after a while of walking along in comfortable silence. “Will I catch up with him and let him race there?”

“Go easy,” Agatha said as she stopped them both and turned to look at Rio properly. Rio could see the concern suddenly in her eyes, the same look she’d given her countless times the night before. It made her want to lean in, want to kiss that look away. But she held her ground, only smiled, only nodded, and the darted off to jog after Nicky who’d dutifully stopped not too far away.

“Hey! Let’s see how fast this puppy can go, okay? There’s a coffee stand just straight ahead. So we’re gonna head towards it and you can go as fast as you want and I’ll do my best to keep up okay? But remember, there are people about so be careful. Remember how to use your brakes?”

“Sí, melliza.”

“Okay, good.” She stepped back, surveyed Nicky for a second and then said, “On three! One… two!”

She burst off before she finished her countdown and heard Nicky laugh behind her, shouting her name as he hurried to catch up.

He soon did but that wasn’t the point. The point was that Rio felt alive. The point was that she was moving her body in a way she had neglected to for weeks now. The point was that the little boy on the little green bike was giggling as he streaked past her.

The point was that his mother wasn’t far behind, smiling at the two of them.

Rio could feel the burn of the cool air in her throat as she forced herself to keep her speed up. She could feel the groan of each limb as she made them do what they used to be so good at, but had since forgotten the joy of.

Her mind took her to foot races with her dad. To days when he’d take her to this very common and toss a ball around with her in the green to celebrate their beloved team winning. She thought of the desperate way she’d gasp for air as he flung her into his arms and span her around.

She thought of what it meant to feel joy and that she was now able to give some to Nicky.

She hoped he felt it, hoped he’d remember it in years to come when she’d gone up to meet her dad again.

Nicky was just up ahead. In spite of his desire to go fast he’d stopped to check Rio was following still. He was grinning at her. He felt her joy. She laughed as she flew past him again, shouting an encouraging, “vamos, mellizo!”

Nicky was soon passing her again but still she didn’t mind. Her limbs were paying attention now. She was flying.

The coffee stand at the end of the pathway was in view now and Rio kept going until she reached Nicky, parked up just a few feet from it. He was beaming at her, his cheeks flushed and his eyes wide.

“You run so fast!”

“Not as fast as you.”

Rio was panting softly, replacing her cap on her head. She felt on the verge of total, resplendent collapse. But the strain on her lungs had been worth it. She felt different now. She felt free. Agatha had been right. She did need to start looking after herself. She had to move her body more, had to make more of an effort.

After all, the reward would be worth it.

And the reward arrived just as Rio was breathing normally again. Agatha squeezed her elbow and ducked below Nicky’s helmet to check on him. “That was so fast!”

“Did you see?!”

“Oh I saw, honey. You were so fast I almost lost you.”

Nicky grinned and Agatha kissed her son’s cheek, “Hot chocolate?”

Rio, however, was looking around them, and had already spotted a couple of women nearby eyeing them up. She moved a little closer to Agatha, suddenly unsure but extremely tense.

“Hey,” she said as casually as she could. “Two over there.” She pointed to herself but hoped Agatha would know she meant behind her. “Think they might-…”

Agatha’s whole face changed instantly. She paled, her jaw flexing, her gaze sharpening.

“Will you take Nicky? I’ll go fetch drinks.”

Rio nodded mutely and wasted no time in ushering Nicky further away from the coffee stand until they were at a bench far enough away that they could have a good view of Agatha without being close enough to hear anything.

“Who are those ladies talking to mama?”

Nicky had dismounted now and was cradling his helmet in his lap, sitting next to Rio on the bench.

“Oh,” Rio said lamely, “they’re fans of your mama’s work.”

“Mama gets annoyed when fans try to talk to her. Maybe we should go and tell them no.”

Rio smiled a little and reached her arm around Nicky to pull him closer into her side. “She seems okay right now.”

“You have fans too,” Nicky pointed out, a slight frown on his face where he focused in on Agatha talking to the two women.

“I do, baby.”

“Do you like them?”

Rio thought about it for a second. “Some of them.”

“They’re nice to you?”

“Yes.”

“Okay. Good. I don’t want anybody to be mean to you.”

Rio smiled, but only slightly, her gaze was still on Agatha, on the women with her. She’d been talking to them for much longer than she’d thought she might. Maybe a minute now? Maybe longer. But she couldn’t leave Nicky. And she couldn’t take him over.

Nicky seemed to notice her concern and he shuffled where he sat to gaze up at her, still frowning his older-than-his-years frown. “Did you have a fight with mama?”

“What?” Rio’s attention was back on Nicky now, “When? No, of course not.”

“I woke up late last night and I thought I heard shouting.”

Rio raised her brows, hoping it was the shouting portion of the evening he’d heard and nothing else. “No, Nicky, it was-…”

“Mellizo.”

“No, honey, ‘melliza’.”

“No,” Nicky shuffled more, wrestling with himself until he was on his knees facing Rio on the bench. “You call me ‘mellizo’.”

Rio’s arms had moved to try and prevent Nicky from falling in the shuffle, though she knew he was okay. It was a reflex, one she didn’t even know she had.

“Not Nicky?”

And then Nicky pulled a face that was half him, half his mother. It made Rio grin.

“I like mellizo.”

“Okay, baby. Oh. Is baby okay? What about honey? Sweetheart? Patito?”

Nicky was still scowling, but Rio knew he was okay because he was placing his helmet in her lap and shuffling closer. He was a mini Agatha, all bark but no bite. Not for Rio, anyway.

“River is also okay. Because it’s your name too. I learnt it the other day.”

Rio’s heart stuttered in her chest. “You did?”

“Yes, your name means my name.”

Before Rio could respond a noise nearby alerted her to Agatha’s arrival and she turned to grin up at her, leaning to gently pry two of the cups from her hands. Agatha did not look pleased.

“All okay?”

“One’s coco,” Agatha offered, nodding at the two cups in Rio’s hands. Rio sniffed one and gave Nicky the one that smelled of chocolate.

“Careful, it’ll be too hot right now.”

Nicky nodded and shuffled to sit properly again on the bench. Rio reached for him once more and Agatha settled beside him. She still looked pissed.

“What were you talking about?”

“Rio Vidal’s new girlfriend.”

Rio’s mouth fell open and Nicky beside her gasped, “Who, mama?”

Rio cleared her throat because she already knew who Agatha was going to say. Not her actual girlfriend, but Wanda.

“Wanda.”

Rio sighed and Nicky’s head spun round to her so quickly that even where he’d been so careful before in holding his hot chocolate he was suddenly spilling it over his hands.

“You said she wasn’t.”

“Honey,” Agatha jumped in before Rio could, gently wiping his hands and taking his cup from him so he couldn’t spill any more. Clearly she’d planned ahead because she had napkins ready in her pocket and placed the cups on the ground before wiping Nicky’s fingers and mopping up the few spots of hot chocolate on his jacket.

“She isn’t,” Rio insisted gently, “she’s just a friend. Your mama knows that too, don’t you, Agatha?”

Agatha didn’t say anything and made as if she were still cleaning Nicky’s, admittedly now, clean hands.

“Agatha.”

Blue eyes darted up furtively, and as Agatha met her gaze she softened a little, her initial frustration melting somewhat under Rio’s steadiness.

“No, honey, Wanda isn’t Rio’s girlfriend. Some people are just… they got it wrong.”

Nicky hadn’t looked away from Rio this whole time and Rio looked back at him now, feeling somehow guilty that Nicky felt any which way about her having a girlfriend. He was still frowning, still looking so like his mother.

“Mi mellizo,” she said quietly, watching as Nicky’s gaze slowly drifted down to the hand she was offering to him. “I would never lie to you.”

Rio glanced at a guilty looking Agatha and shot her a small smile before she looked down just in time to see Nicky taking her offered hand. She wrapped her fingers around his and ducked her head down to whisper to him: “Wanna know a secret? You can’t tell anyone. Only your mama. You and your mama are my two favourite people.”

“Really?”

“Sí, mellizo. Tres patitos, ¿recuerdas?”

Nicky grinned at her, taking a second before he agreed, “Tres patitos.”

Rio laughed at his enthusiasm and sat back up again, taking a sip of her too-hot coffee and grimacing the moment it touched the tip of her tongue. “Agh. Shit.”

She stuck her tongue out and went cross-eyed to see it, making Nicky burst into a fit of laughter and Agatha across from her try to hide her adoring smile with an added roll of her eyes.

“Showing off for my son, are you?”

“‘Urnin’ ‘y ‘ongue,” Rio corrected with her mouth open and her tongue still half out, seeking the cool air to calm it.

“Juvenile.”

“Silly.”

Rio grinned and the stuck her tongue properly out at Nicky only for him to do the exact same to her. Her anxiety calmed in that instant and she grinned at him, then shot that same grin Agatha’s way and saw that she was a little misty-eyed. She wished then that they were somewhere private, somewhere Rio could reach around to pull her close.

She knew she still couldn’t kiss Agatha with Nicky there but she could hold her, and that had to be enough.

“Why don’t we cycle some more and we can drink as we go?”

“I can be the official hot chocolate holder for Mr Nicholas Harkness.”

“Mm’kay,” Nicky hummed happily as he went to fetch his bike but Rio was more interested in the fingers that grazed her own as she took the hot chocolate from Agatha. For just a second they were connected again. But then it was over, and they were back to focusing on Nicky.

In Agatha’s gaze Rio had caught at least some of the yearning she felt.

It didn’t make it any easier.

Nicky now cycled just a little ahead, his path truncated by quick stops to look back and make sure he was close. He smiled every time he saw Rio and Agatha walking along not far behind.

Agatha now had Rio’s arm again, and they were walking along like any other couple in the park.

“The girls before,” Agatha said in a low voice as Nicky turned back to kick off and ride slowly ahead again. “They wanted to meet you. Were asking about Wanda. Wanted to know how long you’d been together, was it serious.”

Rio nodded stiffly, felt Agatha’s hand flex around her bicep. Even through her heavy jacket she could feel the tension in her fingers.

“What did you say?”

Nicky had stopped to look back and grinned before kicking off again.

“I said that if it were true then Wanda was a very lucky woman but they couldn’t meet you because you were looking after my son.”

Rio nodded again and shot Agatha a look, finding that Agatha was already watching her. “You complimented me even though you were furious?”

Agatha looked away then.

“Do you want to kiss me?”

“What?”

Nicky had stopped once more, checking, grinning, and then he pushed back off again.

“Kiss me? Do you… do you want to?”

Rio frowned as she looked back around and this time Agatha wasn’t looking her way.

“Is that a trick question?”

“No, a very simple one. Yes or no is fine.”

Rio couldn’t get a hold on what Agatha was asking, or why she was asking it. Because the answer was yes, all the time, constantly, but that seemed too easy, too obvious.

But Agatha had clearly grown bored because she answered before Rio had even opened her mouth, “I’m asking because it’s what I’d like to do. Here. Now. Then. When they asked, when I came over with the drinks, after you burnt your tongue, right now as we’re walking. And it’s constant. And I can’t shake it.”

Rio turned her face away, seeking solace in the oblivious little boy now stopped and checking again.

“Tonight,” Rio said after Nicky turned back to go again, “Tonight we can-…”

“I don’t think you understand.”

Agatha had tugged her arm, had pulled her to a stop. For a shimmering moment in time, Rio thought she was about to kiss her. But Agatha’s face was too haunted for that. She was too pained.

Agatha glanced away, looking back to Nicky for a second before she turned to Rio.

“I can’t stand it.”

“My love,” Rio breathed out, suddenly more aware than ever that they were in public. That eyes and cameras were on them wherever they went. That Nicky, now stopped and turned again, waiting patiently for them to start moving, couldn’t know what was going on between them.

Agatha dropped her arm. She pulled away and Rio had no choice but to follow.

This time Nicky didn’t move and Agatha reached him before Rio did. He took his hot chocolate and was instructed by his mom to blow on it before he took a sip. Rio just watched, just stood there in her inability to do anything to fix what Agatha needed fixing.

She couldn’t even reach out to her properly, couldn’t hold her hand. But later, later she could do that.

She stepped in as Agatha was adjusting Nicky’s helmet.

“How about, when we’re all cycled out, we pile up back home and get all warm and watch a movie? Before we all have to leave?”

Agatha shot her a glance but it was Nicky who picked up the bait first, “Can we stay? It’s nice here. It’s colder and Celtics are here and-…”

“Honey, we all need to fly home tonight. Rio and I have work tomorrow and you’ve got school. Don’t you want to show off your new bike to your friends?”

Nicky thought on this for a second and then agreed, “They’ll love it!”

“Then let’s make the most of being tres patitos in Boston today, okay?”

“Si, mama. Okay.”

Rio took Nicky’s cup back from him after he took another gulp and turned to speed off again. She sipped her coffee just for something to do.

“Another movie?” Agatha asked suspiciously as she settled in step with Rio once more, her hand already wrapped around her arm.

“Well,” Rio took a sip of her coffee, trying to play down the tension she felt between them. Like the string of a violin, it longed to be played, allowing for different tones to be emitted with each light press of pressure.

Rio’s words were a steady not, sitting below the stave. Her note wasn’t pushing or pulling, nor did it waver. It was steady, supporting the melody that was in its infancy still, waiting for time to write it.

“It’s the only time I can hold you when Nicky’s close. And I want to hold you as much as I want to kiss you.”

Agatha exhaled a breath beside her, took a sip of her own coffee, and in clearing her throat she said. “Then a movie it is.”

Nicky had stopped again and this time didn’t start cycling again. He instead waited for his fellow ducklings to catch up and his grin never once faltered. “Can I have my coco, please?”

“Of course, melizzo. Cycling is hard work.”

“Mmhm,” Nicky agreed, taking Rio very seriously as he took several large gulps of his hot chocolate and created for himself a chocolate moustache. Rio laughed at the sight and Agatha swooped in to clean it gently off.

Their brief distraction, their focusing on the little boy with the green bike, meant that Rio didn’t notice the couple as they approached. She was only alerted to their presence when she heard Agatha’s name over her shoulder.

Both women turned and both stepped a little closer to Nicky.

“Agatha Harkness! Oh my GOD!! We are, such fans, I mean… wow! You were robbed by the way. That Oscar should have been yours. I mean, wow!”

Rio bit the inside of her cheek and tried not to laugh as Agatha put on her most gracious voice and thanked the clearly insane woman before her. The man standing beside her looked like he’d rather be anywhere else.

“Thank you. It’s always great to meet a fan. But if you don’t mind, I’m here with my son so I should be getting along.”

To Rio’s horror the woman leant around Agatha, ignoring Rio’s presence entirely, to get a look at Nicky. “Oh and isn’t he a sweetheart! You must look like your daddy. I bet he’s handsome too!”

Agatha cleared her throat purposefully and moved to block the woman, placing a hand on her arm as Rio turned to steal Nicky’s attention back. He looked as serious as he ever had and his brow was as furrowed as Rio’s was.

“C’mon, lift your legs off the pedals and I’ll steer you.”

Nicky did as he was told and with some difficultly given she was still carrying a nearly full coffee, Rio pushed Nicky away from Agatha and the fan so he wouldn’t be subjected to anymore ogling.

Agatha soon wasn’t far behind and she touched Nicky’s back when she caught up. “You okay, honey?”

Rio glanced around them before steering them all in the direction of a bench.

“I don’t look like daddy,” Nicky said quietly, placing his foot gingerly on the ground when Rio had stopped them. “Nobody says I do. Why did that lady think I did?”

Agatha crouched down and Rio stood tall with her hand on his shoulder still, her eyes cast around the place to make sure no one was even close to approaching again.

“Because, honey, it’s just what people say. People assume you either look like me or your daddy.”

“I look like Rio. Handsome like Rio.”

“Very handsome like Rio.”

Rio turned back then and bent round to kiss Nicky’s cheek beneath his helmet. “Shall we ride all the way back home without stopping? I’ll race you back to the edge of the park?”

Nicky’s face lit up and Rio grinned down at him, thrilled she could elicit this reaction from something so simple. Just attention and play. She turned to Agatha and raised her brows, “Would you like to race too?”

“No, no. I think I’ll leave it to the professionals.”

Nicky giggled and Rio took his cup and checked he was done with it before she tossed it with her own into the trash.

“Okay, on your marks, get set,” Nicky pushed off before she did this time and Rio laughed as he streaked ahead and almost forgot to chase after him. But she did. And it felt just as good as the first time.

Her body was a little less reluctant the second go around. It still felt heavy and slow but it’s moved with more fluidity, more desire to keep moving, and to keep moving faster.

Nicky kept checking where she was and each time he did Rio’s grin grew impossibly larger across her face. Her lungs were straining for breath but her legs didn’t know. They carried her to the edge of the park where she thundered her steps as she attempted to slow and finally halt by Nicky.

Panting heavily and red in the face, she placed her hands on her knees and swallowed deep breaths to try and relax her heart now hammering against her chest.

“I… almost… had you.”

Nicky laughed and shook his head, leaning over to the side with his bike to pat Rio’s back, “Good race, melliza. You were so fast.”

Rio laughed as she straightened up and stretched her arms above her head, bending her neck back to blink up at the sky. “God I need to start exercising again.”

She heard Nicky adjust his bike so he could tiptoe it closer to her and soon felt his small hand on her jacket. “We can play more basketball if you want to?”

Nicky was grinning up at her, his helmet having slipped a little so he had to really tilt his head to see her. She adjusted it for him and grinned when more of his face came into view.

“Yeah? How about a game that goes on forever? We just need to hit infinity and then we can stop.”

Nicky beamed in wonder at this, his clutch on Rio’s jacket tightening. “Infinity?! That’s so much!”

“Exactly.”

“So who won?”

Agatha had arrived, smug in her ability to breathe normally where Rio was still struggling.

“Your son.”

“Mm.”

Agatha swooped in and lavished the winner in kisses and Rio suddenly wished that she’d won. Only when Agatha relented her attack did she speak up: “What does the loser get?”

Agatha’s eyes flashed to her own, a strange mix of teasing and longing. “All the purple Skittles you can eat.”

Rio rolled her eyes.

“That doesn’t really seem fair.”

“Why? There’s a whole bunch of them in the bowl in the kitchen.”

Rio huffed as they made for the exit and Agatha kept a hold on Nicky’s shoulder. “So I’m just your purple Skittle eater now?”

“Perhaps you should’ve won.”

A low blow. Softened by the hand that reached out and curled back around Rio’s bicep. The gentle squeeze it gave told Rio that Agatha would have given her the same treatment she gave her son, regardless of whether Rio won or not, if she’d been at all able to.

So, for now, the purple Skittle eater, was happy enough to walk along with her two fellow ducklings - one of whom was talking about how many games it could possibly take to reach infinity points.

When they got in, Rio removed her jacket but not her scarf, and helped Nicky with his helmet as Agatha rested the bike up against the wall. It was soon decided that Rio would go set up the tv so they’d all be ready to watch ‘How To Train Your Dragon 2’, Agatha would go fetch snacks, and Nicky would help with drinks.

By the time Rio was standing before the tv in the cosy family room, she was feeling less murky than usual. Maybe it was the fresh air, maybe it was the - mostly - uninterrupted morning with her two favourite people. It didn’t matter why, it just mattered that she felt no pain, experienced no slowness, wasn’t struggling to keep her mind in check.

She found the movie, clicked to play it and paused before the first note of the credits could sound.

Rio then situated herself on the couch. She placed a cushion by the arm and rested her head against it. She spread her legs out and just as she was figuring out what to do with her arms Agatha appeared beside her.

“Are you going to sleep?”

“No. You are.”

Rio grinned as Agatha arched a brow and ignored the arms that were now held out to her.

“Actually I’m watching a movie.”

“Come here.”

“No.”

“Why not?”

Rio’s grin didn’t falter even as Agatha’s frown deepened. “If I lie on you I’ll sleep.”

Rio rolled her eyes and began to wriggle her fingers. Nicky entered, stage left, and Rio, without looking at him said: “Mellizo, please tell your mama she needs to nap.”

“Mama, melliza says you should nap so I think maybe you should.”

Agatha rolled her eyes this and muttered “traitor” before she took a seat by Rio’s feet and curled her legs beneath herself. Rio only hummed in amusement, propping herself up on her elbows to get a good look at her.

“So stubborn.”

“So stubborn,” Nicky agreed as if Rio had just said the wisest thing he’d ever heard. He was now sitting on the floor with his bowl of grapes, close enough to Rio’s head that he could turn around and offer her one.

She gladly accepted and popped it in her mouth before she fell onto her back again.

Agatha would give in eventually. She just had to give her time.

The movie started and even after the credits, Agatha hadn’t moved. Nicky continued to offer Rio grapes and she continued to gladly accept them. It went: one for Nicky, one for Rio.

After grape number fifteen for both of them, a certain someone crawled up Rio’s body and collapsed down against her without so much as a word. Rio, intent on Agatha sleeping and not scaring her away, said nothing.

She simply accepted another grape and wrapped her free arm around Agatha as she slipped her had beneath her scarf to clutch at her collar.

“This scarf looks ridiculous,” Agatha mumbled petulantly.

“And who is to blame for that?”

Agatha huffed but within five minutes she’d fallen asleep.

Rio didn’t think her plan would work. She thought Agatha might come over, might sit closer, maybe lay with her. But she’d thought Agatha would be too stubborn for sleeping, too aware of herself in front of Nicky. But she’d been asleep on her for twenty minutes now. Her left hand still curled around the collar of her sweatshirt and her head resting against her chest.

She was half on Rio, half buried between her and the couch. The perfect, most beautiful, weighted blanket.

Nicky kept glancing over, craning his neck to see Agatha fast asleep, his wide eyes darting from her sleeping form up to Rio’s face, then back to the screen. Every time he did this Rio smiled to herself, counting the seconds until he said something. Which he did, after less than a minute.

“I’m so tired, melliza.”

“Oh? You are?”

Nicky nodded and gave a very poor, but dramatic, performance of yawning. “Yes so tired. Maybe I should take a nap too.”

Rio’s amused smile became a grin and she watched Nicky watch her for a second before she lifted her arm up and whispered down to him, “Well, there’s plenty of space here if you’re really-…”

Nicky was already moving before she’d finished her sentence. He scrambled up and soon Rio had two weighted blankets over her. One significantly smaller and warmer than the other.

She kissed the top of Nicky’s head as Agatha made a soft noise in her sleep and Nicky placed his hand over his mama’s where it was tucked beneath her scarf.

“Don’t you want to watch your movie?”

“No. This is better.”

Rio looked up at the ceiling and smiled at it because she could no longer smile at the boy now buried against her in an exact mirror image of his mom.

“Okay,” she uttered after a few seconds, “I’ll wake you up soon then.”

She felt Nicky nod against her. After a few minutes of silence she knew Nicky wasn’t asleep yet. He shifted every so often, but made no noise and Rio just knew he was trying his best to pretend to be fast asleep just like his mama.

She wondered if it were because he wanted to be doing everything Agatha was doing. Or maybe it was because he’d never seen Agatha cradled like this. It was a sight so unusual that he had to be a part of it. His melizza and his mama.

Tres patitos. All cuddled and warm.

Over an hour later, Rio cautiously lifted her arm from Nicky to check the time and when she saw it was almost two, she angled her head down and gently whispered, “Mi vida? Agatha?” She squeezed her side gently, knowing Nicky was already awake. “Time to wake up.”

It made Agatha twitch awake against her and Nicky welcomed her back to the land of the living with a gentle: “Hey, mama. Did you sleep okay?”

Agatha was slow to wake, and Rio felt her nuzzle in, felt her rumble her agreement against her.

“Mm’yeah.”

Nicky shifted up as Rio smiled and allowed him to whisper against her ear, “I slept good too.”

Rio raised her brows and turned her head to look at Nicky now just inches from her own face. “Oh yeah?”

“Yeah. So good that… that maybe we can have a proper sleepover and me and mama can sleep like this again.”

Rio grinned and asked, “Did you sleep though, mellizo? I was sure you were still awake.”

She felt Agatha laugh against her chest and saw Nicky’s cheeks flush a soft pink. “I was resting.”

“Resting?”

“Sí.”

Rio hummed and lifted her hand to mess Nicky’s already messy hair. “You are so like your mama.”

“Cute as a button and very smart?” Agatha this time. Nicky’s grin appeared again and he raised his brows as if that was exactly what Rio had been getting at. She smiled up at him, and though it hadn’t been exactly what she was getting at it wasn’t technically untrue.

“The cutest and the smartest.”

Nicky giggled and scurried back down again to be level with Agatha. In a stage whisper he said: “I think we are all cute and smart.”

“Me too, honey. But maybe you the most.”

“Noooooo,” Nicky protested as Rio ticked his side and Agatha tapped his nose.

“But this cute and smart boy needs to go pack his things. We have to get ready for the flight. I’ll be up to help in a minute, okay?”

Nicky nodded and rolled from Rio’s hold to quite literally fall onto the floor. But he bounced back up and Rio only had to panic for a second whilst Agatha remained calmly where she was. He was hurrying out the door before she could even shout after him, “Careful up the stairs please!”

Rio laughed as Agatha grumbled a quiet, “Oh to be young and not afraid of pulling your back.”

“You’re still young.”

“You once told me I’d be playing your mom in a movie soon.”

“And now you’re playing my wife.”

Agatha hummed quietly, rolling too but stopping once she was fully over Rio, unworried about pressing her whole body weight into her as she held her cheeks. “A different kind of mommy, I guess.”

“You said you wouldn’t tease.”

“No I believe you asked me not to and I didn’t agree.”

Rio narrowed her eyes but Agatha just grinned down at her, looking more energised than she had all day. And Rio was pleased, despite her scowl.

“You are going to be the death of me.”

“I think we established that that is the last thing I want.”

Rio rolled her eyes and huffed but said nothing because Agatha was sitting up now and pulling Rio with her. “This Saturday? I’m with my lawyers all day but I’ll be home before the news breaks. Can you keep Nicky occupied and have him back by, say, four?”

Rio nodded, the answer to taking Nicky for the day now much easier to give. Then again, anything felt easy to agree to with Agatha in her lap.

Agatha tugged at her scarf, peeking beneath it to see what it was covering. “Thank you.”

Her fingertips grazed over what Rio knew must have been one of the marks she’d left and she smiled just a little, still in awe of the way Agatha looked at her sometimes.

“Do you think he enjoyed today? The bike ride, I mean?”

Agatha’s gaze rose to meet her own and she looked surprised for a second before she answered, “I can only imagine how excited he’ll be to go back home and tell all his friends about it. I don’t think you know how much he loves you.”

“A little less than I love him, maybe.”

Agatha hummed gently, slipping her hand from beneath Rio’s scarf to hold her cheek, “I sometimes don’t believe my luck. I just keep… waiting for the bad to happen.”

“What bad?”

Agatha didn’t answer and as her thumb brushed down to graze Rio’s lips there was a noise in the hall that suggested Nicky was hurrying back. Agatha was quick to slip away and Rio turned just in time to see a flustered Nicky standing in the doorway with a big grin.

“All packed, mama.”

Agatha hummed suspiciously and went to kiss Nicky’s head. “Rio will make you a sandwich and I’ll go check you’ve got everything, okay?”

Rio was standing, already keen to oblige when Agatha turned to her and pointed, “Sandwich for you too. Big one.”

“¡Mandona!”

Agatha winked and Rio rolled her eyes as she walked through to the kitchen with Nicky trailing close behind.

“What does that mean?”

“It means your mom is really good at taking care of people.”

“She’s very good at that.”

Rio smiled to herself as she opened the fridge and began to rummage for ingredients. “Okay, okay, pick your poison. We got: cheese, tomatoes, ham,” she held up some prosciutto, “fancy ham, peanut butter, jel-…”

“Peanut butter!”

Rio paused and turned with a grin to see Nicky leaning up on the stool across the counter, half crawling on top of it. “Do we have a winner?”

“Yes and jelly too, please.”

“PB&J it is.”

“You too?”

“Me too.”

“But,” Rio paused, “Let’s make your mom something fancier.”

“Yes good idea, mi vida.”

Rio paused again, her gaze turning to Nicky where she’d been grabbing the prosciutto. She smiled and Nicky just grinned, unaware he’d said anything remotely surprising or unusual.

“Can I have triangles, please?”

“You bet.”

Rio turned the radio on after piling up all the ingredients on the island and Nicky turned the conversation to his favourite topic: basketball.

“And then in two weeks we have another game and it’s against this other school where all the boys are really, really tall so we might not win but coach says we get pizza either way so that’s okay.”

“Are you kidding?” Rio sliced the French bread from the side and began to cut it open for Agatha’s much more sophisticated sandwich. “Aren’t you the captain?! Of course you’ll win! I told you before remember, you don’t have to be the tallest to be the best.”

Nicky nodded thoughtfully and watched as Rio began to slice up their bread. “Maybe if I were a little taller, though.”

“Well,” Rio said as she lathered on the peanut butter to each slice. “You will get taller, mellizo. But you will always be good at basketball. And that’s more important than height.”

“Daddy’s tall.”

“He is.” Rio jammed the knife a little too hard into the jello but Nicky didn’t notice.

“But mama isn’t very tall. She’s not as tall as you.”

“No, baby.”

“So… maybe I’ll be as tall as you. In the middle.”

“Yup,” Rio agreed, her mind elsewhere now as she placed the finished sandwiches onto a plate for Nicky. “Just like me. In between your mom and dad.”

She slid the plate across and went to grab Nicky some water and a bag of chips to go with it. The only chips she could find were in a share bag but she figured that was fine. Ducklings shared.

“Will you come to my game please, melliza? I can save you some pizza.”

Rio turned with the goods and saw that Agatha had arrived and was leaning against the door frame, watching the two of them carefully. “Your game?”

“Yes.”

Rio approached the island again and placed the bag of chips and water down. “I’d love to.”

“Really?”

Rio glanced very briefly at Agatha but in Nicky’s excitement he missed it. Agatha was smiling, and Rio thought she caught a glimmer of pride in her gaze. To distract herself from the warmth filtering from her chest to the rest of her body she went back to finishing Agatha’s sandwich.

“Really.”

“I hope that isn’t my sandwich there.”

Rio bit the inside of her cheek as Agatha sauntered into the room as if she’d hadn’t just been openly eavesdropping.

“Nope. Only fancy sandwiches for you.”

Rio held up one half of her PB&J and grinned, “You can have a bite though, if you want.”

“I’ll pass.”

“Hmm.” Rio went back to the fridge to get the arugula she’d spotted earlier and heard the bag of chips being opened.

“Usually with lunch we have some vegetables or fruit. Did Nicky not tell you that?”

Rio arched a brow and turned around to see Nicky looking sheepish behind his sandwich, “I got distracted, mama.”

“Mmhm.”

Rio smiled as she grabbed an apple from the fruit bowl and held it out to Nicky. “Here, mellizo. Fruit.”

“Thank you, mi vida.”

Rio, having heard this new little choice once already, looked to Agatha to see her response to it. Her cheeks were pink and her eyes wide. Nicky didn’t notice so Rio got to enjoy the view all to herself.

Before Agatha could see that she’d been caught, Rio returned to adding the finishing touches to Agatha’s sandwich, adding the arugula to the prosciutto mozzarella baguette. With a flourish she handed it over and smiled at Agatha’s still pink cheeks.

Rio leant over the island on her elbows as she picked up her own sandwich. Agatha hadn’t touched hers yet.

“Nicky, honey…”

Rio raised her gaze to see where Agatha was going. But Agatha had paused and seemed to reconsider. “Eat your apple, please. But you can have some chips. Just not too many.”

Nicky took a bite of the fruit as Rio took a handful of chips on to her plate. Agatha stole one without a word and Rio shot her a smile, receiving one back.

Conversation continued, with Nicky driving it, Rio facilitating it, and Agatha observing it. They talked of basketball, of peanut butter being better than jelly, of what Nicky would do on the flight home (the answer to that was read his book and play his switch).

It was as Rio was gathering the finished plates that the door went and Agatha went to answer, returning just as Rio and Nicky were stealing more chips from the large bag.

“One duffel.”

Agatha placed the bag on the island and Rio blinked at it, momentarily dumbfounded. “I was going to grab that later.”

“Well, I thought it would be easier to have it brought to you so you didn’t have to chase about town before your flight.”

“When is your flight, melliza? Soon after ours?”

“It’s at six. Yours is at-…”

“Five.”

“And,” Rio shot Agatha a brief look, catching her nod before she turned back to Nicky, “I’m sleeping over with you again tonight. So we can start our infinity game tomorrow after school?”

“Really?”

“Absolutely.”

“Okay, honey, go and freshen up in the bathroom, we have to get going soon.”

Nicky ran off without complaint and Rio raised her brows across at Agatha, “Fetching my bag for me now?”

“I called for it before my nap. Figured you deserved some time to relax before your flight. Seeing as you were such a good mattress for me earlier.”

“A mattress now, am I?”

Agatha was moving to her now, stopping just as she came around the corner of the island. She reached for Rio’s scarf and tugged it gently, “A comfy one.”

“Will you sleep on the plane?”

“No, I’ll sleep later, when my girlfriend is with me.”

Rio bit her lip, glancing at the entrance to the kitchen before she leant closer and loosely draped her arms around Agatha’s hips. “And we’ll talk?”

“Yes.”

“Plans, how we’ll do this?”

“Yes.”

Rio nodded, her eyes closing as Agatha rested their foreheads together. “Maybe I should come with you to the airport just to make sure-…”

“You can’t, Rio. We can’t be seen too often together. Not when Nicky is now calling us ‘mi vida’.”

Rio grinned and opened her eyes to see Agatha grinning back at her, a flush of pride across her features. “He asked me to not call him Nicky earlier, you know. Or less asked, insisted. Very like his mama.”

“We just want you all to ourselves.”

Rio hummed and had been just a breath away from Agatha’s lips when Nicky could be heard thundering down the stairs to them. They pulled back and Rio knew that they’d just missed their last opportunity to kiss before they had to part.

“All ready!”

Rio’s disappointment didn’t last long when Nicky’s grin existed. She smiled at him and before he could say another thing she’d swaddled him so tightly in her arms that he laughed for it and hugged her right back.

“You be good for your mama on the plane, okay? It’ll be late by the time I’m back tonight but I’ll see you tomorrow.”

“Sí, melliza. We can play our big game.”

“The biggest game ever. Maybe we’ll break a world record or something.”

Nicky hummed and laughed as Rio pulled back and kissed his cheek sweetly, only to have Nicky copy this and kiss her own.

“I’ve written down the code for the gate,” Agatha was saying somewhere over her shoulder, “Seeing how useless you are on your cell. This is the key for here,” Rio turned and looked to the gold key Agatha was holding up. “And this one is for the house.”

Rio nodded, doing her best to concentrate on the only two things she had to remember. She pocketed the code that Agatha had just scribbled down. “Okay, easy.”

Nicky was back on her though and she forgot whether the gold key was for this house or the LA one. She placed her hand on his upper back and looked down at where he was pressed into her side.

She had been expecting him to say something but he remained silent, his eyes on his mom as he held on. So Rio looked up too and saw Agatha looked far away, locked inside her own world as she stared at the two of them.

“Gold for Boston,” she eventually said, “Silver for LA.”

Rio nodded but wasn’t really listening and lifted her arm up for Agatha, only to gather her in a second later. Nicky wriggled from her side to slip between them and soon they were all limbs, no one quite sure which belonged to who.

Rio could have stayed like this for an eternity. But eternity was interrupted by a knock at the door and they had to separate so Agatha and Nicky could be taken to the airport.

Rio followed them out, she helped wheel the bike to the car as the suitcases were taken by the driver. She gave Nicky another tight hug, placed her Celtics cap on his head, and then gave Agatha a hug equally as tight before waving them both off.

And then she was alone again, the door to Agatha’s Boston retreat closed and her back to it. The space felt empty without Agatha’s presence and Nicky’s noise. But she wouldn’t let herself move back into the depths of her misery.

She focused on Nicky’s promise to play an infinite game with her. She focused on Agatha wanting to talk, wanting to tell her things, wanting to plan. She focused on hopping in the shower to freshen herself up.

From her duffel she painted on concealer so she could get away with not wearing her Celtics scarf through the airport. She did a reasonable job of it and went overboard by applying a little more to the bags beneath her eyes.

Rio Vidal still looked tired, a little thinner than she usually would, less viral, less healthy. But whether real or imaginary, her eyes looked brighter.

Or perhaps it was the magic touch éclat she’d just applied.

By the time she was done hurrying around the house, making sure it was pristine for whenever Agatha would return, it was time to call a cab to take her to the airport.

She heaved her duffel over her shoulder and wrapped her scarf around her neck for good measure before she locked the door with the gold key and jumped into the waiting car.

Her airport experience was much like the one she’d had on her way to Boston. Everyone looked, everyone knew who she was, most people kept their distance. She no longer had her cap to hide behind but she was glad Nicky had had it.

By the time she was in her seat on the plane she felt exhausted, defeated, lonely. She wished Agatha were beside her, that she could at least feel her arm pressed up against her on on the arm rest, that maybe Nicky could be asking her more questions about basketball - or anything, for that matter.

The flight was long, too long to be enjoyable. she managed a nap for half of it, and watched a movie for the rest. But really she kept checking her watch, kept seeing how long it would be before she could be back with Agatha. Before they could talk. Before she could be a willing mattress to her.

At LAX, the paps got her. She kept her gaze ahead, kept her duffel held securely over her shoulder, but couldn’t deny that it bothered her now more than it ever had. Didn’t they know she was grieving? Didn’t they know she could barely think straight, let alone offer the smiles they were requesting?

A cab took her to Agatha’s house and in it Rio managed to calm her nervous system down enough to be presentable to her girlfriend. Her anxiety had spiked somewhere between disembarking the plane and slipping into the comfy environs of the Mercedes car that carried her to Agatha.

But she breathed through it. She focused on getting to Agatha and soon she felt more at ease.

The moment wasn’t lost on Rio as she strode down the garden path of Agatha’s LA home. This was a house that a year ago she could only have dreamed of visiting and now she had a key, she had access.

Agatha wanted her here. She wanted her here so badly she trusted Rio to come and go when she pleased. She trusted her to be around with her son, to stick around when he’d gone to bed, to have breakfast with them.

She trusted the woman who sometimes forgot to lock her own front door.

Rio stepped into the house, heaving the heavy door open, closing it securely and turning the key in the lock again until she heard the clank of the mechanism. It was locked. They were safe.

“Thank fuck you’re here.”

Rio’s moment of calm was destroyed the second she heard Alice’s voice. She whipped around, her duffel falling heavily to the floor by her feet as she stared across at the little ball of anxiety that was her best friend.

“What’s happened?”

“They’ve been going at it for almost thirty minutes now.”

“Ralph.”

“Jen.”

Without another word Alice grabbed Rio’s arm and dragged her through the house until they were in touching distance of Agatha’s office door. Through it, she could hear Agatha’s voice: “That is not your job, Jennifer! Your job is to talk to studios, to manage my schedule, to-…”

Agatha had stopped the moment Rio and Alice had stepped inside. It was like a switch had been flicked. The brunette with the wild hair stormed over to pull Rio to her. Agatha’s body felt rigid against her own, but her hands were gentle as they caressed up and down her back.

“You’re here. Was the flight okay? Did you-…?”

She’d pulled back, caressing hands now on her face, searching for any sign of harm that may have befallen her between the Boston house and LAX.

“I’m fine,” Rio said with a dazed kind of smile, “What’s happened?”

Agatha’s wide-eyed look dropped from her face then and her hands moved down to Rio’s arms as Jen behind them said, “Agatha’s pissed I was doing my job well.”

Alice cleared her throat and Rio watched as she went to stand in front of her girlfriend in a stance Rio knew was protective more than anything else. Rio did the same for Agatha, only her own version. She slid an arm around Agatha’s waist and turned her around to stand beside her, holding her close.

“You know I’m doing the right thing, Agatha. Don’t be a bitch.”

“Jen.”

“Jen.”

Rio’s fingers flexed against Agatha’s side but she wasn’t holding her enough to prevent Agatha from ripping away from her. Alice made a move to cover Jen but Agatha wasn’t aiming for her, she’d walked to the other end of the room and left Rio by the door.

“Is someone going to tell me what’s going on?”

Her eyes remained on Agatha, watching as she buried her fingers in her hair, making it double in volume with her frustrated touch. But Jen answered, her tone full of resentment, smugness, everything that could possibly piss Agatha off.

“I’ve pulled a profile of you. I’ve been digging for weeks now. I have everything that I need to know ahead of any issues. Any leaks.”

Rio’s whole body felt hot all of a sudden. Her eyes had moved over to Jen so she missed Agatha swinging back around, her hands fallen from her hair, her gaze on Rio.

“A… profile?”

“Like she’s in the fucking FBI or something.”

“Did you know?” Her gaze moved sound to Alice who looked like she was stuck between a Jen and an Agatha-place. And like she wanted to be anywhere else.

“No.”

Rio was blushing. She must be bright red. Redder than she’d ever been. Jen wouldn’t meet her gaze, only scowling down at the floor. Alice was watching her closely, but her body was still angled towards Agatha.

And Agatha? Agatha was marching back over, taking Rio’s wrist and tugging her to the armchair in the corner of the room. She half-directed, half-pushed her into it and then stood like a determined bodyguard before her.

“Delete it all. Now. I want it gone.”

“Agatha,” Alice said in a much softer tone than Rio had been expecting. “Everyone in this room wants this to work. Jen is-…”

“Don’t fucking defend your girlfriend. She’s doing this to sabotage-…”

“Oh, is that right?!”

Jen had stepped forwards now and before Rio could react she was already in Agatha’s face. Rio jumped for her. She snuck her arms around Agatha and held her flush against her front.

“We need to know what might come out, what might happen. Because you two losers are so goddamn awful at being subtle that someone is eventually going to notice something. Your fucking face on that goddamn jumbotron, Agatha. You have an Oscar for christsake, fucking act like it!”

Rio stumbled back a step with Agatha. Agatha didn’t say anything.

“You may not give a shit about your career right now and I know all of your efforts are focused on keeping Nicky but it’s my job to make sure you have a career to go back to.”

“I’m not interesting in my fucking career if-…”

“It’s not just yours, Agatha,” Jen spat. Rio had never seen her so vicious, never seen the fire in her usually calm, often discerning eyes. But her words obviously hit a nerve because Agatha relaxed in her arms as Rio pulled her slowly back again.

“Besides,” she added, less spit this time. “From even a surface knowledge of playgirl Rio Vidal, she’s not exactly a judge’s dream parental figure. She might get in the way of you even getting joint custody if your bitch of a mother has anything to do with it.”

It was like Jen had stabbed Rio right through the chest. It was as if she’d pierced through skin and sinew and slashed right through to her already broken heart. Rio gasped, swallowing down air she didn’t know if she wanted anymore.

Even as Rio couldn’t decide whether breathing was any longer for her, she could feel every breath Agatha took. She could feel the anger ebbing and flowing through her body. The rising tide of her desire to scream, of her need to explode. So she kept her arms securely around her, nudged her way in to press her face in against Agatha’s.

Agatha being close was helping. Agatha’s perfume and the feel of her body.

She took a breath.

“Mi amor, sit down with me. Come back.” As Agatha began to silently acquiesce, as Rio pulled her down with her into the chair, Jen made the mistake of speaking again.

“Listen to your mistress.”

Rio’s back had just hit the seat when Agatha was ripping herself away. She cursed as Agatha made it to Jen and the two best friends were baring their teeth like two Rottweilers in a violent standoff.

“Say that again, I dare you.”

“I am keeping you both safe! Look at how much press one fucking kiss with Wanda got!”

“Agatha.” / “Jen.”

Rio gave up trying to hold Agatha the way she had been a second ago and instead came around to stand before her, slipping between the two vicious women to find her Agatha again as Alice tugged at her own girlfriend.

Agatha’s jaw flexed and for a fraction of a second she met Rio’s gaze but the she turned again, ripped herself away once more, and marched a few steps towards the wall, her fingers finding her hair and hiding themselves in it.

Alice was speaking in a low voice to Jen but all of Rio’s senses were focused on Agatha still. She could see the tension in her tight body, feel the rage emanating from every aspect of her. It made her own body tense, made her own fright fizzle to nothing, taken over by the strain of Agatha’s furious fears.

She moved closer again and wrapped her arms around Agatha, wanting her to know she was there, that she could rely on her. At least for now.

At least until anything came out about her past, about her wild child ways. For now she could support her. She had to focus on that.

“Mi vida,” she tried quietly, watching as Agatha twitched in response but didn’t turn around. But her hand was across Rio’s arm and it felt soft and hesitant as it lay there. “My past it’s…”

“It’s not about your past, it’s about what Jen is trying to do-…”

“She’s a megabitch with a huge jealous streak.” Jen had clearly decided to speak up now, making sure Agatha could hear at least this portion of her conversation with Alice.

Agatha’s hold on her arm tightened but Rio didn’t let it change the way she held Agatha. She was firm, yes. But not unyielding, not unnecessarily trapping her. Agatha had freedom of movement and she hoped that with the knowledge of that she wouldn’t feel the need to pull away again.

“There’s no need for you to have any kind of profile on Rio. You don’t need to know anything other than she is my girlfriend. That’s it.”

“It’s the girlfriend part that’s the problem, Agatha! This is a woman who doesn’t date! Who fucks around and-…!”

“Jen.” Alice.

Rio’s cheeks were flaming red again, and she slid her arms from around Agatha to turn around and collapse back in the armchair, her head in her hands.

Perhaps Rio had ruined this before it had even begun.

“She is my girlfriend. My son loves her and she is more a parent to him, has been more a parent to him in the last few months than Ralph ever has!”

Rio said nothing. Could think of nothing other than how her presence in Nicky’s life might mean Agatha would have to share her son with her deadbeat husband. No parent would allow that. No good, loving person would allow that to happen.

“And I am doing my best to make sure nothing fucks this up, Agatha. You know how these things can be twisted. You know how-…!”

“Jen. Jen.” Alice was intervening again. She could hear her urgent whispering to Jennifer on the other side of the room.

Rio forced herself to breathe. Forced herself to focus on what she could do: she could step back, she would wait. She could give Agatha time.

In her sprila, a soft brush against her hair told her that Agatha was closer again. She looked up as Agatha’s fingers skimmed down to caress her cheek and Rio blinked up at the woman who’d softened suddenly, looking suddenly like her Agatha again. Hers and Nicky’s.

Their soft, gentle Agatha.

She watched as she took a breath, as her lips parted and her pale cheeks tinged a little pink.

“¿Etás bien, mi amor?”

Agatha knew she was spiralling, perhaps even knew the decision that was swirling around in her brain, begging to be made.

Give her time. Step back. Protect Nicky by giving her time.

Her spiral spun its last as Agatha continued to gaze at her, as her eyes held her in place so Rio could lift her head from the depths of her clouded mind. Rio smiled once she surfaced because how could she not. She leant into Agatha’s touch as her fingers slipped down and she held her chin, her thumb just touching her lower lip.

“Sí, mi vida. Estoy bien.”

“I’m trying to help,” Jen’s voice filtered into Rio’s consciousness, her gaze still on Agatha as blue eyes moved over her face, taking all of her in, trying to see the lie in Rio’s whisper. She was trying to fix the spiral she didn’t know she’d already halted.

“She’s right,” Rio said softly. Rio knew she was. Agatha had to know too. It couldn’t be denied that anything anyone dragged up during the divorce, during the custody hearing, could cause a problem for Agatha. Rio could cause problems for Agatha.

Agatha’s brow twitched into a light frown and she dropped her gaze to Rio’s lips, raising her thumb tenderly to press into the cushion of her lower one. She didn’t say anything and Rio took her hand away and kissed the fingers that curled around her own.

She had to think clearly now, had to break the habit that had formed over the weeks of sinking instead of even trying to swim.
