“Knowledge is power and if we have all the information and know what they could uncover or try to hit us with then-…”

“I don’t want to talk about it anymore,” Agatha said more firmly than when she’d been checking in on Rio. “You have it. You’ve done the research. You know now. I don’t need to hear it.”

Agatha’s gaze had fallen from Rio and she was pulling away to stand again, raising herself to her full height to look at Jennifer now leaning against the desk with Alice holding her hand in two of her own.

“We’ll be good. Until everything’s settled and I have full custody. You won’t need the information. And I don’t want it brought up again.”

Rio took Agatha’s hand, shuffling forwards in the chair to be able to reach it and Agatha didn’t turn but she squeezed her hand when she held it.

“It’s not enough to do the beforehand Agatha. After you’re out, after you announce your relationship it’ll all-…”

“Jen.”

Rio stood then, not because she thought Agatha would snap but because this was her part to play.

“Let them release it all when this is over. Let them interview everyone I’ve ever dated. I’m not ashamed of any of it. And once Agatha has custody they can’t take him away just because her girlfriend has a past.”

Her voice had faltered over her last sentence, suddenly unsure of herself.

Agatha squeezed her hand and Jen nodded just once.

“It won’t be easy,” Alice warned, the first thing she’d said in a while. Her face was tight, her brow pulled together, her cheeks a little pink. She was scared of Agatha, Rio knew that. But Agatha didn’t bite and Rio never would.

“I know.”

Agatha tugged her hand and Rio looked to her and realised she didn’t want her attention, she was just reminding herself she was there.

“I’ve only ever wanted this to work. As soon as I knew. As soon as-…” Jen.

Agatha stiffened beside her, and Rio looked back at her once more, seeing her jaw flex. But her eyes, previously alert again and focused only on Jen were now hidden from her as she stared at the floor. Rio moved her free hand to Agatha’s arm and squeezed her.

“I’m trying to protect you.”

Jen’s face was open again, her eyes wide even as she pursed her lips. Rio wondered if she’d ever said anything similar to Agatha before outside of the context of the usual manager/client relationship. Because she didn’t mean professionally. Rio knew that, Alice knew it, and Agatha did too.

It was why she was looking away, why she was hiding.

The air in the room was still until Agatha breathed life into it again with her next words: “I know you’re trying your best. I know I haven’t made it easy. But whether it destroys my career or not,” she took a breath and revealed herself again.

Agatha looked up to Jen and to Rio’s surprise she looked calmer, as if she’d been wrestling with a decision this whole time and she was finally experiencing the peace of making a choice.

“I choose Rio over my career.”

“Agatha.”

Agatha didn’t turn to Rio, didn’t even look around as she moved her hand to her cheek to try and make her turn. “Mi amor, No llegará a eso.” It won’t come to that.

Rio’s hand was still against Agatha’s cheek, warm and insistent. But Agatha was looking around her, not acquiescing. She had eyes only for her friend. “Which means you can’t just pull shit like this. Everything related to the divorce, to Rio, it goes through me. Through us.”

Rio’s gaze softened, her heart choking on its need to beat faster in her chest. She felt the flutter of it, the very moment it forgot itself and tried to canter where it had barely been jogging.

Her fingers slipped until they were lining Agatha’s jaw and only then did Agatha turn to her. Only then did she look away from Jen. And Rio frowned at the sight. Agatha looked lost, suddenly unsure of what she was doing and where she was.

So Rio nodded, because it felt like Agatha was looking for permission to be exactly where she found herself. A glimmer of relief flashed across Agatha’s face and then she turned again and Rio slipped back to kiss her shoulder, to go back to being steady by her side.

“You’re so fucking gay.”

Jen again. Though with a vague, bemused smile on her face.

“How no one’s ever seen it, I don’t know. Which is the fucking worry.”

Rio scoffed and received a scowl from Agatha and soon found that she was pulling away and marching over to Jen. “I’ll accept your apology, Jennifer. When you’re ready to give it. Preferably now.”

Jen was the one to scoff now and Rio sighed as she went to settle back in the armchair, watching the two friends with interest. The tension was gone now and the two were back to bickering rather than raging so she felt comfortable leaving them to it.

Her spiral was paused for now, but it was dormant, just waiting to continue spinning again if Rio lost control of it.

Alice slipped away, still skittish around Agatha. She settled on the arm of Rio’s chair and muttered from the corner of her mouth as across the room Jen was protesting.

“Girlfriends?”

“Mmhm.”

“Feeling better?”

“Getting there.”

“Are you ready for what’s to come?”

“We will be.”

Alice nodded and both looked across at their girlfriends, raising their brows in tandem as both Agatha and Jen formed fists at their sides.

“Should we break them up?” Rio asked as Agatha now threw her hands up and stormed around the desk to sit at her chair, soon finding a pen to tap as Jen was spouting words like: “longevity”, “working relationships”, “box office draw”.

“When she’s riled up I usually have a better change of getting laid.”

This made Rio bark a laugh and she looked up to her grinning friend. “I’m so glad this little evening has all basically been foreplay for the two of you.”

Alice shrugged and turned her attention back to the other two. “She seems determined.”

“Jen?”

“Agatha. On the relationship.”

Rio stiffened slightly, wondering what trust level Alice was currently at with Agatha but knowing it was definitely somewhere still in the fiftieth percentile.

“You still don’t trust her?”

Alice’s mouth opened and then closed again but before she could say anything Rio heard her name being called and she turned to see both Agatha and Jen looking at her expectantly. She raised her brows and Agatha repeated: “Can you please tell my manager what we’ve agreed?”

Rio’s mind ran through the possible answers: I can’t rail Agatha until I start taking care of myself, my cowboy shirt is now our cowboy shirt, purple skittles are now Rio’s to eat so Agatha doesn’t have to, they are two of three ducklings, Rio can’t move in.

The last. It had to be the last.

“I’m staying here until Saturday but I’m not moving in.”

“Moving in?” Alice.

“I really don’t think-…” Jen.

“We agreed, Jen. Drop it to TMZ on Saturday evening. He’s being served at four. They’ll have it by five past. Rio will be with Nicky and me in the new place. We’ll be hidden away. No one knows where-…” Agatha, agitated.

“My name on the deed doesn’t mean you’re totally hidden, Agatha.” Jen, again. Angrier.

“It’s in the hills. It’s secluded.” Agatha, even angrier.

“Do you know how fucking famous you are?! It’s bad enough you’re a dyke and now you’re moving one in!”

Agatha was on her feet before Rio was. She’d slammed her hands onto the desk and the slap of it reverberated around the room, settling in Rio’s chest and causing her heart rate to kick up again.

“Call me that again and I’ll fire your sorry ass before you have a chance to say ‘oh Agatha, what will people say when they see me on Alice’s arm?! Surely I can do better?!’”

Time with Agatha often felt slower. Felt different to time without her.

And time now felt slower too. Time felt heavy.

Rio watched in slow motion as Jennifer Kale launched herself at Agatha Harkness.

Agatha had thrown herself back and Rio was on her in a second. Just as Alice was on Jen.

“You fucking lying bitch! I never said that! I never said that!”

Agatha wasn’t fighting as Rio held her wrists down and pressed her against the shelves behind her desk, but she wasn’t backing down either.

“You said it, Jen. You told me-…”

Agatha grunted when Rio shoved her backwards in an attempt to get her to shut up.

“You bitch. You liar. You fucking-…”

“ENOUGH!”

Alice. Little, intimidated, terrified Alice. Agatha was shocked into straightening again where she’d already begun to lean around Rio once more. Rio still wasn’t budging but she turned her head to look at her friend.

Alice’s cheeks were being held by a panicking Jen and Rio could see the hurt in her eyes, the shock too, that she’d even raised her voice in front of Agatha. But she turned back because as Jen tried to make frantic amends, Agatha was the only person she wanted to turn to.

“Why did you say it?”

Agatha flinched at her tone, and looked at Rio properly for the first time since she’d thrown Jen’s words back at her.

“Agatha.”

Agatha looked like she might deny she’d even said anything. She looked like she might deny even having been in the room when such things were said. But maybe it was Rio’s refusal to look away. Maybe it was her tightening hold on her wrists, the way she pressed her body against Agatha’s to keep her where she was.

Only something told her Agatha wouldn’t try to push her away.

A flex in her jaw told her that Agatha was struggling with what to say, with how to manage this. But Rio wouldn’t look or move away. She made her deal, made her struggle, until eventually she said: “I’m sorry.”

Rio pressed in briefly before she released her wrists and let go. Agatha’s eyes clouded over and she stepped into Rio, her hands clutching now at her sweatshirt, “I’m sorry.”

Rio shook her head but had no time to respond because Jen had spoken before she could form the words.

“Tell her, Agatha. Tell her you’re a liar. Tell her.”

Agatha wasn’t looking at Jen; even as she slammed her hand on the desk. Her eyes were still on Rio, seeking her absolution before she even deigned to look at her angry friend. But Rio couldn’t give what she was looking for because it wasn’t hers to give.

She shook her head again, barely an inch either way.

“Agatha,” Jen insisted.

“Jen,” Alice tried to calm her.

“Mi vida,” Rio breathed, her fingers grazing the cheek where a tear now traced its miserable path. Agatha took the cue, like any professional might, and with her hands still twisted in Rio’s sweatshirt she turned to her friend and swallowed.

“Months ago,” Rio realised as she spoke how afraid she was. Her voice was hoarse and soft and Rio brushed another tear from her cheek, “Jen came to me and said she was nervous about, about being seen with you.”

Agatha dropped her gaze and Rio laid her hand gently on her chest, a silent request for her to breathe.

“She was nervous about…”

Rio pressed her palm a little harder against her chest. Breathe, Agatha.

“About what people might say, because of your jobs. The… other bit… she never said that.”

“Agatha.” Rio couldn’t keep the disappointment out of her voice and Agatha caught it as her eyes moved back to her. She looked devastated and her face began to crumple before her very eyes.

Rio gathered her in, and felt the first sob against her neck. The hands that had been clutching the front of her sweater were now against her back. Agatha was clinging to her like she was about to disappear.

If Jen and Alice said anything during that time, Rio didn’t hear it.

She wasn’t sure if it was the stress of the past few weeks or something else that had set Agatha off. But she’d raged and then she’d disintegrated before her eyes.

Shame, fury, fear. They were sobbed out against Rio’s willing skin as Agatha continued to clutch at her, not content until she could claw her way in.

Rio just held on, eventually pressing Agatha back into the shelves so she could feel contained, trapped between the hard wood and Rio’s consenting body. Agatha began to calm soon after, and as her breathing evened, her clawing hands disappeared beneath Rio’s sweatshirt to get to her skin. She clutched her still, her nails scraping and fingers desperate. And Rio held her through it all, ducking her head down to encourage Agatha to look at her, to press her hot, sticky face into her own.

To become one of sorrow.

“Rio,” Alice’s voice broke through as Agatha gasped against Rio’s parted lips, nuzzling her broken features as close as she could get.

“Rio.”

Rio moved her arms from around Agatha and placed her hands on her cheeks, keeping her head in place as she kissed her.

“Rio.”

Rio turned her head to an angle that would show she was listening but that meant she didn’t need to turn too far from Agatha.

“You need to rethink staying here. Both of you do.”

Rio turned her head back, frowning now as Agatha’s hands began to move across her back, seeking a place to rest. She felt Agatha’s response before she heard it, “No.”

But she said it only for her. Jen and Alice may as well not have been in the room. But Rio knew they were, so she pulled back, and was gentle as she pried Agatha off of her and managed to turn to the two other women in the room.

Jen looked as though she, too, had been crying. And Alice didn’t look far off. Perhaps Rio had simply cried too much recently for her body to allow it. But she felt the swell of tears that starts in the throat when Agatha said her name from behind her and tried to turn her back around.

“We’ll do as we’ve agreed until Saturday. I’ll take Nicky during the day, and bring him to the new house before the press start their hunt. After that, we’ll be careful,” Agatha said her name again, but Rio ignored it, “We’ll be so good and so discreet that even you two won’t notice.”

She heard Agatha suck in a breath and exhale it shakily as her hands crossed across her bare stomach beneath her sweatshirt. It made her fall back into her, made her falter for a second before she made a promise she didn’t know if she could keep: “We’ll let you manage when we can see each other.”

It was an overcorrection, a response to the fear that still lingered that she could be the cause of Agatha losing Nicky. Because even sharing him with Ralph was inconceivable. And it being Rio’s fault would be something she simply couldn’t live with.

“No,” Rio was tugged backwards this time and heard the thud as Agatha fell into the shelves, “No. No. No. We’re not. I’m not.”

“I think that is the best way to do this,” Alice agreed, her eyes on Rio, who felt the weight of guilt in her stomach as Agatha pressed her fingers there.

“No. I’m not agreeing. No. I-…”

“Agatha.” Jen. “You know it’s for the best. For a while, at least. Until we can get a gage on public interest. On press levels, on-…”

“I will not be told when and where I can see my girlfriend. Only by Rio. Only by Rio.”

Rio lost her breath then because Agatha had moved her hands. One now had reached to curl around her shoulder and the other was holding her opposite hip. She held her securely against her, as if frightened that this time she wouldn’t disappear, but instead be taken.

In front of them Jen and Alice looked defeated, and Rio felt sorry for them both. She really did.

“We’ll do it,” she said, before Jen could utter the words she had looked like she was about to shout. Over her sweatshirt she lay her hands on Agatha’s, letting her know she wasn’t going anywhere. “Because doing it is extra protection for Agatha and for Nicky. And neither of us want anything we do to upset him. He-…” Rio swallowed and felt Agatha tug impossibly at her, “We will do it because we love him.”

Agatha’s hold changed and Rio knew she was relenting but she wouldn’t say anything to Jen or Alice. Her hand on her shoulder moved to her ribs instead. It rested over her heart and Rio just knew she wanted to feel the beat of it, she wanted a metronome for her own.

Agatha pressed her face into her shoulder and silence descended again.

“When you’re feeling ready to apologise, I’ll be waiting for your call.” Jen. Looking less than the anger her words implied.

Alice had taken her hand and was pulling her towards the door and just as they reached it Rio felt Agatha lift her head up, felt her squeeze over her ribs as she said: “I’m sorry. Alice. Jen. I… thank you. For trying to help.”

Jen pursed her lips but inclined her head and though Rio didn’t think she’d say anything at all she eventually spoke up: “What I said earlier, everything about… about Rio. You’re right about her. It’s why we’re trying so hard. It’s why I’m being hard on you both. We need to be so careful. Now more than ever.”

Rio swallowed as Agatha’s hold lessened.

Jen was looking at her now. Agatha must have spotted it too because she was shifting behind her, uncomfortable with her friend’s eyes on the woman she’d been clinging to.

“Agatha’s right. You’re already a better parent to that boy than Ralph ever was.”

Rio choked on nothing and Agatha brought her hand out from its hidden resting place to wrap around her neck. Her touch was healing.

She could breathe again.

“Try to get some sleep. You both look like shit.”

Alice smiled weakly and Jen offered no other softness and then they were gone.

The clock on the desk told Rio it was creeping closer to morning and they had to be up in just a few, miserable hours. But she couldn’t think of her tiredness. She could only thing of Agatha who had now moved her hand to hold her head, making her turn around and fighting to keep her as close to her body as possible.

Agatha was pale, and looked beyond exhaustion. Her blue eyes were downturned, her heavy lids covering them from Rio’s view. Her voice was soft again, feeble.

“I want you to live with us.”

“I want that too.”

“It’s all my fault. Everything is-…”

“Mi vida, all anyone wants is for you and Nicky to be happy and safe and together. That’s all that matters.”

“You matter too.”

“I cannot be the reason he gets taken away. Even sharing him, I-…”

“I knew you were thinking that. I knew you were thinking that.”

Rio sighed heavily and dropped her head to Agatha’s shoulder, feeling her instantly cradle her close, instantly become the holder of the two of them. The were silent for a while, Rio wading through the waters of her misery and Agatha holding her steady as she passed through them.

Rio didn’t know who decided it was time they went up to bed. They just did.

Agatha only left Rio to go check on Nicky and returned to her when she’d seen him sleeping soundly in his bed, thankfully the opposite end of the house to the office.

Rio was already tucked under the sheets, wearing her underwear and a t-shirt she’d found under the pillow. Agatha joined but didn’t bother with the t-shirt and settled down beside Rio, curling as close as possible.

They hadn’t spoken, had barely looked at each other since they’d left the office. But Rio couldn’t find the words anymore and Agatha clearly couldn’t either. They’d have to talk another time.

Rio began to brush her fingers up and down Agatha’s side where she lay facing the same way as Rio, hoping to lull her to sleep first with her soft touch.

But Agatha found words soon enough.

“Those other women…,” Agatha’s voice was quiet in the still room, barely above a whisper. “Did any of them have kids?”

Rio traced her nose along the soft skin of the back of Agatha’s neck, taking a second to try and understand the reasoning behind the question. “Some.”

Agatha nodded, her hold on Rio’s hand tightening, “Did you meet them? Did you ever-…?”

“Agatha? I never met anyone’s kids. It was mostly just sex. I wasn’t interested in anything more with any of them.”

In the slowness of Agatha’s response, in the tightness of her hold on her, Rio knew she was worried that Rio had a pattern. That Jen wasn’t right, but was close to being so. Perhaps Rio liked the chase, enjoyed the comfort for a while before she had to bolt and seek something exciting again.

With her mouth she reassured, she pressed deliberate, open kisses along to column of Agatha’s neck. With her body she cradled, she pressed in closer, holding her more tightly. With her words she calmed, breathing them into Agatha’s ear, “I’ve never found someone I wanted to settle down with. I didn’t even know I was looking until I found you. You’re the only person I want to be with.”

Agatha pressed back, attempting to turn, so Rio shifted up so she had room. When they locked eyes Rio knew she’d been correct. Agatha was still nervous, still unsure about Rio’s true feelings.

Her heart sunk in her chest.

“Life with me and Nicky, when all this is finally over, it’ll be schedules and parent teacher conferences. Making dinner and doctor’s appointments. It’s all boring, all the same, all-…”

“Exactly what I want.”

Rio moved again, no longer satisfied leaning over Agatha. She wanted to be all over her, to wrap herself around her, to let her feel her need to be with her. She slid her hand down her side and held her still as she hovered her body weight above her, sinking down to press against her without fully letting go.

“Does it feel real to you?”

Agatha asked quietly, having taken a second to respond as Rio was nuzzling against her, her hand slipping below her shirt to feel her warm side.

“Does what feel real?”

“This? Us?”

“Yes.”

Rio kissed Agatha, partly because she wanted to and partly to see how in her head she was. She kissed back, and her hands flew up her waist.

“Imagine seeing the most beautiful woman you’ve ever seen on a screen in your tiny neighbourhood move theatre and then years later she’s lying beneath you as your girlfriend.”

Rio kissed her again, and Agatha kissed back again.

“No, it doesn’t feel real. But it also feels like the most real thing that’s ever happened to me. You are more real than anything or anyone I’ve ever met. And you are all I want.”

Agatha smiled and Rio felt her heart stammer in her chest as if it had been about to say something but had thought better of it. Only she took over for it, and said the thing she’d been worried about all evening: “Would this be easier if we weren’t together? If we waited?”

Agatha’s smile disappeared and Rio knew what her answer would be before she gave it.

“No. None of this. None of it would be easy without you.”

“I’m thinking of-…”

“I know what you’re thinking of but I am telling you, and I need you to believe me, that nothing would be easier without you.”

Rio dropped her gaze, finding it hard to believe Agatha’s words when she still felt so ineffectual. And after this evening, she felt like a burden.

Agatha’s hands were tracing the lines of her back now, retracing the journey they’d made earlier when they’d been desperate instead of delicate. Each muscle in her body began to relax until she collapsed fully above Agatha and turned her head on the pillow to nuzzle in against her.

“I can’t do this without you.”

Rio nodded but didn’t say anything. Agatha’s hands continued to move against her.

“Say it.”

“You can’t do this without me.”

“I love you. I will not allow the press, or Ralph, or my mother, to take you away from me.”

Rio nodded again and Agatha’s hands stilled against her. Her fingers splayed over her ribs and Rio focused on the warmth of them, the way Agatha held her steadily there as if supporting her body to continue breathing.

She felt like death was much farther away when Agatha was this close.

She wondered if Agatha knew her touch helped.

She wondered if she knew she was keeping her alive.

“I love you,” she whispered, a strange calmness to her voice. “Everything is easier with you too.”

Rio moved to lean up again, putting an arm’s length of distance between them as she rested her hands either side of Agatha’s face. Agatha’s hands moved once more, her nails dragging down the line to her hips, encouraging goosebumps in their wake.

Agatha’s face was more relaxed now. And Rio knew Agatha liked access to her so she rolled off but took Agatha’s hand to kiss it like a romantic hero might.

Agatha was silent, allowing Rio to keep her knuckles pressed to her lips for as long as she wanted. But knuckles turned to a palm and then a wrist and Rio whispered as Agatha made a soft noise of contentment.

“Goodnight, mi vida.”

She leant in to kiss Agatha then, lingering for twice as long as before. The hand she’d been holding was now buried in her hair and Rio gasped quietly as Agatha captured her lower lip. She wanted to deepen the kiss. She wanted to turn it into something hungry, build it to something feverish.

But her bones ached for sleep. So she pulled away to press a a kiss to Agatha’s nose, forehead, cheek. And the she was beside her again. Agatha had turned to press back into her and Rio wrapped her in her arms.

As Rio settled, as she nuzzled, as she let her body relax, her brain wouldn’t follow it. It turned over the conversation in Agatha’s office. It twisted its neurones around Jen’s desperate need to control a narrative not yet written. It curled around Alice’s desire to protect her girlfriend, and Rio, but also her fear and mistrust of Agatha.

It secured itself tightly to the reminder of Agatha’s outburst, of the tension in her body, of the way she’d lashed out and went for Jen’s throat when she was in the peak of her rage.

Rio nudged her nose along the soft skin at the base of Agatha’s neck, she breathed her in for a second, thinking of the way Agatha had broken down against her when she’d felt the shame of what she’d done.

Jen had once told her: “a feral cat attacks when it’s cornered.” But then she’d corrected herself. “An abused cat.”

It made Rio feel nauseous as she thought of those words from that night. Of Agatha breaking down then too, but alone, without Rio to hold her.

Rio made Agatha turn to her then. It was no longer enough to hold her from behind. She wanted Agatha to bury close. She wanted to feel the heat of her breath against her skin. She wanted to hold on to the woman she couldn’t stand to be apart from.

The woman she now had to leave and see only when her manager deemed it safe enough that she could.

Sex had been the spark that had lit Rio’s stubborn flame of self-improvement. But fear was the fuel that began the inferno. As she tangled herself in Agatha, as she tucked her under her chin and held her close, she burned with the knowledge that she’d get better, she’d get stronger.

She’d protect the fuck out of Agatha Harkness and her son.

Chapter End Notes

I'm sure Rio looking after Nicky will be totally fine and nothing will happen

Chapter 44: Speak of the Devil…

Chapter Summary

A summoning

Chapter Notes

Idk why this has been the hardest chapter to write but I hope you enjoy

See the end of the chapter for more notes

Agatha didn’t say a word to Rio the whole of the next morning. Or, what little of it they spent together. She wasn’t in the bed by the time Rio woke and when she went downstairs to find her she was already in her office with Jen.

Alice was waiting in the kitchen.

“What’s happening?”

“Nothing. Nothing shout-worthy anyway.”

Rio cleared her throat in a “don’t start” way and Alice said, “We should go. She wanted you to stop by before you left. So be quick about it and we can head straight to set.”

Rio didn’t need to be told twice. She marched straight to Agatha’s office and didn’t hesitate to knock on the door. Jen opened it, looked Rio up and down in Agatha’s borrowed t-shirt and the shorts she’d found before she left the bedroom, and stepped aside.

Agatha was at her desk, her glasses on the tip of her nose, her blue eyes tired but bright. She looked up when Rio walked over and made to pull Rio in before she was even close.

Rio grinned, the bridge of her nose bumping the arm of Agatha’s glasses as she turned into her. The hug was too tight to truly be comfortable but she’d take this over nothing. In fact, she wouldn’t protest if she had the indent of Agatha’s glasses on her face the whole rest of the day.

“You’re pap fodder, Rio. Did Alice tell you they’re outside your house?”

Rio broke the hug and turned to Jen.

“What? No?”

“They’re curious,” Alice said by the door. “You disappeared off with Agatha and Wanda was caught out for dinner with Jess.”

Rio nodded silently, piecing the two bits of information together as she felt Agatha’s hand brush her side. “We’re going straight to set?”

“Yeah. Can bundle you in before anyone spots you.”

Rio nodded again, aware Agatha was now back behind her desk.

“Starting to feel like stolen goods.”

Agatha snorted.

“It’s just easier to keep you between here and set.”

“So,” Rio shifted on the spot, “I can stay here this week?”

“Well,” Jen sighed as she settled back in the chair the other side of Agatha’s desk. “I’ve just been threatened with being fired and then, very dramatically, being hanged, drawn, and quartered. Whatever that means.”

Rio smirked and looked around to Agatha who seemed to be busy trying to hide her own smirk as she shuffled around some papers.

“Babe,” Alice nudged, “Let’s go, come on.”

Rio swept in to briefly kiss Agatha’s cheek before she turned to follow her friend out, with a slight spring in her step.

“Your neck is a disaster zone, by the way,” Alice said without looking round to her as she held out her jacket for Rio to take. “She’s a menace.”

Rio didn’t acknowledge whether she thought Agatha were a menace or not but she did wrap her scarf securely around her neck to make sure no one else caught the evidence of Agatha’s jealous temper.

“I really would have liked to have seen Nicky before we left.”

“It’s five in the morning.”

“Still.”

“Relax. You’ll have every evening this week to see him. He was asking for you before bed last night, by the way. Did Agatha tell you? Wanted to stay up until you arrived.”

Rio raised her brows as she pulled the heavy wooden door shut behind her, watching Alice as she marched along the path with her duffel over her shoulder.

“Hideous watches, by the way. And I’m buying you a DNA kit for your birthday.”

Rio jogged a little to catch up. “What? Why?”

“That kid’s getting more and more like you. He spent thirty minutes talking to me about his new watch his ‘melliza’ bought for him. Drones on and on just like you do.”

“I don’t drone on and neither does he.”

“Whatever. The face thing is creepy.”

“It is not creepy. He just… I don’t know. It’s just a genetic fluke. Maybe Agatha’s got some Puerto Rican in there somewhere.”

“I could make a dirty joke but honestly I’m too tired. She’s as white as they come and Ralph is practically Aryan. That boy is yours. I’m convinced.”

They’d reached the car now and Rio rolled her eyes as she slipped into the passenger seat.

“You think I hid a pregnancy from you?”

“That or you donated eggs.”

“Jesus, Alice.”

“I’m just saying.”

Rio huffed and pulled the mirror down to check herself over. Jen had been right the night before, she did look like shit. And not only did she look like shit but she also looked like she’d been let loose in a Sorority House judging by the marks on her neck as she pulled the scarf down to check. Makeup and Hair would have their jobs cut out for them but she tried not to think of how embarrassing it would be to expose her neck to the team for now.

She had other things to think on: learning her sides for the day, knowing her marks, being on her very best and most careful behaviour so as not to draw attention to the fact that her girlfriend was Agatha Harkness.

Those things and she had to get better. She had to fuel her body and move it too.

It felt like a lot. But Agatha was worth a lot. She was worth everything.

Rio didn’t see Agatha again until she was caked in makeup and on set by mid-morning. They were in matching Christmas sweaters and Agatha looked somehow to be glowing. Rio could see her freckles when she was close and she wondered if she even had any makeup on at all.

Her own makeup artist had done a tolerable job on her but she couldn’t help but think she didn’t glow like Agatha. Maybe the lights would do her a favour. Maybe she could make friends with the Editor and ensure she looked better on camera than she did in real life.

Maybe she could offer to pay for that CGI facial retouching thing she’d heard some older actresses use.

“You’re staring,” Agatha whispered to her as they were being prepped for the scene.

Agatha was about three feet away, someone fluffing her hair, another person down by her ankles, adjusting her socks.

“I’m admiring.”

Agatha arched a brow, motioning a little to the people around her with her head. But Rio ignored the warning.

“Did you have breakfast?”

“A bagel.”

“Will you be having lunch in your trailer again?”

“I might try a run around the lot.”

Agatha raised her brows and looked around at her properly, ignoring the assistant now adjusting the sleeves of her sweater.

“Really?”

“Mmhm. Gotta get fit.”

Agatha’s lips twitched and Rio just grinned.

“Take it steady, hotshot.”

“Not really my style, Harkness, but I’ll do my best.”

Agatha’s eyes narrowed but Rio knew she couldn’t do anything else with people so close. Still, she grinned at her girlfriend, and for a moment enjoyed that Agatha seemed to be struggling with not screaming.

“Don’t,” she whispered, her jaw tight, “call me that.”

The people around her moved away when it was called for positions to be taken.

“Your name?”

“Are you trying to-…? Don’t.”

A runner came close and went to adjust Agatha’s collar. Agatha twitched away, smacking his hand as she did.

“Who are you?”

Rio watched as the fury she’d just sparked in Agatha was taken out on the young try-hard and she grimaced as it was.

“Sorry, only Frankie said to-…”

“Then Frankie can do it. Don’t just touch me.”

Rio shifted on the spot, unable to intervene without embarrassing either one of them. The runner blinked, looked to Rio briefly, then scurried away.

“Go easy on him. He’s just a kid.”

“He touched me.”

Rio raised her brows, looking back to a hard jawline and fierce eyes. “If someone touched you without your consent I’d destroy them.”

“Mi corazón.”

“A runner doing his job and touching your collar is different to-…”

“My husband groping you?”

Rio blinked but couldn’t find a word to say in response before Frankie appeared and muttered, “Go easy on the runners, Agatha. They’re quite literally run off their feet as it is.”

Agatha didn’t say anything but when Frankie moved on to adjust Rio’s rolled up sleeves Rio managed to smile at the woman. Inside she felt sick, a sudden panic rising despite the current calm of their surroundings - the kitchen set was decorated for a quaint family Christmas.

When they were alone again Rio said, “Tell me you’re not doing anything reckless because-…”

“I’m destroying him for it.”

“Agatha.”

Agatha cleared her throat as quiet was called for on set. Rio stepped an inch to the right and glanced at her mark, a little green t-shape on the ground just inches from the counter, which meant she couldn’t lean against it. Who did this blocking anyway? Her mind was blank suddenly and she looked up in a panic at the script supervisor just as action was called.

Too late. The scene had started.

“You’re too soft with him,” Agatha said, easily in character now. Rio turned to her and saw she no longer looked furious, she was instead all of Kate’s exasperation.

But Rio didn’t know what she was supposed to say.

So she said nothing.

“You’re too soft with him,” Agatha repeated, not breaking character but finding a way to give Rio a second.

“Dani,” Agatha tried again, “You’re too soft with him.”

“Cut!”

Rio jolted back to life and turned to see the script supervisor already rushing to her side. Agatha, noticeably to Rio, had not moved closer.

A cursory glance at the script was all it took for Rio to nod and thank the kindly woman who’d run to her aide. She stepped back and glanced at her mark again.

Maria was by the camera operator, talking about something Rio couldn’t hear. So Rio took the opportunity to look back around to Agatha and saw her staring at her own mark.

“Later,” Agatha whispered just as Maria was barking orders for the setup again.

This kiss would be seen all around the world.

Girlfriend to Agatha Harkness,

Melliza to Nicholas River Harkness,

Seven-time recipient of a public, recorded kiss from her girlfriend, and love of her life, Agatha.

Far from being lost in the murky depths of her brain, she was now floating above everything and everyone. But Rio’s job was done for the morning. She was allowed to go.

The only main cast member absent from the scene was little James, which meant the adults had free rein to shoot for the rafters with their performances. The scene was scheduled to be filmed over the next few days, with today mostly B-roll and blocking.

With Agatha being close not optional.

After she’d been kicked off her parents’ plan at the tender age of twenty six, Rio had relied on her SAG membership for Health Insurance. And now, a little older and also earning a little more, she could afford to have more regular check-ups, even the occasional physio appointment.

Emphasis on the occasional. Getting Rio to go to the Doctor was like getting Agatha to follow the instructions of her Director.

And then she saw the a sight too devastating to describe.

There it was. The simple fear Agatha kept repeating. The fear Rio knew she couldn’t make her forget by simply repeating she never would. The fear her mother had sowed into her from birth.

Rio could listen to the story of her beauty forever.

The more she looked, the more she craved. Agatha had been graced with it but Rio was blessed by it. It was a beatitude from a land far away, a time long since forgot.

Agatha was her blessing.

The hairline cracks appeared in the marble of Agatha’s face. She was trying to make herself smaller, trying to hide. But Rio couldn’t allow it, wouldn’t be witness to Agatha shutting herself away.

“Tell me why you’re afraid.”

“Forever is what we agreed. You can’t take it back now, okay? You can’t think that I don’t want it.”

After a while of soft kisses and whispered promises, Agatha calmed down enough to fall asleep in Rio’s arms. The two remained asleep until an alarm went off somewhere in the room.

 

TUESDAY

Morning brought a renewed strength to the two of them. Agatha, unburdened now with the tales of her past and the therapy she’d been having, and Rio, sure as all shit with what she needed to do.

Rio was gone again before Nicky woke but that morning, before Alice arrived, they kickstarted a new tradition that would last the rest of the week. They made out, slowly, languidly, all tangled together in the bed. Then against the wall. Then by the front door.

Rio only peeled away from her girlfriend to open the door for Alice and she only stopped thinking about the prospect of more minutes spent kissing her girlfriend when she had to focus in on her lines.

Rio mostly spent the day waiting around until she was needed for the the dinner party scene. It was the first time she’d seen Agatha since she’d had her tongue down her throat that morning.

And visions of pulling her into her lap and really giving the crew something to film filled her brain.

But she remained professional. She hit her cues, said her lines, managed to not focus entirely on the woman next to her. Plus, about an hour in to filming, James had arrived on set.

The young, energetic actor made a beeline for Rio and unfortunately for her, she spent the next two hours with him in her lap instead. It took him an hour to calm down and only then did filming get to really resume.

Agatha helped. She was best at calming him. Something about Rio’s energy riled him up so she was useless at tempering his behaviour.

When the day was done Agatha managed to grab her for all of two minutes to tell her she’d be late that night due to her filming schedule and her filming later. So Rio agreed to take over from Nicky’s nanny, to get him a healthy (she took this under advisement) dinner, and get him ready for bed.

She even managed to steal the quickest of quick kisses.

Her evening was much better than her afternoon. It turned out parenting was easy when your kid was Nicholas River Harkness. All he wanted to do was to play basketball, ask Rio questions she was happy to answer, and eat whatever she gave him.

And she gave him a reasonably cooked omelette with a side of broccoli.

He didn’t complain. Especially when the next course was ice cream.

Even when she called bedtime at eight, he happily went to brush his teeth and change into his pyjamas. His only request was that Rio read to him. So she did.

And that’s how Agatha found them just after nine, both fast asleep on the bed, both with their faces turned to the side with their left arms flung above them. Rio with an open book about dinosaurs on her stomach.

Agatha tucked Nicky in and kissed his temple before she went around to softly nudge Rio awake. Rio grumbled some but soon followed Agatha out the room and yawned as she pulled the door to behind her.

“What time is it?”

“Time for me to fall asleep on you.”

“Hmm? How did it go?”

Agatha was already walking away from her. “I don’t want to talk tonight. I just want to sleep.”

Rio frowned some as she followed Agatha into her bedroom. She waited for her on the bed as Agatha went to brush her teeth and change into a pair of sleep shorts and Rio’s cowboy shirt.

“Mi amor? What happened?”

“I’m tired, Rio. Come to bed.”

Rio sighed but went to brush her own teeth and came back out soon enough. She simply slipped out of her sweats but kept her sweater on, already not wearing a bra. Agatha was waiting for her in the middle of the bed and the moment she got in Agatha was on top of her already.

Her familiar weight helped to calm Rio’s worries but she held her close regardless. Agatha said nothing for a while and then: “You were asleep in the same pose. Both with your arms up. Both with your mouths open.”

“My mouth was not open.”

“Mm.”

Rio sighed and kissed the top of Agatha’s head. “Do you want to talk about therapy?”

“Not tonight.”

Agatha’s hand curled around her collar and Rio felt a flash of anxiety run through her at the simple gesture.

“I love you,” Agatha breathed quietly into Rio’s chest, making the anxiety fan into a flame that engulfed Rio’s entire body. But she whispered it back.

Agatha fell asleep. Rio did too, a long time after, her head to the side, her mouth open.

 

WEDNESDAY

The day started how days now would. After they were both minty fresh, they piled back into the bed and lost themselves in each other’s mouths. Rio had Agatha up against the door again when Alice knocked.

This time she’d made it as far as her hands beneath Agatha’s shirt, but for the most part it was chaste. They hadn’t even reached second base.

And Wednesday went much like Tuesday had. Only Rio squeezed in a run before she had to be on set. And found that the exercise helped with her anxiety more than ever.

Agatha still hadn’t spoken to her about what had happened in Therapy.

James was there again, for a longer period, on and off, because he was still little. But he was with Rio mostly, with her at the table. By her side, in her lap, shouting in her ear between takes.

Agatha did all she could to help.

But Rio couldn’t help but be reminded of how different this kid was to Nicky. How much she had enjoyed spending the evening one on one with Agatha’s son.

She didn’t get a chance to talk to Agatha about her desire to remain silent about therapy the night before but she remained so distracted all day by little James and Agatha’s constant, secret touches, that she almost didn’t worry about it at all.

By the time it was evening again and Rio arrived at Agatha’s house only five minutes after Agatha, the worries were back.

She played with Nicky until it was time for dinner - a much more delicious pasta compared with the omelette from the previous night. And then it was time to crash on the couch. Only this time Agatha had calls to take in her office.

So only dos patitos watched 101 Dalmations.

“She’s a bit like grandmother.”

Rio raised her brows and turned to Nicky in surprise. “Cruella?”

Nicky looked shy suddenly, like he shouldn’t have said it.

“A little.”

Rio hummed, trying to think of a way to not call Evanora a raging bitch who she could totally see would skin puppies. She couldn’t think of anything so said nothing. Soon Nicky had made his way over to her and she instead tucked him under her arm, only hoping he knew that he’d be safe from any Cruellas with her.

That night Agatha didn’t want to talk about therapy again. They made out and Rio hit second base and she stayed there until they fell asleep.

 

THURSDAY

She barely spent the requisite two minutes brushing her teeth and instead did a cursory once over, just to be polite, before she had Agatha up on the counter, both still holding their toothbrushes.

“Good,” Agatha repeated, finishing her word with a kiss to Rio’s nose. “And tell her I send my best.”

“I’ll tell her you’re withholding sex.”

“Please don’t.”

Rio huffed again but Agatha was pushing her back now, sliding down onto the ground again.

“Alice will be here soon.”

But Alice arrived and their day began properly.

James was a pain in the ass again, clinging and jumping and shouting. Even Agatha couldn’t tame him and their only respite was when he was taken off set due to the god sent miracle of child labour laws.

But their dinner party scene was a complicated one, with lots of moving parts, lots of food, forks, and fraught energy between the characters. The one win for her day was that Rio could keep her hand on Agatha’s thigh, they were married after all.

Rio did call her mom though, on her way to Agatha’s in the car with Alice. Her mom was as pleased as she always was to hear from her, and this time they discussed the family for only five minutes and spent another ten talking about Miguel.

It was nice. It felt easier than she thought it might.

At dinner they ate at the table, an unfussy chicken salad, accompanied by well-deserved wine for Agatha and Rio, and a milkshake for Nicky. Agatha came to fetch her as she had before and in leaving, Rio saw on her watch that it was midnight. She sighed as she placed it down on the side, worried for Agatha’s late night and secretive hours spent in her office.

“How is everything going?”

“Mm? Fine.”

“How are you feeling about Saturday?”

“Fine.”

“You don’t want to talk about it?”

Agatha shook her head against the pillow and Rio tried: “What you said about Ralph the other day, about destroying him because-…”

“I’d have destroyed him either way. I’ll just take more pleasure out of it because of what he did to you.”

Rio smiled sadly, deciding to let the topic lie and instead changing it: “I was thinking of taking Nicky to the park? There’s a small one off Riverside. I think we’d be secluded enough that-…”

“If they find us, Rio. If they find us, it won’t be a few paps sitting outside your house. It’ll be every paper and online publication the world over with vans and-…”

Rio shifted in the bed, tugging Agatha that much closer. “You know I will.”

“Look at Boston. Look at what happened there. You were swarmed and no one was around to help. That guy didn’t even turn up.”

“My love,” Agatha whispered, softening when Rio was beginning to show signs of panic. “I promise you we’ll be safe.”

“You only feel safe with me.”

“We’re tres patitos,” Agatha murmured, and attempt to soothe, now brushing her fingers delicately through Rio’s hair as Rio fought the shiver that threatened her body as her adrenaline kicked in.

Rio shook her head and Agatha smiled sadly, “Please. Just this once. Just one night. I’ll call you all day Sunday, let you know we’re fine.”

Rio shivered, Agatha changed her hold on her, rolling them over until she was above her. She began to kiss over her face, and Rio clung to her as she felt the first of Agatha’s tears. But neither of them said anything and soon Agatha’s kisses had settled against her throat, soft and tender.

Rio fell asleep first this time. Her body shivered as she slept and Agatha tried to keep her warm but knew it was nothing to do with heat.

On Friday both Agatha and Rio slept in. At least, they only woke up when Alice called Agatha and her cell vibrated obnoxiously on the bedside table.

In the hurry for Rio to leave, they missed their typical makeup session but Agatha managed to kiss Rio goodbye, to hold her close before she inevitably had to let go.

Rio hadn’t been in trouble with Alice, which was weird. Alice had instead seemed a little more tense and explained only when they were halfway to the set.

“Jen and I aren’t speaking.”

“What happened?”

“We had a fight about you two.”

Rio raised her browns and decided turning to focus on the road was a better idea than staring at her friend’s tense side-profile.

“Let me guess,” Rio said bitterly, “she thinks I’m going to fuck Agatha over.”

“No,” Alice said with a scoff, “she thinks Agatha’s going to fuck herself.”

Rio turned back then and raised her brows once more, “What does that-…?”

Alice sighed and flipped someone off who tried to overtake too close. “She thinks she’s not thinking straight and is more focused on you than-…”

“Agatha is putting Nicky first. We’ve discussed it. Everything is about keeping custody of Nicky.”

Alice just shook her head and after a second muttered, “I told her that. She’s just worried and I… I’m being stubborn.”

“Why?”

“Imagine all Agatha spoke about was Jen.”

Rio shook her head and sighed, looking down her her hands in her lap. “Alice, it’ll be hard for a while but-…”

“I want to propose but I’m putting it off because… well because of all this shit.”

Rio, a person who once had been privy to all of Alice’s decisions before she’d even considered them decisions, was taken aback by this. And, if she could admit it to herself, a little hurt.

“Have you bought a ring?”

“Not yet, I have been saving and-…”

“Do you need a salary increase? I can-…”

“Jesus, Rio. No. Listen to me. I’m saving, I have the cash, I just want to go with my best friend to a store and not have the world looking or following or-…” She sighed heavily, and Rio saw in Alice for the first time something that she’d been missing for weeks.

Alice was as broken as she was.

She reached for her friend and wrapped her fingers around her wrist. “I’m going to have my mom come visit soon. Will you stay with us?”

Alice’s tense little body relaxed an inch or two and her eyes softened, moving from the road briefly to meet Rio’s gaze. She nodded, her lips twitching into the affirmative but not making any sound.

Rio held her for the rest of the drive.

When they stopped she said, “Jen’s a lucky lady, you know.”

“Shut up.”

Rio was shoved away and the gentle comfort that had settled in the little car dissolved as Alice began to bully Rio out of the door, making her bark her laughter and nearby crew all turn to see.

The day got better from there. Rio and Alice found a way to behave like normal friends might and neither of them bought up Agatha or Jen. Neither of them brought up how much they missed Miguel.

Filming went as smoothly as it could have gone that day. James kept making appearances between his tutoring and down time. Rio was “mama Rio” and was soon partially deaf in one ear because of that fact.

But Agatha was close, Agatha was her wife for the day. Pretend or not, it was nice to call her that.

Agatha had calls to make anyway.

“Both still awake?”

Rio hummed as she placed the book on the side and then grunted when Nicky threw his covers and himself over her.

“Sleeping, actually.”

“Buenas noches, mellizo.”
