“Argue about dinosaurs?”

“No, be together.”

Rio smiled and shuffled down so they could be face to face. She went to say something, something loving, something patient, something kind, but found words failed her as she drowned in deep blue.

When they fell asleep, they both dreamed of a time where they could read about dinosaurs every night and fall asleep, just like this, in each others arms.

 

SATURDAY

As if to make up for the fact that they’d barely kissed the day before, not five minutes after waking and barely bothering to brush her teeth, Rio was back on top of Agatha, pressing her up against the bathroom wall.

She’d decide the countertop was too dangerous.

But Agatha’s wrists were being held up against the wall so firmly that she’d dropped her toothbrush and it now lay destined for the trash by their feet.

The kiss today was furious, more feverish than it had been all week. Which meant it was dangerous too. Rio knew she wouldn’t be seeing Agatha until later and even then she wouldn’t have time alone with her. So she tried to put all she could into the kiss, trying to let Agatha know she was already feeling stronger, already healthier, already ready to protect her and her son.

Agatha moaned into Rio’s mouth as she arched against her and Rio soon introduced teeth where she’d previously only been using lips and tongue. It made Agatha protest, made her tug until Rio relented and she could use her hands to push Rio away.

She felt feral, like a rabid dog denied its treat.

All she wanted was Agatha, and yet, Agatha was everything she couldn’t have.

“No. Not-… not yet. Not today. I need… I have to think straight.”

Rio turned from her, running hers fingers through her hair and taking in a big, hopefully soothing breath. And then Agatha’s hands were sliding across her front, she was holding her the way she had when she’d held her for the first time.

On a jet ski in the Mediterranean Sea.

Her body reacted now how it had reacted then: she was on fire.

Agatha kissed along her neck until she pressed her face in against her shoulder and Rio held over her hands and looked at the two of them in the mirror.

“I’m scared.”

“I know.”

“Can you wear your shirt today? I’ll need it tonight.”

Rio closed her eyes, unable to see the sight before her anymore when she knew she’d need to leave Agatha and Nicky all alone, at the mercy of the world’s media.

“Mi vida.”

“Please, just, say you’ll wear it.”

Rio nodded and sighed out as Agatha moved slowly around her, finding her lips again in a soft kiss.

“I should go get Nicky up. I need to be at the lawyer’s office early. Will you have him up at the house by four? You have the address?”

Rio nodded, her eyes still closed until Agatha nudged their noses together and she fluttered her lashes until they were open, knowing what Agatha had been silently asking.

“I love you,” Rio whispered, watching the way Agatha’s sea blue eyes seemed to swirl with unshed emotion. “I can’t wait to start our lives together.”

Agatha’s face, carved from marble, was warm to the touch. Her cheeks were flushed still, her eyes soft, “Tell me one more time. Please. I need to hear you say it.”

“Para siempre, mi corazón. Te amo.” Forever, my heart. I love you.

Agatha’s head ducked in the briefest of nods and then she kissed Rio again and against her lips she promised: “Forever. I love you too.”

It was hard to leave the little bathroom after that. But Agatha needed to say goodbye to Nicky and they both needed to start their days.

Down the stairs, both of them now dressed, Agatha in a casual yet smart pantsuit, and Rio in jeans and her shirt, they fussed around Nicky, making sure he was as happy as he could be.

Agatha told him to be good for Rio but Rio really didn’t think there was any other way he could be for her. She told him she’d packed a bag for him of all his most precious things and that she’d see him later that evening in their new house. She told him to do everything Rio said and to not leave her side.

She told him she loved him more than anything and would see him soon. And then she hugged him and Rio had to look away for fear she’d be unable to hide the emotion in her face.

But Agatha was soon hugging her and Rio sighed out, forgetting herself briefly and pressing her lips for too long against her cheek. But Agatha didn’t pull away. She held her close and only stepped back when Rio loosened her hold first.

They made eye contact and though they didn’t say it, Rio knew Agatha felt it. She loved her beyond words.

Her thumb had been rubbing over and over Agatha’s fingers of her right hand, holding them loosely, reluctant to let go but not brave enough to cling on. She looked down at the motion and held Agatha’s hand between them as her thumb found a new ring on Agatha’s finger.

“I can’t wear the diamond,” Agatha said softly, knowing Rio’s question before she asked it. “This is the wedding band. Only on my right hand because-…”

“Because it’s a pretend one but only for now.”

Agatha nodded once and Rio looked up and smiled sadly, unable to stop herself from pulling Agatha back in for a tight hug. She was crinkling her suit but that didn’t matter. Holding her close was more important that proof she owned an iron - or her housekeeper did.

But Rio had to let Agatha go.

And Agatha left with her own bag of precious things after kissing Nicky one last time and then it was just them, dos patitos, and the whole day ahead of them. Rio had already fixed her face into a smile and moved around to steal one of Nicky’s toast soldiers from his plate by the time the door closed on Agatha.

“So. I was thinking… we spend all day in the park, we come back here, we grab your bag, head out for burgers, then head to the new house? How does that sound?”

Rio had never seen Nicky so happy. So happy, in fact, that she was able to steal another soldier.

“Yes!! Yes that sounds like the best plan ever!”

Rio laughed, biting into the soldier like an old King might his turkey leg. “Excellent because I’d have been very upset if you’d have said no to basketball and burgers.”

“Can we get milkshakes too?”

“And ice cream.”

It was quite difficult to make Nicky eat the rest of his breakfast before it got cold then. The rapid fire questions that came Rio’s way made her pour herself a larger coffee, for fear he’d tired her out before they even got to the park.

But somehow, they made it.

Rio had kept true to her word and kept her shirt on for Agatha, hoping she wouldn’t get too sweaty in it and secretly hoping even then Agatha wouldn’t mind. Or maybe that she’d prefer it.

Nicky had opted for his Celtics jersey, or, more accurately, Rio’s old Celtics jersey. The one that was too big for him. The one that he basically hadn’t taken off since he’d borrowed it from Rio the first time they met.

But Rio insisted he also wore a sweater. She did, however, allow him to have it partially open so people could see the green of his jersey. Though she neglected to point out that people could already see the bottom of it sticking below the hem of the sweater, as big as it was.

As a finishing touch, he also put on Rio’s Celtics hat, just to really show the world who his favourite team was.

In the meantime, Rio had packed a bag full of snacks and water and grabbed a basketball from outside.

So, making sure to lock the door and then the gate behind them, Rio and her little mellizo, stepped out into the sunshine hand in hand, with Nicky still chatting away happily and Rio still answering as best she could.

Everything changed as soon as they were in the car.

Rio had helped to strap Nicky in, not because she thought he couldn’t do it himself but because she wanted to make sure Agatha’s son was as safe as safe could be.

But that was when she realised that her little hybrid wasn’t the safest place for him.

Agatha had been right all those weeks ago. Her car was too small, too unsafe.

She felt sick suddenly.

Fuck fuck fuck, Rio thought the moment she’d started the engine of her little hybrid. This car was a death trap. It was so small and so obviously not suitable to transport her precious cargo anywhere.

She was going to kill Agatha’s son.

She broke out into a cold sweat as Nicky swung his legs and continued to talk about basketball.

Managing to respond but not really thinking about anything other than what an idiot she was for sending back Agatha’s gift of a big, sturdy, admittedly garish, car, she kept her focus on the road.

Clearly her responses weren’t good enough.

“What’s wrong, melliza?”

“Oh. Um. Nothing. I’m just… just trying to get us there safely.”

“Am I talking too much?”

“No, baby. Never. Sorry. I. Sorry.”

“It’s okay, we can be quiet.”

Rio chewed on her lip and kept her eyes on the road. She was a good driver, always had been. She was conscientious and deliberate. Her reactions were fast and she never went too fast or too slow.

There was no reason to think she’d crash when she never had before. She’d not so much as dented her car.

She took a breath and quietly asked: “Are you excited about the park?”

Nicky turned to her and grinned and for the first time Rio, briefly, took her eyes off the road. His smile relaxed her.

“Yes! We have so far to go to hit infinity.”

Rio nodded and forced herself to relax. Nicky was safe with her. She was a good driver. She would keep him safe. He would be returned to Agatha in one piece.

She’d promised Agatha she’d keep her son safe. She kept her promises.

Nicky was soon spouting off again, the shy little boy he was in company completely missing now he was on a roll with his favourite person. Even Rio’s softer responses, the way she wouldn’t look at him and kept her eyes on the road, didn’t seem to phase him.

He was simply happy to be there.

And Rio would only be happy once she’d trashed this damn car and bought a new one. A big one. An expensive, full of mod-cons, gas-guzzler that would keep Nicky safe. She could think of nothing else until they were parked up safely and Agatha’s son was back on solid ground.

Rio couldn’t help it when she checked him over briefly, wondering if she’d taken the last few corners too sharply and without knowing it had thrown Nicky about when actually he’d been very secure in his seat.

Nicky blinked up at her, allowing the check with a shy smile.

“You okay, melliza? You look upset.”

“I’m okay. I’m just… just making sure you’re okay.”

Nicky frowned as his smile faded, his eyes scanning over Rio’s face for a while before he said: “Melliza? What’s wrong?”

Rio bit down in her lip and paused where she’d been adjusting Nicky’s zipper on his sweater, tugging it up a little to protect from the cold and then down again so he didn’t overheat.

“I just want to make sure you’re okay.”

Nicky placed his hand over her own and made her stop. “Mama said you might worry.”

“She did?”

“Well, she told me last night,” Nicky shifted on the spot, “but I wasn’t supposed to tell you that.”

Rio’s lips twitched a little, “I won’t tell her you did.”

“Okay,” Nicky said softly, “only she said you might worry a little today and I was to be on my best behaviour for you so you don’t worry too much.”

“Is that right?”

Nicky was getting into it now, nodding his head enthusiastically as he said: “Yes and she said that I was to tell you that we are dos patitos today and we will have the best time and that I feel safe with you. Safe and happy.” He frowned as Rio smiled, “Seguro y feliz.”

He grinned when he remembered the words Agatha had taught him and Rio grinned right back at him, her heart rate hammering in her chest now for different reasons.

“Okay, mellizo. I guess if your mama says so then we will have the best time.”

“She is very smart.”

“Very smart.”

Nicky rocked up onto the balls of his feet and Rio straightened, taking his hand as she did.

Rio marched them away towards the empty basketball court and sat them both down on the mini bleachers set up to the side. The space around them was quiet, the sun was getting higher in the sky, though the air was cooler than usual for mid-March.

With her free hand she began to rummage in the tote bag for the cereal bars she’d packed earlier and when she found them she turned to pass one to Nicky and saw him measuring up his hand against Rio’s palm.

“One day your hand will be much bigger than mine.”

Nicky grinned up at her and filled the spaces between Rio’s fingers with his own, “But you’ll still hold my hand?”

“Oh I don’t think you’ll want me to.”

“No I always will! It’s soft and warm and it’s nice.”

Rio hummed and motioned for Nicky to take the offered bar. “For energy. We have a lot of points to get to infinity.”

Nicky decided holding her hand could wait in exchange for having enough energy to reach infinity. Rio smiled as he tucked into it and turned her gaze to the quiet surroundings, taking a bite of her own bar.

They ate in silence for two bites worth of the surprisingly delicious peanut butter flavoured bar until Nicky said something that was equally as surprising.

“My mama told me something else, melliza. Well, I told her something, I asked her something and she said that… she said I should tell you I love you.”

Rio almost choked.

Nicky patted her back in a manner that wouldn’t have made any difference at all if she had.

“She-…” Rio coughed, “She did?”

“Mama says it’s important to tell people you love them and… and also I think it’s nice to say so, I wanted to say it. My mama tells me everyday and I like it. So maybe you would like to hear it too. Because I do, I… so I wanted to say but I got nervous and mama said it would be okay.”

Rio nodded slowly, turning to the little boy with the big eyes and the hopeful grin. She opened her arm out and accepted him into a hug. Against his growing hair she whispered, “Yo también te amo, mellizo. Hasta el infinito.”

“Hasta el…?”

“Infinito. It means to infinity.”

Nicky nodded against her head and sighed out dramatically, “Hasta el infinito.”

“You sound upset, mellizo.”

“I just wish I’d said it sooner so then every night this week we could have said it.”

Rio placed her cereal bar down and held Nicky in a proper hug, “Then how about we promise to say it every day from now on?”

Nicky nodded again, “Okay, I’d like that.”

Rio hummed and gave Nicky a tight squeeze. Her gaze fell to a distant soccer game across the way and she lost herself in the sight of the tiny figures running about the place, surely having as good a time as she currently was. And all she was doing was sitting, holding her mellizo, knowing he loved her.

“Seguro y feliz,” Nicky whispered, “Dos patitos. Seguro y feliz.”

Rio turned her head and pressed a kiss to Nicky’s temple. “Dos patitos.”

The little boy in her arms pulled back and smiled his brilliant smile at her, dazzling her for a second. He placed a clumsy kiss to her cheek and Rio laughed, “Okay, okay, what about basketball? Are you ready to play?!”

Nicky grinned then and Rio laughed again as she stood with him and dragged him down to the court with the basketball from the car. She left behind their snacks and water for later on the bleachers.

On the court, with Nicky giggling and shouting, she wondered why she’d even been scared in the first place. They had the whole space to themselves, no paps, no fans, no one to have to protect Nicky from.

And for a while it was blissful.

Dos patitos running like wild animals around the deserted court. Rio could feel the pull of her body to the exercise. She could feel the rush of endorphins that came sooner now than they had been all week.

She’d been eating well, barely drinking, and she’d been sleeping better. Not to mention the calorie-killing make out sessions she’d been having.

She could feel that she was getting back to health again, less weak, sharper, more attuned to her body and her mind.

The first portion of their game lasted over an hour, then they stopped for water and snacks over at the bleachers. There were a few more people around now, a couple cars parked up. But no one was much interested in a woman and a child running like crazy people around a basketball court.

So Rio and Nicky sat happily with their snacks, blissed out still and unbothered by anyone near by.

Across the dusty little court there was someone with red hair leaning over her knees on the opposite bleachers, tapping away on her phone. But she was the closest person to them and she wasn’t a threat.

Rio had made sure to pack some fruit as well as the other chocolate and candy in the bag for fear Agatha might kill her for sending Nicky to the dentist with cavities. But the fruit got ignored because they both preferred the chocolate and Agatha wasn’t around to enforce the law.

Once refreshed they ran back onto the court and continued their quest to hit infinity points.

Play lasted for over an hour this time and even Rio was feeling the pangs of exhaustion and thirst as she shot the last hoop and bounced the ball back to Nicky.

“Time out, two secs. Give me your sweater, you must be so warm.”

She helped him shrug it off and swept his hair back from his brow, checking he wasn’t overheating after running around full pelt for so long.

“I’ll grab some water and some candy bars, okay? Keep practicing your jump shots.”

With a heavy, exhausted exhale, she turned from him and walked back to the side of the court and the bleachers. Placing Nicky’s now folded sweater down beside the bag, she first fished out her bottle and took a large, necessary gulp of water.

She could feel it trickle down her throat, and settle in her stomach. Perhaps she’d over-egged the feeling better a little. She took another mouthful and then grabbed Nicky’s and two chocolate bars from the bag, only feeling a little guilty that the apples in the bottom remained untouched.

And then she turned.

And her stomach dropped.

The red head from the opposite bleachers was now standing in the middle of the court with Nicky, bending down to get on his eye level.

Rio dropped everything in her arms and sprinted to his side, immediately pulling the little boy behind her.

Nicky gasped as he clung to her.

“Melliza!”

“Who the fuck are you and why are you talking to my kid?”

“Oh,” the woman straightened up. She was shorter than Rio by a few inches but was smirking as she looked her over, her eyes briefly flitting to Nicky peaking out from behind Rio’s hip. “I just wanted to say hello.”

Rio’s whole body felt hotter than it had felt even when she’d been tearing up the court earlier. She could feel her muscles tensing beneath her skin, either ready to fight or to run. But the woman before her seemed at ease, completely oblivious to Rio’s distress and the confusion of the little boy still hiding behind her.

The basketball had long since been forgotten and Nicky had his arms around Rio instead.

“Are you a journalist?”

“No,” the woman uttered, a vague look of amusement in her green eyes, “just a fan. I truly mean no harm.”

Her voice was sultry, pillow soft, and she looked Rio over again in a way that let Rio know she was coming on to her, or trying to, even with Nicky currently clutching at her. She sneered and took a step back, making Nicky take one too.

“You really don’t need to be worried.”

“You approached my kid and decided that-…”

“We were just getting to know one another, weren’t we, Nicky?” She looked back up at Rio and smiled, “I’m Natalie. I promise I mean no harm.”

“Melliza,” Nicky whispered, making Rio tilt her head slightly towards him but not taking her eyes off of the stranger. “She said she was a friend not, not a fan. Melliza she’s lying… Y-you’re lying!”

Nicky added the last part in a shout, leaning around Rio to look up at the woman who seemed absolutely nonplussed by the accusation. She simply raised her brows and looked expectantly up at Rio.

“Cute.”

Rio knew danger when she saw it. The woman had been watching them. She’d been waiting.

She’d lied to Nicky.

She didn’t waste another second.

She turned, gently prying Nicky off of her and ushering him ahead, keeping him out of view of the smirking stranger.

“Let’s go. Now. Quick.”

Nicky hurried along ahead of her but Rio wasn’t moving fast enough. She started to run, ushering Nicky along as quickly as she could.

“Nice to meet you, Rio Vidal. Drive safe now.”

If Nicky hadn’t been there, or if Rio could have handed him over to Agatha in that moment, she’d have turned around and smacked the bitch. But he was here. Agatha wasn’t. So she didn’t. She just ran with him, got to her car, helped him into his seat and ignored his panicked questioning.

“Melliza? Melliza? Did I-…? Did I do something w-wrong?”

When he was strapped in, and Rio checked three times that he was, she jumped in the driver’s seat, turning only once to see the woman still standing there, now simply watching them from the centre of the court.

Rio put the keys in the ignition and pulled out of the parking lot.

“M-melliza?”

“You’re okay, baby. We’re okay. We’re okay.”

“She said-… She said you were her friend a-and I didn’t say anything to her, she already knew my name a-and she said she liked my hat a-and-…”

“It’s okay, mellizo. It’s okay. You did nothing wrong. Nothing at all.”

Nicky beside her was digging his fists into his eyes and Rio looked around in horror at the sight of him hiding his face below the peak of his cap.

“Nicky, I mean, I mean, mellizo. Baby. Please don’t cry. It wasn’t your fault. I shouldn’t have, fuck, I shouldn’t have left you and she shouldn’t have approached you.”

Rio smacked her horn, and growled in frustration. The very thing she’d promised Agatha and Nicky she could do she clearly couldn’t. She was inept, incompetent, immature.

And then a hand wrapped around her arm and Rio took a breath before she glanced at Nicky and saw in his face that he didn’t think any of those things. He still loved her. To infinity.

“Melliza?” He asked softly, his wide eyes watery, “Please don’t be sad. O-or angry. Can I have-… can we stop please? Can we? Please?”

Rio just swallowed, her throat feeling tight all of a sudden. She drove on a little further to put more distance between them and the stranger but soon pulled in along the next side street and parked up. Without saying anything she hopped out of the car and went around to Nicky’s side.

He’d already freed himself from his seatbelt by the time she got to him. He flung his arms around her neck and she did the same around his middle.

He was safe. He was unharmed. She’d kept him safe.

Nicky clung to her for more than five minutes, making her shoulder damp, but she couldn’t care about anything other than him being safe in her arms.

“I’m sorry, melliza.” He hiccuped softly, sniffing. “I thought I was doing the right thing. Mama says don’t talk to strangers a-and I don’t but she knew you a-and my name and said she was a friend a-and so I didn’t run because I-…”

“Shh,” Rio rushed out, rubbing soothing circles along Nicky’s back, “It’s okay. It’s okay. I shouldn’t have left you. I’m so sorry, Nicky.”

“M-mellizo,” Nicky corrected with a sniff, now pulling back and frowning where he looked down at the mess he’d made on Rio’s shirt. “It’s okay, you protected me. You took me away from the lady and I’m safe now. We’re both safe now. I-I-I want you to be safe with me too.”

He began to cry again and Rio pulled him right back in, holding him so fiercely she worried she might be hurting him. But he didn’t protest, he just cried quietly against her until all that was left were soft sniffles and gentle hiccups.

Rio continued to rub his back, trying to think back on how long she’d left him, how long he’d been vulnerable and exposed for. How angry Agatha would be when she told her.

But she’d endure Agatha’s wrath. Because Nicky was safe. That was all that mattered.

“Some people,” Rio said as softly as she could, not wanting Nicky to feel like he was in any trouble, “some people will know your name, and my name too, and your mama’s, and even if they say they’re friends it doesn’t mean they are okay, mi angel?”

Nicky just nodded against her, “Mama said so too. She says all the time. I forgot. I forgot.”

“I know, baby. It can be confusing. It’s okay. It’s okay.”

Only when Nicky’s sniffing had died down enough, only when he was holding onto her instead of clutching, did Rio pull back again. She gently removed his hat and wiped over his face until it was as dry as she could make it and she held him up to look her in the eye.

He smiled weakly and Rio smiled the same.

“Let’s go grab your bag and get you to the new house.”

“Okay, melliza. That… sounds good. You’re not mad?”

“Never mad at you.”

Nicky nodded and Rio jumped into the car with him again. She checked his seatbelt three times once more and then put the keys in the ignition. The drive back was somehow less tense than the drive to the basketball court.

Perhaps because the big bad had happened. Perhaps because nothing else could possibly go wrong.

Perhaps because Nicky’s hand was holding her arm.

She parked up outside Agatha’s house and took in a deep breath. Nicky’s hand moved to her own on the wheel. She turned to him and he smiled, his cheeks a little pink from the earlier tears.

“You okay, melliza?”

“Are you okay, mellizo?”

Nicky nodded and Rio nodded too. She squeezed his hand and then released it so she could jump out and run around to get Nicky’s door. His seatbelt was already undone again and Nicky launched himself into Rio’s arms.

It was a desperate hug, a drier one than before. But Rio heaved him out of the car and held him as close as possible before she dropped him gently down again.

But away from Rio’s arms, out of the car, Nicky was tense again. This little boy couldn’t have been more different than the little boy he’d been before Rio had been an idiot. His little hand wasn’t holding hers anymore, it was clutching. He was squeezing the life out of it and she didn’t even know if he realised.

But Rio made long, fast strides towards Agatha’s house, making Nicky run alongside her to keep up. Inside was safe. Inside meant that no one would come to try and talk to the boy she’d been asked to look after for the day.

The boy who she’d left alone for all of ten seconds and had suddenly been approached by a stranger. She should have known. She should have done better.

They made it through the gate after Rio tapped in the code and Rio already felt herself begin to calm. But Nicky’s hold remained secure.

“Okay, kid,” she uttered in as calm a voice as she could, “Grab your bag and we’ll head back to the new house, okay? You excited?”

“Yeah, melliza.”

Nicky’s voice was quiet still, and Rio stopped before they got to the front door. She turned him to face her and dropped to one knee before him. “Baby, what happened in the park, it wasn’t your fault, okay? That lady shouldn’t have approached you. I’m sorry you got scared. You did nothing wrong. So, let’s head in, grab your bag, and then we’ll get burgers and ice cream, okay?”

Rio held Nicky’s sides and smiled hopefully up at the little boy who’s frown was slowly morphing into a shy smile. “You’re still not mad?”

“At you? Never.”

Nicky nodded and Rio smiled a little more, “So? Burgers and ice cream?”

“And movies?”

“And movies.”

Nicky nodded and his shy smile became a pleased grin as he launched himself at Rio and she grunted and then lifted him into the air with an exaggerated groan that made Nicky giggle.

He didn’t feel as heavy as he’d felt a week ago and just as Rio was wondering whether she was stronger now or if the emotions of the day had fuelled her body the door beside them opened.

Rio span with an expectant grin. Because who else but Agatha would be opening her own door?

Only it wasn’t Agatha.

It was the person Rio despised more than anyone else in the world. The person who'd tried to destroy her vida, who'd cut her mellizo's hair.

It was Evanora Harkness.

Chapter End Notes

I know people will ask so yes we will find out what Agatha discussed in therapy and why she won't tell Rio about it

as always thank you so much for reading

Chapter 45: …And She Shall Appear

Chapter Summary

Rio meets Agatha’s mother

Chapter Notes

Just a short, easy read for you

See the end of the chapter for more notes

A chill ran through Rio’s basketball-warmed body.

Of all the people in all the world, she hadn’t expected her. Agatha, yes. Her housekeeper? Maybe. Jen? Potentially. Even Alice wouldn’t have been as big a shock.

Hell, even Wanda wouldn’t have been as surprising.

But then, if the few Psych classes she took in College could have told her anything it was that abusers, narcissists, they thrived on their victim’s misery. Perhaps Evanora could just feel Agatha’s stress and fear and she simply manifested here, ready to feed off of it.

Rio had to shake her brain, had to make herself focus. Because it didn’t matter why she was here. It mattered that she was and that Nicky, who’d just relaxed, who’d just thrown himself at Rio, excited for burgers and ice cream and movies, was now tense and frightened in her arms.

Nicky was all that mattered.

The little boy adjusted himself in her hold to look over his shoulder just as Evanora said: “Nicholas. Come inside. Now.”

Rio’s grip on Nicky tightened and she stepped back, stumbling slightly as she fell down the small step of the porch. She managed to stand tall, to keep Nicky in her arms.

The witch before her just stared at her grandson, refusing to meet Rio’s shocked gaze.

She was tall, perhaps an inch taller than Agatha, so not as tall as Rio. Her long silvery hair was piled in a neat bun on top of her head. She was beautiful, there was no doubt about it. But sharp, her features all inclined to the dangerous, rather than the welcoming.

Agatha’s beauty was different. Completely so.

And Rio realised in an instant that, just like Nicky was nothing like his father, Agatha was nothing like her mother.

“Nicholas,” Evanora repeated, “I will not ask again. Get away from this woman.”

Evanora held out a bony hand towards them and Rio stepped back again.

Whether real or imagined Rio felt like she could feel Nicky’s heart hammering against her chest but she didn’t let go. She didn’t even loosen her hold.

She’d hold him forever, risk her muscles atrophying in this position just to keep him away from this woman.

And Nicky didn’t let go either.

His left arm, wrapped around her neck for leverage, adjusted so his fingers could bury in her short hair, tangling himself to her. It reminded Rio of what this woman had done to this little boy, of why he was currently growing his hair out. She held Nicky closer.

“Grandmother,” Nicky said quietly, “this is Rio. My… melliza.”

“Está bien, mellizo,” Rio murmured, speaking her dad’s language in a reflex, the words soothing just in the speaking of them, to her at least. She hoped Nicky understood, hoped he took comfort too in the language that she always returned to, the words that took her home.

Nicky turned to her. His cap was touching her forehead he was so close. She could feel his warm, fast breath across her cheeks and the look in his wide eyes sent shock waves through her body. He wasn’t scared, he was terrified. “Está bien,” she whispered again, giving Nicky a reassuring squeeze.

“Do you speak English?”

It wasn’t even subtle, the microaggression. Rio blinked and looked around to Evanora, seeing that she was looking at her for the first time. Her eyes were blue, but not like Agatha’s. They were an ice blue, almost unreal in their brightness. They had none of Agatha’s warmth, none of her depth.

And Rio realised that she was no longer beautiful. Her beauty disappeared the moment she saw the hatred in her blue eyes. This woman was twisted evil and there was nothing soft, nothing kind about her.

Rio swallowed. Adjusted her hold, making sure Nicky was secure in her arms. He was getting heavier but she wouldn’t drop him, she wouldn’t let him know he was anything other than safe in her arms.

Seguro hasta el infinito.

All Agatha had asked her to do was to look after her son. And as she felt Nicky’s fingers twist and tangle more securely in the hair at the base of her head, she couldn’t help but think: our son.

Her namesake.

Her mellizo.

The boy who loved her and wished he’d been able to say it every day.

“Grandmother,” Nicky’s cheek was practically against Rio’s now, she could feel the warmth of it, the growing heat as he continued bravely on, “Rio is, she-…”

Evanora took a step towards them and Rio took another step backwards. She’d narrowly missed grabbing Nicky’s arm and Nicky gasped quietly. Rio was suddenly under no illusion as to how frightened he was. His hold on her hair tightened and Rio would have endured the sharp pain of it for a thousand lifetimes if it meant she could also feel now how she felt with his cheek against her own.

Agatha had named him for her. She’d birthed this miracle of a child and forged him through love to create this dulce ángel clinging to her in her arms.

He was proof that Evanora had no real power over Agatha. She had none over Nicky.

She sure as shit had none over Rio.

Evanora wouldn’t get in their way. She stepped forwards and Nicky must have been fearful she was going to pass him off because he buried closer, tightened his hold of her hair. He was tugging it now with every desperate grasp and twist of his fingers, though Rio knew he wasn’t meaning to.

He was just frightened, and it made Rio feel stronger than she’d felt in weeks. She held him tighter. Nicky pressed closer. He suddenly wasn’t as heavy.

Evanora had the good sense, because it sure as shit wasn’t manners, to step aside and let Rio into the house. But she found her voice just as Rio was crossing the entranceway.

“You are trespassing!”

The venom in Evanora’s tone made her hold on Nicky tighten until she was worried she was hurting the boy. But he didn’t protest and kept pressed flush against her, moving in her arms only to turn back and look at his grandmother. Rio quickened her steps as Evanora shouted: “I’m calling the police!”

Empty threats, she repeated to herself. Empty threats. Agatha had given her the passcode, the key, she’d told her to look after her son for the day. She had every right to be here.

Nicky wanted her here. He’d asked for her to be here.

And how the hell was Evanora here?!

She got to the bottom of the stairs and bent to try and place Nicky down. But he held on.

Rio felt like she could no longer breathe. She straightened up, readjusted him.

“No me voy. Estaré aquí enseguida. ¿Puedes subir a buscar tu mochila? ¿Me entiendes? Estaré aquí enseguida. Ve a buscar tu mochila, mellizo.” I'm not leaving. i'll be right here. Can you go upstairs and get your bag? Do you understand me? I'll be right here. Go get your bag, twin.

All the while Nicky looked panicked, looked wide-eyed and frightened. Rio knew he wouldn’t want to let go but she didn’t trust herself to be at the top of the stairs with Evanora close by. She’d push her down them and then she’d lose Nicky forever.

She nodded slowly, hoping Nicky understood her words, at least the context of them, the soft plea for him to run and get his bag, to get away from his grandmother for even two minutes.

It seemed like he did. Nicky reluctantly let go, his feet were on the floor but his hands were still in her hair. So Rio was down on his level, hovering between a crouch and a cry. She held his sides, held him firmly, locked eyes with her twin.

In a quieter voice than before, just for Nicky, she whispered, “Tres patitos.”

She felt his fingers flex against her scalp, felt him start to untangle himself from her. But slowly, cautiously. Even as Rio nodded encouragingly again when his hands fell to her shoulders, even when she gave him a gentle squeeze, he didn’t want to let go.

Evanora spoke from just over her shoulder. “Nicholas, come to me. This woman should not be here. It seems your mother needs to learn who she should and should not be associating with.”

Rio’s jaw clicked but she kept her eyes on Nicky, tried to keep them soft. “Okay, mellizo?” She lowered her voice even further. “¿Me etiendes?” Do you understand?

She felt a hand on her shoulder and Nicky’s hands flew back to her hair, his eyes breaking their stare and looking up to his grandmother again. “Baby,” she whispered at the same time Evanora barked: “Nicholas.”

Rio began to pry Nicky’s hands from her hair as the little boy looked torn, look panicked. And Rio began to feel the panic rising in her own chest. She needed Agatha and she needed to get Nicky out of here.

“Esta bien, mellizo. Rápidamente.” She nodded towards the stairs and Nicky finally loosened his grip, looked at her one last time, and then began to stumble his way up the stairs.

She watched as he used his hands to help him up, as he kept looking back at her, as his little body tried its hardest to carry him as fast as it could.

But she couldn’t keep looking. Evanora had growled and heaved Rio around, making her face her. Rio stumbled where she’d been crouched. She fell backwards and caught herself last second, jamming her right palm onto the floor to catch herself.

She heard Nicky gasp out and looked as he began to run back down to her but she shook her head no and the boy stopped in the middle of the stairs.

“Nicholas. Here now.”

Rio grimaced as she pushed herself up and stood to her full height. “Esta bien, mellizo. Rápidamente.”

Nicky looked unsure but Rio nodded again and he turned to face back up the stairs. When he was out of sight Rio’s head was tugged backwards, a sharp, vicious movement that made her gasp in shock and pain.

She fought to keep her face neutral and made to grab at Evanora but the old woman removed her hand. She’d got the reaction she wanted.

She was nothing like Agatha, in the way she looked or the way she behaved. Agatha’s furies were bright, a sun with infinite storms. But Evanora was different. Her fury was dark, like oil bleeding across an ocean, infecting and forever changing everything in its path.

Only Rio wouldn’t let her poison anywhere near Nicky. She could try, she could inject it into Rio’s veins and drown her in it but she wouldn’t touch that boy. Not while Rio still had air in her lungs and eyes to see.

“Listen to me,” Evanora’s hand moved to her shoulder again and she felt the threat of her sharp nails but Rio chose not to flinch. “You will stay away from my grandson, and you will stay away from my daughter. You and your filth. Do you understand me?”

Rio inclined her head just a fraction, no longer attempting to keep her face neutral. She pulled her shoulder back and Evanora raised her brows. Clearly she was expecting a “yes, ma’am.”

Rio had read her right because her next words were: “I see your parents dragged you up.”

Rio’s jaw flexed again and violence was on the tip of her tongue until she heard the heavy footsteps of a frantic little boy hurrying his way back to her. She turned from Evanora and looked up to see Nicky with a backpack too large for his small frame and a familiar looking cuddly toy in the form of some sort of floppy animal in his clutches.

“Ten cuidado, mellizo,” be careful, Rio called out as Nicky raced towards her.

“Nicholas,” Evanora barked again, just as Nicky flew past the first two steps. Her voice was practically shaking with rage now, “I forbid you to go anywhere with this feral woman. You are to stay with your grandmother until your mother gets home. We all need to have a little family talk.”

Rio had started up the stairs already, her arms open to grab Nicky before he could fall in his haste. He threw himself at Rio and she just about managed to keep them upright. His backpack worked as a sort of opposing force that meant she didn’t fall over backwards. He was almost impossible to hold, so she half-held, half-led him down the stairs.

But he was safe. He wouldn’t fall. Rio had him.

Back on solid ground now, Nicky pressed close and squashed his toy between them but kept his eyes on his grandmother. “I-I want to stay with Rio.”

“Out of the question,” Evanora snapped, reaching a hand towards Nicky as Rio turned to look at her, cradling Nicky’s head against her as she did.

“Dile adiós a tu abuela,” say goodbye to your grandmother, Rio uttered as calmly as she could, looking back at Nicky now who felt so tense against her.

Evanora scoffed and stepped closer but Rio stepped her and Nicky away, unwilling to let the woman touch the boy.

“You cannot take him from me, from this house.” Every word was spat, every consonant perfectly enunciated, every vowel rounded and whole. But no real woman with any class or high ground of any kind would have spoken like that.

Rio ducked her head down to kiss the top of Nicky’s head and whispered a quick, and what she hoped was reassuring, “Te tengo, mellizo.” I’ve got you.

She tried to guide him now, tried to direct him around his grandmother so they could leave.

And Nicky tightened his hold then let go so he could begin moving with her. But she’d been too slow, she’d underestimated Evanora. Or perhaps she just couldn’t comprehend that anyone would hurt a kid.

Nicky’s grandmother had reached between them as Nicky had begun to pull away. He was slow, reluctant to move, but he was doing it.

He was being brave and Rio was so proud that he trusted her in that moment that she didn’t react in time.

The old witch had secured her claws around Nicky’s ear, had made him yell in shock and pain. She twisted it, tugged his head backwards.

“Just like your mother.”

Evanora had been a coiled snake up until that moment. A cobra standing tall, primed to strike. And the strike had been precise, vicious, deadly.

Her words were spat at a little boy so terrified and so innocent. And Rio saw red.

She reacted quickly this time. She grabbed Evanora’s wrist and wrenched her hand off of Nicky’s ear, throwing the crone’s arm away without mercy. She could have ripped it from its socket for all she cared. The old woman gasped and held her wrist up like Rio had burned it.

“Don’t fucking touch him.”

Evanora glowered.

Nicky was back to hugging her, back to clinging to her, back to trying to crawl into her skin.

“So the mongrel can speak the language of its betters?” Evanora’s laugh was high, more a cackle than anything else, but Rio didn’t stick around to watch her eyes flame in delight.

She was grabbing Nicky, trying to be firm but gentle, turning him in front of her and hurrying him as quickly as she could towards the door. She could hear her heartbeat in her ears, could feel her body curling towards Nicky, trying to form some sort of barrier between him and his grandmother even as they ran.

She’d touched him. She’d hurt him. She was going to kill her.

“This is kidnapping! You cannot take my grandson away from me!”

If Nicky weren’t there she might have turned around and actually killed the woman. But Nicky was there. So Nicky was instead the priority.

They reached the door, Rio leaning to help Nicky open it when Evanora’s voice sounded again, closer than it had been before. She’d been following. She was determined.

“Take your hands off of him!”

The door was open, Nicky had taken his first step out.

Rio was grabbed back, half-turned now away from the little boy.

Evanora had her claws in her forearm and Rio bared her teeth and raised her fist as Evanora clung to her arm. Her sharp talons were purposefully pressing as hard as she could. But Rio didn’t cry out. She didn’t flinch even as they broke skin.

She wouldn’t give Evanora the satisfaction.

“You have a sickness! You have infected my child with your filth. I will not let you infect my grandson, you you… Mexican DOG.”

Spit flew form Evanora’s lips and landed across Rio’s cheek. She fell from her brain. Everything stopped until it started again.

Until Nicky brought her back to life.

“NO! No! Let go! Let go of her!”

Nicky had joined the fray, trying to tug Rio’s arm away from Evanora but she wouldn’t release her hold and Rio wasn’t attempting to pull away. She just let her cling, let her think she had the upper hand.

But she’d lost already.

Rio had Agatha.

Rio had Nicky.

She stared into eyes of brightest blue and with a mouth full of hatred she said:

“You are not worthy of either of them.”

Evanora’s eyes widened infinitesimally and she pressed her nails in harder. But the pain of it was nothing to Rio’s loathing of the woman before her.

She wouldn’t give in. She wouldn’t cower or back down.

This woman was the reason that for almost forty years Agatha had hidden herself away, had denied herself the chance to be happy. This woman was scum, she was poison, and Rio would not let her win.

“Melliza, melliza,” Nicky began to insist, his hands grabbing Rio’s arm, still trying to pull her free of his grandmother’s hold. Rio didn’t look round but if she had she’d have seen tears falling silently from his eyes as he continued to insist before her, trying to tug her arm back still, “Está bien, melliza. Estoy aquí. Estoy aquí.” It’s okay. I am here. I am here.

Evanora’s bright eyes flashed at the sound of her grandson speaking Rio’s language, the language he’d been learning so he could speak with her in the words of her beloved papa. The language that represented everything that Evanora was not.

The language that contained their love for one another. The language that made them a family, a brood. It had made them what they were now: tres patitos.

She saw something register on Evanora’s face as she looked between Rio’s dark gaze down to the face of Nicky, his own eyes wide, but the very reflection of his melliza’s.

Whether she recognised the stark similarity or she simply didn’t know how else to proceed, she released her hold.

With the loosening of Evanora’s grip, Rio’s arm flew back and Nicky kept a hold on her, beginning to tug her out the door. She felt the warm trickle of blood against her wrist as she turned to usher Nicky out. Nicky was practically dragging her now, holding her injured arm with that same clutching grip.

She wiped her face of Evanora’s venom and made a solemn vow: she’d not let Nicky see his grandmother ever again.

She raced with him, trying to help him by holding his backpack up as he ran with it. They must have looked insane, an Oscar Winner and a tiny boy with a big backpack chasing up the street. But they made it to Rio’s car without seeing anyone else.

Rio turned to check over her shoulder as she ripped Nicky’s door open. The street was empty. Evanora hadn’t followed.

Rio helped Nicky into his seat, made sure his belt was on, that he was secure, and placed the backpack down by his feet, not wanting to waste time getting it in the back.

She checked his ear, made sure he wasn’t bleeding. It was red, hot to the touch, but she hadn’t broken skin.

“Melliza, melliza,” Nicky chanted her nickname, trying to grab at her even as she pulled away. She didn’t have time to reassure him. She only had time to get them out, to get them as far away as possible.

She jumped into her side of the car, barely able to breathe.

“You’re bleeding!”

“It’s okay, it’s okay.”

Rio turned the engine on before she’d even secured her own belt and pulled from the curb as fast as she could.

“Melliza, you’re bleeding!”

“I know, baby. It’s okay. I’m okay.”

“No, no, Rio! She hurt you!”

Rio could feel her pulse in her throat but she had to keep going, had to get Nicky as far away as possible. She had to get to the house, the hideaway, had to get Nicky safe.

She’d fucked up. Twice. She’d exposed him to an over-familiar stranger and now she’d not been able to keep him from his evil bitch grandmother. Agatha would never trust her again. She’d never leave her alone with him.

Her head began to thump. The pain she hadn’t experienced in days now was back. Tenfold.

Nicky beside her was trying to get to her, trying to reach as his desperation took over. He was crying but Rio couldn’t comfort him. She had to keep driving, had to get them safe before she started to see any colours.

“R-Rio! Your arm! You’re hurt!”

Rio shook her head, shook it as if she were shaking off something rather than denying it. Her arm did hurt. It stung, the bitch had buried her claws in as deep as she could manage for the pure thrill of watching Rio suffer.

Punishment, Rio realised as she overtook a slow-moving truck.

The promise Agatha had been brought up with. Be too loud: punishment. Have opinions: punishment. Defy your mother in any way: punishment.

Love someone other than the straight white man I forced you to marry: punishment.

Something in Rio’s peripheral flashed and she turned to see but there wasn’t a car beside her.

“Melliza?” Nicky was breathless, desperate, his hand curling cautiously around her arm.

Rio looked down at it, saw the fierce red marks across her inner forearm where Evanora had plunged her talons. Four. Four gashes across her skin, all bloody and raw.

Nicky’s fingers were curled just by them, a stark contrast to his grandmother. Soft, gentle, cautious.

She looked back to the road again.

“Si, cariño?”

Nicky sniffed, “Why does, why does she hate you? Why did she hurt you?”

“It’s complicated, sweetheart.”

Nicky was silent for a while and Rio was fighting with her foot, feeling too trigger happy on the gas.

“I hate her.”

Nicky was sniffing again, and Rio glanced at him as he used his free hand to wipe at his eyes. He looked miserable, blotchy from tears. She took a breath and moved her arm to take his hand, her eyes already back on the road.

Nicky continued to sniff quietly, and Rio could see from the corner of her eye that he kept wiping his eyes so she knew he was still crying. But Rio kept her eyes on the road, kept checking the rear view mirror every so often just to make sure they weren’t being followed.

She had two options now, take Nicky directly to the hill house purchased to keep him hidden, to keep him out of harm’s way, or take him someplace else.

Anywhere else.

It was a decision she didn’t want to have to make. A decision she felt like she couldn’t make.

She glanced at Nicky again and felt his fingers curl more tightly around her hand. He was looking down at her arm and she caught his frightened stare.

Something about the way his face was now formed reminded her of Agatha. And she knew what she had to do.

She had to trust that the house would remain their sanctuary. High up in the Bird Streets in the hills, far away from the witch with the sharp claws and venomous tongue.

She looked back at the road. She swallowed. She made her decision.

They drove on in silence for a little while longer, Rio focused in on driving as safely as she could but fast, always pushing that little bit just to get them to their destination sooner. In her peripheral vision she could see Nicky clutching at the toy she’d noticed earlier and she glanced at it before she turned back. She was still in a steel deathtrap after all, she had to be extra careful.

“What’s their name?”

Nicky was silent for a second and then said, “Scratchy. I just sleep with him sometimes. I got him when I was little. I didn’t want him left with grandmother.”

Rio nodded silently, keeping her eyes on the road.

“He’ll be happy you took him.”

“Melliza,” Nicky’s voice was quiet still, almost drowned out by the hammering of her heart. “Can you call my mama, please? I don’t want her to get hurt and I want her to fix your arm and… and I want her to be with us.”

“Yes, yes, of course. I-…”

Rio cleared her throat and glanced at the screen on the console between them. She didn’t know where her phone was. Somewhere in her bag which was by Nicky’s feet and now under his backpack.

“Can you get me my phone? Do you know how to use it?”

Nicky scrambled down to reach her bag and just about managed to shift his backpack but couldn’t quite get to it and Rio flew a hand out to make him sit up again. The last thing she needed was for him to hit his head in his haste to get to her phone. Or worse.

“Wait, wait. We’ll call her when we get in, okay? I promise. As soon as we’re home.”

She cursed silently for not having thought of it sooner. Of course Nicky would want his mom. Of course she should have called his mom.

Of course they needed Agatha.

But Nicky had her hand again and had placed Scratchy in her lap. She glanced down at it, recognising now that it was clearly a rabbit. He had floppy ears and that well-loved look most kids toys were never blessed with.

Nicky clearly loved him, had clearly held him many times, cuddled him all through his childhood. She imagined Nicky as a baby with the pristine version of Scratchy by his side in his crib.

And then another flash happened and she looked to see where it had come from but again saw nothing.

Nicky as a baby had reminded her that he still was a baby. A baby who had just been grabbed by his grandmother. A baby who had valiantly defended her, who had tried to save her even when he’d been terrified.

“Melliza?” Rio glanced Nicky’s way. “Are you okay?”

Rio swallowed the lump that had long ago lodged in her throat and nodded, “Let’s just get home, okay? Are you excited to see your new house?”

“Does my grandmother know where it is?”

“No, baby. Only us. Only us, your mama, and Jen, okay?”

Nicky nodded slowly, and Rio looked back at him as he focused on her arm. “And Alice? She can know too.”

“Alice can know too,” she agreed quietly, focusing back in on the road.

“Alice looks at me sometimes,” Nicky whispered, his free hand moving to touch by one of Rio’s cuts. It didn’t hurt but she looked down to see what he was doing. He was just looking, just curious. His brows pulled tightly together in a sad frown and Rio wondered whether he was still trying to understand how someone could do what his grandmother had did.

The apple had fallen very far from the poisoned tree.

“She looks at you?”

Rio knew what Nicky meant but she was too caught up on getting them to the house safely, on fighting the pain in her head, on avoiding flashing lights.

Nicky sniffed, “I don’t think she likes me.”

Rio bit down on the inside of her cheek, she stared out the front window, she cleared her throat quietly, “Did you know I’ve known Alice since I was eighteen? Almost half my life?”

“Really?”

Rio nodded, keeping her eyes forward even as she could feel Nicky looking up at her. “So she knows my face really well. Really, really well. And I think when she looks at you she’s actually just looking because-…”

“Because we look a little the same.”

Rio smiled a little and glanced at Nicky. “Exactly, mellizo.”

Nicky’s hand flexed against her arm and then he held her hand in two of his. “Maybe more than a little, you know. Maybe that’s why my grandmother was so…”

Rio stuck her tongue in her cheek as she took a bend, wending their way up now into the hills. Nicky was wiser than his years. He had his mom’s intellect, her desire to learn, to know more than she was offered.

She remained silent, let him think his thoughts for a little while.

The further into the hills they got the more she felt like she could breathe. But she didn’t have the SatNav on. She had to keep a close eye on the street signs.

“Mama will be upset,” Nicky whispered, and Rio could feel his eyes on her again. She held his hands a little tighter.

“Only because she’ll be worried about you, mellizo. But she’ll be okay. We’ll be okay.”

She took a turn up a steeper hill.

“She’ll be upset that you’re hurt and that,” Rio paused, realising they were on the right street. She slowed down, feeling her heart rate slow alongside the engine. “that you got scared.”

“And that you’re bleeding,” Nicky added so quietly Rio almost missed it as she concentrated.

“Sí, mellizo.” She was distracted, too intent on getting to the right house. There weren’t many on the street, in fact, she didn’t see one for a while and soon became worried she’d forgotten the address.

But then there it was, cresting just over the break of the hill. From the looks of it, it was a mission revival style house. White and terracotta, not quite the Spanish style of Rio’s house across town. Rio pulled up to the large gate and leant out to input a code, her own birthday, chosen because who would guess that knowing the day Rio Vidal first breathed life into the world would be the key needed to access Agatha Harkness and her son.

She pulled in slowly, on high alert for anyone else suddenly appearing. But it was just the house. Just Nicky, Rio, Scratchy, and the house.

Rio parked up, she went to help Nicky, and found that more than that was impossible now the boy had his arms around her neck and his face pressed in against her shoulder. She relaxed enough to not hurry him along, to not insist they get moving.

She relaxed enough to hold him for as long as he needed held and only when he felt ready did she begin to pull back. Her heart was in her throat, the pain in her head subsiding with each second Nicky clung to her, only to be vanquished entirely by his next words: “Te amo, melliza. Está bien.”

“Nicholas River Harkness,” she said slowly, deliberately, wanting him to understand her completely. She pulled back and Nicky’s brows knit together as if he were afraid he were in trouble. But Rio just wanted to say his full name, wanted to speak aloud the pieces of him that were Agatha and the tiny piece of him that was her.

“I love you too. Very much. And I am so proud of you for being so brave. I promise I’ll keep you safe. You and your mama.”

Nicky nodded slowly and took an audible breath in before he said: “Sí. Entiendo. Lo sé.”

Rio didn’t have to force herself to smile. Nicky looked worried still, his eyes ever-wide, but his lips trembled into a half-smile too and she kissed his cheek as a seal of their agreement.

Rio loved him. She’d keep him safe.

She hurried him then, grabbing his bag and her own. They made their way to the front door together and Rio found that the closer they got, the closer Nicky got. But she held his hand firmly, and with her non-dominant hand she found the keys Agatha had left her.

She fumbled in her haste but she managed it.

She let them in, she expected Nicky to go ahead but he stayed back. So she stepped inside first.

The house smelled different, unlike Agatha’s actual home. It hadn’t been lived in by her yet so Rio didn’t know why she was expecting to have Agatha’s stamp all over it. But then she turned her head and on the console table where she placed her keys was a framed photograph of Agatha and Nicky.

And in front of it, lay a light blue origami flower.

Rio swallowed, knowing Agatha had left it for her.

But Nicky hadn’t moved yet and she knew he was waiting for her to do so. She looked up, looked into the quiet house. They needed to call Agatha to let her know what had happened but that they were safe but first Rio needed to make sure they were.

She shouldered Nicky’s backpack and walked him through to find the living room and found it to be open, airy, a pretty space with prettier furnishings. Money couldn’t buy taste but Agatha had both in droves.

They didn’t stop there. She took them instead deeper into the house, passing a guest bathroom, the chef’s kitchen, and through again until she found a smaller family room. It was decorated just as well as the first lounge but was cosier, and she felt safer already.

She placed Nicky’s backpack down by the coffee table and settled with him close beside her on the couch. But something still didn’t feel right.

She stood and Nicky stood too. She’d turned to tell him to wait on the couch but saw his face and said nothing.

Safety was paramount but reassurance was a close second. A very close second judging by the fact that Nicky had been silent since they’d stepped into the house and was still clutching her hand.

So she walked with him round each room of the lower floor of the house and with his help she closed every blind and every drape. No one would see in. No human eyes, no long lens, no flying drone.

They’d be safe.

Only then did she take Nicky back to the couch. Only then did she offer him a drink or some snacks.

He refused both and was soon crawling into her lap.

There, in the dark house high up in the hills of Hollywood, Rio Vidal sat with her frightened mellizo. Nicky was in her lap, his arms around her neck, his head resting against her shoulder. She held him close, held him securely, his little knees pointing up to the sky and tucked in against her side.

He was safe now. No one knew where they were. No one could see in.
She leant over when Nicky was comfortable and with the tips of her fingers managed to grab the strap of her cross-body black bag. She pulled it onto the couch with them and fished out her cell.

When the screen lit she saw that she had the usual number of texts and calls but none from Agatha or Jen. Good. Nothing had happened on their end.

Only five texts from Alice appeared and one missed call.

She didn’t check them.

She instead pressed to dial Agatha and held the phone to her ear. Nicky shuffled a bit to sit up more.

Agatha answered after one ring.

“Rio,” she said her name on an inhale and Rio could feel the worry in her voice.

“We’re safe,” she reassured quickly, needing Agatha to know that at least. “We’re at the house. Nicky is right here with me.”

“What’s happened?” Agatha knew. Of course she did. Why else would Rio, a woman who never picked up her phone, choose to pick up her phone to call Agatha when she knew she was busy.

She took a breath, felt Nicky tangle his fingers in her hair.

“Your mother was at the house. We’re fine, we-…”

“Put Nicky on.”

Rio blinked. It wasn’t usual for Agatha to dismiss her like that. Something settled in her stomach as she passed the phone to Nicky and whispered: “Your mama.”

Perhaps Agatha was mad. Perhaps she was done with her. Perhaps…

But Nicky had begun to speak a mile a minute and she realised what it was instantly. Rio would tell half-truths, seeking to inform but to placate, to soften. Nicky would tell the whole truth, unencumbered by the burden of guilt, not frightened of what Agatha might say to him, simply determined to get her here sooner.

“Mama, she was just in the house and she tried to get me to stay with her but I didn’t want to and Rio wouldn’t let her and, and,” he took two sharp breaths and Rio kissed his temple. “And Rio got me to the stairs but she kept coming and was saying bad things to Rio and, and I went up the stairs but then she pushed Rio but Rio told me to go so I ran I ran so fast and I got my bag and Scratchy and came back down and Rio was waiting for me and then grandmother grabbed my ear and Rio shouted at her and then we kept going even as she kept shouting at us to stop but then then she grabbed Rio and and she’s bleeding mama she hurt her arm but she wouldn’t let go but I tried to make her and and she called her she she called her a dog then we got away and we drove we drove up to here and we’ve closed all the blinds so it’s just us and we want you with us please come please come now we want you mama I want you here please don’t go home please don’t go home.”

Nicky was crying again and Rio waited with bated breath to hear what Agatha would say on the other end of the line. She pulled Nicky close, cradled his head, covering the ear that had been grabbed by Evanora with her hand. Agatha’s voice was faded, and Ro knew she’d be moving already, would have wrapped up the meeting with a simple look to Jen and would be on her way.

“I’m coming, honey. You stay right there with Rio. She’ll keep you so safe. I love you, I’m coming. Pass the phone back to Rio, honey.”

Nicky did as he was told and buried back in against her. Rio took a deep breath before she placed the phone to her ear and as soon as she had she heard Agatha’s sharp voice: “You’re hurt.”

“I’m fine.”

“That isn’t what Nicky said. What did she-…”

Rio shook her head and held Nicky that bit tighter, feeling him silent cry into her shirt. “Just get back as quickly as you can.”

“He said you were bleeding.”

“It’s healed. I promise I’m okay.”

In the background she heard Jen’s voice and Alice’s name being spoken. Agatha said nothing for a second and then whispered, “He’s okay?”

“He’s okay.”

“You’re okay?”

“I’m okay.”

“Tell me what she said.”

Rio shook her head silently again, unable to even think the words she’d said, let alone repeat them with Nicky close.

“No. Come back, drive safe. We’ll see you soon.”

“Rio,” Agatha insisted but Rio could barely stand to hear her voice and not see her face. She closed her eyes, felt Nicky shuffle up until he could lean in and speak to his mama too.

“Mama hurry please. Please hurry.”

She heard Agatha’s breath, heard her struggle with it. Then: “I’m coming. I’ll be there soon. Don’t worry, honey. I’m coming.”

“Drive safe,” Rio whispered and before Agatha could say anything else, she hung up.

Nicky hugged her again and Rio held him through it, wondering what he was feeling and whether Agatha had ever been more scared or angry in her life. She didn’t think so, assumed she must be on the verge of erupting.

It would come. She knew it would. It was just whether it was directed solely at Evanora or whether Rio would be burned by the flames.

Nicky eventually settled down against her again and Rio felt like she could breathe with him close but felt pain with every breath.

What if Agatha realised she was incompetent. What is she found her to be all those things she’d accused her of being: not ready, a child, immature.

She sighed quietly and closed her eyes as she rested back into the cushions.

Her headache was knocking again.

They just had to wait for Agatha.

Rio just had to wait to see how long it would be before Nicky was ripped away from her and Agatha broke it all off.

As they sat there in the near-darkness, Nicky was quieter than she’d ever known him to be. He just held on, toyed with the ends of her hair. It took her back to having him against her when Agatha had been asleep and Nicky had been attempting to fool her into thinking he was.

Only no one was fooling anyone anymore. Everything was out in the open, raw and bloody like the untreated wounds on Rio’s wrist and forearm.

As time ticked on she checked in on Nicky every so often, making sure he knew he was safe, that his mama was still coming, that she was still here. Every soft utterance in Spanish was met with a gentle head nod from the boy but he made no sound.

By the time Rio heard the front door being opened, she’d petrified around the little boy. Her bones had cemented in their position, her muscles frozen in their protective hold. After all, she had Agatha’s heart in her lap. He was safe in her arms. She had to keep him safe, had to keep him protected, and so she didn’t move. Even when everything ached, even when she had to fight the urge to fidget, to stretch, to tear the paint from the walls with her fingernails just to feel try to rid her body of the anger she felt.

She remained still. She held Nicky, protected Agatha’s heart.

By her reckoning it had been close to forty minutes before there was noise again in the silent house. No more than an hour. No less than thirty.

She heard frantic footsteps and Jen’s voice shouting Agatha’s name.

And then.

There she was. Standing in the entrance to the dark family room Rio had holed them up in. At some point in the day she must have shed her blazer because it was no longer on her tense frame. She was wearing her glasses, her hair twice the volume it had been when she’d left that morning, evidence of her hysteria, evidence of her fear.

Agatha’s cheeks were pale beneath the large-frames but creeping down her neck and across what could be seen of her chest through her white shirt, Agatha was flushed. Her sleeves were rolled up and Rio knew it must have been a nervous impulse, something to do as she shouted at Jen to drive faster, for more gas! More gas!

And her eyes, her eyes were what she focused on next, what she couldn’t look away from. Storms of terror were raging in them.

Agatha was drowning even as she stood on solid ground.

Rio’s frozen hold on Nicky broke open as he struggled from her lap and flew across the space to get to his mama. Rio watched as he tried to climb up her, as Agatha bent to catch him, as she struggled to lift the desperate child into the air.

Rio couldn’t move. She could no longer look.

Chapter End Notes

Hope she was worth the wait

Afterword

Please drop by the Archive and comment to let the creator know if you enjoyed their work!
